Novelty is a tradition in American food—our stomachs rumble for the next big thing. And right now, the next big thing is Georgian food. A trend forecaster recently named it “Cuisine of the Year,” with the “Dish of the Year” being “khachapuri,” a term that refers to any number of Georgian cheese-filled breads. The dish is having a moment on Instagram, where #Khachapuri has been tagged more than 36,000 times. Swipe through to see some of our favorite shots, then tap the link in our bio to read Lauren Collins on the woman who, more than 120 years after her death, is inspiring chefs all over Tbilisi.

Stacks House, an L.A. pop-up museum that costs $38 per ticket, is part inspiration, part photo op. In a series of highly Instagrammable exhibits, you can pose in shower stalls that appear to rain money, punch bags printed with the phrase “deadbeat friends," and ride a bucking piggy bank in the “retirement rodeo.” Behind Stacks House is the idea that, if women felt more comfortable talking about money, they would have more of it, and the country’s cultural and political life would shift accordingly. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the personal-finance-themed experience where cash is queen.
Photograph by Deborah Spencer
A tale as old as time. #TNYcartoons

Most of the year, Kitzbühel, a medieval town in the Tyrolean Alps, is a fancy resort, with swank hotels and shops. But once a year, the Hahnenkamm, the world’s most dangerous ski race, transforms Kitzbühel into a riotous carnival—part Indy 500, part South Padre Island. Tap the link in our bio to follow Nick Paumgarten down the Hahnenkamm’s punishing pitch, then into the melee of its notorious afterparty. Photographs by @ImmoKlink for The New Yorker.

The seventy-five-year-old Agustín Par, pictured above, is in charge of a nursery with tens of thousands of tree saplings just outside the city of Totonicapán, in the western highlands of Guatemala. In a nearby village called Paraje León, a group of agronomists is showing local residents how to diversify their crops, conserve water, and reforest some of the surrounding areas as the community grapples with the ongoing effects of climate change. In honor of #EarthDay, tap the link in our bio to follow the photographer @limauricio and the writer @jonathanblitzer to the western highlands, where a variable climate affects nearly every aspect of daily life.

In last night’s episode of “Game of Thrones,” Jon Snow, Arya Stark, and the rest of the crew gathered around the Stratego board to plan for the coming battle with the dead. Fire brought out cozy glows in everyone’s hearts, and sex was on the mind of many. Tap the link in our bio to read our weekly "Game of Thrones" recap by @asarahlarson. Photograph by Helen Sloan / HBO

In the twenty years since the massacre at Columbine High School, there have been at least 165 other mass shootings in America. These events account for a tiny fraction of firearm deaths in that span, but they have become the most visible symptom of the gun-violence epidemic in America. At the link in our bio, physicians speak out about treating the victims of mass shootings.
This issue has been redacted. #TNYcartoons

In recent years, the N.R.A. has run annual deficits of up to forty million dollars while a small group of executives, contractors, and venders have extracted hundreds of millions of dollars from the nonprofit’s budget. Read Mike Spies’s report on the dire financial state of the N.R.A., and the potentially crippling threat to its non-profit status, at the link in our bio. 
Illustration by @bmwiseman
An early look at next week’s cover, “Our Lady,” by @bobstaake. #TNYcovers

Will the Mueller report restore public confidence in nonpartisan investigations? The answer depends on the extent of the Attorney General William Barr’s redactions. Tap the link in our bio to read about the precedent set by the Muller report, which will be released to the public tomorrow.

Illustration by @mikemcquade ; Source Photograph by Win McNamee / Getty (Mueller); Tom Brenner / Getty (Trump)

The Rock ’n Play Sleeper was once everywhere, a cult-status product for parents of young children. Our editor Jessica Winter used the sleeper for her baby, pictured above, but she held some misgivings. Although the Rock ’n Play was marketed as safe for overnight use, it seemed to flout safe-sleep guidelines. Last week, an investigation found that the Fisher-Price sleeper was linked to multiple infant deaths. Tap the link in our bio to read about the downfall of this near-ubiquitous sleeper. Photograph by @winterjessica.
It’s been a long news cycle. #TNYcartoons
Notre-Dame’s peak has long been a standby of Paris wayfinding. This 1954 cover by Charles Addams features the famous cathedral. #TNYcovers

Vince Aletti's apartment has a lot of issues—literally. In four-plus decades, he has filled his space with thousands and thousands of magazines. Tap the link in our bio to see some of the iconic spreads he has saved over the years.
Photos by @mattelife for The New Yorker.

Mohamedou Salahi arrived at Guantánamo Bay in 2002, on suspicion of connections to al-Qaeda. For the next fourteen years, he endured brutality and torture, and was subjected to daily twenty-hour interrogations. Salahi’s detainee dossier listed his reason for transfer to Guantánamo: “to provide information.” Notably absent was any allegation that Salahi had committed a crime. Tap the link in our bio to read @bentaub91 on Guantánamo’s darkest secret. Illustration by @tylercomrie; source photograph from Stringer / AFP / Getty
This week’s cover, “Taking Care,” by @loveiswiseillu. #TNYCovers

Unruly crowds are willing to wait up to three-and-a-half hours for a table at Au Cheval, a new Tribeca burger joint that specializes in decadent, egg-topped burgers (“au cheval” means “on horseback” in French, or “topped with a fried egg” in short-order parlance). But the real draw is a fried-bologna sandwich that could single-handedly redeem the floppy deli meat. Tap the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield on the New York outpost of Chicago's famous Au Cheval. Photographs by Amy Lombard for The New Yorker.

When the legendary photographer Richard Avedon asked Myla Goldberg to visit his studio, she grabbed a thank-you gift (a bouquet of basil) and two outfits (a men’s bathing suit and a checkered dress) and headed to his townhouse on East Seventy-fifth Street. “Though the session didn’t last longer than twenty minutes, I will forever remember the feeling of standing barefoot in that light-filled room while Avedon apologetically tilted his head toward the lens I kept ignoring.” Tap the link in our bio to read Myla Goldberg’s account of sitting for Avedon.
Photograph by Richard Avedon / © The Richard Avedon Foundation

This year, we have been nominated by @thewebbyawards for our reporting, videos, podcasts, and more (including yours truly, pictured above, nominated for social media). Tap the link in our bio to cast your vote.
A cartoon by @farleykatz. #TNYcartoons
This week’s cover, “Double Play,” by Mark Ulriksen. #TNYcovers
By @richiehof, from this week’s issue. Visit the link in our bio to read the full poem.

Many refugees arrive in France after surviving dangerous journeys, with few personal possessions. Their wardrobes may consist of only the clothes on their backs, along with whatever they choose from donation bins. Fashion becomes a way to maintain ties to their homelands, or to manifest how they wish to be seen in this new country. The collaborative project "Sneakers Like Jay-Z" portraits the personal styles of migrants from Sudan, Afghanistan, Guinea, and beyond. Check out more at the link in our bio / Photographs by @ambroisetezenas and @fred_delangle

In the western highlands of Guatemala, food shortages and extreme weather events are forcing residents to flee to the U.S. “There are always a lot of reasons why people migrate,” an expert on forestry in Guatemala said. “But in every situation, it has something to do with climate change.” Click the link in our bio to read @jonathanblitzer on how climate change is fuelling the U.S. border crisis. / Photographs by @limauricio for The New Yorker and the Pulitzer Center

Publishers are racing to print the long-awaited Mueller report, following in the footsteps of classic page-turners from the Warren Commission and Kenneth Starr. We asked ﬁve graphic designers to create book covers for the special counsel’s masterwork, twenty-­two months in the making, which is said to weigh in at more than three hundred pages. Swipe to see them all, and read more about the literary tradition of political potboilers at the link in the bio.
A cartoon by Leo Cullum, from 2006. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week’s cover, “The Acrobat,” by Kenton Nelson.

At a North Dakota outcrop of the Hell Creek geological formation, the young paleontologist Robert DePalma may have discovered a record of the most significant event in the history of the planet: the day the dinosaurs died. “It’s like ﬁnding the Holy Grail clutched in the bony ﬁngers of Jimmy Hoﬀa, sitting on top of the Lost Ark,” DePalma said. Click the link in our bio to read about the discovery that may forever transform our understanding of life on Earth. Photo by @richardbarnes for The New Yorker.

Rocco DiSpirito came to prominence in the late nineties as a promising young culinary talent, but he quickly became one of the first celebrity chefs, spending more time on TV shows and hawking products than actually cooking. Now, after a decade out of the limelight, he’s back in the kitchen, at Manhattan’s Standard Grill, where he’s reintroducing some of the signature dishes of his heyday—and playing catch-up on newer trends. Click the link in our bio to read about DiSpirito’s nostalgic return to cooking.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A poem by Christian Wiman, from this week’s issue.

The Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel has been a resting place for various distinguished personalities, including Judy Garland, Tennessee Williams, and the Notorious B.I.G. Recently, the funeral home became a muse for the artist Cynthia Talmadge, whose paintings depict the Campbell building in a notably un-grim pointillist style. “The technique was perfect for the subject matter, because it prescribes a scientific way to mix colors to achieve an effect of light—and what goes on at Frank E. Campbell is both mechanical and romantic,” Talmadge said. Click the link in our bio to read more about the exhibition’s opening, which turned the funeral home into an art gallery. Paintings by @cynthia_talmadge / Courtesy of @56henry.nyc
This week’s cover, “Brooklyn or Bust,” by Bruce McCall.

A few years after her mother died, the South African photographer @lebohang_kganye reënacted her mother's old portraits, creating a set of spectral double exposures. Her project took her across the country, to relatives who had been uprooted by apartheid-era policies of forced removal. In the resultant series, “Ke Lefa Laka: Her-Story,” Kganye situates herself within a complex political history. Click the link in our bio to view more from the series, which Kganye describes as an attempt to replenish the “paucity of memory.” Photographs by Lebohang Kganye.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by Harry Bliss and Steve Martin, featuring the contents of the Mueller report. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more.

The Fly, a new tavern on the border of Bed-Stuy and Clinton Hill, makes a case that roast chicken is as perfect a bar food as the burger, especially when paired with gently smashed, roasted potatoes and a gamut-running natural-wine list. Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield on the new Brooklyn rotisserie that seems to be nailing it right out of the gate. Photographs by @zaczavv for The New Yorker.

In 2011, just as "Game of Thrones" was about to become a worldwide phenomenon, the actor @emilia_clarke, who plays Daenerys Targaryen, faced the first of two life-threatening brain aneurysms. "Just when all my childhood dreams seemed to have come true, I nearly lost my mind and then my life," she writes. "I’ve never told this story publicly, but now it’s time." Click the link in our bio to read Clarke’s own account of the battle that almost cost her her mind and her life. Portraits by @carlota_guerrero for The New Yorker.
A cartoon by Roz Chast. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Late in life and seemingly overnight, the former poet Peter Sacks became a visual artist with a fully formed and dauntingly complex aesthetic. He builds paintings through a painstaking process that takes years, layering fabric, text, maps, paint, and cardboard over canvas. “I’m trying to do justice to my feeling of what the mind is like,” he said. “It’s sedimentary.” Click the link in our bio to learn more about how Sacks draws power from the hidden layers of his canvases. Photo by @francesfdenny / Paintings by Peter Sacks @petersacksstudio / @marlboroughgallery

For years, Shen Yun advertisements have been comically ubiquitous, commonly found in subway cars, at bus stops, and over highway exits. The posters feature an indelible image: a bright shade of lilac, a woman leaping in the sky, and the enigmatic phrase "5,000 Years of Civilization Reborn." Behind these meme-friendly ad blitzes lies a bizarre story of religious-political propaganda, homophobia, anti-evolution rhetoric, and supposed persecution from the Chinese Communist regime. Is the Shen Yun Performing Arts troupe a cult? Visit the link in our bio to read Jia Tolentino's investigation. Illustration by @ram__han.

A new film by the director @clayjeter explores the world of Japanese master craftsmen, called Takumi, who can take up to sixty thousand hours to learn their disciplines. These artisans, like Nahoko Kojima, a traditional paper cutter, embody an unparalleled dedication to craft and excellence. Kojima spends up to eight months creating a single sculpture from paper, hand-cut into elaborate designs. Her meticulous, manual work is particularly remarkable in our modern technological age. With the rise of artificial intelligence, will artisans like her disappear? Or will their work become more valuable than ever? #takumidoc
A cartoon by Barry Blitt, featuring a custom suit for Paul Manafort.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
An early look at next week's cover, "Crazy Time," by @markulriksenart. #TNYcovers

"Takumi: A 60,000 Hour Story on the Survival of Human Craft" is a new film by director @clayjeter that explores the world of Japanese master craftsmen, known as Takumi, who can take up to 60,000 hours to learn their discipline. This degree of dedication is hard for the modern brain to conceive—it begs the question of whether there is an ineffable human cost to our technological advances. The film follows Hisato Nakahigashi, a two Michelin-star chef, who fishes and forages for ingredients in a forest near his restaurant in order to provide the ultimate experience for his guests; Shigeo Kiuchi, who has trained from age six to become a specialized temple and shrine builder; and Katsuaki Suganuma, the final inspector for the Japanese luxury vehicle manufacturer Lexus. Suganuma has spent more than 30 years honing all of his senses so they are acute enough to detect the slightest flaw. There’s also Nahoko Kojima, one of the very few artisans specializing in traditional papercutting, who spends up to eight months creating a single sculpture from paper, hand cut into elaborate designs. #TakumiDoc
A cartoon by Michael Maslin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Virgil Abloh’s work is often referential, but he sees this as rooted in the ethos of streetwear, which, to him, does not necessarily mean T-shirts, hoodies, and sneakers. “Streetwear in my mind is linked to Duchamp,” he says. “It’s this idea of the readymade. I’m talking Lower East Side, New York. It’s like hip-hop. It’s sampling. I take James Brown, I chop it up, I make a new song. I’m taking IKEA and I’m presenting it in my own way.” Click the link in our bio to read @doreenstfelix on the multi-hyphenate “maker.” Photograph by @lorenzovitturi for TNY.

When Ethan James Green began his photography project—which is collected in the new book “Young New York”—he was a self-described lone wolf, looking for friends. He found them at clubs, at fashion shows, and online—and would invite them to pose for portraits. His subjects are confidently beautiful, masters of style and attitude. Click the ink in our bio to see more of his work. Photographs by @ethanjamesgreen / Courtesy Aperture.

In the 1960s, the age of Ann-Margret and Jean Shrimpton, the photographer Kwame Brathwaite co-founded a group called the Grandassa Models. “We said, ‘We’ve got to do something to make the women feel proud of their hair, proud of their blackness,’ ” he recalls.  The models’ skin tones ranged from light brown to dark brown, and they had full lips, natural hairstyles, and a variety of body shapes. The first monograph dedicated to the photographer’s work, titled “Black Is Beautiful,” will be released on May 1st. Photograph by @kwamebphoto.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In his eight years on S.N.L., Bill Hader came to love the show’s camaraderie, but dreaded the live performances, and the rage and shame he knew he’d feel if he screwed up. “It was embarrassing how unhappy I was,” he says. “I’d wake up Saturday morning crying.” Click the link in our bio to read about how the beloved comedian reinvented himself as a writer-director with “Barry,” his bleakly funny TV show. Photograph by @maleriemarder for TNY.
A cartoon by Pia Guerra. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Matt Eich’s images of Baptist Town, Mississippi, create a detailed portrait of life on the country’s economic fringes. But they also show a common aspect of the experience of poverty in America: the role of family and community as sources of hope. Click the link in our bio to see more from his new book, “Sin & Salvation in Baptist Town.” Photograph by @matteich.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by Bernard Schoenbaum, from 1993. #TNYcartoons

Nearly every contemporary restaurant's tasting menu owes its identity to kaiseki, a high-end Japanese cuisine that is dominated by male chefs. When Niki Nakayama opened her restaurant, n/naka, in L.A., it may have been the only kaiseki restaurant run by a woman in any country. Now it is booked out months in advance. Click the link in our bio to read @helenr on the female chef making Japan’s most elaborate cuisine her own. Photograph by @ damon_c for TNY.
A slideshow of #TNYcovers by some of our favorite women artists, for #InternationalWomensDay.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

At Shigetoshi Nakamura’s newest restaurant, Niche, on the Lower East Side, the ramen is what’s known as mazemen, a relatively new style that omits most or all of the broth. There’s something thrilling about having unadulterated access to ingredients that would otherwise be veiled in liquid, and here the noodles and unexpected toppings get star billing. This is ramen that cuts to the chase. Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield’s review. Photographs by @nothinginpassing for TNY.
A cartoon by @rozchast. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Photographs of Luke Perry from the early 1990s still stir a potent sense of recognition in those who knew him as Dylan McKay on “Beverly Hills, 90210.” Somehow, Perry, who died yesterday, at fifty-two, was able to withstand the more pernicious aspects of early fame and its subsequent diminishment. He was never a has-been, because he never seemed to try and recapture a role that he had outgrown. Click the link in our bio to read @frynaomifry on what the late actor meant to so many, at a very particular time and place. Photograph by Mikel Roberts / Sygma / Getty.

At eighty-two, Buddy Guy is bald, twinkly, and preternaturally cool. The way he sees it, he’s like one of those aging souls who find themselves the last fluent speaker of an obscure regional language. In this case, that language is the blues. Click the link in our bio to read David Remnick’s Profile of the last great Chicago bluesman. Photograph by @stefanruizphoto for TNY.
A cartoon by Frank Cotham. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Since Donald Trump became President, a direct pipeline has been established between the Oval Oﬃce and Rupert Murdoch. “He’s an incredibly cunning political player. He’s been in the game of influencing government behavior to his benefit longer than most of us have been alive,” a former F.C.C. staffer says of the media tycoon. Click the link in our bio to read Jane Mayer on the making of the Fox News White House. Illustration by Tyler Comrie; photograph from Getty.
This week's cover, "Off the Path," by @gaylekabaker. #TNYcovers
A cover, from 1968, by Albert Hubbell. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by P. C. Vey. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Alejandro Cegarra’s photo series “State of Decay” is an unflinching portrait of Venezuela’s collapse. Shot between 2013 and 2019, his black-and-white images show what real life in Caracas is like: precariously strung-out and pared-down, shorn of any softness. We see street preachers shouting, inmates weight lifting, children running in fear, and bloodstains on the ground. See more on our Stories. Photograph by @alecegarra.

Last week, @hailunma took over our photo department’s account to share images from her “Hometown Series” taken in Xinjiang, China. Growing up, she was fascinated by the colorful and vibrant Uyghur traditional clothing, and, in the series, she explores how the Uyghurs understand trends and style. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by @carolitajohnson. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Today in New York: The Temptations are getting the “Jersey Boys” treatment in “Ain’t Too Proud,” which starts previews at the Imperial. In the musical—starring Jawan M. Jackson, James Harkness, Derrick Baskin, Jeremy Pope, and Ephraim Sykes—you can expect backstage drama (egos, drugs, lawsuits) to keep the action moving and Motown earworms (“My Girl,” “Just My Imagination”) to make it go down smooth. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.

Michael Cohen was a bad man before he met Donald Trump, he remained a bad man afterward, and he became, if anything, even worse after Trump started running for President. But Cohen has—it seems possible—become penitent and regretful about one aspect of his badness, specifically the bad things that he did for Trump over the past twelve years. Click the link in our bio to read Adam Davidson on what today’s testimony tells us about the President’s business, bluster, and wealth. Photograph by @markpetersonpixs / Redux for TNY.
A cartoon by @tomcheney54, from 1985. #TNYcartoons

“The wonderful thing about dying is the interesting processes. I find it fascinating as an artist and as a writer,” Barbara Hammer says. The pioneering visual artist, who has lived with cancer for thirteen years and has exhausted all available treatment options, tells Masha Gessen about her career, her quest to die with dignity, and why being a lesbian is so much fun. Click the link in our bio to read the interview. Photograph by @elinorcarucci for TNY.
N.Y.C. tourist photos that @siogallagher has appeared in through the years. See more at the link in our bio.
A cartoon by Jack Ziegler. #TNYcartoons

For the costumes in "Black Panther," Ruth E. Carter evoked the fictional African kingdom of Wakanda by melding sci-fi with global fashion history, drawing influence from sources including the color symbolism of the Maasai people, samurai armor, and the jewelry of Ndebele women. For her work, she has just won the Oscar for Best Costume Design. Click the link in our bio to see more of her costumes, for films including "Selma" and “Do the Right Thing.” Photograph by Awol Erizku.
A cartoon by @christopherweyant, from 2014. #TNYcartoons

Are you planning to watch the Oscars tonight? Catch up on some of our best writing on the nominated films, at the link in our bio. Even if you don’t watch, you’ll be ready to talk about it. Photograph from Bettmann / Getty.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Today in New York: Anderson .Paak and his band, the Free Nationals, take the stage at Hammerstein Ballroom for a kinetic, one-of-a-kind jam session. .Paak’s music radiates with farsighted imagination, unfettered humor, and an astute appreciation for craft. Photo illustration by @shaedetar for TNY.
An early look at next week’s cover, “The Real Emergency,” by Barry Blitt. #TNYcovers

When Janice Guy won a grant that enabled her to move to Rome, in 1980, she packed up her prints and negatives, and stored them in a friend’s basement. Within two years, she had quit making art to become a gallerist. But now, her early experimental work has found itself on display. Click the link in our bio to see more of Guy’s feminist self-portraits, also on view at Higher Pictures, through March 9th. Photographs by Janice Guy / Courtesy Higher Pictures.
A cartoon by P. C. Vey. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

As destructive wildfires become commonplace in California, design details from water tanks to biodegradable flame retardants help people protect their homes. “It’s necessary, especially for architecture and design professionals, to understand how to live in a much more extreme world,” David Hertz, an architect and sustainability expert, told our staff writer Dana Goodyear. “Resilience is the key.” Click the link in our bio to watch our short documentary on California’s fire-prone future, produced in partnership with @van_alen . Photo by @sullyfoto / Getty

“Being a black woman writer is not a shallow place but a rich place to write from. It doesn’t limit my imagination; it expands it,” Toni Morrison, who turns eighty-eight today, said. Click the link in our bio to read Hilton Als’s 2003 Profile of the legendary writer. Photo by Damon Winter / NYT / Redux.
A cartoon by @maggiejanelarson. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cover by Robert Weber, from 1990, for Presidents' Day. #TNYcovers
Meet Mr. Long Legs, by Ashley Franklin.
A cartoon by David Sipress. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Between the years 1897 and 1922, the photographer Hugh Mangum set up makeshift studios across North Carolina and Virginia, where he invited black and white portrait subjects to share space together. In an era of racial terror and Jim Crow segregation, Mangum's work acts as a record of shared experience in the face of racist American customs and laws. Click the link in our bio to view these dynamic portraits. Photographs by Hugh Mangum.
A cartoon by @lianafinck. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

After closely escaping a bombing in Mosul, and dodging sniper fire in Baghdad, the Army Reserves veteran and newspaper columnist Rachael Van Horn decided to work through her P.T.S.D. in the fields of Oklahoma. Now, she is something of a celebrity in the state. Click the link in our bio to read more about her adventures in oil-pumping—a profession that is dominated by men. Photograph by @katygrannan for TNY.
A cartoon by Donald Reilly, from 1994. #TNYcartoons
Can't find love this Valentine's Day? Here's a slideshow of #TNYcovers instead.

A newly uncovered videotape that shows R. Kelly sexually assaulting an underage girl may soon lead to his indictment in Illinois, according to a senior law-enforcement official. Click the link in our bio to read the breaking report. Illustration by @maischotz; Source Photograph by M. Spencer Green / AP

Culturally relevant valentines, by Sophie Johnson. Click the link in our bio for more.

The photographs in Robin Hammond’s “Where Love Is Illegal” document anti-gay discrimination around the world. Are the images so beautiful because they celebrate the human spirit, the will to be oneself and to love, whatever the circumstances and the laws? Perhaps, but it is the disjuncture between the pictures and the stories behind them that makes the series so haunting. Photograph by @hammond_robin/Panos for @witness_change
A cartoon by @tomcheney54. #TNYcartoons
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. #TNYcartoons

The actor Richard E. Grant has loved Barbra Streisand since 1969, when he was twelve years old and living in the tiny African nation of Swaziland. “I was at full hormonal storm at that point,” he says. “I thought that she was just the sexiest thing on the planet.” Now, at sixty-one, he is taking a tour of Streisand’s New York, from the housing complex where she grew up to the Village Vanguard, where she performed an invite-only cabaret show in 2009. Click the link in our bio to go along. Photograph by @victor.llorente for TNY.
A cartoon by Edward Steed. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

If this year’s Grammy Awards had one theme, it was female empowerment. The show’s host, Alicia Keys, kicked off the ceremony with remarks from an electrifying lineup of Michelle Obama, Lady Gaga, J. Lo, and Jada Pinkett Smith. A stream of female performers appeared—and the winners of the awards finally started to reflect the dramatic evolution of popular music. Click the link in our bio to read more about the ceremony. Photograph by Kevin Winter / Getty.
The cover for this year’s Anniversary Issue, “Spring Blossoms,” by @kadirnelson. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @lianafinck. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Dave Pasternack, of the midtown seafood mecca Esca, is bringing Manhattan-style dining to Staten Island with Barca. The restaurant, which is located in a sleek new development not far from the ferry terminal, offers oysters and clams on the half shell, fluke crudo, and lobster spaghetti—not to mention an uninterrupted view of the Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge. Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield’s full review. Photographs by David Williams for TNY.
A cartoon by Charles Barsotti, from 2002. #TNYcartoons

Today in New York: The new exhibition “Frida Kahlo: Appearances Can Be Deceiving” opens at the Brooklyn Museum. The artist’s indelible self-portraits on canvas are joined—for the first time in the U.S.—by a selection of the Tehuana garments and jewelry with which she cannily constructed her public persona—a reminder that, in Kahlo’s case, style was substance. Photograph by Nickolas Muray, © Nickolas Muray Photo Archives.
A cartoon by @carolitajohnson. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In 1972, on the first day of her sophomore year at Yale, Joyce Maynard dropped out of school to live with the writer J. D. Salinger. She was later spurned for writing about their affair. Now, four and a half decades later, she is back at college. Click the link in our bio to read about how she thinks attitudes have changed—and how they haven’t—since the early seventies. Photograph by @wutangkait for TNY.
Predictions for fashion week, as drawn by @ohhhaeee. Click the link in our bio to see more.

This week, @gordonparksfoundation is taking over our photo department’s account to share images from Gordon Parks’s expansive archive, like this self-portrait from around 1948, which was used as his employee photograph at “Life” magazine. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by @blisscartoons. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

There is a carrousel of professionals involved in any television production—there are the writers, the directors, the executive producer, and the stars. Pamela Adlon spins all these plates at once. She talks about about “Better Things,” sudden success, and her relationship with Louis C.K., at the link in our bio. Photograph by Amanda Demme for TNY.

At President Trump’s second State of the Union address, a triangular tranche of the House of Representatives stood out, as if lit by a spotlight: the female members of the 116th Congress, dressed in white, the traditional shade of the suffragette movement. You can’t compose an image like that if you don’t have the numbers for it. Click the link in our bio to read Alexandra Schwartz on the joyful defiance of the Congresswomen in white. Photograph by Zach Gibson / Getty.
A cartoon by Christopher Weyant. #TNYcartoons

With the new Hudson & Charles Dinette, Hudson & Charles Meats joins a handful of specialty shops that have thought to advertise their wares—and take advantage of liquor margins—by opening restaurants. Though the menu is extremely meat-centric, and includes a steak of the day, there are two salads on offer, a handful of vegetable sides, and a fantastic “borscht” sausage, made with ground pork and beet purée. Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield’s full review. Photographs by @erichelgas for TNY.
This week's cover, "Love Interest," by Pascal Campion. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by David Sipress. #TNYcartoons

Today in New York: The English R. & B. artist NAO plays at Terminal 5. Her latest album—which was inspired by Saturn’s return, the astrological paradigm shift said to usher in one’s thirties—depicts her psychic transformation in vulnerable confessionals and jubilant tales of romance. Photograph by @damienmaloney for TNY.
A cartoon by @daveostowdraws. #TNYcartoons

An Irving Penn portrait, from 1947, of the hulking Arctic explorer Peter Freuchen and his chic wife, Dagmar, seems made for the coldest days of winter. Click the link in our bio to read @rachsyme on why she comes back to this image, winter after winter. Photograph by Irving Penn / © The Irving Penn Foundation.
A cartoon by Frank Cotham. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This week, the team from @chandohacats took over our photo department’s account to pay tribute to the life and work of Walter Chandoha, who died in January. Chandoha is known as the pioneer of cat photography, taking some ninety thousand photos of felines over the course of more than seventy-five years. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
@rozchast repurposes some exchanges snipped (and rearranged) from a learn-to-speak-French booklet, from the fifties, that belonged to her father.

A reborn is a doll that is painstakingly made from vinyl or silicone and meant to appear as much like a real baby as possible. The photographer Jamie Diamond uses these dolls in two of her series, “I Promise to Be a Good Mother” and “Forever Mothers,” to query the seemingly natural and essential roles that women are made to play in society. Click the link in our bio to see more of her work. Photograph by @jamiediamond.
A cartoon by @kendra_allenby. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Nashville hot chicken may sound like a viral novelty, like the cronut, but it long predates Instagram: it became popular more than eighty years ago, in the city’s black community, and the recipe originated with one family, the Princes. The dish’s “queen mother,” André Prince Jeffries has run Prince’s Hot Chicken Shack since 1980. She’s spent the better part of her adulthood recounting its legend, for she inherited both the recipe (which is secret) and the family lore (which is unverifiable). Click the link in our bio to read more about the family business that put Nashville hot chicken on the map. Photograph by @yabliko for TNY.
A cartoon by @lianafinck. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week's cover, "Winter Garden, by Tom Gauld. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

After his last novel won the Man Booker Prize, in 2015, Marlon James told an interviewer that he was going to write an African “Game of Thrones.” For a writer who once lamented that no one would ever read his books, his timing is auspicious: among the sort of people who pay attention to literary prizes, snobbery about wizards and dragons and aliens is increasingly passé. Click the link in our bio to read @jiatortellini’s Profile of the Jamaican novelist, whose first installment of what he calls the Dark Star trilogy, “Black Leopard, Red Wolf,” comes out in February. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
New stamps from the U.S. Postal Service, as drawn by @alifitzgerald80s.

The Cuban musician Brenda Navarrete plays at least ten instuments, but it is on the batá that she has distinguished herself. A cornerstone of Santería religious ceremonies, batá drumming is a hypercompetitive ritual among men. “ ‘How cute,’ they say, ‘a woman playing the drums,’ ” Navarrete says. “I am serious. I prepare a lot, I have studied with the masters. The concept of cute doesn’t interest me.” Check out our Instagram Stories to learn more about a new vanguard of women in Cuban jazz. Photograph by @rorosiemarie for TNY.
A cartoon by @paulnoth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“I think everyone is born with humor, but your life can beat it out of you, sadly, or you can be lucky enough to grow up in it,” Catherine O’Hara says. The comedian tells @rachsyme about the way she got her start (as an understudy for Gilda Radner), the origins of her collaboration with Eugene Levy (they once dated. . . ), and the reason she left Toronto for L.A. (love, of course). Click the link in our bio to read the full interview. Photograph by @caitoppermann for TNY.
This week, @tamejawdin took over our photo department’s account to share photos from his upcoming book, “Instant Honey.” Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
How to get great ideas, as @drawnbytom.
A cover by @kadirnelson, from 2017, for #MLKDay. Click the link in our bio to see more #TNYcovers featuring Martin Luther King, Jr.

Leonti offers a heady dose of a largely bygone uptown glamour. In the dining room, which is inspired by the aesthetics of Milan and Bergamo, gracious servers in suits remove domed lids from silver platters with dramatic flair. The chef Adam Leonti mills grains himself to make bread, pasta, and pastries. This all, of course, comes at a cost. But if ever there were a special-occasion restaurant that feels worth the high price tag, this is it. Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield’s review. Photographs by @erichelgas for TNY.
A cartoon by Edward Steed. #TNYcartoons
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In 2012, Patti Smith travelled to the former home of the artists Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera, which now serves as a museum. She took several black-and-white Polaroid photographs of objects she encountered there: a pair of crutches that belonged to Kahlo; her worn corset. The images, taken while Smith was ill, are stark and dim, and they reflect a deep reverence for ordinary objects and the poetry they contain. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photographs by @thisispattismith / Courtesy Kurimanzutto.
An early look at next week's cover: "Walled In," by John Cuneo. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @christopherweyant, from 2013. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“This man has lived through everything imaginable,” the director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck says of Gerhard Richter. His new film, which is inspired by the painter, blurs the line between fiction and biography—hewing closely to Richter’s youthful experiences, particularly his first marriage, but leaving room for conflation and outright invention. Richter says that it goes too far. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Hendrik Kerstens for TNY.

“I thought I was a student. I thought I was a teacher. And then I discovered that I liked to tell stories and make people cry,” Susan Sontag, who was born eighty-six years ago today, said of her fiction. Click the link in our bio to read Joan Acocella’s 2000 Profile of the writer. Photograph by Richard Avedon / © The Richard Avedon Foundation.
A cartoon by @hartley._.lin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“I think the contemporary world that has claimed him needs to read him more deeply,” @hilton.als says of James Baldwin. With his latest art exhibition—which includes works by Richard Avedon, Kara Walker, and Diane Arbus—Als attempts to give shape to a man who is celebrated as a writer-prophet of racial injustice but too often overlooked as an artist and a human being. Click the link in our bio to read more about what Als hoped to accomplish with “God Made My Face: A Collective Portrait at David Zwirner.” Photograph by Richard Avedon, © The Richard Avedon Foundation.
Still got it. Covers by Mark Ulriksen and Pascal Campion, from 2009 and 2019. #10yearchallenge #TNYcovers

Donald Trump, in typical form, spun Monday’s White House catering as ultimately the fault of his political opponents, an inevitable result of his own elective government shutdown, which has left hundreds of thousands of federal employees furloughed—including, presumably, the White House kitchen staff. But we might wonder if there is also something more pure in his decision to bring in a drive-through feast for the history books—an attempt, however opportunistic, for a man who loves fast food to fulfill his straightforward desires. Click the link in our bio to read @helenr on the pure American banality of Donald Trump’s fast-food banquet. Photograph by Chris Kleponis / Getty.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The 1981 musical, “Merrily We Roll Along,” closed after just sixteen performances on Broadway, but its afterlife has been long. The story, about three friends who drift apart as they navigate show business, is told in reverse, starting with disillusioned middle age and winding back to idealistic youth. Fiasco Theatre, the Roundabout’s scrappy company-in-residence, is staging a six-person revival at the Laura Pels, now in previews. Photograph by @ioulex for TNY.
This week's cover, “Big City,” by Pascal Campion.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

You might liken “Singaporean cuisine” to “New York cuisine” in that it reflects the city’s cultural makeup—it’s a mosaic of dishes from Malaysia, China, Indonesia, India, and parts of Europe. At Yummy Tummy, a new Singaporean restaurant in Flushing, the chef and owner, Richard Chan, serves a selection of his favorites—including a platter of chili crabs and fried buns. Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield’s review. Photographs by @zaczavv for TNY.
How to survive a cold, as @drawnbytom.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
"Boys I will date in my twenties" vs. "Boys I dated in middle school," by @drawingolive and @juliaedelman_.
A cartoon by @sofiawarrenart. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This week, @___benthomas is taking over our photo department's account to share a new body of work shot in Tokyo. Through these images, he is looking to better understand the intersection between the citizen and built environments. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.

The most enduring subject of Lee Friedlander’s personal photographic memory palace is his wife, Maria, whom he married in 1958. Over sixty years, he made portraits of her—sometimes with their children, and later, their grandchildren—that compel with their air of casual inevitability. They are artful but not arty, imbued with sentiment but not sentimental. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photographs by Lee Friedlander / Courtesy Fraenkel Gallery at Deborah Bell Photographs.
A cartoon by David Sipress. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Brand-new Fortnite dances, by @drawnbysharon.

In 2016, the photographer Matthew Genitempo decided to trek deep into the Ozark Mountains. His resulting series, “Jasper,” is an idiosyncratic travelogue, combining elegiac black-and-white landscapes with portraits of the men and women he encountered as he wandered. The people in these photographs are not complete recluses, he says. Many offered him a drink or a place to stay. A few have phones. They’ve chosen to limit their access to society, not cut it off entirely. Click the link in our bio to see more of his work. Photographs by @genitempo/Courtesy Twin Palms Publishers.
A cartoon by @pia.guerra. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

When Donald Trump was elected with some 80% of white evangelical support, Karen Swallow Prior saw it as a call to address the problems within the evangelical community. Last month, along with twenty female leaders from different denominational traditions, she launched the Pelican Project, an effort to provide orthodox women with scriptural guidance. Click the link in our bio to read Eliza Griswold on a new movement of Christians looking to reclaim their faith from the regressive politics that have coöpted it. Photograph by @JaredSoares for TNY.
Notebooks that were abandoned last year, as illustrated by @corinnemucha.

The menu at the newest outpost of Mission Chinese Food, in Bushwick, offers a pared-down selection of the chef Danny Bowien’s greatest hits with a few new additions. Much has been made, on the Internet, of an appetizer that appears on the menu as “water pickles” and is, effectively, ice on a bed of kimchi. But what ice! Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield's review. Photographs by @kristaschlueter for TNY.

Is marijuana as safe as we think? The answer is we don’t really know. At the link in our bio, @malcolmgladwell looks at the potential public-health consequences of widespread cannabis use. Illustration by @javier_jaen.
A cartoon by @naviedm. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Subway ads for rejected startups, by Dayna Evans and @j.a.k._.
A cartoon by @lila__ash. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Sophie Mackintosh’s début novel, “The Water Cure,” is sometimes grouped with the new crop of feminist dystopias, but it doesn’t much resemble them in that it constructs not a world but a bubble within a world—in other words, a family. The story, which concerns three sisters brought up in fear and isolation, is a sort of twisted fairy tale about toxic masculinity. Click the link in our bio to read Laura Miller’s review of the book. Photograph by @niallmcdiarmid for TNY.
A cartoon by Ivan Ehlers. #TNYcartoons

“Welcome to Congress,” a cover by Barry Blitt. #TNYcovers

Today in New York: “Under the Radar,” the Public’s annual emporium of the avant-garde and the out of this world, kicks off—featuring the show “Hyperbolic!” In it, the Illustrious Blacks perform disco-infused Afrofuturist funk while channelling the androgynous glamour of Prince, David Bowie, and Grace Jones. Photograph by @workdaily for TNY.
Mistakes you're going to keep making forever because it's a new year, but you're still the same old you—by @j.a.k._ and @phil_mcandrew.
A cartoon by @kimwarp. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

For a profile of the indie rocker Cat Power, the photographers Inez and Vinoodh captured this striking portrait of Chan Marshall, who for decades has provided a template for generations of young women coming up in the aggressively male genre of indie rock. Photograph by @inezandvinoodh for TNY.

We hope you enjoyed seeing some of our favorite images from 2018.
A cartoon by P. S. Mueller. #TNYcartoons

“When I was younger, I gave a lot of attention to things I feel maybe I have to give less attention to now. Like being a musician. The more practice you get, the easier it is,” Robert De Niro says. In the last decade, the actor has appeared in more than two dozen feature-length movies, and he has no plans of slowing down. Click the link in our bio to read his interview with Michael Schulman. Photograph by @richardburbridge for TNY.
This week's cover, "Out in the Cold,” by Harry Bliss. Click the link in our bio to read about the artist's inspiration. #TNYcovers

The photographer Bill McCullough captured Beto O'Rourke among a crowd of supporters, as he campaigned for Senator of Texas, in this November's midterm elections. Photograph by Bill McCullough for TNY.

For a report on immigrant rights, the photographer Carolyn Drake captured a mother holding up a blouse that her daughter left behind in Texas, after a traffic stop led her to being deported to Mexico. Photograph by @drakeycake for TNY.

The photographer Awol Erizku captured this portrait for a profile of the sketch comic, standup comedian, writer, actor, D.J., musician, and budding movie star, Donald Glover, by our staff writer Tad Friend. Photograph by @awolerizku for TNY.

This year, a record hot summer and a dry fall set the stage for the most destructive fires in California's history. The photographer Kevin Cooley captured the Woolsey fire, near Los Angeles, as seen from the West Hills, for a report on how climate change and extreme weather is shrinking the planet. Photograph by @kevincooley_ for TNY.

This summer, the Swiss-Guinean photographer Namsa Leuba travelled to Lagos to showcase the biggest Afrobeats stars of the Nigerian music scene, including the musician Falana. Photograph by @namsaleuba for TNY. .

Between opening presents and carving the Christmas turkey, take a moment to swipe through these vintage covers. Santa Claus has been featured on more than thirty #TNYcovers since 1925. Click the link in our bio to see more.
A cartoon by @lizadonnelly. #TNYcartoons

The photographer Davide Monteleone traversed the Asian continent for his extensive coverage of the "new" Silk Road, the most ambitious infrastructure project the world has ever known—and the most expensive. Photograph by @davidemon for TNY.

For our coverage of the most recent midterm election, the political photographer Mark Peterson captured the Florida gubernatorial candidate Andrew Gillum in a voting booth with two of his small children standing by. Photograph by @markpetersonpixs for TNY.

From breaking-news photographs to portraits composed for magazine features, we’ll be sharing one of our favorite images from 2018 each day until the end of the year.

The look of Vincent Ferrané’s series “Milky Way,” which documents his wife breast-feeding their infant child, is somewhere between that of fashion photography and of amateur home snapshots. The starkly composed, brightly lit scenes present a world deeply private and tender—a mother and baby joined repeatedly in the act of nourishment, as the father looks on. Click the link in our bio to see more of his work. Photograph by @vincentferrane.

The photographer Awol Erizku paid homage to the brilliance of the "Black Panther" costume designer Ruth E. Carter, with cinematic, dramatic photographs of her portfolio that contain whole narratives themselves. Photograph by @awolerizku. .
.

From breaking-news photographs to portraits composed for magazine features, we’ll be sharing one of our favorite images from 2018 each day until the end of the year.

The photojournalist Adriana Zehbrauskas photographed children at the U.S.-Mexico border during a trip she and the writer @jonathanblitzer made to follow the migrant caravan as it moved north through Mexico, in October. Photograph by @adrianazehbrauskas for TNY.

From breaking-news photographs to portraits composed for magazine features, we’ll be sharing one of our favorite images from 2018 each day until the end of the year.
Intentionally vague, nondenominational holiday cards, by @ernio_art.

From breaking-news images to on-the-ground coverage, stunning portraiture to meticulously planned photo essays, @newyorkerphoto’s photographers were hard at work in 2018. Pari Dukovic travelled to the French Riviera in search of the roses that make up Chanel No. 5 perfume, and the resulting pictures are so vibrant that you expect the fragrance to emanate from the screen. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
.

Follow along as we share one of our favorite photographs each day until the end of the year.
The most-liked cartoon on @newyorkercartoons this year was by Peter Steiner, from 1990. Click the link in our bio to see our followers’ other favorites. #TNYcartoons

Since Donald Trump’s tariffs were implemented, in June, the price of imported steel has risen by 25%. Mid-Continent Nail, the largest nail manufacturer in the U.S., has had to raise its prices—and has lost half of its orders and had to let go of almost half its workforce. “It’s been devastating. Never did I think when Trump campaigned on ‘Make America Great Again’ we’d have to lay off all these people,” Chris Pratt, the plant manager, says. Click the link in our bio read Alex Kotlowitz’s dispatch from Poplar Bluff, Missouri, where hundreds of jobs are being lost because of Trump’s trade war. Photographs by Aaron Hardin for TNY.

Today in New York: The distinguished trumpeter Wynton Marsalis and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, along with the promising vocalists Vuyo Sotashe and Veronica Swift, offer “Big Band Holidays,” a program brimming with seasonal confections, both classic and reimagined. Like all good traditions, the series comes with  dollops of carefree nostalgia and abundant cheer. Photograph by Dan Winters for TNY.
A cartoon by @margaret__elisabeth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Things your things know about you, by @drawingolive and @svollman.

The Evelyn Hotel has become a mini-empire under the rule of the chef Jonathan Benno. At Benno, his restaurant for capital-“F” Fine Dining, the best things on the prix-fixe menu are the least fussy. The much more casual Leonelli Taberna serves Italian comfort food, and Leonelli Focacceria e Pasticceria offers focaccia, topped and sliced like pizza, plus pastries, sandwiches, and salads. Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield’s review. Photographs by @erichelgas for TNY.
A cartoon by @blisscartoons. #TNYcartoons

The widows of ISIS fighters in Iraq often have to flee their towns, for fear of retribution. They end up in camps, where many are harassed and raped by armed men. It’s not uncommon for relatives of suspected ISIS members, even those who have not been formally charged, to be rounded up by security forces and sent to remote desert camps, where they are denied food, medical services, and access to documents. Click the link in our bio to read @bentaub91 on how the corruption and cruelty of the Iraq state could likely lead to the resurgence of the terror group. Photograph by @moisessaman / Magnum for TNY.
This week's cover, “Elementary,” by Barry Blitt. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Glen Baxter, from 1992. #TNYcartoons

Today in New York: Kevin Beasley's politically conscious twist on the late Robert Morris’s 1961 piece “Box with the Sound of Its Own Making” opens at the Whitney Museum. In 2012, then a grad student at Yale, the artist drove to the outskirts of Selma, Alabama, to buy a century-old motor that had powered a cotton gin for thirty years, during both the Jim Crow and the civil-rights eras. At the museum, he sequesters the still operational one-ton machine in a soundproof glass box and transmits the audio into the adjacent room. Photograph by Steve Harries for TNY.
A cartoon by Christopher Weyant. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Donald Trump has said that if Robert Mueller tried to investigate the Trump family’s business dealings he would be crossing a “red line.” Representative Adam Schiff plans to obliterate that line when he becomes chairman of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence next year. Click the link in our bio to read Jeffrey Toobin on Schiff’s plans to probe President Trump’s connections to Russia, Saudi Arabia, and other places around the world. Photograph by David Williams / Redux for TNY.
We're calling it a tradition! Our very bookish Christmas tree is back at the @newyorkermag offices for the second year in a row. 📚 Photograph by @rachelraudenbush.
A cartoon by Matthew Diffee, from 2009. #TNYcartoons

Since the late nineteen-eighties, Lyle Ashton Harris has been using himself as a lapidary tool to dismantle preconceptions about race, gender, and sexual identity, and to construct an ongoing, oneiric memoir about African diasporic life. For his new pictures, the artist posed, nude or nearly so, in African masks, many of them from his uncle’s collection, rooting an en-plein-air masquerade in his private history. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @lyleashtonharris / Courtesy @salon94.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“I have a different kind of view of my life now, having seen that edge—that we’re all going to see at some point, and which, really, as a mortal person you don’t allow yourself to consider, ever,” Julia Louis-Dreyfus says. She tells @arielvlevy about battling breast cancer, challenging comedy’s sexism, and becoming the star of her own show, at the link in our bio. Photograph by @ryanpfluger for TNY.

Surfers spend much of their lives looking for the perfect wave. @kellyslater —the best surfer in history—started making them on demand, at his artificial wave pool in the farmlands of California. Kelly’s Wave, as his invention is known, seems designed to make someone who surfs feel stunned, turned on, needy—but it hasn’t been met with universal acclaim. Click the link in our bio to read William Finnegan, himself a longtime surfer, on what the machine means for the future of the sport. Photograph by Ben Lowy for TNY.
This week's cover, “Santa’s Little Helpers,” by John Cuneo. #TNYcovers

Keith Carter has spent five decades documenting small-town Texas. His life’s work, to be published in a new collection next year titled “Fifty Years,” amounts to a vast tribute to the state. But what interests him even more than the stories Texas tells about itself are the everyday figures—idle kids, blue-collar workers, animals both domesticated and less so—that contribute to the state’s mythology. Click the link in our bio to see more of the rich, allegorical images he produces. Photograph by @keithcarter.art / Courtesy University of Texas Press.
A cartoon by Pia Guerra. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Would an omnivore give up meat if she could still have foie gras? That question seems to be what Champ Jones, a former Eleven Madison Park sous-chef and an omnivore himself, is exploring with Sans. The restaurant, which opened in September, gives vegan food the fine-dining treatment, offering a five-course tasting menu with optional beverage pairing. If you didn't know it going in, it wouldn’t necessarily be apparent that it’s a vegan restaurant at all. Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield’s review. Photograph by Haruka Sakaguchi for TNY.

Liv Ullmann burst into prominence playing an actress fallen mute in Ingmar Bergman’s 1966 “Persona.” Her performance, with its extremes of vulnerability and ferocity, is central to the film and to the time. The actress went on to make nine more movies with Bergman, to act in forty-eight other films, and to direct five features. Yesterday she appeared at BAM for her eightieth-birthday celebration, which included a discussion with her and a screening of Jan Troell’s historical drama “The Emigrants,” from 1971. Photograph from Santi Visalli / Getty.
Dr. Seuss’s freelance rhymes and woes, by @jeremywins.

Edward Gorey hated New York—he thought Manhattanites were a bunch of phonies—but he carved out a life for himself in the city that he would have had a hard time constructing elsewhere. He loved going to the movies and went to see the City Ballet perform pretty much every night for almost half the year. And, somehow, in between all his moviegoing and ballet attendance, he created art books of a singular quality. Click the link in our bio to read Joan Acocella on a new biography of the book artist. Photograph by Richard Avedon / © The Richard Avedon Foundation.
Fashionable outfits for working from home, as drawn by @danajerimaier.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“We have entered a period of chaos. Putin didn’t invent the chaos. He just sort of helped it along,” Garry Kasparov says. The chess grandmaster turned political activist has launched movements to oppose two Presidents, first Vladimir Putin and now Donald Trump. Click the link in our bio to read his interview with Masha Gessen about democracy, optimism, and—of course—chess. Photograph by @dedecim for TNY.

This week, @therainbow_is_underestimated is taking over our photo department's account to share pictures he made in Puglia, the region of Southern Italy where he lives. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Today, Earl Sweatshirt is a symbol of how quickly rap moves, and also an example of how a young rap star can evolve. At twenty-four, an age when most people are just starting a career and beginning to dabble in self-discovery, he is an elder statesman of hip-hop. Click the link in our bio to read Carrie Battan on the jaded Odd Future alum’s new album, “Some Rap Songs.” Photograph by @awolerizku for TNY.

With her new book “Liberty Theater,” the photographer Rosalind Fox Solomon revisits her uncanny excoriation of the great myths of the South. Taken from the seventies to the late nineties, the extraordinary portraits and scenes are not quite documentary, but they pursue a truth about fear, pleasure, confusion, family history, and who and what whiteness feeds on in order to cohere. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photographs by Rosalind Fox Solomon / Courtesy Mack.
A cartoon by Felipe Galindo. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week's cover, "Cat Fancy," by Edward Gorey. Click the link in our bio for more about the drawing, which was submitted more than twenty-five years ago. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Frank Modell, from 1990. #TNYcartoons
Mascots for the rest of us, by @instachaaz.

Most New Yorkers are familiar with bubble tea and gua bao, but Taiwanese food has long been a limited commodity in the city—and we’ve been missing out on a lot. Luckily, in the past few years, a growing group of young Taiwanese-Americans have been doing an excellent job of showing how much more there is to explore, and of fulfilling the cravings of diners already in the know. Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield’s review of 886, Ho Foods, and New York’s Taiwanese new wave. Photographs by @zaczavv for TNY.
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by Nancy Fay, from 1928. #TNYcartoons
A slideshow of iconic New York covers, from our archive. Tell us which one is your favorite in the comments. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Chon Day, from 1957. #TNYcartoons

Arthur Elgort’s photographs of jazz dandies, from 2000, recreate the Harlem of fabulous furs, of Tallulah Bankhead hanging out with Billie Holiday, of Helen Lawrenson stepping out of a big Checker on her way to visit her lover, the gangster Bumpy Johnson. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photographs @arthurelgort for TNY.

Today in New York: Tunde Olaniran plays Rough Trade. The multi-threat singer-songwriter, producer, choreographer, and activist—who is, in his own words, a miracle—makes music that redefines what it means to live in a queer black body that is often politicized before it’s humanized. He recently described his shows as equal parts performance, spell, and ritual. Photograph by Lawrence Agyei for TNY.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This week, @paridukovic is taking over our photo department’s account to share works he has made for our magazine. He writes that this image, taken for Janet Malcolm’s Profile of the concert pianist @yujawang.official, wasn’t an easy task compositionally: “I had to think about how to introduce the piano in the frame in a unique way and capture the energy that Yuja Wang brings when she plays.” Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by Jack Ziegler, from 1985. #TNYcartoons

“We tried to be really evil. We dropped ’ludes. We dropped anyone who had the temerity to fall in love with us,” Hilton Als wrote, in 1996. This week, we’ve opened the archive to share some of our favorite New York stories, including his chronicle of early-eighties clubbing, when he got to know the city’s d.j.s and even tried his hand at d.j.’ing himself. Read it at the link in our bio. Photograph by Michel Delsol.
A cartoon by Charles Barsotti, from 2006. #TNYcartoons

“Whatever white people do not know about Negroes reveals, precisely and inexorably, what they do not know about themselves,” James Baldwin wrote, in "Letter from a Region in My Mind.” This week, we’ve opened the archive to share some of our favorite New York stories, including his 1962 essay on growing up in Harlem, deciding to join a church, and serving as a minister. Read it at the link in our bio. Photograph by Richard Avedon/© the Richard Avedon Foundation.

Our Cyber Week sale is here! Save 50%. Plus, get a free tote. International offers with the tote are available for as low as $6. Click the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week, we've reprinted one of our covers for the first time: "New York Lights Up," by Matías Santoyo, originally graced our April 2, 1927 issue. #TNYcovers

At Misi, the new Italian restaurant from the beloved chef Missy Robbins, half the menu is devoted to pasta: ten different shapes, all made in-house, including fettuccine, chickpea pappardelle, and tortelli. But there are also things other than pasta on offer. Vegetable-focussed appetizers include marinated shishito and Jimmy Nardello peppers, for layering on crusty toast with thickly squiggled ricotta that’s been whipped until it’s as densely creamy as labneh. Click the link in our bio for @hannahgoldfield’s review. Photographs by @erichelgas for TNY.
A cartoon by @lianafinck. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. Click the link in our bio for more Black Friday #TNYcartoons.

Heading into the melee that is #BlackFriday shopping? First, take some advice from a professional. Betty Halbreich dressed Bergdorf Goodman customers for more than forty years—Meryl Streep, Mia Farrow, and Liza Minnelli among them. Click the link in our bio to read Judith Thurman's 2012 Profile of the legendary personal shopper. Photograph by Ruven Afanador.
A cartoon by Mick Stevens. #TNYcartoons
While you’re waiting for the turkey to roast, enjoy this slideshow of #Thanksgiving covers from over the years. Tell us which one is your favorite in the comments. #TNYcovers
Some ideas for a calm and collected Thanksgiving, as drawn by @eflakeagogo.
A cartoon by Edward Frascino, from 1999. #TNYcartoons

When Nirvana released its 1991 album, “Nevermind,” everything changed. Nobody—not the band’s label, its management, or its members—was prepared for the velocity of the ascent. Kurt Cobain started to be called the voice of Generation X, and his resistance to the tag merely entrenched it further. People gravitated toward his persona because it didn’t seem like one—but, of course, it was a persona—just a more thoughtful, conflicted, and unguarded one than we're used to seeing. Click the link in our bio to read @huahsu on how the album made him wonder how an artist could work both inside and outside the system.
A cartoon by Mick Stevens and Jenny Allen. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Today in New York: Lileana Blain-Cruz’s revival of Lynn Nottage’s 2004 play, “Fabulation, or The Re-Education of Undine,” starts previews at Pershing Square Signature Center. Cherise Boothe stars as a high-powered publicist who winds up back in the Brooklyn projects where she grew up—and pregnant—after her husband makes off with all her money. Photograph by @mirandabarnes for TNY.
This week's cover, "Thankfulness," by @rozchast. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @lianafinck. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

No matter how you feel about eating fish, eating at Zauo is a disaster. The Japanese novelty chain encourages diners to catch what they’ll eat, using small fishing rods and nets. Every time someone catches a fish, employees are required to cheer, chant, and strike a taiko drum, resulting in an endless dystopian cacophony. But the restaurant’s greatest offense is the food. Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield’s review. Photographs by @davidwilliamsphoto for TNY.
The people Facebook thinks you should add as “friends,” by @phil_mcandrew.
A cartoon by Michael Maslin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Shaming people who live in poverty is an old reflex in America, but what Brenda Ann Kenneally has done in her sprawling chronicle of life in Troy, New York, makes it impossible to treat her subjects with contempt. She reminds us that the fault lines of capitalism are everywhere within our nation, running through the very foundation we keep building upon. Click the link in our bio to read Adrian Nicole LeBlanc on Kenneally’s “Upstate Girls.” Photograph by @alittlecreativeclassinc.

California is currently ablaze, after a record hot summer and a dry fall set the stage for the most destructive fires in the state’s history. Because of extreme weather—including wildfires, heat waves, and rising sea levels—large tracts of the earth are at risk of becoming uninhabitable. But the fossil-fuel industry continues its assault on the facts. Click the link in our bio to read Bill McKibben on our shrinking planet. Photograph by @kevincooley_ for TNY.
A cartoon by @rozchast. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Are your snow shovels ready? A cover, from 1972, by Arthur Getz. #TNYcovers

Today in New York: The composer Du Yun, who won a Pulitzer Prize for her opera “Angel’s Bone” last year, joins the International Contemporary Ensemble—she was a founding member—to present “LEGO.” In it, a selection of instrumental works from the past two decades, is reconfigured as an interlocking whole. Photograph by @andreaslaszlokonrath for TNY.
A cartoon by David Sipress. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Last week, members of the migrant caravan, which now consists of nearly five thousand people, met to choose a final destination for the group. Tijuana was considered the safest possibility—the route skirts territory controlled by violent cartels—but it was also the farthest away. And because C.B.P. agents have, for months, been turning away asylum seekers at official ports of entry, the city itself poses a number of dangers. “There are over a thousand asylum seekers waiting at the port of entry right now,” the director of the Border Rights Project at Al Otro Lado said. “When the caravan arrives, we’re going to be in a real crisis.” Click the link in our bio to read @jonathanblitzer on the manufactured crisis at the U.S. border. Photograph by @adrianazehbrauskas for TNY.

This week, the artist @reneecoxstudio is taking over our photo department’s account to share work from her twenty-five-year career, including “River Queen,” from 2004. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by @pia.guerra. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In the fall of 2017, @abstractsunday spent four days in Los Angeles, waiting to meet the artist David Hockney, and wandering around the city, making sketches. The finished drawings, which tell the story of the trip, will be on view at the ZieherSmith gallery, in Chelsea, from today through December 21st. Click the link in our bio to see more.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Trends in art come and go like the weather. But the several that Andy Warhol initiated six decades ago constitute a climate unabated by time. In a splendid, though inevitably too small, retrospective, now at the Whitney, almost everything on display feels definitively new, and much of it is, as we know, incredibly expensive. Click the link in our bio to read Peter Schjeldahl’s review. Image courtesy the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts, Inc./ARS.

Deval Patrick’s political career has so far consisted only of his two successful races for governor of Massachusetts. Compared with Joe Biden and Elizabeth Warren, he is practically a nobody. But, if he decides to run in 2020, he would enter the Presidential race with one significant distinction: he is a kind of political heir to Barack Obama, and enjoys broad support from people close to the former President. Click the link in our bio to read Jeffrey Toobin’s Profile of the former governor and managing director at Bain Capital. Photograph by @unamericain.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. #TNYcartoons

To get recipes for his new Long Island City restaurant, Adda, the chef Chintan Pandya quizzed food-stall operators in Delhi. The resulting menu is full of unpretentious, homey food that “Indian people actually eat,” his parnter Roni Mazumdar says, including street-food snacks, curries, rice, and meat, cheese, and vegetables cooked in a tandoor oven. Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield's full review. Photographs by @zaczavv for TNY.

In 2000, when the photographer Josephine Sittenfeld was a junior at Princeton, she captured portraits of her classmates on medium-format film and, after exhibiting the prints, consigned them to a closet in her parents’ home. At her fifteen-year college reunion, she decided to re-create the same shots in present day. “Reunion,” the result of that labor, is a series of moody, satisfying diptychs that fast-forward life’s natural transformations. Click the link in our bio to see more before-and-after shots. Photographs by @josittenfeld.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan. #TNYcartoons

A retrospective of Terence Nance's work, at BAM, this month, will include the filmmaker's first feature, “An Oversimplification of Her Beauty,” as well as his new six-part HBO series, “Random Acts of Flyness," a furiously imaginative, pain-filled yet jubilant vision of black people’s social and inner lives amid American racial and gender prejudices. The series will also include short films from his collaborators Nuotama Frances Bodomo and Mariama Diallo. See it from November 12th to 15th. Photograph by @lindsayellary for TNY.
An early look at next week's cover, “Welcome to Congress,” by Barry Blitt. #TNYcovers
Warning signs for your new relationship, explained by @juliaedelman_ and @drawingolive.

For decades, Vivian Maier supported herself as a nanny in the wealthy enclaves of Chicago. But her real work was roaming the streets with her camera, capturing images of sublime spontaneity, wit, and compositional savvy. When pressed about her occupation by a man she once knew, she said, “I am sort of a spy.” All the best street photographers are. Click the link in our bio to see more of her work in color, which is finally getting its turn in the limelight with a new book and exhibition at Howard Greenberg Gallery. Photographs by Vivian Maier/Courtesy the Estate of Vivian Maier and @howardgreenberggallery.
A cartoon by @larskenseth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This week, @huiuh_ is taking over our photo department's account to share his work. "I used to be a very sensitive and shy person. Photography has become a vehicle for me to explore the world through the camera and has encouraged me to become more open to my surroundings," he writes. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.

Stacey Abrams will not concede the Georgia governor's race to her Republican opponent, Brian Kemp. “Voices remain to be heard,” she told the crowd in a downtown Atlanta hotel ballroom last night. “Across our state, folks are opening up the dreams of voters in absentee ballots, and . . . I can promise you tonight we’ll make sure every vote is counted.” Click the link in our bio to read Charles Bethea on the scene at her party. Photographs by @landonnordeman for TNY.
A cartoon by Paul Noth, from 2016.

Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has become the youngest woman ever elected to Congress. Earlier this year, the 29-year-old won New York’s Democratic primary for the Fourteenth Congressional District, defeating the incumbent, Joseph Crowley. Click the link in our bio to David Remnick on her historic primary upset. Photograph by @markpetersonpixs/Redux for TNY.

Andrew Gillum, one of the most talked-about candidates in the midterms, voted with his children today, in Tallahassee. While we wait to see if he is elected governor of Florida, and whether the Democrats take back the House, stay up to date with our #ElectionDay coverage on the Current at the link in our bio. Photograph by @markpetersonpixs/Redux for TNY.
A cartoon by @daveostowdraws. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

@charlotteparler remembered to take her New Yorker tote along to the polls on #ElectionDay. Will you vote today? Share your favorite magazine moments with #newyorkerinthewild and we might regram you. Photograph by Wang Ying/Xinhua/Getty.
For the midterms, a cover, from 1960, by Charles Martin. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @mortgerberg. #TNYcartoons

After several election cycles where targeted analytics and social media dominated discussions of strategy, Beto O’Rourke’s U.S. Senate campaign is a return to the belief that face-to-face interaction is what motivates voters the most. All over Texas, people have offered their living rooms, home offices, bars, garages, restaurant patios, or breweries as spaces for neighborhood volunteers to gather for outreach efforts. Click the link in our bio to see more from over 700 pop-up campaign offices getting out the vote for Beto. Photographs by @bill_mccullough.
This week's cover, “Central Park Row,” by Eric Drooker. #TNYcovers

Saint Julivert Fisherie, a new restaurant in Cobble Hill, shares in the small-plate tradition to excellent effect, offering an impressive gamut of exciting bites. The menu is divided into dishes served chilled—like raw-scallop tacos—and hot, like a skate wing finished with butter, fried garlic, and parsley. The bar serves wines from coastal vineyards and cocktails like ti’ punch, a Caribbean standard made here with rum, gomme syrup, and lime. Click the link in our bio for @hannahgoldfield’s review. Photographs by @kyokopajama for TNY.
A cartoon by @farleykatz. #TNYcartoons

The late photographer Ara Güler, who was affectionately known as the Eye of Istanbul, created images that interpreted Turkey for a Western audience without ever exploiting its people. His poignant, majestic archive preserves a vision of the country that began to vanish early in his lifetime. Click the link in our bio to see more of his work. Photograph by Ara Güler/Magnum.

“The good news,” President Barack Obama said, on Friday, in Atlanta, “is in four days you can reject bad politics.” He appeared at the Forbes Arena, at Morehouse, a historically black college, to stump for Stacey Abrams, the Democrat vying to become Georgia’s next governor. “You can be a check on bad behavior. You can choose a bigger, more prosperous, more generous vision of America,” he added. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photographs by @landonnordeman for TNY.

All of Bruce Nauman’s works are partly—or largely—ordeals for viewers. You may ask: what does it take to tolerate, much less to esteem, such art? A commitment equalling that of the artist—making of the show an adventure that is as much ethical as it is aesthetic.
