Click the link in our bio to read Peter Schjeldahl on a new retrospective of Nauman’s work, now on display at @themuseumofmodernart and @momaps1. Courtesy Museum Associates/LACMA © 2018 Bruce Nauman/Artists Rights Society.
A cartoon by Robert Leighton. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by @maddiedai. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
It's drunk bath season! By @cartoonsbyhilary.

In the race for Senate in Texas, Beto O’Rourke has been shuttling across the state in a Dodge Grand Caravan, taking on both Ted Cruz and President Trump. He may be a nationally viable candidate, have raised $38 million dollars in the last quarter of the campaign, and have run one of the largest grassroots campaigns the state has ever seen. But this is still Texas, which hasn’t elected a Democratic senator since 1988. Click the link in our bio to read Emily Witt’s dispatch. Photograph by Bill McCullough for TNY.

The south-central Great Plains is a part of the world where extreme weather hangs out. When the prairie is tinder-dry and winds blow at fifty-plus miles an hour, conditions are perfect for wildfires. A megafire is considered to be one that burns more than 100,000 acres. The one that began on March 6th, 2017, burned a total of almost 2,000,000 acres. Click the link in our bio to read Ian Frazier on how it was eventually put out. Photograph by Larry Schwarm.

The Morgan Library & Museum celebrates the legacy of Mary Shelley and her monster in the exhibition “It’s Alive!,” co-organized with @nypl. Pages of the original “Frankenstein” manuscript appear with memorabilia including a restoration of the iconic silver-streaked wig worn by Elsa Lanchester in the 1936 movie “The Bride of Frankenstein.” See it through January 27th. Photograph by @michael_marcelle for TNY.
A cartoon by Frank Cotham. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Nearly three years after the polar explorer Henry Worsley died attempting to cross Antarctica alone, his close friend Louis Rudd plans to honor his memory by embarking on solo expedition of his own. As soon as the weather permits, Rudd will fly to a starting point near the Weddell Sea. Click the link in our bio to read David Grann on the quest to retrace the Antarctic journey of Henry Worsley. Photograph by @renemariakoster.

From the perspective of today’s young hip-hop fan, the most unfathomable aspect of the past might be that fans were once starved for photographs of their favorite artists. Vikki Tobak’s new photography book "Contact High," tells the history of how hip-hop first learned to pose in front of the camera. Click the link in our bio for a glimpse into a time when nobody quite knew where hip-hop could go. Photograph by @bcafricanus.
For when a simple spell won't cut it. By @heatherlow_c.

This week, @levimandel is taking over our photo department's account to share images of his favorite season, autumn, focusing on the quiet, colorful, often surreal moments that he finds so alluring. Follow @newyorkerphoto for more.
A cartoon by @paulnoth. #TNYcartoons

No matter what awful news the world may bring, come Halloween, it’s time for a few hours of escapism. Here is a selection of our Halloween covers featuring all kinds of monsters, real and imagined. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @pia.guerra. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

As the migrant caravan advanced inside the Mexican state of Oaxaca this week, the group’s size, at almost 5,000 people, seemed to overwhelm each new locale. In Santiago Niltepec, a village of only 4,000 residents, people wrestled with competing impulses: to help the migrants or recoil from them. Still many people quietly managed to donate mounds of food and clothing. The caravan entered town to find giant grills smoking with chicken for lunch. Click the link in our bio to read @jonathanblitzer’s dispatch from Mexico. Photographs by @adrianazehbrauskas for TNY.

Today in New York: “The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui” starts previews at Classic Stage Company. In Bertolt Brecht’s allegory of Hitler’s ascent, written in 1941 and first performed in 1958, Raúl Esparza plays a nineteen-thirties Chicago gangster who wrests control of the cauliflower trade. Photograph by @jeffbrownjeffbrown for TNY.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week's cover, "Boo!," by @markulriksenart.

“My opponent, Becky Corbin, is the queen of special interests,” Danielle Friel Otten says. “I am the queen of parking tickets.” The forty-one-year-old aspiring politician decided to run for the Pennsylvania Assembly only after becoming concerned about the Mariner East pipeline project. Unlike typical suburban lines, which carry gas to heat people’s home, this pipeline, when completed, will carry highly explosive chemicals 350 miles from the Marcellus shale gas fields to a port in Philadelphia. Click the link in our bio to read Eliza Griswold on whether the fight against it can turn a heavily conservative region blue. Photograph by @michellegustafson for TNY.
A cartoon by @bob_eckstein. #TNYcartoons
We all have our thing, right? Autumn’s top fetishists, as drawn by @daveostowdraws.
A cartoon by @margaret__elisabeth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Berthe Morisot is not so much underrated in standard art history as not rated at all against the big guns of Impressionism: Manet, Degas, Renoir, and Monet, each of whom was a close friend and admiring colleague of hers. Today, she’s the most interesting artist of her generation, for feats of form and depths of meaning that were still developing when she died. She is due for full-blown fame. Click the link in our bio to read Peter Schjeldahl’s review of a breathtaking retrospective of her work, now at the Barnes Foundation, in Philadelphia. Image courtesy Art Institute of Chicago.

Janelle Monáe stopped by our offices to talk to David Remnick, the editor of the New Yorker, about her latest album, “Dirty Computer.” (Despite the title, it’s not at all science fiction.) Listen to their conversation on The New Yorker Radio Hour, at the link in our bio. Photograph by @melwelikson.
A cartoon by Seth Fleishman. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The feeling you get when you listen to Robyn—the instant sense of obliteration in the surge of synth and strings—is almost too powerful. The music of the Swedish pop star is something like a club drug: a substance that drastically increases your likelihood of dancing and crying simultaneously. When “Honey,” the title track from Robyn’s long-awaited new album, was released, at the end of September, @jiatortellini found herself taking hour-long walks around Brooklyn at midnight just so that she could listen to it over and over. Click the link in our bio to read about the singer’s new album. Photograph by @Mark_Peckmezian.

The idea that classical sculpture was all white “is the most common misconception about Western aesthetics in the history of Western art,” the professor Mark Abbe says. Greek and Roman statues were often painted with vibrant hair colors and skin tones. And some scholars are now re-creating them in plaster, painted with an approximation of their original hues. Click the link in our bio to read Margaret Talbot on the myth of whiteness in classical sculpture. Photograph by Mark Peckmezian for TNY.
A cartoon by @christopherweyant, from 2010. #TNYcartoons
Halloween costumes you’re definitely going to need to take time to explain, by @j.a.k._ and @phil_mcandrew.

This week, @cianobasmith is taking over our photo department’s account to share images from his latest body of work, “Shanzhai.” The series looks at the phenomenon of Chinese copycat architecture, like that in Shanxia Zhang Venice Town, in the wider context of globalization. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by @joedator. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Five years ago, Abbie Arevalo-Herrera and her young daughter fled Honduras after her ex-husband had threatened to kill her. They entered the U.S. hoping to apply for asylum but—due to a controversial D.H.S. practice that involves giving immigrants a “Notice to Appear” in court that bears no date or time, then trying them in absentia—never appeared before an immigration judge. Now Arevalo-Herrera fears that if she is deported, she risks further assaults from her ex-husband. “It’s so sad to come here to seek refuge, and we can’t find it,” she says. Click the link in our bio to read her story. Photograph by Matt Eich for TNY.

The artist Kehinde Wiley describes his work as a type of self-portraiture. “It’s about looking at people who happen to look like me,” he says. At the 2018 New Yorker Festival, he spoke with Vinson Cunningham about what it was like to paint President Obama, when he knew he wanted to become a portraitist, and how he casts his paintings. Click the link in our bio to read the interview. Photograph by Tony Powell.
A cartoon by @wardsutton. #TNYcartoons

The Latinx transgender phenom Martine Gutierrez’s new project “Indigenous Woman” centers on the September issue of a fictional fashion magazine so glossily convincing that you may try to subscribe. In addition to posing for the Vogue-worthy spreads, Gutierrez also took every picture, styled every outfit, and designed all the layouts. She has, in the most literal sense, made herself up. Click the link in our bio to see more of her work. Photographs by @martine.tv/Courtesy Ryan Lee Gallery.

“I am truly a moderate. To my core, I am a moderate,” the Missouri senator Claire McCaskill says. She is currently running for reëlection in a state that Donald Trump carried in 2016 by nineteen points. Her opponent, the Republican Josh Hawley, insists that she is on the far left. She insists, much more plausibly, that she is one of the few remaining centrists in Congress. Click the link in our bio to read about how the Missouri Senate race has become a test of whether a Democrat who doesn’t openly break ranks with the national party can survive in Trump country. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
@eflakeagogo gives "Patriot Act with Hasan Minhaj," a weekly show that premières on Netflix on October 28th, our signature cartoon treatment.
This week's cover, “Arthur Avenue,” by @jkroik. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Leo Cullum, from 2014. Follow @newyorkercartoons for #TNYcartoons
The freshest tinfoil hats for conspiracy-theorist fashionistas, as drawn by @marisaacocella.

Diana Tandia worked in fine dining for years before opening her unpolished, homey new counter-service restaurant in the West Village. At Berber Street Food, the menu is inspired by the various cuisines of Africa and its diaspora, and the food is made by Tandia and just one other chef. When something’s out for the day—like Calypso jerk-chicken wings with pineapple relish or accara made from black-eyed pea purée—it’s out. Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield’s review. Photographs by @lrnlncstr for TNY.
A cartoon by @caitlin.cass, from 2018. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons

Maira Kalman draws early women’s-rights activists, from Elizabeth Cady Stanton to Sojourner Truth, for her book with Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, “Bold & Brave: Ten Heroes Who Won Women the Right to Vote.” Kalman’s energetic hand brings to life stories of tenacity and resolve while Senator Gillibrand reminisces about her first female role models—her mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother—and challenges the new generation of young activists. Illustrations by @mairakalman.

If you look at many Fall 2018 fashions, you’ll find they have something in common: they look like things that Fran Drescher would have worn in the sitcom “The Nanny.” Think tight, leopard-print trenchcoats from Victoria Beckham; fuzzy, neon-green cropped sweaters from Balenciaga; and We11Done’s line of zebra-print micro-miniskirts. This resurgence of Fran Fine’s style is part of a larger wave of nineties nostalgia in the fashion world—but retains something different, a shorthand for a brash kind of femininity that commands respect without ever quite fitting in. Click the link in our bio to read @rachsyme on why Cardi B is the most obvious Fran Fine heir and what @officialfrandrescher is up to now. Photograph from CBS/Getty.
Which would you join? The best band names clipped from this week’s magazine: October 22nd Edition. By Edward Steed.

Today in New York: “Marnie” opens at the @metopera. In Nico Muhly and Nicholas Wright’s version of the Winston Graham novel, the eponymous fraudster maintains an array of dazzling alter egos, clothed by the costume designer Arianne Philips and voiced by her own personal chorus, her Shadows. Isabel Leonard, a mezzo-soprano who can veer from exuberance to exasperation in the blink of an eye, stars in the production. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The small show “Pontormo: Miraculous Encounters,” at the Morgan Library, centers on one of the damnedest great paintings of all time: Jacopo Pontormo’s “Visitation,” on loan from a church near Florence. It portrays the young, pregnant Virgin Mary graciously greeting her elder, Elizabeth, who is also pregnant (with John the Baptist), as two saints gaze out from behind them. The lovely anecdote nests in a riot of raiment in colors rarely seen together: dark olive, pinks dreaming of magenta, cerulean blue with aqua on its mind, an electric mint green, violent orange, and a creamy white that, in shadow, shifts to sage. See it through January 6th. Photograph courtesy Pieve dei Santi Michele e Francesco, Carmignano.
Water towers that could hold our tears, as drawn by @sranso.
A cartoon by @trferry. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Donald Trump, Self-Made Billionaire: The Early Years. By Barry Blitt.

This week, @shadowontherun is taking over our photo department’s account to share pictures inspired by otherworldly geothermal active areas, like this one, taken on White Island, an andesite stratovolcano located thirty miles off the main coast of New Zealand. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by @sofiawarrenart. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons. 🍏

In its staging, its casting, and its musical arrangements, Daniel Fish’s vivid, stripped-down revival of “Oklahoma!” emphasizes realism to offer audiences a new vision of themselves. Seventy-five years ago, when the original made its Broadway début, we were at war with foreign powers; now the enemy is within. Click the link in our bio to read @asarahlarson’s review. Photograph by @stefanruizphoto for TNY.

“There’s a kind of freedom in being on the West Coast, as if your parents aren’t around,” Janet Delaney says. She came to San Francisco for the Summer of Love and, by the 1980s, was living in the Mission District, photographing moments of quiet revelation in the streets. Her images, collected in the new book “Public Matters,” show the last moment when American neighborhoods were the essential nodes of a true public culture. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @janet_delaney/Courtesy Euqinom Gallery.
A cartoon by @pia.guerra. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week's cover, “Fat Cats,” by @richardmcguirehere. #TNYcovers

We asked our writers to look back on a year of #MeToo in order to anticipate what could—or should—come next. Click the link in our bio to read @helenr on combatting sexual harassment in the restaurant industry. Illustration by @elenikalorkoti.

At one time, the newly reopened Four Seasons might have seemed romantically retro, even thrilling. Now it comes off as dark and sad, the power lunch diminished by abuse of power. The food, never the establishment’s greatest draw, is astonishingly high priced. A single if substantial crab cake, dressed with mustard sauce and kale, costs sixty-two dollars. But the most popular item seems still to be a tower of cotton candy served on a silver platter, reserved for guests celebrating special occasions. Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield's review. Photographs by @kristaschlueter for TNY.
Everyone knows that denim is trending this fall. And it’s not limited to pants, tops, and jackets. By @kaydenhines and @clairegfriedman.

We asked our writers to look back on a year of #MeToo in order to anticipate what could—or should—come next. Click the link in our bio to read @doreenstfelix on the need for a more inclusive language of abuse and victimhood. Illustration by @jningwong.

Luca Guadagnino recalls realizing that “Call Me by Your Name” would be a hit when his fifteen-year-old niece, who’d never seemed remotely interested in his work, texted to say that she and her friends were dying to see it. He doesn’t expect his new feature, out at the end of this month, to have the same effect. “Suspiria” is very much a horror film: flesh is ripped; bones are broken; heads explode. Guadagnino calls it the most personal movie that he has made. Click the link in our bio to read Nathan Heller on the Italian director. Photograph by Alex Majoli/Magnum for TNY.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

One year ago, this week, we published @ronanfarrow’s exposé on the sexual assault allegations against Harvey Weinstein. To mark the date, we asked our writers to look back on a year of #MeToo. Click the link in our bio to read Masha Gessen on what a post-#MeToo world could look like in the United States. Illustration by @jningwong.
A cartoon by @christopherweyant. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Helen, a smart, cheerful five-year-old from Honduras, entered the U.S. with her grandmother after the Trump Administration announced that it would halt its family-separation policy. Yet she was taken away from her family and placed in a shelter contracted to house unaccompanied minors. According to the Flores settlement, Helen should have been brought before a judge, but, on a form that she filled out with assistance from officials, she waived that right. Her story illustrates the third stage of the family-separation crisis—one in which separations are done quietly, and in which reunifications can be mysteriously stymied. Click the link in our bio to read about how Helen was eventually reunited with her family. Photograph Courtesy LUPE.

We asked our writers to look back on a year of #MeToo in order to anticipate what could—or should—come next. Click the link in our bio to read @allysonhobbs77 on the legacy of black women's testimonies. Illustration by @elenikalorkoti.
A cartoon by @maddiedai. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Today in New York: The Zimbabwean-born choreographer @norachipaumire premières her three-part work “#PUNK 100% POP*NIGGA” at @thekitchen_nyc. The rock star of dance will channel a different musical hero in each fifty-minute section: Patti Smith, Grace Jones, and the Congolese barrier breaker Rit Nzele. Photograph by @mamadivisuals for TNY.
A cartoon by @maddiedai, from 2017. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

One year ago, today, we published @ronanfarrow’s exposé on the allegations of rape, sexual assault, and sexual harassment against Harvey Weinstein. Since then, the #MeToo movement has galvanized people across the country and around the world. We asked our writers to look back on the movement so far in order to anticipate what could—or should—come next. Over the next five days, we’ll be sharing what they have to say. Click the link in our bio to read @jiatortellini on the backlash against #MeToo. Illustration by @lorrainesorlet.
Pillocars, by Bruce McCall.
A cartoon by @sofiawarrenart. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This week, @smetana_cecile is taking over our photo department's account to share images from an ongoing personal project called “Virgin Soil.” The first portrait of the series is of her twin brothers at the age of fourteen, shot on the island of Funen, in Denmark, right before crashing the car down into a hole on the side of the road. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Despite the current political climate, our guests at the New Yorker Festival remained optimistic about the power of an informed citizenry. Photographs by Getty Images for TNY.
All-purpose souvenir tees for the generic traveller, as drawn by @unnecessaryobservations.
This week's cover, “Reading Group,” by J. J. Sempé. #TNYcovers

At his unusually beautiful East Village restaurant, Hunan Slurp, the chef Chao Wang serves interpretations of the food he grew up eating in China’s Hunan Province. Mifen, or rice noodles, are the specialty here, in soups that are as carefully composed as oil paintings—and meant to be slurped. Click the link in our bio for @hannahgoldfield’s review. Photographs by @lrnlncstr for TNY.
A cartoon by Zachary Kanin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
The New Yorker Festival is in full swing this weekend! Tickets to some of tomorrow's events are still available, at the link in our bio. Photographs by Getty Images for TNY.
A cartoon by Barry Blitt. #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by Roz Chast. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Despite the renegade atmosphere of the historic Ninth Street Show, held in 1951, there was some initial discussion of whether to include women in the exhibition. Eventually, the jury selected eleven women, and sixty-one men, to represent the creatively rich (if otherwise impoverished) new downtown art world. Three of them were Joan Mitchell, Helen Frankenthaler, and Grace Hartigan. Click the link in our bio to read about how they went on to have international careers, their work collected by major museums and subject to ever-expanding bibliographies. Photograph by Burt Glinn/Magnum.
A cartoon by @joedator. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In her new collection, "Wood River Blue Pool," the photographer Jo Ann Walters shows us her subjects in sunlight, mostly outdoors but in domestic landscapes—front and back yards, gardens, suburban sidewalks and parks—where the chaos of nature is given strict parameters. The women and children, likewise, are wild but contained. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @joannwalters.

Today in New York: “Art of Native America: The Charles and Valerie Diker Collection” opens in the American Wing of the @metmuseum. Among the 116 items on view, representing fifty indigenous cultures, is a ceremonial dance object, made of painted wood, fibre, and feathers, by a Yup’ik artist in Alaska at the turn of the twentieth century. Photograph by @erichelgas for TNY.
A cartoon by @pia.guerra. #TNYcartoons
If you love watching @joescarborough and @mikabrzezinski in the morning, then you won’t want to miss them tomorrow night, at the New Yorker Festival. Click the link in our bio for tickets.

In an era when anyone can art-direct his or her home into an object of design envy, Wendy Goodman is a rarefied gatekeeper. Her stamp of approval is highly coveted, and her new book catalogues her best offerings—among them the homes of Valentino Garavani, Vito Schnabel, Donatella Versace, Diana Vreeland, Tina Turner, and Whoopi Goldberg—from the past three decades. Click the link in our bio for Carrie Battan’s review of “May I Come In?” Photograph by @thomasloof.
A cartoon by Seth Fleishman. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

On her new album, “Wanderer,” Cat Power connects to a lineage of American searchers, from the itinerant bluesmen of the prewar Delta to drifting troubadours, all restless spirits who took off with only their songs to sustain them. Her interest in soul and blues idioms remains, but she has never sounded more like a folksinger. Click the link in our bio for @amandapetrusich’s review. Photograph by @inezandvinoodh for TNY.
Kanye and Kavanaugh rep some favorite beverages. A cartoon by Barry Blitt. #TNYcartoons.
Distract her with "The New Yorker Encyclopedia of Cartoons." Click the link in our bio to order it today.

Greta Thunberg has been protesting on the steps of Sweden’s parliament building for more than a month. The fifteen-year-old is demanding that the government undertake a radical response to climate change. But, because she has also been diagnosed with autism and A.D.H.D., her protest serves a dual purpose. It not only calls attention to climate policy, as she intended, but it also showcases the political potential of neurological difference. Click the link in our bio to read Masha Gessen on the young climate activist. Photograph by Anders Hellberg.

Ruth Bader Ginsburg often waxes nostalgic about her confirmation hearings, as she did this September, when, regretting the partisan furor over Brett Kavanaugh—even before Christine Blasey Ford came forward—she said, “The way it was was right; the way it is is wrong.” The second of those statements is undeniably and painfully true, but the first flattens the past. In 1993 the Senate voted to confirm her ninety-six to three, with one abstention. But the idea that her appointment was uncontroversial is almost entirely a myth. Click the link in our bio to read Jill Lepore on Ginsburg's unlikely path to the Supreme Court. Photograph by @irvingpennphotography/© @condenast.
Which snack are you? Illustrations by Eugenia Viti.

Oxomoco, a new Mexican restaurant in Greenpoint, serves food that’s at once on-the-nose hipster bait and respectful of traditional ingredients and techniques—plus it’s delicious. The “snacks” section of the menu includes smoked mango sprinkled with chili and lime, red-skinned peanuts with garlic and chili, and popcorn with butter, lime, and chili. Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield’s review. Photographs by @erichelgas for TNY.
A cartoon by @drewpanckeri. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
@eflakeagogo answers her daughter’s big questions (or at least tries to).

When Bev Grant was twenty-six, she joined hundreds of feminist activists in Atlantic City to protest the Miss America pageant. Her photos of the action, which took place fifty years ago this month, have remained unknown, many of them never even developed. Now they’re among the images on show in Grant’s first-ever exhibition, taking place at Cay Sophie Rabinowitz’s East Village project space, Osmos. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photographs by Bev Grant/Courtesy Osmos.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts. #TNYcartoons.
An early look at next week's cover, “Unheard,” by @anajuan_illustrator. #TNYcovers

For Tracy K. Smith, the current U.S. Poet Laureate, writing about desire is a way of being heard in a world where it’s still necessary to say, as a black woman on “Random Acts of Flyness” recently did, “I only got one body. And I got plans for it.” She is a storyteller who loves to explore how the body can respond to a lover, to family, to history. Click the link in our bio to read @hilton.als on Smith’s poetry. Photograph by @micaiahcarter for TNY.

Judge Brett Kavanaugh is almost certainly going to be appointed the next member of the Supreme Court of the United States. Whatever Christine Blasey Ford said in her testimony on Thursday, and whatever Kavanaugh said in his, and however credible and convincing either one seemed, none of it was going to affect this virtual inevitability. At the time of this writing, composed in the eighth hour of the grotesque historic activity happening in the Capitol Hill chamber, it should be as plain as day that what we witnessed was the patriarchy testing how far its politics of resentment can go. And there is no limit. Click the link in our bio to read Doreen St. Félix on how the Ford-Kavanaugh hearings will be remembered as a grotesque display of patriarchal resentment. Photograph by @melinamara/Getty.

Christine Blasey Ford’s opening statement, at the Senate Judiciary Committee’s Kavanaugh-Ford hearing, was a reminder of how serious her allegation against Brett Kavanaugh is, how hard and precise. Click the link in our bio to follow our live coverage of the hearing, or to watch the live stream. Photograph by @erinschaff/Getty.

"People came after me, but they didn’t stop me," Jane Fonda says. At eighty, the original celebrity activist is still speaking out, talking to voters, and supporting the #MeToo movement. Click the link in our bio to read her interview with Michael Schulman. Photograph by @christophergriffithstudio for TNY.
They think they're people! By @davidferriercartoons.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
On October 6th, the “Random Acts of Flyness” creator Terence Nance will talk with Jelani Cobb at the New Yorker Festival. Click the link in our bio for tickets.

When Seth Murrell was four, he was placed in a statewide network of Georgia schools for students with disabilities—called GNETS. His new teacher was not certified to teach elementary school and didn't understand why Seth, who was eventually diagnosed with autism, couldn’t return to his neighborhood school, where there were more qualified teachers. “I just felt like these students, especially the black boys, were put there, basically, because they intimidated their teachers,” the teacher says. Click the link in our bio to read Rachel Aviv on how GNETS became a method of resegregating Georgia’s schools. Photograph by LaToya Ruby Frazier for TNY.

In “Self Portrait with Fried Eggs,” from 1996, Sarah Lucas sits in an armchair, dressed in a T-shirt and ripped jeans. Laid on her chest are two fried eggs, resembling cartoonish breasts, which undermine the self-assurance of her posture with surreal comedy and serve as a reminder of the ways in which women’s bodies are so often offered up for others’ consumption. Like so much of her bawdy, witty work, the photograph is ironically self-deflating, but nonetheless riven with a sense of purpose. Click the link in our bio to see more of the self-portraits from Lucas’s first solo retrospective, which opens this month, at the New Museum. Photograph by Sarah Lucas/Courtesy Sadie Coles HQ.
A cartoon by Teresa Burns Parkhurst. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week's cover, “Lower East Side,” by @marcellus_hall. #TNYcovers

Senate Democrats are investigating a new allegation of sexual misconduct against Brett Kavanaugh. The claim dates to the 1983-84 academic school year, when Kavanaugh was a freshman at Yale University. The woman at the center of the story, Deborah Ramirez, who is fifty-three, attended Yale with Kavanaugh, where she studied sociology and psychology. Ramirez said that witnessing the attempts to discredit Christine Blasey Ford had made her frightened to share her own story, which she knew would be attacked due to the gaps in her memory and her level of inebriation at the time. “I’m afraid how this will all come back on me,” she said. In a statement, Kavanaugh denied the allegation. Click the link in our bio to read the story. Photograph by @benjaminras for TNY.

There is a fever-dream urgency to the self-portraits in the photographer Zanele Muholi’s series, “Somnyama Ngonyama” (which means “Hail the Dark Lioness” in Zulu). In it, she wrests her identity from every gaze except for her own. Click the link in our bio to see more of her work. Photograph by @muholizanele / Courtesy Yancey Richardson Gallery.
A cartoon by @steinbergdrawscartoons. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Juul’s new adult-focussed marketing ploys, by @lila__ash.

At @Mayanoki, in the East Village, all the seafood served is considered sustainable, and much of it is local. The restaurant’s chef, Jeff Miller, cures the fillets of mackerel from Green Harbor, Massachusetts, in salt and sugar, torches them until they curl up, then fits each around a mound of rice seasoned with vinegar made from aged sake solids. Still translucent, they retain a bit of crunch and a satisfying sweetness that plays perfect foil to a glossy swipe of funky shrimp-head oil and a wispy tangle of fried shallots. Click the link in our bio for more about this eight-seat sushi bar. Photograph by Zachary Zavislak for TNY.
A cartoon by Mick Stevens, from 2011. #TNYcartoons

Last week, the photographer @luisalbertorodriguezstudio shared images from his series “Spectacular Home,” on our photo department's account. The photos were taken between his ancestral home in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
Beyond mayochup: the next generation of condiment mashups, by @eflakeagogo.

A city, the Japanese photographer Naoya Hatakeyama reminds us, is just a product of human intervention, no more permanent than the lime hills it came from. Seeing that construction in its totality, in Hatakeyama’s photographs, forces us to experience, as he puts it, a simultaneous “fear and admiration for the world of things.” Click the link in our bio to see more of his work. Photographs courtesy Aperture / Minneapolis Institute of Art.
A cartoon by @sofiawarrenart. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by @drewdernavich. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

@iamruthecarter’s costumes have captured a generation negotiating a path between materialism and political consciousness. The instinct in theatre costuming is to “preserve, preserve, preserve,” Carter said. Not so in film, and especially not in the indies that she worked on in the eighties and nineties. Here, from Steven Spielberg’s “Amistad,” are two of Queen Isabella’s dresses, and the clothes that the slave-revolt leader Joseph Cinqué wears during his Supreme Court trial. Click the link in our bio to read @doreenstfelix on Carter’s work. Photograph by @awolerizku.

To shoot @iamruthecarter's costumes, which here include both originals and reproductions, the photographer Awol Erizku brought with him items from his personal collection, along with flowers and a parrot. This photograph features a pair of Nike Air Revolutions like the ones worn by Radio Raheem in “Do the Right Thing”; purses and starburst earrings for Coretta Scott King, in “Selma”; and Tina Turner’s pumps, from “What’s Love Got to Do with It.” Photograph by @awolerizku.

While living in Los Angeles, the costume designer @iamruthecarter met a young filmmaker named Spike Lee. In 1987, @officialspikelee gave Carter her first film job, on his feature “School Daze.” She has worked with him on fourteen films, including “Do the Right Thing.” Her costumes—high-tops, jerseys, graphic tees, Afrocentric accessories—captured a generation negotiating a path between materialism and political consciousness. Photograph by @awolerizku.

Throughout her long career, the costume designer @iamruthecarter has created visions of black identity, past and future. Her achievement is rooted both in an understanding of fashion as a crucial component of the construction of the black self and in meticulous realism and historical research. We're sharing some of her work today. These costumes, from “Selma,” are for the four black girls—Cynthia Wesley, Carole Robertson, Addie Mae Collins, and Carol Denise McNair—who were killed when the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church, in Birmingham, Alabama, was bombed by the Ku Klux Klan, in 1963. Photograph by @awolerizku.

For her efforts on “Black Panther,” the costume designer @iamruthecarter has been lauded as one of the essential visual storytellers of Afrofuturism. It’s only recently that her work has received this level of public attention, but her film career has spanned three decades and sixty film and TV projects. We'll be sharing some of that work today. Here, from the 1992 film “Malcolm X,” are two embroidered kufis for Elijah Muhammad, Malcolm X’s sometime mentor, and one kufi for an assistant of Muhammad’s. Photograph by @awolerizku.

“My family was always wondering why I ended up playing people who were mentally ill, insane, downtrodden, and a little crazy,” Carrie Coon says. It’s true that her characters often seem at once sane and unhinged, either affecting normalcy when they’re quietly imploding or showing startling sanity amid extreme adversity. “I think what they don’t understand is that most female parts are written basically as hysterical women. Drama comes from crazy if women are involved. And that’s only now starting to shift.” Click the link in our bio for Michael Schulman’s Profile of the actress. Photograph by @paridukovic.

In the years since Innocent Idibia, a kind of Afrobeats godfather, released his solo début, the Nigerian music scene has produced a riot of new stars and new sounds. This summer, the photographer Namsa Leuba travelled to Lagos to capture the genre’s biggest stars, including Idibia (who is now known as @official2baba), Falana, Skales, and more. Click the link in our bio to see the portfolio. Photographs by @namsaleuba.
A cartoon by @lizadonnelly, from 2010. #TNYcartoons
Before her newest movie, “The Kindergarten Teacher,” arrives on Netflix, come see Maggie Gyllenhaal in person, at the New Yorker Festival. Click the link in our bio for tickets.
A cartoon by @blisscartoons. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

After being turned down by the only film-studies course in the U.K. at the time, Sam Mendes went to Cambridge with the vague ambition to do something he loved. One day, a friend told him that he was thinking of directing a play. “‘I think I should direct it, and you should be in it,’” Mendes recalls saying. “And that was kind of it.” Click the link in our bio for John Lahr’s Profile of the acclaimed British director. Photograph by @nadavkander for TNY.
Some suggestions for Juul's new adult-focussed marketing, by @lila__ash.

Donald Glover, who is up for not one, not two, but five #Emmys tonight, takes an ambivalent view of his widespread acclaim. He says that he thinks of reality as a program and his talent as hacking the code: “I learn fast—I figured out the algorithm.” Click the link in our bio for Tad Friend’s Profile of the multi-hyphenate star. Photograph by @awolerizku for TNY.
This week's cover, “Fourth Wall,” by @adriantomine. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @kimwarp. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Hosting is really what Sofreh’s elegant chef and owner, Nasim Alikhani, does, gliding through the dining room and stopping to chat with guests as though she’s giving a party at home. Her front-of-house style seems just as intuitive as her interpretations of traditional Persian food, including a tender, hulking lamb shank and tahdig—or “stuck pot” rice. Click the link in our bio for @hannahgoldfield’s review. Photograph by @will_mebane for TNY.
A cartoon by Zachary Kanin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

When she was twenty-six, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie was living in a poky apartment in Baltimore, writing the last sections of her second book. She did nothing else—only going outside to buy bananas and peanuts, or to pay for a delivery of Chinese food. If she felt restless, she jumped rope. Today, she turns forty-one, and is known as one of the most vital and original novelists of her generation. Click the link in our bio for Larissa MacFarquhar's Profile of the author. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
A cartoon by Charles Barsotti, from 1994. #TNYcartoons

The artist Nathaniel Mary Quinn paints people as he feels them, not as they look. His fragmented approach to the human figure is a realist riff on synthetic Cubism, although what looks like collage—a hallmark of Cubism—never is. Instead, each piece of the pictorial puzzle is meticulously rendered in oil, paint stick, pastel, charcoal, gouache, and gold leaf on linen or paper. See his work at Salon 94’s spaces on the Bowery and in Freeman’s Alley through October 27th. Courtesy @nathanielmaryquinn and @salon94.

The photographer Amit Elkayam is allergic to some dogs, but he decided to subsist on Benadryl in order to capture Hendrix, a three-year-old harlequin Great Dane, and her humans, Kristina Justice and Talisa Smith, several times over a year. In the images, Hendrix (after Jimi) takes on an almost human quality, as if she were simply a third member of Justice and Smith’s domestic partnership, gathering to blow out candles on a birthday cake or primping for a night out. Click the link in our bio to see more from the series “Big Dog in a Big City.” Photograph by @amitelk.
A cartoon by Edward Steed. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Last week, @emilianoponzi took over our art department's account to share illustrations from his trip through the American West—including this one, from Los Angeles. Follow @newyorkerart to see more.
Just some of the reasons our plans tonight should be in my neighborhood, by @j.a.k._ and @noelwells.

Last week, the photographer @jayantaroy_, who is based in Kolkata, India, took over our photo department's account. " I captured this photograph just after few days of the blue moon in the early morning on the Ganges," Roy wrote. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by William Haefeli. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by @margaret__elisabeth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The women of the Dongria tribe, which has lived for centuries in the remote hills of Niyamgiri, in eastern India, wear ornaments to identify themselves: a dozen rings in each ear, a sunburst of bobby-pins, necklaces, and the triple nose-ring that signifies the tribe’s “niyam,” or law. But, as more young women attend distant residential schools, some worry that such physical marks will fade and the girls will be forced to assimilate outside of their traditional culture. Click the link in our bio for how the diverging paths of two young women foretell the fate of the tribe. Photograph by Arko Datto.
Seventeen years later, a look back at our cover “9/11/2001,” by Art Spiegelman and Françoise Mouly. #TNYcovers

Today in New York: the London-based pop collective Superorganism plays Brooklyn Steel. The group—whose members hail from Maine (by way of Japan), New Zealand, Australia, North London, and South Korea—places bouncy rhythms, sunny backing vocals, and spongy keyboards around the deadpan delivery of its teen-age lead singer, Orono Noguchi, in witty laments like “Everybody Wants to Be Famous” and “The Prawn Song." Photograph by @nathanael.turner for TNY.
A cartoon by @paulnoth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week’s cover, “Looking Up,” by Chris Ware. #TNYcovers

When the trophy presentation after the U.S. Open women’s final was announced, the crowd booed. It was an ugly sound, filling Arthur Ashe Stadium, ricocheting off the closed roof. The champion, Naomi Osaka, tugged her visor over her eyes and cried. It had been her dream to play Serena Williams in the final of the U.S. Open, and her dream to win. Her victory against Williams, on Saturday, was almost ruined by an umpire’s call. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Corinne Dubreuil/Sipa/AP.

In the way that a writer can be deemed a “writer’s writer,” you might say that Via Carota is a restaurant person’s restaurant. People who have mentioned eating there in Grub Street’s popular food-diary column include the writer and editor Ruth Reichl, the former White House chef Sam Kass, and the best-selling cookbook author and soon-to-be Netflix television host Samin Nosrat, who also described it as her favorite restaurant in New York. It’s @hannahgoldfield’s favorite, too. Click the link in our bio for her review. Photographs by Cerruti Draime/@viacarota.
A cartoon by Mike Twohy. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
The many "looks" that a mother-of-the-bride/groom has to choose from, as drawn by Roz Chast.

“That’s just one of the things Bill Cunningham gave the world: his delight in the possibility of you,” @hilton.als writes. “And you wanted to pull yourself together—to gather together the existential mess and bright spots called your “I”—the minute you saw Bill’s skinny frame bent low near Bergdorf’s on Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, his spot, capturing a heel, or chasing after a hemline, because here was your chance to show love to someone who lived to discover what you had made of yourself.” Click the link in our bio for more on the late, legendary @nytimes style photographer. Photograph courtesy The Bill Cunningham Foundation LLC.
A cartoon by Edward Steed. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

At 12:45 A.M. on Thursday night, the climber Alex Honnold got out of bed, picked up his backpack, and walked across the street from his hotel in Jersey City, New Jersey, to a sixty-nine-floor luxury apartment building called the Urby. He ate some dark chocolate, “to get amped.” Then he grabbed hold of a grate at the base of the building and, with no fanfare or dramatic final words, began heading up, without a harness or rope. Click the link in our bio for Charles Bethea on the twenty-four-floor climb. Photograph by @kathrynpalmieri.
A cartoon by Alex Gregory. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Whether you want to see comedians or musicians, activists or artists, the 2018 New Yorker Festival has something for everyone. Don’t miss conversations with Jim Carrey, Janet Mock, Sally Yates, Boots Riley, Kacey Musgraves and more. Click the link in our bio to buy tickets. #TNYfest

When Batsheva Hay began her clothing label, Batsheva, it was a mommy-and-me venture, but no one bought the children’s sizes. Customers wanted the adult dresses, which might appear comically conservative to some, but are coveted by an artsy set of women who appreciate their subversive allure. A Batsheva dress seems to say two things: “You don’t think I know what this looks like?” and “What are you going to do about it? Click the link in our bio for more on the designer rethinking the traditions of feminine dress. Photographs by @paridukovic for TNY.

Whereas Sheryl Sandberg and Mark Zuckerberg can, at times, seem blithely unaware that Facebook is anything other than sensible friends sharing their baby photos and fitness achievements, Twitter’s Jack Dorsey, with his ragged beard and professed shyness, has a more melancholy air. At Wednesday’s testimony before the Senate Intelligence Committee, his low voice, almost baleful at times, suggested some awareness that social media often breaks out in conflagrations of falsehoods, narcissism, and bullying. Click the link in our bio for what more of what happened on Capitol Hill. Photograph by @markpetersonpixs/Redux for TNY.
A cartoon by Teresa Burns Parkhurst. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This week, our art department is hosting its first takeover, by @emilianoponzi. He is sharing illustrations from his trip through the American West—including this one of the Grand Canyon. Follow @newyorkerart to see more.

In the faces of his subjects, whether hipsters or security guards or stock brokers or secretaries, the photographer Christopher Anderson searches for clues to inner longings: “What is their vision of happiness? What do they dream about at night?” The sharp slope of a cheekbone or the moist ridge of the upper lip invites a comparison to polished marble or a lunar landscape. Click the link in our bio to see more of his images of young people in Shenzhen, China. Photographs by @christopherandersonphoto/Magnum Courtesy Stanley/Barker.

In the early 1990s, Wolfgang Tillmans was known for chronicling Gen X and rave culture and taking portraits of musicians like Aphex Twin and the Blur front man Damon Albarn. He saw the acid-house-music nights at Opera House, in Hamburg, or the Love Parade, in Berlin, not just as hedonistic gatherings but as a political achievement. But outside the world of his photos, he has admitted, this freedom only existed in “little nuggets and pockets and areas.” Click the link in our bio for Emily Witt’s Profile of the German artist, whose show “How likely is it that only I am right in this matter?” opens next week in New York. Photographs by @wolfgang_tillmans/Courtesy @davidzwirner.
A cartoon by David Sipress. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Self-care for the city rat, as drawn by @sadgirlpop.

Over her three-decade career in film, the costume designer Ruth E. Carter has brought to life such figures from black history as Tina Turner, played by Angela Bassett in “What’s Love Got to Do with It,” and Malcolm X, played by Denzel Washington in Spike Lee’s bio-pic. For the film “Black Panther,” she evoked the fictional African kingdom of Wakanda by melding sci-fi with global fashion history, drawing influence from sources including the color symbolism of the Maasai people, samurai armor, and the jewelry of Ndebele women. Click the link in our bio for a portfolio of her work, captured by the photographer Awol Erizku, alongside items from his personal collection. Photographs by @awolerizku.
A cartoon by @lianafinck. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The New Group looks back at a New York power struggle with Sharr White’s “The True,” starting previews September 4th, at the Pershing Square Signature Center. Edie Falco plays Dorothea Noonan, known as Polly, who was the confidante of Albany’s mayor of four decades, Erastus Corning II. Set in 1977, the play finds Corning facing a tough primary challenge. Sound familiar? Photograph by @adam.pape for TNY.
A cartoon by Mick Stevens, from 1999. #TNYcartoons

Celebrate Labor Day with 50% off. Plus, get a free limited-edition artist tote. International offers with the tote are available for as low as $6. Click the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.
This week's cover, “Savoring Summer,” by @kadirnelson. #TNYcovers

The chef Alvin Cailan made his name on eggs—in sandwich form, at a food truck called Eggslut, in L.A. At the Usual, he has graduated to chicken, battered and fried so that its crust is as craggy as a mountain range. It’s served with blueberry muffins and house-made ranch, plus a garlicky hot sauce on request. Click the link in our bio for @hannahgoldfield’s review. Photographs by @christaanfelber for TNY.
A cartoon by P. C. Vey. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Mr. Men of Today, as drawn by Lars Kenseth.

The funeral service for John Sidney McCain III, at the Washington National Cathedral, on this swampy Saturday morning, was all about a rebuke to the pointedly uninvited current President of the United States, which was exactly how McCain had planned it. Click the link in our bio to read Susan Glasser on how McCain’s funeral was the biggest resistance meeting yet. Photographs by Pablo Martinez Monsivais/AP,  Saul Loeb/AFP/Getty, and Mark Wilson/Getty.

Imagine the color red that would come from the wounds of dragons and elephants locked in mortal combat. Dragon's Blood, which was reputed in antiquity to have got its vividness from just that, actually owes its intense redness to the resin of trees growing on the islands of Socotra and Sumatra. It's is just one of the 2,500 historic pigments in the Forbes Collection. Click the link in our bio for Simon Schama on more treasures from the color archive. Photograph by Jason Fulford for TNY.
A cartoon by @lizadonnelly. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

At the Palisades Wiffle Ball League, you won’t find any yellow bats. They’re thought to be too thin and too short to hit the pitching of someone like Daniel Whitener, who has been clocked throwing a Wiffle ball at 98 miles per hour. Instead, bats are modified—surgery performed on the handles for more anchor weight. Click the link in our bio to read about the men who have taken Wiffle ball to this crazy, competitive place. Photographs by Timothy O'Connell for TNY.
A cartoon by Julia Suits. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“She wasn’t just beautiful. She was like the sun coming up: coming up giggling,” Clive James wrote of Princess Diana, who died 21 years ago today. Click the link in our bio to read his 1997 ode to his friend, the Princess of Wales. Photograph by Jayne Fincher/Stringer/Getty.

“Hope Never Dies” is a mystery-thriller-fan-fiction mash-up that imagines Barack Obama and Joe Biden as crime fighters. It’s a giddy premise, a bit of Resistance wish-fulfillment for those who’d like to see the pair trading one-liners and cracking skulls. They take on a biker gang, lock horns with a no-nonsense local detective, and, in a very funny sequence, don slacker disguises to blend in with a crowd, with Biden wearing long shorts and a hoodie and Obama wearing a Tapout T-shirt. Click the link in our bio to read Ian Crouch on the book. Photograph by Patrick Smith/Getty.
A cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Cyclist hand signals and their meanings, by @davidferriercartoons.
A cartoon by Jason Patterson, from 2006. #TNYcartoons

This week, @samyoukilis is taking over our photo department's account to share images from his three-month trip through South America, including one of the salt pools of Maras, Peru. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.

“It was such a relief, to see works of art made out of real lives. The pictures named a world he knew, even as he struggled to understand it more,” @hilton.als writes, of a young black boy looking at Dawoud Bey’s “Young Man at a Tent Revival, Brooklyn, NY, 1989.” Click the link in our bio for his essay in full. Photograph by Dawoud Bey.
A cartoon by @steinbergdrawscartoons. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In June, protesters in Nicaragua declared the city of Masaya “territorio libre del dictador”—territory freed from the dictator. President Daniel Ortega, insisting that they were terrorists, began trying to dislodge them. He’s adopted a strategy employed by autocrats in Turkey, Egypt, Venezuela, and elsewhere: condemn your political opponents as traitors, incite mobs to violence, and then deny responsibility. Click the link in our bio to read Jon Lee Anderson’s dispatch from the country. Photograph by Oswaldo Rivas/Reuters.

Fifty years ago, hundreds of thousands of Soviet troops poured over the Czechoslovak border to crush the short-lived experiment in Communist liberalization known as the Prague Spring. A new exhibit at the Czech Center painstakingly documents the first twenty-four hours of that invasion—and includes twenty images that have never previously travelled to the U.S. Click the link in our bio to see more of the rarely seen photos. Photograph by Bohumil Dobrovolský/Courtesy @czechcenter New York.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Glenn Greenwald has argued for two years that the available evidence concerning Russian activity in the 2016 Presidential election has indicated nothing especially untoward. “A lot of Democrats have unfollowed me and a lot of conservatives or independent people have replaced them, which has made my readership more diverse, and more trans-ideological, in a way that’s actually increased my influence,” he says. Click the link in our bio to read Ian Parker’s Profile of the controversial figure. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.

At Kopitiam, you can have nasi lemak—a Malaysian dish consisting of coconut rice, cucumbers, and a boiled egg—at any time of day, but it’s especially satisfying in the morning. At the restaurant, whose name means “coffee shop” in Hokkien, the chef Kyo Pang, cooks the food she grew up eating in Penang, like fish-ball soup with vermicelli noodles. Who ever said you shouldn’t you have fish-ball soup for breakfast? You should! Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield’s review. Photographs by @jeremy_liebman for TNY.

In her portrait series “Major Arcana,” the photographer Frances F. Denny seeks to explore the figure of the contemporary witch beyond the cultural chestnuts that have shrouded and obscured it. Her subjects are all self-identified witches, and yet that fact would not be immediately or necessarily obvious to the uninformed viewer. “I’m not pinning these women down,” Denny says. Click the link in our bio for more of her series. Photographs by @francesfdenny/Courtesy ClampArt.
A cartoon by Edward Steed. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

John McCain has died. “As a valedictory act of patriotism, morality, and public service, he gathered his energies to clarify his principles, to review his mistakes, and to call out the low character and corruptions of the leader of his party,” David Remnick wrote in May. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @christopherandersonphoto / Magnum
A cartoon by Robert Weber, from 1999. #TNYcartoons

The story of Leonard Bernstein, who was born one hundred years ago today, plays like a modern American fable. A prodigious boy from Lawrence, Massachusetts, one day sits down at his aunt’s upright and begins plinking out notes. Within months, he is outplaying his first piano teacher. By twenty-seven, he’s one of the most famous American artists of his generation. Click the link in our bio for Alex Ross’s 2008 look at the legend of Lenny. Photograph by Fox Photos/Hulton Archive/Getty.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

For 158 days, Malik Naveed bin Rehman, Zahida Altaf, and their five-year-old daughter, Roniya, have been living in the basement of a church in Connecticut. It’s only a form of courtesy that prevents ICE from entering sensitive areas such as schools and places of worship—and at least 42 families or individuals facing deportation are now living in churches across the country. Click the link in our bio for Dave Eggers on this family’s story and what it means to do the right thing. Photographs @mattelife for TNY.
An early look at next week's cover, "Closing In," by Barry Blitt. #TNYcovers

In the twenty-six years since his death, David Wojnarowicz has became a Rimbaud-like figure: young, iconoclastic, gay, and gone too soon. In his early career, he stencilled graffiti on abandoned buildings and wrote moving essays describing the beauty he found in the parts of his life that made him an outcast. It wasn't until later, after his close friend Peter Hujar died of AIDs, that his work developed its power and pointedness. Click the link in our bio to read more about Wojnarowicz's controversial art. Photograph by David Wojnarowicz and Tom Warren.
Roz Chast draws what happens when a forlorn street fixture finally finds a friend.
A cartoon by Seth Fleishman. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Awkward greetings for the non-hugger, by Stacy Stevenson and Emily Niland.

Since Alex Katz met his wife, Ada, in the fall of 1957, he has painted her more than two hundred times. Recently, his proposal to place a series of cutout sculptures of Ada on the median of New York’s Park Avenue was accepted by the city. He’s also been commissioned to enhance the interior of a subway station. Click the link in our bio to read Calvin Tomkins’s Profile of the very busy ninety-year-old artist. Photographs by @gigilaub for TNY.
A cartoon by @b_loper. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons

The photographer @david.rothenberg is taking over our photo department's Instagram, where he's sharing pictures taken in different neighborhoods throughout Queens, New York. "My pictures are tied to realism through a specific sense of place, yet are often disorienting or reduced to the point of abstraction," he writes. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by Sam Gross, from 1998. #TNYcartoons
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. #TNYcartoons

"I can tell you with a straight face what it was like watching my mom’s hair fall out in the bathtub, or about the five weeks I spent sleeping in hospitals, but catch me at H Mart when some kid runs up double-fisting plastic sleeves of ppeong-twigiand I’ll just lose it," @jbrekkie writes. Click the link in our bio to read her story on crying in H Mart. Illustration by @andreamongia.

On Sunday, Simone Biles won all five gold medals at the USA Gymnastics National Championship in Boston, Massachusetts. “I felt as if Isaac Newton had written a different set of laws on her behalf,” Reeves Wiedeman wrote in his 2016 Profile of the gymnast. Click the link in our bio to read it. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

A hundred years ago, “razzle dazzle” was the term used to describe the red-and-white camouflage pattern invented by the British painter Norman Wilkinson during the First World War to confuse enemy submarines. To commemorate the centennial of the end of the war, the American artist Tauba Auerbach has “dazzled” the John J. Harvey fireboat for the Public Art Fund project “Flow Separation.” See it at various locations along the Hudson River until May 12, 2019. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.

Kevin Bradford, Kim Harris, and Stacey Lee were tired of having to leave the neighborhood to get the variety of brews they craved, so they decided to open their own beer bar and restaurant. Harlem Hops, on Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard, offers a rotation of sixteen craft brews, plus Bavarian pretzels with beer cheese or beer-infused mustard and bratwursts served on griddled pretzel buns. Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield’s review. Photographs by Cole Wilson for TNY.

Kofi Annan, who died today, believed in the possibility of world order. Before becoming U.N. Secretary-General, he spent four decades working in the United Nations bureaucracy, championing human rights. Click the link in our bio for Philip Gourevitch’s 2003 Profile of Annan. Photograph by DPPA/Sipa/AP.
A cartoon by Leo Cullum, from 2006. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
The new office seating plan, by @instachaaz.
A cartoon by Zachary Kanin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

After his unsuccessful bids at becoming a NASA astronaut, Mark Stucky had resigned himself to never reaching space—until there seemed to be another way. Now, as the lead test pilot for Virgin Galactic, Stucky is helping Richard Branson on his billion-dollar quest to make commercial space travel a reality. Click the link in our bio for Nicholas Schmidle on the ace pilot turned rocket man. Photograph by @danwintersphoto for TNY.
An early look at next week's cover, “The Queen of Soul,” by @kadirnelson. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by James Stevenson, from 2000. #TNYcartoons

Aretha Franklin has died, at the age of 76. Her voice was a pure, painful, and unforgettable expression of American history and American feeling, the collective experience of black Americans and her own life. Click the link in our bio to read David Remnick's remembrance of the Queen of Soul, or to read his 2016 Profile of the singer. Photograph by Richard Avedon / © the Richard Avedon Foundation.
A cartoon by @carolitajohnson. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“He may be bland, but he has ethics, he has integrity, he’s not going to go off on Twitter on you,” Chris Taylor, a Wisconsin State assemblyman, says of the state’s new Democratic candidate for governor. Tony Evers ran as a compassionate, temperate educator who wants to return the state to a less divisive political climate. Could he wrest Wisconsin from a decade of Republican control? Click the link in our bio for Dan Kaufman’s dispatch. Photograph @davidkasnic for TNY.
Forever 37’s fashion looks for adults, as drawn by @jessicaolien.
A cartoon by @lianafinck. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

If you live in a big city, lunchtime is among the choicest hours for people-watching—for what the photographer Charles H. Traub refers to as “the passing parade of the street.” Between 1977 and 1980, he’d take his Rolleiflex SL66 camera out onto Chicago’s Loop and take pictures of strangers during the midday bustle. His resulting portraits—which also include subjects in Paris, Miami, and other cities—present lunchtime characters like species of butterfly in an entomologist’s shadow box. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photographs by Charles H. Traub.

For the L.A. artist Andrea Bowers, art is inseparable from activism. She worked with the immigrant-rights group Movimiento Cosecha to conceive the neon sign at Little West 12th St, which is part of the High Line’s plein-air group show “Agora.” It refers to the estimated number of undocumented immigrants living in the U.S. On the other side of the sign, the slogan lights up in Spanish. See it through March, 2019. Photograph by @tobiashutzlerstudios for TNY.
A cartoon by @blisscartoons. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week's cover, “Safe Travels,” by @r_kikuo_johnson. #TNYcovers

In the course of two decades, a Parisian medical secretary named Isabelle Mège persuaded scores of renowned photographers to take her picture. Not all could be called portraits, and they varied in their style, but they all depicted her body, even if it was a tiny or unrecognizable part of it. When she first contacted the artists, she often used some version of the phrase “J’aimerais m’apercevoir à travers votre regard,” or, “I would like to see myself from your point of view.” Click the link in our bio to read Anna Heyward’s 2016 story on this opposite of a muse. Photograph by Jean-François Bauret.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
“Sea Of Umbrellas,” a cover by Charles Saxon, from 1972. #TNYcovers

“Peter Hujar defined downtown for me,” Vince Aletti writes of the photographer. “He went places I never dared to, and hung out with people I’d only read about.” That included Fran Lebowitz and Susan Sontag, and places like Fillmore East, the Fun Gallery, and the back room at Max’s. In those days, "you didn’t have to be rich or pretty, but it helped if you could dance," Aletti writes. Click the link in our bio to see more of Hujar's work from that time. Photograph The Peter Hujar Archive, LLC; courtesy Pace/MacGill Gallery.

It’s not easy to find fresh couscous in New York, but in June the chef Einat Admony—of Bar Bolonat and the falafel mini-empire Taïm—opened Kish-Kash, a new restaurant devoted to it. The couscous is made by hand, in ten-pound batches, and covered with aggressively spiced meat or vegetable stew, creating a dish that, complete, is also called couscous. Click the link in our bio to read @hannahgoldfield’s review. Photographs by Zachary Zavislak for TNY.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Ruth Bader Ginsburg was appointed to the bench twenty-five years ago today, but she was a groundbreaking litigator for women’s rights long before then. Her greatest legacy may even be in the cases that she argued as an advocate before what was then an all-male Supreme Court—and won. Click the link in our bio to see images of the Justice growing up, from a young girl in Brooklyn to a law graduate who left Columbia as co-valedictorian (but with no job offers) to a young mother and the phenomenon we now know as R.B.G. Photograph from the collection of the Supreme Court of the United States.

Whatever else Paul Manafort’s trial ends up proving, the proceedings have already shown in a most unflattering light the men President Trump chose to run his campaign and organize his Inauguration. And yet to spend a day in the courtroom is to be reminded of a different, pre-Trump era in our civic life—in a good way. An era when basic facts were not subject to endless distortion and truth still mattered. Click the link in our bio for Susan Glasser on what may currently be one of the most Trump-free spaces in America. Illustration by Christian Northeast; Source photograph by Mark Wilson/Getty.
A cartoon by Michael Crawford. #TNYcartoons

Scotty Bowers is a Hollywood legend of sorts. In the buttoned-up middle decades of the twentieth century, he arranged sexual liaisons—or provided them firsthand—to movie stars. He claims to have fixed up men with Spencer Tracy and women with Katharine Hepburn, supplied tricks for George Cukor’s soirées, and had a three-way with Lana Turner and Ava Gardner at Frank Sinatra’s house. Click the link in our bio to read Michael Shulman’s on catching up with Bowers at his ninety-fifth birthday party. Photograph courtesy Greenwich Entertainment.
A cartoon by Liam Walsh. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“When I made that work, I was in the midst of leaving a marriage while trying to break into the art world at the same time,” Jo Ann Callis says of an early collection of color photography. First shown in 1974, at the Woman’s Building, a hub for feminists in downtown Los Angeles, the images showed solitary models in semierotic poses, using props to sexual effect. Click the link in our bio for what Callis has to say about how her fetish project was received during that turbulent time. Photograph by Jo Ann Callis.
A cartoon by Arnie Levin, from 1999. #TNYcartoons

There persists a mistaken belief that fan fiction only consists of bad writing. But “No Reservations: Narnia,” a work that channels the casual charisma of Anthony Bourdain’s writing voice as he samples the culture and cuisine of C. S. Lewis’s Narnia, is so uncannily on point that it is sure to charm any reader. Including, as it turns out, Bourdain himself. Click the link in our bio to read his response to @helenr when she sent him the story. Photograph by Henny Garfunkel/Redux.

“It was Jim’s idea to do ‘Fever,’” Rita Moreno says of the song Jim Henson asked her to perform on “The Muppet Show.” She sang the sultry number, clad in a slinky dress, and accompanied by Animal on drums. “Of course, that appealed to the cartoon side of me. I love silly humor, and that was about as silly as you can get.” Click the link in our bio to watch the clip from 1976. Photograph by Loomis Dean/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty.
A cartoon by Corey Pandolph. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
What to expect from your affordable-hotel experience, by @drawnbytom.
This week, @theatraff is taking over our photo department’s account to take us inside the Condé Nast elevator bank at One World Trade Center. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Sentient coffee, by @rubyetc_.

In 2013, Astrid Holleeder agreed to testify against the most notorious criminal in the Netherlands, a man known as De Neus. His real name is Wim Holleeder, and he’s Astrid’s older brother. Click the link in our bio to read Patrick Radden Keefe on how a notorious gangster was exposed by his own sister. Photograph by Carla van de Puttelaar for TNY.
A cartoon by Charles Barsotti. #TNYcartoons
A cartoon by Edward Steed. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

What did Barack Obama, who turns fifty-seven today, tell his two daughters, Sasha and Malia, after Donald Trump's election? "Your job as a citizen and as a decent human being is to constantly affirm and lift up and fight for treating people with kindness and respect and understanding.” Click the link in our bio to read David Remnick’s 2016 Profile of the former President. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Asking which category Ryan McGinley’s new series, “Mirror, Mirror,” belongs to might seem like a trick question. The introspective collection of his friend's self portraits represents an exhilarating and contemplative new direction for an artist whose work has always been both a looking glass and a lookout. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @ryanmcginleystudios/Courtesy Team Gallery.

“Love takes off the masks that we fear we cannot live without and know we cannot live within,” James Baldwin, who was born on this day in 1924, wrote in “Letter from a Region in My Mind,” which appeared in our pages in 1962. Click the link in our bio to read it in full. Photograph by Anthony Barboza/Getty.

How the mighty have fallen! And by the mighty, of course, we mean Diet Coke. The soda that hit stores in 1982 and rose to prominence in the late eighties and nineties has gone flat in the social-media age. Click the link in our bio for Nathan Heller on the decline and fall of what was once America’s favorite power soda. Photograph by Thomas Eversley/Alamy.
A cartoon by Mike Twohy. #TNYcartoons

Four years after publishing “The Member of the Wedding,” in 1946, Carson McCullers adapted her novel of difference and adolescent disillusionment for the Broadway stage. The play starred Julie Harris and Ethel Waters, who reprised their roles in the 1952 film. A revival runs August 5th-19th at Williamstown Theatre Festival, in the Berkshires, with Tavi Gevinson as Frankie, a Southern tomboy dreaming of the world beyond her own, and Roslyn Ruff as Berenice, a housekeeper who knows the punishing ways of that world. Photograph by  @matthewtammaro for TNY.
A cartoon by @lianafinck. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Ten relationship metaphors drawn by a relatively emotionally literate thirty-three-year-old who is in touch with all her exes, by @slautow.

“I got stoned with Jack Nicholson at your father’s house. You can’t say I was more Hollywood,” Nicole Holofcener says to her best friend since high school, Madeleine Moskowitz. The two grew up in the orbit of stars like Warren Beatty and Robin Williams—yet Holofcener never imagined that she would one day become a director. Even now, she likes to complain that nobody has seen her films. Click the link in our bio to read Ariel Levy on the director whose movies find humor and poignancy in bad behavior. Photograph by Graeme Mitchell for TNY.
A cartoon by @jasonchatfield. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

When Bill Granger first started serving avocado toast at his eponymous restaurant, in Sydney, in was 1993. “Avocado was always just something I ate,” he told Amelia Lester, when they met at a branch (there are now eighteen locations) in Tokyo. “We didn’t even used to sell that much of it.” Click the link in our bio to read more about the man who made the Australian café (and, yes, avocado toast) a global phenomenon. Photograph by Marco Del Grande/Fairfax Media/Getty.
A cartoon by Frank Cotham. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“My mother said when you die, you stand there before the light, and you say, ‘Was I worthy of myself to know that I have liked me?’ Okay? I like me. Okay? And I will tell the whole chorus, honey, ‘I like me.’ I don't hurt anybody, I don't do anybody wrong, you know. I’ve dealt with everything I can, as much as I can. So just find that inside yourself and take time with that person. Faults, flaws, wishes, all of it, it doesn't matter. We're not going to get it all. None of us gets it all. Okay? But what we do have, we can polish. We can polish it, honey, till it blinds them.” —Duchess Milan, 69
.
Last week, @jesstdugan took over our photo department’s account to share quotes and images from her series on transgender and gender-nonconforming older adults. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
This week's cover, “On The Beach,” by @tomgauld. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @j.a.k._. #TNYcartoons

According to its Web site, the seasonal menu at Emma’s Torch features “New American cuisine—prepared by our new American students.” You see, the restaurant is not only a dine-in establishment, with rosé on tap, but also a 501(c)(3) and a school of sorts, where refugees from all over the world are paid a salary to receive culinary training and are then given help finding work in the industry. Our food critic @hannahgoldfield recommends attending one of the monthly graduation dinners, where trainees make a dish or two from their home countries. Click the link in our bio for her review. Photographs by @colewilson for TNY.
A cartoon by Michael Maslin, from 1996. #TNYcartoons

Six women have accused Les Moonves, the chairman of CBS, of harassment and intimidation, and dozens more describe abuse at the company. Four women told @RonanFarrow that Moonves forcibly touched or kissed them during business meetings, in what they said appeared to be a practiced routine. Two said that Moonves physically intimidated them or threatened to derail their careers. Thirty current and former employees of CBS said that the behavior extended from Moonves to important parts of the corporation, including CBS News and “60 Minutes.” CBS and Moonves deny these allegations. Click the link in our bio to read the full story.
A cartoon by Shannon Wheeler. #TNYcartoons

With the book “The Commissar Vanishes,” a British collector and historian of Russia, David King, has published a study of the disappearance of the physical record of Trotsky and a number of other Russians who fell out of favor, and out of history, during the Stalin era. Many of the photographs showcase falsification by commission rather than omission. Click the link in our bio to read Masha Gessen on the photo book that captured how the Soviet regime made the truth disappear. Photograph by F. Kislov / Tate

What kind of a painter is Henry Taylor? He is described by others with labels he mostly rejects—outsider, portraitist, protest painter, folk artist. “I think I just hunt and gather,” he has said. “I feel sort of voracious.” It’s his practice to seek people out—in the street, at an art fair, at his mama’s house—and figure them in paint, but each person is configured differently, sometimes hewing closely to verisimilitude, sometimes ignoring it; sometimes attending to the proportion of limbs, other times leaving them out entirely. Click the link in out bio to read more of Zadie Smith’s Profile of the California artist. Image courtesy the artist and Blum & Poe.
A cartoon by @kimwarp. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Reading a novel requires, if not outright belief, the willing suspension of its opposite. To the nonbelieving reader, a character’s religious fervor can be a hindrance. When an imaginary character cares most deeply about a god who seems equally imaginary, the spell can weaken; a reader may impatiently wonder when the character will wise up and throw off these phantasmal chains. R. O. Kwon’s début, “The Incendiaries,” evades the pitfalls of the religious novel by giving them the widest possible berth. Here are a handful of facts, Kwon seems to say, if they even are facts. Make of them what you will. Click the link in our bio for Laura Miller’s review. Photograph by Mimi Plumb for TNY.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Today in New York: Raphael Saadiq brings his seamless pairing of the old school and the new to Damrosch Park, as part of Lincoln Center Out of Doors. At only eighteen, the bassist, singer-songwriter, and funk auteur toured with Prince—an auspicious beginning to a career that has included producing award-winning music for Solange Knowles and D’Angelo, and collaborating with Erykah Badu. (He also scores Issa Rae’s HBO series, “Insecure.”) Photograph by @ryanpfluger for TNY.
Inspirational-quote cushions for different life stages, by @davidferriercartoons and Evan Williams.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts, from 2006. #TNYcartoons

When Ruth spoke out against the abuse within her community of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, she was exiled from her home and not allowed to see her children. In 2011, the photographer Tanyth Berkeley travelled to Arizona to meet her and to “congratulate her on her courage and to give her support.” The trip was the beginning of a long project that expanded to include another female outcast in the Southwest, and which has now become a photo book entitled “The Walking Woman.” Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Tanyth Berkeley/Courtesy Conveyor Editions.
