A cartoon by Seth Fleishman. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

On Saturday, hundreds of teens marched through Manhattan representing the Zero Hour movement. They were gravely concerned about politicians doing almost nothing for climate justice, and they had created a list of demands—including, most importantly, achieving negative carbon emissions by 2030. “Climate change is the greatest threat of the twenty-first century. Obviously,” Ilana Cohen, one of the organizers, told Carolyn Kormann, who was reporting from the march. Click the link in our bio for her story. Photographs by @levimandel for TNY.

There should be a word other than “artist” for David Wojnarowicz. “Phenomenon” works. So might “sphinx.” He was preposterously talented, notably as a spellbinding writer in the vein of his hero, the French poet Arthur Rimbaud, and as a designer of posters and fliers, including some for his rock band 3 Teens Kill 4. A sensational retrospective of his work is now at the Whitney Museum. See it through September 30th. Courtesy The Museum of Modern Art, New York/Gift of Agnes Gund and Barbara Jakobson Fund.
A cartoon by @carolitajohnson. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

New York or London? @thereadviewer proves that our cover looks almost as at home in Islington as it does in the West Village. Share your favorite magazine moments using #newyorkerinthewild and we might regram you.

For a few days in 1950, Ernest Hemingway, who was born on this day in 1899, stopped in New York on his way to Europe. After arriving at the Sherry-Netherland and taking off his jacket, he telephoned the Plaza and asked for his friend Marlene Dietrich. Then he called room service and ordered caviar and a couple of bottles of Perrier-Jouët, brut. Click the link in our bio to read Lillian Ross’s account of the days she spent with the author. Photograph by Lloyd Arnold/Hulton Archive/Getty.
A cartoon by William Haefeli. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

For a week, an iceberg as tall as the Statue of Liberty filled the villagers of Innaarsuit, Greenland, with existential dread. If a big enough part of it sloughed off, in a process known as “calving,” it would have caused a tsunami, immediately destroying the little settlement on whose shore it rested. Luckily, the iceberg continued drifting north and, by Wednesday, everyone felt safe enough to go home. Click the link in our bio to read Carolyn Kormann on why, with climate change, such events are expected to occur more frequently. Photograph by Magnus Kristensen/Ritzau Scanpix/Reuters.

At Don Wagyu, a new sandwich shop in the financial district, a five-ounce piece of steak, imported from Japan, can cost as much as $180 dollars. But the meat is treated like chicken: breaded in panko, dunked in oil, and placed between slices of crustless white toast for a katsu sando, or fried-cutlet sandwich. Our food critic @hannahgoldfield decides if it is really worth the price tag. Click the link in our bio for her review. Photographs by @dollyfaibyshev for TNY.
A cartoon by Frank Cotham. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This week, the self-taught street photographer @clay_benskin is taking over our photo department’s account to share his favorite images from particular categories, including a set of three underground kissing shots. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by Charles Barsotti, from 1998. #TNYcartoons
Rebranding ideas for Neapolitan ice cream, as drawn by @johnny.dinapoli.🍦

A little more than three years ago, Donald Trump descended an escalator in Trump Tower to announce his candidacy for the Presidency. That image makes a return in next week's cover, “Thumbs-Up,” by Barry Blitt, which remarks on Trump’s performance during and after his summit with Vladimir Putin, in Helsinki. #TNYcovers

On Tuesday, when Barack Obama walked onto a stage in Johannesburg to deliver the 2018 Nelson Mandela Annual Lecture, commemorating the centenary of the former South African President’s birth, he offered the sharpest possible contrast between himself and his successor—between statesman and demagogue—and, crucially, the distinction between a man who grasps history as the living context of our lives and one unburdened by the knowledge of how we arrived at the present and what that means for the future. Click the link in our bio to read the lecture (it’s edited, but not much) or to read Jelani Cobb on Obama’s indictment of Trumpism. Photograph by Alet Pretorius/Gallo Images/Getty

In each of Genevieve Gaignard’s pictures, she portrays a character of her own invention. From a buttoned-up suburbanite, in a dirty-blond bob, carrying groceries to a series of swimmers à la an Esther Williams production, each photograph plays with the outward signifiers and stereotypes of race, class, and gender identity—combining and remixing them into sometimes exaggerated but steadily ambiguous costumes. Click the link in our bio to see more from “Counterfeit Currency,” her show at the flag Art Foundation, in Chelsea. Photographs by @creativecurvyginger/Courtesy Shulamit Nazarian.
A cartoon by @ellisjrosen. #TNYcartoons
A cover by @kadirnelson, from 2013, for the centennial of Nelson Mandela’s birth. #TNYcovers

“I am still emotionally, intellectually, spiritually, and logistically processing all of this,” Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez says, of winning New York's Democratic primary for the Fourteenth Congressional District and defeating the incumbent, Joseph Crowley. Not long ago, the twenty-eight-year-old resident of the Bronx was mixing margaritas at a taco place near Union Square. Today, she is the embodiment of anti-corporate politics and a surge of female candidates in the midterm elections. Click the link in our bio to read David Remnick on the candidate who is almost certain to become the youngest woman ever elected to Congress. Photograph by @markpetersonpixs/Redux for TNY.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A field guide to oligarchs, by Barry Blitt.

All Donald Trump wanted from the Helsinki summit was the attention and the photo op, it seemed. All Vladimir Putin wanted was the mirror of that symbolism, not to make any real deals, let alone concessions. And so it’s no surprise that the summit delivered exactly that: a content-light meeting that gave Trump his pictures and momentary id massage, and allowed Putin to keep in place a rather advantageous status quo, gaining recognition and status for himself and Russia in exchange for, well, essentially nothing. Click the link in our bio for live updates from Susan Glasser and Joshua Yaffa, who are on the scene in Finland. Photograph by Mikhail Metzel/TASS via Getty.
A cartoon by @amykurzweil. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week's cover, “Summertime City,” by @kadirnelson. #TNYCovers

On Sunday, in the fifty-second minute of the final game of the World Cup, four women dressed in Russian-police uniforms charged the field, briefly disrupting the match. They were members of the Russian protest-art group Pussy Riot. The group, by taking the field at the World Cup final, demonstrated exactly how intervention, rule-breaking, and destruction happen. Click the link in our bio to read Masha Gessen on the moral clarity of Pussy Riot’s protest. Photograph by Daniel Malmberg/Getty
A cartoon by @bentschwartz. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

One day, while watching cartoons, George Clinton had the idea that it was far more interesting for his bands to masquerade as characters than to be themselves. They began dressing in costumes: diapers, spacesuits, martial-arts uniforms, wizards’ robes. P-Funk’s songs and album sleeves sketched out an extended, predominantly black cosmos of heroes and villains. If you surrendered yourself to their music, there would always be a place for you on the Holy Mothership. Click the link in our bio to read Hua Hsu on one of the most important musical figures in American history. Photograph by Andres Serrano for TNY.

“This image represents the beginning of my modelling career,” Amelia says. “I have a memory of hugging Ricky, his soft-as-velvet face and warm breath.” Over the course of eleven years, her mother, Robin Schwartz, photographed Amelia with all types of animals—elephants, and sphynx-cats, and a Cotton-Top Tamarin. The collected series, entitled “Amelia’s World,” is a magical portrait of a girl growing up. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @robin_schwartz.
A cartoon by @daveostowdraws. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

If you wish to be reminded of what film can do, or if you doubt the depths that lurk beneath the flat skin of celluloid, Ingmar Bergman is your man. The work of the Swedish filmmaker, who was born a hundred years ago today, should be both outdated and remote. But it continues to resound. Click the link in our bio to read Anthony Lane on why. Photograph by Bonniers Hylen/AFP/Getty.

In the same way that a bouquet of wildflowers is lovely but banal while an alpine meadow of blooming wildflowers is astonishing and sublime, the cactus that’s probably in your bedroom pales in comparison to the sight of ancient, alien cactuses in the places they grow wild. Luckily you can find such cactuses closer to home, in a book three cactus-crazed young men compiled last year. The several hundred pictures inside were drawn from twenty-two explorers’ archives and span 80 years. Click the link in our bio to see more from “Xerophile: Cactus Photographs from Expeditions of the Obsessed.” Photograph by Woody Minnich.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

When Michelle Groskopf moved from New York City to Los Angeles six years ago, she brought the tradition of New York street photography with her. Her quirky, candid images of pedestrians and amblers all over L.A. focus in on visceral details—a thumb stretching the back strap of a bikini, a drop of sweat above a lip, pink strands held back with a baseball cap. Click the link in our bio for more of her work. Photograph by @michellegroskopf.

The malnutrition ward of the Al-Sabaeen hospital, in Yemen, is a quiet place even when it’s busy. Parents speak in murmurs and children are too weak to cry. The war between the Houthi rebels and the Saudi-led coalition has increased the price of food in the country, but it’s the disappearance of millions of jobs that has brought over eight million people to the brink of starvation. Click the link in our bio to read Jane Ferguson's dispatch from Sana’a. Photograph by @janieferg.
A cartoon by @b_loper. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Ottessa Moshfegh is easily the most interesting contemporary American writer on the subject of being alive when being alive feels terrible. She’s known for writing characters who are repulsed by themselves, or who are themselves repulsive. But in “My Year of Rest and Relaxation,” Moshfegh instead builds a façade of beauty and privilege around her characters, forcing the reader to locate repulsion somewhere deeper. Click the link in our bio to read @jiatortellini’s review of the novel. Photograph by Dru Donovan for TNY.
A cartoon by David Sipress. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Seasons in California, by Kathryn Doyle and @farleykatz. Click the link in our bio to see the rest.

In 1952, Charles Addams, at the height of his skills as a cartoonist, painted a lush, monochromatic mural depicting the then-unnamed members of the Addams family at the beach. It was intended to hang over the bar at the Dune Deck, a hotel in the Hamptons. But over the years it wended its way from Long Island to a Penn State library. Click the link in our bio to read about how the nearly fourteen-foot-long, over four-foot-high painting wound up hidden away in a Pennsylvania university. Photograph courtesy Look Magazine Photograph Collection/Library of Congress.
A cartoon by @maddiedai. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This week, @lucatombolini is taking over our art department’s account to share pictures from his series “LS IX” and “LS X.” These were shot using large format film during long solo trips to Morocco and the American West. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
Meals you can eat on the New York City subway, as drawn by @cartoonconnie.
A cartoon by @tomcheney54. #TNYcartoons

The songs that made her famous—“The Greatest Love of All,” “I Wanna Dance With Somebody (Who Loves Me),” “One Moment in Time”—tell you almost nothing about Whitney Houston, who, as Kevin Macdonald’s new documentary vividly catalogues, had more than her share of secrets. “Whitney” is not the first posthumous documentary about the singer, but it goes startlingly deep, both in the damage it dredges up and in the context it gives to her achievements. Click the link in our bio to read Michael Shulman’s review. Photograph by The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty.

The aerial photographer George Steinmetz takes the majority of his pictures from a custom-built contraption that he refers to as his “flying lawn chair.” Photographing from a paraglider rather than from a plane gives him greater flexibility. His perspective, unobstructed by glass or struts, is as close as a human can come to the bird’s eye. Click the link in our bio to read @laurenzcollins’s 2010 Profile of @geosteinmetz. Photograph by FranÇois Lagarde.
A cartoon by @kimwarp. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
An illustrated guide to heartbreak, by @rubyetc_.
A cartoon by David Borchart. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In New York, if you look closely, you can find someone with their nose in a book on every park bench, museum step, patch of grass, and subway car. The photographer Jonno Rattman travelled all over town to find bookworms in unexpected places. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @jonnotherattman.
A cartoon by John McNamee. #TNYcartoons
Freelance achievement stickers, by @jeremywins. Click the link in our bio to see them all.
A cartoon by @lianafinck. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“I just want to see the edge of the building, and then I want to go build it myself,” Ottessa Moshfegh says of her work. She isn’t the sort of fiction writer who conducts methodical research and then labors to produce a faithful simulacrum of a time or a place. Her source material is her own imagination. Click the link in our bio to read more about Moshfegh’s otherworldly fiction. Photograph by Dru Donovan for TNY.
A cartoon by Trevor Spaulding. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Celebrate July 4th. Save 50%. Plus, get a free limited-edition artist tote. Sale offer valid in the U.S. only. International offers with the tote are available for as low as $12.  Click the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.
A cover by William Steig, from 1937, for the Fourth of July. #TNYcovers

In the series “Bored on the 4th of July,” the photographer Chris Maggio uses a flat, snapshot style that makes his subjects look equal parts lurid and lonely. He shot the series last summer, often in the suburbs, and mostly on trips around the Northeast. Maggio hunts for unlikely combinations of the colors red, white, and blue, as if they were a code that might unlock some passage into the American psyche. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @chrismaggio.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. #TNYcartoons

“It is a celebration of the imaginary space of a town that dreams, just like any other,” the photographer @isadoraromerophoto writes of her series “Stardust.” The photos in it were taken between 2015 and 2017 in Mascarilla, Ecuador, a small town in the Chota Valley. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week's cover, "Downtime," by @markulriksenart. #TNYcovers
Where your personalities go while you’re having sex, by @willmcphail4

Stephen Trask’s first new musical since 1998’s “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” travels back to the dirty old New York of 1979, with characters including the Studio 54 impresario Steve Rubell. “This Ain’t No Disco,” now in previews, features Samantha Marie Ware, Peter LaPrade, Theo Stockman, and Chilina Kennedy. Photograph by @merylmeisler for TNY.

At Café Booqoo, in Carroll Gardens, Matt Pace ships the French bread for his po’boys directly from New Orleans. But the fillings incorporate inventive twists. His is one of two new restaurants in Brooklyn that offer a taste of the Crescent City with muffulettas, oysters, and jambalaya. Click the link in our bio to read our reviews of Café Booqoo and Lowerline. Photographs by davidwilliamsphoto for TNY.
A cartoon by Edward Steed. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

You hear Cecilia Vicuña’s fibre-and-video installation “Disappeared Quipu” before you see it, in the Great Hall of the Brooklyn Museum. Quipus are cords, knotted to record information—a system devised by the Inca, which the Spanish banned in 1583. In her piece, twenty-five-foot lengths of pale unspun wool hang from the ceiling, while a soundtrack of Vicuña’s voice plays. A compact retrospective of her four-decade career is also on display at the Lehmann Maupin gallery through July 6th. Photograph courtesy the artist and Lehmann Maupin.
A cartoon by @carolitajohnson. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by David Sipress. #TNYcartoons

“How do you make a photograph that’s more interesting than what happened? That’s really the problem,” the street photographer Garry Winogrand once said. At the 1964 World’s Fair, he captured two men and six women seated on a park bench, each contorted into an expressive pose, the physical links between them implying narratives, but never confirming them. Half a century later, two of the women recollected that long-ago summer afternoon. Click the link in our bio to read their conversation. Courtesy Garry Winogrand/Fraenkel Gallery.
A cartoon by Henry Martin, from 1987. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Jenny Kendler’s installation “Bird Watching” represents a hundred eyes of as many threatened or endangered species. Along with Maya Lin’s glimpse into the secret life of grass and Mary Mattingly’s transplanted tropical-palm grove, the sculpture is currently on display as part of “Indicators: Artists on Climate Change” at Storm King Art Center, in Cornwall, New York. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.

The day after the 2016 Presidential election, Terrance Hayes wrote the first of the seventy sonnets collected in his new book. In it, he freelances inside a form he calls “part music box, part meat grinder,” fashioning a diary of survival during a period when black men are in constant danger. Click the link in our bio to read our review of “American Sonnets for My Past and Future Assassin.” Photograph by @gabrielestab for TNY.
A cartoon by @amykurzweil. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“The Internet means a lot to me, and no one is talking about it correctly,” Bo Burnham says. The former YouTube star wrote and directed his first film, “Eighth Grade,” to change that. Without preaching about the ills of social media, he wanted to “take inventory emotionally” of what it feels like to be a thirteen-year-old online. Click the link in our bio to read Michael Schulman’s Profile of the comedian and filmmaker. Photograph by @ilonaaszwarc for TNY.

Millennial Wingdings, by @charlottemayhem. Click the link in our bio to translate your name, your excuse for cancelling plans, the number of succulents you’ve killed, etc., into this generation-specific dingbat font.
A cartoon by @blisscartoons. #TNYcartoons

The first stop on “The Road to Change,” the Parkland students’ twenty-state tour through America, was the annual Peace March and Rally on the South Side of Chicago. The students understood that they are examples of America’s gun problem but also outliers—and so, in the days leading up to the march, they insisted on speaking to the media only in tandem with Chicago's student activists. “We have to worry about bullets coming from inside of our school, not outside of it. But across America we have to deal with both issues,” David Hogg said. Click the link in our bio to read about how America’s youth are launching a national gun-control coalition. Photograph by Jim Young/AFP/Getty.

This week, the photographer @k.seunggu is taking over our photo department's account to share images from his series "Better Days," documenting the varied spectacle of Koreans enjoying their short vacations. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The adolescents in Justine Kurland’s “Girl Pictures” are messy-haired and free and lovely, smoking, hanging out in meadows or in parking lots, in forests or in playgrounds, enacting their own mysterious routines. The images of lawless girls are menacing, charged with a feral sense of possibility. “I channeled the raw, angry energy of girl bands into my photographs of teenagers,” Kurland writes in the monograph that accompanies her show, currently on view at Mitchell-Innes & Nash gallery. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photographs by @justine4good/Courtesy Mitchell-Innes & Nash.
The elementary-school hierarchy, as drawn by @lianafinck.

Anthony Friedkin was nineteen in 1969 when he first started working on “The Gay Essay,” a four-year-long series documenting gay communities in Los Angeles and San Francisco. The project, which was first exhibited in 1973, includes images of young couples, drag queens, and gay activists. Click the link in our bio to see more from the series. Photograph by Anthony Friedkin.
A cartoon by Zachary Kanin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cover by Frank Viva, from 2016, for #Pride. #TNYcovers

Unlike the Olympics—the only occasion when most people have any time for figure skating or race walking—the #WorldCup serves as a quadrennial testament to soccer’s year-round appeal. By any number of metrics, it is the most popular sport on earth, and the current tournament arrives at a moment of new highs. Click the link in our bio to read Leo Robson on how money and media saturation have changed the nature of soccer fandom. Photograph by Ron Bell/PA Images/Getty.
A cartoon by Edward Steed. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Lifeguards occupy a peculiar cultural niche, at the intersection of “Baywatch” and beach bum. Those who work on busy beaches, such as Jones Beach, often have backgrounds as élite competitive swimmers. Yet much of their job entails sitting, and tanning, and watching and watching. Joseph Szabo has spent three decades taking photos at Jones Beach, capturing the strenuous physicality of the lifeguards’ work and the sensation of endless summer days. Click the link in our bio to see more from his “Lifeguard” series. Photograph by Joseph Szabo/Courtesy Damiani Editore.

Was Meryl Streep, who turns 69 today, ever just an aimless twentysomething, trying to make her way in the world? That’s a question that Michael Shulman spent years trying to answer. His conclusion: “Yes and no.” Click the link in our bio to read more about who the best actress of her generation was before she was the best actress of her generation. Photograph by Ted Thai/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty.
A cartoon by @paulnoth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

On Wednesday morning, Karla and her four children walked to the foot of the Paso del Norte—one of the bridges that connects Mexico with Texas. They intended to request asylum in the U.S. and were crossing at this legal point of entry to avoid criminal prosecution. But for several weeks, Customs and Border Protection has been stationing agents in the middle of the bridge, where they turn away many asylum seekers, preventing them from even stepping onto the U.S. side. Click the link in our bio to read more about her story. Photograph by @philipmontgomery for TNY.
An early look at next week’s cover, "Yearning to Breathe Free," by Barry Blitt. #TNYcovers

Today in New York: The Metropolitan Opera leaves its gilded precincts for the city’s parks, where it will present a series of free concerts headlined by gifted young singers like the soprano Gabriella Reyes de Ramírez. Listen tonight at Staten Island’s Clove Lakes Park, on June 23rd at the Bronx’s Williamsbridge Oval, on June 27th at Harlem’s Jackie Robinson Park, and on June 29th at the Socrates Sculpture Park, in Queens. Photograph by @paolakudacki for TNY.

When migrants crossing into the U.S. are apprehended, Customs and Border Protection agents dispose of much of their personal property during intake. In 2007, while Tom Kiefer was working as a C.B.P. janitor, it was his job to throw away the trash. One day, without telling anyone, he began collecting discarded items: toothbrushes, rosaries, pocket Bibles, water bottles, and keys. “I didn’t know what I was going to do,” he said. “But I knew there was something to be done.” Click the link in our bio to read about his photo series “El Sueño Americano”—a vibrant, startling testament to the lives of those who had been detained or deported. Photographs by @tomkiefer.photographer.
A cartoon by @bentschwartz. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Andrés Manuel López Obrador is running for President on a promise to remake Mexico in the spirit of its founding revolutionaries. Known across the country as AMLO, he has a surging popularity that can be attributed partly to Donald Trump. And, if the polls can be believed, he is almost certain to win the election on July 1st. Click the link in our bio to read Jon Lee Anderson's Profile of the anti-Trump populist candidate. Photograph by Meghan Dhaliwal for TNY.

The photographer Jocelyn Lee has been making frank and intimate portraits for twenty-five years—of teens, of teen mothers, of women of all ages and stages of life, including some near the end of it. The painterly pictures in her new series, “The Appearance of Things,”—currently on view at the Center for Maine Contemporary Art—reveal a symbiosis between human and natural forms, each enhancing the other’s uncanny, shifting beauty. Click the link in our bio to see more of her portraits. Photographs by @jocelynleephotography.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy. #TNYcartoons

Is each of us one person or, over the course of a lifetime, many? The Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Tracy Letts takes on this existential riddle in “Mary Page Marlowe.” The play charts the life of an Ohio accountant, moving back and forth through time, with six actresses playing the title character at different ages. See it, starting June 19, at Second Stage. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.

“Coco” is a movie about borders—the beauty in their porousness, the absolute pain produced when a border locks you away from your family. The conflict in the story comes from not being able to cross over; the resolution is that love pulls you through to the other side. The thesis of the movie is that families belong together. Click the link in our bio to read @jiatortellini on how the Pixar film is a definitive movie for this moment. Photograph courtesy Pixar.
This week's cover, “City Living,” by @blisscartoons. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @paulnoth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Stop stressing about what color tie to buy your dad, and enjoy this slideshow of our Father’s Day covers. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Whatever you think of Instagram poets, their posts do share certain characteristics: brevity, a self-mythology that unforgiving critics will call narcissism, inclusiveness that often manifests as a lack of specificity. One exception to this broad stereotype is @yrsadaleyward, a British writer and model who embodies select elements of Instapoetry while skirting its worst hazards. She is less interested in inspiring readers or glamorizing herself than in voicing, with what can seem like sincere surprise, the contents of her mind. Click the link in our bio to read more about her work. Photograph by @nicolenodland.
A cartoon by Roz Chast. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Carroll Dunham is one of the best living American painters. He is also, almost defiantly, one of the weirdest. In his latest show, at the Gladstone gallery until tomorrow, he continues to wrestle with his one true subject—painting itself—in Crayola-bright pictures of cavemen, going head to head in the wild in Greco-Roman-style combat. © Carroll Dunham/Courtesy the artist and @gladstone.gallery.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Can you imagine living in the same room as your entire family? Masaki Yamamoto can. For eighteen years, the Japanese photographer lived with his mother, father, and four siblings in a one-room apartment in Kobe—a space no bigger than the size of six tatami mats. He celebrates the experience in a new photography book, entitled “Guts.” Click the link in our bio to see more of Yamamoto’s images of life in close quarters. Photograph by Masaki Yamamoto/Courtesy Zen Foto Gallery.

The first game of the World Cup, an entirely lopsided affair between Russia and Saudi Arabia, was enjoyable—despite the mostly middling quality on display—if only because it felt like the beginning of fun, and of the summer. Russia’s second goal of the game, which came during the 43rd minute, was a real and undeniable beauty, no matter how lacklustre the opposition. Click the link in our bio to read about the goal that sealed Russia’s latest victory on the world stage. Photograph by Ryan Pierse/Getty.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The Faroe Islands, located in the North Atlantic 200 miles north of Scotland, boasts a landmass of 540 square miles—and one Michelin-starred restaurant. Koks, which can serve no more than 24 diners a night, offers an 18-course tasting menu, made up almost exclusively of foods that are raised or cultivated on the Faroes, or found in the local waters. The cuisine—which centers of fermented food—challenges even the most adventurous palate. Click the link in our bio to read about the world’s most remote foodie destination. Photograph by Anne Golaz for TNY.
The Lord of All Evil. A comic by Eric Lide.
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Christoph Niemann, the artist behind this week's cover, often draws from his experience with his three sons. "I’d been off Legos since I was thirteen, but since having kids I’ve enjoyed a complete relapse," Niemann said. "We sit quietly next to each other, everyone working on their own projects, occasionally asking around for a blue six-by-two. I’ve even turned these sessions into proper work when I started building New York out of Lego—in the most abstract way possible." Click the link in our bio to read more about Niemann's inspiration for this week's cover. Photographs by @abstractsunday

We are changing the face of the sky. And we are altering its mood; scientists hesitate to link specific storms to global warming, but it’s clear that, on the whole, climate change is making extreme-weather events more powerful and, perhaps, more common. In the photographer Camille Seaman’s cloudscapes, it’s difficult to not also see humankind’s self-portrait: potent, defiant, unforgiving. Click the link in our bio to read more about a storm chasers view of our sky. Photographs by @camilleseaman.
A cartoon by @joedator. #TNYcartoons

Two monumental bronze figures—one eighteen feet long and prostrate, either in prayer or in fear, the other a twelve-foot-tall alien—provide a triumphant coda to “Like Life,” the @metmusem’s deep dive into the history of polychrome sculpture at the Met Breuer. Both were cast from works that the artist Huma Bhabha made in her studio using lo-fi materials. Together, her characters fuse centuries of sculptural traditions with political and pop-culture references—Rodin waylaid by Rastafarians, in a dream of Samuel R. Delany’s. See it on the roof of the museum through Oct. 28. Photograph courtesy the artist, @salon94, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art

The photographer KangHee Kim is sharing images from her series “Street Errands” on our photo department's account. It is comprised of collaged photographs that mix New York and a few other places she has travelled within the United States. "They are a construction of my own form of surreal escapism, made by manipulating images that are produced from those mundane encounters," @tinycactus writes. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more of her work.

Typically a balmy summer treat, the @publictheaterny's Shakespeare in the Park series made national headlines last year with its Trumped-up “Julius Caesar.” Unless Roseanne Barr plays Desdemona, there likely won’t be a similar fracas surrounding this season’s first offering, “Othello” (through June 24). But Ruben Santiago-Hudson’s production does retain at least one element from the last go-round: Corey Stoll, who played Brutus and returns as Iago, a different sort of troublemaker. In the title role is the Nigerian-British actor Chukwudi Iwuji, who appeared at the Delacorte in 2014, as Edgar in “King Lear.” Illustration by @allisonfilice.
A cartoon by Mike Twohy. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week's cover, “Father’s Day Off,” by @abstractsunday.

John Witzig was one of the first people to document Australian surf culture, publishing his first surf photograph in 1962, when he was just eighteen. He was shooting with the only waterproof camera at the time: Nikon’s Nikonos, which had a fixed 35-mm. lens and no automatic focus, meaning that it required both technical skills and proximity to the subjects. “I’m sure that some of my friends got sick of me sticking a camera in their faces,” he says. Click the link in our bio to see more of Witzig’s work from the 1960s and ‘70s. Photograph by @johnwitzig.
A cartoon by @slautow. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Legacy Records, the latest from the hospitality group behind hot spots Charlie Bird and Pasquale Jones, is a genuinely buzzy destination. The menu feels like a careful primer on current trends, including tiny portions of crudo and rotating flavors of gelato. But anyone expecting the same cool factor may be disappointed: both the building and the dining room have the sprawling, swanky, but slightly sterile vibe of a luxury hotel in a blander city. Click the link in our bio to read our full review. Photograph by Zachary Zavislak for TNY.

In a photograph by Wayne Lawrence from his series about Orchard Beach—the Bronx Riviera, as the project titles it—two girls with swim caps stretched tightly over their hair perch symmetrically on the knees of their father, who squats at the ocean’s edge. How many more years, one wonders, until they’re too old to hang out with dad and would rather strike out for summer fun on their own? Click the link in our bio to soak up more of New York City's pools and beaches. Photograph courtesy @waynelawrence.
A cartoon by @drawnbytom. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Today in New York: The 34th New York Salsa Festival takes place at Barclays Center. The city’s love affair with Latin dance music began in the forties with the rise of mambo kings and queens, and shifted focus in the late sixties, when a new assertion of Puerto Rican identity fostered hit-makers like Willie Colón. He'll play today in a lineup that also features Andy Montañez, Tito Nieves, and Oscar D’León. Photograph by @adam.pape for TNY.
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Anthony Bourdain has died at the age of sixty-one. The peripatetic chef turned writer inspired many with the when-in-Rome avidity with which he partook of other customs and cuisines on his travel series “Parts Unknown.” Click the link in our bio to read our 2017 Profile of the chef. Photograph by @will_mebane for TNY.
A cover, from 2011, by Eric Drooker. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Edward Steed. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
“That’s what I get for trying to find love on Tinder,” by @ms.gabriellebell.

Convinced that the unadorned bag she really wanted for herself was not available, Kate Spade decided to make her own. The designer, who died on Tuesday, created a brand that came to represent a kind of Holly Golightly sophistication for the masses. Owning one of her bags was like drinking champagne out of a chipped teacup, or pairing your grandmother’s pearls with a frothy lime-green party dress. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Wendy Maeda/The Boston Globe via Getty.

Before “Sex and the City,” the vast majority of iconic “single girl” characters on television (think: Mary Tyler Moore) had been you-go-girl types—which is to say, actual role models. Then, twenty years ago today, Carrie, Miranda, Samantha, and Charlotte appeared—odder birds by far, jagged, aggressive, and sometimes frightening figures, like a makeup mirror lit up in neon. Click the link in our bio to read Emily Nussbaum’s 2013 look at the first female anti-hero on television. Photograph by Moviestore Collection Ltd/Alamy.
A cartoon by David Sipress. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Robert F. Kennedy was assassinated 50 years ago today. After his funeral at St. Patrick’s Cathedral, in New York, his casket was put on a train to Washington, D.C., where he would be buried in Arlington Cemetery.  A photographer named Paul Fusco took a series of photographs from the window of that train, capturing the crowds who came out to witness Kennedy’s body being carried to its grave. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Paul Fusco/Magnum/Courtesy Danziger Gallery.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz and Marc Philippe Eskenazi. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

On Monday morning, Serena Williams announced that she was pulling out of the French Open with a pectoral muscle injury. Even so, her performance, over three rounds of the tournament, exceeded expectations. Click the link in our bio to read Louisa Thomas on why Williams is an inspiration both on and off the court. Photograph by Tim Clayton/Corbis/Getty.
A cartoon by @emessodoodles. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Porochista Khakpour’s deliberately unheroic memoir, “Sick,” chronicles her experiences with Lyme disease: her halting, years-long journey toward a clear diagnosis, her burgeoning career as a writer and her various love affairs and friendships along the way. It’s a strange book, one that resists the clean narrative lines of many illness memoirs—and raises questions about what we expect of female patients with chronic illness. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @​​francesfdenny for TNY.
Tell us below. A comic by @smallsuture.

For months, even years, at a time, the artist Wendy Ewald has moved into rural communities around the world—from Mexico and Morocco to India and the Netherlands—to teach local children how to use cameras. She says that they create more powerful and more intimate pictures than she could. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @wendytewald/Courtesy Steven Kasher Gallery.
A cartoon by Zachary Kanin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

On a summer day in 1968, the British photographer Tom Murray was invited by a colleague to come along while he photographed the Beatles. The adventure, later known as the Mad Day Out, resulted in a series of pictures around London, including an unforgettable scene of the Beatles sitting next to and leaning over an oldish man seated on a park bench, sound asleep. You can see twenty-three of Murray's rare Beatles photographs on display at Soho Contemporary Art. Photograph by Tom Murray/Courtesy Soho Contemporary Art.
A cartoon by @lianafinck. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo. #NationalDoughnutDay #TNYcartoons

In a behind-the-scenes image from the set of the 1954 film “There’s No Business Like Show Business,” we see Marilyn Monroe doing more or less nothing while an elaborate headdress is being pinned in place and her makeup is being touched up. Yet the actress, who would have turned ninety-two today, exudes a blithe lightness that radiates big, unholy knowledge. Such photographs—used by the studio to document wardrobe, makeup, and hair styling—are a treat because they let us see behind the on-screen character, to who these movie stars really were. Click the link in our bio to see more images from the book “Styling the Stars.” Photograph courtesy Insight Editions/Twentieth Century Fox.
A cartoon by @carolitajohnson. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The artist Hannah Whitaker shot the photos for the three short stories in our Fiction Issue. Click the link in our bio to read Karen Russell’s “Orange World,” David Gilbert’s “Fungus,” and Lu Yang’s “Silver Tiger.” Photographs by @_hannahwhitaker for TNT.

When the Vegas Golden Knights first started winning hockey games, there were jokes about “the Vegas flu,” a theoretical contagion afflicting visiting teams who might be drawn, long past bedtime, to the blackjack tables. Tonight, the team will play in Game 2 of the Stanley Cup Finals. Whether they win or lose, they’re already the most successful and memorable first-year expansion team in the history of North American sports. Click the link in our bio to read about how Ben McGrath’s son became a Golden Knights fan, before the team even technically existed. Photograph by Marc Sanchez/Icon Sportswire/AP.

In April, 2009, Peter Aaron, a veteran architectural photographer, went on a family vacation to Syria. He brought along a Canon 5D that he had modified to render blue skies in dark black and foliage in milky white. His images from that trip amount to a staggering chronicle of Syrian monuments, many of which have since been damaged or destroyed in the war. Click the link in our bio to see more of the personal travelogue, which now carries the weight of historical record. Photographs by @peteraaron.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week, the photographer @jimmangan is taking over our photo department’s account to share a series of images from the Death Valley Superbloom of 2016. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
Insufferable eaters, as drawn by @drawingolive.

In Nigeria, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie is as recognizable as the President. Her face is on billboards. Sometimes, at restaurants, she will ask for the check and discover that someone else has paid for her meal. But, because she is so visible, everything she does or says is scrutinized. Click the link in our bio to read about how the author is coming to terms with global fame. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
A cover by Mark Zingarelli, from 1994, for Memorial Day. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @paulnoth. #TNYcartoons
This week's cover, “Nurture,” by @cosmicsomething. #TNYcovers

The photographer Arthur Fellig, self-insistently known as Weegee the Famous, wanted people to think his monikercame came from being recognized as a human Ouija board—that he got to gritty New York scenes so fast because he was psychic. His success actually had more to do with a bell that connected his room to the Fire Department’s alarms, and the police radio in his ’38 Chevrolet. And his name derived from his early drudgery as a squeegee boy—a dryer of just developed prints—in the Times’ darkroom. Click the link in our bio to see more of his work. Photograph by Weegee/ICP/Getty.

The filmmaker Claire Denis wants her actors and actresses to want her as much as she wants them.” On set “they become, metaphorically, either her babies or her lovers—it’s a bit hard to tell which.” Click the link in our bio to read about the French director's English-language début, "High Life." Photograph by Paul Rousteau for TNY.
A cartoon by Pia Guerra. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by Charles Barsotti. #TNYcartoons

In her series “Drummies,” Alice Mann retrofits the genre of flashy sports photography to capture drum majorettes who are mostly from low-income families in Cape Town. Staying after school to practice is one of the ways that the girls create distance between themselves and “weapons and drugs” that a sign on one school wall warns are not allowed on the premises. It also holds the promise of future scholarships and tuition subsidies. Looking at the images with that in mind, one can see the aspiration that buttresses every pose and practiced smile. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @alicemannnn/Institute.

To see Harvey Weinstein turn himself in on Friday at the same precinct where Ambra Battilana Gutierrez made her report, in the same neighborhood where he caused so many women anguish and pain, was simply cathartic. For all the handwringing about the mob power of #MeToo, the fact is that most men who have assaulted women will not face criminal charges for doing so. Click the link in our bio to read @doreenstfelix on the rush of seeing Weinstein’s perp walk. Photograph by Spencer Platt / Getty
A comic by @maggiejanelarson.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The instantly recognizable art of Takashi Murakami, Japan’s answer to Andy Warhol, has graced handbags, phone cases, skateboards, and album covers. Now his imagery is back in its natural habitat, hanging on walls at the Perrotin gallery, through June 17th. Photograph by @landonnordeman for TNY.

Three years ago, when a team of archaeologists ventured into the Honduran rainforest to explore a mysterious civilization, they found that the animals there appeared never to have seen people before. Spider monkeys gathered in the trees, large cats prowled at night, and venomous snakes abounded. The ecosystem was pristine, as obscure to human knowledge as the lost city itself. Click the link in our bio to read more about what they found. Photographs by Trond Larsen/Conservation International.
A cartoon by Seth Fleishman. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

When Clarissa Glenn’s husband, Ben, was wrongly convicted on drug charges, she set out to prove that he was framed by a Chicago police officer. Even though she struggled to raise their sons alone, suffered from depression, and at times was unemployed, she kept at it—and her efforts started a chain of events that led to a mass exoneration. Click the link in our bio to read about how Chicago is reckoning with years of wrongful arrests. Photograph by @zorajmurff for TNY.
A cartoon by @bruceerickaplan. #TNYcartoons

Stacey Abrams made history last night by becoming the the first black woman to receive a major party’s nomination for governor. Her path to this point has not been a traditional one. Rather than court white moderates to win in Georgia, a state that hasn’t had a Democratic governor since 2003, she emphasized bringing new voters to the polls—particularly minority voters. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by John Bazemore/AP.

This week, the photographer @kelseyemc and the stylist @pandahandler—the image-making duo known as Terrence Caviar—are taking over our photo department's account to share images from "Wardrobe Snacks," their 2017 series of colorful laps. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by P. C. Vey. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

When Alice Mann visited schools in Cape Town to photograph their drum majorettes, the “Drummies” were naturals before the camera. They even acted as self-appointed assistants in the staging of scenes. That playful complicity between the image-maker and her subjects is apparent in the entire series, but most so in an image of Dernika Williams, the youngest of the group. Click the link in our bio to see more from “Drummies.” Photographs by @alicemannnn/Institute.

You’ve probably seen the art of Takashi Murakami before, as it’s graced everything from skateboards to album covers—and recently, in Moscow, it was even charbroiled onto a hamburger. Now you can see his instantly recognizable otaku flowers here in New York, at the Perrotin gallery, through June 17th. Photograph by @landonnordeman for TNY.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week’s cover, “Jump!,” by @gaylekabaker. #TNYcovers
A comic by @willmcphail4.
A cartoon by Jon Adams. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Outside the walls of Windsor Castle, where Prince Harry and Meghan Markle married this morning, a crowd of an estimated hundred thousand is partaking in a sort of trickle-down wedding reception—less grand but perhaps more interesting. Click the link in our bio to see more of the celebration in the streets. Photographs by Immo Klink for TNY.
Prince Harry of Wales and Meghan Markle are now married! And @willmcphail4 is documenting the entire #RoyalWedding for posterity. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more.

In the 1960s, when sixty acres below Canal Street were slated for clearing, Danny Lyon set out with a view camera, slipping in and out of demolition sites from the East River to the Hudson. He photographed the folks leaving buildings and those tearing them down, and, in so doing, documented the social dismantling that buzzes under every project billed as urban renewal. Click the link in our bio to see more of his work. Photograph by @dannylyonphotos/@magnumphotos/Courtesy Cleveland Museum of Art.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
@eflakeagogo draws what it's like to be haunted by pre-mom versions of herself.

Looking at the photograph of Meghan Markle’s father reading online coverage about Meghan and Harry, it is easy to imagine his pride, tinged with his regret at losing his daughter—the photograph emphasizing the suddenly unbridgeable divergence between his world and hers. Learning that the paparazzi shot was in fact staged makes it doubly touching. We can only guess at the deep shame felt by the daughter when confronted with her father’s scheme. Click the link in our bio to read Naomi Fry on why we are all Thomas Markle. Photograph by Jeff Rayner/Coleman-Rayner.com.
A cartoon by @drawingolive. #TNYcartoons

Chip the Chihuahua’s Petfinder profile described him as “a tiny bit bossy,” with “ears for years.” On the site, no pup is ever listed as mean or neurotic or difficult or simply pathetic. Rather, a creatures’ every blemish is turned into a mark of appealing individuality. Click the link in our bio to read about the poetics of Petfinder and a tale of accidental adoption. Photograph by @NotTaylerSmith for TNY.
A cartoon by @larskenseth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Today in New York: “Singlet” opens at the Bushwick Starr. In it, the performance artist Erin Markey draws on everything from Jean Genet’s 1947 play “The Maids” to downloadable couples counselling and Olympic weight lifting in order to explore “the erotic undertones of a friendship.” It’s impossible to take your eyes off her as she matches sirenlike self-possession with off-the-wall non-sequitur humor. Imagine Tilda Swinton crossed with Yogi Berra, but weirder. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.

Wondering whether to spend your time watching BBC America’s “Harry & Meghan: A Very Modern Romance” or Lifetime’s “Harry & Meghan: A Royal Romance”? Don’t worry—@untitledprojectile has already made a definitive sampling of all the Prince-Harry-and-Meghan-Markle television specials. Find it at the link in our bio. Photograph by Alexi Lubomirski/Kensington Palace/Getty.

Tom Wolfe, who died on Monday, took the taste for the potent phrase, the loaded short sentence, the startling intervention, even the wild punctuation, of sixties advertising copy, and turned it into a kind of art. He did something more than get down his time right, as journalists ought to. He found a tone to match the time. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Roger Kisby/Redux.
A cartoon by @carolitajohnson. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The Australian musician Courtney Barnett’s lyrics recall the talky folksingers of the 1960s and 70s, but she has a punk-rock heart. It often feels as if she’s leaning over, conspiratorially, and whispering something just to you: “Dude, can you believe how ridiculous it is to be alive?” Click the link in our bio to read about her new album, “Tell Me How You Really Feel.” Photograph by @yabliko for TNY.

“She pinched my butt, and that was that,” Michael Northrup says of meeting his ex-wife, Pam—whom he photographed often over more than a decade. Some of those photos are now collected in “Dream Away,” a book with a tone of playful intimacy and the private feel of a personal photo album. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @michaelenorthrup/Courtesy Stanley/Barker.
A cartoon by @lianafinck. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week’s cover, “The Swamp,” by @johncuneo3. #TNYcovers

The photographer Rachel LaCour Niesen’s project Save Family Photos is an online archive devoted to gathering images and stories from people around the world. To mark Mother’s Day, here is a selection images of family matriarchs. Click the link in our bio to read the moving reflections from their children and grandchildren. Photographs courtesy @savefamilyphotos.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Gifts your mom actually wants for Mother’s Day, by @hallithbates and her mom, @hopkinssuzy.
A slideshow of our covers, through the years, for Mother's Day. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Edward Frascino. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The chef T. J. Steele is challenging the idea that Mexican food should be inexpensive and informal with Claro. The new restaurant in Gowanus serves several kinds of elevated mole, and treats mezcal like wine—a knowledgeable bartender will walk you through tasting notes for the fifty or so varieties. Click the link in our bio to read our full review. Photograph by @colewilson for TNY.
A cartoon by Edward Frascino. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Bad mom cards, by Roz Chast.

@moakarlberg's photographs, half of which were taken in Sweden and half in Tanzania, capture the faces of women in the final stages of giving birth. While the images emphasize the women’s shared experience—the inward focus and physical determination—if you look closely, you’ll see signs that they are having drastically different experiences. Click the link in our bio to read more about giving birth in different worlds.
A cartoon by @bentschwartz. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In 1920s Paris, Chaim Soutine haunted the Louvre and painted still-lifes in a mélange of styles informed by both Cézanne and van Gogh. His genius peaks in his meat pictures—whose subjects he bought from slaughterhouses and held on to for so long that, according to an oft-told tale, their rotting stench drove his neighbors to call the police. Click the link in our bio to read more about the underrated Russian-French artist. Courtesy ARS, NY.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In her series “Women Crying,” Anne Collier casts a slyly feminist eye on hidebound clichés about emotional women by zooming in on the same kind of vintage romance comics on which Roy Lichtenstein based his paintings. Click the link in our bio to see more of her pointillist portraits of tristesse. Photograph by Anne Collier/courtesy @antonkerngallery.
A cartoon by @mortgerberg. #TNYcartoons

When Ryan Murphy, whose shows include “Glee” and “American Horror Story,” first entered the TV industry, he sometimes struck his peers as an aloof, prickly figure. He has deep wounds from those years, although he admits that he contributed to this reputation. Over time, Murphy has moved steadily from the margins to television’s center. He changed; the industry changed; he changed the industry. Click the link in our bio to read about how Ryan Murphy became the most powerful man in TV. Photograph by @martinschoeller for TNY.

Rihanna is the rare star who has never committed a sartorial misstep at the #MetGala (or perhaps in her whole life). She arrived early, wearing an ornate, beaded white Margiela corset dress with a matching jacket, clutch, and mitre—also known as the hat that the Pope wears. Subsequent guests arrived to fill out her makeshift Vatican City, including @nickiminaj, @sarahjessicaparker, @lanadelrey, and @jaredleto. Click the link in our bio to see more from the Catholic-themed event. Photograph by Kevin Mazur/MG18/Getty.
A cartoon by @mecharliehankin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Today in New York: The @MetCostumeInstitue hosts its annual #MetGala to celebrate the opening of “Heavenly Bodies: Fashion and the Catholic Imagination.” The exhibition includes papal robes and accessories on loan from the Sistine Chapel sacristy, like the dalmatic of Pope Pius IX. Courtesy of the Collection of the Office of Liturgical Celebrations of the Supreme Pontiff, Papal Sacristy, Vatican City. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
A cartoon by Darrin Bell. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week's cover, “Smart Design,” by Joost Swarte. #TNYcovers

In Deana Lawson’s pictures, everything has an otherworldly aura, each space is both the particular and the universal, and each person at once an individual and a symbol, an archetype, an avatar. In “Wanda and Daughters,” it is easy to think of Wanda as a queen, or, if you prefer, an African lioness, protecting her cubs. But you can also read the photograph sequentially rather than sentimentally, moving from face to face, and find a more ambivalent story. Click the link in our bio to read Zadie Smith’s explanation of what that story is. Photograph Sikkema Jenkins & Co. and Rhona Hoffman Gallery, Chicago.
What we'll eat in the future, as illustrated by @saskdraws.
A cartoon by @blisscartoons. #TNYcartoons
A cartoon by Zachary Kanin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The Ortiz brothers, Jose and Irad, will be starting in the six and nine spots (“holes,” in track speak) in today’s Kentucky Derby. Jose, the younger of the pair, will be on Good Magic, and Irad aboard Hofburg. Neither is the favorite, but it’s true that when two Ortizes are in the same race one of them often wins. Could that be the case today? Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by thomas_prior for TNY.

The model Shudu Gram has been courting controversy since she first appeared on Instagram, originating from the fact that she is a C.G.I created by a twenty-eight-year-old white man. Cameron-James Wilson says that he considers @shudu.gram a work of art, and the idea that he might be participating in the tradition of racial expropriation doesn’t seem to have occurred to him. Instead, Wilson is more interested in muddying the already blurred lines between reality and artifice on Instagram. Click the link in our bio to read more. Art courtesy @cjw.photo.

“I became the Forrest Gump of counterterrorism and law enforcement,” Patrick Skinner says, of the almost decade he spent in the C.I.A. running assets in Afghanistan, Jordan, and Iraq. In this time, he came to believe that the most meaningful application of his training and expertise—the only way to exemplify his beliefs about American security, at home and abroad—was to become a community police officer in Savannah, where he grew up. Click the link in our bio to read about why the spy who became a beat cop in Georgia. Photograph by @jonnotherattman for TNY.
A cartoon by @lianafinck. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Today in New York: Heartbeat Opera’s new production of Beethoven’s “Fidelio” opens at Baruch Performing Arts Center, taking the story of a heroic woman risking everything to save her husband from wrongful incarceration and updating it for the Black Lives Matter era. The American soprano Kelly Griffin and the Angolan tenor Nelson Ebo play the faithful couple. Photograph by @mamadivisuals for TNY.
A cartoon by @ellisjrosen. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

While other industries have faced calls for accountability over gender discrimination and harassment, the financial sector had largely escaped public attention—until Lauren Bonner filed a lawsuit against her employer, Point72 Asset Management. Click the link in our bio to read about the case bringing the #MeToo movement to Wall Street. Photograph by @kyokopajama for TNY.

“Whether I want kids is a secret I keep from myself—it is the greatest secret I keep from myself,” Sheila Heti writes in her new novel. In place of telling a story, “Motherhood” asks a question: Should she have a child before it is too late? Click the link in our bio to read more about Heti’s big decision. Photograph by @odey_plus_bebe for TNY.
A cartoon by @tomcheney54. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Watching a young Chloe Sevigny read a fashion magazine made one think of Alexander Woollcott devouring a ten-pound lobster à l’américaine or Casanova undressing a servant girl. “I’m like a fashion-magazine junkie. I love them, but they’re usually pretty lame. By the time they print it, it’s already happened,” she mused, sitting at Stingy Lulu’s, on St. Mark’s Place just off Avenue A, and devouring the just-out September 1994 Vogue. Click the link in our bio to read Jay McInerney’s Profile of the downtown darling from that year. Photograph by Catherine McGann/Getty.
A cartoon by @thepatbyrnes. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“When I’m going out to make work,” the photographer Deana Lawson has said, “usually I’m choosing people that come from a lower- or working-class situation.” Outside a Lawson portrait a person might be working three jobs, just keeping her head above water, struggling. But inside the frame she is beautiful, imperious, unbroken, unfallen. Click the link in our bio to read Zadie Smith on Lawson’s kingdom of restored glory. Photograph Sikkema Jenkins & Co. and Rhona Hoffman Gallery, Chicago.
A cartoon by Pia Guerra. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week’s cover, “Biking in the Rain,” by Jean-Jacques Sempé.  #TNYcovers

There are lots of jokes you could make about Annicka, a new Greenpoint restaurant which operates under Governor Cuomo’s “farm brewery” license. You could roll your eyes at the “Portlandia” aesthetic, or laugh at the fact that the bathroom door handles are made of farm tools. But then you might miss the fact that the food is excellent. Click the link in our bio to read our review. Photographs by @davidwilliasphoto for TNY.
We all know somebody who won. Genetic-lottery tickets, by @jeremywins and @carriesnotscary.
A cartoon by @kimwarp. #TNYcartoons

A cloud can be beautiful, terrible, or both—the embodiment of the sublime. In the photographer Camille Seaman’s cloudscapes, we see a power larger than ourselves. But, as smokestacks and airplanes create new classifications of clouds, it’s difficult to not also see humankind’s self-portrait: potent, defiant, unforgiving. Click the link in our bio for more of her work. Photographs by @camilleseaman.
A cartoon by @jeremywins. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

James Rebanks reveres the unknown generations of men and women who crafted Cumbria’s farming ways—“nobodies,” he calls them—but, since he was a teen, he has had a writer’s self-regard. Maybe that’s why, in 2012, he began tweeting about life as a shepherd. Now he has over 109k Twitter followers and a bestselling memoir. Not to mention 250 sheep to look after (a number that’s growing by the day). Click the link in our bio to go inside the life of a modern shepherd during lambing season. Photograph by @gregorschmatz for TNY.

A few weeks ago, the 9-year-old Alice Kassnove’s ruthless cartoon-captioning nearly broke the Internet. So we brought her in to show us her skills. Here are some Alice originals. Check out @newyorkercartoons’s Instagram story to see her in action.
Decode the captions to reveal what life is really like in D C-T. You can find the answer key at the link in our bio. By @joanaavillez and @mollybethyoung.
This week, @merylmeisler took over our photo department’s account to share images she took on the Lower East Side during the 1970s and 1980s. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The writer Rachel Kushner has owned several motorcycles; she skis like a racer, and rides around town, wearing Rouge Coco lipstick, in a black-cherry 1964 Ford Galaxie. She uses the novel as a place to be flamboyant and funny, and to tell propulsive stories, but mainly as a capacious arena for thinking. Click the link in our bio to read more about her new book, “The Mars Room.” Photograph by @amandademme for TNY.
"Kanye’s 2020 Vision," a cover by Barry Blitt, from 2015. #TNYcovers

The Mexican-American photographer Laura Aguilar, whose work explored the precariousness of existing in a marginalized community within another marginalized community, has died. In her nude self-portraits, Aguilar made the curves and shadows of her round body echo beautifully the shapes of the landscape around her. She was at once part of the American land, and the viewer’s eye, and apart from them. Click the link in our bio to see more of her work. Photograph by Laura Aguilar/Courtesy the artist and the UCLA Chicano Studies Research Center.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Today in New York: George Bernard Shaw’s “Saint Joan” opens at the Samuel J. Friedman Theatre starring Condola Rashad as the warrior, martyr, saint, and troublemaker Joan of Arc. The thirty-one-year-old actress, who has become a force on Broadway in roles like Juliet (opposite Orlando Bloom’s Romeo) and the smiling yet iron-willed daughter in “A Doll’s House, Part 2,” has shown a mixture of poise and fortitude echoing that of her mother, Phylicia Rashad. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.

In 1972, a British photographer named John Myers started taking portraits of his neighbors in and around the town of Stourbridge, England. Like a court painter, he captured the material environs of his subjects as intensely as he suggested their inner life. The resulting black-and-white images, which offer a rich catalogue of early-seventies design choices, also provide a gloss on Britain’s current crisis of national identity. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by John Myers/Courtesy RRB PhotoBooks.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. #TNYcartoons

In a new series of digital-collage photos, Ina Jang cut out the models found in Asian soft-core magazines and photographed just their outer contours, empty from edge to edge, leaving behind not women but woman-shaped absences and the physical postures of sexual offering. The implied beholder—Jang’s true subject—sees only vacant playthings, and the deficits of vision that were there all along. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photographs by @inajang/Courtesy @foleygallery.

Miznon pita is plush, Miznon pita is pillowy—you could happily take a nap on a stack of Miznon pita. The first U.S. outpost of a beloved international chain, started by the Israeli celebrity chef Eyal Shani, opened a few months ago and has already achieved pita primacy at Chelsea Market. Click the link in our bio to read our review. Photographs by @kristaschlueter for TNY.
A cartoon by @blisscartoons. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This week's cover, “Stickball Alley,” by @kadirnelson, captures the thrill and tension of a pickup game. “When I was a kid, we played stickball, dodgeball, kickball, you name it,” he says. Swipe to see an early rough sketch of the cover, and click the link in our bio to read more about Nelson’s influences. #TNYcovers

In 1702, Johannes Schenk composed twelve viol sonatas as a swan song to the now archaic ancestor of the modern violin. Shirley Hunt, Wen Yang, and Sarah Cunningham, of New York Baroque Incorporated, bring the instrument back to life with one of those sonatas, along with works by Bach and Couperin, on April 24th at the Morgan Library. Photograph by Samantha Casolari for TNY.

To make his series “The Sea in the Darkness Calls,” the photographer Bryan Thomas chose an unusual tool—a large-format camera, “kind of old-timey, similar to Ansel Adams’s cameras.” The reason, he said, is that climate change “is not kinetic.” It unfolds slowly, affording time for contemplation. The resulting images are stark and haunted, American Gothic: Florida Edition. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photographs by @bryanthomasphoto.
A cartoon by Christopher Weyant. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cover by Eric Drooker, from 2014, for Earth Day. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @cartoonamy. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

On the second anniversary of Prince's death, a look back on our cover "Purple Rain," by Bob Staake. Click the link in our bio to read about the first, wildly longed-for release to eke out of the artist's vault. #TNYcovers

David Hockney’s recent work plays with photography, collage, and hexagonal canvases—like that of his new painting “Tall Dutch Trees After Hobbema (Useful Knowledge).” Swipe and you might recognize it. This week’s cover features a detail of the painting, which is currently on view at Pace Gallery. Click the link in our bio to learn about the inspiration behind the work. Photographs by @kristaschlueter for TNY.
A cartoon by Edward Steed. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Rudy Giuliani, Trump’s loyal ally, didn’t work for the Trump Administration—until yesterday, when he announced that he was joining the White House legal team that is dealing with special counsel Robert Mueller’s Russia investigation. The news came amid a raft of other developments related to the probe and the Department of Justice—so many, in fact, that it was hard to keep up. Click the link in our bio to have John Cassidy break down what you need to know. Photograph by @markpetersonpixs/Redux.

Today in New York: "Refraction: New Photography of Africa and Its Diaspora" opens at the Kasher gallery in Chelsea, and includes works by the Texas-based Nigerian artist Hakeem Adewumi. Photograph by @hakeemthedreem. Courtesy Steven Kasher Gallery.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A sampling of the many fish in the sea, as drawn by @sranso.

This year, 472 women have entered the race for the House, 57 are likely to run for Senate, and 78 are likely running for governor (a record high). The last time women challenged the overwhelming gender imbalance among elected officials this forcefully was in 1992. And this wave of candidates has some striking features besides its sheer size. Click the link in our bio to meet some of the women running in the midterms. Illustrations by @cristianacouceiro.
A cartoon by @maddiedai. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Each winter, for close to a century now, hundreds of Amish and Mennonite families have travelled south to Pinecraft, a small, sunny neighborhood in Florida. Away from their barns and cows, the typically stringent rules of Anabaptist life are somewhat suspended: Earrings, usually forbidden, can be seen glittering from beneath white bonnets, swimming is allowed, ice-cream cones are a nightly ritual. Click the link in our bio to see more of Dina Litovsky's pictures of this place of brief leisure. Photographs by @dina_litovsky.
A cartoon by J.B. Handelsman. #TNYcartoons
Already filed? Well done! Still procrastinating? Here’s a slideshow of our Tax Day covers to help. #TNYcovers

Yesterday, we toasted @ronanfarrow, who, along with @jodikantor and @mega2e from the @nytimes, was honored with the 2018 #PulitzerPrize for public service, and Jelani Cobb, who was honored as a finalist for commentary. Photographs by @nicoleconflenti.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. #TNYcartoons
The thin red line of breakups, as drawn by @easypiecescomic.

This week's cover, “The Road,” features a detail of a new painting by the artist David Hockney. It adapts “Tall Dutch Trees After Hobbema (Useful Knowledge) 2017,” which is itself a riff on “The Avenue at Middelharnis,” a seventeenth-century work by the Dutch artist Meindert Hobbema. Hockney recently sat down to answer a few questions about it. Click the link in our bio to read the interview. #TNYcovers

When sunlight starts stretching sideways at the end of the day, it stops reaching the water below Sunset Cliffs, a bend in the coast of San Diego where young people flock to jump from high ledges. For his series “Falling,” the photographer John Francis Peters shot bodies vaulting toward the water, buffeted in the air by shards of coastal light. Between the jump and the splash, Peters finds his subjects weightless and seemingly placeless, too. Click the link in our bio to see more images of what it looks like when we fall. Photograph by @jfpetersphoto.

What the photos from Dolce & Gabbana’s multi-day extravaganza, to début its latest Alta Moda line, reveal is a world of opulence beyond opulence, where no material desire is too far-fetched, and where guests who own a thick slice of the world’s pie can feel right at home with their equally deep-pocketed peers. Click the link in our bio for a peek into the events. Photograph by @paridukovic.
A cartoon by @blisscartoons. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The college wrestlers at the N.C.A.A. championships tend to compete year-round. This causes young wrestlers to look haggard but phenomenally fit, a contradiction that the photographer Ben Lowy captures in his post-match portraits from 2016. The athletes are required to wear headgear during collegiate matches but not during practice, and the repeated bruising leaves their ears permanently thick and lumpy, their faces bony and hollowed-out, with cheekbones so high their eyes swell like a boxer's. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photographs by @benlowy for TNY.
Original sin, as told through Eve’s Instagram account. By @hayleyphelan.

The title of Martin Parr’s photography book, “Real Food,” makes it sound like the manifesto of a clean-eating, weight-dropping, soul-lifting life-style guru. But the photos in Parr’s collection have no resemblance to the aspirational-rustic stylings that dominate food photography today. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photographs by @martinparrstudio.
A cartoon by Roz Chast. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This photograph, by @magnuswennman, won the World Press Photo award in the People category: Uppgivenhetssyndrom, or resignation syndrome, is said to exist only in Sweden, and only among refugees. The patients seem to have lost the will to live. “They are like Snow White,” a doctor said. “They just fall away from the world.” Click the link in our bio to read about the trauma of facing deportation.
A cartoon by @joedator. #TNYcartoons

Every day, people generate a volume of trash that weighs roughly as much as a million elephants. By 2050, if things don’t change, the plastic waste in the ocean will outweigh the fish. The photographer Paul Bulteel is deeply interested in this problem. For his book of photographs, “Cycle & Recycle,” Bulteel travelled to recycling plants in Belgium, Luxembourg, Germany, the Netherlands, and France. The result is bewildering, evocative, and often beautiful. Click the link in our bio to see more.

This past weekend, the Italian fashion house Dolce & Gabbana staged a multi-day extravaganza to début its latest Alta Moda line—over-the-top, one-off sartorial creations that are presented biannually in a series of lavish runway shows and then readily snapped up by attending members of the international monied set. Check out our Instagram story for more scenes from the extravaganza. Photograph by @paridukovic.
A cover by @mairakalman, from 2016, for the arrival of spring. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @b_loper. #TNYcartoons

Looking at Edward Mapplethorpe’s portraits of one-year-old children, from his 2016 book “One: Sons & Daughters,” we can’t help but think of others—the faces of the children shown here put us in mind of other children and of what we know of the child’s mind. For when it comes to children, we are between myths. Click the link in our bio to read about baby faces and the myth of the child's mind. Photographs by @edwardmapplethorpe.
Inspirational quotes: Ideal for home or office! By Edward Steed.

Today in New York: Gone are the days when Martha Graham’s dancers performed only works by Graham. From today to April 14th, at City Center, the company presents three distinct programs, each of which contains just one or two examples of vintage Graham. Among the new works, the most intriguing is a world première by the cool minimalist Lucinda Childs, “Histoire,” set to music for harpsichord by Krzysztof Knittel, mixed in with some Astor Piazzolla. The company will also perform Lar Lubovitch’s fluidly musical “The Legend of Ten,” originally made for his own company. Photograph by @hibbard_nash.

Cardi B’s trajectory has been idiosyncratic, but on her songs she is a traditionalist. She is the first to admit that rapping takes work, and that her progress has required intense study. Her début album, “Invasion of Privacy,” is a mercifully cogent thirteen-song breeze that mixes hard-slapping street rap with dashes of velvety, heartbroken R. & B. Click the link in our bio to read our review of her album. Photograph by Sean Zanni / Patrick McMullan via Getty.

The Mark Zuckerberg who arrived at the Hart Senate Office Building on Tuesday afternoon very much resembled an adult. His hair was cut short. His presentation was polished, without glibness or arrogance. The android-smooth forehead, now 33 years old, still appeared unmarked by age or adversity, but there were no flip-flops or pajamas this time. Despite this evident preparation, Zuckerberg did not have much in the way of answers. Click the link in our bio to read about the Facebook C.E.O.'s dorm-room defense in Congress. Photographs by @markpetersonpixs for TNY
A cartoon by @joedator, from 2015. #TNYcartoons
A series of reworked fables; please adjust your ethical framework accordingly, by @maddiedai.
A cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez, from 2013. #TNYcartoons

“Here, in a man-made tropical utopia, the battle between the forces of nature and culture is vivid,” the photographer @anasamoylova writes of the photos of Miami, Florida, that she is posting on our photo department’s account. The series is taken from her ongoing project “Flood Zone,” which focusses on coastal communities dealing with increasingly frequent flooding due to rising sea levels. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.

Junot Díaz breaks the silence of his past: “I never told anyone what happened, but today I’m telling you. And anyone else who cares to listen.” Click the link in our bio to read his account on confronting his childhood trauma. Illustration by @bmwiseman; photograph courtesy the author.
A cartoon by @coreyartpandolph, from 2014. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The photographer Dario Calmese and the sixty-eight-year-old style legend Lana Turner have collaboratively created a work about “Sunday presentation,” or about the ways in which churchgoers—particularly black women churchgoers—consistently infuse glamour and imagination into the realm of faith.
