Click the link in our bio for more. Photographs by @dariothephotog.
A cartoon by @paulnoth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

If you’re a true gourmand and enjoy abandoning all caution with respect to food, then put yourself at the mercy of Krolewskie Jadlo (“king’s feast”), the sole Polish medievalist eatery in the five boroughs. Yes, that is a life-size statue of a cuirassed knight standing guard at the entrance. But behind the mock solemnity of the décor—rust-stained scimitars, faux-candle chandeliers—is a seriousness of culinary intent. Click the link in our bio to read our review. Photograph by @christaanfelber for TNY.

On June 8th, 1968, Robert F. Kennedy’s funeral was held at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in New York. Immediately afterward, the casket was put on a train to Washington, D.C., for burial in Arlington Cemetery. Paul Fusco was aboard, and for eight hours, he shot picture after picture of the crowds who came out to witness Kennedy’s body being carried to its grave. Twenty-one of those photos are part of a new exhibition, entitled “The Train: RFK’s Last Journey,” at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Paul Fusco/Magnum/Courtesy Danziger Gallery.
A millennial’s guide to cocktails, as drawn by @instachaaz.
A cartoon by @tomcheney54. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Brand-new internet quizzes for dark times, by @whitltaylor.
A cartoon by Pat Byrnes. #TNYcartoons
Fresh new looks for spring, by @lianafinck.

Today in New York: The Migratory Bird Treaty Act, passed in 1918, is back in the news. The Trump Administration has proposed rolling back rules that discourage corporations from harming wildlife—for example, a company would no longer be fined for an oil spill. In “Feathers: Fashion and the Fight for Wildlife,” opening today, the New-York Historical Society revisits the treaty’s origins, when crusading environmentalists successfully battled to regulate the fashion industry’s craze for plumed accessories, including the early-twentieth-century fan pictured here. Photograph by @adamkremer for The New Yorker.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._. #TNYcartoons
Whatever it is @tchalamet made you do, @drawingolive is here to tell you that it's not your fault.

The photographer Elle Pérez (who uses the gender-neutral pronouns “they” and “them”) says that they are interested in “this idea of making work where you are,” of building a world wherever they bring their camera. Their first solo show in New York, at 47 Canal Gallery through April 8th, consists of just nine images, and makes public an appreciation of what happens in private, makes love enmeshed in the practice of making images. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @elleperex Courtesy/47 Canal.
A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“There is no greater agony than bearing an untold story inside you,” Maya Angelou wrote, in her memoir “I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings.” The poet and civil-rights activist, who was born ninety years ago today, lived a public life that spanned decades and received the National Medal of Arts and the Presidential Medal of Freedom, as well as a nomination for the Pulitzer Prize. Click the link in our bio to look back at her life in pictures. Photograph © Chester Higgins, Jr./chesterhiggins.com.

A cover by Barry Blitt, from 2015, on the 50th anniversary of Martin Luther King, Jr.,'s death. Click the link in our bio to read Jelani Cobb on why it is either damning irony or inspiring continuity—or, possibly, both—that this day falls amid the largest antigun-violence mobilization that we have seen since King departed. #TNYcovers
@mairakalman draws her life in three cakes. Click the link in our bio for a recipe.
A cartoon by Teresa Burns Parkhurst. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“You have to keep shining a light on things,” the documentary filmmaker Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy says. Her films, which have won two Oscars and three Emmys, range from reportage on xenophobia in South Africa to an inquiry into the ethics of honor killings in Pakistan. Click the link in our bio to find out why she hopes her documentaries make their audiences angry. Photograph by Alex Majoli/Magnum for TNY.

From the 1970s until her death last August, the photographer Arlene Gottfried combed New York City’s streets, parks, beaches, subways, and night clubs, in search of the shock of recognition one sometimes finds in perfect strangers. Her first posthumous exhibition, which is on view through the end of April, includes fifty photographs that capture her fantastic openness. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Arlene Gottfried/courtesy Daniel Cooney Fine Art.

It may be snowing outside, but The New Yorker Spring Sale is on. Save 50%. Plus, get a free tote bag. Sale offer valid in the U.S. only. International offers with the tote are available for as low as $12. Click the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.
A cartoon by @paulnoth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This week’s cover, “Gluten-Free Gluten,” by Bruce McCall. “The cover solves an eternal puzzle: Where do the Cart People eat?” he says. Click the link in our bio to read more about his inspiration. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Mike Twohy. #TNYcartoons
Instead of colorful eggs, we've rounded up a selection of our Easter covers for you to enjoy. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @joedator. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
The world's most demanding cat, as drawn by P. C. Vey.

Craving warmer weather? Perhaps a trip to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, where the Japanese pink pussy willows are already afuzz and the cherry trees are beginning to blossom, is in order. Inside the Steinhardt Conservatory’s Desert Pavilion, it actually feels like spring. Photograph by @paridukovic.
A cartoon by @mecharliehankin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

A few weeks ago, the Harlem photographer Kwame Brathwaite arrived in Queens to shoot his first commission in more than two decades, a portrait of the artist @joannepetitfrere for our magazine. To prepare for the shoot, his son, Kwame, Jr., worked with @newyorkerphoto to decode the technical aspects of his father’s previous work. In these nineteen-sixties portraits, the skin and hair of the Grandassa models has a haptic quality, created by soft glowing light, an absence of shadows, and a palette of earth and jewel tones. Click the link in our bio to read more from @siobhanbohnacker about the making of the portrait. Photographs by @kwamebphoto/ Courtesy Philip Martin Gallery.

We’re so used to white being the color of Western figurative sculpture that to contemplate the 127 colored renditions of human bodies in “Like Life: Sculpture, Color, and the Body,” at the Met Breuer, is to fight off regarding them as discursive illustrations. You may disagree, relishing an effect, at once scholarly and populist, like that of a TED talk. Anyhow, go see. But first, read Peter Schjeldahl's review, at the link in our bio. Photograph courtesy Estate of Duane Hanson/VAGA, New York.
A cover by Mark Ulriksen, from 2001, for Opening Day. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @emessodoodles. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Among the photos of North Korea's Kim Jong Un’s surprise encounter with China's Xi Jinping, this week, one portrait invites closer inspection. The Chinese President wears a tight, faintly irritated smile and a deep-navy Western business suit—while Kim, thirty years younger, is a man out of time, with a white-wall pompadour from the 1950s and a pinstripe outfit of no easy description. The two men shake hands, balancing the weight of self-interest, dignity, and mutual suspicion. Click the link in our bio for more on why Kim Jong Un went to China. Photograph from KCNA/KNS/AP.

“I scour estate sales, bookstores, garage sales, other people’s cabinets,” Carmen Winant says, of the found photographs of women in various stages of labor and childbirth that make up her new book and exhibition (currently on view at MoMA). Birth, these images suggest, is a surpassingly intimate event, animal and violent and mysterious and beautiful. It is also ordinary, universal. Click the link in our bio to see more from “My Birth.” Photograph courtesy @carmen.winant/SPBH Editions and ITI Press.
A cartoon by @slautow. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Britney Spears has long been almost uniquely incompatible with the fashion industry. She was not a designer’s girl; in fact, she communicated best when shedding clothes. Now she’s the face of Kenzo’s retrophilic La Collection Memento, which recalls the 1986 début of Kenzo Jeans with miniature backpacks, lace-up thigh-high boots, and underwear made from denim. Click the link in our bio to find out why the campaign seems almost redemptive. Photograph courtesy @kenzo.

“Spring is like a perhaps hand,” E. E. Cummings wrote. Sure enough, this year, on the second official day of spring, New Yorkers were dealt a big maybe-not, when the fourth nor’easter of March arrived. Meanwhile, at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the Japanese pink pussy willows were already afuzz; soon, the cherry trees will begin to blossom. But, whatever the conditions are like outside, visitors to the Steinhardt Conservatory’s Desert Pavilion are guaranteed a stint of warm weather. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
A cartoon by @kuperart. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Marianne Elliott’s past two hits on Broadway each won the Tony Award for Best Play—as well as the best-director prize, making her the only woman with more than one Tony for directing. Now, she takes on Tony Kushner’s “Angels in America.” Click the link in our bio to read about how the British stage director wrestled with the notoriously difficult play, and with its writer. Photograph by @geordiewood for TNY.

Today in New York: Macy’s kicks off its annual two-week flower show—featuring ornate, aromatic displays of flora from around the country—at the Herald Square flagship store. This year’s theme is “Once Upon a Springtime,” which draws on the mythical, soft-focus forestry of wonderlands and fairy-tale kingdoms. Photograph by Barry Fidnick.

In the six weeks since the young survivors of Parkland, Florida, jump-started a new movement for gun control, its leadership has managed to broaden the locus of concern beyond mass shootings at comfortable suburban schools like Marjory Stoneman Douglas, to gun violence in urban neighborhoods as well. Click the link in our bio to read about the extraordinary inclusiveness of the #MarchForOurLives. Photographs by @markpetersonpixs/Redux for TNY.
A cartoon by @mecharliehankin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

After every mass shooting, there’s a public outcry, but it frequently fades without real progress. As thousands of students and parents gather in Washington, D.C., for the #MarchForOurLives, something feels profoundly different. How do you define or explain a tipping point? Click the link in our bio for updates from the march. Photographs by @markpetersonpixs/Redux for TNY.
@eflakeagogo takes on her daughter's bullies.
A cartoon by @tomcheney54. #TNYcartoons

Nina Delibash was just one of the thousands of people who were executed every day during the Soviet Great Terror. In 2016, as Russians, even those formerly dedicated to preserving history, have come to think that these numbers may have been exaggerated, the photographer Misha Friedman and the writer Masha Gessen set out to document the memory—or the lack of memory—of Stalin’s Gulags in Putin’s Russia. Click the link in our bio to see more of what they found. Photograph by @indeepborscht.

Shia LaBeouf’s style has stirred interest among menswear enthusiasts not because it is outrageous but, rather, because it is just the slightest bit off. He has a habit of stuffing his pants into his socks, or tucking his sweatshirt into his pants—small but significant diversions from the norm that reveal the underlying conventions that most of us adhere to, and open up a path to reconsider them anew. Click the link in our bio to read about how LaBeouf became a style icon in Uggs. Photograph from Alamy.
A cartoon by Zachary Kanin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

When Larry Fink began photographing Jerry Brown for our Profile of the California governor, it was during a meeting with a group of educators. But that didn’t stop him from moving in. “I see his shoulders, and his head, and his hands gestating, and my immediate response—and this is without meeting the governor—is to get in really tight,” he says. The photographer, whose work is known for its signature intimacy, remembers Brown asking: “Can you stand back a little?” Swipe to see how the portraits turned out, then click the link in our bio to read the Profile. Behind-the-scenes photo by Jonno Rattman. Portraits by @larryfinkphoto for TNY.

In the fourteen years since “Mean Girls” came out, the lives of teen girls have only become more fraught, with Snapchat chronicling every after-school power play. The musical adaptation, with an updated script by Tina Fey, is now in previews at the August Wilson. Does that mean “fetch” will finally happen? Photograph by @elizabethrenstrom for TNY.
@maggiejanelarson draws Copey, the eighth dwarf who just deals with it. (He’s fine.)
A cartoon by Edward Koren. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Cheyenne Dalton, 17, took up shooting after she was recruited by a professional trainer at a concealed-carry course taken by her mother, who wanted to protect herself from crime. Now, @cheyennedaltonshoots is a two-time ladies' world champion in an event that involves a pistol and a rifle, and she’s sponsored by an ammunition company. Click the link in our bio to read more about how gun-advocacy groups and manufacturers are catering to the next generation of American gun owners. Photograph by @sharifhamza.

The new paintings in Barnaby Furnas's current show, "Frontier Ballads," were made with the aid of robotic technologies, designed specifically for the artist with the support of the M.I.T. Media Lab. See them at Marianne Boesky gallery until April 18th. Photography courtesy the artist and @marianneboeskygallery, New York and Aspen.
A cartoon by @paulnoth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

George Rodriguez’s photographs of the East L.A. “blowouts”—in which thousands of Mexican-American students protested school conditions with an organized walkout—serve as a visual reminder that teens have long been at the forefront of demanding political change. Contrasted with his later images of Van Morrison, the Jackson 5, and Eazy-E, we can see two seemingly disparate L.A. worlds: one fantasy-filled and glamorous, the other gritty and politically attuned. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by George Rodriguez.

Today in New York: Charli XCX headlines Elsewhere’s big room, performing from “Pop 2,” the bubblegum mixtape she released in December. A product of the mid-aughts MySpace music era, when the social-networking site first became a viable platform for artist discovery, the singer is slated to perform with Taylor Swift’s “Reputation” stadium tour this spring. Photograph by Noam Galai/WireImage via Getty.
A cartoon by @carolitajohnson. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

A number of years ago, a young painting conservator entered a forgotten storeroom in a Florentine villa and stumbled on a pile of Louis Vuitton steamer trunks. She opened them to discover a collection of exquisite dresses, the kind usually seen only in movies or museums. Closer inspection revealed silk labels, hand-woven with the name “Callot Soeurs.” Click the link in our bio to read more about the discovery of one of the most important archives of gowns by the Paris haute-couture house Callot Soeurs. Photograph by @paridukovic.
A cover by Constantin Alajalov, from 1935, for St. Patrick's Day. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @humanitybytes. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

When the photographer Dario Calmese met the Harlem style legend Lana Turner, at Abyssinian Baptist Church, he was immediately drawn to her radiant self-presentation. He asked to photograph her for a class project, which soon turned into a collaborative a work about “Sunday presentation,” or about the ways in which churchgoers—particularly black women churchgoers—consistently infuse glamour and imagination into the realm of faith. His photographs are now on display at the Projects + Gallery, in St. Louis. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photographs by Dario Calmese.
An early look at next week's cover, "Exposed," by Barry Blitt. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @lianafinck. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

A groundbreaking litigator for women’s rights before being appointed to the bench, Ruth Bader Ginsburg has worn many aspects in her eighty-five years. On the Justice’s birthday, flip through some photographs of her as a girl in Brooklyn, as a law graduate who left Columbia as co-valedictorian (but with no job offers), as a young mother, and as an advocate whose greatest legacy may be in the cases that she argued before what was then an all-male Supreme Court—and won. Link in bio. Photographs from the collection of the Supreme Court of the United States.

Like a Cavaillon melon or a piece of Sèvres porcelain, Chanel No. 5 comes from a specific place. On fifty acres in Pégomas, France, the Mul family grows jasmine and roses exclusively for the brand to make its perfume. “We have a phrase, ‘la fleur au flacon’—the flower into the bottle,” Olivier Polge, Chanel’s head perfumer, says. In the end, each thirty-millilitre bottle represents the afterlife of a thousand Pégomas jasmine flowers and twelve Pégomas roses. Click the link in our bio to see more of the process. Photograph by @paridukovic. Text by @laurenzcollins.
A cartoon by Mary Lawton. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Last Saturday, as the city’s art scene was bogged down by eight art fairs, “All About Frank” popped up on the second floor of a town house in Little Italy. The weeklong exhibition is a free-associative riff on the syllable “frank,” from Walter Robinson’s breezy paintings of mustard-frilled frankfurters to Andrea Bergart’s teen-dream abstractions of Lisa Frank Trapper Keepers. Click the link in our bio to read about why the show presents a refreshing counterpoint after Armory Week. Photograph courtesy @andreabergart/SPRING/BREAK Art Show.
Subway performers, as drawn by @willmcphail4.

If you’re here, you’ve probably seen a photo of the India Mahdavi-designed Gallery at Sketch—the most Instagrammed restaurant in London. Its color has been described as dusty pink, bubble-gum pink, baby pink, and—by a Reddit user—as “getting drunk inside a vagina.” But @indiamahdavi calls it “pink that is like the essence of pink.” She is a sort of supertaster for color, a possessor of perfect chromatic pitch, which she seems to experience as taste, touch, feel, and smell. Click the link in our bio to read more about the designer’s life and work. Photograph by @leandro.farina for TNY. Text by @laurenzcollins.
A cartoon by Bishakh Som, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

A viewer looking too quickly at Deana Lawson’s hyper-staged portraits could think that the saturated images were found family photos, extracted from boxes in an attic. She has a knack for identifying the strangely potent components of black interiors that mean nothing and so much—the Michael Jackson poster, unframed on the wall; the light of the unshaded bulb; the devotional candle, unlit. The scenes look natural, and yet, in their organization, distantly painterly. Click the link in our bio to read more about the artist. Photograph by Deana Lawson/courtesy @sikkemajenkins.

Three decades ago, a crew of hair stylists began flaunting their most fantastic designs at night clubs around Detroit. “Hair Wars”—equal parts performance art and promotion—is still going strong, and it arrives at MOMA PS1 on March 18th. Among the participants is @joannepetitfrere, who models her own creation in this portrait taken by Kwame Brathwaite, a photographer who helped to pioneer the “Black Is Beautiful” movement, in the 1960s. Photograph by @kwamebphoto for TNY.
A cartoon by Edward Steed. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This week's cover, "In Full Bloom," was inspired by the headwear at the Spring 2018 Valentino show, in Paris. “I’m always looking at the couture shows, and Philip Treacy’s hats are completely captivating,” the artist @mairakalman says. “A painter can’t help but paint them.” #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This may look like a typical plate of crudo. But, in fact, these slippery pink slices of fish contain between two and five milligrams of THC. Restaurant-quality dishes that just happen to incorporate cannabis aren’t hard to find in cities like Portland and L.A., but in New York, where distribution of even a single joint is still considered a misdemeanor, cannabis is finding culinary outlets Prohibition-style. Our food critic @hannahgoldfield takes us inside an invitation-only marijuana dinner party. Link in bio. Photograph courtesy Krug Studios.

If there’s a Mozart opera in need of updating at the Met, it’s “Così Fan Tutte,” which since 1996 has been presented in a gentle and sunny production that largely ignores the show’s complex musings on men, women, power, and society. Its new staging, by Phelim McDermott, evokes Coney Island in the nineteen-fifties, with a troupe of carnival performers backing a cast that includes the radiant comedienne Kelli O’Hara. See it beginning March 15th. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
A cartoon by Bob Eckstein. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“Jane the Virgin” is not a guilty pleasure. Instead, the show is a joyful manifesto against that very putdown, a bright-pink filibuster exposing the layers in what the world regards as shallow. Click the link in our bio to read our TV critic Emily Nussbaum on why “Jane the Virgin” should come up more often when we talk about visually provocative television. Photograph by Patrick Wymore courtesy The CW.
A cartoon by Edward Koren. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

"I was the first one to write it like the women lived it,” Loretta Lynn has said. In 1975, she released her single “The Pill,” and, like several of her other songs, it was banned. We learn why on the first episode of “Cocaine & Rhinestones,” an opinionated, feverish, wildly entertaining podcast about twentieth-century American country music, written and hosted by Tyler Mahan Coe. Click the link in our bio to read @asarahlarson’s review. Photograph by Sylvia Pitcher/Redferns/Getty.

Even at Atlanta's Hartsfield-Jackson airport (the busiest airport in the world), the photographer Mark Steinmetz finds moments of intimacy and solitude. A baggage cart becomes an unlikely beach chair, and a sidewalk a waterfront. A jumbo jet passing overhead blends into a tree, and, beneath it, kudzu continues to grow unimpeded—reminding us that the natural world remains supreme, that even our unnatural ability to fly is less impressive than the rising of the sun or the moon. Click the link in our bio to see more of his work. Photograph by Mark Steinmetz.
A cartoon by Frank Cotham. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“People are always asking me, ‘Who will you pass the torch to?’ The question makes me angry. There is no one torch—there are many torches—and I’m using my torch to light other torches,” Gloria Steinem says. Click the link in our bio to revisit our 2015 Profile of the woman who has spent her life on the feminist frontier. Photograph by @inezandvinoodh for TNY. #InternationalWomensDay
A slideshow of our covers, through the years, for #InternationalWomensDay. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @carolitajohnson. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Where would you rather be? This cover by H O Hofman, from 1927, has us dreaming of a tropical vacation. #TNYcovers

One of the pleasanter aberrations of the Trump Era is the emergence of Robert Mueller as a fashion icon. With his discreetly striped Brooks Brothers suits, white shirts (only white shirts), and Casio DW-290 sport watch, the former F.B.I. director’s sartorial rhetoric encodes heroic values. He is armored in the good, clean, honest look of an extremely civil servant, unaffected and, therefore, inimitable. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Doug Mills/NYT/Redux.
Wondering what to have for dinner tonight? Try one of these twenty-minute meals, as drawn by @jessicaolien.
A cartoon by @paulnoth. #TNYcartoons

This week, @billgaaskins took over our photo department's account to share images from his book "Good & Bad Hair." This photo, of Tamara and Tireka on Easter Sunday in Baltimore, 1995, is the most published portrait from the series. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.

“I’m on the subway all the time,” the artist @jkroik says, about her inspiration for this week’s cover, "Next Stop: Spring." “It’s a great place to let your imagination loose and get ideas. You’re surrounded by so many people and stories.” #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Jack Ziegler. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Don't miss all of @j.a.k._'s live-drawings from last night's #Oscars ceremony on @newyorkercartoons.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz and Marc Philippe Eskenazi. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cover by Bruce McCall, from 2012, for the #Oscars. #TNYcovers

Sometime in the 1980s, riding the monorail into Tokyo, Naoya Hatakeyama had an epiphany about limestone—namely, that it was everywhere, except in the vast holes where it used to be. “The quarries and the cities,” he wrote, “are like negative and positive images of a single photograph.” His career could be described as a decades-long quest for that photo. Click the link in our bio to see more of his work. Photographs courtesy Aperture/Minneapolis Institute of Art.

In 1961, Charlayne Hunter-Gault was one of two black students who desegregated the University of Georgia. Now, she says, such civil-rights history should inspire those fighting for gun control. Click the link in our bio to read her essay on finding hope in the #NeverAgain movement. Photograph by Joseph Scherschel/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty.
A cartoon by Edward Steed. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Is it summer yet? A cover by Adrian Tomine, from 2009, which perfectly captures our feelings about this weather. #TNYcovers

Today in New York: “David Bowie Is” opens at the Brooklyn Museum. The exhibition displays four hundred items—costumes, handwritten lyrics, album art, videos—from the artist’s personal archive, including this photo-collage, made from production stills from the movie “The Man Who Fell to Earth.” Courtesy the David Bowie Archive, StudioCanal, and the Victoria and Albert Museum.
A cartoon by @naviedm. #TNYcartoons

Arriving at the Capitol on Tuesday, to testify before the House Intelligence Committee, Hope Hicks turned toward the camera and gave a perfect, ten-out-of-ten smize. She smized as if her life depended on it—which, to some extent, it did. If you’re going to tell Congress that working as the communications director for the Trump White House involves telling only “white lies,” you’d better come with your game face on. Click the link in our bio to read about whether there is something more to Hicks’s expression in Chip Somodevilla’s photo. Photograph by @somophoto/Getty.

Janelle Monáe is the purest interpretation of the pop star as cipher—a human on whom misfits of race, of love, and of gender can project their own aspirational fictions. She has taken the concept album to complex heights; by now, the most surprising thing she could do would be to perform as herself. Click the link in our bio to read @doreenstfelix on the artist’s new single (and video for) “Make Me Feel.” Image via YouTube.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
@eflakeagogo draws the fallout of mommy rage.

The photographer Sally Mann makes work so rooted in place that it is inseparable from history, from lore, and from the effects of slavery. She doesn’t assume that she is speaking about the black experience but about a black experience—one that is linked to the Virginia that made her. Her view is that the South can be unbearable to look at. And yet she makes it bearable enough to make a photograph from it. Click the link in our bio to see more of her work. Photograph by Sally Mann.
A cartoon by @ellisjrosen. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

No one disputes that Pablo Escobar was a murderer, a torturer, and a kidnapper. But he was loved by many in Medellín, and, increasingly, he is an object of fascination abroad. So-called “narcoturistas” now visit Colombia to see the places where the drug lord lived and worked. Click the link in our bio to read about how Escobar’s posthumous celebrity is being received in the country he once terrorized. Illustration by Nicolas Ortega.

How does law enforcement work in a place in constant crisis? The answer is that it doesn’t, not really. In Flint, Michigan, one of the nation's poorest and most violent cities, law enforcement is, according to one officer, “scraping the bottom of the barrel, just trying to keep up.” Click the link in our bio to go inside the city’s broken police department. Photographs by @canepari_til_i_die.
A cartoon by Alex Gregory. #TNYcartoons

As a boy, Donald Glover wanted to be a wedding planner. Instead, he has been a sketch comic, a standup comedian, a writer, an actor, a D.J., a musician, and a budding movie star. “He can push the envelope in all these different areas,” Ryan Coogler, the writer and director of “Black Panther,” says. “And it’s not that difficult for him.” Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @awolerizku for TNY.

This week’s cover, “Golden Opportunity,” by Chris Ware, nods at a tumultuous year in the film industry, during which revelations of sexual misconduct in Hollywood helped ignite the #MeToo movement. “For too long,” Ware says, “we have forgotten that, while actors like Clara Bow, Marilyn Monroe, or Lupita Nyong’o may be film stars, they are also human beings, subject to the totality of life.” #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Leo Cullum. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Today in New York: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center proudly presents the Danish String Quartet, which has made a true niche for itself with its unvarnished but elegant sound and its astute programming of modern, classic, and folk-derived music. Photograph by Caroline Bittencourt.

Jewish deli food and appetizing are not the world's sexiest culinary traditions (it's hard to sound cool asking for a "schmear"), but in the past few years a wave of restaurants with young proprietors have remarketed pastrami sandwiches and bagels with smoked fish to appeal to a new generation. At 2nd Floor Bar & Essen (Yiddish for “food”), above the 2nd Ave Deli, on the Upper East Side, the millennial makeover goes a step further: Old World dishes are given the fussy small-plate treatment. Click the link in our bio to read the full review. Photograph by Zachary Zavislak for TNY.
A cartoon by Alex Gregory. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“We’re just trying to make art, have fun, and not feel like idiots,” the eighteen-year-old photographer Colin Combs says, speaking of his friends (who are also often his subjects). Moony and unruffled, they laze together in parking lots, sprint home through rainstorms, and cuddle beneath grubby duvets, doing their best to bear the work of the world. Click the link in our to see more. Photographs by @heliumpaperweight.

During the White House’s “listening session” with survivors of mass shootings, on Wednesday, the photographer Carolyn Kaster caught President Trump fiddling with a list of questions written for him. The final item on the list was the most prominent: “I hear you.” While it’s not news that Trump has an essential inability to lead in times of crisis, what must routinely frighten us is that he needs to be provided with basic cues to convincingly play the human in relation to any person who is not himself. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @ckaster/AP.

Today in New York: Tyler, the Creator, a rapper-songwriter, clothing designer, and director, plays Madison Square Garden. Since 2011, when he emerged as the central member of Odd Future, he’s grown from a foulmouthed seedling into something more refined. His latest album, “Flower Boy,” traces a mind in transition and a body in constant motion, with confessional stories and baroque production that draw from the best of aughts-era outsider pop. Photograph by @durimel for TNY.
A cartoon by @kimwarp. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Queso is not nearly as simple as one might think—just ask Chipotle. A new cookbook by Lisa Fain, of the popular food blog Homesick Texan, makes it clear that those who stick to the classic Velveeta-and-Ro-Tel recipe are missing out on the dish’s surprising variety and versatility. Click the link in our bio to follow our food critic on her search for the truth about queso. Photograph by Suzi Pratt/Shutterstock.
A foolproof guide to achieving literary success, as drawn by @willmcphail4.
A cartoon by P.C. Vey. #TNYcartoons
A cartoon by P.C. Vey. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

When ISIS began targeting Yazidis in Iraq, intending to wipe them out, the U.S. State Department struggled to intervene. Then a group of Yazidi immigrants marched to the White House with a three-point plan to save their people. Click the link in our bio to read about the daring plan to save a religious minority from ISIS. Photograph by @moisessaman/Magnum.

Missing the former President today? The new podcast “Making Obama,” from WBEZ Chicago, helps the Obama-nostalgic to push past wistfulness and despair by reacquainting us with who @BarackObama was before he became mythologized. In six episodes, the series traces his career from his arrival in Chicago to his keynote speech at the 2004 D.N.C. Click the link in our bio to read @asarahlarson’s review. Photograph by Charles Ommanney/Getty.
A cover by Robert Weber, from 1990, for Presidents' Day. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Liam Francis Walsh. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

International offers with the tote are available for as low as $12. Click the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.
This week's cover, “Slippery Slopes,” by @markulriksenart. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by David Sipress. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

If you can’t afford to try Masa Takayama’s sushi mecca Masa—which at at $595 per person, before drinks and tax, must be the most expensive prix fixe in the city—head to Tribeca, where the chef opened his much more casual Tetsu last November. The sushi is impeccable. Click the link in our bio for our full review. Photograph by @jamespomerantz for TNY.

On November 13, 2015, Henry Worsley set out from the coast of Antarctica, hoping to achieve what his hero, Ernest Shackleton, had failed to do a century earlier: to trek on foot from one side of Antarctica to the other. The journey was more than a thousand miles, and would traverse what is arguably the most brutal environment in the world. Click the link in our bio to read David Grann’s story of how a solitary trek became a singular test of character. Photograph courtesy Shackleton Foundation.
A cartoon by @citycyclops. #TNYcartoons

Peter Hujar is best known for his deeply felt, often sexually charged portraits of bohemian East Village habitués. But some of his first, and most enduring, subjects were animals. The photographer's richly varied oeuvre is finally getting its full due, partly thanks to a travelling retrospective that is at The Morgan Library & Museum through May 20th. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photographs courtesy Peter Hujar Archive, Pace/MacGill Gallery, and Fraenkel Gallery.

The painter Tarsila do Amaral is so famous in Brazil that forty-three years after her death, an homage was paid to her 1929 painting “Setting Sun” during the closing of the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Olympics. The landscape hangs now at MoMA, in the artist’s first-ever museum exhibition in the U.S. See it through June 3rd. Image Courtesy Tarsila do Amaral Licenciamentos.
A cartoon by @joedator. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
@jjoongie asked if this looks like research or pleasure. You know what our answer is. 😏 Share your favorite magazine moments using #newyorkerinthewild, and we might regram you.
A cartoon by Mick Stevens. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Kesha (Mama) Morse is the president of an organization that teaches inner-city kids about a neglected aspect of American history: black cowboys. According to scholars, one in four cowboys working in Texas during the golden age of westward expansion was black. Many others were Mexican, mestizo, or Native American—a far more diverse group than Hollywood stereotypes of the cowboy would suggest. Click the link in our bio to see images from a 2017 exhibit at the Studio Museum in Harlem, entitled “Black Cowboy.” Photograph by @bradtrent.

Mikaela Shiffrin, who just won Olympic gold in the women's giant slalom, dominates her sport with the kind of predictability and grace that draws in casual viewers, awes the experts, and inspires a lot of super-slo-mo check-that-out. Before she competes again on Friday, revisit Nick Paumgarten's Profile of the American Alpine ski racer. Link in bio. Photograph by Tim Clayton/Corbis/Getty.
Culturally relevant valentines, as drawn by @ohoksophie.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Can’t find love this Valentine's Day? Here’s a slideshow of #TNYcovers instead.
A cartoon by Robert Weber. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cover by Rea Irvin, from 1926, for Mardi Gras. #TNYcovers

In @KehindeWiley’s presidential portrait of @BarackObama, his face is all gravitas (that little smirk notwithstanding) but he’s tieless, his posture at least semi-casual. He’s the leader of the free world, but also a guy you might know, taking it easy after work. As President, Obama was exceptional and relatable; aloof and an empath; a global celebrity and a ponderous professor; a radical presence but somehow, simultaneously, a company man. Will that balance, captured so well in Wiley’s portrait, persist? Click the link in our bio to read @vinsoncunningham's take on the painting. Image © Kehinde Wiley.

Calaya is confident, quirky, and creative. Baraka is laid-back and attentive to his troop. A matchmaking algorithm paired them both—and they were smitten from the beginning. Click the link in our bio to read about how a dating site for gorillas is now a key to survival of a species officially considered to be critically endangered. Photograph by Connor Mallon/Smithsonian’s National Zoo.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In 2015, the Dutch photographer Robin de Puy, riding her motorcycle through Nevada, discovered a skinny youth named Randy. Over the next two years, she travelled to the U.S. three times to take hundreds of photos of him (with his family's permission). In exchange, Randy asked only that de Puy kiss a live, flopping trout. Click the link in our bio to see more of this joyous portrait of rural American boyhood. Photograph courtesy The Ravestijn Gallery.

Today in New York: The Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show kicks off at Madison Square Garden. This pup, a one-and-a-half-year-old Sussex spaniel named CH Tara’s N Primetime Dark Star Imperial Stout, is competing for the first time—at the Garden, she’ll just be called Star. Photograph by @grantcornett for TNY.
A cartoon by Alex Gregory. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The eagerly anticipated release of the Marvel movie “Black Panther,” on February 16th, has sent BAM Cinématek to the archives for “Fight the Power: Black Superheroes on Film.” The offerings include independent and low-budget films that set the tone for black action heroes, including “Cleopatra Jones,” from 1973, starring Tamara Dobson as a federal agent who works undercover as a model while fighting to destroy a drug cartel. The film series runs until February 18th. Photograph from Entertainment Pictures/Alamy.

This week, the conceptual photographer @nakeya_brown took over our photo department’s account to share her practice, which centers itself on black female subjectivity, black beauty, and black womanhood. Follow @newyorkerphoto to learn more about the series “If Nostalgia Were Colored Brown,” and to see more of her work.
A cartoon by @rozchast. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

On January 30th, a government-led media blackout shut down Kenya’s major TV networks, to prevent them from covering an event where the opposition candidate Raila Odinga planned to declare himself the “people’s President of the Republic of Kenya.” But recent signs of deteriorating democracy in the country have extended well beyond attacks on the press. Click the link in our bio to read about Kenya’s dangerous path toward authoritarianism. Photograph by Luis Tato/AFP/Getty.
A cartoon by Sam Gross. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“I don’t know how I did it,” Danh Vo says, of his rise to prominence in the contemporary art world. His use of ready-made materials and artifacts (his work has included kitchen appliances, furniture, historical documents, and more) challenges the whole idea of aesthetic authorship. Today, his first big survey show in the U.S. opens at the @guggenheim. Click the link in our bio to read our Profile of the artist. Photograph by José Luis Cuevas for TNY.
How to survive a cold, as drawn by @drawnbytom. 🤧

With her bold experiments in subject matter, color, modelling, and brushwork, Paula Modersohn-Becker—who was born on this day in 1876— was among the painters who created modernism in the first years of the twentieth century. That an artist of such gifts was a virtual unknown in North America seemed all the more amazing given the dramatic details of her short, tragic life. Click the link in our bio to read more. Image courtesy of Kunsthandel Wolfgang Werner KG, Bremen/Berlin.
A cartoon by Teresa Burns Parkhurst. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In August, @vinsoncunningham wrote that this could prove to be the defining image of the White House’s Scaramucci moment. That era seems to have come to a close. 
Corey Lewandowski: Fired, June, 2016 
Omarosa Manigault: Fired, December, 2017
Anthony Scaramucci: Fired, July, 2017 
Sebastian Gorka: "No longer with the White House," August, 2017
Rob Porter: Resigned, today.

Click the link in our bio to read the original story. Photograph by Jonathan Ernst/Reuters.

Most tourists pass a cultural landmark and snap an iPhone photo in an instant. But that isn’t the case for the photographer Markus Brunetti. His image of the ornate façade of the Duomo di Santa Maria Nascente, in Milan, took eight years to create. And, you’ll notice, is missing any pigeons, postcard venders, or other signs of modern life. Click the link in our bio to read about his process, and why it takes such a long time to achieve the finished product. Photograph courtesy Yossi Milo Gallery.
A cartoon by @farleykatz. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

It was on his grandparents’ farm that Peter Hujar developed a deep love for animals, who were among his first, and most enduring, photographic subjects. Though less glamorous than his portraits of bohemian East Village habitués, his pictures of animals still capture a sense of individuality and mystery. See more at the link in our bio. Photographs courtesy Peter Hujar Archive, Pace/MacGill Gallery, and Fraenkel Gallery.

At fifty-five, Henry Worsley set out on a solo journey to cross Antarctica on foot. No food caches had been deposited along the route to help him forestall starvation, and he had to haul all his provisions on a sled that weighed 325 pounds. It was a feat no one had attempted before. Click the link in our bio to read David Grann’s story about Worsley’s trek, and the man who inspired it. Photograph by @copelandadventures.
A cartoon by @bob_eckstein. #TNYcartoons

“I seek to depict an Africa free from stereotypes preconceived by the West,” the photographer Émilie Régnier says about her project “Passport.” It is “an attempt to show photographic truth located in the bodily presence of young West Africans proudly negotiating their future.” Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more of @em.regnier's images.
A cartoon by Charles Barsotti, from 1987. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Peter Hujar was among the greatest of all American photographers and has had, by far, the most confusing reputation. A dazzling retrospective, curated by Joel Smith at the Morgan Library & Museum, of a 164 pictures affirms Hujar’s excellence while, if anything, complicating his history. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photographs courtesy Peter Hujar Archive, Pace/MacGill Gallery, and Fraenkel Gallery.
A cartoon by David Sipress. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In “Blue Planet II,” the seven-episode follow-up to the 2001 BBC series, David Attenborough promises to introduce us to “creatures beyond our imagination.” The broadclub cuttlefish, for instance. The show is oceanic in topic, tone, scope, and majesty. Click the link in our bio to read the full review. Photograph courtesy BBC.
A cartoon by @paulnoth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Feeling a little down this winter? Don’t worry. Just tell everyone within earshot that, actually, you really appreciate how New York has seasons, you know? Keep repeating it until it becomes true. Or try one of our other tricks for staying deliriously happy this February, at the link in our bio. Illustration by @despairlarson.
A cartoon by James Stevenson, from 1976. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In the 1980s, the Lo Lifes collected, flaunted, and, most infamously, stole large amounts of Polo Ralph Lauren clothing. The Crown Heights and Brownsville-based crew was nothing like the white, upper-middle-class vision of America that the brand advertised. And they gave Polo something that it never really sought: street cred. Click the link in our bio to read about how the brand may finally be embracing its complicated streetwear past. Photograph by @tom_gould.
A cartoon by @ellisjrosen. #TNYcartoons

Brandon Truaxe was working as a computer programmer for a skin-care lab when he noticed the drastic difference between the cost of raw ingredients and the price of finished products. In 2016, he launched The Ordinary with the aim of selling luxury ingredients at wholesale prices. Its products have become so popular that the waitlist for a seven-dollar foundation swelled to 75,000 names. “Nobody plans a waiting list. This is not an Hermès bag. It’s skin care,” Truaxe says. Click the link in our bio to read about the new cult clutch of the beauty industry. Photograph by Jay Brooks.
A cover by @kadirnelson, from 2016, for Black History Month. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Everett Opie, from 1986. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Among an affluent demographic of Californians, who are heavily invested in optimizing personal experience, cannabis has become part of a booming wellness industry. Gone are the purple bongs, sexy nurses, and dancing bears. In their place is an array of alluring products whose seduction lies in their eminently rational design. Click the link in our bio to read about the disposable vape pens and CBD-infused gummies that are changing the way we think about weed. Photographs by @chad_pitman_studio.

“Clog life is not lived off the grid but grid-adjacent,” Lauren Mechling writes. One of her first acts after losing her job, last November, was to bound into the No.6 flagship store and buy a pair—thus joining the ranks of clogerati including Chloë Sevigny, Lena Dunham, Kim Gordon, and Michelle Williams. Click the link in our bio to find out why @laurenomics loves the shoe so much. Photograph by Camera Press/Redux.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The photographer @bydvnlln, who is taking over our photo department’s account this week, is known for documenting the 2015 Baltimore protests that followed the death of Freddie Gray. "I'm going to take you through a short journey through my city, through my eyes," he writes. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.

Kendrick Lamar ruled last night’s #Grammys, opening the telecast with “xxx.,” from his album “DAMN.,” which was up for seven awards, and won five. It was a beautiful and tense performance that made the rest of the evening feel tepid by comparison. Click the link in our bio to read @amandapetrusich on everything from the Premiere Ceremony to Jay-Z for President to Lorde’s snub. Photograph by Christopher Polk/Getty.
This week's cover, “Figured Skaters,” by Mark Ulriksen. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Michael Maslin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

When Joseph Cornell saw “The Man at the Café,” a collage by the Spanish painter Juan Gris, in 1953, it inspired the most extensive series of his career. Now, an exhibit at the Met unites the Cubist masterpiece from 1914 with twelve of the shadow boxes that Cornell made in response to it, including “Untitled (Le Soir),” circa 1953-54. See it until April 15. Photograph by @adamkremer for TNY.

Have you used Google’s Arts & Culture app to find your museum doppelgänger yet? Our staff writer Adrian Chen gave it a try, and got a portrait by the Japanese artist Ryusei Kishida. But what interested him more than his 44% match was the current state of facial-recognition algorithms, which are famously bad at parsing nonwhite features—it’s a phenomenon some call the “coded gaze.” And the rise of that gaze has implications that go beyond the details of any one app. Click the link in our bio to learn more. Photograph courtesy Google Arts & Culture.
A cartoon by @amykurzweil. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The director Madeleine Sackler reached out to about twenty state departments of correction. Her ask: to make a movie about life in prison, using inmates and guards as actors and extras.  Finally, one responded with something other than a pro-forma no. Click the link in our bio to read about the making of “O.G.,” a prison film shot in a prison. Photographs by @krisannejohnson for TNY.

The bar for pasta in New York has been set especially high. The field is crowded and the competition fierce—how, then, is a restaurateur to corner the market? At a new West Village restaurant called Raviolo, the tactic is to offer what is perhaps the city’s first “Italian dim sum,” a concept we never knew we needed. Click the link in our bio to read our new food critic’s survey of recent attempts at noodle innovation in N.Y.C. Photograph Courtesy @raviolonyc.
A cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The Tokyo-based photographer Yoshinori Mizutani routinely practices a kind of photographic version of shinrin-yoku—literally translated as “forest bathing.” It is based on a simple premise: immerse yourself in the forest, absorb its sights, sounds, and smells, and you will reap numerous psychological and physiological benefits. Click the link in our bio to see more of his work. Photograph by @yoshinori_mizutani.

This week, the Harvard art history professor @sarahelizabethlewis1 has taken over our photo department's account to share some of the images she uses in her "Vision and Justice" class. This one, by the photographer @awolerizku is a layered response to and send up of Vermeer’s “Girl with the Pearl Earring,” 1665. Follow @newyorkerphoto to learn more.
@eflakeagogo draws the joys and pressures of sleep training.

On just about every Sunday for the past seventeen years, the artist Byron Kim has made a painting of the sky, accompanied by a few lines of diaristic rumination. (He isn’t perfect—"Despite carrying a panel in the car all day yesterday, I forgot to do a Sunday Painting,” he wrote on May 7, 2012, a Monday.) Now a selection of more than a hundred of the paintings, arranged chronologically, can be viewed at James Cohan Gallery in Chelsea. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photographs courtesy the artist and James Cohan, New York.
A cartoon by @carolitajohnson. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Looking for something to read on those cold winter nights? Don't miss The New Yorker Winter Sale. Save 50%, plus get a free tote bag. Valid in the U.S. only. Click the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.

“Phantom Thread,” which was nominated for six Oscars today, tells the story of an obsessive couturier and the woman who fights to love him. It’s full of sumptuous images of the designer and his staff at work—cutting luxurious fabric or smoothing perfect seams—but isn’t a movie about fashion any more than “American Psycho” is a movie about banking. It is, instead, one of the great food movies in recent memory. Click the link in our bio to find out why. Photograph by Focus Features/Everett.
A cartoon by @paulnoth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

From our art department: @wesleyallsbrook’s illustration for Anthony Lane’s review of “The Shape of Water,” which led today’s #OscarNoms with thirteen nominations. Click the link in our bio to read the review, and follow @newyorkerart for more New Yorker artwork.

When she was in graduate school, the photographer Natalie Krick began taking pictures of women in what she calls “female drag.” Think: bright lipstick, false nails and eyelashes, pushup bras. One day, when her mother came to visit, she decided to try photographing her in the same way. The resulting images play with the louche, lurid, come-hither aesthetic of high-end fashion advertising—though the special relationship between photographer and subject is always front and center. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @nattynattynatnatnat.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“I wanted to show just the horribleness of January,” the cartoonist Roz Chast says, of “Cruelest Month,” her cover for this week’s issue. “Winter is really here, no vestige of fall. Four-thirty rolls around and it’s getting dark, and I’m thinking, Do I need anything? But why bother? Why ask for trouble? There isn’t much motivation to go outside. It’s 'Why don’t I just open a can of tuna?' month.” #TNYcovers
Actual personalized shopping suggestions that prove that the Internet is judging us, as drawn by @nomikane.
A cartoon by @blisscartoons. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by Michael Shaw. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

One year after an estimated two million women marched across the U.S., supporters lined up in New York and scores of other cities for 2018’s #WomensMarch. Bettina Cruz Velásquez, fifty-five, is visiting from Oaxaca, Mexico, for a few days. “It’s a very symbolic march for women all over the world,” she said, through a translator. See our Stories for more scenes from the march. Photograph by @elizabethbick.

One year ago today, Donald Trump was sworn in as President. At the time, the balmy narrative was that he would grow into the position. But since then, the optimists have, for the most part, been proven wrong. Click the link in our bio to read Jelani Cobb attempt to find persistent patterns within the madness of Trump’s first year in office. Photograph by Mark Peterson/Redux for TNY.

@jamelshabazz’s portrait of a “Sophisticated Lady” pays tribute to the Harlem Renaissance photographer James Van Der Zee, who was a torchbearer during the 1920s. Our photo department is celebrating Black History Month, from now through the end of February, by showcasing work that celebrates black culture and meditates on the black experience. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by Dana Fradon, from 1979. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

How has “Sesame Street” evolved since its move to HBO? Episodes now run a peppy half-hour, instead of the sixty-minute servings of yore. Elmo has a new sidekick named Smartie, an animated yellow phone, whose catchphrase is “Look it up.” And this season, the show’s 46th, brings a new franchise, “Cookie Monster’s Foodie Truck,” where the charismatic blue glutton acquaints himself with the farm-to-table scene. Click the link in our bio to find out what else has changed. Photograph by Richard Termine/Sesame Workshop.

Don’t feel like cooking tonight? Why not try Werkstatt, a casual spot in Prospect Park South, where the leading New York chef Thomas Ferlesch cooks delicious Viennese fare. Order a big soft pretzel and then a tangy bratwurst or smoked Polish kielbasa, served on a heaping pile of sauerkraut and potatoes. For dessert, try the apple strudel or the Linzer torte, and, when one of the friendly servers offers up a mug of steaming glühwein to wash it all down, accept without hesitation. Click the link in our bio to read our full review. Photograph by @amylombard for TNY.
A cartoon by Alain, from 1943. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by Teresa Burns Parkhurst. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
@lianafinck draws a selection of children’s literature, updated for adults. Click the link in our bio to see more.
A cartoon by Julia Suits. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The Cranberries singer Dolores O’Riordan, who died on Monday, had a sublime recklessness to her voice that favored meaning over conventional prettiness. In the early nineties, she helped further the then-iffy-seeming idea that a woman could be both beautiful and ferocious. She appeared accountable only to some internal voice—which made young women like @amandapetrusich feel like they could be, too. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Francesco Castaldo/Getty.

It was Richard Avedon’s photographs and James Baldwin’s text, in “Nothing Personal,” that made @hilton.als realize that current events can be art—that being humane is art. He wrote about what the book means to him in the introduction to a facsimile edition, which was recently released by Taschen. Read an excerpt at the link in our bio. Photograph by Richard Avedon/© The Richard Avedon Foundation.
A cartoon by Charles Barsotti. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cover by @kadirnelson, from 2017, for #MLKDay. #TNYcovers

Make laundry day a little more fun with Sally Gall's whimsical photographs of clean clothes flapping on a line. Much of the wash looks rather anonymous, just streaming scarves or other bits of fabric, but the biggest blossoms are distinctly feminine: skirts that Gall invites us to look up. “I’m searching for poetry in the everyday,” she says. See more at the link in our bio. Photograph ©️ Sally Gall/Courtesy Julie Saul Gallery, New York.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Passive aggression reaches new comedic heights in “Miles for Mary,” which tracks the efforts of earnest high-school teachers to organize a fund-raising telethon in 1988 Ohio. Devised and performed by the Mad Ones, it takes place in the teachers’ lounge, and swiftly reveals the frustrations bubbling under a veneer of ingratiating politeness. See it at Playwrights Horizons, through February 4th. Photograph by @erichelgas for TNY.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

If you’ve found yourself contemplating Oprah—or even #Oprah2020—this week, you’ll find the three-episode podcast “Making Oprah” terrifically illuminating. By tracing Oprah’s rise through the context of “The Oprah Winfrey Show” (and avoiding her personal life and other projects), it allows for a clear view into what made her so powerful in the first place. Click the link in our bio to read @asarahlarson’s review. Photograph by Charlie Knoblock/AP.
A cartoon by William Haefeli. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
An early look at next week’s cover: “In the Hole,” by Anthony Russo, is a response to President Trump’s recent comments about immigration. #TNYcovers

You oughtn’t have bar snacks and raw bar, and an appetizer, and pasta, an entrée, and an ice cream sundae—or ought you? At the highly polished new brasserie The Loyal, on Bleecker Street, the chef John Fraser crowds enough indulgent items onto the menu to challenge one’s duty to decorum. Click the link in our bio to read the full review. Photograph by David Williams for TNY.
A 2018 high-school reading list, as drawn by @jazimated.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Today in New York: Habibi will play surf punk tinged with Motor City soul at Elsewhere as part of a benefit concert for climate refugees. Since the band's quiet début in 2013, fans have been patient: a new EP is due in March, recorded partially in Farsi to blend Jamalifard’s Iranian roots with the band’s tasteful take on the Midwestern pop legacy. Photograph by @caitoppermann for TNY.

“Satire works in standup, film, rap, for sure,” the artist Sanford Biggers says. “But not as fluidly, really, in visual art.” Yet, as he deals with ever more harrowing real-world materials, comedy offers him a way to destabilize the work, complicate it. Click the link in our bio to read about how he is using his art to upend received ideas about race and history. Photographs by @erichelgas for TNY.
A cartoon by Brendan Loper. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

David Bowie, who died two years ago today, was always an original. Rock stars are not generally known for their generosity to other artists, but Bowie used his considerable fame to help popularize those who would have had less of a chance without him. He was an outsider who made different kids feel like dancing in that difference, and who had a genius for friendship, too. Click the link in our bio to read Hilton Als's remembrance of the late singer. Photograph by Terry O'Neill/Getty.

In his series of photographs taken through the gray diamonds of chain-link fences, Lee Friedlander ties together scenes in distant cities and decades, and bends a ubiquitous, mass-produced object to frame a portrait of American culture. He tells us where and when the images were taken, but otherwise the only context is a broad idea of restricted space, a distinction between inside and outside, or between sanctioned and unsanctioned. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Lee Friedlander/Courtesy Fraenkel Gallery.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The photographer Joshua Woods grew up in Harlem’s Le Petit Sénégal, where, as a child, he heard fly, elder male émigrés speak gloriously of easy black living and independence in Senegalese cities. In early October of last year, he finally travelled to the country. The pictures he took there are meant to highlight how black urban communities, whether in Harlem or Dakar, create, against the odds, their own distinct style of fashionable living. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @joshuawoods.
A cartoon by Seth Fleishman. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week’s cover, “In Creative Battle,” by @markulriksenart. #TNYcovers

While accepting the Cecil B. DeMille Award for lifetime achievement at the Golden Globes (the first black woman ever to do so), Oprah Winfrey seemed to grab hold of every live wire of rage, sadness, hope, and uncertainty dangling around the room and channel them into a truly breathtaking oration. It was a galvanizing and important speech, forward-looking and inclusive: the kind we used to hear from the person running the country. No wonder everyone on Twitter immediately posted “OPRAH 2020.” Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Paul Drinkwater/NBCUniversal via Getty.
A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

According to Thai superstition, you should call a newborn “ugly baby” in order to misdirect thieving ghosts enamored of comely young things. At a new Thai restaurant tucked away on a quiet stretch of Carroll Gardens, the method of misdirection has the opposite effect, reeling in a certain breed of New Yorker for whom the interplay of an underexplored cuisine, a well-regarded chef, and a memorably insouciant name is irresistible. Securing a table at such an establishment is a prize almost as precious as a sweet-smelling babe. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @dollyfaibyshev for The New Yorker.

"It’s a special moment when the animals you’re photographing share your same curiosity. This group of king penguins saw me lying at the edge of the colony and slowly waddled over in my direction and stopped about four feet from my boot. I said 'Good morning' and asked them about the weather, half expecting a reply. They inched forward, gaining more and more confidence. Eventually, one of them decided it wanted to make first contact."
.
.
.
The photographer Peter Fisher is sharing his images from an expedition to South Georgia Island on our photo department’s account. Often referred to as the Serengeti of the Southern Ocean, it is one of the most remote and unforgiving islands on the planet. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more photos from his trip. Photograph by @pet__fish.
A cartoon by @jeremywins. #TNYcartoons

Coney Island’s boardwalk is far from the minds of most New Yorkers during this brutal winter. But, in 2014, the photojournalist Yunghi Kim ventured to the end of the Q train during the winter to see how the seagulls, the Cyclone, the Polar Bear Club, and the local residents were faring during the snowy off-season. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Yunghi Kim/Contact Press Images.
Why you shouldn't go outside today, by @drawnbytom.

The video for Justin Timberlake's “Filthy” sees him playing a Steve Jobs-type executive (in wire-frame glasses, a dark turtleneck, and a headset mike), launching a dancing robot at something called the “Pan-Asian Deep Learning Conference.” Is the robot supposed to represent the sterile externalization of some deep and unspeakable lust? The outsourcing of desire? Our ongoing disassociation from our wild and imperfect bodies? We don’t know. It’s fun to watch it dance. Click the link in our bio to read more about @justintimberlake's new single. Image courtesy YouTube.
A cartoon by @slautow. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Mommy & me yoga poses, as drawn by @glynnisfawkes.

The photographer Peter Fisher is sharing his images from an expedition to South Georgia Island on our photo department’s account. Often referred to as the Serengeti of the Southern Ocean, it is one of the most remote and unforgiving islands on the planet. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more photos from his trip. Photograph by @pet__fish.
A cartoon by @joedator. #TNYcartoons

In Douglas Levere's photographs of snowflakes, the white of the falling flake is replaced with the translucence of ice, with its etched-in patterns and pathways. Some of his flakes are geometric, with an almost mechanical exactitude. Others are fluid, resembling liquid blossoms. He catches his subjects as they fall or sweeps them up with a fine paintbrush, sometimes from off the hood of his car. He puts them on glass slides and brings them to his garage, the only place in his house where it is cold enough to work, and then, using a homemade device, he photographs them in close-up. Finally, he combines the many images into one sharp portrait. Photographs by @douglaslevere.

To capture this photograph of Times Square on New Year’s Eve, in 2014, the aerial photographer George Steinmetz flew in a helicopter to an altitude of forty-five hundred feet, or more than three-quarters of a mile—the highest he had flown for his project photographing New York City from above during each of the four seasons. Swipe to see more of his images. Photographs by @geosteinmetz.
A cartoon by @christopherweyant. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In 2013, President Xi Jinping announced that the Silk Road would be reborn as the Belt and Road Initiative, the most ambitious infrastructure project the world has ever known—and the most expensive. Like most Chinese official-speak, the phrase “Belt and Road” obscures more than it clarifies: the “belt” will be composed of land routes running from China to Scandinavia, the Iberian Peninsula, and the Middle East; the “road” refers to shipping lanes connecting China to Southeast Asia, the Middle East, and Africa. In the fall, the photographer Davide Monteleone traced stretches of one of those land routes. Click the link in our bio for more. Photographs by @davidemon.
A cartoon by William Haefeli. #TNYcartoons

All pop stars are constructs, but that’s especially true of Shasta Geaux Pop, a glamazon hip-hop icon who exists, like Tinkerbell, only to the extent that you believe in her and clap your hands. Invented by the performer Ayesha Jordan and the director Charlotte Brathwaite, @shastageauxpop is part of this year’s “Under the Radar” festival (Jan. 4-15), the Public Theatre’s showcase of the avant-garde, where she’ll be hosting get-down parties on select nights in the Public’s lobby. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
Mistakes you’re going to keep making forever because it’s a new year, but you’re still the same old you—by @j.a.k._ and @phil_mcandrew.
This week’s cover, “Ferried Across,” by @thejorgecolombo. #TNYcovers

Ring in 2018 with our New Year's Sale. Save 50%, plus get a free cartoon calendar. Valid in the U.S. only. Click the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller, from 2012. #TNYcartoons

The moth doesn’t enjoy the same charmed reputation as its lepidopteran cousin, the butterfly. They're usually dismissed as pests, waging war on our sweaters when they’re not dive-bombing the lights. But with his kaleidoscopic project “Mariposas Nocturnas,” the photographer Emmet Gowin transforms the apparently lowly subject into riveting art. He photographed more than a thousand species on visits to Bolivia, Brazil, Ecuador, French Guiana, and Panama, in the company of entomologists. Click the link in our bio for a closer look at each one of these. Photograph by Emmet Gowin.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller. #TNYcartoons
Getaway suggestions for doomsday preppers, by @sammarlow27.

Arielle Bobb-Willis's film photography is a practice that blends twentieth-century black figuration with the schools of photography epitomized by image-makers like the Ukrainian duo Synchrodogs. Her subjects, styled in bright, polychromatic thrifted garments, pose against brilliant urban and rural backdrops. They are in physically challenging positions, but their bodies seem to be at ease, even graceful. Bobb-Willis says that living with depression can evoke a similar sensation. Click the link in our bio for more. Photographs by @relbw.
Alternatives for avocado toast in 2017, by Whit Taylor.
A cartoon by Mick Stevens. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Midtown Manhattan is going green—at least at the New York Botanical Garden, where the Holiday Train Show sports a skyline fashioned from foliage. The construction materials of the miniature buildings include hickory bark, honeysuckle twigs, grapevine tendrils, mimosa seedpods, magnolia leaves, and canella berries. (The MetLife tower called for some orange slices.) The trains will traverse their nearly half-mile-long track in the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory through Jan. 15. Photograph by @dina_litovsky for The New Yorker.
A cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez, from 2015. #TNYcartoons

In the nineties and early aughts, the photographer David LaChapelle’s slick aesthetic, which lifts lavishly from Christian pageantry and Renaissance painters, was inescapable. By 2007, having been derided in some quarters as a vapid commercialist, he’d left the business and absconded to Maui, where he lived off the grid at a shuttered nudist colony. Two hefty new books of his photographs, “Lost + Found Part I” and “Good News Part II,” compile old and new work, some of it previously unpublished. The books are teeming with very popular people (Tupac Shakur, Elizabeth Taylor, Amy Winehouse) doing very unpopular things (standing nude in front of tanks, getting nosebleeds). Click the link in our bio to see more of his work. Photograph by @david_lachapelle/Courtesy @taschen.
@juliarothman draws the many clocks of New York City ringing in the New Year. Swipe through to see the city’s iconic timepieces strike midnight and welcome 2018.

The novelist Leïla Slimani’s books beg to be read in an unfashionable way. You engage with her characters as people, not as constructs. Her best-seller, “Chanson Douce,” explores the dark relationship of a mother and her babysitter. Click the link in our bio to read about the killer-nanny novel that conquered France. Photograph by Paolo Roversi. Text by @laurenzcollins.
A cartoon by @maggiejanelarson. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

"In Mexican-American culture, there is a time each holiday season, beginning around Thanksgiving, when all foods except tamales recede. We eat them fresh at home. We pack two or three for lunch at the office. We bring tamales by the bagful to holidays gatherings." Click the link in our bio to read about how in a year of chaos and anxiety for Mexican-Americans, the holiday ritual of tamale-making is a time of reflection. Photograph by Leela Cyd/Getty.

Dick-adjacent buffoonery is central to the charm of the Netflix show, “American Vandal,” but it also exposes how human beings are so uncomfortable with ambiguity that we’ll do nearly anything to avoid it. Click the link in our bio to read more about how, even in between its endless dick jokes, “American Vandal” can be a brutal indictment of how our culture codifies and institutionalizes narrative. Illustration by @mark_todd.

When Sydney celebrates the new year, a rainbow-colored waterfall of fireworks will cascade from the Harbour Bridge, celebrating the long-overdue change of marriage equality finally coming to Australia. Click the link in our bio to read about what it took to bring about this momentous change. Photograph by Scott Barbour/Getty.

Since the mid-nineties, Brian Cross, better known as B+, has been well known among people who scrutinize hip-hop album sleeves and music magazines. His photographs of music stars, like Biggie, do not try to demystify their majesty, just remind us of the larger worlds, communities, and traditions that make stardom possible. Click the link in our bio to see more of his work. Photograph by @bpleasel.
This week’s cover, “Cramped,” by George Booth. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by P.C. Vey. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more.
A cartoon by @lizadonnelly. #TNYcartoons

In what was certainly our most glittery assignment of the year, Eva O’Leary ventured to Beautycon L.A. The makeup convention, which has been described as “Sephora meets Coachella” draws twenty thousand people, many of them aspiring social-media influencers—and lavishes them with products and tutorials to aid their pursuit of their next Instagram-ready look. Photograph by @evaoleary for TNY.
.
.
.
From on-the-ground coverage to finely crafted portraiture, we’ll be sharing one of our favorite images from 2017 each day until the end of the year.
A cartoon by Liam Walsh. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A slideshow of our Christmas covers, to look at once all the presents are open, of course. #TNYcovers

The photographer Max Pinckers had his flash taken away when he travelled to North Korea with Evan Osnos, but he MacGyvered a new one out of a flashlight and duct tape, and captured the scene at the Pyongyang Orphans' Secondary School. Photograph by @maxpinckers for TNY.
.
.
.
From on-the-ground coverage to finely crafted portraiture, we’ll be sharing some of our most powerful photography from 2017 each day until the end of the year.
A cartoon by Mike Twohy. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

At Ernest Heminway’s house in Cuba, in the big sala, or living room, is a set of upholstered furniture. It’s covered in flowered chintz, and serves as evidence that, though he may have thought himself as living one kind of life—that of the hunter, the writer—Hemingway was also living another, that of the cocktail party. Click the link in our bio to find out what it’s like visiting Finca Vigía. Photograph by Tore Johnson/The LIFE Images Collection/Getty.

Our staff photographer Pari Dukovic ventured to Pier Forty-five this summer to photograph swing dancers for our Goings On About Town section. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
.
.
.
From on-the-ground coverage to finely crafted portraiture, we’ll be sharing one of our favorite images from 2017 each day until the end of the year.
A cartoon by Glen Baxter. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cover by Arthur Getz, from 1955, for the holidays. #TNYcovers

In the final months of the battle to push ISIS out of its capital city, Raqqa, Mauricio Lima travelled to Syria with the reporter Luke Mogelson and embedded with Kurdish revolutionaries, including an all-female unit, as they fought to free the city. Photograph by @limauricio for TNY. .
.
.
From on-the-ground coverage to finely crafted portraiture, we’ll be sharing some of our best photography from 2017 each day until the end of the year.
Spotted at the @newyorkermag offices: a very bookish Christmas tree. 📚 Photograph by @rachelraudenbush.
A cartoon by @christopherweyant. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Isabel Magowan’s photographs of “The Nutcracker” at New York City Ballet capture both the ballet’s enchantment and the reality of the world behind the scenes: the waiting, the preparation, the order, and the work. As a young ballerina, Magowan danced in the ballet, playing tug-of-war in the party scene, banging the drum in the battle of the toy soldiers, and pointing her toes as a little polichinelle. She remembers the experience as an almost magical time. Click the link in our bio to see more of her work. Photograph by @isabelmagowan.

A kidskin-cork-and-suède wedge sandal, made by Ferragamo for Judy Garland, in 1938, was among the stylish pieces that Lorenzo Vitturi photographed for our portfolio of Italian fashion archives. Photograph by @lorenzovitturi for TNY.
.
.
.
From on-the-ground coverage to finely crafted portraiture, we’ll be sharing one of our favorite images from 2017 each day until the end of the year.
A cartoon by Roz Chast. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In the aughts, Coach K managed two of the Atlanta’s most important rappers—Young Jeezy and Gucci Mane. Nowadays, he guides the careers of Migos, Lil Yachty, and a clutch of other young hip-hop stars.
