Click the link in our bio to read about how he's helped turn Atlanta from a regional music hub into hip-hop’s cultural home. Photograph by @philipmontgomery for TNY.

In Montgomery County, Ohio, where the number of drug-overdose deaths has almost doubled since 2010, the photographer Philip Montgomery provided an up-close look at the human consequences of the opioid epidemic. Photograph by @philipmontgomery for TNY.
.
.
.
From on-the-ground coverage to finely crafted portraiture, we’ll be sharing some of our best photography from 2017 each day until the end of the year.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

When “Once on This Island” returned to Broadway this November, our staff photographer Pari Dukovic captured its star, the eighteen-year-old newcomer Hailey Kilgore, in rich, floral magenta hues. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY. .
.
.
From on-the-ground coverage to finely crafted portraiture, we’ll be sharing one of our favorite images from 2017 each day until the end of the year.
A cartoon by Michael Maslin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Do you have your Christmas tree yet? A cover by Garrett Price, from 1942. #TNYcovers
New forays into environmentally friendly clothing, as drawn by @pastapatel.

For our first-ever Television Issue, Richard Burbridge photographed comedy auteurs including “Broad City” stars Ilana Glazer and Abbi Jacobson, whose portrait manages to convey both their alchemic bond and their distinctive performative spirits. Photograph by @richardburbridge for TNY.
.
.
.
This was a year of political upheaval and creative flourishing, of societal reckonings and moments of light relief, and @newyorkerphoto’s photographers were on hand to capture it all. From on-the-ground coverage to finely crafted portraiture, we’ll be sharing one of our favorite images from 2017 each day until the end of the year.

“I never wanted to shoot another pop star as long as I lived,” David LaChapelle says, of his retreat from the world of celebrity photography to a shuttered nudist colony in Maui. His photographs are teeming with very popular people (Nicki Minaj, Whitney Houston) doing very unpopular things (standing nude in front of tanks, getting nosebleeds). But the pictures have aged well, perhaps because what seemed like surreal hyperbole five or ten years ago seems bluntly, embarrassingly honest today. Click the link in our bio to read about two new books of his work. Photograph by @david_lachapelle/Courtesy @taschen.
A cartoon by Zachary Kanin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Post-breakup confessions, as drawn by @mollysdrawth.

Curl up with a good read this winter. We're giving our Instagram followers 12 weeks for $6, plus a limited-edition tote. Valid in the U.S. only. Click the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.
A cartoon by P. C. Vey. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Sex, a cup of coffee the morning after, a quality bag of weed: as the Los Angeles R. & B. singer Miguel puts it, in a single from 2014, it is the “simplethings” that make life worthwhile. He seems to pursue the higher peaks of pleasure for their own sake, but throughout his new album, “War & Leisure,” Miguel wonders whether we can make an actual life out of moments of bliss. Click the link in our bio to read Hua Hsu’s review. Photograph by @jimmangan for TNY.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz and @stolincokes. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Jet lag is the bane of long flights, but it doesn’t have to be. Step aboard @SingaporeAir’s new A350 and discover the state-of-the-art features that can help you beat the long-haul blues. Click the link in our bio for more information. #FlySQ
A cartoon by Edward Steed. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Djamel Ameziane’s painting of a tranquil landscape is the sort of soothing, contemplative image that you might expect to find in the dining room of a country inn, not in a cell of one of the world’s most notorious prisons. But Ameziane painted it inside of Guantánamo. It’s just one of the works currently on display in “Ode to the Sea: Art from Guantánamo Bay,” a startling exhibit at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice. Click the link in our bio to learn more about the eight Guantánamo detainees (half of whom have been released) who contributed their art. Art work by Djamel Ameziane.
This week, @siandavey1 took over our photo department's account to share pictures of her daughters, Alice and Martha. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A guide to heartbreak, as drawn by Ruby Elliot. 💔

It’s unusual for a short story to generate the kind of online commotion created by Kristen Roupenian’s “Cat Person,” which appeared in the magazine last week. For many readers, it felt not just true but revelatory. And the accompanying photograph? It caused nearly as much fuss, online, as the story itself. Click the link in our bio to read "Cat Person," and to find out more about Elinor Carucci, the photographer behind the image. Photograph by @elinorcarucci for TNY.
A cartoon by @carolitajohnson. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In what could appear as either a squeaker or a rout, Democrat Doug Jones won tonight’s special election in Alabama, beating Republican Roy Moore by a few thousand votes. African-American turnout was extremely strong for Jones, and so was turnout in the educated white sections of the state. The votes were depressed in rural, conservative areas. Tonight, Alabama looked a bit different, all around. This isn’t the America of 2016 any longer. Click the link in our bio to see our coverage of the evening. Photograph By Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call via Getty.

This year, Nicholas Nixon shot his forty-third portrait of the Brown sisters. In July of 1975, when he took the first photograph, his wife, Bebe, and her three sisters were 25, 23, 15, and 21. In the ensuing years, the project has become one of photography’s most affecting bodies of work. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photographs by Nicholas Nixon/Courtesy Fraenkel Gallery.

In 1977, just weeks before "Star Wars" premièred, the actress Carrie Fisher contacted Columbia University's philosophy department. She was looking for a private philosophy coach, and found one in a second-year graduate student named Mark Notturno. “We had a lot of discussions about life. And her life,” Notturno said recently. Click the link in our bio to find out what it was like to be Fischer's private philosophy coach. Photograph by Lucasfilm/Twentieth Century Fox/Alamy.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Marcus Yam’s picture of the California fires is a kind of counterpoint to the classic SoCal image: a sunset tucking into the horizon. The charred silhouettes of the palm trees stand like reminders that even paradise, unwatered, passes away. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @yamphoto.

In Arielle Bobb-Willis’s photography, the body seems to be at once a shelter and a cage. Her subjects, styled in bright, polychromatic thrifted garments, are in physically challenging positions—but their bodies seem to be at ease, even graceful. The artist says that living with depression can evoke a similar sensation. Click the link in our bio to see more of her work. Photograph by @relbw.

Washington D.C.’s Southwest Waterfront is heating things up this winter as one of the District’s most exciting entertainment, dining, and shopping destinations. Cozy up beside one of The Wharf’s fire pits, or gather with friends around the Torch on Recreation Pier. Grab dinner at one of the area’s delicious restaurants, or catch a show at the state-of-the-art concert hall The Anthem. Follow @visitwashingtondc for more reasons to make holiday memories in D.C. #MyDCcool

Today in New York: The four virtuosos of Genghis Barbie, which calls itself “the leading post post-feminist feminist all-female horn experience,” perform holiday tunes both goofy (“All I Want for Christmas Is You”) and solemn (“O Come, O Come Emmanuel”) at their “Ugly Holiday Sweater Party” at Miller Theatre. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
A cartoon by @mecharliehankin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

For thousands of years, the inhabitants of St. Kilda (the most remote settlement in the British Isles) farmed little and fished less, preferring to subsist on seabirds. They developed extraordinary climbing skills, and widely-separated toes. Today, the only human inhabitants of the archipelago are seasonal. It has returned to the birds, which now number nearly a million. Click the link in our bio to learn more about Scotland’s lost utopia in the sea. Photograph by Philip Mugridge/Alamy.

In the nineteen-sixties, Alice Gray, an entomologist at the American Museum of Natural History and an origami whiz, decorated a three-foot-tall tree in her office with folded-paper insects for the holidays. A tradition was born. Since 1972, the museum’s official tree—now in the Astor Turret, on the fourth floor—has displayed an increasingly elaborate paper menagerie. Stop in to see it, through January 7th. Photograph by @mushroom_collector for TNY.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The Met’s ravishing survey of David Hockney’s six-decade career arrives as a revelation, a retort to all the avant-gardist eye-rollers who dismiss the eighty-year-old British artist as, at best, a guilty pleasure. The retrospective unfolds over eight rooms—each so cohesive it’s a show of its own—as a bracing reminder that beauty and ideas aren’t mutually exclusive and that great art is always, in some sense, conceptual. Photograph © David Hockney.
A cartoon by Alex Gregory. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Trying to avoid holiday weight gain? The answer may not be heading for warmer weather. There’s a maxim in the cruise-ship industry that the average passenger gains a pound a day while on board. In 2014, David Owen boarded Royal Caribbean’s Oasis of the Seas to find out how America’s global reputation for gluttony translated on the water. Click the link in our bio to read about what he found out. Photograph by Brian Finke.

“I am trying to create something that is questionable, something that is difficult, if not impossible, to put into words,” the artist Peter Doig once said. For a long time, his use of figuration and narrative struck many people as hopelessly out of date. When some of those same works began to sell for surprisingly large amounts of money, around 2002, no one could explain why. Click the link in our bio to read more about the virtuoso of the unpredictable. Photograph by @danielpshea for TNY.
A cartoon by Maggie Mull. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“It’s almost Christmas and Donald Trump’s former national-security adviser Michael Flynn is singing for all to hear,” the artist Barry Blitt says, about next week's cover, “A Christmas Carol.” “But something tells me that the President is too Scrooge-like to enjoy the carolling.” #TNYcovers

Stephen Shore bloomed into his calling like a hothouse orchid, with his first darkroom kit (the gift of an uncle), when he was six. When he was fourteen, he sold three photographs to @themuseumofmodernart. Now, the museum is showing an immersive and staggeringly charming retrospective of his work, which showcases an easeful acceptance of the world. Click the link in our bio to learn why @stephen.shore is our art critic Peter Schjeldahl’s favorite American photographer of the past half century. Photograph courtesy the artist/MOMA.

We’re so accustomed to Julia Child the ample lioness, hooting over a slippery chicken, that it’s a shock to see her gamine, gawky as a gazelle in her early days in Paris. A new book of photographs taken by her husband, Paul, during that time shows a Julia before books, before cooking on television, before fame. She’s bent over the telephone, or sunbathing with a friend on a Paris rooftop. She’s laughing. She looks like a woman with an appetite. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Paul Child/© The Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe Institute, Harvard University.
Everyone who wants to sublet your apartment this winter, as drawn by @cartoonsbyhilary.

David Mullins and Charlie Craig filed a complaint when a bakery refused to design a cake for their wedding. The case, which was heard before the Supreme Court today, began with comedy, but may have ended in tragedy. Click the link in our bio to read about why the outcome seems to rest, as it does so often in the current Court, with the vote of Justice Anthony Kennedy. Photograph by Chip Somodevilla/Getty.

In a column she started writing for Life in 1969, Joan Didion introduced herself as “a woman who for some time now has felt radically separated from most of the ideas that seem to interest other people.” We think she has always spoken for us, but the truth is she’s not like us. She’s weird. And that’s why we want to read her. On the writer’s eighty-third birthday, revisit Louis Menand’s review of the 2015 biography “The Last Love Song.” Link in bio. Photograph by CSU Archives/Everett/Alamy.
A cartoon by @lianafinck. #TNYcartoons
It's beginning to look a lot like Christmas. A cover, by Alain, from 1955. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

From the beginning, Jay-Z—who turns forty-eight today—was admired for the quality of his verse. He compared his rhymes to luxury goods, as a way of flattering his listeners’ powers of discernment. If his skill accounts for his reputation, and his practical approach to marketing his skill accounts for his success, then his ability to sense what his audience wants to hear before his audience senses it—to tell stories that don’t just demand belief but inspire it—accounts for his longevity. Click the link in our bio to read our 2001 story on the rapper and the rise of corporate rap. Photograph by Frank Micelotta / ImageDirect via Getty.
Do you recognize these New York City elevators? Click the link in our bio to test your knowledge. Illustrations by @juliarothman.

“Going past vacant lots filled with large Christmas trees, I have often wondered how people take them home,” @tomgauld, the artist behind this week’s cover, “Holiday Track,” says. “I’m fascinated by this strange annual migration where large trees come to the city for their final moment of glory.” #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo. #TNYcartoons

“Happily, New Yorkers are more open-minded than ever,” Meir Adoni recently told a patron at Nur, his inaugural N.Y.C. restaurant. A famous chef in Israel, where he owns two restaurants and judges a popular cooking-contest show, he serves the region’s flavors while avoiding the clichés of falafel and baba ghanoush. Click the link in our bio for the full review. Photograph by Zachary Zavislak for TNY.
A cartoon by P.C. Vey, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“We eat one meal per day, at most,” a Boudouma chief says. “Often we eat nothing.” His tribe is one of the many that reside on the islands of Lake Chad, and have been devastated by Boko Haram, climate change, local militaries, and extreme poverty. Click the link in our bio to read about the complex humanitarian disaster that's unfolding in the region. Photograph by Paolo Pellegrin/Magnum for TNY.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._. #TNYcartoons

Irad and Jose Ortiz may not be household names, but the two Puerto Rican jockeys are lighting up horse racing. While most jockeys become known as specialists in one or another part of the race, the Ortiz brothers excel at all areas. What is it that makes them so good? Click the link in our bio to find out. 🏇🏇 Photograph by @thomas_prior for TNY.

Today in New York: Angel Olsen, whose folk rolls by slowly but travels far, plays Brooklyn Steel. On “Phases,” the songwriter’s new collection of outtakes, rarities, and covers, she excavates several past numbers, and retraces trails found in the work of roamers like Bruce Springsteen and Hoyt Axton. Photograph by Morgan Ashcom for TNY.
A cartoon by Paul Noth. #TNYcartoons

The photographer Laura Aguilar’s most formally inventive series consist of nude self-portraits taken in the New Mexican desert. By curling against the rocky ground, or stretching out along the edge of a lagoon, she makes the curves and shadows of her round body echo beautifully the shapes of the landscape around her. Aguilar is at once part of the American land, and the viewer’s eye, and apart from them: in her own words, both present and persistently unseen. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Laura Aguilar/Courtesy the artist and the UCLA Chicano Studies Research Center.

“The tantalizing prospect of great wealth bedeviled Mark Twain for much of his life.” On the famous author and capricious entrepreneur’s birthday, read about his inventions and investments: from elastic pants to a powdered food supplement derived “from waste products fed to pigs.” Link in bio. Photograph from from Library of Congress via Getty.
A cartoon by @lizadonnelly, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The New Yorker Cyber-Week Sale. Save 50%. Plus, get a free 2018 cartoon calendar. Valid in the U.S. only. Click the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.

Few pop musicians have seemed so futuristic and so weird for as long as Björk has. Since the early nineteen-nineties, the Icelandic artist has charted extremes, always attuned to the possibilities emerging from dance music’s experimental communities. Her new album, “Utopia,” suggests that each of us can make the world in which we want to live. Click the link in our bio to read Hua Hsu’s review. Photograph by Santiago Felipe/Getty.

On Monday, to unveil the White House Christmas decorations, Melania Trump wore a creamy white dress with bell sleeves and a low flared skirt—the silhouette of a tree-topper made by Dior. In photos, she stood motionless on a red staircase as ballerinas twirled before her and walked through a darkened hallway lined with bristling white branches. Either this was her vision of festivity or it was someone else’s, and depending on which of those options you favored, Melania either looked like a beautiful prisoner or a wicked queen. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Saul Loeb/AFP/Getty.
A cartoon by Teresa Burns, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Which titles will Prince Harry and Meghan Markle receive upon their marriage? The Queen will most likely make the Prince a duke (this is somehow a promotion) and Markle a duchess. The question of which dukedom is most eligible offers a view into the labyrinthine history of the Royal Family (one in which borders have always been blurry, and respectability not always so respectable). Click the link in our bio to find out why Sussex is a probable choice. Photograph by Matt Dunham/AP.

Today in New York: The Met opens its retrospective of David Hockney’s work, in celebration of the artist’s eightieth birthday. The exhibit includes “Mt. Fuji and Flowers,” which Hockney painted after a 1972 trip to Japan. Landscape and autobiography often entwine in his work, from the sun-splashed swimming pools of L.A., his adopted home town, to the rolling hills of his native Yorkshire. Photograph courtesy the @metmuseum.

Don’t stay inside all winter. Washington, D.C. is hosting an array of outdoor art installations this season. During "Georgetown Glow," see one-of-a-kind light displays by visual artists from around the globe. Head to CityCenterDC where the “Dream Closet,” over Palmer Alley, is back with its illuminated exhibit of seasonal ornaments and decorations. Stop by the National Christmas Tree and National Menorah in the National Mall area; or visit the National Zoo for ZooLights. Follow @visitwashingtondc for more reasons to make holiday memories in D.C. Photo by @citycenterdc. #MyDCcool

“I saw this on one of my frequent trips back to the city,” @kimdem, the artist behind this week’s cover, “Special Delivery,” says. “A bundled-up guy passed me on a deserted street of the Village, where I used to live. I don’t think he was delivering—more likely he was going home with a fresh, hot pie, late at night, just when it was starting to snow. I love these New York moments.” #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @paulnoth, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In 1931, Janet Flanner wrote about how Gabrielle “CoCo” Chanel revolutionized modern dress by freeing women from the corset and bringing menswear items into their wardrobes: “She turned a trick that even Marie-Antoinette, dressed as a dairymaid, had not been able to, and if in doing it Chanel ruined the corset and hairpin-makers, at any rate mondaine Parisian women breathed freely and were at ease for the first time in French history.” Click the link in our bio to read the story. Photograph by Horst P. Horst/Conde Nast via Getty.

When the photographer William Gedney left for India, in the fall of 1969, he intended to make directly for Calcutta, but got off his train at Varanasi, halfway across the girth of India’s northern plains. He spent a year there before returning to the U.S. Only a decade later did he get to Calcutta, where he shot this image, in 1980. Click the link in our bio to see more of Gedney’s work from the two trips. Photograph by William Gedney courtesy of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.
A cartoon by @tbtoro, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“My father was a shaman,” the fashion designer Alessandro Michele says. “He told me that time doesn’t exist. He didn’t use a clock. He didn’t know when my birthday was.” In fact, it’s today. Make that an excuse to revisit our Profile of Gucci’s creative director. Link in bio. Photograph by @davidemon for TNY.

Tired of ordering in pizza on Friday night? Give pinsa a try. The Roman flatbread is the specialty of the newly opened Camillo, in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens. Made from a mixture of organic wheat, soy, and rice flours, the dough rises for more than two days before being baked in a Moretti Forni electric oven. The result, the chef and owner Michele Baldacci says, is easier to digest than its Neapolitan cousin. Read our full review at the link in our bio. Photograph by @dollyfaibyshev for TNY.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz, for #BlackFriday. #TNYcartoons

Heading into the melee that is #BlackFriday shopping? First, take some advice from a professional. Betty Halbreich has been dressing Bergdorf Goodman customers for more than forty years—Meryl Streep, Mia Farrow, and Liza Minnelli among them. Click the link in our bio to read Judith Thurman on the legendary personal shopper. Photograph by Ruven Afanador.
A cartoon by Mick Stevens, for #Thanksgiving. #TNYcartoons
While you’re waiting for the turkey to roast, enjoy this slideshow of #Thanksgiving covers from over the years. Tell us which one is your favorite in the comments. #TNYcovers

When the authorities in the Mexican town of Olinalá could no longer be trusted, Nestora Salgado organized a citizens’ police force. Did she go too far? Find out at the link in our bio. Photograph by @iancbates for TNY.
For all of you who are travelling today, a cartoon by David Sipress. #TNYcartoons

Have you ever wondered how Tofurky came to be? Probably not. But in case you did, we’re sharing the brief semi-accidental history of Thanksgiving’s fake meat, at the link in our bio. Photograph courtesy Tofurky.
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In the introduction of a new book of his portraits, the photographer Duane Michals describes the frustration he often felt at the predictability of his sessions with public figures. He would suffer through his disappointment when the practiced professional smile flashed back at him through the lens, and wait patiently until, say, the subject sneezed. “A reflex. A surprise! I’ve found the surprise, the metaphysical glance,” he writes. Click the link in our bio to see more of his work, including portraits of Andy Warhol, Joan Didion, and Johnny Cash. Photograph by Duane Michals/Courtesy DC Moore Gallery.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

At Pyongyang Orphans’ Secondary School, in North Korea, uniformed students sit in individual cubicles, like office workers, while a washed-out shade of pink pervades the classroom. This photo was taken by Max Pinckers, in August, while he travelled with our staff writer Evan Osnos to the country Donald Trump has announced he will designate a state sponsor of terrorism. Click the link in our bio to see more scenes from North Korea. Photograph by @maxpinckers for TNY.

This week's cover, “Nowhere to Hide,” by Barry Blitt, comments on the seemingly endless string of revelations of sexual abuse committed by powerful men. “The small figure depicted here is not specific. He could be any one of the parade of names that gets longer every day,” Blitt says. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Harry Bliss. #TNYcartoons

"We tend to look to nature for authenticity, but even here we encounter illusion," the photographer Simen Johan says. For his project “Until the Kingdom Comes,” he made use of subtle digital manipulations to push familiar wildlife imagery into the realm of the not quite real. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph © @simenjohan, Courtesy Yossi Milo Gallery, New York.
A cartoon by Alice Cheng, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cover by Charles E. Martin, from 1976, for an autumn afternoon. Follow @condenastarchive for more covers and photos from the past. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @j.a.k._. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

When sunlight starts stretching sideways at the end of the day, it stops reaching the water below Sunset Cliffs, a bend in the coast of San Diego where young people flock to jump from high ledges. For his series “Falling,” the photographer John Francis Peters shot bodies vaulting toward the water. Between the jump and the splash, they look weightless and seemingly placeless, too. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @jfpetersphoto.

Before you can have an Audrey Hepburn-inspired breakfast at the new café at Tiffany & Co., in New York City, you have to navigate the barriers outside Trump Tower and wait in line for several hours. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Collection Christophel / Alamy.
A cartoon by William Haefeli, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In 2000, when the photographer Josephine Sittenfeld was a junior at Princeton, she captured portraits of her classmates on medium-format film and, after exhibiting the prints, consigned them to a closet in her parents’ home. Last spring, at her fifteen-year college reunion, she decided to re-create the same shots in present day. “Reunion,” the result of this labor, is a series of moody, satisfying diptychs that fast-forward life’s natural transformations. Swipe through to see the before-and-after shots. Photographs by @josittenfeld.
@jeremywins draws new innovations in noise-cancelling headphone technology. Finish the story at the link in our bio.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Lucas Foglia’s “Human Nature” is absent of many of the images one would expect to see in a photo series inspired by the ravages of climate change. There are no indigenous tribespeople staring blankly out over clear-cuts and no flooded streets or flattened palm trees or giant storm clouds. Instead, there are photographs that, at first, appear familiar and then reveal an unsettling irony. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @lucasfogliaphoto/Courtesy Fredericks & Freiser Gallery.

These days, you can find Taylor Swift, a baby hedonist, meeting men in dark bars, buying a dress just so her lover can “take it off,” dropping a curse word—the first in her career stronger than “damn” or “hell”—and channelling a “Criminal”-era Fiona Apple. Wholesomeness has gone out of fashion, and her abrupt moment of maturation finds her playing catch-up. But is Swift admitting to flaws or just trying to fit in? Click the link in our bio to read Carrie Battan’s review of “Reputation.” Photograph via YouTube.
A cartoon by Charlie Hankin, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Since taking over as editor of @vanityfair, in 1983, Tina Brown has become synonymous with the last great renaissance of American print magazines. That time was filled with famous people, endless parties, comic misadventure. In her new book, “The Vanity Fair Diaries: 1983-1992,” Brown gives us a private account of it all, and her reports on editing offer an illuminating thrill. Click the link in our bio to read Nathan Heller’s review. Photograph by Tony Palmieri/Penske Media/REX/Shutterstock.

A boy in Mwananyamala, Dar Es Salaam, Tanzania. The photographer Ethan Tate (@scooternet) shared photos from his nine week-long expedition around the world on our photo department's account. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by @b_loper. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more #TNYcartoons.

Merakia—officially called Merakia Greek MountainThief Spithouse + Steak—is a new Flatiron restaurant that celebrates the Klephts (or, as the owners would have it, Greek MountainThieves) and their love of spit-roasted lamb. The space is lovely and considered. Soft golden lighting illuminates whispering couples tucked into mint-green upholstered booths. Between them, Andreas, a flowing-haired Hellene, strides the aisles proffering wine suggestions. Click the link in our bio to read the full review. Photograph by Frances F. Denny for TNY.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by @eflakea. #TNYcartoons

“I’ve got a thing for my laptop computer,” Poppy sings on one of her many meta-songs, uploaded to her YouTube channel alongside hundreds of sterile, cybernetic monologues. Portrayed by Moriah Rose Pereira, Poppy reads the Bible, interviews plants, and denies belonging to a cult. Followers can see her in person when she plays the Music Hall of Williamsburg on November 15. Photograph by @stephaniegonot for TNY.

“I have tried to do a painting a day since I moved here from Oregon, a year and a half ago,” the artist jkroik (who is also behind this week’s cover) says. She shared some of those paintings with our art department. Follow @newyorkerart to see more.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The photographer Afshin Shahidi’s new book, “Prince: A Private View,” shows how Prince was better at presenting his ideal image than most. In his fifty-seven years, he mastered the art of control—not merely the show of self-possession but the daily practice of it. In a foreword by Beyoncé, she writes it was Prince who made her “curious about the world behind the stage, the business of show.” Click the link in our bio to read more about who Prince was in private. Photograph by @afshinashahidi.

Last month, Alex MacLean rented a four-seat airplane in Nashville and flew to areas hit by Hurricane Harvey to photograph the landscape from above. He hoped to capture what had made Texas so vulnerable, and why disaster planners, in preparing for future storms, can’t ignore the changes that climate scientists say global warming is bringing. Click the link in our bio to see more of his images. Photograph by @landslides.
A cartoon by @farleykatz. #TNYcartoons

In many American towns, the most enterprising kids leave for college and stay away rather than starting a business at home, which means there are fewer jobs at home, more people leave, and the town begins to die. But in Orange City, Iowa, most kids stay. And it’s mainly for that reason that the town has prospered. Click the link in our bio to read about the rural community where the American dream lives on. Photograph by @brianfinke for TNY.

Barack Obama is hardly the first American President to use photography for political advantage. But pictures mean something special in his case, because, from the beginning, we consumed him as a specifically visual symbol. Obama knew it, too—one of his signature rhetorical moves was to point to his own presence at the podium as irrefutable proof of real, radical change. Look at me, he seemed to be saying, as if the looking were a politics in itself. Click the link in our bio to see more images from a new coffee-table book by Pete Souza, the former chief White House photographer. Photographs by @petesouza.
A cartoon by @maddiedai, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
On the anniversary of Donald Trump's election: Two Presidents, two pivotal moments in American history, shown in two covers by @bobstaake. #TNYcovers

Richard Avedon and James Baldwin’s 1964 collaboration, “Nothing Personal,” was designed to reflect America at the time. The book, in which Avedon’s photographs were accompanied by Baldwin’s text, brought together four aspects of American life and culture—civil rights, the rise of black nationalism, our mental-health system, and the old Hollywood guard giving way to rock and roll. It included images of Marilyn Monroe, Allen Ginsberg, and more. Check out our Instagram Stories to see more. Photograph by Richard Avedon/© The Richard Avedon Foundation.
Things to secretly love about N.Y.C., as illustrated by @misslaskogross.
A cover by Charles E. Martin, from 1960, for Election Day. #TNYcovers

Sunday's mass shooting at a church in Sutherland Springs, Texas, left twenty-six dead and twenty wounded. Feelings of powerlessness and depression are bound to infect those who would like to see something done to prevent these increasingly common occurrences of mass slaughter. It is hard to be hopeful. But there is never a time to give way to hopelessness: the politics are hard but far from insurmountable. Click the link in our bio to read Adam Gopnik out-argue and expose the repeated myths and absurdities of the gun lobby. Photograph by Nick Wagner/Austin American-Statesman, Statesman.com via AP.
A cartoon by @b_loper. #TNYcartoons

"I like to loiter around the city looking for interesting things,” the artist @JKroik says. Her painting for this week’s cover, "At the Strand," depicts another loiterer at the @strandbookstore, a beloved institution in lower Manhattan. "Bookstores are really good places for inspiration–you see people interacting with the books they have an affinity for, you see how people consume the culture." #TNYcovers

A Caribbean island ravaged by storms: it’s a sadly familiar image from the news, but one that sets the stage for romantic fable in the 1990 musical “Once on This Island.” A Broadway revival begins previews on November 9th, at the Circle in the Square, starring the eighteen-year-old newcomer @haileyfkilgore, as a peasant girl who braves the gods and the elements on her quest for love. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
A cartoon by Jack Ziegler. #TNYcartoons

Streecha, a rustic luncheonette in the East Village, is easy to miss. It’s situated in a basement beneath a chiropractor’s office and is demarcated by a blue banner in Cyrillic. The restaurant was conceived about four decades ago (no one recalls the precise year), as an income-generating project for St. George Ukrainian Catholic Church, up the street. All the cooks are volunteers and the menu consists of exactly four items, all paragons of traditional Ukrainian fare. Read our review at the link in our bio. Photograph by @kyokopajama for TNY.
A cartoon by Edward Steed, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
The trendiest parenting fears of 2017, as illustrated by Trevor Spaulding.

Kahlil Joseph, the creator of intellectually and emotionally dense short films showcasing black excellence, strangeness, and history, has worked for many artists, including @Beyoncé Knowles and @KendrickLamar. He draws very little distinction between his commercial work and the art that he produces on his own. Now Joseph has made his most personal film to date, the twenty-three-minute “Fly Paper,” which is part of his installation “Shadow Play,” at the New Museum through January 7th. Click the link in our bio to read more from @hilton.als on the artist. Photograph by @nate_nate for TNY.
A cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez. #TNYcartoons

Last week, @GideonsByeBull, the former creative director at @MagnumPhotos, took over our photo department’s account to share images from some of his favorite photographers, including this one by Ali Kate @Cherkis. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by Julia Suits, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Writing under censorship in Soviet-dominated Poland, Stanisław Lem turned to the fantasies of science fiction to offer radical critiques of modern life. His novels inspired many filmmakers, including Andrei Tarkovsky and Steven Soderbergh, whose adaptions are part of a series screening at Anthology Film Archives until November 11th. Photograph courtesy the National Film Archive, Czech Republic.

Why have Harvey Weinstein’s alleged transgressions been taken so much more seriously than Donald Trump's? One answer, it seems, has less to do with the accused than with the accusers. Anita Hill, a woman who, 26 years ago, famously testified that Clarence Thomas was unsuitable for confirmation to the Supreme Court, on the grounds that he had repeatedly harassed her while he served as her boss, agrees that the nature of Weinstein’s accusers is the reason that his exposure has proved to be a watershed moment. Click the link in our bio for Jane Mayer's full interview with her. Photograph by Mark Reinstein/Corbis via Getty.
A cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Rose Marie had multiple lives in performance by the time she found fame on the “The Dick Van Dyke Show.” She started out as a child singer and, by the 1940s, was treated as the “cat’s meow” among the mobsters of Las Vegas—but she never had much success in movies. After rebuffing the advances of a producer on 1954’s “Top Banana,” Rose Marie moved on to television, where, seven years later, she began working with Van Dyke. Click the link in our bio to read about a new documentary detailing her show-biz survival stories. Photograph courtesy of Rose Marie.

“She is on the fast track to being very famous,” Rachel Maddow said of Tulsi Gabbard, the night after she was elected congresswoman for Hawaii's Second District. Gabbard is an Iraq veteran, a lifelong surfer, and the first Hindu in Congress. Her political profile is similarly hybrid. She’s a fervent Bernie Sanders supporter with equally fervent bipartisan tendencies. Click the link in our bio to read about the making of a charismatic, unorthodox Democrat. Photograph by @peterbohler for TNY.
A cartoon by P.C. Vey, for Halloween. #TNYcartoons
Skip the tricks and treat yourself to these Halloween covers from over the decades. 🎃👻 #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @wooden.nickels. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Hellen Van Meene’s portraits of adolescent girls cross over into fantasy and horror. In one, a pale red-haired girl seems to possess two heads, one facing the camera and one twisted back and away. Are they Siamese twins or two girls locked in a rigid embrace? The pleasure is in not knowing. Photograph by @hellenvanmeene/Yancey Richardson Gallery.

“One of the great things about living in the woods is that I can watch leaves fall and never think about the fact that they’ve got to be bagged or raked. They’re simply just mulch for my lawn,” the artist @johncuneo3 says. His cover for this week’s issue, “A Rake’s Progress,” is inspired by the seasonal suburban chore. 🍂🍂 #TNYcovers

Hillary Brenhouse started wearing a bra in 1997, at age twelve. She stopped wearing one seventeen months ago, on a trip through South America. “It wasn’t a political decision, except insofar as everything a woman does with her body that isn’t letting someone else dictate what she ought to do with it is a political decision.” She shares the joys of going braless, at the link in our bio. Photograph Courtesy Everett Collection.
A cartoon by @joedator, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The documentary “The Center Will Not Hold”, which is available on Netflix starting today, offers an intimate, affectionate, and partial portrait of the writer Joan Didion. In it, she describes one domestic routine of her marriage: her husband would rise in the morning, build a fire, make breakfast for their young daughter, and take her to school. “Then I would get up, have a Coca-Cola, and start work,” she says. Click the link in our bio to read about the most revealing moment of the film. Photograph by Julian Wasser/@netflix.

As Netflix subscribers who swoon to pop Americana of a 1980s vintage will know, “Stranger Things 2” is available to stream starting today. The “2” in the title positions this collection of nine episodes not as a second season but as a sequel—the four boys are now about thirteen years old and the onset of puberty is an omnipresent horror. Click the link in our bio to read Troy Patterson’s review. (Warning: spoilers.) Photograph by by @netflix via Everett.

The photographer Raghubir Singh was a master of color—#nofilter avant la lettre. His images draw you in with their intricacies, none of which are the result of digital intervention. They are on display in the quietly magnificent show “Modernism on the Ganges,” which opened this week at the @metbreuer. Click the link in our bio for more. Photograph © 2017 Succession Raghubir Singh.

Iggy Pop tried to intimidate the British photographer Brian Griffin by bringing a bucket, putting it at his feet, and urinating into it. Siouxsie Sioux never said a word to him throughout their entire session. These are just two of the stories behind Griffin’s portraits of ‘70s and ‘80s rock stars—which have been collected into a new book called “Pop.” Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Brian Griffin/© Brian Griffin.
A cartoon by Julia Suits, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
@nomikane draws Halloween costumes inspired by the Trump Administration.

A family mourns the death of their son, who overdosed on heroin in the basement of their home. Opioids now kill more than 50,000 Americans a year. Montgomery County, Ohio, has the highest overdose rate in the country, per capita. That’s where the photographer Philip Montgomery travelled to document the epidemic up close. See his images at the link in our bio. Photograph by @philipmontgomery.

The New Yorker Fall Sale. Get 12 weeks for $6, plus a free tote. Valid in the U.S. only. Click the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.

When she was in her early twenties, Laura Owens wrote a fourteen-point list entitled “How to Be the Best Artist in the World.” Among the dictates: “Think big,” “Contradict yourself constantly,” “No Guilt,” “Do not be afraid of anything,” “Say very little,” and “Know that if you didn’t choose to be an artist—You would have certainly entertained world domination or mass murder or sainthood.” Click the link in our bio to read more about Owens, before her show opens at the @whitneymuseum next month. Photograph by @davidbenjaminsherry for TNY.

In 2017, Dungeons & Dragons, a game played far from the Internet, can feel slightly rebellious, or at least pleasantly out of place. Gathering your friends in a room, setting your devices aside, and taking turns to contrive a story that exists largely in your head gives off a radical whiff for a completely different reason than it did in 1987. The game seems to have been waiting for us somewhere under the particular psyche of this generation. Click the link in our bio to read about the uncanny resurrection of D. & D. Illustration by Edward Steed.
A cartoon by Zachary Kanin, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons. 🍕🍕

Harry & Ida’s Luncheonette, in Tribeca, reflects a clash of contemporary and iconic. The pastrami, heftily cut and intricately marbled, is something of a specialty. It’s coated in a pepper-heavy rub and smoked, then served in sandwiches topped with buttermilk-fermented cucumber kraut and cracked rye berries. Pastrami aside, there is trendified luncheonette fare. (Smoked apricot chicken, anyone?) Click the link in our bio for the full review. Photograph by @will_mebane for TNY.
Some British terms for rain, as illustrated by @drawnbytom. ☔️
This week's cover, "October Surprise," by Carter Goodrich. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @steinbergdrawscartoons, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

There is a fever-dream urgency to the self-portraits in the photographer Zanele Muholi’s recent series, “Somnyama Ngonyama” (which means “Hail the Dark Lioness” in Zulu). In it, she wrests her identity from every gaze except for her own. Click the link in our bio to see more of her work. Photograph by @muholizanele/Courtesy Yancey Richardson Gallery.
A cartoon by @farleykatz, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

One of the great gifts the Met Breuer has given New York has been spotlighting modernists beyond art history’s Eurocentric canon. The latest is Raghubir Singh, the Indian photographer—and color pioneer—who died in 1999, at the age of fifty-six. Born in Jaipur, he lived in Hong Kong, Paris, and London, but India remained his inexhaustible muse. A three-decade survey of his photographs, which includes “Monsoon Rains, Monghyr, Bihar, 1967,” is on show until January 2nd. Photograph courtesy Succession Raghubir Singh.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
"Autumn in Central Park," a cover by Eric Drooker, from 2009. Follow @condenastarchive for more covers and photos from the past.

When Janice Moses was just nineteen, she joined the photography department at Playboy. “I so badly needed a job that, of course, I had to tell a lie and say, ‘Yeah, I’ve been around nude models before,’” she says. On the New Yorker Radio Hour, she has a heart-to-heart with her daughter, @michelejmoses, about those years—when she felt empowered as a professional, but increasingly uncomfortable with the content. Click the link in our bio to listen to their conversation. Photograph courtesy of Janice Moses.

In the late 1970s, East L.A. swelled with decade-old soul records; Mexican-American teens cruised to oldies in low-rider convoys, forging a youth subculture that was both nostalgic and new. The Colombian-American singer Kali Uchis, who plays Bowery Ballroom tonight and the Music Hall of Williamsburg tomorrow, revives the sound with magnetic, achy soul ballads free of pop glisten. “I set the table for two, maybe it’s ’cause I’m a fool,” she once riffed—for these gigs, she shouldn’t have a problem filling seats. Photograph by @mutedfawn for TNY.
A cartoon by @maddiedai, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The illustrator @tshopsin and photographer @mushroom_collector let our art department in on their process for creating the artwork that accompanied a recent story on the Oxford University Press’s Very Short Introduction series. See more at @newyorkerart, and read the original article at the link in our bio.

“Every single day, I saw someone dying, or someone being buried,” the photojournalist Moises Saman says. He spent the last week documenting the conditions Rohingya are enduring as they attempt to flee Myanmar. Since August, nearly half of the country’s 1.1 million Rohingya Muslim minority have fled into neighboring Bangladesh in the face of attacks by the military and Buddhist villagers. Click the link in our bio to see more of Saman’s images. Photograph by @moisessaman.
A cartoon by Edward Steed, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

N.B.A. players have used their new prominence to forge something more lasting: solidarity. Click the link in our bio to read @vinsoncunningham on how their quiet brotherhood was on display during last night's game between the Cavaliers and the Celtics. Photo by Gregory Shamus / Getty.

After a devastating bombing, Somalis watched with a familiar disappointment as details of the attack failed to headline broadcast news or resonate on social media. There was no impromptu hashtag of solidarity, no deluge of television coverage. It was as if the bombing were just another incident in daily life. Where is the empathy for Somalia? @aokeowo asks. Link in bio. Photograph by Mohamed Abdiwahab/AFP/Getty.

“I have had plenty of Harvey Weinsteins of my own over the years, enough to feel a sickening shock of recognition,” the actress Molly Ringwald writes, in a (very) personal essay for our Web site. She describes the time, at fourteen, that a married director stuck his tongue in her mouth, how it felt to be asked to wear a dog collar for an audition, and what her hope is for the industry. Link in bio. Photograph by The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty.
A cartoon by @kuperart. #TNYcartoons

For Yola Monakhov Stockton, the question of how to photograph a bird was both a practical problem and a creative challenge. In her series “The Nature of Imitation,” she transformed her thoughts on nature into a series of spectacular photographs, exploring and manipulating images without any loss of authenticity. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Yola Monakhov Stockton.

For someone who remembers New York and American places (like Valley of the Gods, Utah) from the 1970s, even dimly, Wim Wenders’s Polaroids offer the feeling of a time capsule, of a trove of personal memories that conjure an entire lost world. It’s as if the images (which will go on display later this month in an exhibit at the Photographers’ Gallery, in London) were recorded on both sides, capturing the photographer’s inner vision and the outer world at the same time. See more at the link in our bio. Photograph courtesy the Wim Wenders Foundation/Ó Wim Wenders.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._. #TNYcartoons

“I’m not too worried about machines replacing cartoonists,” the artist @r_kikuo_johnson says, about his cover, “Tech Support,” for our Money Issue. “When robots are advanced enough to be neurotic, then maybe I’ll be concerned.” #TNYcovers

The Warhol superstar Brigid Berlin was a lapsed Fifth Avenue debutante, an amphetamine-loving wild child. Throughout the 1960s and 70s, she used a tape recorder and her only camera, a Polaroid 360, to obsessively document life in her social circle. Her collection of sloppy, deadpan snapshots—including Tina Aumont, Nico and Lou Reed, Viva and Candy Darling, and Roy Lichtenstein—accrue with the casual relentlessness of an analogue social-media stream. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Brigid Berlin/courtesy Reel Art Pres

The renowned chef Grant Achatz brings his friendly army of culinary super-nerds to New York with The Aviary. The restaurant’s view, a spectacular one of Central Park from the 35th story of the Mandarin Oriental, will almost certainly make you forget your troubles. And if it can’t there are many drinks that can, served with a wink, a nod, and, often, a show. Click the link in our bio to read the full review. Photograph by Zachary Zavislak for TNY.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Fifty years after Che Guevara’s death, his youngest brother, Juan Martin, has broken his silence with a recently published memoir. His professed intention is both to counteract the degree to which Che’s image has been co-opted and also to explicate his ideas as “a thinker and a social innovator.” In actuality, the book is light on ideology and, instead, succeeds remarkably well as a personal and family history. Read the full review at the link in our bio. Photograph by Elliott Erwitt/Magnum.

Carmen Yulín Cruz, the mayor of San Juan, Puerto Rico, has earned international renown since Hurricane Maria for criticizing Donald Trump’s lackadaisical response to the catastrophe. At one point, Trump fired back, tweeting that she had been “nasty” to him. Soon afterward, she appeared in public wearing a T-shirt emblazoned with that same word. “An insult from Mr. Trump is a badge of courage, thank God,” she says. Click the link in our bio to read about her thoughts on what Puerto Rico needs now. Photograph by Christopher Gregory for TNY.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

On a hot Friday evening this September, a corps of queens kicked off a new era in drag: the inaugural RuPaul’s DragCon. “Drag queens ain’t supposed to be in places like this..." Bob the Drag Queen said, of the Jacob Javits Center, where the event was held. It was a weekend spectacular where fans bought merch, and waited to get photos, while queens sat for panels on makeup and activism, and competed in amateur catwalk-offs. Link in bio. Photographs by Santiago Felipe/Getty.
A visual guide to Italian sweets, as illustrated by @tshopsin.
A cartoon by P.C. Vey. #TNYcartoons

For “Faces Places,” the filmmaker Agnès Varda (born in 1928) and the photographer and muralist JR (born in 1983) travelled to small towns in France to document the heroism of daily life. By creating murals of their interview subjects, they magnify and honor factory workers, farmers, waitresses, and others on a scale usually reserved for public and historical figures. Click the link in our bio to read Richard Brody’s review. Photograph by Cohen Media Group via Everett.
A cartoon by Julia Suits. #TNYcartoons
The best plants to get for the office, as illustrated by @jeremywins.

Multiple women, including Mira Sorvino, Rosanna Arquette, and Asia Argento, have shared their harrowing accounts of sexual assault and harassment by the film executive Harvey Weinstein. “I’ve been damaged. Just talking to you about it, my whole body is shaking. I know the damage is there, and will continue to be there,” the actress Asia Argento said. Click the link in our bio to read the full story, and listen to a recording, secretly captured during an N.Y.P.D. sting operation, in which Weinstein admits to groping a woman. Illustration by Oliver Munday.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. #TNYcartoons

Jon Hamm has one rule when it comes to making decisions about weird comedy roles: "Just do anything Tina Fey says." At The New Yorker Festival, the "Mad Men" actor shared stories about how he failed at nearly 200 auditions in the first three years of his career, how his comic sweet spot is between "really fun and really dumb," and how, when he was a high-school  teacher, Ellie Kemper was a student in his class. Photo by Andrew Toth/Getty for TNY. #TNYfest

In the spring of 1988, Katsu Naito moved to 112th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, in Harlem. A newcomer to the area, he worked up the courage to ask if he could take his neighbors’ pictures, and no one said no. His photographs from the early-nineties, which are collected in the new book “Once in Harlem,” are both of a piece with their surroundings and startlingly direct in their gaze. Photographs courtesy @katsunaitophoto/TBW Books.

Joni Mitchell made the best music of her generation by falling in love, over and over again. Her songs are almost always about what two articulate adults mean, or once meant, to each other. This required some reconnaissance. Men often wanted her to be a wife, a muse, a siren, or a star. Instead they got a genius. Click the link in our bio to read about a new biography of the singer-songwriter. Photograph by Mark Roth/Globe Photos/Zuma Press.
A cartoon by @steinbergdrawscartoons, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Last night, Carly Rae Jepsen caused a sensation at The New Yorker Festival. Cheers and applause filled the theatre at each mention of her music. The pop star talked about her process, what it was like to play Cinderella on Broadway, and how Tom Hanks ended up in her video for "I Really Like You." Photo by Thos Robinson/Getty for TNY. #TNYfest

In the photographer Vincent Ferrané’s new series, “Milky Way,” he documents his wife breastfeeding their infant child. The starkly composed, brightly lit scenes present a world deeply private and tender—a mother and baby joined repeatedly in the act of nourishment, as the father looks on. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @vincentferrane.
An early look at next week's cover, “October 1, 2017: One Day in a Nation of Guns," by @davidplunkert. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

New York Comic Con kicks off today. The convention has grown from a geek refuge to an all but mandatory celebration of the best in upcoming television, film, books, and comics—well, it’s still a geek refuge, but now there are a lot more geeks. Fans and enthusiasts will enjoy unprecedented access to their favorite stars with appearances by Kevin Conroy, Neil deGrasse Tyson, @hamillhimself, @rosariodawson, and many others. Photograph by © ReedPOP. #NYCC

Rachel Maddow’s entrance into broadcasting began as a lark. She was writing her doctoral thesis and doing odd jobs in western Massachusetts when she heard about a local radio audition to announce the morning news. In 2008, she got her own TV show and, since the election, she has become liberals’ favorite storyteller. “I happened to have a fascination with crazy right-wing racist politics—and all of a sudden that’s relevant. It’s my moment,” she says. Click the link in our bio to read Janet Malcolm’s Profile of the MSNBC star. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
A cartoon by @citycyclops, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In one cutting remark, during yesterday’s arguments before the Supreme Court, Ruth Bader Ginsburg silenced Neil Gorsuch, who had just given a patronizing lecture on the Constitution and omitted some of the Court’s most important precedents. There might have been an audible woo that echoed through the courtroom. Click the link in our bio to read Jeffrey Toobin on R.B.G.’s brisk and convincing dismissal. Photograph by Kevork Djansezian/Getty.

"Michelle is a tremendously strong person, and has a very strong sense of herself and who she is and where she comes from." "Barack has helped me loosen up and feel comfortable with taking risks." In 1996, the photographer Mariana Cook visited a young Barack and Michelle Obama, on the brink of their political life. On the couple's twenty-fifth wedding anniversary, read what they had to say about each other when they were just a young couple in Chicago. Link in bio. Photograph by Mariana Cook.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Tom Petty, who died Monday, understood how to address the liminal, not-quite-discernible feelings that a person might experience in her lifetime (that’s in addition to all the big, collapsing ones—your loves and losses and yearnings). He had an astute ear for the strangeness of just kicking around Earth—the way that agitation and anxiety can, on occasion, subsume a person for no good reason. Click the link in our bio to read more from Amanda Petrusich on the singer. Photograph by Richard E. Aaron/Redferns via Getty.

Last night, a gunman opened fire on an outdoor concert murdering more than fifty people and wounding hundreds more. The word “wounded,” of course, fails to capture the extent of the maiming, just as the blank word “dead” fails to capture the dawning of grief for so many families. What we’re told by the entire power structure of American life is that there is nothing at all to be done, save to pray. But the facts remain facts. Gun control acts on gun violence the way antibiotics act on infections. Click the link in our bio to read Adam Gopnik on why there can be no truce with the Second Amendment. Photograph by Steve Marcus/Las Vegas Sun via Reuters.
This week's cover, "Party Rentals," by Bruce Eric Kaplan. #TNYcovers
Whether you know her as Cruella de Vil or Eleanor of Aquitaine, don't miss Glenn Close at this year's New Yorker Festival, on October 6th. Click the link in our bio to buy tickets.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan. #TNYcartoons

What does sound look like? It’s a question that the German photographer Martin Klimas explores in his series “Sound Explosions.” For it, he asked a group of musicians to create “patches” of sound using a variety of analog synthesizers, then played the sounds from speakers positioned beneath a scrim covered with powdered pigments. The results: raw sound converted into sunbursts of brilliant color. Photographs by @martin.klimas/Foley Gallery.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The first thing to say about La Morada, a little Oaxacan restaurant in the South Bronx, is that the food is excellent. Natalia Mendez has been serving delicious examples of her native state’s cuisine in this heliotrope-painted room for almost a decade. A rainbow of moles—red, green, black, even white, delicately spiced with chiles and chocolate and cinnamon and pine nuts—are served over tender dark chicken meat, and have gained a legion of fans. And who could forget the tamales? Once you start, you want to try everything. Click the link in our bio to read the full review. Photograph by  @dollyfaibyshev for TNY.

@cathyland1's portrait series "Wait-And-See-Pudding with Patience Sauce" looks at the potential of geothermal energy on the small island of Nevis. This week, she took over our photo department's Instagram account to share images from the Caribbean, Mongolia, and across China. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by @paulnoth, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Every medium has its breakout star. For Instagram Stories, it's Busy Philipps, who has transformed her daily life as a struggling actor and L.A. mother into an addictive sitcom. Click the link in our bio to read more about why the star's stories are so beloved. Illustration by @emhaasch.
A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The rise of Cardi B is dizzying. Earlier this week, she became the first solo female rap act to top the Billboard charts since Lauryn Hill in 1998. In her own way, she has made the Billboard rankings, an industry relic, of sorts, seem relevant, again. Click the link in our bio to read @doreenstfelix on one of the most dramatic music stories of the year. Photograph by Thaddaeus McAdams/WireImage/Getty.
@steinbergdrawscartoons draws the unfinished business that will force him to come back as a ghost. 👻

Our staff writer Ben Taub is talking about his encounters with smugglers, jihadis, and spies on our Instagram stories. Check it out, and don't miss his full event at the New Yorker Festival, on October 7th. Click the link in our bio to buy tickets. #TNYfest

The scale of the recent devastation in Puerto Rico, after Hurricane Maria, has been slow to register in the wider American imagination, partly because infrastructure damage has made communication difficult, if not often impossible. What Puerto Rico needs remains the question. It must be taken up as a priority by Congress, and generous federal assistance must be voted on soon. Every part of American society must respond, and that begins by paying attention. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Ricardo Arduengo/AFP/Getty.

The photographer @joshuawoods is sharing his images from Sicily on our photo department’s Instagram. He started off at Scala dei Turchi, on the coast of Realmonte, near Porto Empedocle, in southern Sicily. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.

While recording his self-titled solo album, Harry Styles unearthed an inner rock star—or, at least, buried his past as a member of the boy band One Direction. The result, released in May, was an impressive collection of ballads and bops that aspire to Prince and Bowie, whose shoes no one can be faulted for wanting to fill. He'll be at the Radio City Music Hall on Sept. 28. Photograph by Terence Patrick / CBS via Getty.

To celebrate a million fans on our cartoon account, we're highlighting stories from some of our cartoonists on the first time they made a cartoon sale to us. Head over to @newyorkercartoons to hear the story behind this cartoon by @j.a.k._

The photographer Carolyn Drake set out for the U.S.-Mexico border just after Donald Trump won the Presidency. “There are people in this country who want to protect themselves from what they perceive as the dangers of Mexico and Mexicans, and I wanted to see the place that felt like it needed protection,” she said. For two weeks, she drove from California to El Paso, taking pictures of the people, scenes, and landscapes she saw along the way. “I felt I could see America better from a little north of the border.” Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @drakeycake.
Common Venmo charges, decoded, by @drawingolive.

Donald Trump’s invective toward N.F.L. players who kneel during the national anthem highlights the racially charged demands facing black entertainers. His free-range lunacy shows that the last 60 years haven’t dimmed the dynamic confronted by any prominent black person tasked with entertaining millions of white ones. Click the link in our bio to read Jelani Cobb on how "ungrateful" is the new "uppity." Photograph by Michael Zagaris / San Francisco 49ers / Getty.

“Sitting on the stoop is such a New York thing,” @kadirnelson, the artist behind this week’s cover, "Generations," says. He lives in Los Angeles but has fond memories of the Clinton Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn, from his days as a student at Pratt Institute. “Brownstones, stoops, leaves turning: that’s fall in New York, and I was also thinking about all the sweet moments I’ve had with my daughters.” #TNYcovers

Emily Mae Smith conjures Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres’s “Oedipus and the Sphinx” and a bewitched broom from “Fantasia” in her superbly weird painting “The Riddle,” on view through October 29th at the Simone Subal Gallery. Courtesy @emaesmith and @simonesubalgallery.
A cartoon by Edward Steed, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The demolition of the Kosciuszko Bridge, which was scheduled to begin this morning at 5:00 A.M., has been postponed. But any day now, maybe, the last sections of the bridge (which has connected Queens and Brooklyn since 1939) will be blown up, and the original bridge will be no more. Recently, the illustrator @abstractsunday took a morning to draw the old structure—remembering the agonizing hours he’d spent on the highway above— and simply enjoying the view. Swipe through to see more.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The Dutch fashion designer Iris Van Herpen is considered one of the most innovative and consequential fashion designers currently at work. Her designs unite the most forward-looking technology with artisanal craftsmanship. Think: a minidress that resembles a stylized skeleton and was 3-D-printed with a white synthetic polymer. That dress was acquired by the Metropolitan Museum in 2012—a fate befalling more and more of her designs that end up in museums. Read more about the avant-garde designer and her hi-tech couture at the link in our bio. Photograph by @carlavandeputtelaar for TNY.

Amaka Osakwe, the designer of the fashion line @maki.oh, is obsessed with the female form and seduction—subversive interests for a Nigerian woman. Her clothes, for the clients who can afford them, are both armor and lingerie: intimidating but inviting, with unyielding lines and delicate materials. They reflect her sense that women in her country are constantly negotiating how tough or how soft to be in a patriarchal society. Click the link in our bio to read @aokeowo's story on West Africa's most daring designer. Photograph by @lakinogunbanwo for TNY.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz, for the first day of fall. #TNYcartoons

“What if you could take Sephora and Coachella and smash it into one thing?” Moj Mahdara, the C.E.O. of Beautycon, says of the multicity cosmetics festival. The events are a surreal convergence of cosmetics, “influencers,” and a new generation of customer—where cosmetics are sold with the self-empowering language of Instagram. Click the link in our bio to see photos from Beautycon L.A., which drew some 20,000 attendees this year. Photograph by @evaoleary for TNY.
A cartoon by @drawnbytom, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Riz Ahmed has joined The New Yorker Festival lineup. On October 6th, he’ll talk with @aokeowo about life after "The Night Of." Click the link in our bio to buy tickets. #TNYfest

For MOMA’s first fashion exhibition since 1944, John Edmonds photographed his friends—young men and women of color— in clothes the museum has deemed among the past century’s most indispensable. By treating the clothing like it is as crucial to design as an apartment, or a car—the exhibit digs away at the idea of fashion, its surface charms, to ask the questions that trend doesn’t bother with, such as why we wear what we wear and how it affects not just the self but others. Click the link in our bio to read @hilton.als on “Items: Is Fashion Modern?” Photograph by @johncedmonds. Photo editor @siobhanbohnacker.
A cartoon by David Sipress, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Russell Westbrook’s manner of dress is inextricable, on some level, from the way he acquits himself on the court. In both arenas, he seems interested more in expression than rote utility, and is, in this way, more artist than competitor, more couturier than stylish pedestrian. The M.V.P.’s interest in fashion is an increasingly large part of his off-court profile—as his glossy new coffee-table book proves. Click the link in our bio to read Vinson Cunningham on “Style Drivers.” Photograph by Zach Beeker/OKC Thunder.

“Feathers are about seduction,” the plumassier Eric Charles-Donatien says. His work, creating feathered clothing and accessories for the fashion industry, is trickier than one would expect. The world is full of birds, but the loveliest ones are off limits, protected by international conventions against the trade in exotics. Even antique feathers can be used only in the occasional, one-of-a-kind piece, and then only if the client agrees never to take it out of the country. So Charles-Donatien haunts the flea markets and taxidermy shops of Paris, eyes peeled for a flash of feathers. Photograph by @paridukovic.

Need an evening dress embellished with acrylic spikes? Or a top crafted from flame-burnished iron mesh? Then Iris van Herpen is your go-to. Click the link in our bio to learn how the Dutch fashion designer combines 3-D printing and hand stitching to reimagine the possibilities of the human body. Photograph by @carlavandeputtelaar for TNY.
A cartoon by @slautow, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

It's been ten years since "Gossip Girl" premièred on the CW. Remember Blair, Serena, and our “one and only source into the scandalous lives of Manhattan’s élite” with Nancy Franklin's review of the first season, from 2007. Link in bio. Photograph by AF archive/Alamy. #TNYarchive
Get your weekly art and design fix from our newest Instagram account. Follow @newyorkerart.
A cartoon by @carolitajohnson, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by @joedator, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Don’t miss Tracee Ellis Ross in conversation with Doreen St. Félix, on October 8th, at the New Yorker Festival. Click the link in our bio for tickets. #TNYfest

Last month, an enormous salmon farm off Cypress Island in Washington State spilled tens of thousands of Atlantic salmon into Puget Sound. Luckily, Lummi Nation fishermen promptly took their boats to the site and cast their nets, seining hundreds of disoriented escapees, who could have otherwise threatened native king, silver, and chum salmon. Click the link in our bio to read more about the incident and the environmental perils of fish farming. Photograph by Brandon Sawaya/SOULCRAFT ALLSTARS.
A cartoon by Roz Chast, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

For a long time, it has been hard to love the man once known (and now known again) as Cat Stevens. He formally retired from the music world in 1978, changing his name to Yusuf Islam, and disowning his previous artistic output—a confusing, dispiriting slap in the face to those it once meant a great deal to. Then, in 2006, came “An Other Cup,” his first album of commercial music in twenty-eight years. How welcome it was to hear that voice with that guitar again, after all those years. Click the link in our bio to read about the unlikely return of Cat Stevens, who releases a new album this week. Photograph by Matt Writtle/ eyevine/Redux.
A cartoon by @paulnoth, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

For more than a decade, Matthew Pillsbury has been photographing city scenes using long exposures, a process that turns his environs, whether a cherry-blossom-filled park in Tokyo or the High Line in New York City, into opalescent blurs of light and movement. For his latest exhibition, which opened yesterday in Chelsea, he says he was interested in “how we maneuver the pathways in between the political chaos.” Click the link in our bio to see more of his work. Photograph by @screenlives.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Jeremy Scott finds inspiration in jarring sources—in junk food, for instance, or Jesus—and he likes to dress adults in teddy-bear prints. After years bouncing between obscurity and the outright disdain of the fashion cognoscenti, his label’s 20th anniversary is made all the more notable by the fact that he has only recently experienced popular, critical, and financial success. Click the link in our bio to learn how he became the designer for stars like @katyperry, @madonna, and @mileycyrus. Photographs by Peter White/Getty and Jason DeCrow/AP.

Father John Misty’s music and his persona are at entrancing odds. The former is chillingly poignant and aching in tone: Randy Newman meets John Lennon meets Tupac. The latter is cocksure, scrambled, alternately enraged and uninterested: Eric Cartman meets Charles Manson meets Dash Snow. Before he plays at Capitol Theatre in Port Chester, New York, tonight, read Nick Paumgarten’s Profile of the artist at the link in our bio. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This would have been our post-election cover if Hillary Clinton had won the Presidency. On Election Night, she expected to give a victory speech. Instead, the next morning, before hundreds of shocked, weeping staﬀers, she made her way through a hastily drafted message of endurance and gratitude. As she and Bill Clinton were driven away in their car, she was hollowed out, unable to speak, struggling to breathe: “At every step I felt that I had let everyone down. Because I had.” Click the link in our bio to read David Remnick's interview with the former Presidential candidate. Cover by @malikafavre.

Is something missing from your life—possibly involving valets, brooding, and the Spanish influenza? Consider filling the void left by “Downton Abbey” with “Time and the Conways.” The Countess of Grantham herself, Elizabeth McGovern, will star in a the revival of J. B. Priestley’s 1937 drama, which charts the changing fortunes of a wealthy Yorkshire clan from 1919 to the thirties and back again. Previews begin tomorrow at the American Airlines Theatre. Photograph by @dedecim for TNY.
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“I didn’t get the most positive reaction from actual Georgians,” Netty Davit’ashvili, the owner of Cheeseboat, said of the restaurant’s name. It’s based on the shape of Georgia’s national dish, actually called khachapuri. The kitchen—headed by Netty’s mother—has reimagined the centuries-old recipe baking in a slew of new ingredients: spinach, beetroot, prosciutto, lobster, house-made truffle butter. Click the link in our bio for the full review of the Williamsburg bistro. Photograph by @amylombard for TNY.

The latest work of the French artist JR, an enormous portrait of Kikito, a smiling toddler, now peers over the border wall in Tecate, an hour southeast of San Diego. By pasting the child’s portrait onto a special scaffolding placed just behind the border fence with California, the little boy seems to be peering over the slatted fence as if from inside a crib, getting ready to crawl toward something that’s caught his interest. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by John Francis Peters/NYT via Redux.
A cartoon by @maddiedai, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Sixteen years later, a look back at our cover, “9/11/2001.” #TNYcovers
A cartoon by David Borchart. #TNYcartoons

The moth doesn’t enjoy the same charmed reputation as its lepidopteran cousin, the butterfly. They're usually dismissed as pests, waging war on our sweaters when they’re not dive-bombing the lights. But with his kaleidoscopic project “Mariposas Nocturnas,” the photographer Emmet Gowin transforms the apparently lowly subject into riveting art. He photographed more than a thousand species on visits to Bolivia, Brazil, Ecuador, French Guiana, and Panama, in the company of entomologists. Click the link in our bio for a closer look at each one of these. Photograph by  Emmet Gowin.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“Sometimes I feel like my singing voice is coming from them,” Káryyn says of her ancestors. From a young age, the Syrian-American artist understood that a legacy of misfortune haunted her family. And it’s their history of perseverance and strife that informs the supernatural and ancient sound of her music. Click the link in our bio to read @pitchfork's story about Káryyn’s curiously powerful experimental pop. Photograph by @annadobos.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts. #TNYcartoons

This week, @womenphotograph took over our photo department’s account to share work from female and non-binary visual journalists, including the Australian photographer @raphaelarosella. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
