Whether you want to see comedians or musicians, authors or artists, the 2017 New Yorker Festival has something for everyone. Don’t miss talks with Chelsea Manning, Jerry Seinfeld, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Ai Weiwei, Carly Rae Jepsen, and more. Click the link in our bio to buy tickets. #TNYfest

An early look at next week's cover, "Warhead," by Eric Drooker. "I tried to capture the mystery—and the deep anxiety—of the moment,” he says of Kim Jong Un, who is the subject of a new story by Evan Osnos about North Korea. Click the link in our bio to read it. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez. #TNYcartoons

Del the Funky Homosapien is one of rap’s last true enigmas. After writing for the rapper Ice Cube (his cousin), in 1990, he sketched his own wacky slacker style as an alternative to big-budget sounds, perfected on the blissed-out verses he lent to the Gorillaz for their 2001 trip-hop hit, “Clint Eastwood.” The Oakland cult hero has since led an unhurried career of cherished offshoot projects and sporadic appearances. He materializes at Brooklyn Bowl on September 12, before floating off again. Photograph by @mahaney_mark for TNY.

According to the N.Y.C. health code, “wild” animals cannot legally be kept by private owners in the city without a special permit. But that doesn’t stop people from keeping them. Raja may look like regular house cat on a back-yard porch, but this diabetic savannah cat is lean, spotted, and big enough to slay your neighbor’s poodle. Click the link in our bio to see more images of the exotic pets of N.Y.C. 🐯🐍 Photograph by @matias.wo.

Korean pop music—characterized by visual outrageousness, factory-made superstars, and sounds and styles that reflect Western pop like a fun-house mirror—became widely known to Americans after the world-conquering success of “Gangnam Style.” Now, it hits Off Broadway, in @arsnovanyc’s “KPOP,” a new immersive theatre piece. Photograph by @mjasik for TNY.
A cartoon by @drawnbytom, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The twenty-year-old rapper cupcakKe, born Elizabeth Eden Harris, delights in the freedom of being a self-released, independent artist on the Internet. Her music is teeming with pornographic vernacular that is rarely heard or seen among more mainstream artists. But, like Lil’ Kim twenty years ago, it's mainly preoccupied with the subject of vulnerability. Click the link in our bio to read more about @cupcakkeafreakk. Photograph courtesy YouTube.
A cartoon by @jeremywins, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This weekend, the photographer Philip Montgomery visited Houston and its surrounding areas to document the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey. He accompanied Lauren Gundlach and her father to their home on Legend Lane, where the water reached well above Lauren’s waist (though you could see from the brown line on the walls that it had crested a foot higher). It isn’t expected to recede for another two or three weeks. See more photos on our Instagram story. Photograph by @philipmontgomery.

Join us for the 2017 New Yorker Festival on October 6th, 7th, and 8th—three days of in-depth discussions, live performances, and excursions in New York City. Tickets go on sale September 8th, at 12 P.M. E.S.T. Early access for Mastercard cardholders begins September 7th, at 11 A.M. Click the link in our bio for the full lineup.
How did this happen? A cartoon by Mick Stevens, for #LaborDay. #TNYcartoons

Watching the apocalyptic photographs and videos released in the wake of Hurricane Harvey this week, the cartoonist Chris Ware singled out moments of grace as inspiration for this week’s cover, "Hurricane Harvey." #TNYcovers
A cartoon by David Sipress, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

For our Television Issue, we dove into our archive to revisit how we’ve reviewed some iconic TV shows. Here’s the final series we’re looking back at: “'The Wire' débuted in June, 2002, looking more or less like a cop show. But the differences were important. It spent as much time with the lawbreakers as it did with the law enforcers. And you didn’t see the suspects through the cops’ eyes only—you saw them through their own as well. The drug trade emerged as its own intricate bureaucracy, a hierarchy that subtly mirrored that of the police department." Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by HBO via Everett.
Roz Chast traces a lifetime of TV shows.
A cartoon by John Norment. #TNYcartoons

“There has certainly never been anything like it on TV, and on network TV there never could be anything like it—it goes out on a limb that doesn't even exist at networks. ‘The Sopranos’ has become a phenomenon: the word of mouth since it began has caused people to suddenly and urgently sign up for HBO after years of living contentedly without it.” Read more of Nancy Franklin's 1999 review of the show in our archives. Photograph by HBO via Getty.
.
Our inaugural Television Issue is out this week, but our writers have been covering TV for a long, long time. So we dove into our archive to revisit how we reviewed some iconic TV shows.

“It’s hard to say what’s great about ‘Friday Night Lights’ without feeling that you’re emphasizing the wrong thing, because although the show’s particulars are distinctive and special, it seems not to be made up of parts at all—to just be an organic whole. In short, it feels like life. The show isn’t merely set it the world of West Texas football; it is that world.” Read more of Nancy Franklin’s 2007 review at the link in our bio. Photograph by Collection Christophel / Alamy. #ClearEyesFullHeartsCantLose
.
Our first-ever Television Issue is out this week, but our writers have been covering TV shows for a long, long time. So we dove into our archive to revisit how we reviewed some iconic TV shows.

“Well is it named Labor Day, for travel is never so laborious as then.” This sentence, written for our magazine in 1925, still applies today—maybe more than ever. We’re wishing you all safe travels and a happy Labor Day weekend. Don’t forget to take along your @newyorkermag. Photograph by David Jay Zimmerman/Getty.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Michaela Coel was a playwright before she began starring as Tracey, a lusty Pentecostal virgin with bumbling verve, on the show “Chewing Gum”—a show that she adapted from one of her plays. She's one of a new breed of bold writer-performers, who’ve created roles only they can play. For this week's Television Issue, the photographer Richard Burbridge made portraits of several of these television-comedy auteurs, including @issarae, @peteholmes, and more. Click the link in our bio to see them all. Photograph by @richardburbridge.

Our inaugural Television Issue is out this week, but our writers have been covering TV shows for a long, long time. So we dove into our archive to revisit how we reviewed some iconic TV shows. Up next: Nancy Franklin’s 2000 review of “The West Wing.” The show “manages to make the White House staff, and their work, seem glamorous. They're all witty, quick on their feet, effective, and attractive. And their leader, President Josiah Bartlett, a liberal Democrat, a former governor of New Hampshire, and a Nobel Laureate in economics, is a man you can believe in.” Read more of the review in our archives at the link in our bio. Photograph by NBC via Everett.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week's issue. #TNYcartoons
Netflix shows recommended hyper-specifically for you, by @j.a.k._ and @blythelikehappy. Click the link in our bio to see them all.

“‘Gossip Girl,’ by its very title, promises both to tell you the secrets of the city and to remind you that you weren’t invited to the party. The chances of a tornado coming along to lift you up out of your farm in Kansas and deposit you (and your annual tuition fee of $30,000) at the Constance Billard School for Girls, on Ninety-third Street, just east of Fifth Avenue, which Blair Waldorf and Serena van der Woodsen attend, are about the same as the chances of Blair and Serena ever finding themselves in Kansas.” Read more of Nancy Franklin’s 2007 review at the link in our bio. Photograph by The CW via Everett.
.
Our inaugural Television Issue is out this week, but our writers have been covering TV for long time. So we dove into our archive to revisit how we reviewed some iconic TV shows.
A cartoon by @maggiejanelarson, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“As Liz Lemon, who’s in charge of the writers of a ‘Saturday Night Live’-like show-within-a-show, Tina Fey is the central character of ‘30 Rock.’ The character is obviously inspired by Fey’s career at ‘S.N.L.’ The show doesn’t have the neat structure of most sitcoms; its roots are in sketch comedy and in improv, with their set pieces and their eagerness to keep you entertained every second without worrying too much about the story.” Click the link in our bio to read the rest of Nancy Franklin's 2008 review. Photograph by George Taylor/Everett via Alamy.
.
Our first-ever Television Issue is out this week, but our writers have been covering TV for a long, long time. So we dove into our archive to revisit how we reviewed some iconic TV shows.
A cartoon by @kuperart, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“Despite ‘Law and Order: SVU’’s feminist bona fides, it’s striking how many stories have retrograde themes. In one, a classic ‘bad rape victim’—she lies, she cheats, she dresses trashily—is redeemed because she’s a good mom. In another, a workaholic detective murders a kindergarten teacher because she got what the cop couldn’t: a proposal and a baby. The dialogue can lean hard on stereotypes. Yet even flawed stories can be saved by great guest performances.” Read more of Emily Nussbaum’s 2013 story on the pulp appeal of “Law & Order: SVU” at the link in our bio. Photograph by Virginia Sherwood / NBC via Everett.
.
Our first-ever Television Issue is out this week, but our writers have been covering TV shows for a long, long time. So we dove into our archive to revisit how we reviewed some iconic TV shows.
This week’s cover, "Screen Time," by Bruce Eric Kaplan. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @carolitajohnson, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“A Week of Revolution” begins today at Boscobel House and Gardens, the home of the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival. Only ninety minutes north of the city, the week will including reënactments, picnics, hikes, and a staging of Richard Nelson’s play “The General from America,” about Benedict Arnold, who tried to hand his command of West Point—visible across the river—over to the British. Photograph by @caitoppermann for TNY.

Our first-ever Television Issue is out tomorrow, but our writers have been covering TV for a long, long time. So we dove into our archive to revisit how we reviewed some iconic TV shows. Here's what Terrence Rafferty had to say about the first season of “Twin Peaks,” in 1990: “On the face of it, the idea of David Lynch's creating a series for television sounds like a joke. His movies, which include ‘Eraserhead,’ ‘The Elephant Man,’ and ‘Blue Velvet,’ are everything that American television isn't: adventurous, disturbing, erotic, visually exciting, and absolutely personal. What could he possibly do for the bland, corporate medium of prime-time television? And what could it do for him (other than make studio moviemaking look liberating by comparison)? The first episode, two hours long, is directed by Lynch, from a script he wrote with Mark Frost (who worked on "Hill Street Blues"), and it's miraculously good.” Photograph from Everett. #TwinPeaks
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In Valérie Belin’s series “Super Models,” she presents store-window mannequins in three-quarter-length poses, their plastic bodies surreally superimposed with raster-dot patterns and concentric circles. With visible arm joints and missing nipples, the mannequins advertise their artifice from the start—suggesting that even our endless digital-image stream has room for the uncanny. Click the link in our bio to see more of the French photographer’s work. Photography by Valérie Belin /Courtesy Galerie Nathalie Obadia, Paris/Bruxelles.
A cartoon by David Sipress, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

For art-world denizens of a certain age, the Polish artist Piotr Uklański’s most significant work will always be the light-up dance floor at Passerby, the defunct bar on West Fifteenth Street owned by his former dealer Gavin Brown. Those who are a bit younger might remember the photographs from his series “The Joy of Photography,” many of which were displayed at the @metmuseum in 2015. But if you missed that too, don’t worry. You can see more of his work at the link in our bio. Photograph © Piotr Uklański.
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo. #TNYcartoons

The photographer Steven Laxton was travelling in Bangkok when he decided to shoot the city’s cabaret theatres. A popular tourist attraction, the venues’ razzle-dazzle performances—featuring extravagant costumes and burlesque-style dances—are known for featuring the transgender women and gender non-conforming men known as kathoey, in Thai. Laxton’s lush, careful portraits draw individuals from beneath the cabaret’s gaudy spectacle, and serve as quiet rebuttals to the gawking caricatures of kathoey elsewhere in Western pop culture. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @steven_laxton.
A N.Y.C. summer scavenger hunt, as drawn by @misslaskogross. How many of these have you spotted today?
A cartoon by Zachary Kanin. #TNYcartoons

The artist Kim Keever is known for crafting elaborate dioramas in an aquarium, then releasing pigments into the tank and taking pictures of the underwater scenes. The resulting images sit somewhere “between reality and artificiality,” he says. His inspiration comes from geology, botany, and from his own personal experiences of the natural world, many of them from his childhood on the Eastern Shore of Virginia. Click the link in our bio to see more of his “Abstract” series. Photograph courtesy @kimkeever.art/Waterhouse & Dodd.

“It’s all about sex and drugs and sadness,” Annie Clark, the songwriter and multi-instrumentalist known as St. Vincent, says of her new album. For it, she’s hooked up with the producer Jack Antonoff, who’s also produced records for Taylor Swift and Lorde. This has led people to wonder: is she making a grab for pop success? Click the link in our bio to read Nick Paumgarten's Profile of the artist. Photograph by @marilynminter for TNY.
A cartoon by Julia Suits, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Balarama Heller began venturing into the Florida Everglades at night with the hope of photographing a Burmese python. When, even with the help of herpetologists and snake hunters, he couldn’t find one, he turned his lens on the local ecosystem instead. Repeated bouts of sleep deprivation and hallucinatory run-ins with the local fauna gave his photos the quality of an eerie dreamscape. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @balaramaheller.

“Wit has truth in it; wisecracking is simply calisthenics with words,” Dorothy Parker, who was born on this day in 1893, once said. The writer, who was known for her acerbic wit and satirical humor, joined our staff at the magazine's inception, in 1925. Over the next 38 years, she contributed more than a hundred pieces, many under the nom de plume Constant Reader. Click the link in our bio to read one of her columns, from 1928, about the book “The House at Pooh Corner.” Photograph by Anthony Calvacca/New York Post via Getty.
A cartoon by @maddiedai, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Today, people across the U.S. stopped what they were doing to watch the first total solar eclipse to cross the country since 1918. In Clinton, S.C., the townspeople were enraptured by the darkening sky above. Comment below and tell us where you watched #eclipse2017. Photographs by @davidburnettfoto ©contactpressimages.
New York City's most eligible pigeons, as drawn by @willmcphail4. Swipe through for more.

The Wavestorm Classic Longboard is a soft surfboard that sells for $100 at Costco. The Wavestorm World Championship is a soft-top-surfboard-only contest, founded in 2015 by the big-wave surfer Shawn Dollar and some friends. Part demolition derby, part beach party, it has no affiliation with Costco and serves as a kind of sendup of the “kooks” (or surf newbies) who tend to ride on these boards. “No matter who you are, when you ride a Wavestorm, you’re a kook,” Dollar says. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Peter King.
A cartoon by @lianafinck. #TNYcartoons
Jason Novak and Adam Bessie imagine philosophers at theme parks. Swipe through for more.

Wes Anderson’s “Moonrise Kingdom” is a great summer-camp movie and a tender, graceful young-adolescent romance. An idiosyncratic reimagination of the 1960s, it relates the era’s struggle against moral and bureaucratic constraints with exuberant energy. This weekend, it made our film critic Richard Brody’s list of movies to stream (all are seaside frolics). So if you’re looking for something to watch tonight, click the link in our bio for more of his picks. Photograph courtesy YouTube.

"A romance is one of the few inherent or natural narratives in human existence," the writer Curtis Sittenfeld says. This week, she joins "The New Yorker Radio Hour" to talk about the timeless appeal of a good romance novel (especially if it contains sex on horseback). 🐎 Click the link in our bio to listen now. Illustration by @rebeccamock.
A cartoon by @jeremywins. #TNYcartoons

Since the 1960s, there haven’t been jazz musicians as artistically significant and generally popular as Duke Ellington, John Coltrane, or Bill Evans. Today, jazz music is a miscellaneous collection of wide-ranging and disputed genres that stands to the side of American culture. How did the train go off the tracks? A listen to two musicians’ performances from one night in New York City—August 17, 1967—offers a few clues. Click the link in our bio for more. Photograph by Marty Lederhandler/AP.
Clowns, they’re just like us. Swipe through to see more of @humanitybytes’s illustrations.

An early look at next week’s cover, “Blowhard,” by David Plunkert. Plunkert seldom takes on political subject matter, but felt moved to do so in light of Trump’s response to the violence in Charlottesville. “A picture does a better job showing my thoughts than words do; it can have a light touch on a subject that’s extremely scary,” he said. #TNYcovers

After Donald Trump’s Inauguration, our staff writer Raffi Khatchadourian flew to London to visit Julian Assange—the first of several trips. His four-part story, in this week’s issue, explores how Assange runs WikiLeaks, how his political views have changed, and what role Russia has in his operation. Link in bio. Photograph by @nadavkander for TNY.

A famous case study by the neuropsychologist Alexander Luria helped spark a myth about a man who could not forget. But the truth is more complicated. Click the link in our bio to read about the mystery of S., the man with an impossible memory. Illustration by @leighguldig.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Last week, the photographer @david_ablehams took over our photo department's Instagram to share his images from Morocco. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more of his work.
The President explores some alt-hair styles. A cartoon by @kuperart. #TNYcartoons

Over the weekend, in Charlottesville, the photographer Steve Helber shot an image of peculiar symmetry. Two men extend weapons: one is the Confederate flag, furled, and the other is an aerosol can, modified to eject fire. The composition is fiercely theological, @doreenstfelix writes. The black man is wielding what the black theologian James Cone, quoting the prophet Jeremiah, might call the “burning fire shut up in my bones”; what James Baldwin would have identified as “the fire next time.” Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Steve Helber/AP.

At fifty years old, “Bonnie and Clyde” is one of the oldest American movies you can watch today without feeling like you’re watching an old movie. One big reason is that it was made in between two regimes of self-censorship: the old Production Code and the ratings system. Two years earlier, the movie would not have been approved by the M.P.A.A. Two years later, it would have been rated X. It found a historical sweet spot. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Glasshouse Images/Alamy.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“Spending time in nature is something I do solely for the happiness of my children, like going to puppet shows or listening to Katy Perry,” @adriantomine, the artist behind this week’s cover, "Upstate," says. He recently went upstate with his family for a taste of fresh air. “I can wander around the city with my kids, potentially surrounded by psychopaths, and I’m completely at ease. But put us in some tall grass, and all my neurotic, protective instincts come out.” #TNYcovers

Sally Gall’s photographs of laundry flapping on a line transform a domestic chore into a celebration of color and abstract form. Seen from below against cloudless blue-and-white skies, garments billow and flow, becoming jellyfish, calla lilies, birds in flight. See more at the link in our bio. Photograph © Sally Gall/Courtesy Julie Saul Gallery, New York.

This weekend in Charlottesville was not the first time this country has witnessed the mass mobilization of Nazis. But it is the first time we’ve seen such a feeble response to those gatherings in the upper echelons of American power. In his latest comments, Donald Trump spoke in platitudes. He was a man looking for gray areas where there were none, Jelani Cobb writes. Click the link in our bio to read his piece on Charlottesville. Photograph by Glenna Gordon for TNY.
A people-watcher’s guide to N.Y.C. park poses, as drawn by @unnecessaryobservations. Swipe through to see more.

In traditional Chinese culture, mandarin ducks, which are believed to mate for life, symbolize unflinching fidelity. A similar degree of devotion can be inspired by Sichuanese cuisine—like that served at Birds of a Feather, a new eatery in Williamsburg. With surefire hits like spicy cumin lamb and standout dishes including spicy-and-sour tofu pudding, the food blithely defies preconceived notions about Americans’ low heat tolerance. Click the link in our bio to read Jiayang Fan’s review. Photograph by David Williams for TNY.
A cartoon by Corey Pandolph. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

You probably haven’t seen Orson Welles’s 1962 adaptation of Kafka’s “The Trial,” but now you can watch it for free—that is—if you have a New York Public Library card. It’s just one of a wealth of films that the library has made available to stream at home through the service Kanopy. Click the link in our bio to read our film critic Richard Brody’s picks for what to watch this weekend. Photograph from Everett.

What does Viceland’s first scripted series, “What Would Diplo Do?,” which stars James Van Der Beek as the D.J. and producer, have to say about the millennial condition? Our staff writer Amanda Petrusich tries to sort it out. Link in bio. Photograph by Shane McCauley/@viceland.
A cartoon by Zachary Kanin. #TNYcartoons

Damon Krukowski’s six-episode podcast, “Ways of Hearing,” begins with an exciting analog sound: that of a needle descending on a record. It proceeds to make us think about the act of listening itself, in ways that feel timely and vital. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @spiritditty.

Jackie Siegel has a private plane, a closet full of clothes from Chanel, and a taxidermied dog (a former family pet) named for that brand. She was the subject of Lauren Greenfield’s 2012 documentary, “The Queen of Versailles,” and is included in the new book “Generation Wealth,” which brings together images Greenfield has taken over the last 25 years. The book is concerned with displays of wealth, be it among teen sneaker collectors, plastic-surgery aficionados, or seventy-two-year-old pageant queens. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @greenfield_lauren.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. #TNYcartoons

Ben Zucker, a photographer from upstate New York and avid sailor since childhood, moors a small sailboat at the City Island docks, in the Bronx, which he takes out regularly. He describes the docks as “a strange mixture of outer-borough New York and New England coast." In 2014, he documented a single day of sailing around New York City. Click the link in our bio to see more of his images. Photograph by @saltysearabbit.

For each self-portrait in her series “Daze: Stage of Mind,” the Korean artist Jee Young Lee created an elaborate installation in her studio, in Seoul. The scenes were constructed from everyday materials—plywood, paper cups, straws—and Lee decorated each handmade prop herself. The constructed landscapes are her interpretations of personal experiences, dreams, and Korean folk tales. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Jee Young Lee.
Future civilizations will toil for centuries trying to decode the clues we leave behind, so let’s give them a challenge. Swipe to see all of @nomikane's maddeningly mystifying time capsules.
A cartoon by @larskenseth. #TNYcartoons

The double feature used to be a staple of New York repertory houses, and Film Forum is bringing it back. The “Summer Double Features” series, from Aug. 11 to Sept. 5, includes twenty-eight pairings, ranging from silents to independents, from European political fantasies to Hollywood extravaganzas. The Aug. 22 program offers two film-noir classics, both from 1949, about lovers on the run—Nicholas Ray’s first feature, “They Live by Night,” and Joseph H. Lewis’s “Gun Crazy,” a key inspiration for “Bonnie and Clyde.” Illustration by Mike McQuade / Courtesy Film Forum / Photofest.
A cartoon by Charles Barsotti, from 2008. #TNYcartoons.

The photographer @amivitale's work from Montana is both a testament to a disappearing way of life and an ode to its endurance. Her pictures take us to the Centennial Valley, where she spent time with some of the remaining ranching families in the region and couldn’t help but be impressed by the fortitude, work ethic, and sense of community there. “Neighbors rely on neighbors,” she said. Swipe to see more. Photographs by Ami Vitale.

Every August, the Battery Dance Festival enlivens summer evenings with a series of open-air performances in Battery Park City. One full program, on Aug. 15, is devoted to Indian classical dance, under the auspices of the “Erasing Borders” festival. That program is always a highlight; this year’s participants include a young couple specializing in bharata natyam; Dimple Saikia performing the less-known sattriya, a dance practiced in the monasteries of Assam; and the Bethesda-based kuchipudi ensemble Kalanidhi Dance. But the entire weeklong series, which includes performances by international companies like Mophato Dance (from Botswana) and Compañía Elías Aguirre (from Spain), is worth exploring. Photograph by Darial Sneed.
A cartoon by David Sipress. #TNYcartoons

Here’s to summer days and long reads, like @thereadviewer's. Thank you for sharing this #newyorkerinthewild. Tag us in your photos of The New Yorker, and we might regram you.
Click the link in our bio to read Hye-young Pyun's short story "Caring for Plants."
Freelance achievement stickers, as illustrated by Jeremy Nguyen. Swipe to see more.

In its second season, #Insecure still avoids going out of its way to translate the specificity of the world it portrays. That defiance can be gloriously funny. Click the link in our bio to read more about what Issa Rae's HBO show gets right. Photograph by Justina Mintz / HBO.
A cartoon by @mecharliehankin. #TNYcartoons

Tuki is a kind of break dance and music which mixes street styles, pop culture, house, and techno. In Venezuela, it is taught at a school across the street from Petare, a huge barrio clustered on a hill in the Palo Verde district of Caracas. Click the link in our bio to see more of @janettephoto's photographs of this Tuki crew.

Two grandmothers watch the wedding of their grandson and granddaughter in a tent at the Za’atari refugee camp, in Jordan. For Hanin (center), it was a tough day: “Six men in our family have died in the fighting, and the bride’s brother, Mustafa, was recently killed. This wedding is not just a marriage but a day to remove some sadness that is in our hearts.” Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Alixandra Fazzina.
A cartoon by @kuperart. #TNYcartoons
A little boat takes the photographer @marijastrajnic toward the splashy base of the Niagara Falls. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.

Encores! Off-Center concludes its summer season tomorrow with a concert version of Carole King and Maurice Sendak's children’s musical, "Really Rosie," starring Taylor Caldwell and featuring songs like “Pierre” and “Chicken Soup with Rice.” Illustration by @loris_lora.

“Your job as a citizen and as a decent human being is to constantly affirm and lift up and fight for treating people with kindness and respect and understanding,” President Barack Obama, who was born on this day in 1961, told his daughters, Sasha and Malia, after the results of the election. Click the link in our bio to revisit David Remnick’s account of his time with the President before Trump was elected. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
A cartoon by @christopherweyant. #TNYcartoons
A cartoon by @joedator. #TNYcartoons

Robin Schwartz’s body of work “Amelia’s World,” which features her daughter, is a magical portrait stretching over eleven years. It pictures Amelia with all types of animals—the largest is an elephant and the smallest is a Cotton-Top Tamarin. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @robin_schwartz.
Today's daily cartoon by @larskenseth. #TNYcartoons

Hamed Sinno, the lead singer and lyricist of the Lebanese group Mashrou’ Leila, may be the most prominent gay musician in the Arab world, and much of his songwriting takes aim at homophobia and misogyny. As the group’s stature has grown, so have the concerns of the authorities in many countries where they play. Click the link in our bio to read more about the band. Photograph by Karim Sahib.
Subway substitutes for summer, as illustrated by Luci Gutiérrez.

“We may be able, handful that we are, to end the racial nightmare, and achieve our country, and change the history of the world,” James Baldwin, who was born on this day in 1924, wrote in "Letter from a Region in My Mind," which appeared in our pages in 1962. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Ted Thai/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty.

#LanaDelRey is getting out from under the narratives that have determined her. She is starting to work as if she’s seeing things rather than being seen. Click the link in our bio to read Jia Tolentino on how, on “Lust for Life,” for the first time, the singer isn’t figuring herself as the protagonist but as the narrator. Photograph courtesy YouTube.
Today's daily cartoon by @steinbergdrawscartoons. #TNYcartoons.

The playwright Sam Shepard, who died on Thursday at the age of seventy-three, had an outsider’s mojo and a cagey eye for the main chance. From the day he hit New York to the day he died, his image was always in line; the music of his plays—the fantasy rhymes—sussed the spiritual impasse of his generation. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Michael Ochs Archives / Getty.

The sacking of Anthony Scaramucci signals that John Kelly, a retired marine general, may actually be empowered to be a true chief of staff. There was no bigger test for Kelly than the fate of Scaramucci, who, in his Wednesday phone call, demanded that our staff writer Ryan Lizza reveal his sources for a trivial tweet about who the President had dinner with that night, threatened to fire his entire staff if he didn’t, alleged that he had called the F.B.I. to investigate his White House rivals, attacked Reince Priebus as a “paranoid schizophrenic,” and described Steve Bannon as engaging in auto-fellatio. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Pablo Martinez Monsivais / AP.

Between 1943 and 1944, the internee Bill Manbo, an amateur photographer, captured family portraits and scenes of everyday life at Heart Mountain, a Japanese internment camp, in Wyoming, often set against the camp’s desolate but stunning natural surroundings. Click the link in our bio to see more of Manbo's photos.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. #TNYcartoons

“The commute between my house and studio on Cape Cod is forty-five feet, so what do I know about subway rage?” @bobstaake says, about his cover, “Hell Train,” for this week’s issue. “O.K., maybe I don’t have to ride the subway every day, but my kids, who live in Brooklyn and Queens, do,” he continued. “For me, the only thing worse than descending into a New York City subway in July is descending into a New York City subway in August.” #TNYcovers

The fatalism and menace of film noir has inspired photographers from Bill Armstrong to Cindy Sherman and David Lynch. Their highly-charged images, often modelled after movie stills, are rich in atmosphere and style and evoke a narrative pull, leading the viewer to think about the moments before and after the snap of the shutter. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Bill Armstrong/ClampArt.
Ruby Elliot illustrates some of the reasons your creative type may have broken up with you. Swipe through for more.
A cartoon by Harry Bliss. #TNYcartoons

Advanced-pop criticism believes that you can talk about cultural goods loved uncritically by millions in terms originally developed to talk about cultural goods known mainly to an overeducated few. It’s erudite but caj, geeky and hip, alienated and savvy. Another word for the attitude might be “Brooklyn.” Click the link in our bio to read about a new book of critism that asks whether poetry and pop music can change your life. Illustration by @tshopsin.
A cartoon by @christopherweyant, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by @kuperart. #TNYcartoons

The New Yorker Movie Club, our new Facebook group, is a place for film lovers to gather with like-minded people—it’s like an online book club for films. Discuss everything from your favorite director to the worst movie you’ve ever walked out of. Click the link in our bio to join. Illustration by @virginie.morgand.

Cactuses are spiky and rough; gnarled, Seussian, and sometimes toxic. 🌵They’ve become a mainstay of millennial décor. But, in the same way that a bouquet of wildflowers is banal when compared to an alpine meadow of blooming wildflowers, cactuses in a terrarium pale in comparison to the arresting sight of ancient, alien cactuses in the places they grow wild. It’s a concept illustrated in the book that three cactus-crazed young men put together of pictures drawn from 22 cactus explorers’ archives and spanning 80 years. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Woody Minnich.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

On his new solo album, “Flower Boy,” Tyler, the Creator trades in his trolling behavior for more introspective material. This is especially true on the song “Where This Flower Blooms.” Click the link in our bio to read @laurettaland's review of the track.

On a recent evening, at the Cooper Hewitt, one child discovered the whirling pleasure of the “Spun Chair,” designed by Thomas Heatherwick, in 2010. Every Thursday, until August 24th, the museum hosts an outdoor party on its terrace, an all-ages affair with music and a cash bar for the cocktail set. Tonight, from six to nine, the Juilliard Jazz Trio performs American standards from the nineteen-twenties and thirties. Photograph by @landonnordeman for TNY.
A cartoon by Liam Francis Walsh, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In 2012, Coney Island’s carnivalesque Freak Bar was devastated by Hurricane Sandy. Now it’s back. Check out our Instagram story to go inside the bar and the iconic circus sideshow next door. Photograph by @rebecca.ann.fudala.

In 2010, while Medhanie Yehdego Mered was smuggling migrants through Sinai, Medhanie Tesfamariam Berhe was completing his studies in Eritrea. So why is the latter now in Italy on trial for smuggling? Click the link in our bio to read @bentaub91’s story on the Sicilian prosecutors who are trying the wrong man. Illustration by Oliver Munday.

A candy-factory worker. A caretaker. An apple picker. A hotel worker. All of them mothers. All of them targeted for deportation since January. Donald Trump has portrayed the undocumented as “bad hombres” who threaten the American family unit, but his crackdown has torn some families apart. Click the link in our bio to read the stories of four women who are either primary caretakers of young children or primary family breadwinners, and who are now threatened with deportation. Illustration by @rachellevit.
A cartoon by @ellisjrosen, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In 2009, when Sadiq Khan was sworn in as a member of the Privy Council, he brought his own Quran to Buckingham Palace and left it there—because the palace didn’t have a copy. Now, as mayor of London, he draws much of his political power from the hopeful possibilities he symbolizes. Click the link in our bio to read Sam Knight’s Profile of the first Muslim major of a Western metropolis. Photograph by @nadavkander for TNY.
A cartoon by David Sipress, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“The beach is always only three hundred feet from my studio,” @mariscaloficial says of his cover for this week's issue, entitled "Private Beach." Mariscal works as a graphic artist, furniture designer, painter, and sculptor in coastal Barcelona, Spain. “I go there every morning to look at the different waves, the different blues. I love the way the pine trees harbor a cool breeze—they’re so happy to be close to the sea. Their deep black shadows are a great contrast to the bright light.” #TNYcovers

When Bob Marley died, in 1981, at the age of 36, he didn't leave behind a will. In the decades that followed, he became a sort of myth, his likeness plastered on everything from T-shirts to room mist to cannabis. Click the link in our bio to read Hua Hsu's story on a new oral history that shows just how much of Marley's story is up for grabs. Photograph by David Burnett/Contact Press Images.
A cartoon by Edward Steed. Swipe through to see the rest.

In 1978, Sandy Skoglund did what every parent instructs their children never to do: she played with her food—and then she photographed it. The resulting series of giddy still-life images includes “Cubed Carrots and Kernels of Corn” and is on view at the Ryan Lee gallery through August 11. Photograph courtesy the Artist/Ryan Lee Gallery.

The French photographer Charles Fréger has travelled the world in pursuit of people in costume, interested (always) in how they “look the part.” Between 2013 and 2015, his work took him to Japan to catalogue the Yokai, or monsters, of the country’s folklore. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph © 2016 @charlesfreger.
A cartoon by Alex Gregory, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The photographer Palani Mohan began travelling to the Altais mountains, in far-western Mongolia, to document the traditions of eagle-hunters known as burkitshi. These men climb high into the mountain’s rugged peaks to capture the birds. Then train them, fed them, and love them like their own children. Years later, they set the eagles free. Click the link in our bio to see more images of a dwindling class of Mongolian eagle-hunters. Photograph by @palaniphoto/Courtesy Merrell Publishers.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“It’s like having a birthday party where too many relatives show up,” Ettore Sottsass once said about retrospectives. Tonight, the Met Breuer invites the whole family. Its six-decade survey of the Austrian-Italian designer’s impertinent genius includes everything from the lipstick-red typewriter he conceived for Olivetti, in 1969, to his gonzo work with the Milan-based Memphis design group, in the early eighties. Photograph by @andrewbmyers for TNY.

Starting tonight, The Lincoln Center Festival will celebrate the 50th anniversary of the ballet “Jewels,” by George Balanchine, with three of the world’s greatest companies: the Paris Opera Ballet, the New York City Ballet, and the Bolshoi. Each of the work’s three sections is devoted to a gemstone and set to the music of a different composer, so the French dancers will perform the quiet “Emeralds,” set to music by Gabriel Fauré, while the Americans and the Russians will take turns in the jazzy “Rubies” (set to Stravinsky) and the majestic “Diamonds” (set to Tchaikovsky). Photograph by Agathe Poupeney.

Today is the 48th anniversary of the moon landing. 👨‍🚀🌕 "'Ad astra' ('to the stars') will inspire everyone to forever reach upward and onward," the astronaut Buzz Aldrin told the photographer Steve Pyke years after he walked on the moon. Swipe through to see more of Pyke’s portraits of the astronauts from the Apollo missions.
A cartoon by Sam Gross, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“I wonder if any other photographer in the world has photographed as many cat yawns as I have,” Masahisa Fukase says. When the Japanese photographer’s kitten disappeared, and a stranger returned the wrong animal, he took the stray in anyway and made it the subject of a playful photo series. Each image seems to discover a new shade of the cat’s colossal personality, with no feline gesture too small to celebrate. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Masahisa Fukase.

Tomorrow marks the end of his first half year in the White House, and Donald Trump’s Presidency is in crisis, John Cassidy writes. He is ignoring the turmoil that letting “Obamacare fail” would generate for millions of Americans whose welfare it is his duty to protect. Click the link in our bio to read about the President’s clueless abdication of responsibility. Illustration by @dougchayka.

It’s fitting and strange that Don Draper, who was introduced to us in "Mad Men" ten years ago today, should seem so well-preserved. He falls into the messiness of the sixties with an adman’s militant sense of hygiene. His teeth are the battlements on the castle walls of his face. Meanwhile, in every episode, the bodies of other characters are breached. Click the link in our bio to read more about the weird agelessness of the show's protagonist. Photograph by Craig Blankenhorn/© AMC/Courtesy: Everett Collection.

George Strait is, by some measures, the most popular country-music singer of all time and, by any measure, the most consistent. At his concerts, people go “fucking crazy,” as one executive put it. But in an age of shameless self-promotion, can such a reserved star keep holding on? Click the link in our bio to read Kelefa Sanneh’s Profile of the musician. Photograph by @maxinehelfman2 for TNY.
A cartoon by William Haefeli, from this week's issue. #TNYcartoons
Theodore certainly seems to be enjoying last week's issue. 🐱Thank you for sharing this #newyorkerinthewild, @missvickihughes. Tag us in your photos of The New Yorker, and you could be featured too.
Nelson Mandela would have turned 99 years old today. Our 2013 cover, "Madiba" by @kadirnelson, celebrated the legendary leader. #MandelaDay #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @cartoonamy, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Eight months before she was killed in Auschwitz, the artist Charlotte Salomon poisoned her grandfather. She documented the event in real time, in a 35-page letter and an ink drawing, which her family hid for over sixty years. The English translation of the letter will be published this fall. Click the link in our bio to learn more about the painter, auteur, enigma, and murderer. Photograph courtesy the Jewish Historical Museum © Charlotte Salomon Foundation.

“I never realized I wanted to spend time with people. I was so used to being isolated and alone,” Jennifer Lee said of meeting her partner, Michelle Ainsworth. Last year, the couple made the decision to undergo gender-confirmation surgery together. Jennifer had her surgery first, an experience that Geraldine Hope Ghelli chronicled in a photo series entitled “Born Twice.” See more at the link in our bio. Photograph by @geraldinehopeghelli.
A cartoon by Tom Chitty, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
@lianafinck imagines what it would be like to make yourself at home in New York City’s discarded furniture. (Beware of bedbugs!) Swipe through for more.

What did our Pulitzer Prize-winning critic Emily Nussbaum think of "Game of Thrones" all the way back in 2012? Take a moment before tonight’s première to find out. Link in bio. Illustration by Vasili Zorin. #GOT

Behind a pub in rural England, a doctor is working to change the laws governing outer space. He talks about his novel strategy to claim Mars on this week’s “New Yorker Radio Hour.” Link in bio. Illustration by @richiepope.
A cartoon by @lianafinck. #TNYcartoons
A cartoon by Alice Cheng, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

An early look at next week's cover, "Grounded." When we asked Barry Blitt about his image for the issue, he responded by quoting a Russian: “Tolstoy said that ‘happy families are all alike, but every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.’ Somehow this seems to apply to the Trumps, particularly lately.” #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @maggiejanelarson, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

What’s so winning about a flattened avocado offered at a manageable yet also totally exorbitant price? Something about avocado toast taps into a deeper sense of where the world is headed, and—depending on your view of that future—is either scrumptious or abhorrent. Nathan Heller shares his grand unified theory of avocado toast at the link in our bio. Photograph by Evgenija Lanz/EyeEm/Getty.
@eflakeagogo draws the things she's afraid her daughter will be doing in 2026. Swipe through to see them all.

The Micronesian atoll of Pingelap is sometimes called “The Island of the Colorblind.” Most of its population is affected by complete achromatopsia, or total color blindness. A few years ago, the Belgian photographer Sanne De Wilde travelled there to shoot traditional black-and-white photographs and digital-infrared images, which she used to challenge her own understanding of color. After returning to Amsterdam, she asked color-blind collaborators to paint over some of the black-and-white pictures, which will be released in a book this month. Check out the link in our bio to see more of her work. Photograph by Sanne De Wilde.
A cartoon by @kimwarp. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“It is still nothing,” a Trump-campaign official kept saying about Donald Trump, Jr.',s meeting with a Russian lawyer during the campaign. Then Trump's emails were posted, and the official amended his reaction. Click the link in our bio to read Ryan Lizza's reporting on how, in less than 90 minutes, the sentiment from people sympathetic to the President’s son shifted from "nothingburger" to “I hope he doesn’t go to jail.” Photograph by Mark Peterson/Redux.

Andy Freeberg began photographing art fairs, like Art Basel Miami Beach, after completing a series on the large white entrance desks in Chelsea galleries. He was looking for a more colorful, transparent atmosphere with the dealers and gallery directors right in the middle of the action. “I was attracted not only to the people but to the combinations of art, clothing, technical devices, and postures,” he says. Click the link in our bio to see more from his series “Art Fare.” Photograph by @andyfreebergfoto/Kopeikin Gallery.
A cartoon by David Sipress, from 2014. #TNYcartoons

In 1964, the novelist and screenwriter Nell Dunn invited a few friends to her house, opened a bottle of wine, and started asking questions. The result: “Talking to Women,” a short book of the edited conversations, which are revealing about the time just before second-wave feminism—yet still feel contemporary. Read more about the forgotten classic at the link in our bio. Illustration by @bethhoeckel.

“Can you imagine if I named this place Casablanca?” Mario Carta says of his new Mediterranean-Moroccan bistro, Chouchou. From the frosted hanging lanterns to the slinky, willow-waisted staff, the restaurant evokes a sultry night club where the mood is determinedly romantic and the lights are dangerously dim. When, after ordering, a parade of tiny saucers appears, first-time patrons might wonder if an entrée is even necessary. Don’t forgo the entrée. Read the full review at the link in our bio. Photograph by @michael_marcelle for TNY.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

A frequently overlooked aspect of Zelda Fitzgerald’s life is her passion for ballet. At twenty-five, she began taking lessons in Paris with the great Russian ballerina Lubov Egorova and, within two years, decided to become a professional ballerina. How the physical demands of the art form affected her mental health are still debated. Click the link in our bio to read more about her ballet years. Photograph by CSU Archives/Everett.
@cartoonsbyhilary illustrates a few of her favorite things to freak out about. Swipe through for more.

In June, the photographer @halberstam took over our photo department's Instagram account to share his images from New York City. Check out @newyorkerphoto to see more in this series, and other takeovers by photographers from all over the world.
A cartoon by @paulnoth. #TNYcartoons

In New York, if you look closely, you can find someone with their nose in a book on every park bench, museum step, patch of grass, and subway car. The photographer Jonno Rattman travelled all over town to find bookworms in unexpected places. Click the link in our bio for some highlights.

“For me, it’s an easy way to make money,” Nick Kyrgios says of professional tennis. The twenty-two-year-old Australian has been called the most talented player since Roger Federer—but he would rather emulate the career of Gaël Monfils, a Frenchman known for being one of the most talented players never to win a major. Click the link in our bio to read Louisa Thomas’s Profile of the reluctant tennis star. Photograph by Jonas Unger for TNY.

Wondering what your favorite New Yorker writers are reading this summer? We asked @vinsoncunningham, Rebecca Mead, Richard Brody, and more to share what book they’re diving into this season. Link in bio. Illustration by Cynthia Kittler.
“Hey, I just met you, and this is crazy. But here’s my number. Obama tapped it, maybe.” Swipe through to experience some more of Trump and Putin’s lesser-known collaborations.
A cartoon by Alice Cheng. #TNYcartoons
A summer pop-up from our Fiction Department. Ten writers, ten stories. Click the link in our bio to read “Elevator Pitches” by Jonathan Lethem, the first in the series.

"There is something very strange about experiencing 'The Merchant of Venice' when you are somehow imaginatively implicated in the character and actions of its villain." Click the link in our bio to read more about what “The Merchant of Venice” taught Stephen Greenblatt about ethnic hatred and the literary imagination.

The cartoonist Michael Crawford had a thing for America—the map of it, the shapes of it, the names of it. He would often grab a paintbrush or Sharpie and fiddle with the national form, make a fresh mess of the mainland, or carve characters out of county lines. Click the link in our bio to read more about the significance of his obsession with maps of the U.S.A.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan. #TNYcartoons
#HeadOverEels? #MyBigFatBeakWedding? Swipe through for some of @drawingolive's wedding-hashtag ideas for natural nuptials.
A cartoon by Trevor Spaulding. #TNYcartoons
Tired of watching that parade? Swipe through these Fourth of July covers instead. #TNYcovers

“When you have kids, you take them to the playground; and when you have dogs, you take them to the park,” Mark Ulriksen says, about his cover, “Off the Leash,” for this week’s issue. “Some of our favorite neighbors come from the dog park. We see them every day, even if we didn’t know their names for six months. Puppies learn from bigger dogs, and everyone gets to socialize.” #TNYcovers

This child is the newest addition to a family of Changpa, the nomadic pastoralists who live in the Changtang Plateau, a high-elevation desert spanning India into Tibet. She’ll join the bevy of young ones, not still fresh faced (the wind and cold do away with that quickly), who have more opportunities than ever before.
.
.
.
The photographer @robbiel1 and writer @leche_smith are sharing their images and words from their time in Ladakh, a region in the Himalayas of North India, on @newyorkerphoto.

The New Yorker July 4th Sale. Get 12 weeks for $6, plus a free tote. Valid in the U.S. only. Click the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo. #TNYcartoons
A cartoon by P. C. Vey, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
It’s tough out there for a freelancer. You might even call it the Wild West. Click the link in our bio to see more artists, graphic designers, and adjunct gunslingers. Drawn by @alifitzgerald80s.

Did you know that there are over 55 outdoor swimming pools scattered around New York City? Hanging out the side of a helicopter in 2014, Tobias Hutzler captured the W.P.A.-era heft of McCarren Pool in Brooklyn, showing us just one way to keep cool in the summer heat. Photograph courtesy @tobiashutzlerstudios.
A cartoon by @lianafinck. #TNYcartoons

How did @spencerpratt, the former villain of “The Hills,” become a self-aware commentator on fame culture in the age of Trump? Click the link in our bio to read about the reality-TV star's reëmergence. Illustration by @geoffjkim.

For the better part of the past decade, Jay-Z has developed a reputation as a “dad rapper.” He’s been dismissed laughingly as just a washed-up, out-of-touch member of the 1%. "Daaaaddddd," the Internet groans. But “4:44” finds him confronting this “Dad” label head on. It is the introspective and often lyrically dazzling work of a veteran who seems freshly energized. Click the link in our bio to read Carrie Battan's review. Photograph by Jason LaVeris/FilmMagic/Getty #444 #JayZ

“Peter Hujar defined downtown for me,” Vince Aletti writes of the photographer. “He went places I never dared to, and hung out with people I’d only read about.” That included Susan Sontag and Fran Lebowitz, as well as Fillmore East, the Fun Gallery, and the back room at Max’s. Click the link in our bio to see more of Hujar’s work. Photograph The Peter Hujar Archive, LLC; courtesy Pace/MacGill Gallery.

In the figure of Paddington Bear, Michael Bond, who died this week, depicted the struggles that a new arrival to any land faces. A small bear from South America who arrived in London in the late 1950s, Paddington’s story is really an immigrant story. The precariousness of his status underpins his adventures—will he or won’t he be allowed to stay?—and, reread in the current climate, gives his narrative an exceptional poignancy. Illustration from Everett.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. #TNYcartoons

Some days, Jacqui Kenny’s agoraphobia can make it difficult to leave the house. Getting on a plane is a huge ordeal. But that hasn’t stopped her from visiting places all around the world (the more remote the better) using Google Street View. And just like any other traveller, she takes photos, snapping a screenshot whenever she comes across a particularly striking image. She shares them on the Instagram account Agoraphobic Traveller (@streetview.portraits). Swipe through to see more. Courtesy Jacqui Kenny/Map Data via Google Street View.
A cartoon by Jeremy Nguyen, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Each year, for @xxl’s “Freshman” Issue, the magazine chooses ten new or emerging rappers as the most promising of their rising class. The 2017 list skews heavily toward artists with big hits on SoundCloud and social-media-friendly aesthetics, like the buoyant Oakland rapper Kamaiyah. She’ll perform, along with the rest of the class, tonight at the Playstation Theatre. Photograph by Tim Mosenfelder/Getty Images.

Last week, while Magnum Photos’s storied photographers were in town to celebrate the agency’s 70th anniversary, we asked them to capture New York City’s golden hour—that time shortly before the sun sets (or after it rises), when shadows grow longer and everything appears to glow. Their images offer a glimpse of what the city is like in the vanishing light of long summer evenings. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @christopherandersonphoto/@magnumphotos for The New Yorker.
A cartoon by Harry Bliss, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Kmart’s new shopping bag, and retro rebrand, offers a kind of time travel back to when Americans still raced through the aisles of big box stores. The irony of Shana Novak’s photo—with its over-the-top, somewhat desperate slogan, plastered, for all its bombast, on a wispy plastic bag—seems built in, first by Kmart itself, and again by the photographer’s straightforwardly beautiful, self-consciously patriotic framing. It reflects perfectly the American predisposition toward hyperbole under duress. Photograph by @thenotsostillife/The Licensing Project.

It has been twenty years since the first #HarryPotter book was published. “The Potter story is a fairy tale, plus a bildungsroman, plus a murder mystery, plus a cosmic war of good and evil, and there’s almost no classic in any of those genres that doesn’t reverberate between the lines of Harry’s saga. The Arthurian legend, the Superman comics, 'Star Wars,' 'Cinderella,' 'The Lord of the Rings,' the 'Chronicles of Narnia,' 'The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes,' Genesis, Exodus, the Divine Comedy, 'Paradise Lost'—they’re all there,” Joan Acocella wrote, in 2000. Maybe that’s why the story never gets old. Photograph by Alex Wong/Newsmakers/Getty.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“It's a diverse celebration for the Fourth of July,” @kadirnelson says, about "Bright Star," his cover for this week’s issue. “Family and friends get together with kids just being kids, and parents being parents." #TNYcovers

The chef Claire Welle calls her new restaurant a “modest bistro.” But when dining at Otway, after the foie-gras torchon, and before the smoked tongue showered with carrot greens and peppercorns, you might mistake it for an extremely ambitious enterprise. Rich refinement shows up everywhere. Click the link in our bio to read the full review. Photograph by @maggiehshannon for TNY.

“I am now fascinated by the theatrical aspect of fashion,” the photographer Pari Dukovic says. “When I shoot, I always look for moments that capture the ethereal quality of the shows.” His Rag & Bone pictures, from 2014, locate this theatricality and ethereality in backstage preparations as well as on the runway. See more at the link in our bio. Photograph by @paridukovic.
A cartoon by Trevor Spaulding, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Some call Bob Mizer a forerunner of Robert Mapplethorpe, but he was just as much the gay Hugh Hefner—a tireless collector of physical specimens. In 1951, he founded what is generally considered the country’s original gay magazine, Physique Pictorial, which he would continue to publish for nearly four decades. Celebrate Pride with more of his photographs, at the link in our bio. Photograph by © The Bob Mizer Foundation, Inc.
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo. #TNYcartoons

Many of the definitive images of the past half century were taken by Magnum photographers, even if we never knew their names. A show at the International Center of Photography, in lower Manhattan, brings a selection of these photos together—including Jonas Bendiksen’s shot of villagers collecting scrap material from a crashed spacecraft, surrounded by thousands of white butterflies. Click the link in our bio to see more of the images on display. Photograph by @jonasbendiksen.
A cartoon by P. C. Vey, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Was #MerylStreep, who turns sixty-eight today, ever just an aimless twentysomething, trying to make her way in the world? It’s a question that set Michael Shulman on a two-and-a-half-year immersion into the life of the swanning diva and “greatest living actress.” His answer: yes and no. Click the link in our bio to find out why he says so. Photograph by Ted Thai/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty.

Temperatures were so cold during Jimmy Chin’s climb up Mount Everest that his shutter was frozen shut for most of the trip. Luckily for us, he caught this stunning sunrise above the Balcony, with Makalu in the background. He shares more images from the climb, along with his thoughts on the other “climbers, dreamers, mad men, and trophy hunters” who attempt it, on our Web site. Link in bio. Photograph by @jimmy_chin.
It’s officially summer—and in New York that means picnicking in Central Park, sunbathing at Chelsea Piers, and strolling along the High Line. Photograph by @geosteinmetz.
A cartoon by Zachary Kanin. #TNYcartoons

Amid interpersonal discord, creative frustration, and the discontent of turning thirty, the folk musician Josh Tillman discovered his alter ego (or, in his words, truer self): Father John Misty. He found a way to make art out of making fun of himself and others like him who were engaged in the vain act of making art. And people loved him for it, or in spite of it, but many declared him insufferable. He tries to explain himself in this week’s issue. Link in bio. Photograph by @paridukovic for TNY.
A cartoon by Ellis Rosen. #TNYcartoons

Decades before hip-hop was born, in New York, swing dancers favored a hop called the Lindy. Tonight, anyone can get into the swing with an intro lesson and dance party on Pier Forty-five, in Hudson River Park. Click the link in our bio for more info. Photograph @paridukovic for TNY.

“Brooklyn’s eccentricities are an endless font of inspiration for a guy in my line of work,” @peterdeseve says, about his cover, "Topknot," for this week’s issue. “I live in Park Slope, and my covers are often inspired by a person or place a few blocks from my home—if not right outside my window.” #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan. #FathersDay #TNYcartoons

“The photographs are my expression of fatherhood,” Jack Radcliffe says of the many images he has taken of his daughter, Alison. Starting in the delivery room, in 1975, he captured summers at the beach, violin lessons, and a rebellious adolescence peppered with cigarettes. Swipe through, then visit the link in our bio to see the rest of the series. Photographs by Jack Radcliffe. #FathersDay
A cover for #FathersDay, by @kadirnelson.
A cartoon by John McNamee, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

At The Fat Monk, on the Upper West Side, the love of confit is rapturously embraced as creed. The bacchanalia of brûléed bone marrow, pig knuckles, and bone-in rib eye makes the cheese board and devilled eggs look like dieter’s specials. In this no-rules suzerainty, calorie counting might be the only criminal offense. Click the link in our bio to read @jiayangfan's review. Photograph by @amylombard for TNY.

Ever since the First World War, jazz greats, like #MilesDavis, have travelled to France to perform in Paris clubs, theatres, and at the Antibes Jazz Festival. The late photographer Jean-Pierre Leloir captured the French love of jazz in photos, which have been turned into an alluring, atmospheric book. See more of his work at the link in our bio. Photograph by Jean-Pierre Leloir.
A cartoon by William Haefeli, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

#Lorde used to play the role of a teen who watched from a balcony. Now she’s tiptoeing down into the party, and learning just how messy adulthood can be. Click the link in our bio to read Carrie Battan’s review of the artist’s new album, “Melodrama.” Illustration by @r_kikuo_johnson.

It was on a trip to Japan that the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky came across a CD of a Richard Strauss ballet he’d never heard of, “Schlagobers”—or, in English, “Whipped Cream.” Now, he revives the neglected ballet at American Ballet Theatre. Click the link in our bio to read Joan Acocella’s review. Photograph by @marceloagomes for TNY.
This week, @davidemon took us inside the "Sphere" of EXPO 2017, which opened in Astana, Kazakhstan on June 10. To see more of his images of the city's architecture, follow @newyorkerphoto.
A cartoon by @kimwarp. #TNYcartoons
In Daily Shouts: Birthday cards for Donald Trump, as drawn by Jed Feiman, Nehemiah Markos, and @j.a.k._.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The work of the wildlife photographer Nick Nichols is widely admired for the intimacy he achieves with his animal subjects. Known for a time as “Nick Danger,” he has travelled through some of the most forbidding terrain on Earth to shoot so-called naïve chimpanzees, which have never seen humans before; western lowland gorillas; and forest elephants. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @michaelnicknichols.

Last winter, David Sedaris spent a week in Hawaii, mostly signing his autograph on 5,000 sheets of blank paper and watching episodes of “Intervention.” The show caused him to think of his mother: a lady who never wore pants (only skirts and dresses) or left the house without makeup. In a new essay, he remembers the bright, funny woman who always got people laughing—and the darker, drunk one whom he never confronted about her alcoholism. Read it at the link in our bio. Photograph courtesy Lisa S. Evans.

“If you walk along the northern lip of Lac Léman, between Montreux and Lausanne, you will see before you the lake’s flat shine all across to Évian-les-Bains, in France,” Teju Cole writes in his new book. Out this month, "Blind Spot" explores music, myth, vision, and cities around the world. Click the link in our bio to read an excerpt. Photograph by @tejucole.
A cartoon by Christopher Weyant, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Over the years, the photographer Brigitte Lacombe has captured behind-the-scenes portraits of such iconic theatre actors as Alec Baldwin, Jessica Lange, Dustin Hoffman, and even Madonna. Read about what it was like to work with Philip Seymour Hoffman, why her career high came from Richard Avedon, and how she first got started. Link in bio.
New Yorkers, you understand. Drawings by @lianafinck.

In the mid-sixties, when smart technology was the stuff of sci-fi, the British collective Archigram drew up plans for a utopian metropolis in which people would live in roaming pods, docking at charging stations as needed. The Croatian artist Dora Budor pays homage to that project in her sculpture “The Forecast (New York Situations),” currently at the High Line. Photography by @ward.roberts for TNY.
A cartoon by Lars Kenseth, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Garry Winogrand's 1952 photo of a young man hosting a woman into the surf at Coney Island is proof that some of the best ways to beat the heat never change. The prolific photographer exposed 26,000 rolls of film between 1950, when he began making photographs of midtown street life, and his death in 1984. Take a look at more of his work at the link in our bio. Photograph from the estate of Garry Winogrand, courtesy of Fraenkel Gallery, San Francisco.
A cartoon by Maddie Dai, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Barbara Browning likes a bit of contrived mischief. Its pursuit is the force behind her writing and also, arguably, her life. Click the link in our bio to read about the author's penchant for posting videos of herself online, and forging creative relationships with the strangers who come upon them. Illustration by Nathaniel Whitcomb/Photograph by Kari Orvik.
A cartoon by @joedator. #TNYcartoons

The photographer Max Pinckers's 2015 project, “Will They Sing Like Raindrops or Leave Me Thirsty,” includes portraits of couples who have sought help from the Delhi-based nonprofit The Love Commandos, which provides protection to couples who want to break with Indian tradition and marry across caste, class, or religion. Link in bio. Photograph courtesy Max Pinckers / Chobi Mela
A cartoon by @paulnoth. #TNYcartoons

With the rise of foodie culture, a certain strain of food photography (hi, Instagram!) has gone the way of cliché. But that doesn’t stop us from ogling a juicy cheeseburger or a hot-pink hibiscus doughnut. Especially those in a new coffee-table compendium that dates back to the time before smart phones and #foodporn. Prepare to be hungry. Link in bio. Photograph by Nickolas Muray.

“Lordy, I hope there are tapes,” James Comey said of the President's tweet about their taped conversations. Reading between the lines of today's hearing, #Comey was doing his best to strengthen those who believe Trump’s actions were indeed obstruction. Link in bio. Photograph by @gdemczuk for TNY.
A cartoon by Edward Steed, from 2016. #TNYcartoons

In 2015, the photographer @annielingphoto travelled to Ólafsfjördur, a town of eight hundred residents in northern Iceland, where she captured natural landscapes, residents’ daily routines, and the many local holiday celebrations. Pictured here is the fishing town of Siglufjörður. Click the link in our bio for more.
A cartoon by @paulnoth. #TNYcartoons

Although Carl Van Vechten made his name as a writer, he began to explore photography in the early 1930s, photographing luminaries of the Harlem Renaissance, including Joyce Bryant. His photographic project represents a rich and lasting record of one man’s interest in a culture that he believed represented the “essence of America.” Click the link in our bio to see more.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Nineteen years ago today, “Sex and the City” premièred and originated the unacknowledged first female anti-hero on television: Carrie Bradshaw. Click the link in our bio to read Emily Nussbaum’s 2013 look at the brilliant and, in certain ways, radical show. Photograph by Paramount Pictures/Getty. #SexandtheCity

“It’s not a question of ‘Oh, I would really love to do that,’ it’s more a question of ‘I am one of those people,’” Rebecca Hall says of acting. The daughter of the founder of the Royal Shakespeare Company and an internationally known opera singer, she quite literally grew up in the theatre. Click the link in our bio to read more about her complicated inheritance. Illustration by Rosanna Webster; Photograph by Mike Windle/Vanity Fair/Getty.

"For me, the success of a climb has less to do with reaching a summit and is more about the power of the story you bring back to share with others,” @renan_ozturk says. In 2013, he took @newyorkerphoto along on an expedition to the Bugaboos in British Columbia. Swipe through to see more, and follow the account to never miss a story.
A cartoon by @tbtoro, from 2015. #TNYcartoons
A cartoon by Michael Crawford, from this week’s Fiction Issue. #TNYcartoons

Beware, for this is not your average guacamole. Enrique Olvera adds mint to the otherwise innocent, chunky recipe at his chic new all-day café in NoHo. At Atla, nothing costs more than $20 and the cool graphics and smooth terrazzo surfaces belie a laid-back, friendly vibe. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Zachary Zavislak for TNY.

As part of an ongoing series exploring the cultural effects of climate change, Daesung Lee photographed former nomads enacting scenes—of hunting, herding, and, in one case, Mongolian wrestling—in living dioramas that juxtapose the old Mongolian landscape and the new. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Daesung Lee.

“I always spend at least one week just walking around a place and not photographing,” Cécile Smetana Baudier says. She spent five weeks living in a tent in the secluded Mexican fishing village of El Azufre to document its large population of Afro-Mexicans—a group who has had to grapple with a history of erasure and marginalization. Click the link in our bio to see more of her work. Photograph by @smetana_cecile
A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon Ellis Rosen. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In Daily Shouts: From Googling “wemwelsters” to Photoshopping clothes onto naked people, everyone has a favorite online activity. So tell us, what do you like to do on the computer? Then swipe through for more. Illustrations by @mtshelves.

“It is one of the best films about a Hollywood star that the industry has produced,” Richard Brody writes of 1981’s “Mommie Dearest.” The movie tells the story of Joan Crawford’s life and career from the perspective of her daughter Christina. Faye Dunaway plays Crawford, capturing the star’s passionate yet controlled and rock-hard presence. Click the link in our bio to read the full review. Photograph from Alamy.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. #TNYcartoons

"I happen to be a snowman expert," Bob Eckstein writes. As such, he is fully aware of the snowman’s colorful history of sex and violence—and believes that treating the snowman as modern art brings back its deservedly lofty status. Click the link in our bio to read about Peter Fischli’s “Snowman,” which Eckstein drew, currently on display on the roof of the Art Institute of Chicago. Illustration by @bob_eckstein.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

"Istanbul is one of those places that you easily fall in love with," @nicoletung writes. She is taking over @newyorkerphoto this week to share her photography from the Turkish city. Follow the account to see more.

Opera that merges the personal and the political is a longtime transatlantic tradition, so it’s no surprise that the European master Peter Eötvös’s decided to adapt Tony Kushner’s play “Angels in America.” The work gets its New York première in a limited run at Jazz at Lincoln Center, starting June 10. Photograph by @christaanfelber for TNY.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

When Jennifer Egan was in her twenties, she spent more than two years working as a private secretary for a countess. "Although she told me often how much she liked and admired me, I was unmistakably a servant," she writes, in our Fiction Issue. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @abstractsunday.

“After a few interviews in which I saw my interlocutor flick his eyes over my résumé and register that I had no relevant experience, I decided to start lying,” Akhil Sharma writes. He shares how he landed his first finance job, in our Fiction Issue. Link in bio. Illustration by @abstractsunday.

When Toni Morrison was young, she earned two dollars a day cleaning houses after school. She shares an early lesson about work, from her father, in our Fiction Issue. Link in bio. Illustration by @abstractsunday.
A cartoon for #MemorialDay, by Christopher Weyant. #TNYcartoons

The New Yorker Memorial Day Sale. Save 50% and get 12 weeks for $6. Valid in the U.S. only. Click the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.
A cartoon by @drawnbytom, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

If you study the frequency of breast jokes in “Baywatch,” it seems to have been made by 14-year-old boys. Only Dwayne Johnson saves the life of this movie, but whether it deserves to be saved is another matter. Click the link in our bio to read Anthony Lane’s review. Illustration by Bendik Kaltenborn. #Baywatch

In Rena Effendi's photos of Havana, we see a city almost frozen in time. Relics of another era dot the streets, like props from a period film. The city’s lively street life is a rush of people in motion against a backdrop of vivid murals and signature pastel colors. Swipe to see more. Photographs by @renaeffendiphoto/Institute.
A cartoon by Joe Dator, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Jean-Michel Basquiat’s “Untitled,” from 1982, has sold for more than $110 million dollars, a record for American art. Let’s take a moment to be nauseated by the price paid. Then let’s ignore it and talk about the art. Click the link in our bio to read more. © 2017 The Estate of Jean Michel Basquiat/ADAGP, Paris/Ars via Sotheby’s. #JeanMichelBasquiat
A cartoon by @blisscartoons, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

At his new restaurant, Jean-Georges Vongerichten serves meatless dishes, juices, and restorative tonics—but he won’t call it vegetarian. The word, he likes to say, “sounds like a disease.” Click the link in our bio to read about abcV’s plant-based intelligence. Photograph by @yudi_ela for TNY.

This year, Mohau Modisakeng is one of two artists representing South Africa at the Venice Biennale. His haunting self-portraiture excavates the traumas of apartheid—which his family faced first-hand—and creates striking images of a country that is reëvaluating itself. Click the link in our bio to see more of his work. Photograph © Mohau Modisakeng, courtesy Tyburn Gallery.
A cartoon by Edward Steed. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Today is the 40th anniversary of #StarWars. The movie’s release, in 1977, coincided with a peak in pot-smoking among U.S. high schoolers (which didn’t hurt ticket sales). Christopher Walken was originally cast as Han Solo, a character who was partly based on Francis Ford Coppola. And George Lucas took the name “Wookey” from the surname of a friend of a friend. Find out more interesting "Star Wars" facts at the link in our bio. Photograph by Terry O’Neill/Getty Images.

Czeslaw Milosz was obsessed with the idea of the poet’s responsibility.
