His experiences under both Nazi and Communist rule convinced him that poetry must not darken the world but illuminate it: “Poems should be written rarely and reluctantly, / under unbearable duress and only with the hope / that good spirits, not evil ones, choose us for their instrument.” Click the link in our bio to read more about Poland’s great exile poet. Illustration by @andreaventuramay68.

The Hubble Space Telescope has brought us visions of space that are wondrously sharp and clear. And though their purpose is scientific, the images have more than a touch of the sublime. Click the link in our bio to see the best Hubble photographs of 2010. #TBT
.
.
.
Photograph: NASA, ESA, R. O’Connell (University of Virginia), F. Paresce (National Institute for Astrophysics, Bologna, Italy), E. Young (Universities Space Research Association/Ames Research Center), the WFC3 Science Oversight Committee, and the Hubble Heritage Team (STScI/AURA).
A cartoon by @j.a.k._, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The most famous of Elliott Erwitt’s images elicit surprise, even when viewed for the hundredth time. Who can resist his shot of a woman, her reflection captured in the rear-view mirror of a car, grinning giddily as she’s kissed by her lover? See more of Erwitt’s work at the link in our bio. Photograph: Harry Ransom Center Collection © Elliott Erwitt/Magnum Photos.
Bob Dylan turns seventy-six today. Our 2016 cover, “The Laureate” by @malikafavre, celebrated the legendary musician’s Nobel Prize in Literature. #TNYcovers
Rest in peace, Roger Moore. A cartoon by Kim Warp. #TNYcartoons

For $90 dollars, you and several friends can down a jumbo-sized pitcher of cocktails surrounded by mid-tier financiers in midtown. Click the link in our bio to learn what it’s like to drink a fishbowl in the Dream Hotel. Illustration by @thejorgecolombo.

Born to a wealthy family at the end of the 19th century, the French photographer Jacques Henri Lartigue began taking photos as a young boy, capturing with rare visual wit and style the recreations of his élite Parisian milieu. His work in color was rarely seen until 2016. Swipe for more. Photograhs © Ministère de la Culture – France/AAJHL.
A cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The artist Jill Magid turned the cremated ashes of the most celebrated architect in Mexico, whose designs include the Cuadra San Cristóbal, into a diamond. What ensued was a national controversy. Click the link in our bio to read what all the debate was about. Photograph by Rene Burri/Magnum.

Jonah Reider was a senior at Columbia University, running a “restaurant” from his dorm room in Hogan Hall, when the school newspaper ran a review of it. Overnight he became a famous chef. Now he’s reincarnating Pith as a supper series, three nights a week, in a ritzy Brooklyn town house. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @will_mebane for TNY.
The drycleaner comes after the matcha lattes and gluten-free bagels. A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Bryan Thomas's photos of his native Florida are what he calls “a love letter and a eulogy” to his childhood home. Most of the state’s shoreline communities are likely to be underwater by the end of the century. “They’re playing on beaches now and relaxing, but in thirty or forty years they could be walking through waist-deep water with their clothes in bags,” he says. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @bryanthomasphoto.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
The photographs in Dougie Wallace’s series “Well Heeled” capture the resplendent humanity of #dogs, up close. Swipe to see more. Photographs by @dougie_wallace/Institute.
It pays to be honest up front. A cartoon by @j.a.k._, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Givonna Joseph founded OperaCréole in 2011, after hearing one too many times, “You’re an opera singer? Black opera singers? I don’t know any black opera singers.” The company performs works by composers of color, like Lucien-Léon Guillaume Lambert, whose “La Flamenca” will be heard for the first time in 114 years tonight. Kenya Lawrence Jackson and Tyrone Chambers star in the production. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @caellsworth504/Nola Vieux Photography.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Young men being arrested or crammed into a jail cell, murdered bodies lying in the street, family members with terrified expressions: Tommaso Protti’s photos tell the story of a sublime Amazonian wilderness lost to the violence of the narco world. Swipe through, or click the link in our bio, to see more of his work depicting the toll of the drug trade in the Brazilian Amazon. Photographs by @tomprotti.

“It’s a ballet féerie: ballet in its purest form,” Alexei Ratmansky says of his newest work for American Ballet Theatre. “Whipped Cream” features dancers dressed as candies, pralines, and liqueur bottles and occurs mostly in a dream. It opens at the Metropolitan Opera House on May 22nd. Photograph by @marceloagomes for TNY.
Wednesdays. A cartoon by @drewdernavich. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Among photographers and photography aficionados, Gerhard Steidl’s name recognition equals that of Johannes Gutenberg: he is widely regarded as the best printer in the world. Making a book with him is, for an artist, like “going to kiss the Pope’s ring.” They must travel to Steidl’s factory and private guesthouse, in Göttingen, Germany, where they while away the days in a library and can be summoned at all hours to work on their book. Swipe through to see more of the process.
.
.
.
Click the link in our bio to read Rebecca Mead’s Profile of the master printer. Photographs by @mark_peckmezian.

In Daily Shouts: Having sexual intercourse with your partner in a stranger’s home is an essential part of a romantic getaway in the sharing economy, so @stolincokes wrote up some simple guidelines for Airbnb renters. Click the link in our bio to read them. Illustration by Lea Heinrich.
A cartoon by David Sipress, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The artist #Jlin first heard footwork, a niche form of club music that originated in Chicago, when she was four years old. On her new album, “Black Origami,” she internalizes that sound to produce an astonishing global exploration of what drums can do. Click the link in our bio to read Hua Hsu’s review. Photograph by @ryanlowry.
What is it that distinguishes a selfie from an artist’s self-portrait? Photographers, including Jun Ahn, weigh in at the link in our bio. Photograph courtesy Christophe Guye Galerie, Zürich.
A cartoon by Alice Cheng, from this week's issue. #TNYcartoons

The Hulu adaptation of “The Handmaid’s Tale” makes everything blunter and more explicit, almost pulpy at times. Some of its smartest moments—like Ofglen’s story—are radical edits from the book, turning a passive plot active, Emily Nussbaum writes. Click the link in our bio to read her full review. Photograph by George Kraychyk/Hulu. #TheHandmaidsTale

Rich kids seldom become committed artists—but Florine Stettheimer did just that by making richness her subject. Life as a serving of whipped cream on top of whipped cream functioned as a master theme of her visions, like this costume design for a sort of fan-fiction ballet she composed in 1912. Click the link in our bio to read more about the Jazz Age artist whom Andy Warhol called his favorite. Image courtesy MOMA.
A cartoon for #MothersDay, by Roz Chast.

A photography teacher once urged Mickalene Thomas to explore a subject close to her, one that came “from a vulnerable place,” and after initial resistance she decided to focus her lens on her mother, Sandra Bush, from whom she had been estranged. Thomas would later say, “The moment I started photographing my mother was the moment my work completely changed.” Pictured here is “La leçon d’amour,” from 2008. Click the link in our bio to see more of Thomas's photos.
A cover by Chris Ware, for #MothersDay.
A cartoon by Edward Frascino, for #MothersDay.
A cartoon by Roz Chast, from this week's issue. #TNYcartoons

The photos featured in @milesaldridge's 2013 show, “I Only Want You to Love Me,” all taken between 2005 and 2012, offer a glimpse into the artist’s cinematic, highly saturated world of female models and conventional household settings. Aldridge uses vivacious color and dramatic poses to add an element of tension to the photographs. Pictured here is “Actress #6,” from 2012. Click the link in our bio to see more.

There is a growing trend of crossbreeding domestic #cats with their more feral cousins in an effort to create a #feline that looks exotic but is tame enough to cohabit with humans. In 2013, the photographer @mark_peckmezian travelled to Ponca City, Oklahoma, to photograph the A1 Savannahs cattery, whose specialty is a type of #cat called the Savannah, known for its leopard-like coat, large ears, and unusual height. Swipe to see more.
A cartoon by Will McPhail, from this week's issue. #TNYcartoons

The bodies of the people that Maïmouna Guerresi photographs—usually friends and family, in Dakar, Senegal—seem to extend beyond their physical boundaries. Her subjects are shot in costumes that Guerresi constructs herself. The outfits are sculptural creations that fuse the face and limbs of the subject with the space and air around them. The photos are dense with religious allusions, often mixed and melded: a woman’s long, draping robes could be a Muslim head scarf or the veil of a Renaissance Madonna. Pictured here is "Red Oracle, 2006 (Italy)." Click the link in our bio to see more of Guerresi's photos.

New to The Bronx Zoo are eight Indian gharials—critically endangered reptiles of the crocodilian order, indigenous to the Chambal River, in India. They eat mainly fish, and not humans, perhaps only because their mouths aren’t wide enough. You can find them basking in the JungleWorld exhibit. Pictured here is the photographer Philip Montgomery snapping the gharials. Swipe to see the final result.
.
.
.
Photographs by @philipmontgomery for The New Yorker.

The allure of the Dead Sea is in showing us that “our bodies and the environment are profoundly interconnected,” Vittoria Mentasti says. Her photographs of the sea and its surrounding deserts capture close-up mineral springs and people who come in search of rejuvenation. Swipe to see more.

An early look at next week's cover, "Ejected," by Barry Blitt: “It’s probably a bit of a leap,” Blitt says. “James Comey is six feet eight—he probably would have been happy to give up his seat in a cramped cabin.” #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Trevor Spaulding, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by Paul Noth. #TNYcartoons

Subscribe to The New Yorker. Get 12 weeks for $12. Valid in the U.S. only. Click the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.

“You don’t see with the eyes. You see with the brain,” the neuroscientist Paul Bach-y-Rita explains. His invention, the BrainPort, enables blind people to use the sense of touch as a substitute for sight. Click the link in our bio to read about the science of sensory substitution. Illustration by Chad Hagen.

Donald Trump’s firing of James Comey is an attack on American democracy. He can now pick his own man (or woman) to run the F.B.I., and this person will have the authority to close down the Russia investigation. Click the link in our bio to read John Cassidy on how this is potentially despot-like behavior. Photograph by Mark Peterson/Redux for The New Yorker.
Comey out. A cartoon by David Sipress.
A cartoon by Edward Steed, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
In Daily Shouts: To recover your lost password, simply answer these queries, by @lianafinck.

What if a work of art was so smart that it could free itself from the artist who made it? The digital whiz Ian Cheng takes a deep dive down that wormhole with “Emissaries,” now at MOMA PS1. Click the link in our bio to read more about what he describes as “video games that play themselves.” Image courtesy the artist.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In the past few years, companies like TaskRabbit, Postmates, Uber, and Airbnb have collectively helped create a new business model: the gig economy. For growing numbers, gigging is not only a living but a life. Is this the future of American work? Click the link in our bio to find out. Illustration by @mr_jti.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy. #TNYcartoons

Zora Neale Hurston, Gil Scott-Heron, Nina Simone, Marvin Gaye: these are just some of the famous black Americans whose photos the artist Rico Gatson uses to create his work. By surrounding them with bright, colorful lines that shoot outward, he makes the ecstasy in personhood as visible as people themselves. Click the link in our bio to read Vinson Cunningham’s story on radical portraiture. Photograph by Lanternier, 2007/Countesy Ronald Feldman.

“I sometimes feel like a magician,” the artist Hellen van Meene says. The adolescent girls in her portraits do seem to be under some kind of spell. They appear to have their heads screwed on backwards, or else their necks are eerily elongated, or their bodies hover strangely above the floor. Swipe through to see more. Photographs by @hellenvanmeene/Yancey Richardson Gallery.
A cartoon by William Haefeli, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In 2014, the photographer @matteich visited Churchill Downs for the #KentuckyDerby. For the most part, he said, #DerbyDay was a whirl of extreme wealth and extravagant hats. He heard several people recite, approvingly, the headline of Hunter S. Thompson’s 1970 article “The Kentucky Derby Is Decadent and Depraved.” Swipe through to see more.
A cartoon by David Sipress. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The first thing to know about By Chloe is that the chipotle aioli and the beet ketchup are very good, and very free. Think Shake Shack but without the meat. Instead burgers involve lentils, tempeh, and chia, and the faux mac and cheese is better than the real thing. Click the link in our bio to read more about the vegan fast-food chain. Photograph by @simonelueck.

In Justin Peck’s “The Times Are Racing,” the dancers wear sneakers, and the ballet is set to rock music. The choreography somehow pushes New York City Ballet’s perfect dancers into becoming fully human—tender, surprising, even awkward. It’s as if Peck is creating ballets about people trying to do ballet. Click the link in our bio to read Joan Acocella’s full review. Illustration by @cynthiakittler.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._. #TNYcartoons

When Judd Apatow heard about Kumail Nanjiani’s life, he said, “That should be a movie.” And now it is. “The Big Sick,” which premièred at the Sundance Film Festival offers portrayals of secular Muslims that American audiences rarely see. Click the link in our bio to read more about the comedian and actor. Photograph by @nathanealturner.

What is a poodle doing hosting a cooking show? “Cooking with Dog” is one of those gifts of the Internet that raises many compelling questions. But it is delightful precisely because it refuses to answer them. Click the link in our bio to read more about Francis the dog. 🐩 Photograph courtesy YouTube.
A cartoon by Trevor Spaulding, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
What do sled #dogs do in the summer? Luckily for us, the photographer @katieorlinsky went to Alaska to find out. Swipe through to see more.

“I’m a bad singer, I confess it,” a young Valerie Teicher warns through cassette hiss. The home recording is one of many that break up the début record she recorded as Tei Shi. On May 9-10, she’ll perform “Crawl Space” at Rough Trade. And at 26, she’s grown into her voice, and her tone is just as brave. Photo-illustration by @carmendaneshmandi.
“It’s not about the dogs,” Bruce Eric Kaplan says, about his cover for this week’s issue: “Man’s Best Friend.” Click the link in our bio to find out what he says it is about. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Why does harvest gold connote “sad old appliance” but rose gold say “sexy new iPhone”? That’s one question posed at the center of Sara Cwynar’s captivating new show, “Rose Gold,” a seven-minute film collage and selection of photographs, which makes it vividly clear that color is a cultural construct. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @cwynars, courtesy Foxy Production.
A dress from Comme des Garçons’ Autumn/Winter 2012-13 collection, which will be part of the Costume Institute’s upcoming Rei Kawakubo exhibition. Photographed by @paridukovic. #MetGala

A dress from Comme des Garçons’ “Blood and Roses” collection, Spring/Summer 2015. It will be featured as part of the Costume Institute’s upcoming Rei Kawakubo exhibition. Photographed by @paridukovic. #MetGala

Ahead of tonight’s #MetGala, we're giving you a peek at the Costume Institute’s upcoming Rei Kawakubo exhibition, as photographed by @paridukovic. Here, a piece from Comme des Garçons’ Autumn/Winter 2012-13 collection.
A cartoon by Corey Pandolph, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
In 2014, we asked Bob Eckstein to draw some of his favorite New York bookstores. Celebrate Independent Bookstore Day by checking out some of them yourself. Click the link in our bio to see more.

Donald Trump has made us laugh until we cried, and then continued to cry in perpetuity. On his 100th day as President, we could all certainly use a little humor. Cheer up with some of our best Trump cartoons. Swipe for more.
.
.
.
Cartoons by Benjamin Schwartz, Robert Leighton, @paulnoth, @tbtoro, @willmcphail4, @kimwarp, @christopherweyant, David Sipress, and @j.a.k._.

Today is Donald Trump’s 100th day in office. David Remnick took a look back on this span, noting that every day brings some new outrage or embarrassment. “Trump flouts truth and liberal values so brazenly that he undermines the country he has been elected to serve and the stability he is pledged to insure,” he writes. Click the link in our bio to read more.

According to Anthony Lane, this is how you should attend Jean-Pierre Melville movies: Tell nobody what you’re doing. If it comes to a choice between smoking and talking, smoke. Dress well but without ostentation. If you don’t have a hat, you can’t go. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @malikafavre.

A cartoon by Bob Mankoff, who, after 40 years with us, is stepping down from his current role. Today, @newyorkercartoons is posting some of his most iconic creations, and having him explain what makes them special. Follow along—it’s #BobMankoffDay on @newyorkercartoons!

Morgan Parker has fourteen tattoos. She lives in Bed-Stuy. And she just published a book of poems about Beyoncé. Yet she prefers to avoid what she calls “living in the bubble of now” and focus on “historical connections and repetition and same ol’, same ol’.” Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by Trey Wright; source photograph by Rachel Eliza Griffiths.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“Portrait (Nabokov), 2017” is a riotously beautiful work by the American painter Jackie Saccoccio. It’s currently on show as part of “Sharp Objects & Apocalypse Confetti” at the 11R gallery in New York until April 30. Click the link in our bio to see more of what is currently at galleries around the city. Courtesy 11R Gallery, N.Y.

In his 1967 book, “Making It,” Norman Podhoretz hoped that by confessing to his own ambition, he would make it safe for others in his literary set to confess to theirs. Almost everyone he showed the book to advised him not to publish it. One friend said it would take ten years for his reputation to recover—that was low-balling it. Click the link in our bio to read about the book that scandalized New York’s intellectuals. Illustration by @yannkebbi.
A cartoon by @muchcoffeeman, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The role of Dolly Levi plays to a diva’s strengths: it demands pathos and defiance, grief and comedy. And who better than #BetteMidler to give us all that? She has remade the character in her own image—as a scrappy trickster—and it’s breaking our hearts. Click the link in our bio to read @hilton.als's review of the Broadway revival of “Hello Dolly.” Illustration by @ben_kirchner.

This week, @davidwilliamsphoto took over @newyorkerphoto to share pictures of the Ancient Society of York Florists, the oldest existing horticulture society in the world. Follow the account to see more.
A cartoon by David Sipress, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Growing up in Moscow, the photographer Anastasia Samoylova was exposed, from a young age, to the work of the Russian Romantic poets, whose ecstatic descriptions of nature helped form her early impressions of Russia’s geography. “Mountains were embedded into my memory before I ever saw them in real life,” she said. Her series “Landscape Sublime” explores and transfigures the clichés of nature imagery. Swipe to see more.

From the late 1960s through the early 1990s, the artist Saul Leiter adopted the practice of painting over his own photographs of nude figures. Here, his devotion to color and form took on a baroque sensuousness that has something in common with the erotic energy of turn-of-the-century Vienna. The effect is of a turbulent maelstrom of color, created with impulsive, almost dancing brushstrokes. Click the link in our bio to see more of his painted nudes. Photograph by Saul Leiter / Courtesy the Saul Leiter Foundation and Sylph Editions.
In Daily Shouts: This week’s episode of generic medical drama, by @rubyetc_.

These days he's a dishevelled presence in the Oval Office, but once upon a time, Steve Bannon was a fast-talking, smartly dressed, aggressively fit Hollywood executive, carrying himself with “alpha swagger.” Only, barely anyone in Hollywood remembers him. And those that do are bewildered by his story of himself as a major dealmaker. Click the link in our bio to read Connie Bruck on Steve Bannon’s Hollywood years. Illustration by Barry Blitt.

“There’s drama inherent in every pitch,” Mark Ulriksen, the artist behind this week’s cover, “Strike Zone,” says, about the baseball season. “For the next six months, there’ll be a cast of characters,” he says. “You follow your team with the kind of rapt attention that you would a good book. When fall comes, you get a grand finale. Last year, it all went to the Chicago Cubs. This year, who knows?” #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Now that the @metmuseum is staging contemporary exhibitions at the Breuer, its eatery has been recast with a downtown gaze. In Flora Bar, the pair behind @estelanyc faces its steepest challenge yet: museum café by day, neighborhood restaurant by night, Mediterranean-Pacific tapas menu at all times. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @francesfdenny.

Growing up near #Hollywood, @alinesmithson regularly traversed sun-bleached streets dedicated to stardom. She became fascinated by how celebrity is created and, eventually, set out to make her own portraits—inspired by the Technicolor images of the 1940s and 1950s. Here, she re-creates the look of vintage publicity photos using ordinary people. Swipe through for more.

When Daniel Mendelsohn started teaching Classics 125: The Odyssey of Homer, his eighty-one-year-old father decided to sit in on the course. Then the two men sailed for Ithaca. Click the link in our bio to read about their trip in search of an epic. Illustration by @goldencosmos.
A cartoon by Pat Byrnes. #TNYcartoons #MarchForScience
A cartoon by Paul Noth, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In “Poor People’s TV Room,” Okwui Okpokwasili looks at the effects of history on Nigerian women. The piece draws on two momentous incidents: the Women’s War of 1929, when black women challenged colonial British power, and, 85 years later, the Boko Haram kidnappings, which sparked the #BringBackOurGirls movement. Click the link in our bio to read @hilton.als on the play. Illustration by @chowsaiman.

One year ago today, #Prince died. Our cover “Purple Rain,” by Bob Staake, is a tribute to the great performer. Click the link in our bio to read David Remnick, Margaret Talbot, Emily Nussbaum, and more remember the iconic popstar. #TNYcovers
Make it stop. A cartoon by Pat Byrnes. #TNYcartoons

Edibles were once associated with pot brownies in college dorms, but Laurie Wolf is leading a gourmet revolution. A long-time chef and food editor, she stands out as a source of reliable information in a nascent industry without dependable methods for cooking and dosing. Like Julia Child introducing Americans to French cuisine, Wolf serves as both a guide and an ambassador to this world. Click the link in our bio for her recipe for cannabis-infused chocolate bark. Illustration by @olimpiazagnoli.

#Vanlife isn't just an aesthetic. #Vanlife isn't just a mentality. #Vanlife is—as people keep insisting—a “movement.” It’s about self-sufficiency and freedom, but with Instagrams of sunsets, oceans, and bikinis. Click the link in our bio to read more about a lifestyle free from the tyranny of a 9-to-5 office job. Photograph by @newminton.
A cartoon by Harry Bliss. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

A lifeguard at LEGOLAND Dubai, one of Dubai Parks and Resorts theme parks.
.
.
.
Click the link in our bio to see more of @b_e_n__t_h_o_m_a_s's photos of the cosmopolitan city.

Dubai Mall is impressive, but the Mall of the Emirates includes the one attraction that most epitomizes this non-place of a city: Ski Dubai, a full-scale indoor ski slope in the middle of the desert. The interior is kept at exactly thirty-two degrees, with exactly zero wind. Pictured here: the indoor ski area.
.
.
.
Today we’re sharing photos from @b_e_n__t_h_o_m_a_s's trip to the cosmopolitan city. Click the link in our bio to see more.

The exterior of a building at Bollywood Parks Dubai.
.
.
.
Today we’re sharing photos from @b_e_n__t_h_o_m_a_s's trip to the cosmopolitan city. Click the link in our bio to see more.

Religion is often evoked in hip-hop, but #KendrickLamar’s “DAMN.” uses it in a more profound manner. The phrase “What happens on Earth stays on Earth” is repeated on a few songs—a reminder of something greater, beyond this existence. It’s something the rapper remains drawn to: the idea that we will be judged by the path we walk, and by the work we leave behind. Click the link in our bio to read Hua Hsu’s review. Illustration by @kristianhammerstad.

When Newsha Tavakolian was growing up in Iran, her family rarely took vacations. Public space was no fun: there was always someone disturbing your privacy, making you feel uncomfortable. Now she photographs today’s youth as they hitchhike their way through the country, discovering its islands, mountain passes, and changing-color deserts. It took more than three decades for Iranians to venture out once again; now they can’t seem to get enough of it. Swipe through to see more. Photographs by @newshatavakolian.
A cartoon by Roz Chast, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
In Daily Shouts: Grudges against exes (in haiku form), by @lianafinck. Swipe through for more. #NationalHaikuPoetryDay

It remains an essential paradox of New York City—that a place with so many people living so close together can also be so isolating. This is the phenomena that the photographer @PeterGarritano documents in his series of portraits of New Yorkers who have posted Strictly Platonic personals ads on Craigslist. The woman featured here posted an ad with the subject line “Hire me to Talk & Listen – w4mw.” Click the link in our bio to see more.

This week's cover, “Taste for Adventure,” by Cannaday Chapman for our Food & Travel Issue: “For me, one of the finest things about travelling is trying new and exotic foods,” Chapman says. He recently returned from Argentina, where he ate “a whole lot of steaks and the best pork chops I ever had.” Click the link in our bio to read more. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller. #TNYcartoons

Golden tickets, Oompa Loompas, the great glass elevator: the world that Roald Dahl conjured in “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,” was as fanciful as it was menacing, and so full of pure imagination that it left an indelible cultural mark. A musical version of the children’s novel opens on Broadway on April 23, featuring songs from the psychedelic 1971 movie and new tunes from the “Hairspray” songwriting team. Photograph by @andrewbmyers.
A cartoon by Paul Noth. #TNYcartoons
Tired of looking for eggs? Swipe through some of our whimsical Easter covers instead. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Harry Bliss, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Subtlety, traditionally undervalued in Chinese cuisine, is raised to an art form at the premier dim-sum restaurant #TimHoWan. The 45th outpost of the global chain recently opened near Union Square, where the line to enter has been known to wrap around six New York City blocks. The secret to the restaurant’s success is the care with which it makes genre-defining staples—everything is made the day it’s served and even the soy sauce is done in-house. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @will_mebane.
A cartoon by @drawnbytom, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

The movie adaption of “The Lost City of Z” is best approached, Anthony Lane says, as a fantasia on Fawcettian themes. It is beautiful, mournful, and measured. But the tale that it tells cries out for madness. Click the link in our bio to read his full review. Illustration by @wesleyallsbrook.

Paul Tollett combined the best parts of indie-rock, SoCal raves, and Burning Man. And thus #Coachella was born. As the musical festival kicks off today, read up on the mastermind who wrangles the biggest artists in the world into performing in the California desert. Link in bio. Illustration by @cynthiakittler.

The Belgian artist Sammy Slabbinck started making found-photo collages in 2009 using vintage ads and images culled from old magazines. His deceptively simple pieces often contain only two visual ingredients, but through skillful manipulations of perspective and proportion, and juxtapositions of color and black and white, turn banal source material into scenes of whimsical confusion. Swipe to see more. Collages © @sammyslabbinck.
A cartoon by David Sipress, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

For this week's episode of The New Yorker Radio Hour, David Remnick stopped by #TheDailyShow offices to talk to #TrevorNoah about political satire in the age of Trump. Click the link in our bio to hear their conversation, along with more from Andy Borowitz, Bassem Youssef, and the founders of Reductress.

Penguin poop in Antarctic lake sediments helped researchers chart the history of a colony of gentoo penguins with censuslike precision. By combining chemical analyses of this sediment with an estimate of the average gentoo’s guano “productivity,” the researchers were able to determine Ardley Island’s historic penguin occupancy with censuslike precision. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @petfish25.
