#MargaretAtwood’s fiction has imagined societies riddled with misogyny, oppression, and environmental havoc. But she is a buoyant doomsayer. Like a skilled doctor, she takes evident satisfaction in providing an accurate diagnosis. Click the link in our bio to read Rebecca Mead’s Profile of the author. Photograph by @paridukovic.

For their project “Processed Views,” Barbara Ciurej and Lindsay Lochman have recreated iconic American landscape photos, taken by Carleton Watkins, with junk food. A photo of the Albion River in Mendocino, California, becomes a milky pool snaking through rainbowed mountains of Froot Loops; the imposing face of Cathedral Rock, at Yosemite, is reconstructed as a heaping pile of white bread. Swipe to see more of their cheeky dioramas. Photographs courtesy of the artists.
We're toasting @hilton.als, who has won the 2017 #PulitzerPrize for Criticism! 🍾 Click the link in our bio to read some of his pieces from 2016. Photograph by @thecooperrrr.
A cartoon by Paul Noth. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more #TNYcartoons.

This week's cover, “Fashion District,” by Harry Bliss: “I’ve nearly met my demise many times by stepping in front of traffic as I search the skyline for inspiration,” Bliss says, about his drawing of the Flatiron Building. Click the link in our bio to read more. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The photographer Simen Johan gained notoriety in the 1990s for his creepy images of adolescents—doll-faced children and child-faced adults whose likenesses he stitched together using an unusual combination of darkroom techniques and early digital manipulation. For the images in his project “Until the Kingdom Comes,” he again made use of subtle digital manipulations, this time to push familiar wildlife imagery into the realm of the not quite real. Pictured here: “Untitled #181,” from 2015. Click the link in our bio to see more.

The exhibit “Living Modern,” at the Brooklyn Museum, makes clear that Georgia O’Keeffe’s style was not ancillary to her genius but fundamental to it. She was an expert seamstress who made her own clothes and altered or otherwise preserved them herself. A row of blouses on display shows the care she put into details: she liked mother-of-pearl buttons and occasionally allowed for a modest flourish, like a ruffle or a bow. She never took to wartime synthetic fabrics, favoring silk, cotton, and wool. Click the link in our bio to read more about the show, which runs through July 23rd. Photograph by Alfred Stieglitz © Georgia O’Keeffe Museum.
A cartoon by Pat Byrnes. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Gabe McMackin’s Clinton Hill bistro, The Finch, serves exceptional versions of staples, but it’s the intrepid eater who will be most rewarded. For an obscure place, the honor of a Michelin star seemed implausible. But, apparently, the owner's commitment to being a neighborhood spot appealed to Michelin’s judges. (Ironically, the star made the food pricier.) The kitchen can be adventurous, but McMackin also wants to give the people what they want. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @jeremy_liebman for The New Yorker.
A cartoon by Amy Hwang. #WorldHealthDay #TNYcartoons

All Prince Charles wants to do is be a good, responsible monarch and to heal "the poisoned soul." Unfortunately for him, the British public dislikes enthusiastic do-gooders nosing about their poisoned souls. The Prince of Wales is deeply reviled across Britain—and a new biography sets out to answer why. Click the link in our bio to read Zoë Heller on where Prince Charles went wrong. Illustration by Floc’h.
These New York City surgical residents recreated @malikafavre's cover for our Health, Medicine and the Body Issue. Thanks for sharing, @kickasananyc!

A movie star is someone about whom the camera’s X-ray-like stare reveals an entire inner universe. “Styling the Stars,” a new book of photos of actors from the 1930s to 1970s, illustrates that fact. The images, which were meant for internal use only (to ensure that the actors’ appearances were kept consistent over shooting days), contain overwhelming emotional power. Just look at #MarilynMonroe here. Check out our Instagram story to see more, from Humphrey Bogart to Debbie Reynolds. Photograph courtesy Insight Editions/Twentieth Century Fox.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Blessing, Juliet, and Gift are just three of the thousands of girls trafficked from Nigeria to Europe each year. Once they reached Italy, they were sent to a makeshift camp in a former baseball stadium. Traffickers often coach girls to lie about their ages, so that they are sent to the country’s main reception centers, where migrants can move about freely. That way they can leave to do sex work in Palermo, or across Europe. 80% of the Nigerian women who cross the Mediterranean are trafficked into sexual exploitation. This winter,  Blessing, Juliet, and Gift were placed in a shelter for underage migrants. “The reason that I will not do prostitution is my mummy,” Blessing said. “I am my mummy’s breath of life.”
.
.
.
Click the link in our bio to read @bentaub91's story about the desperate journey of a trafficked girl.

The Prophetess Odasani, a retired wigmaker from Ghana, has helped many Nigerian women in Italy escape prostitution by challenging juju. Sex traffickers use this spiritual tradition to guarantee the obedience of their victims by having a juju priest perform a bonding ritual before the women leave Nigeria. Women and girls believe that unless they do sex work to make money and repay their debt to the trafficker, they will be killed by the juju. “They have bad spirits inside them—that’s why they do prostitution,” Odasani said. “I ask the spirit, What is your name? And the spirit answer. . . . I say, O.K., in the name of the Lord, depart from the person. Depart!”
.
.
.
Today, we’re sharing photos from @bentaub91's story about the desperate journey of a trafficked girl. Click the link in our bio to read more.

Libyan smugglers crammed roughly 150 people into this dinghy and launched them into the Mediterranean with only enough fuel to reach international waters. If the fuel leaked, those in the center would suffer chemical burns. Those straddling the sides could easily fall into the sea. Among them was a young Nigerian girl named Blessing. She was one of more than eleven thousand Nigerian women who were rescued in the Mediterranean last year. When a Médecins Sans Frontières field coördinator pulled Blessing out of the dinghy, her feet were pruning; they had been soaking for hours.
.
.
.
Today, we’re sharing photos from @bentaub91's story about the desperate journey of a trafficked girl. Click the link in our bio to read more.

Oumar, a young Toubou driver who lives in Agadez, in central Niger, smuggles migrants across the Ténéré, an expanse of sand roughly the size of California. Sometimes years pass without a drop of rainfall. “Nothing lives there, not even insects,” he said. On each trip, Oumar sees more desiccated corpses, covered and uncovered by the shifting sands. Migrants often fall out of trucks, and the drivers don’t always stop. When asked if he is afraid of dying, he shook his head and clicked his tongue: “C’est normal.”
.
.
.
Today, we're sharing photos from @bentaub91's story about the desperate journey of a trafficked girl. Click the link in our bio to read more.

Doris and her children live in Benin City, Nigeria, in a small apartment without plumbing or electricity. In February of last year, her daughter Blessing left home hoping to find education and decent work in Europe. Thousands of girls set out on the same journey voluntarily and find themselves trafficked—many forced into sex work. Three months after Blessing left, Doris received a phone call from a Nigerian woman with an Italian number. The caller demanded the equivalent of $1,500; otherwise, Blessing would be sold into prostitution. Doris borrowed the money.
.
.
. 
Today, we're sharing photos from @bentaub91's story about the desperate journey of a trafficked girl. Click the link in our bio to read more.
A cartoon by Mike Twohy, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated 49 years ago today. The image of King, which has often appeared on our cover, serves as a reminder that the march of progress can be made even in the face of forces pulling us back. Swipe to see more. #TNYcovers

At 40, #TuckerCarlson lost his bowtie, then his job, and started a website called the Daily Caller. What followed was one of the most unlikely comebacks in the annals of cable news. Click the link in our bio to read Kelefa Sanneh’s Profile of the Fox news star and fierce critic of the political and cultural establishment who is also, unapologetically, a member of it. Photograph by @philipmontgomery.

#DanaSchutz has spent her career using abstract and figurative images to tell enigmatic stories. But a recent painting depicting Emmett Till has made her an incendiary figure. Click the link in our bio to read Calvin Tomkins's story on the Brooklyn-based artist. Photograph by @gabrielestab.

Last week, @chiaragoia took over @newyorkerphoto to take us on her train voyage from Colombo to Mirissa, Sri Lanka. Check out the account to see her lush photos of tea plantations, lotus flowers, and school children. #SriLanka #TravelPhotography
A cartoon by John McNamee, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Few amateur runners were more admired by friends and strangers alike than Ed Whitlock, who, until his death last month, at age 86, was setting astounding age-group records. At 73, Whitlock became the first person over 70 to break three hours in the Toronto Waterfront Marathon. Around that time some photos of him were taken, gracefully mid-stride, that we might look for some secret, not just of running, but of life. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photographs by Jason Fulford.

“Riverdale,” which airs on the CW, has a witty conceit: take the “Archie” comic-book characters, then peer at them through the neon-noir lens of “Twin Peaks.” It began well enough, but the show has devolved into dull cosplay bracketed by bogus profundity. And it’s a shame, because on the surface the mashup makes perfect sense, Emily Nussbaum writes. Click the link in our bio to read her full review. Illustration by @keith_negley. #Riverdale #ArchieComics
A cartoon by Pat Byrnes. #TNYcartoons #AprilFools
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

An early look at next week's cover, “Broken Windows,” by Barry Blitt: “I see that the word ‘duffer’ is defined as ‘a person inexperienced at something, especially at playing golf,’” Blitt says. “That’s the word that comes to mind as I watch President Trump ploughing one drive after another through the glass windows of American politics.” #TNYcovers

For the poet Bill Knott, publication—and the page itself—was a constant source of conflict. He resented publishers, assumed the worst in readers, and thrived in the era of the flame wars. Yet his work remains a delight. Click the link in our bio to read about Knott’s anti-career of guerrilla mischief. Illustration by @riccardovecchio70.

A cartoon by Jack Ziegler, who died yesterday. Over 1,600 of his cartoons have appeared in our pages since 1972, when this one ran. Tributes from fellow cartoonists Roz Chast, Mick Stevens, Liza Donnelly, Michael Maslin, Mort Gerberg, and many others are pouring in. Click the link in our bio to read them.

Tonight, #VinceStaples and Kilo Kish bring brainy rap and back-of-the-classroom cool to New York’s Terminal 5. They’re an intriguing pairing: Staples dishes angular stanzas about family, friends, and the ills of fame, while #KiloKish saunters through airy half-raps, weaving tales of quarter-life crises. All while sidestepping common pop tropes, and stoking young devotees in the process. Photograph by @awolerizku.

#SaraBareilles may not have much acting experience, but she waitressed for a time in college. Those skills could come in handy when she takes over the lead role in “Waitress,” the effervescent musical she also composed, on March 31. A cinnamon-dusted parable of sisterhood and self-reliance, the show has lured audiences with the pie scent that suffuses the lobby and the lush harmonies of Bareilles’s score. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by Luis Mazón.

For some reason, #JohnMayer’s music always reminded Amanda Petrusich of hard-boiled eggs—until now. His latest album, “The Search for Everything,” is a tender and smarting breakup record, presumably about the end of his relationship with #KatyPerry. It is Mayer at his most human, and Petrusich can finally see the appeal. Click the link in our bio to read her review. Photograph by Ryan Pfluger/The New York Times/Redux.
A cartoon by Roz Chast, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by @farleykatz, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
@r_kikuo_johnson draws how the space between teeth can become so much more. Swipe through to see the whole story.

Good news/bad news: the most proven way for a man to live 14 years longer than average is to become a eunuch. For those not too keen on this option, Silicon Valley has been working on other alternatives, and transfusions with the blood of the young are not entirely off the table. Click the link in our bio to read Tad Friend’s story on the tech world's quest to live forever. Photograph by @grantcornett.
A cartoon by Pat Byrnes. #TNYcartoons

Melina Duterte, from Oakland, makes emotive indie pop that sticks, as #JaySom. After pillaging backlogs of nineties rock on Limewire, some ten years ago, the twenty-two-year-old multi-instrumentalist began self-recording songs that shine with an affable edge and a soft quirk. See her at Baby's All Right, in Brooklyn, on March 29th. Illustration by Claire Merchlinsky. Click the link in our bio for more information.

The New York-based artist Kim Keever is known for crafting elaborate dioramas in an aquarium then releasing pigments into the tank and taking pictures of the resulting underwater scenes. Keever, who studied as an engineer and began his art career as a painter, has said that he draws inspiration from geology, botany, and from his own personal experiences of the natural world, seeking to create images that “sit between reality and artificiality.” The image shown here, from his “Abstract” series, from 2015, devote entire frames to conflagrations and billows of radiant paint. Clink the link in our bio to see more.
If you've ever wondered what men would be like as doors, @drawingolive has the answers. Swipe through to see the full series, and then tell us if you know any such doors.

Verdi’s interpretation of Shakespeare’s "Otello" would be beyond the upstart company LoftOpera's range, but Rossini’s lighter, bel-canto version should be a better fit. John de los Santos has set the opera in the time of Italy’s postwar “economic miracle”; Sean Kelly conducts a cast headed by Bernard Holcomb and Cecilia Violetta López. Click the link in our bio for more information. Photograph by Robert Altman.
A cartoon by Jack Ziegler, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Bunna Café, in Brooklyn, is one of those vegan restaurants where the absence of meat and dairy isn’t obvious while you’re there, but when you venture out the door your step has a new spring in it. Click the link in our bio to read more about the Ethiopian restaurant. Photograph by Simone Lueck for The New Yorker.
A cartoon by @wooden.nickels, from this week's issue. What would you be watching? Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more #TNYcartoons.

Patrick Keohane uses @revolvingstyle to explore a long-standing obsession: #fashion. His collages are a funny form of mixed media: created with scissors, paper, and glue, they come to life on Instagram. With their hodge-podge aesthetic, they are perfectly suited to fashion’s current mood. Last year, Keohane told our writer Lizzie Widdicombe that his aesthetic is Internet-driven: “My theory is that we’re so used to being able to pick and choose what we like. It’s this obsession with piecing together different ideas.” Click the link in our bio to read more. #BellaHadid
Senator Al Franken at the Supreme Court confirmation hearing for Neil Gorsuch, March 21, 2017. Photograph by @markpetersonpixs/Redux for TNY.
A cartoon by @drawnbytom. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more #TNYcartoons.

The Jazz Passengers, a post-bop gang of music-class clowns, were East Village darlings in the nineteen-eighties. Three decades after the group’s début, it gathers at Roulette, on March 28th, with a new album. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by Daniel Krall.

Yola Monakhov Stockton's subject for the project “The Nature of Imitation,” in 2015, was nature in general, and birds specifically. For any photographer, birds are particularly difficult subjects to capture, and for Stockton the question of how to control them was both a practical problem and a creative challenge. Click the link in our bio to read more about her project.
Today's daily cartoon by Pat Byrnes. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In Shouts & Murmurs: Enemy of Niceness V. Putin perseveres in his campaign to shamelessly gush over naïve rookie U.S. President D. Trump. Dear Leader Kim Jong-un knows this to be a Russo-American conspiracy to ridicule the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea, Kim Jong-un’s haircut, and his honored sibling. Click the link in our bio to read "Announcement: Kim Jong-un No Patsy." Illustration by @allan_sanders. #humor
A cartoon by David Sipress for #WorldPoetryDay, from 2000. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more #TNYcartoons.

Lynn Nottage’s play “Sweat” is a tough yet empathetic portrait of the America that came undone. She has built a career on making invisible people visible. Click the link in our bio to read @michaelschulman on the playwright who may just have produced the first theatrical landmark of the Trump era. Photograph by Nathan Bajar.
A cartoon by Paul Noth, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more #TNYcartoons.

The Italian artist Nicola Lo Calzo's ambitious opus, “Regla,” is a celebration of Afro-descended forms of cultural expression in contemporary #Cuba. The strength of it is the way that Lo Calzo, whose process involves conducting extensive interviews with his subjects, finds overlap and exchange not only among Afro-Cuban cultural forms but between the official Cuban narrative and the “silent, ordinary” ones that carry on beneath the surface. Pictured here are Eba Emerida Augustin and Sergio Ramo, the Queen and King of the carnival group Carabalí Olugu, in Santiago de Cuba, 2015. Click the link in our bio to see more.
It's the first day of #spring! To celebrate the imminent warm weather and blooming flowers, here's a slide show of some of our spring-themed covers. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
This week's cover, “Shelf Life,” by Luci Gutiérrez: “I drew a bookshelf, and the lines made me think of the streets of a map,” Gutiérrez says. Click the link in our bio to read more.

Beneath the zingers and the chain-smoking, #Feud is about how skillfully patriarchy screws with women’s heads—mostly by building a home in there. The show is at once blunt and compassionate about the Realpolitik of being an older woman in Hollywood. Click the link in our bio to read Emily Nussbaum’s review. Illustration by Luci Gutiérrez.

There are so many ways to fall into Roe Ethridge’s terrific, polymorphic new pictures that logic stalls and looking takes over. The New York-based artist’s sixth show, titled “American Spirit,” is currently at the Andrew Kreps gallery and mingles outtakes from his commercial photography with images made on his own time. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph courtesy of the Artist and @andrewkrepsgallery.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Chuck Berry has died. Berry's heyday was during the fifties and early sixties; but he had been surprising us ever since, like he did last year when he announced a new album, "Chuck." Click the link in our bio to read Sarah Larson on the musician. Photograph by Michael Ochs Archives/Getty. #ChuckBerry
A cartoon by @emessodoodles, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Every watch geek has an origin story. In this week’s issue, Gary @Shteyngart shares his, from a childhood musical #Casio to a vintage #Rolex Air-King from the seventies. Click the link in our bio to join our resident W.I.S., or Watch Idiot Savant, on a descent into horological madness. Illustration by @nishantchoksi.

Before being a social-media influencer was a job, Carol Lim and Humberto Leon were New York outsiders who became the city’s resident curators of hip. With their famous friends and specific tastes, they turned a single store on Howard Street into a global name in fashion. Click the link in our bio to read about the pair behind #OpeningCeremony. Photograph by @paridukovic.
What will you give up for #Lent? Some sacrifices are harder than others. Illustrations by @r_kikuo_johnson.
A cartoon by @carolitajohnson, from 2010, for #StPatricksDay. #TNYcartoons

While Disney’s live-action take on #BeautyAndTheBeast doesn’t offer something brand-new (its plot, and much of its dialogue, is preserved intact from the animated 1991 movie), it does provide a banquet of the decent and the sumptuous, where filigrees of gold float through the air and land on the silk of a dress. Only the sternest viewer will be able to resist its thoroughly marketed magic, Anthony Lane writes. Click the link in our bio to read his review. Illustration by @malikafavre. #BeOurGuest

Union Square Café may have a new location (on East 19th Street), but the service is as humble and friendly as ever. You’ve got to love a server who cheerfully explains that “the Bitter Almond Negroni eschews gin,” as if it were entirely the Negroni’s own excellent judgment call. Click the link in our bio to read our review of Danny Meyer’s revamped restaurant. Photograph by @francesfdenny.
A cartoon by @kimwarp, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Subscribe to The New Yorker. Get 12 weeks for $12. Valid in the U.S. only. Visit the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfilfillment.com.

Each fashion house’s archive is different. Many of #Pucci’s color-saturated fabrics and bright scarves hang in the historic Palazzo Pucci, in Florence. #Ferragamo stores fifteen thousand old shoe models and rare leathers from python, skate, toad, viper, seal, and various types of lizard. And #MaxMara keeps 350,000 meticulously catalogued items, including noteworthy ensembles of Audrey Hepburn and @carineroitfeld. Swipe to see inside Italy’s finest fashion attics. Photographs by @lorenzovitturi.
A cartoon by Edward Steed, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
F. Scott Fitzgerald’s “The I.O.U.” was lost in the sparkling shuffle of the author’s first fame. Click the link in our bio to read the previously unpublished story, from 1920. Illustration by Seth.
#Snowday? These covers will make you glad you stayed inside. Swipe to see more. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @krimsteincartoons. #TNYcartoons

“Nature is at its best in the spring,” Tomer Hanuka says, about his cover, "Spring Awakening," for this week’s Style Issue. “Humans try to keep up; they want to bloom and look good. It’s instinctive to try to polish your looks to celebrate the renewal of the seasons.” Click the link in our bio to see a slideshow of our covers that have celebrated spring fashion. #TNYcovers

The movie “Personal Shopper” is one of the weirder amalgams since “Surf Nazis Must Die.” And the weirdest thing of all is that it works, Anthony Lane writes. Click the link in our bio to read his review of Olivier Assayas’s movie starring #KristenStewart. Illustration by @strautniekas. #PersonalShopper

A chance encounter with @Pharrell Williams helped launch Maggie Rogers’s career. “I’ve never heard anyone like you before,” he said. “That’s a drug for me.” Click the link in our bio to read about the singer-songwriter who is the product of her time. Photograph by Laura Henno.
A cartoon by Trevor Spaulding, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Spring forward for #DaylightSaving. A cover by Anatol Kovarsky, from 1961. #TNYcovers

The photographer Catherine Opie’s work subverts expectations. In her photographs, surfers don’t surf: they wait for waves. Click the link in our bio to read Ariel Levy’s Profile of the prominent Southern California artist. “Untitled #4 (Surfers),” 2003 by @csopie / Courtesy of Regen Projects, Los Angeles and Lehmann Maupin, New York & Hong Kong.
A cartoon by @tbtoro, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Twenty years ago today, Sarah Michelle Gellar made her début as #BuffySummers in Joss Whedon's "Buffy the Vampire Slayer." How did the figure of the vampire evolve from hideous to heartthrob? Click the link in our bio to find out. Photograph by 20th Century Fox/Everett. #BuffytheVampireSlayer #JossWhedon

In “Exit West,” Mohsin Hamid rewrites the world as a place gorgeously, permanently overrun by migrants. The novel feels immediately canonical, so firm and unerring is Hamid’s understanding of our time and its most pressing questions. Click the link in our bio to read @jiatortellini’s review. Illustration by @juncenart.

“‘Kong: Skull Island,’ is not to be confused with ‘Skull Island: Reign of Kong,’ a trackless ride at Universal Orlando Resort, in Florida. But why not? The two of them beg to be confused,” Anthony Lane writes of Jordan Vogt-Roberts’s new movie. Click the link in our bio to read his full review. Illustration by @joooheeeyooon. #KongSkullIsland
A cartoon by P. C. Vey, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In Angela Carter’s version of Little Red Riding Hood, the heroine doesn’t fight the wolf. She goes to bed with him. A new biography shows how the British author made fairy tales psychological and sexy. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by Oliver Munday.

#JackWhite isn't just a rock star. He’s a songwriter, a producer, a label owner, and a furniture upholsterer, too. He reads scripts in the hope of directing a movie, and contributes designs for baseball bats. Click the link in our bio to read about the musician's infinite imagination and interests. Photograph by @paridukovic.
A cartoon by Roz Chast, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

A strike illuminates the system in which it takes place. It pushes people to think about the entities that pay them, the people whom they rely on, and also the people who rely on them. Click the link in our bio to read @jiatortellini’s piece on today’s Women’s Strike. Photograph by Emma McIntyre/Getty. #InternationalWomensDay

Eloise J. Ellis, at the Naval Air Base in Corpus Christi, Texas, 1942. She is just one of the women who have served in combat roles since long before the Pentagon formally allowed their presence on the battlefield in 2013. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph: Howard R. Hollem/Library of Congress. #InternationalWomensDay
A cartoon by Edward Steed, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The Megalodon, a species of prehistoric shark that lived between twenty-three and 2.6 million years ago, is the largest shark in history. Its teeth, common along low-country coasts from North Carolina to Florida, are worth anywhere from thirty dollars to thousands, depending on their size. Click the link in our bio to read about the dangers of hunting Megalodon teeth. Illustration by Jee-ook Choi.

As Donald Trump cracks down on immigrants, desperate refugees are risking their lives and fleeing to Canada. A safe house in Buffalo, New York, is often their last stop before the border. Click the link in our bio to read Jake Halpern’s story on the Underground Railroad for refugees. Illustration by @thomasdoyleart.
A cartoon by Lars Kenseth, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This week’s cover, “Opening Night,” by Carter Goodrich. “I sketched this after coming back from a gallery,” he said of the curious scene in which gallery visitors appear more interested in each other than they do in the art. “It’s a comedy that repeats itself, over and over.” Click the link in our bio to see past covers that poke fun at the trend.
A cartoon by @jimbentonshots, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Ryan McGinley's early work captures the contagious exuberance of being young and beautiful, and also down and out, in New York. Taken between 1999 and 2003, the same year he became the youngest photographer to have a solo show at the @whitneymuseum, the photographs are now gathered in a new exhibition at Team Gallery. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph courtesy of the Artist and Team (Gallery, Inc.).
In Daily Shouts: Ben Ward reimagines his old boss as various Pokémon. Swipe through for more.
A cartoon by @ellisjrosen, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

What started a decade ago as a down-and-dirty all-vinyl dance party has blossomed into a local institution—no small feat for an underground party in New York City. Click the link in our bio to read more about the New York Night Train Soul Clap and Dance-Off, which turns ten this month. Illustration by @lilibellons.
The photographer @edkashi took over @newyorkerphoto last week to share images from a trip to Myanmar. Visit the account for more.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. #TNYcartoons

After a long hiatus, @lordemusic has returned as a 20-year-old whose jadedness has given way to earnestness. Click the link in our bio to read about her fiery new single "Greenlight.” Photograph by Buda Mendes/Getty. #Lorde
A cartoon by Roz Chast, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Our staff writer Evan Osnos is at @thedailyshow with #TrevorNoah to talk about his investigation into Russia's role in the 2016 election and what it all means. Tune in at 11:00 P.M. E.S.T. to watch.

We know, somewhere in our heads, that clowns must cram into cars so that they can jump out of them later, but there’s a mischievous thrill in seeing them actually folded into the trunk. In 1977, Meryl Meisler, a photographer with an eye for the zany and the performative, went backstage at the Ringling Brothers Circus to show us just that. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @merylmeisler.

For all avid readers who have been self-medicating with great books their entire lives, it comes as no surprise that reading books can be good for you. Click the link in our bio to find out why reading makes us happier. Illustration by @sarahmazzetti. #WorldBookDay

“When you write my epitaph, you must say I was the loneliest person who ever lived,” #ElizabethBishop said to Robert Lowell. The poet was vigilant about giving nothing away in her poetry, but a new biography examines her harrowing personal life. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph courtesy Yale Collection of American Literature/Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

The photographer Pieter Hugo’s lastest series, “1994,” refers to the year of the Rwandan genocide; the same year that apartheid ended in South Africa. While the children represent hope and equality, in contrast to the weighted history of atrocities and racial oppression, their gazes are steady and sober, as if they have not entirely escaped their nations’ pasts. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph courtesy #PieterHugo/Yossi Milo Gallery.

In the wake of Donald Trump's election, Congress experienced a surge of calls from citizens. But how effective were they?  Click the link in our bio to read Kathryn Schulz on the most underrated liberty guaranteed by the First Amendment:  the right to complain to our elected officials. Illustration by Oliver Munday.
A cartoon by Jack Ziegler, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“Big Little Lies” begins as a prestige-TV twist on “Real Housewives”—but it deepens to reveal risky observations, especially about the dynamics of domestic abuse. It’s most interesting when it’s examining the aftermath of violence—and the false faces that women put on. Click the link in our bio to read Emily Nussbaum’s review. Illustration by @keith_negley. #BigLittleLies

Last night's Best Picture mix-up revived the whodunit. Was it an accountant? A stagehand? Warren Beatty? Faye Dunaway? @michaelschulman was on the scene at the Dolby Theatre as everyone tried to figure out what happened at the #Oscars. Click the link in our bio to read his dispatch. Photograph by Christopher Polk/Getty.

As a black woman in an industry dominated by white men, the video director @msmelina has a unique affinity with her most frequent collaborators. “I feel safe working with her and expressing or revealing things about myself that I wouldn’t with any other director,” #Beyoncé says of her. Click the link in our bio to read more about the provocateur behind artists including #Rihanna and #IssaRae. Photograph by @awolerizku.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
The cartoonist @bob_eckstein live-drew the #Oscars tonight. Click the link in our bio to see more. #Moonlight #LaLaLand

#Moonlight has won the Oscar for Best Picture, after it was mistakenly announced that #LaLaLand had won the award. The winning film, directed by Barry Jenkins, undoes our expectations as viewers, and as human beings, Hilton Als writes. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Gabriele Stabile for The New Yorker. #Oscars
The cartoonist Bob Eckstein is live-drawing tonight’s #Oscars as they unfold. Click the link in our bio to follow along. #JanelleMonae #PharrellWilliams #EmmaRoberts #MimiValdez

This week's cover, “#OscarsNotSoWhite,” by Eric Drooker. Recently, the world of moviemaking, which will celebrate its 89th Oscars ceremony today, has been criticized for its lack of diversity, culminating in the hashtag #OscarsSoWhite. “I’m glad this is finally beginning to change,” Drooker said. “Movies have a powerful influence on us. They can stimulate—or limit–our imaginations.” Click the link in our bio to see a slide show of some of our past #Oscars covers.
A cartoon by Alex Gregory, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

@ianpurkayastha’s aim in writing a book about truffles was in part to “demystify this bourgeois product for a new generation.” The twenty-four-year-old’s new memoir chronicles how he began supplying chefs like Daniel Boulud and David Chang long before he was old enough to legally drink. Click the link in our bio to read about how a Texas teen became New York City’s premier truffle dealer. Photograph by Kristen Gladney/Wieden+Kennedy.

#OscarsSoWhite opened up a now familiar dynamic in American life: as marginalized groups attain more inﬂuence, others feel resentful. Led by Cheryl Boone Isaacs, its first black president, the Academy is trying to solve its diversity problem. Click the link in our bio to read Michael Schulman on the shakeup at the #Oscars. Illustration by @goldencosmos.
Jordan Peele’s movie “Get Out” is a rousing social farce—and a horror film centered on racial hypocrisy. Click the link in our bio to read Anthony Lane's review. Illustration by @richiepope. #GetOut
A cartoon by Alice Cheng, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

An early look at next week's cover: “I’m boning up on my Cyrillic,” Barry Blitt, the artist behind the cover of the new issue, says. In a riff on the magazine’s first cover, from 1925, by Rea Irvin, Blitt imagines a future in which our dandy mascot has become Eustace Vladimirovich Tilley and the lepidopteran under scrutiny is none other than a stunned Donald Trump. Click the link in our bio to read more. #TNYcovers

It’s been ten years since “The O.C.” went off the air. Remember Marissa, Ryan, and “the land of endless summer” with Nancy Franklin’s review of the pilot episode, from 2003. Link in bio. Photograph by WB/Everett. #TNYarchive

In nineteen-sixties Brazil, the band Os Mutantes challenged the military class with its own brand of riveting psychedelic rock. The musicians melded American rock, British pop, and Brazilian bossa nova, ornamenting political messages as suavely as Harrison and Hendrix. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @virginie.morgand.

The rich colors of Bill Manbo’s photos of Japanese internment during World War II remind us that the injustices of long ago took place in the same vivid hues as the present. Click the link in our bio to see more of his images of Heart Mountain camp in Wyoming. © Takao Bill Manbo.
A cartoon by Stuart Leeds, from 1988. #TNYcartoons #NationalMargaritaDay

The S.S. Mendi sank in 1917. It is said that the men still aboard the ship, while it was sinking, danced in unison, stamping a rhythm on the deck with their bare feet. Click the link in our bio to read about how a First World War shipwreck became one of South Africa’s most cherished political symbols. Illustration by Robert G. Fresson.

On Monday, we kicked off our event series with @publictheaterny with a discussion between David Remnick, Tony Kushner, Claudia Rankine, and Salman Rushdie. The writers tried to make sense of the current moment, when facts are said to have alternatives and truth often feels stranger than fiction.
A cartoon by @drewdernavich. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

On February 21, 1965, multiple assassins fired shotguns and pistols at #MalcolmX as he stepped up to a lectern for a speech. On the fifty-second anniversary of his death, learn how Malcom Little, a boy from Omaha, transformed himself into an electrifying proponent of black nationalism. Click the link in our bio to read David Remnick’s story. Photograph by Eve Arnold/MAGNUM.
On this day in 1925, we débuted our first magazine cover, featuring the dandy Eustice Tilley drawn by Rea Irvin. #TNYcovers

Desire lines can be found all over the world, scarring pristine lawns and worming through forest undergrowth. They appear anywhere people want to walk, where no formal paths have been provided. Click the link in our bio to read Robert Moor on the crusade to get New York City’s walkers to stick to the beaten path. Illustration by @marinamuun.
Wear a part of history. Click the link in our bio to purchase your “The March” t-shirt at newyorker.modthread.com. A percentage of sales will go to the Committee to Protect Journalists.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The New Yorker Presidents' Day Sale. Get 12 weeks for $6, plus a free tote. Valid in the U.S. only. Visit the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.

Who exactly are we celebrating on #PresidentsDay? The bouncing apostrophe bespeaks a certain uncertainty. Apostropheless, it implies a promiscuous celebration of all forty-four—Jefferson but also Pierce, F.D.R. but also Buchanan. To say nothing of the incumbent, of whom, perhaps, the less said the better. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by Tom Bachtell.
A cartoon by @drewdernavich. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Old movies are a recurring theme in the fiction of Robert Coover. His short story, “Matinée,” evokes a number of film classics, including ”Belle de Jour,” “Brief Encounter,” “City Lights,” and “Jane Eyre.” Click the link in our bio to read it. Illustration by Jorge Arevalo.

In Daily Shouts: @halliecantor and @j.a.k._ reimagine classic rom-coms for the Trump era. Here, “Clueless”: Instead of people being weirdly cool about Cher crushing on her stepbrother, they’re weirdly cool about her crushing on her mega-rich dad. Click the link in our bio to see more.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._, from 2015. #TNYcartoons #NationalDrinkWineDay

“What continues to surprise me, when I walk down a street at night and catch the corner of a bedroom beyond a window’s curtain, or someone flipping through TV channels from the couch, is the longing I feel for these homes I’ll never be invited into—or, maybe more accurately, for the lives I’ll never live,” Kristen Radtke writes. Click the link in our bio to see more of her illustrations of apartments from the outside. #NewYorkCity #NYC

Two days before Donald Trump's Inauguration, #MichaelFlynn sat down with our staff writer Nicholas Schmidle. "I want to go back to having an out-of-sight role," he said. His ambition proved illusory. Click the link in our bio to read the story on what Flynn's downfall reveals about the Trump White House. Illustration by Bob Staake. #Flynn

Artificial intelligence has achieved much of its recent success by mimicking biology. Now it must go further. Click the link in our bio to read about a computer to rival the brain. Illustration by @goranfactory.
A cartoon by @joedator, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

It’s #MichaelJordan’s fifty-fourth birthday. Back in 1998, Henry Louis Gates, Jr. wrote about how the greatest player in the history of basketball became the greatest brand in the history of sports. Click the link in our bio to read his story. Illustration by Mark Zingarelli.

In the late nineteen-seventies, the photographer Bill Bernstein captured scenes of New York’s most beloved clubs, including Studio 54. He avoided shooting celebrities and, instead, showcased the ordinary people who reinvented themselves nightly on the dance floor. Click the link in our bio to see more of his exuberant images. Photograph courtesy @billbernstein.
A cartoon by Robert Leighton, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Some serious breakfast envy from @gilliehouston. Thank you for sharing this #newyorkerinthewild. Tag us in your photos of The New Yorker, and we might regram you.

The restaurant @ChineseTuxedo is a reincarnation of Chinatown’s finest eatery, which was located just across the street a century ago. The building is a former opera house, and a certain theatrical allure extends to the parade of well-heeled patrons who glide into its dim, capacious parlor. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @christaanfelber.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons

P-45 is “the John Wayne Gacy of mountain lions.” P-19 is nicknamed "selfie cat." They and their kittens, pictured here, are among the many pumas loose in the hills outside L.A. Click the link in our bio to read Dana Goodyear’s story, from this week’s issue. Photograph courtesy National Park Service.

Long before artificial intelligence came into its own, a pioneering programmer taught a computer to write love letters. Click the link in our bio to read about Christopher Strachey’s nineteen-fifties love machine. Illustration by @wr3nm.

We asked ten photographers and artists to respond to the kitschy commodification of romance that takes place each February, utilizing whatever Valentine’s ephemera caught their eye. Here, @thisismayan captures teen heartbreak in a bottle. Click the link in our bio to see more. #ValentinesDay
A cartoon by Tom Cheney for #ValentinesDay.
A #ValentinesDay cover by Mark Ulriksen, from 2000.
A cartoon by Roz Chast, just in time for #ValentinesDay. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In 2014, Sayed Kashua moved his family from Jerusalem to the U.S. out of safety concerns. Now he wonders if it is again time to leave. “After all, this isn’t our war, we came here only as guests looking for peace and security for our children,” he writes. Click the link in our bio for more. Illustration by @annaparini.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This photograph of a couple kissing at café Chez Moineau, Paris, in 1953 comes from the pages of Ed van der Elsken’s book “Love on the Left Bank.” After seeing it, Nan Goldin knew she had found her real predecessor. "Somehow, Ed was able to document life in the truest way, always finding beauty and staying connected to the otherwise mundane,” she writes. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph courtesy of Nederlands Fotomuseum / © Ed van der Elsken / Collection Ed van der Elsken estate.
@lianafinck live-drew the #GRAMMYs for us tonight. Pictured here: #ATribeCalledQuest. Click the link in our bio to view all of her drawings.

Adele's "25" won Album of the Year and Record of the Year at the #GRAMMYs. There are echoes of past soul acts in her work, but #Adele's voice stands on its own. Click the link in our bio to read Amanda Petrusich on the singularity of the singer's soul. Photograph by Matt Sayles/AP. #25
@lianafinck is live-drawing the #GRAMMYs for us. Pictured here: #JoshDun of #twentyonepilots.

"With every hint of romance wrapped in layers of tough constitutional politics, does ‘#AUnitedKingdom' even qualify as a love story?” Anthony Lane asks of @iammmmaasante’s new movie, starring Rosamund Pike and David Oyelowo. Click the link in our bio to read his full review. Illustration by @yannkebbi.

It’s #JamesBaldwin’s voice—his luminescent words describing and analyzing dark matters—that ties together Raoul Peck’s latest film. With “I Am Not Your Negro,” he seems to be stepping in to make the movie that Baldwin couldn’t. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Richard Avedon / © The Richard Alvedon Foundation.
A cartoon by @farleykatz, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“I suspect from feedback over the years that at least 75% of readers find a story more entertaining (or more something) with sex,” the author #CurtisSittenfeld says of writing sex scenes, like the one in this week’s fiction. Click the link in our bio to read her story “The Prairie Wife.” Photograph by @grantcornett.

Emil Ferris’s début graphic novel, “My Favorite Thing Is Monsters,” follows a ten-year-old girl named Karen Reyes in Chicago in the nineteen-sixties. It takes the form of Karen’s diary, in which she chronicles her attempts to solve the mysterious death of her neighbor. On the eve of the publication of a work about the past, Ferris is surprised by its relevance to the present: “When I started on this—years and years ago—we were living in a different time,” she said. Click the link in our bio to read more.
A cartoon by David Sipress, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“I wanted the photographs I made to take readers to the front of this war, and to introduce them in an intimate way to the people fighting it,” @victorblue writes about photographing an élite Iraqi police unit fighting to take back the city of Mosul. Click the link in our bio to read his view of the battle to destroy ISIS.

How seriously to take it is an uncertainty that haunts all of #RaymondPettibon’s art. His robust pictures and refined prose suggest at once the sagacity of an old mind and the vulnerability of a young heart. Click the link in our bio to read about a new retrospective of his work at the @newmuseum. Courtesy Collection Florence and Philippe Ségalot, New York.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. See more on @newyorkercartoons. #TNYcartoons

In a beautiful and heartrending new story collection, Viet Thanh Nguyen chronicles the lives of people poised between their devastated homeland and their affluent adopted country. Click the link in our bio to read Joyce Carol Oates's review of “The Refugees.” Illustration by @juncenart.
A cartoon by Harry Bliss, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Conceived nearly a century ago, the Second Avenue subway, in New York City, débuted at noon on New Year’s Day. Its completion—on time and on budget, by some metrics; anything but, by others—was a cause for celebration, self-congratulation, and heavy Instagramification. Certain subsets of the city treated its arrival like the moon landing. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by Ben Wiseman.

Rather than capturing light and shadow, midwave infrared cameras record contours in heat. For his series of panoramic images, titled “Heat Maps,” the photographer Richard Mosse co-opted these capabilities to document scenes from routes commonly travelled by refugees, from the Persian Gulf to Berlin, and from northern Niger to the now-cleared Jungle camp in Calais, France. Click the link in our bio to see more of Mosse’s work. Photograph courtesy the artist and @jackshainman gallery.
In Daily Shouts: Faces of February decoded, by @joanaavillez. Click the link in our bio for more.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Guided by a lusty appetite for indigenous culture and cuisine, @anthonybourdain has become a travelling statesman. Click the link in our bio to read Patrick Radden Keefe’s Profile of the peripatetic chef turned writer who hosts the Emmy-winning travel show “#PartsUnknown,” on CNN. Photograph by @will_mebane. #AnthonyBourdain

"The defining emotion of losing things isn’t frustration or panic or sadness but, paradoxically, hope," Kathryn Schulz writes. Click the link in our bio to read her essay on the art of losing things. Illustration by @bianca_bagnarelli.

The day of the Inauguration, #KaraWalker, a painter and installation artist, couldn’t turn on the news; she started painting. The result is a monumental, nine-by-twelve-foot work, alluding to Emanuel Leutze’s 1851 “Washington Crossing the Delaware.”
A cartoon by @tbtoro. #TNYcartoons

In the course of a frenzied #Patriots comeback, this year’s #SuperBowl joined an inner circle of the most exciting championship games ever played. Click the link in our bio to read more about the historic game. Photograph by Kevin C. Cox/Getty Images.
Get 12 weeks for $12, plus a free tote bag. Valid in the U.S. only. Visit the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com
They're going to need it. A cartoon by Ed Fisher, from 1989. Click the link in our bio for some more #SuperBowl cartoons to tide you over until tonight's game. #TNYcartoons

“By far the most timid performer in ‘Gold’ is gold,” Anthony Lane writes. “We barely get a glimpse of the damned stuff.” Click the link in our bio to read his review of Stephen Gaghan’s latest film starring #MatthewMcConaughey. Illustration by Mikkel Sommer.
A cartoon by Alice Cheng, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This week’s fiction, by David Gilbert, is about a man who is essentially trapped as a boy—as Hemingway called them, the “great American boy-men.” Click the link in our bio to read the story. Illustration by Floc’h.

Gary Shteyngart, Joyce Carol Oates, and more of our writers share the authors they’re seeking out to make sense of the world in the early days of the Trump Administration. Click the link in our bio to see the full list of books we’re turning to now.

@sexytacodirtycash, on the corner of Malcolm X Boulevard and 118th Street, brings San Francisco street food right to the heart of Harlem. The dishes are quick and easy, and the décor is dominated by two giant pictures of scantily clad women. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @amylombard.
A cartoon by Paul Noth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

An early look at next week's cover: Under more ordinary circumstances, the cover of our Anniversary Issue, marking ninety-two years, would feature some version of Rea Irvin’s classic image of the monocled dandy Eustace Tilley. This year, as a response to the opening weeks of the Trump Administration, particularly the executive order on immigration, we feature John W. Tomac’s dark, unwelcoming image, “Liberty’s Flameout.” Click the link in our bio to read more. #TNYcovers

The powerful excitement of 1980s art has been languishing in a blind spot of art history. An exhibit at the @whitneymuseum comes to the rescue. Click the link in our bio to read Peter Schjeldahl on the the sensuous, cheeky, and grand efflorescence of the eighties. Photograph courtesy @David_Salle / VAGA, NY.
The photographer @vishalparadigm is taking over @newyorkerphoto this week to share a visual journey through Los Angeles. Follow the account to see more.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In Daily Shouts: In 2014, “The Groundhogs” wrote an open letter to Mayor de Blasio, addressing his not-so-iron grip and penchant for dangling them in the air. They are still awaiting a response. Click the link in our bio to read the letter in its entirety, by @stolincokes. Photograph by Roberta Olenick/Getty.
A cartoon by Zachary Kanin, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

#TheGoodPlace started as a daffy screwball comedy and ended as something uncomfortably appropriate for our apocalyptic era. Click the link in our bio to read Emily Nussbaum on the TV comedy with the quest to be moral–even when the truth gets bent, bullies thrive, and sadism triumphs. Illustration by @licknittle.
Our 2016 cover by Kadir Nelson celebrates the legacy of #BlackHistoryMonth, which begins today. #TNYcovers

What sets Mo Willems’s books apart from most other children’s books is that they are very funny. But they also teach young readers to confront problems and be resilient. Click the link in our bio to read Rivka Galchen’s story on the author’s funny failures. Illustration by @tshopsin.
A cartoon by William Haefeli, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In Shouts & Murmurs: “After the ceremony, I clutched at President Obama and whispered, urgently, ‘Please take me home with you.’” Click the link in our bio to read Melania Trump’s diary from 1/21/2017. Illustration by Luci Gutiérrez.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. #TNYcartoons

For two months, Luke Mogelson embedded with an élite Iraqi force fighting to recapture Mosul from ISIS. Inhabitants of the city were instructed to stay inside, because ISIS snipers often shot at civilians attempting to flee. Click the link in our bio to read his story from this week’s issue. Photograph by @victorblue.

Major Mezher Sadoon (right) is the deputy commander of the SWAT team. Every team member either had been wounded by ISIS or had lost a loved one to terrorism. They all wanted revenge. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @victorblue.

A SWAT team, led by Muslims and composed of men who have suffered at the hands of terrorists, battles ISIS—and exacts revenge. Click the link in our bio to read Luke Mogelson’s battlefront dispatch from Mosul. Photograph by @victorblue.
A cartoon by @larskenseth, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
PAID POST: Earthy spices, exotic ingredients, unique cuisine: savor a taste of desert flavor in Arizona. See more and start planning your trip at @visit_arizona. #azexpedition

Nuclear weapons and the weather are twisted together, a wire across time, the long fuse to an ongoing debate about the credibility of science, the fate of the Earth, and the nature of uncertainty. Click the link in our bio to read Jill Lepore’s story on the atomic origins of climate science. Illustration by @paulsahre.

A cover from 2011: "Promised Land," by @abstractsunday. “I draw a parallel between current immigrants and early settlers—the hope is that it will provide context, to help keep things in perspective," he says. "Cartoonists, not politicians, should be the ones who condense political discussions into simple images.” #TNYcovers

“She found it hurtful to see other people’s smiling, healthy families or, even worse, to hear about lives that seemed as fragile as her own.” This week's fiction, by Alix Ohlin, opens with a twenty-three-year-old who is more or less couch-surfing in Barcelona while waitressing, drinking too much, having sexual adventures, and detailing it all in her journal. Click the link in our bio to read “Quarantine.” Illustration by @thomasdoyleart.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Click the link in our bio to read #LenaDunham on everything she learned from #MaryTylerMoore.

Sleight of hand is typical of the director, Asghar Farhadi, who has shown himself to be a master of disorientation. Click the link in our bio to read Anthony Lane’s review of his latest film, "The Salesman." Illustration by @jamiecoeart.
Or are you just happy to see me? @lianafinck updated well-known children's books by Dr. Seuss for everyday life. Click the link in our bio to see more.

An early look at next week's cover: “The March." "I went to the march in Augusta, Maine,” Abigail Gray Swartz, the artist behind the cover, said. She used her artistic skills to make signs and a cape. “I marched for all those who need our support, for equality and diversity. And, even if I couldn’t take them with me, I marched for my three-year-old son and for my six-year-old daughter. I was there for them.” Click the link in our bio to read more. #WomensMarch #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @tbtoro. #TNYcartoons

#MarisaMerz was routinely identified as the wife of one of Arte Povera’s leading figures. But her own work is among the movement’s best. Click the link in our bio to read about her new retrospective at the @metbreuer. Photograph by @francesfdenny.

"Mary Tyler Moore, who died today, at the age of eighty, meant a lot to all of us; for feminists who remember the seventies, she was a member of the family," Sarah Larson writes. Click the link in our bio to read the postscript. Photograph via AP. #MaryTylerMoore #MTM
A cartoon by @joedator, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
@alifitzgerald8 illustrated her positive experience at the #WomensMarch in Washington, D.C. Click the link in our bio to view the entire sketchbook.

When a spot on a late-night show or a turn at the Comedy Cellar no longer holds the promise of success, the many little fish of New York standup swim toward the Creek and the Cave. The sprawling Long Island City comedy complex includes a Mexican restaurant, a theatre, a podcast operation, and a bar. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @thejorgecolombo.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

A compact but exciting new exhibit, “Black Cowboy,” at the Studio Museum in Harlem includes photographs that seem to ask the question: how might it change our national story to envision black bodies—past and present—not as criminals or captives but as dignified, heroic, and free? Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @bradtrent.

#BlackTap has been building an empire, based not on the strength of its burger, which is considerable, but on the Willy Wonka decadence of its milkshakes. People wait in lines around the block not to have a culinary epiphany but to make a declaration, preferably on social media: Watch me! I’m having fun!! Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @joshd.in.nyc.

Everybody was coming from everywhere: women, men, girls, boys, trans people, old, young, black, white, brown, Asian, gay, straight, sighted, blind, babies in strollers, people in wheelchairs, people with walkers, immigrants, and more. Click the link in our bio for more scenes from the #WomensMarch. Photograph by @paridukovic.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. #TNYcartoons #WomensMarch

“I would always be measured against my birth wine; the wines kept getting better. It’s hard to compete with 1959 Cheval Blanc.” Click the link in our bio to read John Seabrook's essay on learning how to drink, and how to stop. Illustration by @greg_clarke.

It made sense to organize the first major post-Inauguration protest march around women, who are almost fifty-one per cent of the American population, who have been maligned and attacked by the new President, and who make up a group within which every other vulnerable population exists. Click the link in our bio to read @jiatortellini's story on the radical possibility of the #WomensMarch. Photograph by @paridukovic for The New Yorker. #WomensMarchonWashington
A cartoon by @tbtoro. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In El Salvador, the call-center company Sykes is known as “homieland,” because so many of its employees were deported from the United States. Click the link in our bio to read Jonathan Blitzer on how American immigration policy has fuelled an unlikely industry. Illustration by Dave Plunkert.

The funereal mood of the Inauguration gave way to ebullience among the women and men making their way to Saturday’s protest in Washington, D.C. Click the link in our bio to read Sarah Larson on travelling to the #WomensMarch. Photograph by Shannon Stapleton/Reuters.
A cartoon by William Haefeli, from 2014. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

An American #Inauguration is like a wedding: the President is the groom, the people his bride. Donald Trump has pledged his troth. Click the link in our bio to read Jill Lepore on the romance of the Inaugural address. Illustration by Cristiana Couceiro.
The 45th President of the United States of America, drawn by @j.a.k._. Click the link in our bio for more. #InaugurationDay

Donald Trump is about to be sworn in as the President of the United States, and our cartoonist @j.a.k._ is live-drawing the #InaugurationDay events. Click the link in our bio to follow along. #Inauguration
A cartoon by Paul Noth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The @interferencearchive, in Brooklyn, hopes that its posters, stickers, and other forms of agitprop will become part of the visual landscape. Click the link in our bio to see more of the images protesting #DonaldTrump. Graphic by Janina A. Larenas.
PAID POST: Paris is not always a good idea. Watch Zach Galifianakis as Chip Baskets in the Season 2 première of @BasketsFX, tonight at 10 P.M. Cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez.

Today is the Obamas’ last day in the White House. "There is a strong possibility that Barack will pursue a political career, although it’s unclear," #MichelleObama said, in 1996, when they were still an unknown couple living in Chicago. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Mariana Cook. #BarackObama
A cartoon by @tbtoro. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Maya Shankar’s unusual White House team applies behavioral science to public policy. But will their work survive in the age of Trump? Click the link in our bio to read Sarah Stillman’s story in this week’s issue. Illustration by @r_kikuo_johnson.

Donald Trump was that hostile-jaunty comic in the big flappy suit, with the vaudeville hair, the pursed lips, and the glare. There’s always been an audience for that guy, Emily Nussbaum writes. Click the link in our bio to read about how jokes won the election. Illustration by @tshopsin.
A cartoon by @paulnoth. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

We devote vast resources to surgeons and specialists while undervaluing the physicians whose steady, intimate care helps many more. Click the link in our bio to read Atul Gawande’s piece in this week’s issue on why you should go see your doctor. Illustration by @toddstjohn.
