Michelle Obama’s time as First Lady changed this country and clarified its vision. On her birthday, click the link in our bio to read Amy Davidson on her many accomplishments. Photograph by @cherissmay/NurPhoto via Getty. #MichelleObama
A cartoon by Matt Diffee. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In 2009, the Martin Luther King, Jr. holiday pointed to how far we had come. This year, it highlights the fact that we’ve arrived at a place where the familiar landmarks are missing. Click the link in our bio to read Jelani Cobb on #MLKDay with Donald Trump. Photograph by Bruce Davidson/Magnum.
Our 2015 cover, “The Dream of Reconciliation,” by Barry Blitt, seems even more relevant this year. Click the link in our bio to read more about his inspiration.
A cartoon by @tbtoro, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The soul of silent film is comedy—the knockabout, loose-limbed antics of vaudevillians who sacrificed speech and song to the movies’ technical wonders. From Jan. 13 to 26, @themuseumofmodernart’s silent-era series will offer just that. Click the link in our bio for more info. Photograph from Everett.

#KirkFranklin is the most successful contemporary gospel artist of his generation. But he isn’t a singer. Click the link in our bio to read @vinsoncunningham’s piece about the man who wants to “make God famous” through his music. Photograph by Brent Humphreys.
A cartoon by @carolitajohnson, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“The story jumped into my head during the Republican primary debates last spring. Make of that what you will,” says Thomas Pierce, the author of this week’s fiction. Click the link in our bio to read “Chairman Spaceman.” Photo-illustration by @paulsahre.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

"However decent the director’s original intentions, 'The Founder' emerges as the first Trumpist film of the new era." Click the link in our bio to read Anthony Lane’s review of John Lee Hancock’s take on the origin of McDonald’s. Illustration by @mistergash.

A decade later, emo teens are grown up, sort of, and they are re-immersing themselves in the sound of adolescence with emo nights across the country. These are oddly specific celebrations of near-term nostalgia in which music made to help teenagers flail their way to adulthood provides an opportunity for adults to succumb to the histrionics of teendom again. Click the link in our bio to read @jiatortellini’s post on the rise of emo nostalgia. Photograph by James Donnely/Emo Night.
PAID POST: Clown’s worst friend. Watch Zach Galifianakis as Chip Baskets in the Season 2 première of @BasketsFX, January 19th at 10 P.M. Cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez.

If Steve Cohen had gone to jail, it would have been one of the most significant Wall Street prosecutions in history. Government officials spent years investigating his financial empire without ever going to court. Click the link in our bio to read Sheelah Kolhatkar on the nearly ten-year battle. Illustration by Ben Jones.
A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

@forthwanderers got their start with a self-released album, which quickly caught the attention of @lordemusic and Father/Daughter Records. Tomorrow night, they bring their adolescent malaise to @babysallright in Brooklyn. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @rrebekkaa.

Since the late 1970s, the streets of Jamaica’s capital city, Kingston, have been decorated with dancehall signs promising quick, transformative thrills. A new book, published by @hatandbeardpress, showcases over a hundred of them. Click the link in our bio to read more. Poster from “Serious Things A Go Happen,” by @maxine.walters.

Albert Woodfox spent longer in isolation than any other American. Often he woke up gasping and felt that the walls of the cell were squeezing him to death. Click the link in our bio to read about how this member of the Angola 3 survived solitary. Photograph by @markhartman.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In his #farewelladdress, President Obama carried on his long-running argument in favor of positive thinking, not as a perfect analytic tool but as a moral obligation. Click the link in our bio to read about the increasingly lonely hope of #BarackObama. Illustration by @edmon_deharo. Source photograph by @leighvogel/Wireimage.

Tonight, #BarackObama delivered his final speech as President of the United States. This cover, titled “Reflection,” by Bob Staake, was published eight years ago to honor his victory. #FarewellAddress #TNYcovers

For a man who readily identifies with Peter Pan, attaining the age of seventy, as #StevenSpielberg recently did, seems a mistake, somehow. Yet he is picking up the pace. Click the link in our more to read about a new study on the prolific director. Illustration by @paulrogersstudio.

A Yezidi girl displaced from Sinjar by ISIS makes faces at Sebastian Meyer’s camera. The photographer has been capturing images of Iraqi Kurdistan since 2008. Click the link in our bio to see more of his work. Photograph by @sebmeyerphoto.
#DavidBowie, who died a year ago today, was always an original. A cartoon tribute, by Benjamin Schwartz. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The @GoldenGlobes award for best drama went to “Moonlight.” In October, Hilton Als wrote about how the film avoided a clichéd version of black America. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Gabriele Stabile. #GoldenGlobes @moonlightmov

Last night, @lalaland set a new record for the most @GoldenGlobes won by a single movie. Click the link in our bio to revisit Anthony Lane on the musical’s dynamic thrills. Illustration by @mistergash. #GoldenGlobes

“What would Dr. King think of the world today?” the artist @kadirnelson asks. His cover, “After Dr. King,” on this week's issue, pays tribute to the civil-rights leader. Click the link in our bio to read more. #TNYcovers #MLK
A cartoon by @tbtoro, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Do you want to share your thoughts on a recent story in The New Yorker? We want to hear from you. Send us a letter, and it could be published in the magazine. Email your name, address, and daytime phone number to themail@newyorker.com.
Can technology make football safer? The coaching staff at a Fort Lauderdale high school is trying to find out. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @thomas_prior.
A cartoon by Roz Chast, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This week’s fiction, by Yiyun Li, is about a mother’s efforts to draw her son, who has autistic tendencies, into the world. Click the link in our bio to read “On the Street Where You Live.” Photo-Illustration by @_hannahwhitaker.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

For Gregor Hens, stories of love and trauma are told through memories of smoking cigarettes. Click the link in our bio to read more about his darkly funny memoir “Nicotine.” Photograph by @horaciosalinasphoto.

The British band @The1975’s front man, Matty Healy, has some rock-star problems, and they're compounded by the fact that he grew up privileged and connected. Click the link in our bio to read John Seabrook’s story. Photograph by Chuff Media. #MattyHealy #The1975
A cartoon by @kimwarp. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In 1977, the Village Voice sent the young freelance photographer Bill Bernstein to Studio 54. This was post-“Saturday Night Fever,” post-Stonewall, and pre-AIDS New York; when disco was at its glorious height. Click the link in our bio to see more of his exuberant images. Photograph courtesy @billbernstein.

“In the company of #DianeKeaton, one has the feeling of being with an alert and sympathetic carpenter who may be apologetically called to other pressing business at any moment.” On the actress’s seventy-first birthday, click the link in our bio to read Penelope Gilliatt’s 1978 Profile of Keaton during her Annie Hall days. Illustration by Bernie Fuchs.
Why do people talk to themselves, and when does it become a problem? Click the link in our bio to read Jerome Groopman’s story on the voices in our heads. Illustration by Leo Espinosa.
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons. #MariahCarey
Memories of a relaxing holiday break from @melwire. Thank you for sharing this #newyorkerinthewild. Tag us in your photos of The New Yorker, and we might regram you.

The concept of vertical farming all started with a bored class at Columbia University Medical School. Now it could change the future of food. Click the link in our bio to read Ian Frazier’s story on growing crops in the city, without soil or natural light. Illustration by Bruce McCall.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

For the past year, Ako Salemi has travelled through his native country, photographing scenes of drought and looming devastation. Click the link in our bio to see more of his work capturing Iran’s intensifying struggle with climate change. Photograph by Ako Salemi/The Pulitzer Center.
A cartoon by Seth Fleishman. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons

The sixties produced a conviction that “democracy is in the streets.” The Trump era may echo that. Click the link in our bio to read Jelani Cobb’s piece on the return of civil disobedience. Illustration by Tom Bachtell.

Could Trumpism be an actual ideology? There's a movement of conservative intellectuals that genuinely believes so. Click the link in our bio to read Kelefa Sanneh’s story on Donald Trump’s secret admirers. Illustration by Barry Blitt.

“After I procrastinate at my desk all day, I need to get out to get work done; so I go to a café, or to the library, or . . . to the Staten Island ferry,” @thejorgecolombo, who drew this week’s cover, “Waterways,” said. Click the link in our bio to read more about the cover.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Whether you’re feeling anxious or exhilarated, 2017 has arrived. Here is an illustrated guide to the many facial expressions with which we might greet the new year. Illustration by Marc Rosenthal.
A cartoon by Paul Noth, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

A young writer for a cultural magazine stumbles across a topic that intersects with her life in this week’s fiction. Click the link in our bio to read “Most Die Young,” by Camille Bordas. Photograph by @laura_eltantawy.

The end of a year is a time to reëvaluate, resolve, and begin anew. It’s also a chance to celebrate and kick back before the harsh reality of a new year sets in. Our covers have reflected both sides of the holiday. Pictured here: “January 2, 1926,” by Rea Irvin. Click the link in our bio to see more.

On Thursdays, the uptown legend Phil Young invites his musician friends for weekly sets of jazz, blues, and soul at Harlem’s Lenox Saphire, a Senegalese-American restaurant a few blocks from the Apollo. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @dina_litovsky.

Adam Driver plays a bus driver with a calling in Jim Jarmusch’s movie “Paterson.” The film has almost no bite but plenty of moseying charm, and what it does get right is the idea of poets as perpetual magpies. Click the link in our bio to read Anthony Lane’s review. Illustration by @adriantomine.
A cartoon by Sean O’Neill, from 2008. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In a dwindling Puerto Rican neighborhood in Brooklyn, an alluring corner hideaway puts a clever spin on the national drink of America’s largest territory. Click the link in our bio to read about Donna’s signature piña coladas. Illustration by @thejorgecolombo.

Through DNA editing, researchers hope to alter the genetic destiny of species and eliminate diseases. Click the link in our bio to read Michael Specter’s story on rewriting the code of life. Illustration by Bianca Bagnarelli.
A cartoon by Robert Leighton, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The choreographer Kyle Abraham’s best work combines truth and beauty by making a message about race metamorphose, again and again, into symbol. Click the link in our bio to read Joan Acocella’s review of his piece entitled “Pavement.” Illustration by @joshcochran.

The Egyptian President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi rules over an increasingly troubled country. Since coming to power in a coup, he has unwittingly revealed more about himself and Egypt’s political structures than anybody could have imagined. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by Noma Bar.
A cartoon by Peter Kuper, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“If I allow myself to be honest, my private salvation, which cannot and should not be anybody’s concern, is that I disowned my native language,” Yiyun Li writes. Click the link in our bio to read her essay on renouncing her mother tongue. Illustration by @juncenart.

Johann Sebastian Bach has long been seen as a symbol of divine order. But his music has an unruly obsession with God. Click the link in our bio to read Alex Ross on Bach’s holy dread. Illustration by @matt.dorfman.
Demetrius Cunningham taught himself to play the piano, in prison, using only a cardboard keyboard and some music books. Click the link in our bio to read his story. Illustration by Eleanor Taylor.

The biggest threat facing the people of northern Iraq may have nothing to do with who controls the streets. If the Mosul Dam fails, it will likely cause a colossal wave that could kill as many as a million and a half people. Click the link in our bio to read Dexter Filkins’s story on the most dangerous dam in the world. Photograph by @victorblue.

“On a recent walk across the Brooklyn Bridge, I first saw the people putting on locks and taking photos of themselves,” Adrian Tomine said, about his cover, "Love Locks,” for this week’s issue. “In my youth, I would have probably identified with the romantic lovers, but now that I’m a dad cleaning up after two kids, I can readily relate to the sanitation worker with the bolt cutter.” Click the link in our bio to read more.
A cartoon by John Jonik. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Our vintage magazine covers show that holiday preparations have never been easy. Pictured here: “December 9, 1933,” by Ilonka Karasz. Click the link in our bio to see more of our #Christmas covers, from then and now.

For any young dancer, getting to play the Nutcracker Prince is a major life event. Click the link in our bio to read about Ian Zelbo and Emerson Alexander’s princely duties at the @nycballet. Photograph by Paul Kolnik. #TheNutcracker
Even the Magi were known to hit T.J. Maxx for some last-minute candles. A cartoon by Roz Chast. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more. #TNYcartoons

"Everybody who came to visit complimented Mom on the candy-cane wreath. The praise wasn’t enough to keep Mom, Dad, and my sister from hating it. Passionately." Click the link in our bio to read Michele Thomas’s story. Illustration by Cari Vander Yacht.

The phrase “wintry mix” is unforgivably dishonest. A better name for it would be “airborne depravity.” Click the link in our bio to read Kathryn Schulz’s story on the cold, wet, sharp, splashy, slush-creating, hypothermia-inducing abomination. Illustration by @roman_m.
A cartoon by William Haefeli. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The rules of fashion exist to be redefined, but the past year will go down as a time of radical regime change. One no longer follows fashion; one follows @kendalljenner and her B.F.F.s. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @carmenchan/WWD/REX/Shutterstock.

John Lamb, the New York-born Revolutionary War hero, would have marvelled at the posh interiors of @thejohnlamb, a new bar and restaurant tucked on the Lower East Side. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @thejorgecolombo
A cartoon by @eflakeagogo. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

With all due respect to Smokey Robinson, the Motown Sound as we know it was created by Holland-Dozier-Holland. Click the link in our bio to read Vinson Cunningham on the trio who brought us hits like “Heat Wave” and “Baby Love.” Illustration by @jasuhuart.

During each week of 2016, a photographer took over @newyorkerphoto’s Instagram account. Click the link in our bio to see some of our favorites, and follow @newyorkerphoto for more takeovers. Photograph by @markhartman.
A cartoon by Robert Leighton, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The New Yorker Holiday-Week Sale. Get 12 weeks for $6, plus a free 2017 cartoon calendar. Visit the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.

With a new crop of museums, the Emirates was supposed to be the cultural nexus of the Gulf. But at what human cost? Click the link in our bio to read Negar Azimi’s story on the Gulf art war. Photograph by @knutegilwang.

Opened during Prohibition, Chumley’s was frequented by writers, including Ernest Hemingway and F. Scott Fitzgerald. Now, it has been reimagined as a swanky restaurant. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @christaanfelber.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Time may seem slippery and maddeningly abstract, but it’s also deeply intimate, infusing our every word and gesture. Click the link in our bio to read Alan Burdick’s story on the essence of time. Illustration by @miguelporlan.
A cartoon by @mecharliehankin, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

"If you chafe at the lack of incident in “20th Century Women,” try “Julieta,” which has plot enough for two movies,” Anthony Lane writes. Click the link in our bio to read his review of both films. Illustration by @jeffelicious.

"I had a call to adventure, a call to live life bigger than myself. I found the elixir,” @violadavis says. Click the link in our bio to read John Lahr’s Profile of the actress. Photograph by @awolerizku.

“I fell in love too quickly, I got married impetuously, and now I was living with Juan Martín, who irritated and bored me.” In this week’s fiction, an already sour relationship is tested by a road trip north to Paraguay. Click the link in our bio to read “Spiderweb,” by Mariana Enriquez. Photograph by Maurizio Cattelan and Pierpaolo Ferrari.
A cartoon by Mick Stevens, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

As the global consequences of human activity have become unmistakably pressing, @edwardburtynsky has connected his photography more directly with environmentalism. “There has been a discussion for a long time about climate change, but we don’t seem to be ceasing anything,” he says. “That has begun to bring a sense of urgency to me.” In this week’s issue, Raffi Khatchadourian writes about Burtynsky’s quest to photograph a changing planet. Click the link in our bio to read more.

In the Niger Delta, the photographer @edwardburtynsky shot illicit oil refineries, which dump tons of waste into the ground. His work, a curator says, inspires the sensation of “being terribly anxious while also being attracted to the beauty of an image.” Click the link in our bio to see more.

The photographer @edwardburtynsky seeks moments when the view of a landscape falls into order: “You try to let the subject tell you where it is,” he says. In this week’s issue, Raffi Khatchadourian looks at how frame by frame, Burtynsky’s photographs tell the story of a planet reshaped by human ambition.

From high in the air, the photographer @edwardburtynsky captures sweeping images of industrial projects and their effects on the environment, like this image of sawmills in Lagos, Nigeria. We’ll be sharing more of his footage here throughout the day. Click the link in our bio to read Raffi Khatchadourian’s piece on Burtynsky's quest to photograph a changing planet.
A cartoon by @larskenseth, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
A morning mail delivery on the Upper West Side, via @nytimes’s Joe Nocera.

In “Dear Evan Hansen,” the actor Ben Platt brings a new level of reality not just to the musical, but to Broadway. Click the link in our bio to read Hilton Als review of the show that puts pop psychology onstage. Illustration by @keith_negley.

“I hadn’t forgotten the words that were now a part of me. I was simply unable to draw them out,” #PattiSmith writes, of singing at Bob Dylan's #NobelPrize ceremony. Click the link in our bio to read her essay. Photograph by @philipmontgomery/The New York Times/Redux.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

PAID POST: Cate Blanchett and Richard Roxburgh make their Broadway débuts in “The Present,” a searing new adaptation of Chekhov’s “Platonov.” Previews begin this Saturday, Dec. 17. #ThePresent @thepresentbway

Picture the entire Industrial Revolution compressed into the life span of a beagle. That’s what could play out over the next decade or two as more jobs are done by robots. Click the link in our bio to read about our automated future. Illustration by @mattblease.

#TaylorSwift, who turns 27 today, turned teen angst into a business empire by hooking a previously unrecognized audience: girls who listen to country music. Click the link in our bio to read Lizzie Widdicombe's 2011 Profile of the pop star. Photograph by @katygrannan.
A cartoon by @karasikkomiks, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Most Nativity scenes come equipped with shepherds, magi, and a camel or two. But at the @Metmuseum? Roman ruins and a poodle. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @screenlives.

The photographer @johannerahaman spends her weekends driving around Miami’s African-American and Caribbean enclaves, in search of scenes of everyday city life. Click the link in our bio to see inside the black Miami of "Moonlight."

The outcome of the Hogan v. Gawker case is about so much more than a sex tape. Click the link in our bio to read Jeffrey Toobin’s story on what the Trump era means for the First Amendment. Illustration by Oliver Munday.
A cartoon by David Sipress, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This week's cover, “Yule Dog,” by Ana Juan. “Don’t assume this is only a cozy, lovely holiday scene,” Juan says about her painting of a pug in front of a fireplace. “You don’t see the dog’s face, but I can tell you he’s tired, tired of the threats posed by the conservative and reactionary winds blowing in our old world.” Click the link in our bio to read more. #TNYcovers

The idea that nostalgia can be gutsy and purposeful rather than moony and limp is what powers the film “La La Land.” Click the link in our bio to read Anthony Lane’s review of the new movie starring #RyanGosling and #EmmaStone. Illustration by @mistergash. #LaLaLand
In this Sketchbook, by George Booth, Santa Claus gets ready for Christmas.
A cartoon by @drawnbytom, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more #TNYcartoons.

The L.A. Opera’s production of “Akhnaten,” Philip Glass’s saga of ancient Egypt, had a spooky grandeur. Click the link in our bio to read Alex Ross's story on how modern opera is thriving in Los Angeles. Illustration by @daviddoran_.

Two formerly incarcerated undergrads, Steven Czifra and Danny Murillo, knew that others like them were also capable of making it to college and leaving prison forever. Together, they started the Underground Scholars Initiative at Berkeley, which offers mentoring, support, and advocacy to former inmates. Click the link in our bio to read Larissa MacFarquhar’s story "Building a Prison-to-School Pipeline.” Illustration by @annaparini.
A cartoon by Ed Steed, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more #TNYcartoons.

Ritchie Torres, New York City’s youngest elected official, grew up in the projects, in the Bronx. For him, the fight for better public housing is personal. Click the link in our bio to read more about the millennial on a mission to tackle urban poverty. Photograph by @caitoppermann for The New Yorker.
Today's daily cartoon by @eflakeagogo. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more #TNYcartoons.

Jihadis have been decimated on the field, but they have created chaos across the Middle East. Where will they take the war next? Click the link in our bio to read Robin Wright’s piece on the struggle for the soul of Sunni jihadism. Illustration by @staufferstudio.
A cartoon by @farleykatz, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more #TNYcartoons.

#DonaldGlover’s raw talent is obvious, but his obsession with explaining himself has often obstructed his ideas and undermined his jokes. On his new album as Childish Gambino, he abandons his long-standing battle between self-awareness and solipsism. Clink the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by MVM.

In February, the photographer @thomas_prior travelled to the Mexican town of San Juan de la Vega to capture an annual festival full of exploding sledgehammers. In his photographs, we don’t see the faces of the men holding the hammers, just their smoke-shrouded bodies bent on waves of impact. Prior’s “stark framing grants the scene a mythic, muscular force, illuminating the peculiar and self-sacrificing dedication required to make any tradition last,” @vibefortonight writes. Click the link in our bio to see more.
A cartoon by Harry Bliss. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Joan Didion, born on this day in 1934, started out a Goldwater conservative. How did she become a voice of the left? Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Ted Streshinsky / Corbis.

PAID POST: The nation's capital becomes a wonderland in winter. Dine at a Michelin-rated restaurant, ice skate in three different neighborhoods, and marvel at D.C.'s incredible holiday displays. Learn more @visitwashingtondc. Photograph by @samkittner. @officialgeorgetowndc #MyDCcool

“Back in the days when there was still magic” is how Carter Goodrich, the artist of this week’s cover, “Forest for the Trees,” remembers the preparations for the holidays when he was a child. Click the link in our bio to see a slide show of holiday covers, through the years, that may give you a few ideas for how to prepare for the Christmas season. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

"It could also be that I’m dreaming him like that—tiny—because it’s a way of distancing myself, but that’s a bit Freudian, don’t you think?” Click the link in our bio to read Sam Shepard’s story in this week’s issue, “Tiny Man.” Illustration by @ryanheshka.

Charity Hope Valentine is a great part for @suttonlenore, but that affinity gets lost in Leigh Silverman’s conception of the show, which has very little shine or imagination. Click the link in our bio to read Hilton Als’s review. Photograph by @paridukovic.
A cartoon by P. C. Vey, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In “Jackie,” Natalie Portman captures to perfection the breathiness of Jacqueline Kennedy's voice, as it floats above the guttural twang of less exalted lives. Click the link in our bio to read Anthony Lane’s review of the film. Illustration by @olimpiazagnoli.

One of the things that used to make America so distinctive was its cars. They were enormous boats in which you could eat, sleep, make love, change clothes, throw parties, practice unlicensed dentistry—or take your six best friends out for a spin. Click the link in our bio to see more of Langdon Clay’s photographs in “When Cars Ruled the Night: New York City, 1974-1976."

How should a fancy restaurant be? Should it be radical, like Momofuku Ko; grand, like Eleven Madison Park; wacky, like Gabriel Kreuther; haughty, like Jean-Georges? Günter Seeger, a new European-accented place in the West Village, suggests something different: a fancy restaurant should be discreet. Click the link in our bio to read Daniel Wenger’s review. Photograph by Zachary Zavislak for The New Yorker.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons, our account dedicated to drawings and drollery. #TNYcartoons

Research into psychedelics—drugs that produce radical changes in consciousness, including hallucinations—may hold a key to coping with anxiety, addiction, and existential dread. In 2015, Michael Pollan wrote about an N.Y.U. study on psilocybin, the results of which were published yesterday. Click the link in our bio to read his story. Illustration by Stephen Doyle.

A six-story building with movable walls and ceilings and computerized lighting and sound systems, the Shed, under the direction of Alex Poots, may be the city’s first example of performative architecture. In this week’s issue, Calvin Tomkins examines how Poots’s ambitious experimental cultural center could change New York. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @joshcochran.

What should we do about journalism’s role in non-reality-based politics? Click the link in our bio to read Nicholas Lemann’s post on solving the problem of fake news. Illustration by Oliver Munday; photograph by Kevkhiev Yury/Alamy.
A cartoon by Liam Francis Walsh, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The Chinatown bar @beverlysnyc is a paradise for people who value conversation, music, and getting crunk (that would be: crazy drunk). Click the link in our bio to read Nicolas Niarchos’s review. Illustration by @thejorgecolombo.

For three years, “Rectify” has been a small marvel, an eccentric independent drama, filmed in Griffin, Georgia, and airing off the beaten track as well, on Sundance. Click the link in our bio to read Emily Nussbaum’s review of the gothic mystery about small-town secrets and how time gets distorted. Illustration by @tropical_toxic.
A cartoon by @drewdernavich, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The Brooklyn attorney Carrie Goldberg was once harassed online by a vengeful ex. She started her practice, which specializes in the field of sexual privacy, to “be the lawyer I’d needed.” When vindictive men use the Internet to threaten women and post nude images of them without their consent, Goldberg helps the victims fight back. Click the link in our bio to read Margaret Talbot’s piece “The Attorney Fighting Revenge Porn.” Photograph by @paridukovic for The New Yorker.

The New Yorker Cyber Monday Sale. Now through Monday get 12 weeks for $6, plus a free 2017 cartoon calendar. Visit the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.
A cartoon by @joedator, via @newyorkercartoons. #TNYcartoons

This week's cover, “Rat Race,” by Peter de Sève. “I had an inordinate amount of pets growing up, from puppies to parrots, and I even worked in a pet shop as a teen-ager,” de Sève said, when we asked him about his fortieth cover for the magazine. Click the link in our bio for more. #TNYcovers

“The schoolmarm’s just showing off again, making their brains ache, unrepentant criminal that she is.” Click the link in our bio to listen to Robert Coover read his short story “The Hanging of the Schoolmarm.” Illustration by Alain Pilon.
A cartoon by Alex Gregory. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more #TNYcartoons from this week’s issue.
Sean Muldoon's new bar, BlackTail, takes its inspiration from the grand hotel lounges of nineteen-twenties Havana. Click the link in our bio read @weitchou’s review. Illustration by @thejorgecolombo.
A cartoon by Paul Karasik, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Gramercy Farmer & the Fish serves a country-inspired fantasy for those romanticizing the "farm" in farm-to-table. Click the link in our bio to read @jiayangfan’s review of the restaurant. Photograph by @joaquintrujillo.

Throughout his sophomore album, “Always Strive and Prosper,” @asapferg conjures scenes of his father, uncle, and grandmother with a stylish eye and a bold tone. He performs tonight at Webster Hall, in New York City. Click the link in our bio to learn more. Photograph by @ian_allen for The New Yorker.
A cartoon by @mecharliehankin. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more #TNYcartoons.
A Thanksgiving cartoon by @mattdiffee. Click the link in our bio to see a slide show of #TNYcartoons for the road.
Happy Thanksgiving from The New Yorker. Here, Tom Gauld’s #Thanksgiving cover from 2013, “Turkey Day.” #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @drewdernavich. Click the link in our bio to see more cartoons for the road. #TNYcartoons

Can hypothermia save gunshot victims? A new procedure freezes trauma patients who are bleeding out in order to buy time to operate. Click the link in our bio to read Nicola Twilley’s piece in this week’s issue. Photograph by @mauricioalejo for The New Yorker.

The techno-dystopian “what if”s that Charlie Brooker poses in “Black Mirror” are far-fetched, but the meticulous attention to detail gives the show a remarkable plausibility. Click the link in our bio to read Giles Harvey’s profile of the British satirist. Illustration by @malikafavre. #blackmirror
A cartoon by @joedator, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Stevie Nicks’s music has long been considered a balm for stubborn strains of heartache: her songs are unsparing about the brutality of loss, yet buoyed by a kind of subtle optimism. Click the link in our bio to read @amandapetrusich’s piece on the singer's resurgent appeal. Photograph by Neal Preston.

Kenneth Lonergan’s new film, “Manchester by the Sea,” is a litany of human error, with the tragic parts nicked and grazed by semi-comedy. Click the link in our bio to read Anthony Lane’s review. Illustration by Jon McNaught.

The Madrid workshop Factum Arte is using digital technology to craft perfect copies of imperilled art—from Egyptian tombs to Renaissance paintings. Is replication the future of preservation? Click the link in our bio to read Daniel Zalewski’s “The Factory of Fakes.” Photograph by Henrik Spohler for The New Yorker.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This week's cover, “Counting,” by Barry Blitt. “I have to admit to feeling a little nostalgic, drawing a President without a cotton-candy combover,” Blitt says. “Not to mention drawing someone with a little character and decency, as well.” Click the link in our bio to read more. #TNYcovers

"My grandma had just died, and Mike was my rock. He was there for me when I cried, and he was the only ninja skilled enough to avenge her murder." Click the link in our bio to read Jen Spyra's Shouts & Murmurs story "When I Knew I Found the One." Illustration by @taxali.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy. For more #TNYcartoons from this week’s issue, follow @newyorkercartoons.
Laugh your way through the holidays with more than two hundred and fifty of our best cartoons from 2016. Click the link in our bio to buy it now. #TNYcartoons

At Yemen Café, in the northern extremities of Cobble Hill, the food sparkles with unique flavors, so don’t just order the classics. For some reason, the best finale, the fatah with honey, is on the “Appetizer” section of the menu. Click the link in our bio to read Nicolas Niarchos’s review. Photograph by @jeremy_liebman for The New Yorker.

On game days, at Kettle of Fish, a twelve-dollar cover buys two drinks amid choruses of “I Love My Green Bay Packers.” Click the link in our bio to read @stolincokes’s review of the bar where Jack Kerouac used to drink. Illustration by Jorge Colombo.
A cartoon by Robert Leighton, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The poet Ishion Hutchinson’s sound effects are exquisite: clusters of consonants and vowels so open you could fall into them. Click the link in our bio to read about his second book, “House of Lords and Commons.” Photograph by @paridukovic for The New Yorker.

In 1962, J. D. Salinger gave his permission to a TV producer to adapt his beloved short story “For Esmé—With Love and Squalor” into a film—on one condition: he would cast the lead. Click the link in our bio to read Jill Lepore's piece about why it was never made. Illustration by @mistergash.

The photographer @thomasjackson415 assembles artificial objects on outdoor frameworks, then photographs the installations. "The flocks in Jackson’s pictures are so cheeky and vibrant, so artificial and yet so full of apparent animal instinct, that it’s hard to believe a photographer could have created the tableaux without an assist from digital editing,” Max Campbell (@vibefortonight) writes. That’s intentional: “My little inside joke is that I still want my images to look like digital composites,” Jackson said in a recent interview. Click the link in our bio to see more.
A cartoon by @tbtoro, from this week’s issue. Want more? Follow @newyorkercartoons, our account dedicated to #TNYcartoons.
Tune in to @thedailyshow with @trevornoah at 11:00 P.M. on Comedy Central to see The New Yorker's George Packer discuss his recent piece "The Unconnected."

In the aftermath of the election, President Obama talks with David Remnick: “I think nothing is the end of the world until the end of the world.” Click the link in our bio to read the interview. Photograph by @paridukovic for The New Yorker.

At forty, Chris Kraus found herself with a failed film and a growing stack of letters to a guy she once had a crush on. She turned her failures as a filmmaker and in her romantic relationships into the boundary-breaking autobiographical novel “I Love Dick.” Click the link in our bio to read Elaine Blair’s Profile of the author. Photograph by @lahubbs.
From 2008 to 2016: Two Presidents, two pivotal moments in American history, two covers by Bob Staake. Click the link in our bio to read more about this week’s cover. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In Georgia, the expectation that brides should be virgins, and that women should live with their parents until marriage, pushes teen couples to wed. Tamuna, pictured here, married at fifteen and became pregnant immediately. She returned to her parents’ house after three years. Kikhani, Kvemo Kartli region, Georgia, 2016. Click the link in our bio to see more photographs by @la.meloni of the teen-age brides of Georgia.

Since Rodrigo Duterte was elected President of the Phillipines, in May, more than three thousand people have been killed in a vicious drug war. Click the link in our bio to read Adrian Chen’s piece on what happens when a populist demagogue takes power. Illustration by Diego Patiño.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. Want more? Follow @newyorkercartoons, our account dedicated to #TNYcartoons.

Last week, the photographer @ryanpfluger took over @newyorkerphoto, sharing images from a three-week, five-thousand-mile road trip. "I wanted to explore the experience, often thought of as a journey for finding oneself or a way to transition, as a queer man in my thirties desperately needing an escape from the hustle of my life in N.Y.C.,” he wrote. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.

In a series of essays in this week’s issue, Toni Morrison, Atul Gawande, Hilary Mantel, George Packer, Jane Mayer, Jeffrey Toobin, Junot Díaz, and others reflect on the outcome of the 2016 Presidential election. Link in bio. Photograph by @philipmontgomery for The New Yorker.
A cartoon by David Sipress. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Glamour vies with grotesquerie in the paintings, photographs, and videos in “Marilyn Minter: Pretty/Dirty,” the @BrooklynMuseum’s retrospective of the American artist. Here, the six-foot-tall painting “Redhead,” from 2015. Courtesy Avenues the World School and Collection of Sherry & Douglas Oliver. Link in bio.

PAID POST: Seasonal celebrations and festive performances make D.C. an ideal destination for the holidays. Revel in everything from the National Christmas Tree and Downtown Holiday Market to a vibrant, Michelin-rated restaurant scene. Learn more @visitwashingtondc. #MyDCcool
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In Death Valley, seeds stay in the soil for years, waiting for a deluge to awaken them. Last October, rain came. Click the link in our bio to read Alex Ross’s story on the Superbloom that caused Death Valley to emerge in full flower. Photograph by @jimmangan.

Some people seek out late-night work for its transformational possibilities. Cesar Villavicencio, who performs six nights a week at Therapy, a bar in Hell’s Kitchen, begins putting on makeup at home around eight in the evening and is onstage two and a half hours later, strutting in front of a crowd as the drag queen Pixie Aventura. In recent months, the photographer @adam.pape has documented scenes of those who go to work while most of the city sleeps or plays. Click the link in our bio to see more. Produced by @theatraff.

In recent months, the photographer @adam.pape has documented scenes of those who go to work while most of the city sleeps or plays. At the 110th Street branch of Animal Care Centers of N.Y.C., one of the city’s largest rescue shelters, the technician Tai Welcome spends a quiet moment with a kitten just after midnight. Click the link in our bio to read more. Produced by @theatraff.
A cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In this week’s issue, Anthony Lane reviews Denis Villeneuve’s “Arrival.” What lingers for days after you leave the cinema, he writes, “is neither the wizardry nor the climax but the zephyr of emotional intensity that blows through the film.” Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by Keith Negley.

@mirandalambert's response to a turbulent year consists of twenty-four songs, which, taken together, suggest that she is just what country needs. Her sprawling concept album, “The Weight of These Wings,” defies Nashville wisdom—and is one of the year’s best releases. Click the link in our bio to read Kelefa Sanneh’s review. Illustration by @rebeccaclarke. #theweightofthesewings
At Take Root, in Brooklyn, the homemade brioche is warm, with a shiny crust and a pillowy, egg-sweet interior. Click the link in our bio to read @thecooperrrr’s review. Photograph by @francesfdenny.
A cartoon by Harry Bliss. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“Swing Time” is Zadie Smith's most affecting novel in a decade. It brings a piercing focus to Smith's favorite theme: the struggle to weave disparate threads of experience into a coherent story of a self. Click the link in our bio to read Alexandra Schwartz's review. Illustration by @olimpiazagnoli

When we first received the results of the election, we felt as though we had hit a brick wall, full force. “To combat authoritarianism, to call out lies, to struggle honorably and fiercely in the name of American ideals—that is what is left to do. That is all there is to do,” David Remnick wrote shortly after the announcement. And so we must go on—with words and images such as this cover by Bob Staake for next week’s issue. Click the link in our bio to read more about next week's cover. #TNYcovers

#LeonardCohen, who died this week, was one of our greatest songwriters. He gave one of his final interviews to David Remnick over the summer. Click the link in our bio to listen to it now. Photograph by Graeme Mitchell.
A cartoon by David Sipress. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Once the richest country in South America, Venezuela now has the world’s highest inflation rate and is plagued by hunger and violent crime. How did this happen? Click the link in our bio to read William Finnegan’s piece “Venezuela, a Failing State.” Photograph by @eltestigo44.

“Mommy and Daddy: This just isn’t working out. I feel like our relationship is stifling me creatively and personally. I’ve discovered this with the help of the expensive weekly therapy that you pay for.” Click the link in our bio to read Cora Frazier’s Shouts & Murmurs piece on breaking up with your parents. Illustration by Antony Huchette.

#HillaryClinton’s party at the Javits Center on Tuesday night was expected to be a historic bash. The photographer @philipmontgomery captured the assembled crowd members as they shed the excitement of near-certain victory, then held tight to grim but fading hope. Click the link in our bio to see more. #election2016 #electionday
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. #TNYcartoons
A cartoon by David Sipress. #TNYcartoons

The election of #DonaldTrump to the Presidency is nothing less than a tragedy for the American republic, a tragedy for the Constitution, and a triumph for the forces, at home and abroad, of nativism, authoritarianism, misogyny, and racism. Click the link in our bio to read David Remnick on the results of the election. Source photograph by Joe Raedle / Getty. #election2016

As we enter the final hours of the 2016 election, click the link in our bio to revisit The New Yorker’s endorsement of #HillaryClinton for President. “The election of Hillary Clinton is an event that we would welcome for its historical importance, and greet with indescribable relief,” our editors wrote. “It will be especially gratifying to have a woman as commander-in-chief after such a sickeningly sexist and racist campaign, one that exposed so starkly how far our society has to go.” Illustration by Tom Bachtell. #electionday #election2016
An #electionday cartoon by David Sipress. #TNYcartoons #election2016

As the nation’s voters cast their ballots, our staff writers Ryan Lizza and Benjamin Wallace-Wells are live-blogging the election. Click the link in our bio to read their analysis. Illustration by Oliver Munday. #electionday #election2016
VOTE! Today’s Daily Cartoon by David Sipress. #TNYcartoons
PAID POST: Boligee, Alabama-based Greene Prairie Shrimp, a @WholeFoods supplier, raises its shrimp in earthen pods scooped into the prairie soil. Illustration by @danbransfield.
Don't miss the artist Christoph Niemann (@abstractsunday) talking about the creative process with our art editor, Françoise Mouly–LIVE on Facebook today around 2:30 P.M. EST.

Last week on @newyorkerphoto, @markpetersonpixs shared photographs from the 2016 Presidential campaign. Here, he captured a moment between #HillaryClinton and her daughter, Chelsea, on the last day of the Democratic National Convention, when Hillary accepted the nomination for President. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
Today's daily cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. #TNYcartoons

This week's fiction, “Are We Not Men?,” envisions a time in which CRISPR has gone mainstream, and animals and babies are genetically engineered. Click the link in our bio to hear T. Coraghessan Boyle read his short story. Illustration by @kristianhammerstad.
A cartoon by William Haefeli. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more. #TNYcartoons.

Gerald Finley is one of the supreme singer-actors of our day and his masterpiece of a performance in a dreamlike production of Gioachino Rossini's “Guillaume Tell” highlights the unease in Rossini’s score. The opera is playing at The Metropolitan Opera for the first time in eighty-five years. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @goldencosmos.
A cartoon by David Sipress, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

"If it hadn’t been for the boat, I would not have left my husband for the man who built it," Dianne Belfrey writes. Click the link in our bio to read her personal history, "Fire and Water: a Brooklyn Love Story." Construction by @doylepartners.

If the Southern Baptist church can’t be bigger, Russell Moore wants it to be better. Click the link in our bio to read Kelefa Sanneh’s story about the president of the Ethics & Religious Liberty Commission and the new evangelical moral minority. Illustration by Ben Wiseman.

PAID POST: On October 29th, Mexico City hosted its first #DayoftheDead parade, a dazzling spectacle featuring aerial acrobats, dancing puppets, and hundreds of catrinas and catrines. See more at @DescubreMiMexico.
A cartoon by @paulnoth, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

An early look at next week's cover, “Anything But That,” by Barry Blitt. “It’ll apply next week, whether it’s one or the other,” Blitt says, about the cover. “And it’s nice to take a break and not have to draw Trump—or Hillary, for that matter.” Click the link in our bio to see more of Blitt's covers on the Presidential campaign. #election2016

This week on @newyorkerphoto, the photographer @markpetersonpixs is sharing images from his Political Theatre series, in which he captured the theatricality of the long campaign trail leading up to the Presidential election. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.

@tovelo’s “sound is of the moment: simple, electronic, and unfussy,” Sasha Frere-Jones wrote after the release of her début album, “Queen of the Clouds.” Now, the Swedish singer is back with her second album, “Lady Wood." Click the link in our bio to read Frere-Jones’s 2014 piece on the Swedes’ pop-charts takeover. Illustration by @antonio__soares. #tovelo

You have a Clinton sign on your lawn. Your neighbor has a Trump sign on his. Can you get along? Click the link in our bio to read Joshua Rothman’s story on what political choices have done to our civilian life. Illustration by @nishantchoksi.
A cartoon by John Klossner, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

In Shouts & Murmurs, @meganamram imagines Trump’s American Girl Dolls. Meet ANGELA! She is an energetic and optimistic girl who follows her heart instead of the crowd, and also she has huge breasts and a tight little ass. Click the link in our bio for more. Illustration by Luci Gutiérrez.
Limited time only. The New Yorker Election Sale. Get 12 weeks for $6. Click the link in our bio to learn more.

Despite ample proof of the average American voter’s cluelessness, why do we still insist on voting rights for all? Click the link in our bio to read Caleb Crain’s story on why democracy is far from perfect. Illustration by Yarek Waszul.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Click the link in our bio to read why this year, watching Fox News became Emily Nussbaum’s chief vice––less for the news and more for the melodrama. Illustration by @ben_kirchner.
PAID POST: The salmon farmers of Kvaroy Aquaculture in Norway, a @WholeFoods supplier, raise their fish in open water pens etched among the fjords. Illustration by @danbransfield.

“All the new high-rises along the Williamsburg side of the East River, aimed at the sunset, are thrilling to live in, I’m sure,” Bruce McCall, one of our resident kvetchers and the artist behind this week’s cover, says. “But they will help turn Williamsburg into a seedy Brooklyn version of Second Avenue. Combined with the loss of the L train, this is a blow to a vibrant young culture and another threat to civilized middle-class living anywhere near the city,” he adds. Click the link in our bio to see a slide show of past New Yorker covers by McCall, in which he expresses both his discontent and his love for the city. #TNYcovers
A #Halloween cartoon by Alex Gregory. See more #TNYcartoons at @newyorkercartoons.
Visit the link in our bio to see a selection of photographs with masks, inspired by the disguises of #Halloween. Here, Tierney Gearon’s “Untitled” (2004), from “The Mother Project.”
Ivan Brunetti’s “Dressed Down,” from 2010. Click the link in our bio to see a selection of #Halloween covers from the archive. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @paulnoth from the archive. Click the link in our bio to see more #TNYcartoons for #Halloween.
“Two people so wired together can do harm even with the best intentions." Click the link in our bio to read Anne Carson’s story “Back the Way You Went.” Illustration by Chloé Poizat.
Our 60s anthology tells the story of a decade, from the likes of Sylvia Plath and Roger Angell. Click the link in our bio to learn more.

Esperanto was invented as the language that would unite humankind. But its own history has been far from smooth. Click the link in our bio to read Joan Acocella’s story on the fraught history of Esperanto. Illustration by @miguelporlan.
A cartoon by Bob Eckstein, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Argentina’s notoriously polluted Riachuelo River is a toxic place to call home, but five million people still do. Pictured here are Maite and Bianca, five-year-old twins who cross the Riachuelo every day to go to school in Buenos Aires. Click the link in our bio to see @akirchuk's photographs of life along a poisoned river.

At The Astor Room, patrons have been known to complain about a woman smoking with a vintage cigarette holder in the ladies’ bathroom—she inevitably disappears on second glance. Click the link in our bio to read @weitchou's review of the bar located underneath Kaufman Astoria Studios, in Queens, N.Y.C. Illustration by Jorge Colombo.

At @luckybeenyc, start with the grilled whole shrimp, work your way to the coconut-poached crab meat, but leave room for the braised short ribs cooked in coconut milk with lemongrass and galangal. Click the link in our bio to read @jiayangfan’s review of a farm-to-table restaurant’s unconventional take on Thai street food. Photograph by @meredithjenks for The New Yorker.
A cartoon by John McNamee. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

What gives a country the right to control its borders? Click the link in our bio to read Kelefa Sanneh’s nuanced exploration of immigration that goes beyond walls, resettlement, borders, and bridges. Illustration by @staufferstudio.
Practice matters, but in many fields it matters much less than you might think. Click the link in our bio to read Maria Konnikova’s post on why practice doesn’t make perfect. Illustration by @wr3nm.

Subscribe to The New Yorker today, and get 12 issues for just $12. Visit the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com. Cover by Frank Viva. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Trevor Spaulding, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more #TNYcartoons.
A cartoon by Liam Francis Walsh, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

PAID POST: Food carts, market stands, roadside restaurants, and neighborhood kiosks—they’ve all been given a hand by @wholeplanet. One percent of sales of @WholeFoods’ Whole Trade products, including flowers, is donated to the foundation, which has funded nearly 1.5 million microloans for entrepreneurs worldwide. Illustration by @danbransfield.

If you pitched the idea of a single currency to a class in Economics 101, there would be an embarrassed pause, and eventually and someone would ask, “Is that even possible?” The answer: “Nobody knows.” Click the link in our bio to read about the failure of the euro. Illustration by David Plunkert.
A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
“Westworld” is explicitly, and often wittily, an exploitation series about exploitation. Click the link in our bio to read Emily Nussbaum’s story on the meta-politics of HBO’s new drama. #westworld
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more.

At Pondicheri, you can sit in the airy café section drinking an iced Assam tea, and then order a roasted quail stuffed with pine nuts for dinner. Click the link in our bio to read about the new restaurant and “bake lab.” Photograph by @will_mebane.

“The sad part is that getting an innocent man out of jail is way, way, way harder than putting a guilty man in jail.” Click the link in our bio to read Stephanie Clifford’s story on an ex-cop rethinking a wrong arrest he made, one that cost an apparently innocent man twenty years of his life. Illustration by @annaparini.

An early look at next week's cover, “Significant Others,” by Barry Blitt. “Both candidates seem to be in a loving relationship right now,” Blitt says, about his cover for the Politics Issue. “But it is worth noting that, in the event of a Trump Presidency, Vladimir Putin would be the first foreign-born First Mate since Louisa Adams.” Click the link in our bio for more.
A cartoon by David Sipress. Want more #TNYcartoons? Follow @newyorkercartoons, our account dedicated to drawings and drollery.

The American right owes its militant rhetoric to the ideas of a group of refugees fleeing the Nazis. Click the link in our bio to read Sam Tanenhaus’s story on how a handful of Weimar émigrés came to have an outsized influence on conservative ideology. Illustration by @erikinstanet.

The film “Moonlight” is virtuosic in part because of the director Barry Jenkins's eye and in part because of the tale it tells, which begins in nineteen-eighties Miami. By avoiding the overblown clichés so often used to represent black American life in film, Jenkins has created something achingly alive. Click the link in our bio to read Hilton Als's review. Photograph by Gabriele Stabile for The New Yorker.
@j.a.k._'s final #debate cartoon. Click the link in our bio to see more. #TNYcartoons
@j.a.k._ is live-drawing tonight's Presidential debate. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more. #TNYcartoons
#HillaryClinton at tonight's Presidential #debate, as drawn by @j.a.k._. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more. #TNYcartoons
@j.a.k._ is live-drawing tonight's #debate. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more. #TNYcartoons

Tonight is the final Presidential debate. If your eyes haven’t been burned out by the action, you should refocus them on @newyorkercartoons, where our cartoonist @j.a.k._ will be live-drawing the #debate. When they go low, he’ll go to the drawing board.

This week, readers sent us their thoughts on recent pieces, from what would happen if Donald Trump became President, to education and the porn industry. Do you want to chime in on a recent piece in the magazine? Send a letter to themail@newyorker.com, and we might publish it. Link in bio.
A cartoon by @wooden.nickels. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Everything about the Kerala Kalamandalam Kathakali Troupe’s show is colorful, wild. On Friday, Oct. 28, and Sunday, Oct. 30, the celebrated dance group will interpret a tale from the Sanskrit Mahabharata, as part of the White Light Festival, at Lincoln Center. Click the link in our bio for more information. Illustration by @ayakakeda.

The shrinking of Greenland’s ice sheet is triggering feedback loops that accelerate the global crisis—when water accumulates on the surface of an ice sheet, more sunlight gets absorbed, which results in more melt. Click the link in our bio to read Elizabeth Kolbert’s Letter from Greenland. Photograph by Daniel Beltrá.

What would Donald Trump carry around with him all day? In a series of illustrations, @broadcity’s @abbijacobson imagines stuff carried by Trump, Oprah Winfrey, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Kanye West, and Prince. Click the link in our bio to see more.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons

PAID POST: At Agrocoex flower farm in Cotopaxi, Ecuador, where roses abound, @wholefoods helped fund more than 100 affordable homes for workers—a community project selected by the workers themselves. Click the link in the bio to learn more. Illustration by @danbransfield.

“It is cold and it is pitch-black. Blacker when he opens his eyes, blacker than it was when they were closed—a stunning nothingness.” Click the link in our bio to read Cynan Jones's short story "The Edge of the Shoal." Illustration by @emilianoponzi.

The tavern The Ear Inn was born in 1977, when the building, previously owned by James Brown, an African-American tobacconist who fought in the Revolutionary War, was bought by its current owners. Click the link in our bio to read @stolincokes’s review.  Illustration by Jorge Colombo.

On @newyorkerphoto, the photographer @sarah_stacke is sharing images from a documentary project in Cherokee, North Carolina, that looks at the interplay between the past and present, the Cherokees’ deep connection to the land, and the everyday life that sustains twenty-first century Cherokee people. Pictured here is the Cherokee Fall Fair, held annually since 1912. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more. Image Courtesy of the State Archives of North Carolina.
A cartoon by William Haefeli, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Until very recently, the front of the new Greek restaurant @1633nyc was intentionally boarded up, in order to throw diners off. Now, even with the boards gone, 1633 continues to vibe, wonderful and strange, in the Upper East Side, a neighborhood not usually synonymous with risk-taking. The effect of the restaurant is as if David Lynch and Marguerite Duras had opened a Mediterranean saloon somewhere in Mitteleuropa. Click the link in our bio to read Nicolas Niarchos's review. Photograph by @amylombard for The New Yorker.

At eighty-two, Leonard Cohen has unpublished poems to arrange, unfinished lyrics to finish, and a new album out soon. Click the link in our bio to read David Remnick’s profile of the legendary musician. Photograph by Graeme Mitchell.

Ursula K. Le Guin says she’s not just trying to get into other minds but other beings. Click the link in our bio to read Julie Phillips’s expansive look into the life and mind of a writer who transformed the literary mainstream. Illustration by @essy_may.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons from this week’s issue.
In honor of #BobDylan, who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature today, an early look at next week's cover, "The Laureate," by @malikafavre. #TNYcovers

#BobDylan has been awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature. "Wiry, tense, and boyish, Dylan looks and acts like a fusion of Huck Finn and a young Woody Guthrie," Nat Hentoff wrote in 1964. Click the link in our bio to read the piece. Photograph by Ted Russell / Polaris.

Few places are less conducive to erotic optimism than the packed waiting room of a public health clinic in Brooklyn, which is where Emily Witt begins her sexual journey in the book “Future Sex.” Click the link in our bio to read Alexandra Schwartz's story. Illustration by @olimpiazagnoli.
A cartoon by Edward Koren. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more #TNYcartoons.

Condemned as a "purveyor of high-toned horror stories,” Shirley Jackson never got the recognition she deserves. Click the link in our bio to read Zoë Heller’s story on a new biography of one of the twentieth century’s most tortured writers. Illustration by @cristianacouceiro.

Rachel Weisz’s performances often create a hunger in her audiences; we want to know more about what’s behind the mysteries and intimacies that her characters let us into and then turn away from. Weisz returns to the stage as Susan Traherne in David Hare’s 1978 play, “Plenty” (at the Public, through Nov. 20). Click the link in our bio to read more from Hilton Als. Illustration by Pierre Mornet.

After Hurricane Matthew, as rescuers in the Carolinas worked to bring people and animals stranded by the storm to safety, and residents began to survey the damage to their homes and property, the photographer Bryan Anselm travelled along the South Carolina coast to capture scenes of life in the aftermath of the storm. Here, a magnolia tree that was damaged by the storm. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Bryan Anselm/Redux.
A cartoon by Shannon Wheeler, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“These window-walls remind me that I am trapped, unable to go to the coffee shop across the street or to the gym.” Click the link in our bio to read Taylor Elizabeth Eldridge’s account of being placed on round-the-clock suicide watch. Illustration by @rrebekkaa.

Susan Sontag, photographed in 1975 by Peter Hujar, who saw his subjects with an understanding that was beyond words. Click the link in our bio to read Vince Aletti’s story on the photographer who intuitively understood the rhythms, nuances, pleasures, and pitfalls of downtown New York. Copyright the Peter Hujar Archive, LLC; Courtesy Pace/MacGill Gallery.

Running Donald Trump's campaign is like being the drummer in Spinal Tap: those who take the position tend to disappear in mysterious circumstances. Kellyanne Conway, his third campaign manager, has been lauded as the “Trump whisperer.” Can she save the Republican Presidential candidate from himself? Click the link in our bio to read Ryan Lizza’s story "Kellyanne Conway’s Political Machinations.” Illustration by Barry Blitt.
A cartoon by Amy Hwang, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

R. Kikuo Johnson, who drew this week’s cover, “The Finish Line," seldom goes to the gym. “I prefer to cycle everywhere to get my exercise,” he says. But he was still able to find inspiration for his cover for this week’s Fall Books Issue in his daily life: “I don’t have much time to read, but I listen to books on tape or podcasts while I draw.” Click the link in our bio to read more. #TNYcovers
Tonight, Edward Steed was live-drawing the Presidential #debate. Click the link in our bio to see more. @newyorkercartoons
Hillary Clinton at the second Presidential #debate, by Edward Steed. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more.
Tonight's #debate, as depicted by Edward Steed. @newyorkercartoons
New Yorker cartoonist Edward Steed is live-drawing tonight's #debate. #regram @newyorkercartoons
@keeganmic at #TNYfest this weekend. Photograph by Anna Webber / Getty for The New Yorker.
@sarahkatesilverman joined Andy Borowitz at the New Yorker Festival. Follow along with our hashtag, #TNYfest. Photograph by Thos Robinson / Getty for The New Yorker.
“Whatever the fuck I choose to do on stage is my show. And if it sucks people will stop coming, and I will suffer the consequences." Last night, Father John Misty joined @trmmll at #TNYfest.

"To this day, ‘Superbad’ is probably the best script I’ve ever read. It just was so funny and filled with so much life. I get really nostalgic when I look at that," #JonahHill says. Today, he spoke to David Remnick at #TNYfest. Click the link in our bio to buy tickets for Sunday's events. Photograph by Thos Robinson / Getty for The New Yorker.

In high school, @andrewbirdmusic's friends listened to goth music. "I didn't care for that. I preferred Dvorak and Mozart's Requiem. Old-school goth." Last night, he joined Atul Gawande at the New Yorker Festival. #TNYfest Photograph by Thos Robinson / Getty for The New Yorker.

How does #DavidLetterman spend his time? “Most of the day I sit around waiting for 'Ellen' to come on." Last night, he joined Susan Morrison at the New Yorker Festival. Follow along with our hashtag, #TNYfest. Photograph by Ilya Savenok / Getty for The New Yorker.

Cartoons for the weekend:
A cartoon by John Klossner, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.
Today, at the New Yorker Festival, Bruce @Springsteen spoke with David Remnick about his music, family, and politics. #TNYfest Photograph by Anna Webber / Getty for The New Yorker.
The seventeenth annual New Yorker Festival begins tonight, in New York City. Click the link in our bio to purchase tickets, or follow along using our hashtag, #TNYfest.

Olmsted, the new garden-to-table eatery in Prospect Heights, is an urban sanctuary. Click the link in our bio to read about the restaurant where the food is put-down-your-fork, close-your-eyes good. Photograph by @adamgolfer.

What lies beneath the dreamy, hyper-feminine aesthetic of @petrafcollins? Click the link in our bio to read Lizzie Widdicombe’s profile of the photographer, model, and 'It' Girl. Illustration by @rebeccaclarke.

It would take black Americans two hundred and twenty-eight years to have as much wealth as white Americans have today. Click the link in our bio to read James Surowiecki's piece on the widening racial wealth divide. Illustration by @capitangallardo.
A cartoon by @zkanin. Want more #TNYcartoons? Follow @newyorkercartoons, our account dedicated to drawings and drollery.

@amyschumer has to circumnavigate her own intelligence in order to make the character “Amy Schumer” come to life. Instead of gagging on her life to pleasure her internal dude, she should feast on it. Click the link in our bio to read Hilton Als's "The Limits of Perversity in Amy Schumer’s Standup." Illustration by @vanderyacht.

Juno is yet another ride-hailing app, but its entire business model centers on getting drivers to defect from its rivals. Click the link in our bio to read Sheelah Kolhatkar’s story on the app that took what Uber created and appropriated it. Illustration by @sebastienplassard.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Jonah Hill has starred in “Moneyball,” “The Wolf of Wall Street,” and, most recently, “War Dogs.” On October 8th, at the New Yorker Festival, he will be in conversation with David Remnick. Don't miss it. Click the link in our bio to purchase tickets. Photograph by Steve Granitz / Getty.
A cartoon by Edward Steed. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

West Virginia is now a red state, but until 2000 it was tenaciously blue. For this election, it solidly belongs to #DonaldTrump. Many West Virginians treat the Republican Presidential candidate like family, brushing off the things he says that sound nuts or that they don't agree with. Click the link in our bio to read Larissa MacFarquhar's story "In the Heart of Trump Country." Photograph by @littlebrownmushroom / Magnum for The New Yorker.
Our annual Money Issue includes pieces about the ride-hailing app Juno, Sweden becoming cashless, Y Combinator’s Sam Altman, and the heart of Trump Country. Click the link in our bio for more.
A cartoon by @drawnbytom. See more #TNYcartoons on @newyorkercartoons.

Alt-glam scenester @harinef finds it exhausting to talk about her identity all the time. Click the link in our bio to read Michael Schulman’s Profile of the the trans model who's still learning to straddle advocacy with stardom. Photograph by @brianvu.

Tracks Raw Bar and Grill bar offers a warm welcome and a vast drink list to people headed home to Long Island or New Jersey. Click the link in our bio to read @weitchou's review of the unpretentious oyster bar in Penn Station. Illustration by Jorge Colombo.
A cartoon by @mecharliehankin. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

On October 7th, join entrepreneurs, scientists, and thinkers at the New Yorker TechFest to explore how technology is changing our society. Click the link in our bio to register. Illustration by @olimpiazagnoli. #TNYtechfest

For ambitious young men in the early heyday of American idealism, utopia schemes were the apps of their day. Click the link in our bio to read Akash Kapur's story on two new books that explore the history of utopian communities in America. Illustration by @goldencosmos.

“Vegan” evokes two images: judgment for abstemious virtue or scarcity on meat-centric menus. Neither happens at the new West Village restaurant @ladybird_nyc. Click the link in our bio to read @jiayangfan's review. Photograph by @erichelgas for The New Yorker.
A cartoon by Joe Dator. Follow @newyorkercartoons, our account dedicated to #TNYcartoons.

In August, Cardinal Jaime Ortega, of Havana, flew to Washington, D.C. carrying a covert letter for President Obama from Pope Francis, offering his support for the Cuba project. The origins of the project can be found in an intemperate remark made during Obama’s initial run for the White House, setting off what he described as “one of the first big hubbubs in my Presidential campaign.” Click the link in our bio to read Jon Lee Anderson's story “A New Cuba.” Photograph by Nicola Lo Calzo.

An early look at next week's cover: “She was the worst we ever had, the worst, the absolute worst, she was impossible,” Donald Trump told Fox News the morning after his debate with Hillary Clinton, defending his treatment of Alicia Machado, the former Miss Universe whom he called “Miss Piggy” and “Miss Housekeeping.” Watching the debate, the artist Barry Blitt recognized a significant moment in the Presidential campaign. Of all Trump’s dangerous beliefs, Blitt said, his misogyny “might just be his Achilles’ heel.” Link in bio. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Roz Chast, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Traces of real history are hard to spot in Antoine Fuqua’s reboot of the film “The Magnificent Seven,” but there isn’t much evidence of a real Western, either. You sense that an entire genre, far from being revitalized, is being plundered for handy tips. Click the link in our bio to read Anthony Lane's review of the film. Illustration by @bill_bragg_illustration.

@aliwong3000 performed in her stand-up special, “Baby Cobra,” while seven and a half months pregnant. Click the link in our bio to read Ariel Levy’s Profile of the comedian who’s not afraid to address the last taboo of female sexuality. Photograph by @stephaniegonot for The New Yorker.
A cartoon by Corey Pandolph, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons

PAID POST: You won't find added hormones in the beef sold at @wholefoods, even though the USDA permits them. This standard is part of the Whole Foods Market commitment to better meat, farming, and quality of life for animals. Illustration by @danbransfield.

A cover from the archive by @abstractsunday. Join us on October 7th for the New Yorker TechFest, when we’ll consider the evolution and future of technology. Click the link in our bio to register. #TNYtechfest
@jasoneight is the winner of our Instagram Caption Contest! Thanks to everyone who submitted captions. Cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz.

There has not been a liberal majority of Supreme Court Justices since Nixon was President. If Hillary Clinton is elected, that will change. Click the link in our bio to read Jeffrey Toobin’s piece on the fate of the Supreme Court. Illustration by Matt Chase.
This week’s cover, “Shift,” by Chris Ware. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Ken Krimstein. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more #TNYcartoons from this week’s issue.

Some call the photographer Bob Mizer a forerunner of Robert Mapplethorpe, but he was just as much the gay Hugh Hefner—a tireless collector of physical specimens. He photographed more than ten thousand men, many of whom did stints living on his compound. Click the link in our bio to see more.
A cartoon by Roz Chast, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons, our account dedicated to #TNYcartoons.
@Sallie.Krawcheck, the C.E.O. and co-founder of @Ellevest, will be joining us at the New Yorker TechFest. Click the link in our bio to see the rest of the day’s participants. #TNYtechfest

Ron Howard’s “The Beatles: Eight Days a Week—The Touring Years” offers rare glimpses of the band’s early years, which leave viewers shocked with excitement. Click the link in our bio to read Anthony Lane’s review. Illustration by @ben_kirchner.

Many dishes at Daniel Rose’s preternaturally elegant French restaurant, @LeCoucou_nyc, are not for the squeamish, or the dainty. Perfectly rare beef filet had a sauce enforced with bone marrow; on top were what one amazed diner could only describe as “globs of fat.” Click the link in our bio to read Shauna Lyon's review. Photograph by @francesfdenny for The New Yorker.

Caption Contest: To celebrate reaching one million followers on Instagram, we’re holding a caption contest, and we want you to participate. To enter, tag a friend and share your caption in the comments. We'll announce the winner on Monday. Cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz.

For one writer, the places on her phone's weather app became a portal to lives lived far away. Click the link in our bio to read Juliet Lapidos's story on reliving her travels through her weather app. Illustration by Goran Factory.
A cartoon by P. C. Vey, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

@davidchang recently wrote about his Unified Theory of Deliciousness. At the New Yorker TechFest, he'll expand on another idea: revolutionizing food delivery. Click the link in our bio to register. #TNYtechfest

Over the summer, Evan Osnos interviewed several dozen people about what the United States could expect from Donald Trump’s ﬁrst term as President. Click the link in our bio to read Osnos's story on what that would look like. Photo-illustration by @jiwiz.
