@heyparkerday's ongoing project “Icons” is a collection of portraits of d.j.s, models, club kids, and other night-life denizens. Visit newyorker.com to see more.

“The Mets are peaking at just the right time,” Mark Ulriksen says about his cover for this week’s issue. “Late Innings” is the rare New Yorker cover that celebrates the @Mets. (We have published many about the @Yankees over the years.) Click the link in our bio to see a slide show of past #TNYcovers that rejoice in America’s pastime—regardless of the team. #mets
PAID POST: High Standards = Quality Meat. All @WholeFoods fresh beef, chicken, pork, and turkey are certified by the 5-Step Animal Welfare Rating System. Illustration by @danbransfield.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The restaurants featured in Paul Freedman’s “Ten Restaurants That Changed America” serve as emblems of the racial, regional, class, and immigrant realities of America’s kitchens. But New York, like Paris or London, has always set the style for the rest of the country, which may account for the fact that six of the ten restaurants in the book were once New York restaurants. Click the link in our bio to read Jane Kramer’s piece “Dining Down Memory Lane.” Illustration by Greg Clarke.

This week, @thecooperrrr visits El Sabroso, a pan-Latin eatery in the back of a loading dock, and Acuario Café, where half a fried chicken and a pound of rice and beans is five bucks. Click the link in our bio to read about the hidden eateries in the Garment District. Photograph by @caitoppermann.

“I like and admire Hayley; she is a team player. I don’t judge. But I have of late been tempted to judge.” Click the link in our bio to hear Rivka Galchen read her short story “How Can I Help?” Illustration by @mcfetridge.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller, from this week’s issue. Want more? Follow our cartoon account, @newyorkercartoons. #TNYcartoons

In 1886, at the Statue of Liberty’s unveiling, it was brown, like a penny. By 1906, oxidation had covered it with a green patina, and people in positions of authority wondered what to do. Despite several rehabilitations and restorations, and other threats of painting over or polishing off the patina, the Statue has been left its own irreproducible color. “When you have the Statue of Liberty green on the brain, you see it all around you….When you look for the color, the city becomes an electric train set you’re assembling with your imagination,” Ian Frazier writes, in this week’s issue. “New York City’s official colors are orange, blue, and white, but its secret, sustaining color is Statue of Liberty green.” Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by Ben Wiseman.

Jessica Brillhart has directed numerous award-winning documentaries and films, including “World Tour,” the first V.R. film made with Google’s Jump camera platform. See her at the New Yorker TechFest on October 7th. Click the link in our bio to register. #TNYtechfest

At @kingtaibar, in Crown Heights, there are only five cocktails, named #1 through #5. But they make up for their minimalist names with elaborate flavor. Click the link in our bio to read @stolincokes’s review. Illustration by Jorge Colombo.
A cartoon by P. C. Vey, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Not all of Underwraps’s models are followers of Islam. Of the seven women on the agency’s roster, four are Muslim. The three of other persuasions—whom the agency founder, Nailah Lymus, calls “my modest models”—don’t cover themselves but are still discreet. “They might go out in a one-piece bathing suit, or boy shorts, but not a bikini,” she said. (Agency guidelines mandate that clients on jobs be provided with a single-sex dressing room, a full-length robe, and privacy from male crew members.) One of the models is an observant Jew. Click the link in our bio to read Judith Thurman's story "Modest Models." Photograph by @paridukovic for The New Yorker. @justinepurdue @tsukihair @splashlightstudios

The modelling agency Underwraps does most of its recruiting through social media, but the founder Nailah Lymus also sometimes finds potential models on the street—she will invite a young hijabi with striking looks to a casting call. Extreme youth, thinness, and height are not prerequisites for a contract. Ali, pictured here, a twenty-eight-year-old mother of two, is a soulful beauty, but she doesn’t have the figure of a clothes hanger. Click the link in our bio to read Judith Thurman's story "Modest Models." Photograph by @paridukovic for The New Yorker. @justinepurdue @tsukihair @splashlightstudios

Underwraps’s models have been hired for video and magazine work; for runway shows during New York Fashion Week; and for the annual “Hijab Fest,” in New Jersey, a cultural event and fashion show whose motto is “Own Your Identity.” The modeling agency exists to counter the stereotype of Muslim women as “oppressed,” the founder Nailah Lymus said. “Covering identifies us, but it doesn’t define us.” Pictured here is the model Savannah Uqdah. Click the link in our bio to read Judith Thurman's story "Modest Models." Photograph by @paridukovic for The New Yorker. @justinepurdue @tsukihair @splashlightstudios

Whether or not a model is covered, her beauty is on public display, and her job is to arouse desire or envy that a beholder transfers to the product she is promoting. The New York-based modelling agency Underwraps is seeking to dispel the idea that Islam and modern fashion are incompatible. Pictured here is Nailah Lymus, the founder of Underwraps. Click the link in our bio to read Judith Thurman's story "Modest Models." Photograph by @paridukovic for The New Yorker. @justinepurdue @tsukihair @splashlightstudios

On a torrid Saturday in August, while mayors in the South of France were busy enforcing a burkini ban that has since been ruled illegal, Jaharrah Ali, a hijabi (a woman who covers, in the Muslim tradition), was modelling at a photo shoot in Tribeca. Ali, pictured here, works for Underwraps, a modelling agency seeking to dispel the idea that Islam and modern fashion are incompatible. Click the link in our bio to read Judith Thurman's story "Modest Models." Photograph by @paridukovic for The New Yorker. @justinepurdue @tsukihair @splashlightstudios
A cartoon by Michael Crawford. See more on our #TNYcartoons Instagram: @newyorkercartoons

@naominailsnyc views nails not just as miniature canvases but as the scaffolding for ambitious and inventive micro-constructions. She has done @kendalljenner’s nails on both coasts and has added pierced black studs into @iamstevent's nails. @aliciakeys prefers short but eye-catching manicures, Yasusa says. Pictured here is nail art inspired by Wassily Kandinsky’s abstract paintings. Click the link in our bio to read Doreen St. Félix's story "The Face of Celebrity Nails." Courtesy Naomi Yasuda.
PAID POST: A new curve on your weekly reading. Introducing the #BulovaCURV watch and the world’s first curved #chronograph movement. @Bulova #newyorkerinthewild

Yvon Chouinard disdains ski areas, professional climbing, and extreme sports as programming and marketing. Yet his company, #Patagonia, made the idea of being outdoors look glamorous. Click the link in our bio to read Nick Paumgarten’s profile of the @patagonia founder. Here, he is pictured in Yosemite, in 1969, with climbing gear he made himself. Photograph by Glen Denny.

With his company, @patagonia, Yvon Chouinard made it look glamorous to be outdoors. But he is apprehensive about the world he created. Click the link in our bio to read Nick Paumgarten’s profile of the #Patagonia founder who turned his eco-conscious, anti-corporate ideals into a successful company. Photograph by @jfpetersphoto for The New Yorker.
@nas and Anthony Saleh, co-founders of QueensBridge Venture Partners, will be joining us at the New Yorker TechFest. Click the link in our bio to register. #TNYtechfest
A cartoon by Mick Stevens, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Alessandro Michele, @gucci’s creative director, looks at modern fashion with a historical eye. Here, he stands in his office, next to a brocaded chair that he found in an antique shop. Click the link in our bio to read Rebecca Mead’s profile of #Gucci’s renaissance man, @lallo25. Photograph by @davidemon / @davidemonteleonestudio for The New Yorker.

Gone is the @gucci of tastefully muted cashmeres. With long sleeves, lots of bows, even more embroidery, Alessandro Michele's clothes would make a Renaissance princess swoon. Click the link in our bio to read Rebecca Mead’s profile of @lallo25, whose Gucci is nothing like the sexy Tom Ford era. Photograph by Paolo Pellegrin / Magnum for The New Yorker.

"It is a little nasty and it is grotesque, but it’s beautiful," says the model @harinef of @gucci. Click the link in our bio to read Rebecca Mead's profile of Gucci's creative director, @lallo25, the man bringing color and costume drama back into couture. Photograph by Paolo Pellegrin/Magnum for The New Yorker.
A cartoon by Seth Fleishman, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons

Filmed in a gritty, low-key style, Donald Glover's new FX show, "Atlanta," explores a society that fetishizes ghetto cool but marginalizes the men who embody it. Click the link in our bio to read Emily Nussbaum’s review. Illustration by Richie Pope. #DonaldGlover

Bruce @Springsteen has joined the New Yorker Festival lineup. He’ll talk with David Remnick on Friday, October 7th, about—among other subjects—his new autobiography, “Born to Run.” Tickets go on sale this Wednesday, September 14th. Click the link in our bio to learn more.

“He explained to them, politely, that there were certain obligatory regulations, and they shot him.” Click the link in our bio to hear Robert Coover read his story “Invasion of the Martians,” which involves a Texas senator’s run-in with some undocumented immigrants from Mars. Illustration by Jason Ford.
A cartoon by Paul Noth. Consider the complexities of the digital world at the New Yorker TechFest on October 7th. Click the link in our bio to register.

The heart of Brian Rose’s new book, “WTC,” is pictures of the intact Twin Towers, photographs that are meant to reflect how the structures were viewed before they became symbols of horror and sacrifice. Click the link in our bio to see more of Rose’s photos.

Alan Moore is an artist committed to his own invented system of symbols and divinities. Click the link in our bio to read the full story on the graphic novelist, who, on his fortieth birthday, declared himself a ceremonial magician. Illustration by @rebeccaclarke.

Some think ayahuasca could change the face of Western medicine and heal civilization at large. Enthusiasts often say that each trip is like ten years of therapy or meditation. Click the link in our bio to read Ariel Levy's "The Drug of Choice for the Age of Kale." Illustration by @bjornlie.

When O'Hara's reopened seven months after 9/11, it became a haven for locals and Ground Zero workers. Today, it's still the liveliest place around. Click the link in our bio to read about the Lower Manhattan pub, where you can get a beer for three dollars. Illustration by Jorge Colombo.
A cartoon by @lizadonnelly. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more. #TNYcartoons

There are few Americans as affected by climate change or as dependent on the continued expansion of the fossil-fuel economy as the Inupiat in Alaska. Click the link in our bio to read Tom Kizzia’s piece on the whale hunters of the warming arctic. Photograph by @katieorlinsky for The New Yorker.

It’s hard to choose when almost every one of the ginormous sandwiches at Pisillo's, the FiDi hole in the wall, attains perfection. Click the link in our bio to read the full story on the panini place where Mayor Bill de Blasio is a regular. Photograph by @lrnlncster.

Today, @miamatangi released “AIM,” a record that she says may be her last. It’s worth taking stock of the way that the world and the music industry have changed since she recorded her first songs, more than a decade ago. Read @cbattan’s story by clicking the link in our bio. Illustration by @jeffelicious.
A cartoon by Sam Gross. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more. #TNYcartoons

A baby giraffe can stand within an hour of birth, and can even flee predators on its first day of life. A human infant can’t even hold up its own head. Click the link in our bio to read Maria Konnikova's story on why human babies are so dumb. Illustration by @wr3nm.

"I’m searching for poetry in the everyday,” the photographer Sally Gall said in a recent interview. Her photographs of laundry flapping on a line—which are the subject of a new show, “Aerial,” at the Julie Saul Gallery, in Chelsea—transform a domestic chore into a celebration of color and abstract form. Click the link in our bio to see more.

The protagonists of “The Light Between Oceans,” starring Michael Fassbender and Alicia Vikander, must be the first lovers on record to greet their blessed seclusion by adding more clothes rather than ripping them off. Click the link in our bio to read Anthony Lane's review of the film. Illustration by Bianca Bagnarelli.
A cartoon by @farleykatz, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“It’s not a new way to watch movies, or a new gaming platform. It’s a new medium. How often do new mediums come along?” Anthony Batt’s company, @onwevr, is at the cutting-edge of virtual reality. Hear him speak at the New Yorker TechFest on October 7th. Click the link in our bio to register. Illustration by @annaparini. #TNYtechfest

When the future of a restaurant depends on his words, how does a critic like @nytimes’s Pete Wells balance his power with fair criticism? Click the link in our bio to read Ian Parker’s story on the restaurant critic whose reviews create a national hubbub about class, money, and soup. Illustration by Luci Gutiérrez.

Child soldiers in foreign conflicts are not treated as perpetrators of violence but as casualties themselves. What about the adolescents in the drug war on the U.S.-Mexico border? In the book “Wolf Boys,” Dan Slater writes about two teens from Laredo, Texas, who became assassins for the Zetas, a brutal cartel. Click the link in our bio to read Patrick Radden Keefe's review. Illustration by Keith Negley.
A cartoon by Sam Marlow, from this week’s issue. Want more? Follow @newyorkercartoons. #TNYcartoons

Join us for the 2016 New Yorker Festival on October 7th, 8th, and 9th—three days of in-depth discussions, live performances, and excursions in New York City. Click the link in our bio for the full lineup. #TNYfest
A summer scene from @yamasakimariko. Thank you for sharing this #newyorkerinthewild. Tag us in your photos of The New Yorker, and we might regram you.

A cover from the archive by Eugène Mihaesco. Join us on October 7th for the New Yorker TechFest, when we’ll consider the evolution and future of technology. Click the link in our bio to register. #TNYtechfest

“It’s one of my few guilty pleasures,” Ivan Brunetti says, about going to the movies—the inspiration behind his cover for the new issue. “It’s a rare instance where I don’t mind being with people.” Click the link in our bio to read more. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Emily Nemens, from this week’s issue. Want more? Follow @newyorkercartoons, our account dedicated to drawings and drollery. #TNYcartoons

“Bruno had for his entire life associated backgammon with candor, the dice not determining fate so much as revealing character.” Click the link in our bio to read Jonathan Lethem's short story “A Gentleman’s Game.” Illustration by Alex Merto.

Wandelweiser is the name of an informal network of twenty or so experimental-minded composers who share an interest in slow music, quiet music, spare music, fragile music. The music of the collective is not for everyone. No music is for everyone, just as no language or no religion is for everyone. Click the link in our bio to read Alex Ross's story "The Composers of Quiet." Illustration by @tenreirui.

There’s an unusual alchemy happening at MIMI, and it stems from the chef Liz Johnson’s bold, visionary food. At first glance, the menu, written daily in the chef’s arty block-letter script and dotted with classical French preparations, reads like an ode to Escoffier. But many classics have been tampered with: pot-au-feu (of tuna), clafoutis (of corn), blanc manger (of coconut, with salmon roe). Click the link in our bio to read Shauna Lyon's review of the tiny bistro on a sleepy West Village block. Photograph by @meredithjenks.

This fall, #KanyeWest stages “The Life of Pablo” for the first time, including two nights at Madison Square Garden (Sept. 5-6). It’s one of the year’s most highly anticipated nationwide tours, as fans and onlookers await the theatrical antics that West characteristically delivers. Click the link in our bio to read Matthew Trammell's “Kanye West Is Back on Tour.” Illustration by @craigandkarl.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

At seventy-one years old, Bernadette Mayer writes on a blue Smith-Corona typewriter. Yet her poetry embodies the genome of Internet language: it’s slapdash, perceptive, sardonic, confessional, deceptive. Click the link in our bio to read about “Works & Days,” the poet's twenty-eighth book of poetry. Illustration by @rebeccaclarke.

The atmosphere inside Harlem Nights is loose and loud, augmented by an array of Southern-themed cocktails and a rolling soundtrack of Biggie and Usher. The bar is a monument to music and to easy living—the frame of a Weber grand piano has been nailed to an exposed-brick
 wall. What to drink? “The Weed Skirt is really good,” a server yells over the music. Click the link in our bio to read Nicolas Niarchos's review. Illustration by @jorgecolombo.

For his series “Falling,” the photographer @jfpetersphoto shot bodies vaulting toward the water below Sunset Cliffs, in San Diego, buffeted in the air by shards of coastal light. Click the link in our bio to see more.

Wigstock ended in the early aughts, but Lady Bunny, with her characteristic acerbic style, has gone on to create other terrific events, like her current show, “Trans-Jester.” Click the link in our bio to read Hilton Als's review. Illustration by @rrebekkaa.
A cartoon by @drawnbytom, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

At the age of five, @shayneoliver began making his own fashions out of scraps of fabric scavenged from his grandmother, a dressmaker. Later, he started cutting up items in his mother’s wardrobe. In 2006, he diverted the tuition money his mother had saved for him and launched #HoodByAir. The phrase suggested a style that was proudly ghetto and proudly élite (“putting on airs”). Within a few years, the label had become the most prominent high-fashion brand to have emerged authentically from street culture. Click the link in our bio to read @seeglazek's piece. Photograph by @jeremy_liebman.

Here, the photographer @jeremy_liebman captures @hirakish, one of @hoodbyair’s most charismatic new models, and @leilahworld, the C.E.O. of the company, at a fitting on the Lower East Side. The fashion world often describes the #HoodByAir aesthetic as “gender-fluid,” but Weinraub dislikes the term. In her view, it’s “not hot.” This week, Christopher Glazek examines the experimental label. Click the link in our bio to read more.

According to @hoodbyair, its sales have doubled every season since 2013. To date, it hasn’t accepted any outside investments—an arrangement that is virtually unheard of in the fashion industry. Pictured here, a model at a fitting on the Lower East Side. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @jeremy_liebman.

Rubber boots that have had their soles dipped in red liquid latex, at a fitting on the Lower East Side, one day before @hoodbyair's Pilgrimage show, in February. H.B.A.’s collections cannily combine the audacious and the accessible. Click the link in our bio to read @seeglazek's piece on the experimental label. We’ll be sharing more of @jeremy_liebman’s photographs throughout the day. #hoodbyair

In this week’s issue, @seeglazek looks at the rigorously experimental label @hoodbyair. One of H.B.A.’s founders, @shayneoliver, says that his designs explore what he calls “formalizing sloppiness”—highlighting the transitional phases between dressed and undressed. We’ll be sharing more of @jeremy_liebman’s photographs throughout the day. Link in bio. #hoodbyair

@shayneoliver, one of the founders of @hoodbyair, feels that some designers who appropriate streetwear have a fascination with urban men but are also afraid of them—he considers their skittish engagement to be “disconnected from the real masculinity” driving street culture. Here, Oliver is behind the scenes at #hoodbyair’s Pilgrimage show, in Manhattan, earlier this year. Click the link in our bio to read @seeglazek's piece. We’ll be sharing more of @jeremy_liebman’s photographs throughout the day.

The rigorously experimental label @hoodbyair has established a cult following among affluent teen-agers and pop stars like @badgalriri, Justin Bieber, and Kanye West. The brand, which turns hoodies and multipocketed jackets into avant-garde objects, has fans lining up for six-hundred dollar T-shirts with the H.B.A. logo. Click the link in our bio to read @seeglazek's piece on @hoodbyair’s radically aggressive streetwear. We’ll be sharing more of @jeremy_liebman’s photographs throughout the day. #hoodbyair

A cartoon by Alex Gregory, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons
 for more #TNYcartoons.
Should clothes do more than cover us? Billie Whitehouse thinks so. Hear her point of view at the New Yorker TechFest on October 7th. Click the link in our bio to register. #TNYtechfest

In Shouts & Murmurs: Your anxiety's fall TV lineup features several shows, including “Emotional Survivor,” in which you are stranded on an island with no water, no shelter, and no meaningful friendships that can withstand your fear of intimacy. You must remain exposed on a wooden plinth for hours in the hot sun and come down only to go to restaurants that your boyfriend chooses and that you secretly don’t like very much. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @sortofbutnotreally.

@yujawang.official is a piano prodigy who is known for the brilliance of her playing and for her dramatic outfits. Click the link in our bio to read Janet Malcolm’s profile of the gifted performer. Photograph by @paridukovic.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz celebrating #GeneWilder. #TNYcartoons

Do you want to share your thoughts about a recent story in The New Yorker? If so, we want to hear from you. Send us a letter, and we might publish it in the magazine. Letters should be sent with your name, address, and daytime phone number to themail@newyorker.com. This week’s cover, “Serve!,” is by @abstractsunday.
A cartoon by P. C. Vey, from this week’s issue. Want more? Follow our new account, @newyorkercartoons. #TNYcartoons

We’ve invented space travel, television, and the Internet, but we're still wrestling with the same questions as the Enlightenment philosophers like René Descartes and Thomas Hobbes. Click the link in our bio to read the full story on how aren’t as modern as we think we are. Illustration by @briancroninart.

Like starting a band in the sixties, or joining a cult in the seventies, taking improv classes has become a popular default activity for today’s postgraduate seekers. Last year the Upright Citizens Brigade trained twelve thousand students—that's about five million dollars in revenue. How did the U.C.B. build its comedy empire? @emmaewallen found out. Click the link in our bio to read the full story. Illustration by @hudson_christie.

At #TNYtechfest, on October 7th, Anthony Batt will discuss his company’s virtual-reality ambitions. Click the link in our bio to register.

“Having a drink in the hotel bar with Luke the Shuttle Driver is almost enjoyable, because it’s like an anthropological experience.” Click the link in our bio to listen to Curtis Sittenfeld read her story “Gender Studies.” Illustration by @pvanagtmael.
A cartoon by Tom Chitty, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

This fall, @abtofficial and @nycballet feature new works by female choreographers, and the choreographer @markmorrisdance curates an Indian dance festival. Click the link in our bio to see our Fall Dance Preview. Illustration by @cdaura.

At his eponymous restaurant, the chef Damon Baehrel serves as forager, farmer, butcher, chef, sous-chef, sommelier, waiter, busboy, dishwasher, and mopper. But you can't get in. It’s booked through 2025. Or is it? Click the link in our bio to read Nick Paumgarten’s story "The Most Exclusive Restaurant in America." Illustration by @squinkyelo.

In Manhattan, there are two broad varieties of Chinese restaurant: the assimilated uptown slickster and their no-frills downtown kinsmen. Now comes Hao Noodles and Tea by Madame Zhu’s Kitchen which offers Cantonese, Shanghainese, and Sichuanese staples and reinventions. It's a unicorn of a restaurant. Click the link in our bio to read Jiayang Fan’s review. Photograph by @christaanfelber.

On Saturday, @djpaypal, an electronic producer from Berlin, unleashes Chicago’s footwork at MOMA PS1’s Warm Up—with a T-shirt obscuring his face. Click the link in our bio for more information. Photograph by @mark_peckmezian.

To make a documentary about the Internet requires nerve. To do so when you can hardly be bothered with a cell phone, however, takes both innocence and bravado, plus a pinch of madness. All of which means that Werner Herzog, now aged seventy-three, is right for the job, and the result is “Lo and Behold: Reveries of the Connected World.” Click the link in our bio to read Anthony Lane's review of the film. Illustration by @leandrocastelao.

Michael Heizer began working on “City” in 1972. A mile and a half long and inspired by ancient ritual cities, it is made from rocks, sand, and concrete mined and mixed on site. Forty-four years later, the behemoth sculpture is almost complete. Click the link in our bio to read Dana Goodyear's story "The Earth Mover." Photograph by @jamie.hawkesworth.
A cartoon by @mattdiffee, from this week's issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

At a time when a pop lyric is only as strong as its potential to become an Instagram caption, #FrankOcean is a genuine misfit. His free-form lyrics are a no-hashtag zone. Click the link in our bio to read Carrie Battan's review of Frank Ocean's new project. Illustration by @siggieggertsson.

What happened at Attica in September, 1971? A series of accidents in a creakingly worn-out prison turned a modest petition for decency into a full-fledged takeover—one as surprising to the inmates as to anyone else—that, after four days, ended in a reprisal riot by guards and state police that left thirty-nine people dead. Click the link in our bio to read Adam Gopnik's story "Learning from the Slaughter in Attica." Photograph from AP.

A look in Melania Trump's diary, in Shouts & Murmurs: "Last week, I had brunch with Ivanka, and we stared at each other blankly until, finally, she said, 'When I made my speech, I just pretended I was talking about Hillary.'" Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @zoharlazar.
A cartoon by Edward Steed, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

For the music industry, cashing in on nostalgia is no longer limited to Rolling Stones reunion tours. Click the link in our bio to read @huahsu's story on how the return of bands like @dinosaurjr and @wearedelasoul is a reminder that yearning for the past shapes pop history. Illustration by @joshcochran. #dinosaurjr #delasoul

Curators have collected more than thirty-five thousand objects from across the country. Michael Jordan and Oprah Winfrey have provided funds. Ahead of its September opening, Vinson Cunningham goes inside the new National Museum of African American History and Culture. Click the link in our bio to read “A Darker Presence.” Illustration by @vincentillustrator.
With @netflix, Reed Hastings brought TV outside the box. Hear his story at the New Yorker TechFest on October 7th, in New York City. Click the link in our bio to register. #TNYtechfest
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Summer is “the season I most easily, and most happily, forget,” Vinson Cunningham writes. The blurriness of “Parking Lot,” by @anderson._paak, is why it suits the hot months so well. Cunningham chooses this as his Song of the Summer. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @andredaloba.

For years, the equities desk at Deutsche Bank's Moscow headquarters allowed mirror-trading: letting clients buy and sell stock to themselves. These transactions, often in billions of dollars, had nothing to do with pursuing profit. They were a way for wealthy Russians to secretly funnel money out of the country. Click the link in our bio to read Ed Caesar’s piece on the $10-billion scandal. Illustration by @annaparini.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

“I would love to become a child on the beach once again,” Jean-Jacques Sempé, the artist of this week’s cover, says. "It may sound infantile, but that’s the feeling I long for: to be a child without care, taking in the immensity of the ocean and still feeling safe.” Click the link in our bio to see a slide show of past New Yorker covers by Sempé that celebrate the pleasure of being at the beach—for children and adults. #TNYcovers
Tan Le’s company makes "brain wearables." Consider their implications at #TNYtechfest, October 7th in New York City. Click the link in our bio to register.

"Errol was not uncomfortable being led about like this, even onto an outbound vessel of dubious seaworthiness, but it did seem time to ask where they were going.” Click the link in our bio to listen to Thomas McGuane read his short story “Papaya.” Illustration by Robert Fresson.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Why waste away in Margaritaville when you can explore the delightful terrain of Margarita Island? This week, @weitchou visits this beachy cantina, tucked along Coney Island’s neon midway. Link in bio. Illustration by Jorge Colombo.

This week, Daniel Wenger visits Le District, a love letter to France amid the puce-colored marble of Brookfield Place, in New York City’s revamped World Financial Center. Click the link in our bio to read the review. Photograph by @amylombard.
A cartoon by Kendra Allenby, from this week’s issue. Want more #TNYcartoons? Follow @newyorkercartoons, our new account dedicated to drawings and drollery.

Sister Nancy’s reggae classic “Bam Bam,” which has been endlessly sampled, most recently on Kanye West’s “Famous," only grows more lustrous with age. Carrie Battan chooses this tune as her Song of the Summer. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @andredaloba.

With its slow drip of sorrow and trauma, “Stranger Things” is much more than a retro roller coaster. Click the link in our bio to read Emily Nussbaum’s review of the eighties-inspired sci-fi horror series. Illustration by @emilianoponzi. #StrangerThings

The final weeks of summer are packed with worthy options for outdoor moviegoing. Coney Island Flicks on the Beach concludes its season this weekend with “Donald Cried,” “Cabin in the Sky,” and “Creed.” Click the link in our bio for more information. Photograph by Matthew Pillsbury for The New Yorker (@screenlives).
To celebrate tonight's full moon, here’s a cartoon by @mickstevens, from 2010. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

We have all spent much of the season listening to Donald Trump, whose repetitive bluster evokes Kid Rock’s 1999 hit single, “Bawitdaba.” @jiatortellini picks this tune as her Song of the Summer. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @andredaloba.

For the past two years, @mitch_epstein has been making large-format black-and-white photographs of rocks and clouds all over New York City. In “Clouds #67,” above, the steel frame of the Parachute Jump, a defunct ride in Coney Island, seems to bridge the sand and the sky. Epstein’s show “Rocks and Clouds” opens next month, at the Yancey Richardson gallery. Link in bio.

Tonight through Sunday, Charles Dutoit, a suave, distinguished veteran, leads the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood. Dutoit’s conducting duties include a staged performance of Stravinsky’s theatrical work, “Histoire du Soldat,” tonight at 8:00 P.M. Click the link in our bio for more information. Illustration by @joooheeeyooon.
A cartoon by Edward Steed from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Hardly anyone used the Underground Railroad, but stories about it provide the possibility of moral comfort in a profoundly uncomfortable past. What do these stories teach us—or spare us from learning—about ourselves and our nation? Click the link in our bio to read Kathryn Schulz’s “Derailed.” Illustration by @leighguldig.

For our readers based outside of the United States: Get 12 weeks of The New Yorker for as low as $12, plus a free canvas tote bag. Click the link in our bio to learn more. Those interested in a domestic subscription can visit subscribe.newyorker.com. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.

This week, New Yorker writers are selecting the songs that seem to best reflect—or, perhaps, provide relief from—the summer of 2016. First up is Amanda Petrusich, who has found solace in “When Summer Comes Again,” an old-time fiddle track by the Lewis Brothers. We’ll be sharing songs of summer from other writers throughout the week. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @andredaloba.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. Join us at #TNYtechfest for more answers to digital-world problems. Click the link in our bio to register. #TNYcartoons

The defining talent of Florence Foster Jenkins was that she had no talent. Who better to play the incompetent socialite than #MerylStreep, whose plenitude of gifts has been an article of faith for almost forty years? Click the link in our bio to read Anthony Lane’s review of the new bio-pic directed by Stephen Frears. Illustration by Pierre Mornet.

@ivankatrump and Jared Kushner are an unlikely couple to represent the ticked-off populism that has emerged as Donald J. Trump’s Presidential theme. Read Lizzie Widdicombe’s piece in this week’s issue on how the pair came to have an outsized influence on Trump’s campaign. Link in bio. Illustration by Pablo Lobato.
A cartoon by @drewdernavich, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

“Like a lot of anxious people, I’ve been obsessively watching all the forecasts, predictions, and computer models, hoping for a break in this feverish political season,” the artist Barry Blitt says about “Donald’s Rainy Day," his cover for this week’s issue. “It’s finally looking like we may be getting some blessed relief.” #TNYcovers

As Obama has shown with his aggressive use of executive action, the power of the President is greater than ever. The choice of a President matters more than ever, too. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @abstractsunday.

Stewart Butterfield aims to change how we communicate in the workplace. On October 7th, he’ll join us at #TNYtechfest, where we will explore the stories behind the technologies that are radically reshaping our lives. Click the link in our bio to register.
A cartoon by Paul Noth. Want more #TNYcartoons? Follow @newyorkercartoons, our new Instagram account dedicated to drawings and drollery.

Today, we shared some photographs from an exhibition at the Central Park Arsenal Building featuring New York City’s pools and beaches. Here, Lauren Welles’s “Hanging Out, Coney Island,” Brooklyn, 2013. Click the link in our bio to see more.

Today, we're sharing some photographs from an exhibition featuring New York City’s pools and beaches. Tobias Hutzler’s “McCarren Pool,” Brooklyn, 2014, is one of the photographs featured in an exhibition at the Central Park Arsenal Building. Hutzler’s aerial photographs "hint at the enormous scale of the city’s aquatic retreats—fifty-five outdoor pools and fourteen miles of beaches,” Max Campbell writes (@vibefortonight). Click the link in our bio to see more.

Today, we’re sharing some photographs from an exhibition featuring New York City’s pools and beaches. In Wayne Lawrence’s “Kye, Kaiya, and Kamren,” "two girls with swim caps stretched tightly over their hair perch symmetrically on the knees of their father, who squats at the ocean’s edge. How many more years, one wonders, until they’re too old to hang out with dad and would rather strike out for summer fun on their own?” Click the link in our bio to read @vibefortonight’s post on soaking up the city’s aquatic retreats.

“SPF16: NYC Pools and Beaches in Contemporary Photography,” a collection of photographs from all five boroughs featuring New York City’s pools and beaches, is currently on display at the Central Park Arsenal Building. We’ll be sharing some of the photographs here throughout the day. Click the link in our bio to read Max Campbell’s (@vibefortonight) post on the exhibition, and to see more. Here, Tobias Hutzler’s “Coney Island, New York,” from 2014.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for a daily dose of #TNYcartoons.

On a recent spring day, Mary Karr was strolling up Ninth Avenue alone when an approaching guy chatting with a tall friend dodged at her to grab her crotch. Click the link in our bio to read her account of a shockingly casual case of sexual assault. Illustration by Rebekka Dunlap.
In his project “Windscreen,” the photographer Phil Jung reveals the lives of strangers through the dioramic worlds of parked-car interiors. Click the link in our bio to see more.
A cartoon by Liam Francis Walsh, from this week’s issue. Want more #TNYcartoons? Follow @newyorkercartoons for a daily dose of drawings and drollery.

Although many people dismiss the fig as a geriatric delicacy, it is a biological and evolutionary wonder. There are more than seven hundred species of fig, and each one has its own species of wasp, whose life cycle is intertwined with the fig's. When you eat a dried fig, you’re probably chewing on wasp mummies, too. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by Rui Tenreiro.

This week the photographer @_nguan_ is taking over @newyorkerphoto’s feed, sharing images from his series “Singapore.” “My photographs are about big city yearning, ordinary fantasies, and emotional globalization,” he writes. Here, he captures the vast development Rochor Centre. These hulking, rainbow-colored apartments and shops will soon be demolished to make room for a new highway. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.

Donald Trump claims that Mexico has not sent us its “best people.” But anyone with even a simple comprehension of the crisis that has befallen Mexico and much of Central America knows that he has it backward. Many immigrants from the Northern Triangle countries of Central America (El Salvador, Honduras, and Guatemala) who seek legal help are fleeing organized crime in their own countries. For them, low-cost legal aid is the difference between life and death. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by Keith Negley.
A cartoon by Sam Marlow, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

It’s almost like Olympic athletes don’t exist, unless they’re on screen at the Olympics. But they do exist outside of the Olympics. When the Games end, the athletes don’t end. Some go on to successful writing careers. Click the link in our bio to see more. By @weitchou and @work_emails.

Cobwebs and shreds of old floral wallpaper hang down from the walls like Spanish moss. Possessions stand in mounds and piles: old newspapers and empty food containers, boxes and bottles and bags. For the past ten years, an elderly woman’s home has been the subject of a photo series, “House of Charm.” Click the link in our bio to see more of Jessica Eve Rattner’s photographs.

In Daily Shouts, @blythelikehappy and @j.a.k._ imagine “Types of Guys I Would Like to Date, If Anyone Could Please Introduce Me to Them,” including a doctor who never talks about being a doctor. Note: must be a real doctor, not a dermatologist. Click the link in our bio to read more.

Bruce Davidson’s 1966 photograph of a campground at Yosemite National Park, on view in “A Cool Breeze,” at the Howard Greenberg Gallery, in New York City. Photograph courtesy of Bruce Davidson/Magnum and Howard Greenberg Gallery.

Two years ago, the composer David Lang wrote “Crowd Out,” a composition for “1000 people yelling.” Now comes “The Public Domain,” a work for “1000 singers,” to celebrate five decades of Mostly Mozart. Click the link in our bio for more information. Illustration by @celyn_brazier.
A cartoon by @steinbergdrawscartoons, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

Riis Park Beach Bazaar, in Queens, is a pop-up for games, featuring beachside tables that have attracted ringers like the seven-year-old Cole Weiner, above. It will be open weekends through Labor Day. For more information, click the link in our bio. Photograph by @thomas_prior.

The Pandering Pig serves excellent, simple fare in a slender space in what’s known as Hudson Heights, a pretty little enclave of shops, bars, and restaurants perched on the western shore of Upper Manhattan. Click the link in our bio to read Nicolas Niarchos’s review. Photograph by @samanthacasolari.

“How worldly was he, coolly inviting her to trespass on the grounds of his second marriage?” Click the link in our bio to hear Tessa Hadley read her short story from this week’s issue, “Dido’s Lament.” Illustration by @daviddoran_.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._, from this week’s issue. Want more? Follow @newyorkercartoons, our new Instagram account dedicated to #TNYcartoons.

Here, Felipe Araoz, a worker for Peru's Ministry of Culture, stands in the spot where an attack by the Mashco Piro, a group of isolated indigenous people, killed Leonardo Pérez, a twenty-year-old Matsigenka man. Pérez’s death threatened to bring about an open conflict. Following the killing, a squad of Matsigenka men armed with guns had pursued the Mashco in the forest. They found their camp, but it was empty, so they destroyed it and threw the Mashco’s arrows in the river. Click the link in our bio to read Jon Lee Anderson’s “The Distant Shore.” Photograph by @avelkaim.

Mario Álvarez is a local evangelical preacher who has tried to convert the Mashco Piro people. When he first saw pictures of them, he said, “I decided I wouldn’t leave this jungle until I embraced them and was able to tell them that they were not alone in this world.” Photograph by @avelkaim. Click the link in our bio to read more.

Pictured here is Nena, a Yine woman whose land was invaded by the Mashco Piro, another indigenous group in the area. Peru’s government has sent workers from the Department of Native Isolated People to engage with the Mashco in controlled contacts to discover why they are coming out of the forest, and to get them to stop their attacks. Click the link in our bio to read Jon Lee Anderson’s “The Distant Shore.” We’ll be sharing more of @avelkaim's photographs throughout the day.

Here, a boy from the Yine village of Diamante swims in the Madre de Dios River, in Peru. The Yine people are related to another indigenous group, the Mashco Piro, but separated by history. The Yine are the descendants of workers conscripted by the rubber baron Carlos Fermín Fitzcarrald; the Mashco are believed to be the descendants of people who fled from him. Click the link in our bio to read Jon Lee Anderson’s “The Distant Shore.” We’ll be sharing more of @avelkaim's photographs throughout the day.

Atalaya, on the banks of the Madre de Dios River, in Peru, is an outpost for adventure tourists. But a recent killing involving an indigenous group has threatened business in the region. A sign posted in the town warns against contacting or photographing isolated indigenous groups. Click the link in our bio to read Jon Lee Anderson’s “The Distant Shore.” We’ll be sharing more of @avelkaim's photographs throughout the day.

For more than a century, a mysterious people called the Mashco Piro had lived in almost complete isolation in Peru's Madre de Dios region. In recent years, small groups of Mashco have ventured out of the forest, making fleeting appearances to travellers on the river. Mostly, the Mashco approach outsiders with friendly, if skittish, curiosity. A few times, they have attacked. The latest attack, last May, took the life of a twenty-year-old indigenous man, Leonardo Pérez, spurring the government to send a team to engage with the Mashco. Here, a group of Mascho await observers sent by the Department of Native Isolated People. Click the link in our bio to read Jon Lee Anderson’s “The Distant Shore.” We’ll be sharing more of @avelkaim's photographs throughout the day.

According to one longtime patron, the beloved lesbian hangout Cubbyhole is “both temple and U.N. of the L.G.B.T. community.” Click the link in our bio to read Jiayang Fan’s review of the dime-size dive. Illustration by Jorge Colombo.
@Tinder is going beyond matchmaking. Hear more from C.E.O. Sean Rad at #TNYtechfest on October 7th in New York City. Click the link in our bio to register.

The imaginatively titled “Jason Bourne” once again finds our man trotting the globe in a bid to discover who he is and what he was and which of his passports to use. Will the poor guy never stop? Click the link in our bio to read Anthony Lane’s review. Illustration by @paulrogersstudio.
The 2016 Rio #Olympics start tonight. Here’s @kimwarp’s take on the Opening Ceremony. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The sheer density of the giggle-inducing animal puns in @bojackhorseman gooses the show’s more harrowing themes, as if Nathanael West had written “Miss Lonelyhearts” in puffy glitter ink. Click the link in our bio to read Emily Nussbaum’s review. Illustration by @benkalt. #bojackhorseman
Summer reading at its finest. Thanks to @charlotteparler for sharing her #newyorkerinthewild, featuring Frank Viva’s cover “Beneath the Waves.”
A cartoon by Roz Chast, from this week’s issue. Follow @newyorkercartoons for more #TNYcartoons.

The British rider Charlotte Dujardin has occasionally threatened the feudal niceties of dressage; she enjoys dominating a sport in which she frequently finds herself up against more gilded competitors. Click the link in our bio to read about how an outsider athlete and her once unruly horse created a new standard in the élite equestrian sport. Photograph by @tereza_cervenova.
In Shouts & Murmurs, by Ian Frazier: “Computers may one day be able to reason exactly as humans do, but will they ever be as dumb?” Link in bio. Illustration by Jay Daniel Wright.

"The fantasy is that learning a new language activates a latent alter ego, righting a linguistic version of having been switched at birth. Could I, would I, become someone else if I spoke French?” In this week’s issue, Lauren Collins reflects on learning about culture, communication, and intimacy in her husband’s native French. Link in bio. Illustration by @elenikalorkoti.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy, from this week’s issue. Want more? Follow @newyorkercartoons. #TNYcartoons

Gucci Mane (@laflare1017), who once boasted of being “geeked-up crazy,” is out of jail and embracing society. The rapper’s new album is the product of a six-day recording session and, you might say, a three-year writing session: as an inmate, he passed the time by composing verses in pencil on a legal pad. Click the link in our bio to read Kelefa Sanneh’s review of “Everybody Looking.” Illustration by R. Kikuo Johnson.  #GucciMane

Advances in tactile research are leading to out-of-body experiences: hugs can be exchanged across oceans and amputees feel pressure through prosthetic limbs. On October 7th, the New Yorker TechFest will explore the potential of this technology, and much more. Click the link in our bio to register. Illustration by @javier_jaen. #TNYtechfest

Back in 1993, Lee Lorenz drew the aftereffects of a certain Donald being everywhere. For more, follow @newyorkercartoons, our new account dedicated to drawings and drollery from The New Yorker. #TNYcartoons

Since “Bright Lights, Big City,” Jay McInerney’s focus has largely shifted from the question of sobriety (or the lack of it) to matters of status (or the lack of it). Click the link in our bio to read Adelle Waldman’s review of McInerney’s new novel, “Bright, Precious Days.” Photograph by Rick McGinnis, from 1988.
How can an employer create an upbeat workplace? By not telling people to be positive. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by Wren McDonald.

Today we’re launching @newyorkercartoons, an account dedicated to some of our favorite and funniest cartoons from ninety-one years of The New Yorker’s history. To start us off, here’s Benjamin Schwartz’s take on Donald Trump’s inner voice. Follow @newyorkercartoons to see more. #TNYcartoons

In the latest episode of “The Cartoon Lounge,” Bob Mankoff and his assistant, @stolincokes, discuss the perils of vacationing. Click the link in our bio to watch the video, produced by @nathanfitch. Photograph by @ekrhyne.
Paid Post: The all-new @JaguarUSA #FPACE—first-class treatment is standard. Cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez. #Jaguar #Luxury #MannerUp
This week's cover, “Something in the Air,” by Mark Ulriksen. Click the link in our bio to read about the artist’s inspiration. #TNYcovers

Game theory was once a tactic crucial to the U.S. military’s strategy for handling a possible nuclear showdown with the Soviet Union. Today, the notion of managing children with it seems appropriate to the threat level imagined by American parents. Click the link in our bio to read Amy Davidson’s “Parental Controls.” Illustration by Leo Espinosa.

The latest “Star Trek” film is a blast, alive to the comic awesomeness of being lost in space. Click the link in our bio to read Anthony Lane’s review. Illustration by @vincentillustrator. #StarTrekBeyond

This year, we’re introducing something big: On October 7, David Remnick will host The New Yorker TechFest, a one-day conference where our writers and editors will talk to the smartest people in tech about the technologies that are radically reshaping our work and our lives. To join them, click the link in our bio. #TNYtechfest

A portfolio in this week’s issue by @markseliger captures the trans community of New York City’s Christopher Street. Pictured here are D’Jamel Young and Leiomy Maldonado, both twenty-nine. “She’s a trans woman and I’m a trans man, so it actually makes us completely normal. I’m a man and she’s a woman, and it’s just as simple as that.” Click the link in our bio to see more.

In a portfolio in this week’s issue, @markseliger photographed the trans community of Christopher Street. Pictured here is Carmen Carrera (right), thirty-one, with her husband, Adrian Torres, and their daughters. “I wished I’d been born a girl, but that wasn’t my reality, so I thought I’m going to have to be a gay man. I started transitioning at twenty-five, when I was already successful in the drag-show realm. The gay person I thought I was started to feel like another character, and it was eating away at my soul. After that, my life truly started.” Link in bio.

Ni’Tee Spady, thirty-three, photographed by @markseliger. “I’m a masculine guy who loves women and I identify as a straight guy. I’ve been with the same lady for thirteen years. She was with me before my transition and during my transition. It wasn’t always easy. I went through my emotional things with testosterone. It was like going through puberty all over again.” Click the link in our bio to see more photographs of the trans community of Christopher Street.

@markseliger’s portfolio in this week’s issue captures the trans community of New York City’s Christopher Street. Pictured here is Bree Benz, fifty-five. “My wife and I separated in January of 2015. It was in March that I made the decision to start taking hormones. I did it thinking that I was still going to stay hidden. It wasn’t until July 1, 2015, that I thought maybe I can go full time—I use July 1st as my new birthday—and by October I was living full time as a woman. Am I happy? Yes.” We’ll be sharing more images here throughout the day. Link in bio.

"It was in the Village, on Christopher Street and the nearby piers, where many trans and queer people first shared space with others like them,” Janet Mock writes. In a portfolio in this week’s issue, @markseliger captures the trans community of Christopher Street, which is recognized as the birthplace of the modern L.G.B.T. movement. Pictured here is Tamia (Tiny) Carson, nineteen. “I always fantasized about becoming a woman. And then one day I saw my first transgender woman, on Christopher Street." We’ll be sharing more images here throughout the day. Link in bio.
The New York City bar @NorthernTerritorybk has at least as many Brooklynisms as stuff from down under. Click the link in our bio to read @emmaewallen’s review. Illustration by Jorge Colombo.

Disco’s revenge plot may be nearly complete. The honeyed vocalists, street flautists, and psych guitarists of the septet 79.5 will play at Bowery Ballroom tomorrow. Click the link in our bio for more information. Photograph by @paridukovic.
A cartoon by Roz Chast, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Paid Post: What’s the best way to bring up children? As a part of the modern world or completely off the grid? #CaptainFantastic, starring #ViggoMortensen, is the story of one father’s journey between worlds. Out now. @bleeckerstfilms

Dispatch from Philadelphia: Hillary Clinton has had low points in her political career. Last night wasn’t one of them. Her acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention made the connection between America’s diversity and its fearlessness. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @philipmontgomery. #DemsInPhilly

This week’s Shouts & Murmurs, by @stolincokes, features updates from your FedEx package: “Package spent two days trying to build up confidence to attempt delivery again. Cried a little.” Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @allan_sanders.

Hillary Clinton made history tonight by becoming the first woman to accept the Presidential nomination by a major party. New Yorker cartoonist @lizadonnelly drew Clinton while she delivered her acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention, in Philadelphia. #DemsInPhilly

Dispatch from Philadelphia: In the current political cycle, darker by far than any in recent memory, love-speech has been used to respond to ever more appalling eruptions of hatred. Pictured here are Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton at the Convention on Wednesday night. Click the link in our bio to read Rebecca Mead’s post on the power of “love” in politics. Photograph by @philipmontgomery. #DemsinPhilly
A cartoon by Alex Gregory, from this week’s issue. Click the link in our bio to see more. #TNYcartoons

On “The Author's Voice” podcast, Joshua Ferris reads his short story “The Abandonment”: “It was no surprise where he wound up. He hoped to find her there. How he loved her—her face, her smile. He took a deep breath and entered the lobby.” Click the link in our bio to listen. Photo-illustration by Blaise Cepis.
"Don't boo. Vote." New Yorker cartoonist @lizadonnelly drew President Barack Obama while he delivered his speech at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia. #DemsInPhilly

"The moment she walks into the Oval Office, Hillary will change our daughters' lives!" New Yorker cartoonist @lizadonnelly drew Vice-President Joe Biden speaking at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia. #DemsInPhilly

On President Obama's second day in office, he issued an executive order to shut down Guantánamo within a year. Now nearly eight years have passed and it remains open, at a cost of $445 million last year. Why? Click the link in our bio to read Connie Bruck’s investigation. Illustration by Brad Holland.

Dispatch from Philadelphia: A young boy holds a protest sign just outside the Wells Fargo Center on the first day of the Democratic National Convention. Photograph by @philipmontgomery for The New Yorker. #DemsinPhilly

New Yorker cartoonist @lizadonnelly is in Philadelphia live-drawing #DemsInPhilly. Last night, she captured members of the Mothers of the Movement, a group of black women who have lost children to police and gun violence, addressing the Democratic National Convention.
New Yorker cartoonist @lizadonnelly is in Philadelphia live-drawing the Democratic National Convention. Last night, she captured Bill Clinton during his speech. #DemsinPhilly

Netflix C.E.O. Reed Hastings realized that viewers had a “managed dissatisfaction” with traditional television, so he set out to give them more. Hear him discuss his methods of disruption at The New Yorker TechFest, on October 7th. Click the link in our bio to register now. Illustration by Leo Espinosa. #TNYtechfest
A cartoon by @paulnoth. #TNYcartoons #pokemongo

Dispatch from Philadelphia: A Bernie Sanders supporter walks through the stream of a broken fire hydrant in South Philadelphia during a march on Sunday. Click the link in our bio to see more photographs by @philipmontgomery, who is covering the Democratic National Convention. #DemsinPhilly

Dispatch from Philadelphia: On Sunday afternoon, supporters of Bernie Sanders marched down Broad Street in South Philadelphia, demonstrating their continuing opposition to Hillary Clinton’s Presidential nomination. @philipmontgomery, who is covering the Democratic National Convention for The New Yorker, captured the scene. Click the link in our bio to see more. #DemsinPhilly

Paid Post: What’s the best way to bring up children? As a part of the modern world or completely off the grid? #CaptainFantastic, starring #ViggoMortensen, is the story of one father’s journey between worlds. Out now. @bleeckerstfilms
This week's cover, “Beneath the Waves,” by Frank Viva. Click the link in our bio to read about the artist’s inspiration, and to see more #TNYcovers that celebrate summer getaways.

Though there is a terrific menu at the Brooklyn cocktail bar Seaborne, the bartender prefers to mix drinks inspired by your mood. Click the link in our bio to read @weitchou’s review. Illustration by Jorge Colombo.

In working-class America, an élite-resenting identity politics has emerged in which whiteness spells dispossession. Click the link in our bio to read Hua Hsu’s “Pale Fire.” Illustration by @doble_entendre.

Lots of people, many of them old enough to know better, keep believing in @blink182. Now in their forties, the band’s members have come to seem less like posers than pioneers. Click the link in our bio to read Kelefa Sanneh’s “Good Clean Punk.” #blink182

Covina, a California-Mediterranean composite in New York’s Kips Bay, offers wood-grilled meats and handmade pastas—well-constructed staples with subtle surprises. Click the link in our bio to read @jiayangfan’s review. Photograph by @jeremy_liebman.

The Andrew Lloyd Webber extravaganza “Cats” has returned (in previews, at the Neil Simon), and a lot has changed in Times Square since its heyday. Will an Elmo-Mistoffelees turf war bring back the old grit? Watch and purr. Photograph by @landonnordeman.
Today's Daily Cartoon by @kimwarp. #TNYcartoons

Dispatch from Cleveland: A scene from the main floor of the Quicken Loans Arena on the fourth and final night of the 2016 Republican National Convention. Photograph by @philipmontgomery for The New Yorker. #RNC
Today’s Daily Cartoon by @kimwarp. #TNYcartoons

Dispatch from Cleveland: Last night, the Republican National Convention made for great live television, Emily Nussbaum writes. “You couldn’t look away, even if you wanted to.” Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @philipmontgomery for The New Yorker. #RNC
From Daily Shouts: A Presidential poster of the now-official G.O.P. nominee, #DonaldTrump. Click the link in our bio to see more Presidential illustrations by Edward Steed.

Dispatch from Cleveland: In place of prominent economists explaining how Trump’s election would kick-start the American economy, we were presented with a golfer, a winemaker, the head of the U.F.C., and Chris Christie. Anyone expecting the presentation of an economic plan, or even a vague resemblance of one, was to be disappointed. Click the link in our bio to read John Cassidy’s “Magical Economic Thinking at the G.O.P. Convention.” Photograph by @philipmontgomery for The New Yorker. #RNC

Dispatch from Cleveland: For some Latino Republicans, the time to attract voters to Donald Trump has passed; the goal now is limiting the damage to other candidates. Click the link in our bio to read Evan Osnos’s “This Year’s Most Awkward Job? Latino Republican Outreach.” Photograph by @philipmontgomery for The New Yorker. #RNC

Election Sale: For a limited-time only, get 12 weeks of The New Yorker for $6. Click the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.
Dispatch from Cleveland: The photographer @philipmontgomery is covering the Republican National Convention. Click the link in our bio to see more. #RNC

Dispatch from Cleveland: A scene from the convention floor on the first night of the 2016 Republican National Convention at the Quicken Loans Arena. We’ll be sharing more of @philipmontgomery’s photographs from Cleveland throughout the week. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by Philip Montgomery for The New Yorker. #RNC

Each of the small protests across Cleveland earlier this week took place within a larger theatre of security and control at the Republican National Convention. In this photograph by @philipmontgomery, members of the Ohio State Highway Patrol stand guard. Click the link in our bio to read Benjamin Wallace-Wells’s dispatch from the streets of Cleveland. Photograph by Philip Montgomery for The New Yorker. #RNC
Today’s Daily Cartoon by @kimwarp. #TNYcartoons #RNC

This week, the photographer @philipmontgomery is covering the Republican National Convention, in Cleveland. Pictured here is a guest at the invitation-only kickoff party. Click the link in our bio to see more. #RNC
A cartoon by @zkanin. Click the link in our bio to see more cartoons from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

“I put lipstick on a pig,” Tony Schwartz, Donald Trump's ghostwriter for “The Art of the Deal,” tells Jane Mayer. In the 1987 memoir, Schwartz helped create the myth that Trump is a charming business genius. Now, speaking out for the first time, Schwartz calls him unfit to lead. Click the link in our bio to read the story. Illustration by @javier_jaen.

Dispatch from Cleveland: #StephenColbert makes an appearance at the “Rock the Night in Cle Welcome Party” at North Coast Harbor, which kicked off the 2016 Republican National Convention. We’ll be sharing more photographs from Cleveland throughout the week. Photograph by @philipmontgomery for The New Yorker. #RNC
This week’s cover, “The Fight Begins,” by Eric Drooker. Click the link in our bio to read about the artist’s inspiration. #TNYcovers

“SPF16: NYC Pools and Beaches in Contemporary Photography,” a collection of photographs from all five boroughs featuring New York City’s pools and beaches, is currently on display at the Central Park Arsenal Building. Click the link in our bio to read Max Campbell’s (@vibefortonight) post on the exhibition. Here, Rona Chang’s “Concrete Bathers, Astoria, NY,” 2011.
A cartoon by Zachary Kanin, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
Today, @nas headlines the Brooklyn Hip-Hop Festival—a Queens insurgency that Kings County won’t mind supporting. Click the link in our bio for more information. Illustration by @seemerch.

Dan Hurlin unearthed four unproduced plays by the artist Fortunato Depero in Rovereto, Italy. He is staging them at Bard SummerScape in New York, through Sunday. Click the link in our bio for more information. Illustration by @goldencosmos.
A Sketchbook by Barry Blitt, from this week’s issue.
A cartoon by Edward Steed. Click the link in our bio to see more cartoons from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
In honor of #nationalhotdogday, Wayne Thiebaud’s 2012 cover, “Hot-Dog Stand.” #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @J.A.K._, from this week’s issue. Click the link in our bio to see more. #TNYcartoons

In this week’s Shouts & Murmurs, by Colin Nissan: The ceremony will be officiated by a longtime friend of the groom, who will stammer through a meandering analogy about how love is like a boat, failing to convince anyone in attendance that love is even remotely like a boat. Click the link in our bio to read “Wedding Announcement.” Illustration by @simonemassoni.
Today’s Daily Cartoon by Kim Warp. Click the link in our bio to see more. #TNYcartoons

At a time when a lot of music production is an assembly-line process, in @mikewillmadeit’s sessions, jamming and messing around—ear drumming, you could call it—lead to happenstance and creativity. This week, John Seabrook examines the rise of the hip-hop producer who has created hits for @mileycyrus, Jay Z, Kanye West, @badgalriri, and @beyonce. Click the link in our bio to read the story. Photograph by @philipmontgomery.

How do you prepare for death? In this week’s issue, Larissa MacFarquhar examines the daily work of a hospice nurse, who treats the physical, psychological, and spiritual needs of people at the most vulnerable point of their lives. Click the link in our bio to read “The Threshold.” Photograph by Eugene Richards.
A cartoon by Robert Leighton, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

With Season 4, “Orange Is the New Black” made a risky leap, taking structural racism as its central subject. Read Emily Nussbaum’s review of @oitnb on newyorker.com. Illustration by Mikkel Sommer. #OITNB

Woody Allen’s latest film, “Café Society,” is another trip to a haven of the past: this time, the nineteen thirties, that far-off land where movies were movies, cars were like boats, and a guy could wear a suit the color of peanut butter and still look good. Read Anthony Lane’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Ben Kirchner. #CafeSociety
Thanks to @christenebarberich for sharing your #newyorkerinthewild. #regram

In this week’s issue, Kelefa Sanneh considers what the term “ghetto” reveals about attitudes towards changing neighborhoods. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by Javier Jaén; reference: Robert Carter / Getty.
This week, Shauna Lyon visits @nixny, a new, forward-thinking vegetarian restaurant that finds the joy in plants. Read her review on newyorker.com. Photograph by Zachary Zavislak.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

“Psycho-Cybernetics, A New Way to Get More Living Out of Life,” by Maxwell Maltz, on Penn Plaza. For more photographs of New York’s bookworms, click the link in our bio or visit newyorker.com. Photograph by @jonnotherattman.
“The Art of Memoir,” by Mary Karr, on Governor’s Island. Last year, the photographer @jonnotherattman captured the city’s final bloom of estival reading. Link in bio.
The New York Post, on Brighton Beach. Click the link in our bio to see more of @jonnotherattman’s photographs of New York’s readers.

The New York Daily News, on the steps of the Federal Hall, Wall Street. Last year, the photographer @jonnotherattman captured the city’s final bloom of estival reading. Click the link in our bio to see more.
People, in Central Park. Click the link in our bio to see more of @jonnotherattman’s photographs of summer readers in New York. We’ll be sharing more here throughout the day.

In this city, if you look closely, you can find New Yorkers with noses in books on every park bench, museum step, patch of grass, and subway car. Last year, the photographer @jonnotherattman captured the city’s final bloom of estival reading. Here, “A Sapphire Season,” by Lynn Morris, in Bryant Park. We’ll be sharing more photos throughout the day. Link in bio.
@astronomicks brought the essentials to the beach. Tag us in your pictures of The New Yorker, and we might #regram you. #newyorkerinthewild
This week’s cover, “A Day at the Beach,” by @kadirnelson. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Seth Fleishman, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
A 4th of July cover from the archive, by Jean-Jacques Sempé. #TNYcovers
Arthur Getz’s 4th of July cover, from 1966. #TNYcovers
In honor of Independence Day, our very first 4th of July cover, by Ilonka Karasz, from 1925. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @tbtoro, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

In Shouts & Murmurs, Jack Handey lists his favorite fireworks, including the Boom-R-Rang: “Light and throw, then run away from where you are standing.” See more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @andyrementer.

In Westeros, vulnerability is always a mistake: feel and you’ll get flayed. It’s the landscape’s only truly democratic quality, Emily Nussbaum writes. In this week issue, Nussbuam explores how the colossal, bloody, intoxicating series Game of Thrones became symbolic of America in 2016. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by Sam Bosma.

Danny Lyon’s photographs, now at the @whitneymuseum, document the civil-rights movement, a Chicago biker club, Texan prisoners, and more. Visit newyorker.com for more information. Photograph courtesy Danny Lyon/Edwynn Houk Gallery/MoMA/SCALA/Art Resource.
A cartoon by Pat Byrnes, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

The first sentence in the preface of Jean Edward Smith’s George W. Bush biography reads: “Rarely in the history of the United States has the nation been so ill-served as during the presidency of George W. Bush.” In this week’s issue, Thomas Mallon reads a new book that exposes the mysterious confidence behind Bush’s greatest failures. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by Oliver Munday.

@devhynes’s new album, “Freetown Sound,” is a wondrous tapestry of eighties dance and R. & B., shot through with questions about migration, Christianity, and black masculinity. Read Hua Hsu’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @adrianjohnsonstudio.

Celebrate July 4th with 12 weeks of The New Yorker for $4, plus a free canvas tote.  Visit the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.
A cartoon by Seth Fleishman, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons #coffee

This week, Alex Ross considers the weaponization of music, which has the power to cloud reason, stir rage, cause pain, and even kill. Read “The Sound of Hate” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @erikinstanet.

After kicking off the season with “The Marriage of Figaro,” Opera Saratoga continues with Philip Glass’s “The Witches of Venice,” an opera-ballet based on a fairy tale by Beni Montresor. Visit newyorker.com for more information. Illustration by @joooheeeyooon.

This week, @emserre visits @legaragebrooklyn, a standout new French place in postindustrial Bushwick, where the chicken for two is an ode to bird and butter. Read her review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @joaquintrujillo.
A cartoon by William Haefeli, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
A Sketchbook by R. O. Blechman, in this week’s issue, depicts the future of the New York City skyline.

For Anthony Lane, watching “Independence Day: Resurgence” was like experiencing a two-hour sci-fi extravaganza and getting his sinuses drained at the same time. Read his review of @independencedaymovie on newyorker.com. Illustration by @hoppeindustries. #IndependenceDay

@loicgouzer, a specialist in contemporary art at Christie’s New York, combines a mannerly European smoothness with an American-style bro-ishness. He surfs off Montauk, flies to remote islands to go spearfishing, swims with sharks, is an adept user of Instagram, and has made millions for @christiesinc by subjecting it to greater risk. Click the link in our bio to read Rebecca Mead’s Profile of Gouzer, who is pictured here with a @jeffkoons sculpture. Photograph by @jeremy_liebman.
A cartoon by @kuperart. #TNYcartoons

“Meridian (Gold)” is a new project by the New York artist Mika Tajima, in Long Island City. Visitors can sit in the sculpture—it looks like a hot tub, from which a geyser of vapor is rising. The mist changes color based on the fluctuating value of gold; computerized lights are fed data, in real time, from global markets. Photograph by @tobiashutzlerstudios.

What makes us engage in casual sex? Do we enjoy it? Does it benefit us in any way—or, perhaps, might it harm us? Maria Konnikova investigates, on newyorker.com. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by Wren McDonald.
A cartoon by Mick Stevens, from this week's issue. #TNYcartoons

At The Original Crab Shanty, you'll want to don the plastic bib provided, to mitigate the inevitable spatter of red sauce and lobster juice as you crack your way through thickets of snow-crab legs. Read Nicolas Niarchos's review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @dollyfaibyshev.

Hillary Clinton has made history as the first woman to claim the Presidential nomination of a major party—the Democratic Party. But it was the G.O.P. that first welcomed women into its ranks. Read Jill Lepore's "The Woman Card" on newyorker.com. Illustration by @abstractsunday.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

In the past five years, Assad's regime has assassinated, bombed, and tortured to death almost seven hundred medical personnel. In this week's issue, @bentaub91 examines Syria's war on doctors. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by @staufferstudio.

Lee Berger has made fossil finds that could represent new species of ancestral humans. Do the bones live up to the hype? Read Paige Williams’s “Digging for Glory” on newyorker.com. Photograph by @ilangodfrey.

An early look at next week’s cover, Barry Blitt’s “Silly Walk Off a Cliff,” which was inspired by Britain’s decision to leave the European Union. Click the link in our bio to read about the artist’s inspiration. #Brexit #TNYcovers
A bonus Daily Cartoon by @kimwarp. #TNYcartoons
Today’s Daily Cartoon by @kimwarp. #TNYcartoons

The canine in Todd Solondz’s movie “Wiener-Dog” is like a relay baton, passed from one character to the next. Read Anthony Lane’s review of the film on newyorker.com. Illustration by Guillaume Plantevin.
This year’s NY Phil Biennial was a tour-de-force survey of contemporary classical music. Read Alex Ross’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @matteberton.
A cartoon by Shannon Wheeler (@muchcoffeeman), from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
The New Yorker took on @esquire last night, for a night of softball in Central Park. Photograph by @jacksonkrule.

The photographs of a new book, “Magnum Cycling,” which collects more than two hundred shots of riding events, are unified in capturing something holy. Here, riders of the 1982 Tour de France are forced to take a break by protesting farmers. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph courtesy of Harry Gruyaert/Magnum Photos.
A cartoon by Emily Flake, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

In Shouts & Murmurs: "I see myself as Donald’s second First Lady. I hear him whisper to me, as he stands before the Senate during his impeachment hearing, 'Baby, you could lose a few.’” Read Paul Rudnick’s “Trump Is My Mr. Everything” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @jean_jullien. #DonaldTrump

In response to mass shootings, terrorist attacks, and talk of gun control, firearm sales have broken records. Evan Osnos examines how fear helps the gun business, in this week’s issue. Click the link in our bio to read “Making a Killing.” Photograph by @danwintersphoto.
A summer cartoon from the archive, by @christopherweyant. #TNYcartoons

It’s the first day of summer—are you feeling less productive? Recent research suggests that this season really does tend to be a time of reduced productivity. Click the link in our bio to read Maria Konnikova’s post on why summer makes us lazy. Illustration by Edwin Fotheringham.

This week’s cover artist, Frank Viva, originally conceived of a silhouetted couple last year, as a celebration of the Supreme Court ruling that legalized same-sex marriage. (Click the link in our bio to see the first iteration of the work.) He returned to the image in the wake of the shootings in Orlando. “It’s a celebration of love,” Viva says. “It’s just that simple.” #TNYcovers

The painter Stuart Davis’s ambition and ideals are on display in his retrospective at the Whitney Museum. Read Peter Schjeldahl’s review on newyorker.com. Here, Davis’s “Egg Beater No. 4” (1928): a concerted effort to transcend Cubism. Image courtesy The Phillips Collection.
A Father’s Day cartoon by Alex Gregory. #TNYcartoons #FathersDay
A Father’s Day cover from the archive, by Charles Saxon. #TNYcovers #FathersDay
A Father’s Day cartoon by William Haefeli. #TNYcartoons #FathersDay

In this week’s issue, @thecooperrrr visits Bar Omar, Williamsburg's cavernous extension of the French-Algerian restaurant Chez Omar, in Paris. Read her review of @baromar_brooklyn on newyorker.com. Photograph by @christaanfelber.
This week, Emily Nussbaum examines the sneaky radicalism of “Call the Midwife.” Illustration by @eleanorsvisions. #CalltheMidwife
A cartoon by @drawnbytom, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
A Sketchbook in this week’s issue, by Barry Blitt, depicts Bernie Sanders as “Icarus Descending.” #BernieSanders

By embracing tropes of traditionally male indie rock, @mitskileaks is remaking the genre in her image. Read Carrie Battan’s review of her new album, “Puberty 2,” on newyorker.com. Photograph by @matthewtammaro. #Mitski

New Yorker cartoonist @lianafinck practiced doodling upside-down yesterday on Facebook Live, adding a few animals to her cartoon in this week’s issue. Find The New Yorker on Facebook to see the whole video. #TNYcartoons

@sarahgertrudeshapiro worked on “The Bachelor,” where her task was to get the contestants to “open up,” “to give them terrible advice,” and to make them cry onscreen. A decade later, “UnREAL” is a diabolically entertaining drama based on her reality-TV experience. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @malikafavre.

Do you want to share your thoughts about a recent story in The New Yorker? If so, we want to hear from you. Send us a letter, and we might publish it in the magazine. Letters should be sent with your name, address, and daytime phone number to themail@newyorker.com.

Just in time for Father’s Day: Get 12 issues of The New Yorker for $12, along with a free canvas tote bag. Visit the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com. Cover by Danny Shanahan. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Amy Hwang. #TNYcartoons

Most of a day’s idle conversation is a sequence of thumbs-up, thumbs-down assertions that we don’t put a lot of thought into. “Nice weather we’re having.” “I love your new haircut.” “This coffee is suboptimal.” Why do we like what we like? This week, Louis Menand examines the mysteries of taste in the Internet age. Illustration by @javier_jaen.
