As Republicans struggle over whether to resist Donald Trump or to capitulate, they also face the Party’s biggest ideological crisis in fifty years. In this week’s issue, Ryan Lizza looks inside the G.O.P.’s Trump dilemma. Illustration by @dougchayka.
A cartoon by @mecharliehankin, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

From the futuristic experiments in László Moholy-Nagy's museum installations to his Dada-flavored photograms, it's hard to believe that he shared the same artistic era as Picasso and Matisse. Peter Schjeldahl visits a retrospective of the artist at the Guggenheim. Courtesy Hattula Moholy-Nagy / VG Bild-Kunst, Bonn / ARS, N.Y. Photograph: David Heald / Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation.
One World Trade Center shines tonight for the victims of the tragedy in Orlando.
Acknowledging the tragedy in Orlando. @thetonyawards are dedicated to this spirit. Illustration by @lizadonnelly. #TonyAwards
New Yorker cartoonist @lizadonnelly is live-drawing the #TonyAwards. Here, Lin-Manuel Miranda wins Best Score for his hit musical "Hamilton."

In August, 1974, as Muhammad Ali was preparing to face George Foreman for the heavyweight title, in Zaire, the photographer Peter Angelo Simon visited Fighter’s Heaven, Ali’s training compound in rural Pennsylvania, and took more than a thousand pictures of the fighter in the course of two days. Here, Ali is pictured during a sparring match at the camp. Photograph courtesy @reelartpress. #MuhammadAli
A cartoon by @paulnoth. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

It’s thrilling to watch performers who stand out because they have that indefinable something—a depth, a spark—that makes you feel alive, Hilton Als writes. In this week’s issue, he identifies two actresses to watch: Cush Jumbo, in “The Taming of the Shrew,” and January LaVoy, in “Funnyhouse of a Negro.” Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @wesleyallsbrook.
Thanks to @vaniamyers for sharing this lovely shot of our annual Summer Fiction Issue. #newyorkerinthewild
An early look at next week’s cover, “Ready for a Fight,” by Barry Blitt. Click the link in our bio to read about the artist’s inspiration. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by David Sipress, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

In her new works at the Fredericks & Freiser gallery (including the untiled picture above), Jocelyn Hobbie strikes an exquisite balance between riotous ornamentation and placid internal states. Visit newyorker.com to learn more. Image courtesy Fredericks & Freiser, N.Y.

Time and again, Diane Arbus crossed into her subjects’ territory—as a guest, a pal, a playmate, or an invader, according to your point of view. In this week’s issue, Anthony Lane reads a new biography that looks into how the photographer’s tumultuous chronicles of the country became unmistakably her own. Photograph by Dan Budnik. #dianearbus
A cartoon by Emily Flake, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

In Ben Lerner's story in our Summer Fiction Issue, a narrator accompanies an artist on a search to recover paintings left in an Uber. “She ran after the Uber, screaming for it to stop, until it had turned off her street toward Delancey.” Read the story on newyorker.com, or click the link in our bio to hear the author read it aloud. Illustration by Ben Wiseman.

Muhammad Ali, who died Friday, was the most original and magnetic athlete of the twentieth century. His story will long outlast the sport he took up sixty-two years ago, David Remnick writes. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photo by John Shearer/The LIFE Picture Collection/Getty Images. #muhammadali
Paid Post: Make this summer a classic with these six great novels for kids, and find more summer reads for ages 8-12 at summerreadingguide.com.
Today’s Daily Cartoon by @kimwarp. #muhammadali

Emma Cline’s début novel, “The Girls,” is a story of corruption and abuse in which a bored and groundless California teen joins a Manson-like cult. “Cline sees the world exactly and generously,” James Wood writes in this week’s issue. Photograph by @isabelmagowan.
A cartoon by Edward Steed, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
In our Summer Fiction Issue, writers revisit the books of their childhoods, and consider reading anew as parents. Read their stories on newyorker.com. Illustration by Gérard DuBois.

Korean barbecue has never been for the faint of stomach, but at @baekjeongnyc, it becomes a marathon for which untrained appetites may be at a distinct disadvantage. Read @jiayangfan’s review of the riotous barbecue joint on newyorker.com. Photograph by @meredithjenks.

Lost in the cult praise for Thundercat's multi-genre chops and studio wizardry is a potent secret weapon: the guy’s got a great voice. Tonight, he’ll perform cosmic soul at @brooklynbowl after Governor’s Ball. Illustration by @benkalt.
A cartoon by P.C. Vey. #TNYcartoons #NationalDoughnutDay

This week, @thecooperrrr visits the Brooklyn bar @yourssincerelybk, where all drinks are served in lab flasks, and the taps are porcelain doll heads, which stare like angelic witnesses to the evening’s festivities. Read her review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @juliarothman.
Today's Daily Cartoon by Kim Warp. #TNYcartoons

Some leatherback turtles swim more than eight thousand miles before eventually returning to the very beaches where they hatched. Dragonflies follow routes so long that they die along the way; their great-grandchildren complete the journey. How do they know where to go? Some scientists have a hypothesis. Learn more by clicking the link in our bio. Illustration by @natandrewson.
A Sketchbook by @richardmcguirehere, in this week’s issue, depicts different modes of modern transportation.

At the Piatigorsky Festival, in Los Angeles, experiments were encouraged: a renegade Italian cellist-composer led exercises in improvisation, and musicians played a Radiohead duet. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by Guido Scarabottolo.
A cartoon by Roz Chast, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

In 1966, the Japanese artist #YayoiKusama installed hundreds of mirrored spheres on the grounds of the Venice Biennale, accompanied by a pair of signs: “Your Narcissism for Sale” and “Narcissus Garden.” Now through the end of November, Kusama’s piece, sans signage, is swarming the pavilion of Philip Johnson’s Glass House, in New Cannan, Connecticut. Visit newyorker.com for more details. Photograph by @paridukovic.

#ZadieSmith’s “Two Men Arrive in a Village” is a kind of parable of political and moral corruption in which two outsiders terrorize a village while its “able-bodied men” are away. The women of the village, Smith writes, “stood in formation, arms linked the one to the next, in a ring around our girls . . . there was something especially moving about the pointless courage of our women at that moment, though it could not keep two men from arriving in the village and doing their worst—it never has and never will.” Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @richard_mosse.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

“The music was uranium, and those seven people, had they been super-duper spies, could not have known more about atomic energy.” Our Summer Fiction issue includes “Seven People Dancing,” a previously unpublished story by Langston Hughes, written circa 1961. Photo-Illustration by Noé Sendas.

In "Maybe It Was the Distance," Jonathan Safran Foer chronicles the struggles of an imploding Jewish family. Read the excerpt from his forthcoming novel in our Summer Fiction issue. Photograph by @mirkalaurasevera.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
“The Night Manager,” starring Hugh Laurie, is an elegant but ultimately empty John le Carré adaptation, Emily Nussbaum writes. Read her review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Daniel Stolle.

One can’t help feeling like a high roller at Leaf Bar & Lounge, sipping a Pineapple Express out of a copper reproduction of the fruit while perusing the terrific selection of Kavalan whiskeys. Read @weitchou’s review of the Queens cocktail lounge on newyorker.com. Illustration by @juliarothman.

At Urbanspace Vanderbilt, with twenty-one venders offering cuisine of all types, the choices range from chicken cheesesteaks, to non-G.M.O. gyros, to a tin of Spanish mackerel with a glass of rosé. Read Shauna Lyon’s review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @amylombard.

Nineteen-year-old @simonebiles has been compared to Michael Jordan, for her ability to escape gravity; to Michael Phelps, for the perfect match of her body to her sport; and to Serena Williams, for her total dominance. In this week’s issue, Reeves Wiedeman profiles the young woman who is changing the face of professional gymnastics. Photograph by @paridukovic.

Anna Magnani, who gained international fame in Roberto Rossellini’s Second World War drama “Rome, Open City,” overflowed with vital energy in comedy and tragedy alike. She is the subject of a Film Society of Lincoln Center retrospective, through June 1. Visit newyorker.com for more information. Photograph by Everett.

In this week’s issue, Laura Miller reads Yaa Gyasi’s début novel, “Homegoing,” a sprawling tale of a family split between Africa and America. Read the review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @jeffelicious.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan, from this week’s issue. Click the link in our bio to see more. #TNYcartoons

Developed in Japan, Hatsune Miku is a sixteen-year-old humanoid persona and pop idol who is touring North America for the first time this spring—as a virtual hologram. Visit newyorker.com to learn more. Illustration by @rrebekkaa. #hatsunemiku

In the early nineties, the photographers Ken Graves and Eva Lipman, a husband-and-wife team, travelled to thirty high schools to photograph an essential landmark in the educations of American teenagers: prom. In the midst of the adult formality and overtones of nascent sexuality, moments of blatant childishness—“the graceless qualities of youth”—are funny and bittersweet. This 1993 photograph was taken at Staples High School in Westport, Connecticut. Click the link in our bio to see more. #prom

In this week’s issue, Nathan Heller looks at trigger warnings, allyship, intersectionality, and what’s roiling the liberal-arts campus. Click the link in our bio to read the story. Illustration by Oliver Monday.
A cartoon by @tbtoro, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Paid Post: Women mean business. According to the 2015 State of Women-Owned Business Report, the number of women-owned businesses soared by 74% between 1997 and 2015. That’s more than twice the growth rate of businesses owned by men during the same time period. That’s a beautiful opportunity. Learn why at oppenheimerfunds.com
#TheRightWayToInvest

Before the Panama Papers, there was Hervé Falciani and his staggering trove of client data stolen from H.S.B.C. In this week’s issue, Patrick Radden Keefe writes about the computer technician who exposed the darkest secrets of the global super-rich. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by Moises Saman.

“Lemonade” is @beyonce’s bid to be a political artist without losing her commercial appeal in a world where pop stardom isn’t what it once was, Hilton Als writes. Click the link in our bio to read more about “Lemonade” and Beyoncé's “Formation” tour. Illustration by @malikafavre. #Beyoncé
This week's cover, “Commencement,” by R. Kikuo Johnson. Click the link in our bio to read about the artist’s inspiration. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Emily Flake. #TNYcartoons
At Hangawi, in midtown Manhattan, shoes are left at the entrance, and diners eat the perfect balance of food. Read Nicolas Niarchos’s review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @will_mebane.
“There’s something so sad-lady about the bath to me, so ‘Cathy’-cartoon.” In this week’s issue, Jessi Klein makes the case against baths. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @jean_jullien.

At Fat Buddha, in New York City’s East Village, the eponymous Buddha, swathed in mini disco balls, looks like a reincarnated bouncer who opted for an off-book route to enlightenment: namely, booze, hip-hop, and happy-hour pork buns. Read @jiayangfan’s review of the Asian-fusian ultra-dive on newyorker.com. Illustration by @juliarothman.
A cartoon by Victoria Roberts, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Camouflage “appeals to me because it’s nature’s way of confusing the things we see,” the photographer @simenjohan says. “We tend to look to nature for authenticity, but even here we encounter illusion.” Click the link in our bio to see more. Photo credit: Simen Johan, Courtesy Yossi Milo Gallery, New York.

For his project “Until the Kingdom Comes,” the photographer @simenjohan used subtle digital manipulations to push familiar wildlife imagery into the realm of the not quite real. Click the link in our bio to see more of his hyperrealistic images. Photo credit: Simen Johan, Courtesy Yossi Milo Gallery, New York.

“There are things which nobody would see unless I photographed them,” Diane Arbus said. Her subjects included Fifth Avenue matrons, Coney Island bathers, and children on the sidewalk. Ahead of the Met Breuer’s show of Arbus's photographs, The New Yorker this week offers never-before-seen images that highlight her artistic evolution. Click the link in our bio to see more. #dianearbus
A cartoon by Peter Arno. In honor of Morley Safer, who died today, we’ve collected some of his favorite cartoons on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons #MorleySafer
A cartoon by @zkanin, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

In this week’s issue, Emily Nussbaum reviews Bravo’s #VanderpumpRules: “It’s always easier to condescend to a reality show before you start watching it,” she writes. Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by Robert Risko.
Thanks to @avecruth for sharing your #newyorkerinthewild. Tag us in your photos of The New Yorker, and we might #regram you.
Today on Facebook Live: New Yorker cartoonist @j.a.k._ was in the office talking about his process—and live drawing dogs. Link in bio.
A cartoon by @tbtoro, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Get 12 issues of The New Yorker for $12, along with a free canvas tote bag. Visit the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.

“People come up to me all the time and say, ‘I just found out about you!’” @billyeichner tells The New Yorker’s Sarah Larson. “Part of me is happy and part of me is, like, Where the hell have you been?” In this week’s issue, Larson profiles the star of truTV’s pop-culture game show “Billy on the Street.” Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by Ben Kirchner.
A cartoon by Emily Flake, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Adia Victoria’s powerful 2016 B-side “Howlin’ Shame” lurches through foggy, spellbinding guitar and violin like the withered woman described in its lyrics. “That girl’s a ghost,” the country-folk singer gasps. She’ll pass through New York City on Thursday for a show at Mercury Lounge. Photograph by @shaedetar. #AdiaVictoria

Antarctica has the world’s richest marine ecosystem. How long before we ruin it? In this week’s issue, Jonathan Franzen recounts taking a luxury liner full of tourists to see Antarctica’s dazzling beauty and rare penguins—before climate change destroys them all. Click the link in our bio to read the story. Illustration by Blexbolex.

Do you have something to say about a recent story? We want to hear from you. Write us a letter, and we might publish it in the magazine. Letters should be sent with your name, address, and daytime phone number via e-mail to themail@newyorker.com.
A cartoon by David Sipress. #TNYcartoons

On a conference call, “any ideas told at length are as distinct as a voice mail from a friend who pocket-dialled you while skydiving.” For our Innovators Issue, we asked writers to tell us what invention they would uninvent. In “Call Me Crazy,” @carrie_rachel opts to do away with the conference call. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by Joon Mo Kang.

The Ship, on Lafayette Street, is where Captain Haddock would meet Tintin, if he trimmed his beard and had a loft in SoHo. Read @stolincokes’s review of the bar on newyorker.com. Illustration by @juliarothman.
A cartoon by @mickstevens. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

“When I first read about Governors Island, I thought, This is the coolest spot on the planet,” the Dutch landscape architect Adriaan Geuze tells @langealexandra in this week’s issue. Geuze’s firm, West 8, won a competition to redesign Governors Island in 2007. The new geography, which opens July 19, includes 70-foot peaks that crown a 40-acre park and frame 360-degree views of Manhattan. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @edosatwork.
@jilldanielle’s scrambled eggs matched a 2015 spring cover by Frank Viva, “Golden Hour.” #newyorkerinthewild

Are co-living startups like @hi.common and WeLive selling a revolutionary housing model, or an excuse for extended adolescence? In this week’s issue, Lizzie Widdicome looks at the companies that promise to transform housing through communal living. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by Harry Campbell.

At El Atoradero, in Brooklyn, even diners with the most abstemious of intentions are inspired to indulge in an artery-corking feast. Read @thecooperrrr’s review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @lrnlncster.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
An early look at next week’s cover, “Grand Illusion,” by Barry Blitt. #TNYcovers

In 2012, there were plenty of educational robots on the market, but Sphero stood out for the simplicity of its coding; unlike robotic cars or dolls, a ball was equally inviting to boys and girls. In this week’s issue, D. T. Max examines a popular robotic toy that is bridging the gap between analog and digital in classrooms across the country. Visit newyorker.com to read the story. Illustration by @jhonhersey.

The work of Namsa Leuba, who is Guinean and Swiss, resembles fashion photography at its most avant-garde. Her photos function as a comment, she says, on how the West perceives Africa—animals, the exotic other. On newyorker.com, Alexis Okeowo looks at @nataalmedia's African-photography exhibit at @redhooklabs, in Brooklyn. Here, Leuba's “Untitled I,” from the 2011 series “Cocktail." Click the link in our bio to see more.

“Oh, womenfolk, as we once burned our bras could we not torch the footwear crucifying us?” In the Innovators Issue, out this week, writers ruminate on one invention they would uninvent. For Mary Karr, that’s high heels. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by Joon Mo Kang.
A cartoon by John Klossner, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

“Audible Cloisters” brings a gaggle of guitarists to Fort Tryon Park, on May 14, for a six-hour marathon of fourteen free concerts spread throughout the hallowed spaces and gardens of the Cloisters. Visit newyorker.com for more information. Illustration by @krookedfingers.

Each weekend until June 12, the artist Duke Riley will tie little L.E.D. lights to two thousand homing pigeons and release them at sunset from a Vietnam-era aircraft carrier, docked at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Read more about “Fly by Night” on newyorker.com. Photograph by @geordiewood.

In recent years, @champagnepapi has grown perhaps too comfortable in a perpetual state of self-examination and light sadness. On “Views,” he bleeds onto the page and then admires the pattern. Visit newyorker.com to read Hua Hsu’s review of Drake’s latest album. Illustration by @stan_chow.
A cartoon by Trevor Spaulding, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Advances in tactile research are leading to out-of-body experiences: hugs can be exchanged across oceans and amputees feel pressure through prosthetic limbs. In this week’s issue, Adam Gopnik considers how new findings are shifting our understanding of human consciousness. Illustration by @javier_jaen.
A Mother’s Day cartoon, by Mort Gerberg. #TNYcartoons
A Mother's Day cartoon by @kimwarp. #TNYcartoons

This week’s fiction, by John L’Heureux, looks at different times in the life of the narrator: childhood, middle age, and old age. Read the story on newyorker.com—or listen to L’Heureux read it aloud on The Author’s Voice podcast. Illustration by @karinelaval.

Legend says Nazi troops buried gold, jewels, art, and weapons in the mountains of Poland. Seventy years later, the hunt for the treasure continues. Read Jake Halpern’s “The Nazi Underground” on newyorker.com. Collage by @rafafak.
A cartoon by @cartoonamy, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
At the bar Paris Blues, in Harlem, visitors are treated to Motown music and local beer. Read Nicolas Niarchos’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @juliarothman.

C. E. Morgan’s new novel, “The Sport of Kings,” explores how African-Americans have been forced off track, literally and figuratively, to the psychological, political, and material advantage of whites. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by Aude Van Ryn.

Some restaurants are comfortable, some are delectable, and a small number, like Brooklyn’s Santa Fe Grill, strike a genial balance between the two. Read Daniel Wenger’s review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @dollyfaibyshev.
Android users, rejoice: We’ve revamped our Google Play Newsstand experience. Click the link in our bio to learn more.

Luca Guadagnino’s new movie, “A Bigger Splash,” is fiercely unrelaxing, and impossible to ignore, writes Anthony Lane. You emerge from it restive and itchy, as though a movie screen could give you a sunburn. Read the review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @malikafavre. #ABiggerSplash
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

The scraping, hazy chamber goth of the singer-songwriter @cchelseawwolfe sounds a bit like Lana Del Ray brooding through Silent Hill. She returns to the @musichallofwb on May 8. Visit newyorker.com for more details. Photograph by @heyparkerday. #ChelseaWolfe

In Shouts & Murmurs this week, Simon Rich recounts the 1991 Foosball Championship of the Whole Entire Universe. “‘Coach cries a lot,’ observed Red Team halfback Donald Mursgard. ‘Like, pretty much every time we lose.’” Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @goranfactory.

Before U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara became known as the scourge of insider trading, he gained attention for the cases he did not bring against the financial industry. In this week’s issue, Jeffrey Toobin profiles the man who terrifies Wall Street. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @platon.

What feels new about TBS’s @fullfrontalsamb is Samantha Bee’s slash-and-burn, slightly gonzo approach to political satire. It has a hilarious, jagged energy—and it treats “women’s issues” as inseparable from the rest of politics. Read Emily Nussbaum’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @benkalt. #SamanthaBee
A cartoon by Drew Panckeri (@wooden.nickels), from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
“Stranger to Stranger,” Paul Simon’s thirteenth solo album, continues one of the greatest comebacks in pop history. Read Kelefa Sanneh’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @stan_chow.

Melania Trump appears to have taken on many of her husband’s habits, from his exaggerated statements to his signature pout. In this week’s issue, Lauren Collins takes an in-depth look at Donald’s Slovenian wife, who, if her husband is elected President, would be the first foreign-born First Lady since Louisa Adams. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by Barry Blitt.
This week's cover, “Regatta on the Hudson,” by Bruce McCall. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by William Haefeli. #TNYcartoons

Empire State Building, 350 Fifth Avenue. This observation deck, which opened in 1931, was known for its celebrity visitors, from Josephine Baker to Groucho Marx. In a portfolio in this week’s issue, James Sanders examines the long ascent to Manhattan’s observation decks, with accompanying photographs by @paridukovic. Click the link in our bio to see more. #empirestatebuilding

Cities Service Building, 70 Pine Street. This observation deck featured open railings intended to let in the breezes of the Upper Bay. Photograph by @paridukovic. Click the link in our bio to see more.

Cities Service Building, 70 Pine Street. The architects of the observation gallery in this 952-foot tall building created a luminous, airy space whose skylighted roof and perimeter of glazed French doors allowed visitors to feel as if they had left the city entirely. Photograph by @paridukovic. Link in bio.

Chrysler Building, 405 Lexington Avenue. An eagle gargoyle peers out below the 71st-floor observatory, which opened in 1930 and closed in 1945. In this week’s issue, James Sanders examines one of the city’s most distinctive architectural traditions: the observation deck. Photograph by @paridukovic. Link in bio. #chryslerbuilding

City Bank-Farmers Trust Company Building, 20 Exchange Place. Though open to the public for only a few years after its opening, in 1931, this deck and arcade offered a series of exquisitely framed rooftop scenes. Photograph by @paridukovic. Link in bio.

Rockefeller Center, 30 Rockefeller Plaza. “The rooftop observation deck is one of the city’s most distinctive architectural traditions. New York not only raised the world’s first modern skyline but pioneered a new way to see it: from a series of perches atop its highest peaks.” In a portfolio in this week’s issue, James Sanders examines the long ascent to Manhattan’s observation decks, with accompanying photographs by @paridukovic. We’ll be sharing some of the images here throughout the day. Click the link in our bio to see more. #rockefellercenter
@jaimiealexander stopped by our party on the rooftop of the W Hotel in Washington, D.C. Photograph by Dimitrios Kambouris/Getty Images @dimitrioskphoto.
@conniebritton joined us last night at the W Hotel in Washington, D.C., to kick off the White House Correspondents' Dinner weekend. Photograph by Dimitrios Kambouris/Getty Images @dimitrioskphoto.

Last night, Damian Lewis joined New Yorker staff writer Jeffrey Toobin at our annual party on the eve of the White House Correspondents' Dinner. Photograph by Tasos Katopodis/Getty Images @tasosphoto.

Larry Wilmore, the host of tomorrow’s White House Correspondents’ Dinner, joins David Remnick at our annual party kicking off the weekend in Washington, D.C. Photograph by Dimitrios Kambouris/Getty Images @dimitrioskphoto.

This week, @jiayangfan enjoys a dry pot—a sauceless medley of anything small enough to be tossed in a wok—at the spirited East Village restaurant @malaproject. Read her review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @jeremy_liebman.

At @bam_brooklyn, from May 4-7, a contemporary circus company employs a backdrop by #SalvadorDali for a show called “La Verità,” or “The Truth.” Visit newyorker.com for more details. Illustration by @dadushin.

This week on @newyorkerphoto, the photographer Ian Teh (@iantehphotography) is sharing images from his journey around China's Yellow River Delta. His project explores the delicate balance between development and the environment against the cultural backdrop of the Yellow River's own historical significance in Chinese civilization. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.

#NaughtyByNature's work has eclipsed the slang and styles it once documented. Now, only the universalities remain to be enjoyed. Tomorrow, the group will perform their fan favorites at Manhattan’s Stage 48. @trmmll has more information, on newyorker.com. Illustration by Cun Shi.

In this week’s issue, Siddhartha Mukherjee explores how the field of epigenetics complicates the nature-versus-nurture debate—a concept that is personal to him, the son of an identical twin. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @dayanitasingh.

In Shouts & Murmurs, @halliecantor and @j.a.k._ imagine a spec script for the rom-com “Uber Ex.” “An Uber pulls up, driven by Francis (Justin Long), Candice’s slacker ex-boyfriend. This comes as a surprise to everybody who hasn’t considered the pun in the title.” Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @timlahan. #uber
A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
Warsan Shire helped @beyonce craft the narrative of #Lemonade. Last year, Alexis Okeowo looked at the poet’s enthralling work. Click the link in our bio to read the story. Photograph by Amaal Said.

Michelle Dorrance (@mashdeez) is a tap dancer of gawky grace with especially quick, smart feet. In “ETM: Double Down” (at the Joyce, today until May 1), the virtuosic footwork of Dorrance and her affable company, @dorrancedance, triggers digitally produced sounds, bringing the rhythms of metal-tipped shoes into the age of electronic dance music.  Photograph by @hokaytokay. #tapdance
A cartoon by @bentschwartz, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Shortly after Harriet Krzykowski began working at the Dade Correctional Institution, in Florida, an inmate whispered to her, “You know they starve us, right?” In this week’s issue, Eyal Press presents a portrait of a deeply dysfunctional institution, where violence, retaliation, and retribution among the people responsible for maintaining order—the guards—was commonplace. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by Elinor Carucci.

Visit newyorker.com to read Alex Ross's piece on the Big Ears Festival, which unfolds every spring in Knoxville, Tennessee, and unites elements of classical composition, jazz, rock, folk, and electronica. Illustration by @hullophia.
Jon Favreau’s remake of “The Jungle Book” is technically astounding, but tames the call of the wild. Read Anthony Lane’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Guillaume Plantevin.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
Pool aficionados and Ping-Pong pros feel right at home at Ocean’s 8, a subterranean spot in Brooklyn. Read @stolincokes’s review of the bar on newyorker.com. Illustration by @juliarothman.

Americans use the adjective “dark” to describe a certain kind of comedy, where Brits prefer the word “grim.” Sharon Horgan, the creator of “Catastrophe,” believes the words “funny and grim” describe all of her work. Read Willa Paskin’s profile of Horgan on newyorker.com. Photograph by @garethwmcconnell.
The Puerto Rican restaurant @sofritonyc, in Harlem, is full of pizzazz and plantains. Read Nicolas Niarchos’s review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @christaanfelber.
A cartoon by @kimwarp, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Lights, Camera, Virtual Reality! In this week’s issue, Andrew Marantz speaks with the pioneers who are making the first virtual-reality narratives. Read “Studio 360” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @annaparini.

As a musician, @erykahbadu sometimes seems to be aging in reverse, embracing a youthful spirit that didn’t hold as much interest for her when she was young and dignified. In this week’s issue, Kelefa Sanneh profiles the Godmother of Soul. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @amandademme. #erykahbadu
In honor of Prince, who died today, an early look at next week’s cover, “Purple Rain,” by Bob Staake. #TNYcovers #Prince

Prince, who died today, was perhaps the greatest living pop performer. Today, we commemorate his mythic impact on music. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph via Michael Ochs Archives / Getty. #Prince
A cartoon by Shannon Wheeler (@MuchCoffeeMan), from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Jenny Hollingworth, 17, and Rosa Walton, 16, of the experimental-pop duo Let’s Eat Grandma, have created a closed-off musical world with their songs. They craft duets with spooky, childlike timbres. Click the link in our bio to see more. Photograph by @elizabethrenstrom. #letseatgrandma

@kodakblack, 18, a street rapper from Pompano Beach, Florida, has a mutinous sound. His young fans hear their own triumphs and missteps in his spare narratives. In our Entertainment Issue, @trmmll spotlights eight musical acts under the age of twenty. Click the link in our profile to see more. Photograph by @elizabethrenstrom. #kodakblack

In our Entertainment Issue, Matthew Trammell (@trmmll) spotlights eight young musical acts—all under the age of twenty—who are engaging pop in new ways. We’ll be sharing images here throughout the day, and you can click the link in our bio to see more. Låpsley (@musiclapsley), 19, is adding a gloomy streak to the landscape of ambient pop. She writes elegiac confessionals and sings with muted control. Photograph by @elizabethrenstrom. #lapsley

When state legislators try to limit L.G.B.T. rights, big business is their toughest opponent. In this week’s issue, James Surowiecki examines the corporate fight for social justice. Illustration by @abstractsunday.
A cartoon by @bob_eckstein, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

The brassy and shrewd ABC sitcom “black-ish” stands out for its rare directness about race and class. As the show’s creator, Kenya Barris, likes to put it, whereas “The Cosby Show” was about a family that happened to be black, “black-ish” is about a black family. Read Emily Nussbaum’s Profile of Barris on newyorker.com. Photograph by @michael_schmelling. #blackish
Congratulations to Kathryn Schulz, Emily Nussbaum, and William Finnegan, who each have won a 2016 Pulitzer Prize. Read their award-winning work on newyorker.com.
R. Kikuo Johnson's “Closing Set” is the cover of our Entertainment Issue, out this week. #TNYcovers

Paid Post: A.I. and robotics have come a long way from their sci-fi beginnings. By 2025, robots will be integrated into nearly every aspect of our lives. For investors, this means peering into the future and seizing opportunities that will redefine how we live. Gain a new perspective on tomorrow’s breakthroughs at oppenheimerfunds.com #TheRightWayToInvest

In Tables for Two, @thecooperrrr goes for a traditional Japanese breakfast at Williamsburg’s twelve-seat haiku of a restaurant, @okonomibk. Read her review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @erichelgas.

The posthumous release of J Dilla’s album “The Diary” serves as a metaphor for his unusual sense of timing and complicates his legacy. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @wesleyallsbrook. #JDilla
A cartoon by @drawnbytom. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
At Tomi Jazz in N.Y.C., Pocky sticks come speared into a milkshake glass glowing sapphire with Blue Curaçao. Read @weitchou’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @jorgecolombo.

“In the cherry blossom’s shade there’s no such thing as a stranger,” the great Japanese poet Issa wrote. If so, there’s no better place to meet new friends this spring than the @brooklynbotanic garden, where more than two hundred flowering trees are in fleeting bloom. Photograph by @paridukovic. #cherryblossom
In this week’s issue, Bary Blitt illustrates a New York primary diary. Click the link in our bio to see more.

In this week’s issue, Clive James, who is battling leukemia, describes binge-watching the most addictive show on television: “Game of Thrones.” Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by @jilliantamaki. #gameofthrones

Niki de Saint Phalle’s psychedelic sculpture park in Tuscany, dreamed up in an asylum, was the capstone of a tempestuous life in art. Read Ariel Levy’s profile of the artist on newyorker.com. Photograph by Peter Granser. #nikidesaintphalle
Get lost and find yourself in @Bermuda, a blend of colours and island magic, just 90 minutes away from NYC. #GoToBermuda
A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

Why break up with the Little Mermaid? #JesseEisenberg stopped by The New Yorker Radio Hour studio with his sister Hallie to explain. For one thing, all those thingamabobs can really clutter up a house. Click the link in our profile to listen.

The shape-shifting songs on @esperanzaspalding’s latest album, “Emily’s D+Evolution,” “leap between frantic spoken interludes, thumping art-rock hybrids, and intrepid jazz numbers that tackle subjects as opaque as theology and as knotted as beauty,” Matthew Trammell writes. Spalding performs tonight at the @apollotheater, in Harlem. Visit newyorker.com for more information. Illustration by Heidi Chisholm. #EsperanzaSpalding

Using a technique called “assisted evolution,” the researcher Ruth Gates aims to create a “super coral” that can withstand changing environmental conditions. “Our project is acknowledging that a future is coming where nature is no longer fully natural,” she says. Read Elizabeth Kolbert’s “Unnatural Selection” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Harry Campbell.
A cartoon by Seth Fleishman, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Get 12 issues of The New Yorker for $12, along with a free canvas tote bag. Visit the link in our bio to learn more. Questions? Contact customer service at 1-800-825-2510 or NYRcustserv@cdsfulfillment.com.

In this week’s issue, @bentaub91 reports on a dangerous operation to smuggle six hundred thousand pages of top-secret documents that tie high-level Syrian officials to mass atrocities in the country. This photograph, taken by Taub, captures the investigators Chris Engels and Bill Wiley inside the evidence room of the Commission for International Justice and Accountability, where each page is scanned, assigned a bar code and a number, and stored underground. Read the story on newyorker.com.

Acts of torture, murder, and detention under inhumane conditions in Syria have been widely reported by survivors but never before linked to signed orders from the country’s President—until now. Read @bentaub91’s “The Assad Files” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Mike McQuade.
A cartoon by Pat Byrnes, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
Thanks to @ariannapapalexopoulos for sharing this #newyorkerinthewild. Tag us in your photos of The New Yorker, and we might regram you.
This week's cover, “Luxury Coops,” by Peter de Sève. #TNYcovers

With his poetry, Stéphane Mallarmé planted a flag at an outer extreme of artistic possibility. In this week’s issue, Alex Ross examines how translators are confronting the supreme enigma of his poetry. Illustration by Hugo Guinness.
A cartoon by Michael Maslin, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
@davidchang flirts with Italian at his newest New York restaurant, Momofuku Nishi. Read @silviakillings’s review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @meredithjenks.

Tonight at the Music Hall of Williamsburg, the electronic producer Sophie stirs up artificially sweetened beats, like his bubbly, tongue-in-cheek track “Lemonade.” Visit newyorker.com for more information. Illustration by @kristianhammerstad.
The Up & Up bar, in New York City, is like “a dive that got a shave and put on a clean pair of slacks.” Read @jiayangfan’s review of @theupandupnyc on newyorker.com. Illustration by @jorgecolombo.

In this week’s issue, James Lasdun recounts hiking the Via Alpina, a network of five interlocked high-altitude trails that extend for more than three thousand miles and crisscross all eight countries of the Alps. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by  Domingo Milella.

This week on @newyorkerphoto, the photographer @albertbonsfills is sharing images of the blooming cherry blossoms in Tokyo, Japan. Here, the Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden’s visitors picnic in the rain. Follow @newyorkerphoto to see more.
A cartoon by @mattdiffee, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Emma, a domestic worker who migrated from the #Philippines, hasn’t seen her children in almost sixteen years. Over time, the tone of her letters from home has evolved. In the early years, the children would guess which holidays might be the occasion for Emma’s return. Gradually, they stopped asking about her plans. “I believe someday, if God permits, you can be with us once again,” her daughter recently wrote. Visit newyorker.com to read more. Photograph by Jehad Nga.

After Emma realized that her white-collar job in the Philippines would never pay her enough to send her children to college, she came to New York and became a nanny. “My conscience was telling me, ‘Don’t leave your kids. Don’t leave your kids. They are young and need you.’” Read Rachel Aviv’s “The Cost of Caring” on newyorker.com. Photograph by Jehad Nga.
This week’s cover, “Take the L Train,” by Tomer Hanuka. #TNYcovers #LTrain
A cartoon by Emily Flake, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

The Salon International de l’Agriculture, Paris's giant celebration of farming, includes anything passably earthy, from pork producers to beekeepers and knife-makers. This year, its lively atmosphere was altered by the country’s ongoing agricultural crisis. Read Lauren Collins’s “Come to the Fair” on newyorker.com. Photograph by @immoklink.

When the Danish food entrepreneur Claus Meyer opened Gustu in 2013, he wanted to train a generation of cooks who would educate their communities and redefine the way Bolivians perceive traditional ingredients. A network of schools affiliated with the restaurant teaches basic kitchen skills and identifies talented cooks. It has nearly six hundred students. Read Carolyn Kormann’s “The Tasting-Menu Initiative” on newyorker.com. Photograph by @benlowy.

Gustu, Bolivia’s most ambitious restaurant, features avant-garde tasting menus composed entirely from indigenous ingredients. But its innovations go far beyond cuisine. Visit newyorker.com to read @carolynkormann's piece about how the restaurant is also an experiment in social uplift. Photograph by @benlowy.
Like any true New Yorker, the #SubwayInn put up a fight after its landlord refused to renew its lease. Read @stolincokes’s review of the bar on newyorker.com. Illustration by @jorgecolombo.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller, from this week’s issue. See more cartoons on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

Anoushka Shankar’s father carried the velveteen sitar west in 1956; by the sixties, with a little help from George Harrison, the classical Indian instrument had become a pop staple. Today through April 4 at City Winery, in New York, Shankar plays from her new album, “Land of Gold,” blending traditional sitar with pop tropes. Photograph by @garethwmcconnell. #LandofGold
Most Tuesdays in Harlem, live music backs the “Afro-Asian-American” cooking at The Cecil. Read Nicolas Niarchos’s review of @thececilharlem on newyorker.com. Photograph by @paridukovic.

Our resident Comma Queen, Mary Norris, sat down with @manrepeller’s grammar renegades @amilli0naire and @leandramedine to discuss man buns, Instagram-speak, and the English language in the Internet age. Visit manrepeller.com for more. Photograph by @krista_anna.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Chhota Shigri is considered one of the Himalayas’ most accessible glaciers, but many of its passes are treacherous. One is known as Rohtang La (“pile of corpses”), so called because of the many people who have frozen to death trying to get through. In this week’s issue, Dexter Filkins visit the glacier to measure how quickly its ice is melting. Click the link in our bio to read the story. Photograph by Simon Norfolk.
Various instruments take measurements of the changing weather on the Chhota Shigri Glacier. Click the link in our bio to read Dexter Filkins’s “The End of Ice.” Photograph by Simon Norfolk.

The glaciologist Farooq Azam, a thirty-three-year-old former bodybuilding champion, has made more than twenty trips to the Chhota Shigri Glacier. On a recent trip with Dexter Filkins, he came to measure three things: the mass of the glacier, its thickness, and the speed with which it was moving downhill. Click the link in our bio to read the story. Photograph by Simon Norfolk.

For the people who live on the Indian subcontinent, the future of the high-mountain climate is of more than academic interest. The three great rivers that ﬂow from the Indian Himalayas provide water for more than seven hundred million people in India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh. Click the link in our bio to read about Dexter Filkins’s visit the Chhota Shigri Glacier. Photograph by Simon Norfolk.

In our Food & Travel Issue, Dexter Filkins journeys to an inhospitable Himalayan glacier with a team of scientists to investigate how quickly its ice is melting. We’ll share some photographs from the glacier throughout the day. Click the link in our bio to read the story. Photograph by Simon Norfolk.

In Lin-Manuel Miranda's “Hamilton,” Thomas Jefferson is a slick pimp daddy who participates in rap battles; in “1776,” he’s a heartthrob who promises to free his slaves. This week, Michael Schulman previews “1776,” the “Encores!” series revival of the 1969 musical. Visit newyorker.com for more information. Illustration by @dadushin.

In this week’s issue, David Remnick profiles the Queen of Soul, Aretha Franklin, and speaks with @barackobama about the breadth of her enduring influence. “Nobody embodies more fully the connection between the African-American spiritual, the blues, R.&B., rock and roll—the way that hardship and sorrow were transformed into something full of beauty and vitality and hope,” Obama tells Remnick. “American history wells up when Aretha sings.” Photograph by Richard Avedon.

Mezcal, tequila's funky cousin, is having its time in the spotlight. In the Food & Travel issue, out this week, Dana Goodyear visits Oaxaca to explore the humble roots and international rise of Mexico's treasured spirit. Visit newyorker.com to read the story. Illustration by @bjornlie.
A cartoon by David Sipress, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Small startups in New York City are taking on traditional opera by supplying cheap seats for curious newcomers, opportunities for young performers, and a theatrical intimacy that can’t be found at the Met. “At their best,” Alex Ross writes, “they give you the feeling of looking at opera from the inside.” Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @matteberton.
Jaime Hernandez’s “Bun Voyage” is the cover of our Food & Travel Issue, out this week. #TNYcovers

Breakfast, lunch, dinner—@highstnyc does it all, making it look so easy that you wonder why so many restaurants in the city are such slackers. (Dinner only? Lazy.) Read Shauna Lyon’s review of the new West Village spot on newyorker.com. Photograph by @jamespomerantz.
A cartoon by Avi Steinberg (@steinbergdrawscartoons). See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
An array of Easter-themed covers from the archive. Click the link in our bio to see more. #TNYcovers

Bo Nickal, Penn State, hundred-and-seventy-four-pound weight class. Young wrestlers can look simultaneously haggard and phenomenally fit, as the photographer @benlowy captures in his closeup portraits from the 2016 N.C.A.A. wrestling championships. See more on newyorker.com.
The scent of apple hookah and taste of local beer define a Friday night at the Washington Heights bar Monkey Room. Read Nicolas Niarchos’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @jorgecolombo.

“Plant Contest,” which the multimedia artist Cao Fei staged in 2000, is one of the earliest works in the Beijing-based artist’s show at MoMA PS1, opening on April 3. Visit newyorker.com for more information. Photograph courtesy of the Artist / Vitamin Creative Space.

Vladimir Nabokov sometimes devoted as much as fourteen hours a day to sketching butterflies. It’s tempting to find, in the author’s detailed drawings, a figure for Nabokov himself—the shape-shifting artist who travelled from Old World to New. On newyorker.com, Elif Batuman examines a new collection of his detailed drawings. Illustration by Vladimir Nabokov/Courtesy The Vladimir Nabokov Archive at the Berg Collection/New York Public Library/The Wylie Agency LLC.

Nobody seems to like big pharma, big banks, or big businesses. In this week’s issue, Nicholas Lemann investigates why the spectre of size has always haunted American politics. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by David Plunkert.
A cartoon by Tom Chitty (@drawnbytom), from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

Es Devlin’s set for Louis Vuitton’s Autumn/Winter 2015 runway show, in Paris. Click the link in our bio to read Andrew O’Hagan’s profile of the set designer, and to see more of Devlin’s creations. Photograph courtesy Es Devlin.

At her “Bangerz” tour, @mileycyrus slid down her own tongue on an @esdevlin-designed set. Click the link in our bio to read Andrew O’Hagan’s profile of the set designer. Photograph by Steve Jennings / Getty.

@adele performing on a set created by @esdevlin, who is widely considered the world’s foremost stage designer. “What I’m really designing are mental structures, as opposed to physical ones,” Devlin says. Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph courtesy Es Devlin.
@esdevlin's set for @u2’s Innocence+Experience tour featured a walkway flanked by video screens, so that band members sometimes appeared to walk through moving images. Photograph courtesy Es Devlin.

In this week’s issue, Andrew O’Hagan profiles Es Devlin (@esdevlin), set design’s biggest star. She creates sets not only for plays and operas but also for rock concerts, fashion shows, and the Olympics. We’ll be sharing some of her designs here throughout the day. Click the link in our bio to read the story. Photograph-illustration by @nadavkander.
A cartoon by P.C. Vey, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
A special offer just in time for spring: Get 12 issues of The New Yorker for $12, along with a free canvas tote bag. Visit the link in our bio to learn more.

Does becoming a more productive worker make you a better human being? In this week’s issue, Louis Menand examines the self-help books that promise us success at work and home. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @richardmcguirehere.

In an essay in this week’s issue, David Sedaris recounts a week spent shamelessly shopping with his sisters in Tokyo: “My sisters and I refuse to feel bad about shopping. And why should we? Obviously we have some hole we’re trying to fill, but doesn’t everyone? And isn’t filling it with berets the size of toilet-seat covers, if not more practical, then at least healthier than filling it with frosting or heroin or unsafe sex with strangers?” Click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @tshopsin.
A cartoon by Amy Hwang (@cartoonamy), from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Introducing “The Author’s Voice: New Fiction from The New Yorker,” a new podcast featuring short stories that appear in our pages, read by their authors. This week, Ian McEwan reads “My Purple Scented Novel.” Click the link in our bio to listen. Illustration by @sarahevanslloyd.
This week’s cover, “The Big Short,” by Barry Blitt. Read between the (palm) lines on newyorker.com. #TNYcovers
Thank you @rufusbixton for sharing your #newyorkerinthewild, featuring a recent cover by Chris Ware. Tag us in your photographs of The New Yorker, and we might #regram you.
A cartoon by Tom Cheney. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
The bar at Sharlene’s, in Brooklyn, is just the right amount of sticky. Read @mckennastayner’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @jorgecolombo.

Steve martin and Edie Brickell wrote the new Americana musical “Bright Star,” in which a soldier returning from the Second World War meets a literary-magazine editor in North Carolina. The show is in previews now, in New York City. Illustration by @daviddoran_.

Han Dynasty’s Upper West Side outpost is good for big crowds—and anyone seeking flavors that are faithfully Sichuan. Read @silviakillings’s review of the Chinese restaurant on newyorker.com. Photograph by @will_mebane.
How should the media cover Donald Trump? Here’s one idea from Nick Bateman and Hallie Bateman. Click the link in our bio to see more.

Tonight at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts, the Robert Glasper Trio will play from its new album, “Covered,” featuring songs by Joni Mitchell, John Legend, and Radiohead. Photograph by @paridukovic.

At “Words on Dance,” at the Baryshnikov Arts Center in New York City, performers and choreographers will talk without the intervention of a moderator. Visit newyorker.com for more information. Illustration by @pingszoo.
We love @stellabugbee’s photograph of @mairakalman’s latest cover, “Spring Forward.”

The pop-culture-fashion prodigy @itsjeremyscott counts SpongeBob SquarePants, McDonald’s, and Barbie among his muses. Visit newyorker.com to read Lizzie Widdicombe’s piece on how he has remade @moschino for the Instagram era. Illustration by @zzdesign.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

“Changing your look every season to please a fickle customer isn’t how I work,” says the Chinese designer Guo Pei. “I aim to create heirlooms that a woman can pass down.” Judith Thurman profiles @guopeiofficial, in this week’s issue. Click the link in our bio to read the story. Thank you for following along. Photograph by @paridukovic.

Guo Pei samples images of dress from Renaissance art, opera, Gothic fairy tales, or wherever she finds them in pre-Sputnik fashion history, and recombines their hallmarks—a sleeve, a ruff, an apron—with fantastical decoration that alludes to her own heritage. Click the link in our bio to read Judith Thurman’s Profile of the Chinese designer. Photograph by @paridukovic.
Backstage at @guopeiofficial’s Paris début. Click the link in our bio to read Judith Thurman’s Profile of the Chinese designer. Photograph by @paridukovic.
A model walks the runway at @guopeiofficial’s first haute-couture show, this January in Paris. Photograph by @paridukovic.

This strapless gown of distressed guipure lace—with scorched edges, stiffened and gilded—was the opening look at Guo Pei’s first haute-couture show, this January in Paris. “I am confident about my work,” she told Judith Thurman, “and I don’t care what people think about it.” Click the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by @paridukovic.

“We’re all part of the club,” one of Guo Pei’s clients told Judith Thurman. Patrons of Guo’s fashion house pay an annual fee, from which their orders are deducted. The club has four tiers of membership, with subscribers in the top tier spending roughly eight hundred thousand dollars. There are about four thousand subscribers in total. Judith Thurman profiles the designer, in this week’s issue. Photograph by @paridukovic.

Guo Pei’s aesthetic, she says, expresses “a visually deprived nation’s pent-up longing for imperial grandeur.” Click the link in our bio to read Judith Thurman’s Profile of the Chinese haute couturier. We’ll be sharing @paridukovic’s photographs of Guo’s designs here throughout the day.

The Chinese designer Guo Pei recently opened a Paris atelier in order to qualify for a slot on the calendar for Paris Couture Week. She is pictured here in her new Paris showroom. Photograph by @paridukovic.

For years, the Chinese designer Guo Pei (@guopeiofficial) was revered in the East, yet virtually unknown in the West. That changed when Rihanna wore her lavish canary-yellow cape to the 2015 Met Gala, making headlines and spawning memes. In this week’s issue, Judith Thurman visits China’s first homegrown haute couturier. We’ll be sharing @paridukovic’s photographs of Guo’s designs throughout the day. Click the link in our bio to read the story.
Beneath the warmth and the jokes of the sitcom “The Middle” is tense debate between fatalism and optimism, Emily Nussbaum writes. Read the review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @stan_chow.
A cartoon by @drewdernavich. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

This week on newyorker.com, Joyce Carol Oates examines David T. Hanson’s landscape photographs, which incorporate both nature and human pollution. Look closely at these beautiful images and they will soon reveal terrible secrets, she writes. Pictured here is a uranium mill waste pond in Colorado, from 1986. Visit newyorker.com to see more.

David Cromer’s singular vision finds new emotional realness in standard works. His latest project, Lucy Prebble’s play “The Effect,” tracks the relationship between two people over the course of a clinical trial for an experimental anti-depressant. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @jonnyruzzo.
A cartoon by Liam Francis Walsh, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
@mairakalman’s “Spring Forward” is the cover of our Style Issue, out this week. #TNYcovers

The Mexican TV star Kate del Castillo led Sean Penn to El Chapo—and says she was betrayed along the way. Robert Draper has the exclusive details. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by Martin Schoeller for The New Yorker.
@nichomegan enjoyed last week’s issue on the beach. Thank you for sharing your #newyorkerinthewild. #regram
A lovely drawing by @giorgia_lupi, featuring a rendition of Danny Shanahan’s recent cover. #regram
A cartoon by Tom Cheney, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
The renovation of Abyssinia, in Harlem, is good news for lovers of Ethiopian food. Read Nicolas Niarchos’s review of the restaurant on newyorker.com. Photograph by @dina_litovsky.
In this week’s issue, Anthony Lane considers the sad grandeur and fragmented narrative of Terrence Malick’s new film, “Knight of Cups.” Read the review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @anujink.
@lineberger's behind-the-scenes look at @awolerizku's photo shoot with @tinashenow. #regram from the makeup artist, @manthony783. Tinashe performs tonight at @websterhall, in New York City. #regram
This week, @thecooperrrr dances to the music of the swingin’ sixties at Home Sweet Home, in Manhattan. Read her review of the subterranean dive bar on newyorker.com. Illustration by @deannadonegan.
Paid Post: Put more giddy in your giddyup with @ToyotaUSA and the all-new #Prius for 2016.

This week, the photographer @juancristobalcobo is sharing images on @newyorkerphoto’s feed from the northern part of Colombia, an area harshly hit by a recent drought. In this photograph, cats stay cool in an old cemetery chapel in Mompós. #regram
On March 12, the singer @tinashenow comes to @websterhall, in N.Y.C. For more shows, see our Spring Night Life Preview, on newyorker.com. Photograph by Awol Erizku.
A cartoon by @paulnoth, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

The two protagonists of Neel Mukherjee’s “A Life Apart” could not be more different, but the politics between their two countries bears down on them equally. Read Joan Acocella’s review of the novel, in this week’s issue. Illustration by  @paulrogersstudio.

The playwright Danai Gurira has a nearly unerring ear for making popular theatre without compromising authenticity. In this week’s issue, Hilton Als considers her new work, “Familiar,” which explores an immigrant experience that is seldom portrayed. Photograph by @geordiewood.

In our Spring Classical Music Preview: A new bio-opera about Charlie Parker at the Apollo Theatre, plus premières at the Metropolitan Museum, the New York City Opera, and the New York Philharmonic. Visit newyorker.com for details. Illustration by Eleanor Davis.

“People are always asking me, ‘Who will you pass the torch to?’ The question makes me angry. There is no one torch—there are many torches—and I’m using my torch to light other torches.” On #internationalwomensday, a look back at our Profile of Gloria Steinem, who has remained at the forefront of the feminist movement for more than fifty years. Photograph by @inezvinoodh.
A cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

A tax loophole helps the wealthiest Americans to perform major acts of public service. Is that fair? Read Alec MacGillis’s piece “The Billionaires’ Loophole” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Oliver Munday.

The activist Alicia Garza is one of the creators of the slogan “Black Lives Matter.” In this week’s issue, she talks with Jelani Cobb about the expanding—and quickly evolving—movement. Photograph by @amyelkinsphoto.
This week's cover, "Stop," by Chris Ware. Read about his inspiration on newyorker.com. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @kimwarp. #TNYcartoons

This week on @newyorkerphoto, the photographer @malinfezehai is sharing images from remote areas of Pakistan that are vulnerable to the effects of climate change. Here, two girls study at a Government Girls Primary School in Thatta, where enrollment has increased since gaining running water and a latrine block. #regram

In a short story from Fiona McFarlane’s new collection, “The High Places,” a teacher underestimates the influence and power of the cool kid in her classroom. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @b_e_n__t_h_o_m_a_s for The New Yorker; design by Annie Jen.
This week, Hilton Als reviews a revival of “Hughie,” the one-act play that signalled an upswing in Eugene O’Neill’s artistic life. Illustration by Ben Kirchner.

What’s the point of a reviewer in an age when everyone reviews? In his new book, the film critic A. O.  Scott examines his craft’s place in an age of opinion. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by Miguel Porlan.
A cartoon by @farleykatz. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

The former C.I.A. chief Michael Hayden spent his entire professional life guarding America’s darkest secrets. Now, he’s written a memoir about redefining privacy. Read George Packer’s review of the book on newyorker.com. Illustration by @emilianoponzi.

In this week’s issue, David Owen looks at how enthusiasts of the card game bridge banded together to expose a cheating scandal involving top-level players. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by @javier_jaen.
@murrayscheesebar, in the West Village, is a cozy, modern extension of the famous shop. Read Shauna Lyon’s review of the restaurant on newyorker.com. Photograph by @erichelgas.
A cartoon by @steinbergdrawscartoons, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

As anxieties have grown around white artists who commit acts of cultural appropriation, @macklemore is reëvaluating his privilege. But is that enough? Visit newyorker.com to read Hua Hsu’s piece on the rapper. Illustration by Evgeny Parfenov.

It’s democracy time again. Who is the best person in America, the one who should be put in charge of all the other people? You decide, with Edward Steed’s presidential posters. Click the link in our bio to see them all.
A Presidential poster by New Yorker cartoonist Edward Steed. Click the link in our bio to see them all.
A Presidential poster by New Yorker cartoonist Edward Steed. Click the link in our bio to see more.

Who is the best person in America, the one who should be put in charge of all the other people? You decide, with New Yorker cartoonist Edward Steed’s Presidential posters. Click the link in our bio to see them all.
A Presidential poster by New Yorker cartoonist Edward Steed. Click the link in our bio to see them all.

It’s democracy time again. Who is the best person in America, the one who should be put in charge of all the other people? You decide, with the New Yorker cartoonist Edward Steed’s Presidential posters. We’ll be sharing them here throughout the day. Click the link in our bio to see them all.

In a world where cable sitcoms often deal in melancholy and rage, @broadcity offers something zany, warmhearted, and sweetly liberatory. Read Emily Nussbaum’s review of the show’s third season, on newyorker.com. Illustration by @stan_chow.

New York City’s Lower East Side is getting a new two-screen movie theatre, @metrographnyc. Read about the venue’s inaugural series, “Surrender to the Screen,” on newyorker.com. Photo-illustration by @akrachey.
A cartoon by @paulnoth, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

The Civilians, a socially concerned, Brooklyn-based theatre collective, have put together “Rimbaud in New York,” a new production that uses songs and prose to investigate Rimbaud’s dense and wild poetry. The show plays at @bam_brooklyn Fisher, through March 6. Visit newyorker.com for more information. Illustration by Oliver Munday.

Justice Antonin Scalia played an instrumental role in moving American law in a more corporate-friendly direction. In this week’s issue, James Surowiecki considers how his absence from the Supreme Court could make corporations more accountable for misbehaviors. Illustration by @abstractsunday.
Tune in to @thenightlyshow tonight at 11:30/10:30c to see Malcolm Gladwell discuss football and Donald Trump with Larry Wilmore.

The education startup AltSchool is an experiment in big data, responsive lesson plans, and surveillance—and students are the guinea pigs. Rebecca Mead examines the private school's ambitious mission to disrupt education, in this week's issue. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by @olimpiazagnoli.
A cartoon by @joedator. Click the link in our bio to see more cartoons from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

“I will often challenge myself to dig into classic cartoon themes–like desert-island cartoons, for example,” Danny Shanahan says of “High Rise,” his cover for this week’s issue. Read more about the cartoonist's inspiration on newyorker.com. #TNYcovers
#Oscars. Illustration by @lizadonnelly.
Brie Larson wins the Academy Award for Best Actress. Illustration by New Yorker cartoonist @lizadonnelly, who is live-drawing the #Oscars.
Alejandro González Iñárritu wins the #Oscar for Best Director for "The Revenant." Illustration by @lizadonnelly, who is live-drawing the awards.
Lady Gaga sings "'Til It Happens to You." #Oscars (Illustration by our cartoonist @lizadonnelly, who is live-drawing the evening's proceedings.)
Best Supporting Actor Mark Rylance, by our cartoonist @lizadonnelly, who is live-drawing tonight's #Oscars. Follow along with us here and on Twitter.
@chrisrock, host of the #Oscars. Illustration by our cartoonist @lizadonnelly, who is live-drawing tonight's proceedings. See more on Twitter.
An illustration of @kerrywashington by the New Yorker cartoonist @lizadonnelly, who is live-drawing tonight's proceedings at the #Oscars. Follow along on Twitter.
New Yorker cartoonist @lizadonnelly is live-drawing the #Oscars red carpet and awards show. We will be sharing some of her drawings here; follow along on Twitter, too.

“The Martian,” Ridley Scott’s Oscar-nominated film starring Matt Damon, “thrums with an appetite for life,” wrote our movie critic, Anthony Lane. Read the review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Tomer Hanuka.
Cate Blanchett is nominated for an #Oscar for her performance in “Carol.” Read John Lahr’s 2007 Profile of the actress on newyorker.com. Photograph by @ruvenafanador.

“Spotlight” is nominated for Best Picture in this year’s #Oscars. In his review, Anthony Lane called it “the year’s least relaxing film, thanks to the attention that McCarthy and his fellow-screenwriter, Josh Singer, oblige you to pay.” Read more on newyorker.com.  Illustration by R. Kikuo Johnson.
This week, @weitchou visits the historically seedy, currently cheery 169 Bar, in New York City's Chinatown. Read her review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @deannadonegan.

“The audience and the director, it’s an S & M relationship, and the audience is the M.” Read Larissa MacFarquhar’s 2003 Profile of Quentin Tarantino on newyorker.com. Tarantino's latest film, “The Hateful Eight,” is nominated in this year’s Academy Awards. Photograph by @ruvenafanador.

This weekend, @chrisrock will take the stage to host the #Oscars. In 2014, he spoke with The New Yorker’s Kelefa Sanneh about his willingness to tell unpopular truths. Read more on newyorker.com. Photograph by @paridukovic.
@officialjld dropped by our office yesterday to speak with David Remnick for an upcoming episode of “The New Yorker Radio Hour.” See more on Snapchat (username: newyorkermag). #regram

Politicians and executives love to talk about leadership. Schools claim to teach it; voters lionize it. But we know surprisingly little about how it works. In this week’s issue Joshua Rothman asks, “What is leadership, anyway?” Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @nishantchoksi.

Justin Peck began as a dancer for New York City Ballet. Now he is making waves as its resident choreographer. In this week’s issue, Joan Acocella examines his precocious rise. Photograph by Andreas Laszlo Konrath.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Paid Post: Six billion people have access to mobile phones. Millions more want them. Providing accessible communication will be essential to help tomorrow’s global economy thrive. That’s a beautiful opportunity. See how we invest in a beautiful world at oppenheimerfunds.com. #TheRightWayToInvest
This week, the Texas-based photographer @bryanschutmaat is taking over @newyorkerphoto’s feed, sharing photographs from his travels in the American West. #regram

The musical “The Robber Bridegroom,” based on a short novel by Eudora Welty and directed by Alex Timbers, doesn’t shy away from depicting the shadowy areas of life. Visit newyorker.com to read Read Hilton Als’s review of the show, which opens March 13 at the Laura Pels in New York City. Illustration by @rikiblanco.

The singer and activist Victoria Ruiz leads Downtown Boys with a sharp tongue and a hoarse throat. On the band’s début album, “Full Communism,” she’s lucid and blunt, shouting down cops, traders, and any other impediment to justice that she can spot. The band will play at New York City’s @babysallright on Feb. 27. Photograph by @philipmontgomery.

By pinching pennies, Peter Adeney retired at thirty. Now, as Mr. Money Mustache, he is waging war on American consumerism as an outspoken advocate of his particular brand of thrift: “financial freedom through badassity.” Read Nick Paumgarten’s piece on the life-style guru of frugality on newyorker.com. Photograph by @michaelfriberg.
In Daily Shouts: Tattoo ideas for the creative millennial, by @j.a.k._ and @blythelikehappy. “People say that millennials can’t keep off their phones. Well, this phone can’t keep off its millennial.”
Find us on Snapchat (username: newyorkermag) to get a behind-the-scenes look at this week’s cover, directly from the office of our art editor. #TNYcovers

For forty years, Father Mike Pfleger—a white clergyman—has led Chicago’s largest black Catholic church. In this week’s issue, Evan Osnos examines how he became a central figure in the fight for reform in a city marred by racism, violence, and poverty. Photograph by @christaanfelber.
A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
“Privileged Characters,” by the cartoonist and scriptwriter Daniel Clowes, is our cover for this week’s issue. #TNYcovers

Grilled fish may taste best when the Aegean is lapping your feet, but New York City's Avra is the next best thing. Read Nicolas Niarchos’s review of the standout Greek restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, on newyorker.com. Photograph by @jeremy_liebman.
HBO’s new series “Vinyl” embraces a long-lost New York, but it has an air of leaden nostalgia. Read Emily Nussbaum’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @kristianhammerstad.
Shouts & Murmurs for a Saturday night: Kelly Stout (@scoutstout) offers juror instructions for the case Just Staying In v. Meeting Up with Rob and Those Guys. Illustration by @sortofbutnotreally.
A cartoon by Peter Kuper, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

The photographer Paul Bulteel travelled to fifty sites in Europe, chronicling what happens to the things we leave behind. He wanted not only to document the “volumes and variety of wastes streams” but also to illustrate and encourage efforts “to recycle waste on an unprecedented scale.” Trash art isn’t typically uplifting, but these images are meant to evoke optimism. Read @carolynkormann’s “The Bewildering Beauty of Recycled Waste” on newyorker.com to see more.

Olivier Messiaen’s “From the Canyons to the Stars. . .” has become a cult work of twentieth-century music. It takes inspiration from the rock formations, birdsong, and night sky of Utah. Read more about “Canyons” and Hans Abrahamsen’s song cycle “let me tell you” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Robert G. Fresson.
A tatted Talk of the Town, courtesy of @surdavid. Thank you for sharing your #newyorkerinthewild. #regram

After years of experiencing Kanye West through Auto-Tune, hearing his natural voice on “The Life of Pablo” is a reminder that doubt remains his greatest motivation. It’s as though a man who refers to himself in song as a “God” and a “genius” still craves validation; the arrogance is real, but it’s also a pose. Read Hua Hsu’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Michael Cho.
A cartoon by Chris Cater, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

This week’s cover, by @kadir_nelson, pays homage to artists and performers like Aaron Douglas and Billie Holiday, the activist Malcolm X, and writers such as James Baldwin and Zora Neale Hurston. Thanks to @epzar for sharing your #newyorkerinthewild. #regram
A cartoon by Christian Lowe. See more from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

Valda Setterfield plays the title role in John Scott’s “Lear,” a  streamlined version of Shakespeare’s play. She says she never focused on the fact that she plays a man. "What I was doing was just a parent," she says. The show plays at New York Live Arts through Feb. 20. Illustration by @edelrodriguez.

All of us possess the same fundamental stress-response system. Why do some people use it so much  more effectively than others? Read Maria Konnikova’s post on how people learn to become resilient, on newyorker.com. Illustration by Gizem Vural.
A cartoon by Edward Steed, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Paid Post: The Pop-In@Nordstrom looks that inspired this illustration, by @Sam_Kalda, show how menswear continues to evolve. They can be found through March 13 in Heartbreakers II, @NordstromMen themed shops inside select stores, and on nordstrom.com/pop, curated by @OliviaKim. #NordstromPop

If you're famous in Los Angeles, even your barista may have a direct line to TMZ. In this week's issue, Nicholas Schmidle examines how the attorney Harvey Levin created a gossip site that operates like an intelligence agency. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @peterbohler.
Kadir Nelson, this week’s cover artist, wanted to create “a stylistic montage as an homage to the great Harlem Renaissance painters.” Read more about his inspiration on newyorker.com. #TNYcovers

We asked ten photographers and artists to respond to the kitschy commodification of romance that takes place each February, utilizing whatever Valentine’s ephemera caught their eye. Here’s one of the photographs, by Mayan Toledano. See more in our Love and Kitsch slide show on newyorker.com.
A 1991 Valentine’s Day cover, by Ronald Searle. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @zkanin. See more illustrations of affection in @stolincokes’s slide show of New Yorker cartoons for Valentine’s Day (link in bio). #TNYcartoons

“Zoolander 2” is overstuffed with celebrity cameos, Anthony Lane writes. “In all honesty, how much of a creative risk is it to show that you can take a joke, when the joke is no more wounding than a back rub?” Read the full review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Ben Kirchner.

For Ramzan Kadyrov, Chechnya’s leader, the rise of another pressing security threat presents both opportunity and peril. Read Joshua Yaffa’s piece “Putin’s Dragon” on newyorker.com. Photograph by Alexander Gronsky.

With its tropical plants and earthy colors, Brooklyn’s Llama Inn (@llamainnnyc) is a quirky portal to Lima, Peru. Read Shauna Lyon’s review of the boho-swanky restaurant on newyorker.com. Photograph by @amylombard.
A cartoon by David Sipress. Visit our Cartoons at Random page (link in bio) to see more. #TNYcartoons
Beauty is the theme of the @cooperhewitt's Design Triennial. Don't expect Grecian urns when the show opens tomorrow. Photograph by @andrewbmyers.

The Italian disco pioneer Giorgio Moroder mapped the patterns of kick and snare drums that get bodies pulsing before many of today's working d.j.s were tall enough to reach the decks. Tonight, he brings five decades of thump to Output, in Brooklyn, for a rare set of disco classics and forward-thinking electronic cuts. Illustration by Daniel Krall.

Garth Greenwell and Darryl Pinckney’s books are both about the ways in which our past and our scars can shape how we love. Visit newyorker.com to read James Wood’s piece on two novels about gay Americans abroad—and at sea. Illustration by Mikkel Sommer.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller. #TNYcartoons

Yves Bouvier made hundreds of millions of dollars selling paintings by using the art industry’s obsession with discretion to his advantage. Was it fraud? Read “The Bouvier Affair,” by Sam Knight, on newyorker.com. Illustration by Ben Wiseman.
In George Saunders’s new short story, “Mother’s Day,” two women reflect on the philanderer they both loved. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @jeff_bark; design by @elanaschlenker.

This week in Shouts & Murmurs, Hallie Cantor offers an official agenda for your sick day. “12:15 P.M. Acknowledge that you’re weirdly lonely right now and that you miss everyone at the office.” Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @taxali.
A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
This week, Nicolas Niarchos visits Berlin, a barrel-vaulted watering hole in New York's Alphabet City. Read the review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @freebrianrea.

On Sunday, the original foursome of the dynamic string quartet Brooklyn Rider will be intact for "The Fiction Issue," a concert at Williamsburg's National Sawdust. The concert also features Schubert's Quartet No. 13 in A Minor. Visit newyorker.com for more details. Illustration by @simonemassoni.
@tbtoro’s sketch, pitch, and final draft of his cartoon in this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
Find us on The List App (our username is newyorker) to see some snowy covers from the archive including this one, by S. Liam Dunne, from 1932. #TNYcovers
Making the past matter in the present is just one aspect of Madlib’s genius. In this week’s issue, Hilton Als looks at the d.j., producer, and m.c.’s rise to fame. Photograph by Graeme Mitchell.

In this week’s issue, Elif Batuman explores her conflicted feelings, as a Turkish American, about wearing a head scarf while traveling in Turkey: “Something about it felt dishonest, almost shameful, as if I were duping people into being kind to me,” she writes. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @annaparini.

This week, @lukas.birk is sharing images from his Myanmar Photo Archive on @newyorkerphoto. Here, a photo from the 1930s taken at a shinbyu ceremony, where boys in Myanmar are initiated into the Buddha’s Order.
A cartoon by P.C. Vey. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

“American Crime Story: The People vs. O.J. Simpson,” an addictive, miraculously well-cast dramatization of the 1995 murder case, feels hot-wired with modern parallels. Read Emily Nussbaum’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @24houremergency.

Sia’s new record, “This Is Acting” (@siathisisacting), shows a mastery of formula rather than a rebellion against it. In this week’s issue, Carrie Battan looks at the forty-year-old Australian artist’s response to stardom. Photograph by @jamesdayphoto; illustration by Ian Wright.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

The mayhem on Wall Street this year has been driven by oil prices—but, as James Surowiecki writes, cheap oil is a good thing for the economy. Read his take on the market’s oil obsession on newyorker.com. Illustration by @abstractsunday.

Paid Post: A sound investment strategy to weather uncertain times is to build a geographically diverse portfolio.
