Forty percent of the 8,389 actively traded companies with a market cap of over $1 billion are in emerging markets. That means it’s time for U.S.-centric investors to expand their horizons. Gain a global perspective on today’s volatile markets at oppenheimerfunds.com. #TheRightWayToInvest
@nicholerobertson settled down with her issue of The New Yorker and a cup of tea. Thank you for sharing your #newyorkerinthewild. Tag us and use the hashtag, and we might #regram you.

The New Yorker’s dandy mascot, Eustace Tilley, appeared on the cover of the magazine’s very first issue ninety-one years ago. This week, he graces our Anniversary issue cover, "Eustace Spreads Out," by @porliniers. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by David Sipress. #TNYcartoons
In this week’s fiction—a trio of short stories by Adam Ehrlich Sachs—three men bear the weight of their fathers. Read the stories on newyorker.com. Photo illustration by @mirkalaurasevera.
Anthony Lane says the new film “Jane Got a Gun,” starring Natalie Portman and Noah Emmerich, fires blanks. Read his review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @bill_bragg_illustration.
Vijay Iyer’s research changed how scholars look at music and the mind. Now, as a jazz pianist, he’s become a star. Read Alec Wilkinson’s profile of Iyer on newyorker.com. Photograph by @ioulex.
A cartoon by @drawnbytom. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

The new Upper East Side brasserie @vauclusenyc is comfortable, reassuring, and consistently delicious without being at all daring, Adam Gopnik writes. Read his review on newyorker.com. Photograph by Zachary Zavislak.

In this week’s issue, Hilton Als reflects on the issues of shame and self-worth at the heart of the play “Slut,” performed by the Arts Effect All-Girl Theatre Company. After a tour of U.S. cities, the play returns to Dixon Place, in New York City, on Thursdays and Saturdays Jan. 28 – Feb. 27. Illustration by @hannahkleeee.

A Lower East Side bar where you don’t have to fight to get in—or be heard—is nothing short of a miracle. This week, @thecooperrrr visits Garfunkel’s, a cozy speakeasy that, at its best, is the most intimate new bar in New York City. Click the link in our bio to read her review. Illustration by @mukaigrimace.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
Thank you to @stellar_regions for sharing your #newyorkerinthewild. Use the hashtag and tag us in your photos of The New Yorker, and we might #regram you.

In the coming weeks, Haiti’s pop-star-turned-President Michel Martelly will leave office. What will his legacy be? Read Jon Lee Anderson’s piece “Aftershocks” in this week’s issue. Photograph by @philipmontgomery.

New York = rat kings, broken dreams; Los Angeles = ombré, Segways. In Shouts & Murmurs, Cirocco Dunlap contends with the allure of the coastal cities. Read “N.Y.C. to L.A. to N.Y.C., Ad Infinitum” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @waltergreenz.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com.
Tune in to @thedailyshow tonight at 11:00 P.M. E.T. Our writer Ryan Lizza will join @trevornoah to discuss his piece in this week's issue on Trump, Cruz, and the G.O.P.'s big problem.

This week on @newyorkerphoto, Rose Marie Cromwell (@rorosiemarie) is sharing images from Coco Solo, a marginalized community in Panama. Here, an image from her King of Fish series, for which she photographed one boy, Pocho, for several years as he matured into manhood.

Three months passed before the body of Bella Bond, discovered in a trash bag in Boston Harbor, was identified. In this week’s issue, Jill Lepore examines the history of the child-protection movement, and America’s fraught efforts to keep kids safe. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by omunday.tumblr.com.
A cartoon by Tim Hamilton, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
@dan2dublin juxtaposed John Cuneo’s wintery cover with a sandy beach scene. Tag us in your #newyorkerinthewild, and we might #regram you.

The trio @wet combines lo-fi folk, brainy electronica, and slow-burn R. & B. for a distinctly different pop sound. This week, the band will celebrate the release of its self-produced major-label début, “Don’t You,” with two engagements, at Bowery Ballroom (Jan. 28) and Rough Trade (Jan. 29). Photograph by @elizabethrenstrom.
A cartoon by @drewdernavich, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
@tiltonfenwick avoided the blizzard altogether and found a warmer place to read. Tag us in your #newyorkerinthewild, and we might #regram you.

The Republican Party is seemingly helpless to stop Donald Trump and Ted Cruz. Insiders loathe them; voters love them. Who will decide the future of the G.O.P.? In this week’s issue, Ryan Lizza reports from the campaign trails of the two Presidential candidates. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @markpetersonpixs.
Today’s daily cartoon by David Sipress. #TNYcartoons

This week, Nathan Heller reads a new book by Christopher Schaberg that argues that, in a networked world, “moving hundreds of bodies around in large vessels will go out of fashion.” Read more about the evolution of air travel on newyorker.com. Illustration by Joon Mo Kang.

It was a snowy weekend in New York City and along the East Coast. Our own @ellara stayed warm with a maple latte and her copy of The New Yorker. Tag us and use the hashtag #newyorkerinthewild, and we might #regram you.

“My biggest challenge was to alter the Presidents’ expressions to make them reflect attitudes of consternation,” Barry Blitt says of “Bad Reception,” his cover for this week’s issue. Read more about the artist’s inspiration on newyorker.com. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Charlie Hankin, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

The true-crime series is bound by no rules of procedure and shaped only by the ethics of its makers, Kathryn Schulz writes. This week, she looks at how “Making a Murderer” went wrong. Illustration by @simon_prades.

Schoolhouse chairs and warm lighting give @housemanrestaurant the look of a place you might slink into for roast chicken and a glass of wine when you don’t really feel like going out. But it needs a few tweaks before it feels like home. Read @silviakillings’s review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @meredithjenks.
A cartoon by Frank Cotham, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

This week, @jiayangfan visits @mothersruinnyc, a cozy hangout in Nolita where the barkeep can whip you up a Lee Marvin (tequila, agave, orange) or a New Fuck Buddy (rum, coffee sauce, lemon). Read the review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @boyounillo.
@mandycorine’s reading and snack break. Thank you for sharing your #newyorkerinthewild. #regram

In this week’s issue, James Surowiecki examines the economics of the armed siege of a wildlife refuge in Oregon. “Bundy’s tactics make him easy to dismiss as a kook,” he writes, “but his ideology is squarely in the mainstream of Western conservatism." Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @abstractsunday.
A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

TV has plenty of ambitious experiments that are brutal to watch. On a cold January day, Emily Nussbaum would rather sit down with “Crazy Ex-Girlfriend” and “Younger,” two warm, funky charmers about women starting over. Illustration by David Saracino.
Two hot drinks and two copies of The New Yorker. Thanks to @anniesvigals for sharing your #newyorkerinthewild. #regram

The Met is placing a big bet on modern and contemporary art at a time when nobody can predict what art will be—or mean—to future generations. Read Calvin Tomkins’s piece “The Met and the Now” in this week’s issue. Illustration by @tshopsin.

Paid Post: Never sleep on a true artist. Zach Galifianakis is Baskets. Watch the premiere of FX’s new comedy @BasketsFX tonight at 10:00 P.M. E.T. Find more exclusive examples of Baskets's illustrated alter ego on the blue panels created by the cartoonist Benjamin Schwartz in the slideshow on newyorker.com/cartoons.

Yesterday senior editor Alan Burdick wrote about Planet Nine, our solar system's newest member, known to the discovering astronomers as "Fatty." Tune in to a special planetary Snapchat with Alan (we are newyorkermag) to learn more about the ice giant. It's out of this world.

In this week’s issue, Steven Shapin reads a new book about how autism activists have shaped the spectrum—and the system that cares for those who are on it. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by Leo Espinosa.
@gabo.tx's lunch with Kim Jong-un. Thank you for sharing your #newyorkerinthewild. #regram
Today’s Daily Cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. #TNYcartoons
Ayman Odeh wants to forge a more integrated Israel. In this week’s issue, David Remnick reports from Jerusalem on the politician’s lonely mission. Illustration by omunday.tumblr.com.

Liberals have praised David and Charles Koch for supporting criminal-justice reform. But do the billionaire brothers have an ulterior motive? Jane Mayer examines, in this week’s issue. Illustration by Matt Dorfman.

@obviousstate reads Anthony Lane’s review of “Anomalisa,” Charlie Kaufman’s desolate stop-motion animated film. “What drives the film is a scowling suspicion that modern man is a mechanized being, created as if on an assembly line, and stripped bare of individuality.” Read the review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Jillian Tamaki. #newyorkerinthewild #regram

“The hardest thing for me to draw was the happy little girl,” John Cuneo says of “Winter Delight,” his cover for this week’s issue. “Drawing unhappy adults in bulky winter clothes hunched over their phones is much more in my comfort zone.” Read more about the artist’s inspiration on newyorker.com. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by @zkanin. #TNYcartoons

The rapper @asaprocky will remember his late mentor, A$AP Yams, with a performance at @terminal5nyc on January 18—the one-year anniversary of his death. Visit newyorker.com for more information. Illustration by Cun Shi.

The New Yorker is a four-time finalist for the ASME Best Cover Contest. Kadir Nelson’s cover for our ninetieth anniversary issue is nominated in the Brainiest Cover category. Click the link in our bio to cast your vote. #TNYcovers
Ludmilla Petrushevskaya’s fiction in this week’s issue is a modern fairy tale of swindlers, oligarchs, and artists. Read “The Story of a Painter” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @henningwagenbreth.
A cartoon by @drewdernavich, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

In an essay in this week’s issue, Tad Friend examines his longtime relationship with the sport of squash. “Deep in a match, when your heart is hammering and your legs begin to seize, fatigue sweeps your mind clean.” Visit newyorker.com to read more. Illustration by @paulrogersstudio.
Mushrooms take center stage at the new restaurant Lowlife, on New York City’s Lower East Side. Read Amelia Lester’s review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @jamespomerantz.

This week, our resident expert on baijiu—high-proof Chinese spirits notorious for their umami-heavy funk—visits a speakeasy in SoHo with a thoughful menu of cocktails. Click the link in our bio to read @weitchou’s review of @lumosnyc. Illustration by @mikeyburton.

Over the weekend, @brennmcd sat down with Ben Lerner’s piece on the @whitneymuseum’s conservation efforts. Visit newyorker.com to read “The Custodians.” What are you reading in The New Yorker? Tag your photos with #newyorkerinthewild and we might #regram you.
Remembering the actor Alan Rickman in this cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. #TNYcartoons

Twenty-two years after misidentifying her rapist, a woman fought to clear the accused man’s name—and change the law in Texas. Read Paul Kix’s “Recognition” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @annaparini.

In this week’s issue, Lauren Collins profiles the actor Damian Lewis. “The great bizarrity of Lewis’s career is that he is a white-tie Briton who has made his reputation playing blue-collar Americans,” she writes. In the new show “Billions,” which premières on @showtime this week, Lewis plays Bobby (Axe) Axelrod, a knockaround guy who scraps his way up from golf caddie to hedge-fund eminence. Visit newyorker.com to read “Blue Blood, Blue Collar.” Photograph by @paridukovic.
A cartoon by @J.A.K._, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
Thanks to @vaniamyers for sharing this photo, featuring an illustration by Romy Blümel. Tag your photos with #newyorkerinthewild and we might #regram you.
In Shouts & Murmurs, Donald Trump tries to get forced out of the Presidential race. Read Douglas McGrath’s “We Have a Serious Problem” on newyorker.com to find out why. Illustration by Istvan Banyai.

The vignettes in @bigdancetheater’s compilation “Big Dance: Short Form” are surreal, but so tightly constructed and lucidly performed that they feel familiar. Visit newyorker.com for more information. Photograph by @ioulex.
The New Yorker cartoonist Bob Eckstein spent last night at his drawing table while watching the Golden Globes. See more of the drawings he sent us on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
Remembering David Bowie, in today’s Daily Cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. #TNYcartoons
A quiet Sunday with The New Yorker, from @chloe4dayz. #newyorkerinthewild #regram
In Anne Carson’s fiction from this week’s issue, a woman considers the struggles of refugees—as well as her own. Read 1=1 on newyorker.com. Illustration by @gray.318.

In a video accompanying Nick Paumgarten’s Profile of @ashimashiraishi, the young climber talks about her love for the sport. Click the link in our bio to see “The Climber’s Life.” Here, a behind-the-scenes shot from the video’s producer, @hellofromcath.

The fourteen-year-old New Yorker @ashimashiraishi seems destined to become the best rock climber in the world. Read Nick Paumgarten’s Profile of the young “Gretzky of the granite” on newyorker.com. Photograph by @paridukovic.
@rachelsaysrock catching up on some old issues of The New Yorker. #newyorkerinthewild #regram

In "#ItGetsBitter” (at @publictheaterny, Jan. 12-14), the South Asian trans performance duo @darkmatterpoetry offers a cheeky radical-queer critique of the gay-rights movement, employing spoken word, fractured nursery rhymes, and fluorescent lipstick. Visit newyorker.com for more information. Photograph by @zzane.

At @babujinyc the dishes wear bold garnishes—brightly colored flowers, shredded beets—like edible fascinators. Read @silviakillings’s review of the new East Village Indian restaurant on newyorker.com. Photograph by @will_mebane.

In Saudi Arabia, women have a legal status resembling that of a minor. But the country’s first female lawyers want to help their peers stand up for themselves. Read Katherine Zoepf’s piece “Sisters in Law” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Eiko Ojala.

This week, James Surowiecki examines the rise of tax inversions—the process by which U.S. corporations reconstitute themselves overseas to take advantage of lower tax rates. “The inversion train seems only to be picking up speed,” he writes. Visit newyorker.com to read more. Illustration by Miguel Gallardo.

In this week’s issue, Ben Lerner spends time with the @whitneymuseum’s replication committee, which steps in when works of art can’t be restored in traditional ways. Here, Carol Mancusi-Ungaro, the head of the committee, works on a painting by Rothko. “We’re not trying to influence the work,” she tells Lerner. “We want the artist to be heard.” Visit newyorker.com to read more about how the Whitney is transforming museum conservation. Photograph by @erichelgas.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
An early look at next week’s cover, “New Toys,” by Anita Kunz. #TNYcovers

The Carnegie Club has the aura of a friendly den of iniquity: leather couches, red striped wallpaper, stone fireplaces, huge ashtrays, cottony clouds of smoke floating by like weather systems. Visit newyorker.com to read Sarah Larson’s review of the elegant two-story cigar lounge in New York City. Illustration by Daniel Krall.

@carlosjavierortiz’s project A Thousand Midnights marks the centennial of the Great Migration, in which six million African Americans relocated from the rural South. Ortiz writes, “The purported racial openness of the north was believed to translate into more economic opportunity for Black migrants. However, as is the case with much of the American story, this dream remains just out of reach for many.” Here, members of St. Sabina Church pray to end violence in Chicago. Visit @newyorkerphoto to see more images and learn more about his work.

@_melissagutierrez looks at Peter Granser's photo portfolio of the futuristic façades of Freddy Mamani Silvestre's buildings in Bolivia. To see more images, visit newyorker.com. #newyorkerinthewild #regram
A cartoon by Paul Noth, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

A behind-the-scenes look at @azizansari in conversation with Sarah Larson at One World Trade Center. Click the link in our bio to hear their conversation on the latest episode of The New Yorker Radio Hour.

On this week’s episode of The New Yorker Radio Hour, @azizansari discusses the authenticity of his show, “Master of None,” with The New Yorker’s Sarah Larson. Visit the link in our profile—newyorkerradiohour.org—to listen in. Illustration by Rebecca Mock.

Red Bull Theatre kicks off its “season of scandal” with Thomas Middleton and William Rowley’s 1622 tragedy, “The Changeling,” in which a woman asks her father’s servant to kill her fiancé. Visit newyorker.com for more information. Illustration by @24houremergency.
Today’s Daily Cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. #TNYcartoons
Marcellus Hall's cover of this week's issue, "The Great Thaw," is a "twist on the usual winter theme in New York." Read more about the artist's inspiration on newyorker.com. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by William Haefeli, in this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
@domenicacooks started the new year with homemade cinnamon rolls and Shauna Lyon’s review of @quality_eats. #newyorkerinthewild #regram

Lauren Worsham and John Kelly star in David T. Little’s devastating opera “Dog Days,” one of seven productions offered as part of this year’s Prototype Festival, Jan. 6-17. For more information, visit newyorker.com. Illustration by Joohee Yoon.

The upstart movie studio STX Entertainment wants to shake up Hollywood. In an industry suffused with pricey superhero films, the studio’s chairman, Adam Fogelson, is betting on stories on a human scale. Read Tad Friend’s “The Mogul of the Middle” on newyorker.com. Photograph by Angie Smith.
A cartoon by Kim Warp, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
A Sunday scene from @esochko. #newyorkerinthewild #regram

In this week’s fiction, a New York man’s predictable life is tragically transformed after a tropical vacation. Read Ottessa Moshfegh’s “The Beach Boy” on newyorker.com. Photograph by @davidbrandongeeting; design by Jason Fulford.

This week in Goings On About Town, “Les Pêcheurs de Perles” returns to the @MetOpera stage for the first time in a century, stripped of fantasy and transported to an impoverished present-day coastal village in the Far East. Diana Damrau, pictured here, portrays the Hindu priestess Leïla. Visit newyorker.com for more information. Photograph by @paridukovic.
A cartoon by Amy Hwang. #TNYcartoons

Combine Quentin Tarantino's "The Hateful Eight" and Alejandro González Iñárritu's "The Revenant," and what have you got? Five hours and thirty-eight minutes of malice and mistrust. Read Anthony Lane's reviews on newyorker.com. Illustration by Zohar Lazar.
This week, @emmaewallen spends an evening at Riddling Widow, a small cellar bar in New York City's Greenwich Village. Read her review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @jeanniephan.

The menu at @quality_eats, a svelte new West Village restaurant, reads like a glutton's day in Heaven, if such a thing were allowed. Read Shauna Lyon's review, in this week's issue. Photograph by @erichelgas.
@rankandfile's quiet start to 2016. This week's cover, by @frankviva, celebrates courageous women throughout the world. #newyorkerinthewild #regram
This week, Alex Ross reviews two new American operas: "Bel Canto" and "Great Scott." Illustration by Vincent Mahé.
@danayners was in Miami Beach when she read Elizabeth Kolbert's piece on Miami's rising sea levels. Tag your New Yorker photos with #newyorkerinthewild and we might #regram you.
A cartoon by @joedator. #TNYcartoons

Leslie Jones had a twenty-five-year career as a standup comedian before she booked Saturday Night Live. Now, she’s well on her way to becoming a household name. Read Andrew Marantz’s Profile of @lesdogggg in this week's issue. Photograph by @jonnotherattman.

A student at Shower of Blessings Junior Bible College has been emboldened by the activism of students nationwide. She lists her imperatives in this week's Shouts and Murmurs, by Paul Rudnick. Illustration by Luci Gutiérrez.
@theaggiediaries enjoys doughnuts and a recent issue of The New Yorker. #newyorkerinthewild #regram
A cartoon by Jacob Samuel, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

When it came to restoring the Florida Everglades, Jeb Bush’s efforts to carve out his own path angered environmentalists and conservatives alike. Dexter Filkins examines, in this week's issue. Illustration by Barry Blitt.

Paid Post: Chef Marcus Samuelsson is reinventing traditional Caribbean fare with Fairmont at Bermuda’s storied Hamilton Princess. Experience @marcuscooks in action at @princessbermuda and see other incredible chefs creating exclusive #fairmontmoments at @theplazahotel’s Palm Court and @fairmontmc’s Nobu.
A cartoon by P.C. Vey. #TNYcartoons
Some of you have asked how to get your hands on this canvas tote bag. With our 12 weeks for $12 subscription plan, you get it for free. Visit the link in our bio to learn more.
The TV show @transparentamazon makes revolutionary art seem both irresistible and inevitable. Read Emily Nussbaum’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @jeannedetallante.

Throughout Wiki's (@wikset) new record, “Lil Me,” he assesses New York’s constant regeneration. The nasal-voiced twenty-two-year-old adores and abhors his city in equal measure, challenged to reconcile the “old blocks” he grew up wandering with the “new kids” that now share his sidewalks. He performs at Aviv in Greenpoint on December 31. Illustration by Celyn Brazier.

With an exuberant president at its helm and half a billion dollars to spend each year, the Ford Foundation is doubling down on combatting inequality. How does it decide what to invest in? Read Larissa MacFarquhar’s “What Money Can Buy” on newyorker.com. Photograph by Andrew Moore.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
@jjoongie always carries a book (usually two) and chocolate in her tote bag. And, of course, a recent issue of The New Yorker. #newyorkerinthewild #regram
Anthony Lane reviews Ron Howard’s “In the Heart of the Sea” and László Nemes’s feature-length début, “Son of Saul,” in this week’s issue. Illustration by @bill_bragg_illustration.

Peter Schickele, the man behind the comic persona of P.D.Q. Bach, is also a talented composer of serious music. On Monday, he plays a fiftieth-anniversary show at Town Hall in New York City. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @benkalt.
The quiet food of Oiji, in New York City's East Village, might have you longing for the chaos of Koreatown. Read Amelia Lester's review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @jamespomerantz.
“This Christmas we are staying in, Skyping en masse with all our kin.” Read the annual Christmas Poem, “Greetings, Friends!,” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Miguel Porlan.
A cartoon by Edward Steed, from this week's issue. #TNYcartoons
“The Big Bag,” by Franco Matticchio, December 13, 1999. See more holiday covers on newyorker.com. #TNYcovers
@zahra_ayub trimmed her tree with a 1942 cover of The New Yorker. #newyorkerinthewild #TNYcovers #regram
Who is behind the grisly murders of four secular bloggers in Bangladesh? Read Samanth Subramanian's piece "The Hit List" on newyorker.com. Illustration by @jhonhersey.
A cartoon by Mick Stevens. #TNYcartoons

In Shouts & Murmurs, Mike Albo and Amanda Duarte offer a list of must-have apps to download in 2016. ”Avoyd: Notifies you when your neighbors have left the building, so you don't have to run into them in the hallway." Illustration by @roman_m.
The Lower East Side’s Bar Goto serves cocktails with ingredients like brined cherry blossom. Read Emma Allen's review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @mikeyburton.
@turnone’s cozy holiday scene. Share your pictures with the hashtag #newyorkerinthewild and we might #regram you.

In the course of nearly four weeks, the Nomads Clinic held five clinics in the Himalayas of Nepal, treating almost seven hundred people. "Some conditions were curable," Solnit writes. "Some were not." The group walked between four and ten hours on the days when clinics were not held, following a steep oval circuit through the mountains that covered about a hundred and forty miles. Read the story on newyorker.com. Map by Carl DeTorres.

In this week's issue, Rebecca Solnit travels to the Dolpo district of northwest Nepal and joins the Nomads Clinic, a medical-service trip, pilgrimage, and adventure expedition started by Joan Halifax in 1980 to provide medical care in places where there is little or none. Pasang Lhamu Sherpa, pictured here, is a record-breaking climber from northeastern Nepal. She and her husband, a physical therapist, began working with the Nomads Clinic in 2013. Photograph by @chiaragoia.

Freddy Mamani Silvestre's teams create the elaborate embellishments of the party halls using wire frames, plaster, and polystyrene, then paint them vividly. The halls accommodate weddings, baptisms, and quinceañeras, which serve as mainstays of the city’s social life. See the entire photo portfolio, by Peter Granser, on newyorker.com.

In Freddy Mamani Silvestre's buildings, ancient motifs, like the Andean Cross and zoomorphic ﬁgures from mythology, are abstracted and merged with futuristic ﬂourishes. See more of Peter Granser's photos on newyorker.com.

Freddy Mamani Silvestre is an Aymara. His people have been subject to successive waves of conquest and dispossession, first by the Inca, then by the Spanish. His architecture incorporates circular motifs from Aymara weaving and ceramics and the neon colors of Aymara dress, and it alludes to the staggered planes of Andean temples. See more on newyorker.com. Photograph by Peter Granser.
El Alto is Bolivia’s newest city. The architect Freddy Mamani Silvestre has said, “I am trying to give it an identity based on Aymara culture.” Photograph by Peter Granser.

In a photo portfolio in this week's issue, Peter Granser captures the futuristic façades and neon colors of the Bolivian architect Freddy Mamani Silvestre's buildings. We'll be sharing photos from the collection throughout the day. Visit newyorker.com to see more.
@natashazoch is wishing for snow, with George Booth’s snowy cover. #newyorkerinthewild #regram
A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

James Surowiecki examines Mark Zuckerberg’s announcement that he will donate ninety-nine percent of his Facebook stock to a new non-profit foundation, and looks at the skepticism surrounding the rise of “philanthrocapitalism.” Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @abstractsunday.

Manu Prakash, a Stanford bioengineer with a passion for all things infinitesimal, has created a microscope that costs less than a dollar. Can it revolutionize global health? In this week's issue, @carolynkormann explores the rise of frugal science. Read "Through the Looking Glass" on newyorker.com. Illustration by Christian Gralingen.
A cartoon by Shannon Wheeler, from this week's issue. #TNYcartoons

Green Day’s Billie Joe Armstrong wrote the songs for “These Paper Bullets!,” the Atlantic Theatre Company’s new musical adaptation of “Much Ado About Nothing,” reset in Beatles-era London. Visit newyorker.com for more information. Illustration by @andrewjrae.
@alliemisch was well prepared for yesterday’s rain in New York City. Share your photos of The New Yorker with the hashtag #newyorkerinthewild. #regram

Paid Post: Since OppenheimerFunds was founded nearly sixty years ago, global literacy has increased twenty-eight percent. Imagine the potential the next sixty years hold. Discover opportunities at oppenheimerfunds.com #TheRightWayToInvest
A cartoon by David Sipress, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com/cartoons. #TNYcartoons

The Pittsburgh native Mac Miller (@larryfisherman) has taken many forms in his short rap career: frat hero, MTV bachelor, tortured recluse, savvy eccentric. Last night, he displayed all of these shades and more at New York City’s Terminal 5. Illustration by @stan_chow.

In the latest episode of our “Comma Queen” video series, copy editor Mary Norris explains how and when to use the ellipsis. “The ellipsis indicates that something has been omitted,” she says. “It could be something you’re trying to gloss over, like a mistake  or an affair, or it could be something unutterably boring, like . . . I can’t think of anything boring enough.” See the video on video.newyorker.com.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller, from this week's issue. #TNYcartoons

Sooner or later—and probably sooner—Miami will have too much water to deal with. Visit newyorker.com to read Elizabeth Kolbert’s piece on the flooding that threatens to dramatically change Miami by the century’s end. Illustration by Jason Escobedo.

Ronnie Spector, of the group the Ronettes, promises the “Best Christmas Party Ever” at City Winery in New York City, Dec. 22-23. With standards like “Be My Baby” and classic renditions of “Sleigh Ride” and “Frosty the Snowman,” it’s a hard holiday evening to beat. Visit newyorker.com for more information. Photograph by @ruvenafanador.
“Marvel’s Jessica Jones,” starring @therealkrystenritter, is a sharp exploration of the superhero as rape survivor, writes Emily Nussbaum. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by Tomer Hanuka.
A cartoon by @tbtoro, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

@gilliehouston’s ideal Sunday situation involves a recent issue of The New Yorker at El Rey Coffee Bar & Luncheonette. Read our review of @elreynyc from earlier this year, on newyorker.com. #newyorkerinthewild #regram

“Christmas has always been a high point for me, ever since I was three and a half and started cartooning,” says George Booth, the eighty-nine-year-old artist behind this week’s cover. See more of his holiday covers on newyorker.com. #TNYcovers

Tune in to @HBO tonight at 9:00 P.M. ET to see “Very Semi-Serious,” a new documentary about New Yorker cartoonists. This morning the magazine’s cartoon editor, Bob Mankoff, the film’s director, Leah Wolchok, and several New Yorker cartoonists rang the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange. Photograph by Valerie Caviness. #TNYcartoons
A cartoon by Emily Flake, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

John Kerry is a political veteran and tireless diplomat. Through extensive interviews in several countries, David Remnick examines the Secretary of State’s tenacious approach to global issues—and whether it can lead to progress in Syria. Read “Negotiating the Whirlwind” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Barry Blitt.

At Mr. Fong’s, in New York City’s Chinatown, bartenders are whipping up Popsicle-hued Tequila Zombies and Salty Plum Old-Fashioneds. Read @jiayangfan's review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @adrian_forrow.
Our new anthology “The 50s: The Story of a Decade” is a history in real time, from the likes of John Updike and Lillian Ross. Visit the link in our bio to learn more.
A cartoon by @mattdiffee, from this week's issue. #TNYcartoons

@devhynes has enjoyed a warm reception downtown and beyond, for his sharp style and affectionate mastery of nineteen-eighties pop tropes. Tonight, proceeds from his show at the Apollo in New York City will go to the Opus 118 Harlem School of Music. “At this point in my life, all that matters to me is giving back to communities and making people happy.” Photograph by @charlieengman.
This week, Malcolm Gladwell reads a new book by Vincent DeVita that argues we could save a hundred thousand patients every year—if we let doctors break the rules. Illustration by Harry Campbell.
A special offer just in time for the holidays: Buy one gift subscription to The New Yorker, and get one free. Visit the link in our bio to learn more.
A cartoon by @farleykatz, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
Le Veau d’Or has been Manhattan French since 1937. In this week’s issue, Adam Gopnik finds out if the restaurant stands the test of time. Photograph by @lrnlncstr.

The D.E.A. strongly defends its use of sting operations in its global pursuit of narco-terrorists: violent offenders with one hand in terrorism and the other in the drug trade. But are they really catching the right people? Read Ginger Thompson’s piece “Trafficking in Terror” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Ben Wiseman.

@jillsoloway, the creator of “Transparent,” is trying to change the way we make entertainment and think about gender. In this week’s issue, Ariel Levy finds out how she plans to topple the patriarchy along the way. Illustration by @stan_chow.
A cartoon by David Sipress. #TNYcartoons

On land, Dick Conant was a homeless loner; on the river he made friends wherever he went. When authorities found the long-distance canoeist’s empty vessel in a North Carolina river last year, they called his acquaintance, New Yorker staff writer Ben McGrath. In this week’s issue, McGrath chronicles an eccentric traveler’s last journey. Map by Carl DeTorres.

A rebellious group of radical conservatives waged a battle against former House Speaker John Boehner. Now they are testing his successor, Paul Ryan—and the stability of the Party. Ryan Lizza reports, in this week’s issue. Illustration by @doble_entendre.
Today’s Daily Cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. #TNYcartoons

This week on @newyorkerphoto, the photographer William Widmer (@misterwidmer) is sharing pictures from his ongoing work about environmental issues in the Gulf Coast. In this image, Terry Lapeyrouse, Jr. weighs shrimp on a dock along Bayou Petit Caillou in the small Louisiana town of Chauvin, where coastal erosion has caused pasture and sugar fields to disappear. #regram
This weekend, riding the success of her viral hit “Queen’s Speech Ep. 4,” the British rapper @imladyleshurr brings her quick, colorful flow to New York City. Illustration by @kristinacollantes.

A free-spirited Navy vet built one of the greatest solo canoeing résumés in modern history. Then he went missing. In this week’s issue, Ben McGrath examines the eccentric life and disappearance of the transcontinental canoeist Dick Conant. Photograph by Victor Schrager.
A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan. #TNYcartoons

The idea of the art installation “Ice Watch” is twofold: the ice is arranged like a watch, or a clock face, to indicate the passing of time; and, in real time, observers will be able to watch the ice melt. If a passerby puts her ear to the ice, she will be able to hear a little moment of pop and crack, the release of the cleanest possible air. “It is a little pop that has travelled fifteen thousand years to meet you in Paris, and tell the story of climate change,” says the Icelandic artist Olafur Eliasson. Photograph by Eric Feferberg / AFP / Getty.
A cartoon by Liam Francis Walsh, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

The performance artist Marina Abramović’s new project is meant to fully immerse listeners in Bach’s music, an effort that involves first relinquishing cell phones and sitting in silence. Abramović teams up with the pianist Igor Levit (@igorpianist) for the performance, starting tonight at the @parkavearmory in New York City. Illustration by @pingszoo.

@thejennchen fittingly paired this recent issue—which features a coffee-centric cover by @abstractsunday—with an espresso at @soloesp. Thanks for sharing your #newyorkerinthewild. Show us what you’re reading, and where, by using the hashtag.

A Jamo & Ginga (ginger ale topped with a Jameson nip, plus lemon and some bitters) at @genuineliquorette in New York City tastes like a gussied-up dorm-room cocktail and drinks like the regrettable make-out session that ensues: inconsistent, awkward, and unnecessarily sloppy. Read more from @thecooperrrr’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Kris Mukai.
A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan. #TNYcartoons

When dining at Ravi DeRossi’s new “passion project,” a vegan restaurant in New York City’s East Village, you get the sense of having travelled through a wormhole to an alternate universe where animal products never existed, so they could never be missed. Read @silviakillings’s review of Avant Garden on newyorker.com. Photograph by Zachary Zavislak.
This season in New York, enduring plays by Dylan Thomas and Thornton Wilder conjure holidays past. Illustration by Carson Ellis.

Roger Angell, a ninety-five-year-old senior editor and staff writer, has contributed to The New Yorker since 1944 and was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame last year, for his writing on the sport. This year, he won a National Magazine Award for his essay “This Old Man,” about aging, loss, and love. On this week’s episode of The New Yorker Radio Hour, Angell speaks with David Remnick about writing in his tenth decade. Visit newyorker.com/podcast to tune in, or subscribe to the podcast.
A cartoon by Roz Chast, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
As he navigates Munich during Oktoberfest, a man observes varying reactions to the refugee crisis. Read Martin Amis’s new short story, in this week’s issue. Illustration by Golden Cosmos.

“What would it look like if I took America’s obsession with firearms to its logical extreme?” says the artist Eric Drooker about “Shopping Days,” his cover for next week’s issue. Read more on newyorker.com.
The latest film adaptation of “Macbeth,” starring Michael Fassbender and Marion Cotillard, is particularly dark and bloody. Read Anthony Lane’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Bill Bragg.
A cartoon by Harry Bliss. #TNYcartoons

In “Pets Allowed,” the first installment of our new “Shorts & Murmurs” humor video series, The New Yorker’s  Marc Philippe Eskenazi goes undercover around New York City with an array of “emotional support animals” in tow. The video is inspired by Patricia Marx’s 2014 piece, which chronicled the rise of therapist-certified emotional-support animals in places that generally enforce strict human-only policies. Click the link in our bio to see the video.

The artist Kim Keever releases paints into an aquarium to create otherworldly nature scenes. See more of his dreamy aquatic photographs in the Photo Booth section of newyorker.com. Courtesy Kim Keever / Waterhouse & Dodd.

With free classes, shows, and festivals, the community-based organization DreamYard is changing lives in the Bronx. Read Ian Frazier’s piece “Bronx Dreams” on newyorker.com. Photograph by @landonnordeman.
A cartoon by @drewdernavich. #TNYcartoons

The composer Julia Wolfe’s “Steel Hammer” distills the many folklore versions of John Henry—the legendary railroad steel driver who died after winning a contest of strength against a steam-powered hammer—into a compelling, unified image. The work has been reinvented as music drama, opening tonight at @bam_brooklyn’s Harvey Theatre. Photograph by @ryanpfluger.

A leading neurosurgeon intentionally introduced bacteria into patients’ brains during surgery in an effort to combat a deadly type of tumor. Was this unusual and untested therapy innovation or overreach? Emily Eakin investigates, in this week’s issue. Illustration by Patrik Svensson.
As the climate-change summit kicks off in Paris, James Surowiecki scrutinizes the U.S. government’s relationship with the coal industry. Illustration by @abstractsunday.
A cartoon by Mick Stevens, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

In Shouts & Murmurs this week, Mike O’Brien offers tips for living an alternative-comedy life style: “After you stop volunteering at the senior citizens’ home, get the most normal job ever. The more normal, the more hilarious.” Illustration by Simone Massoni.

In America’s immigration system, the link between crime, mental illness, and trauma is largely ignored. The New Yorker’s Rachel Aviv examines the psychological struggles refugees face, and how the U.S. is unprepared to help. Illustration by Keith Negley.
A cartoon by Christopher Weyant, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Paid Post: When you bring people together this holiday season, bring together new flavors, like the notes of orange that enhance the palate of #TheGlenlivet Founder’s Reserve. Find new recipes and ideas at theglenlivetcask.com. @theglenlivet_us

The cover for this week’s issue, “Mirror,” becomes a story of its own in an animated video. The video, narrated by Ira Glass and co-produced by “This American Life,” was illustrated by Chris Ware and John Kuramoto and features music by Nico Muhly. Visit newyorker.com to see the video. #TNYcovers

The visual and verbal language of gender fluidity has become a minefield, Anthony Lane writes, and the film “The Danish Girl” is a master class in how to tiptoe through it. Read his review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @tina_berning.

Several lines of research have recently revealed a link between inflammation and chronic disease. But that doesn’t necessarily mean trendy anti-inflammation diets are the key to health. In this week’s issue, Jerome Groopman explores the debate over the latest cure-all. Read “Inflamed” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @chadhagen.
@jimeroo caught up with a recent issue of The New Yorker at @the.peanut.vendor, in London. #regram #newyorkerinthewild
Tune in to @cbssundaymorning today to see David Remnick and a behind-the-scenes look at The New Yorker. Here, the show’s iconic logo as depicted by our own Roz Chast.

In Shouts & Murmurs, Hallie Cantor offers G.P.S. directions for getting home drunk: “As you exit the bodega, arrive at the realization that you still have no idea where you're going. Open the Uber app on your phone, then remember all those articles you considered reading about how the sharing economy is terrible for workers and reverse course. Recalculating.” Illustration by @jean_jullien.

Caitlin Doughty (@thegooddeath) is a Los Angeles undertaker who wants to end our estrangement from death. The New Yorker’s Rebecca Mead explores a field that has become increasingly focussed on customization, with funerals ranging from a luncheon featuring the deceased’s favorite recipes to natural burial in a National Park. Read her piece on the rise of the artisanal funeral on newyorker.com. Photograph by @hollyandres.
In this week’s Bar Tab, @stolincokes tries the ales and spirits at Caledonia, a whiskey bar on New York City’s Upper East Side. Illustration by @boyounillo.
A cartoon from the archive by Liza Donnelly. #TNYcartoons
A plucky ensemble of child rockers take the stage in Andrew Lloyd Webber’s new musical, “School of Rock,” at New York City’s Winter Garden Theater. Photograph by @will_mebane.

This week’s Goings On About Town offers several ways to celebrate the holidays in New York City, from a Hanukkah Family Party at @thejewishmuseum to the Holiday Train Show at the @nybg. Visit newyorker.com to learn more. Illustration by @roman_m.

On a desolate block in Tribeca, there’s a sweet little subterranean sushi den with nine seats and a rare, rather sublime intimacy. Read Shauna Lyon’s review of Sushi Azabu on newyorker.com. Photograph by @jeremy_liebman.
A cartoon from the archive by Danny Shanahan. #TNYcartoons
A cartoon by Zachary Kanin. #TNYcartoons

@gigilaub has been taking pictures of her family for sixteen years. She likes photographing Thanksgiving in particular. “It’s the day my family feels at its best,” she notes. Here, her father and grandfather carve and taste the turkey on Thanksgiving in 2002. Visit @newyorkerphoto to see more images of her family over the years. #regram
A cartoon by Mick Stevens. #TNYcartoons
A cartoon by Roz Chast. #TNYcartoons
This week, Joan Acocella explores the evolution of tap dancing, which, as it grew alongside jazz, emerged with its own special technique and rhythmic qualities. Illustration by @simonemassoni.

Can a retired neurosurgeon become a Presidential candidate without becoming a politician, too? Kelefa Sanneh examines the unlikely rise of Ben Carson, in this week’s issue. Photograph by @markpetersonpixs.

“Purpose” is not subtle about @justinbieber’s desire for rebirth. On many songs, a love interest acts as a stand-in for a public that has turned on him, demanding apologies and repentance. Read Carrie Battan’s review of the new album on newyorker.com. Illustration by @kristianhammerstad.
A cartoon by Amy Hwang, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
Is science kind of a scam? Adam Gopnik examines, in this week’s issue. Illustration by Oliver Munday.

The British photographer Mark Power captures the poignant memorial outside the Bataclan Theatre in Paris on the Tuesday following the attacks. See more of images in his Slide Show, “Paris Overnight,” on newyorker.com.

In a dispatch from Paris, Alexandra Schwartz speaks with a cross-section of Parisians—including a survivor of the attacks—about the aftermath of the violence. Read “The Long Night” in this week’s issue and on newyorker.com. Illustration by @abstractsunday.
A cartoon by William Haefeli, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Paid Post: According to a 2010 U.N. study, cell phones have been one of history’s most effective tools at lifting people out of poverty. What will the next big thing be? oppenheimerfunds.com #TheRightWayToInvest

Marco Rubio made a swift rise from local politics in Miami to the Senate in Washington. Now running for President, will his desire to simultaneously embrace competing views—on terrorism, immigration, and abortion—be the biggest political hurdle he faces? Evan Osnos profiles the candidate, in this week’s issue. Photograph by @markpetersonpixs.

“It’s horrible when war comes knocking at your door. This is where I live—it’s my neighborhood,” says the Parisian artist Charles Berberian about “Paris, November 2015,” his cover for this week’s issue. “The day after the attacks, Saturday, it was so calm here….No one was in the streets. This week though, people are back out.”

Ann Beattie’s short story in this week’s issue is about a lawyer grappling with loneliness after losing his wife to medical malpractice. In a Q. & A. on newyorker.com with our fiction editor, Deborah Treisman, Beattie explains how she drew inspiration for the story from a bumper sticker. Illustration by @theheadsofstate.
Alban Berg’s “Lulu” at the @metopera is a work of complexity and intensity that also succeeds in being funny, Alex Ross writes. Read more on newyorker.com. Photograph by @jeffbrownjeffbrown.
The film “Carol” is a visually stunning tale of forbidden love, Anthony Lane writes. Read the review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @matttaylordraws.
A cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

At Shrine World Music Venue, in Harlem, the walls are decorated with African art, and Red Stripe beer is welcome on the dance floor. Read Nicolas Niarchos’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @pengtagram.
The overly acidic notes of @virginiasnyc’s menu left @silviakillings longing for simple bread and butter. Read her review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @davideluciano.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

As literary subjects go, weather has a terrible reputation. This week, Kathryn Schulz examines the shifting role of meteorology in literature, from Greek mythology to Mark Twain. Visit newyorker.com to read “Writers in the Storm.” Illustration by Aude Van Ryn.
Why don’t we just print more money to stimulate the economy? This week, John Cassidy examines a radical solution to the current economic malaise. Illustration by David Plunkert.

In this week’s issue, Emily Witt meets the eccentric couple—a pair of self-described “tech-hippie liberals” and “drug geeks”—behind the twenty-year-old Web site Erowid, an expansive open-sourced encyclopedia with detailed profiles on more than three hundred and ﬁfty psychoactive substances, which has become a primary resource for recreational users, toxicologists, and ER doctors alike. Read “The Trip Planners” on newyorker.com.
Today’s Daily Cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. #TNYcartoons

This week, The New York Public Library’s Picture Collection is taking over @newyorkerphoto’s feed to celebrate its centennial. Here, a behind-the-scenes look at how @nyplpicturecollection organizes its images. The “FL” tray is for any subject heading that begins with those letters, such as Flags, Flames, and Flashlights. More popular subject headings, like “Flowers,” are subdivided into dozens, and in some cases hundreds, of subheadings. @nypl’s centennial exhibition, 100 Years of the Picture Collection: From Abacus to Zoology, is open now.

The video game Bandit’s Shark Showdown, which aims to create a visceral link between the player’s body and a simulated dolphin, is a radical new approach to treating stroke patients. Read Karen Russell’s “Helping Hand” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @bryanchristiedesign.

Glamour, according to Jacqueline de Ribes, “is a worldly style, lots of allure, a touch of flamboyance, a deep know-how, all wrapped up in natural seduction.” This dress, designed by the Paris-born countess in 1988, is one of sixty ensembles in an exhibition devoted to the eighty-six-year-old’s impeccable style, which opens tonight at the Costume Institute at the @MetMuseum. Photograph by @paridukovic.

Over the weekend, @renyags sat down to read “The Gene Hackers,” Michael Specter’s piece on a breakthrough gene technology, from last week’s issue. CRISPR’s unprecedented ability to edit genetic code is expected to lead to a new generation of medical treatments. #regram #newyorkerinthewild

Humans have survived fires, floods, and storms for thousands of years. Can they survive an innovation of their own making? Raffi Khatchadourian profiles the philosopher Nick Bostrom and explores the future of artificial intelligence, in our annual Tech Issue. Illustration by @toddstjohn.
A cartoon by Kim Warp. #TNYcartoons

In “Pike St.,” Nilaja Sun’s new ninety-minute solo piece (presented by Epic Theatre Ensemble at Abrons Arts Center in New York City, through Dec. 6), Sun tells the tale of a mother trying to make the best life she can for her disabled daughter, in the face of a changing world. Illustration by @srsalme.

In an age of “cord cutting”—people abandoning traditional cable packages for streaming services—the media industry is facing radical uncertainty. Why might Time Warner benefit from spinning off HBO, its most valuable asset? James Surowiecki explains, in this week’s issue. Illustration by @abstractsunday.

The HBO show “Getting On” is set in a failing extended-care ward whose patients are elderly women. Its signature is a pungent blend of compassion and nihilism—a sensibility that may be recognizable to anyone who has floated in the miasmic half-life of a hospital. Visit newyorker.com to read Emily Nussbaum’s reviews of “Getting On” and “Master of None,” @azizansari’s new Netflix comedy. Illustration by @stevewacksman.

Megan Phelps-Roper had been taught the Westboro Baptist Church’s message since birth, and she joined Twitter to spread its doctrine. But when she was faced with questions she couldn't answer, her steadfast belief began to erode. Visit newyorker.com to read "Unfollow," by Adrian Chen. Photograph by @katygrannan.
A cartoon by Corey Pandolph, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Paid Post: At the New Yorker Festival, top chefs came together for a conversation sponsored by The Glenlivet that explored how our own personal histories inspire the food and drink we create. See the flavors and stories #TheGlenlivet has been unlocking for nearly two centuries at @theglenlivet_us.
The artist Seth’s “Virtual Music” is the cover of our annual Tech Issue, out this week. Read about the cartoonist on newyorker.com. #TNYcovers
@kelelam, @janetjackson, and @erykahbadu are coming to Brooklyn. Visit newyorker.com to find more details in our Winter Night Life Preview. Illustration by Heidi Chisholm.
Today’s Daily Cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz. #TNYcartoons
At Bruno, in New York City's East Village, two alums of Roberta’s aim to make virtuous, inventive pizza. Read Amelia Lester’s review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @meredithjenks.

The photographer Angie Smith captures a hallucinatory scene at the Bradbury Building, in downtown Los Angeles, during a performance of “Hopscotch.” Alex Ross calls the opera "a combination of road trip, architecture tour, contemporary-music festival, and waking dream.” Read his piece “Opera on Location” on newyorker.com.

During a performance of “Hopscotch,” The New Yorker’s Alex Ross rides an elevator with Marja Kay, the singer playing the role of Lucha in the scene, and two French-horn players. Nineteen women portray Lucha over the course of the opera, each wearing a yellow dress. Photograph by Angie Smith.
One World Trade Center, home of The New Yorker, shines for Paris tonight.

During the opera “Hopscotch,” which Alex Ross writes about in this week’s issue, audience members ride around Los Angeles in a fleet of limousines, witnessing scenes that take place both inside the vehicles and at designated sites. Ross writes, “By design, you feel uneasy as you move around the city in vehicles associated with fame and wealth. Getting in and out, you are gawked at, until people realize that you are not famous.” See more of Angie Smith’s behind-the-scenes photographs of the performance on newyorker.com.

In this week’s issue, Alex Ross reports from the set of “Hopscotch,” a “mobile opera”—and a considerable feat of logistics—featuring Los Angeles as its stage. Today, we’ll be sharing some of Angie Smith’s behind-the-scenes photographs of the experimental performance. Visit newyorker.com to read Alex Ross’s piece “Opera on Location” and to see more images.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

Like its spiritual hero, Ron Burgundy of “Anchorman,” this popular new Will Ferrell-themed bar on Manhattan’s Lower East Side is a loud, swinging, bad-taste good time. Read Sarah Larson’s review of Stay Classy on newyorker.com. Illustration by Daniel Krall.

In A.D. 79, the eruption of Mt. Vesuvius destroyed a library of scrolls in the Roman town Herculaneum. For centuries, the carbonized scrolls have stymied papyrologists. Can digital technology make them legible after two thousand years? In this week’s issue, John Seabrook joins the quest to unlock an ancient library.  Illustration by @chadhagen.

The latest 007 film, “Spectre,” jumps so remorselessly between countries and climates that many viewers will find the film too episodic for its own good, Anthony Lane writes. Read the review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @srsalme.
A cartoon by Drew Dernavich. #TNYcartoons

Born in Bible-belt Texas, the trans twenty-seven-year-old Juliana Huxtable is a d.j., an emphatic poet, a model, and a muse. At MOMA on Nov. 13 and 14, Huxtable performs a new three-part ode to post-identity politics as part of “Performa 15,” the performance-art festival sprawling through New York City this month. Photograph by @shaedetar.

To reach the Land of Caucuses and Primaries, the Candidate must first cross the Sea of Polls. Lately, it has become deeper and darker than ever before. In this week's issue, Jill Lepore examines the decline in effectiveness of political polls, as well as their increasing influence. Read the story on newyorker.om. Illustration by @doble_entendre.

In Shouts & Murmurs, Annabelle Gurwitch unsubscribes from various bothersome mailing lists: “Dear Google+, Not only do I not want to know when someone adds me to his or her circle, I have no idea what Google+ is, what a ‘circle’ is, or why I am being added to one.” Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @timlahan.
A cartoon by P.C. Vey, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

In Taylor Mac’s play “Hir,” directed by Niegel Smith at Playwrights Horizons, a wife uses estrogen treatments to make her violent husband docile. Read Hilton Als’s review, on newyorker.com. Photograph by @dollyfaibyshev.

CRISPR, a powerful new technology that enables us to manipulate our genetic code with unprecedented ease, may have the potential to unravel the mysteries of autism, contribute to a cure for cancer, and remove the allergens from peanuts. So why are some scientists leery of the breakthrough technology? Michael Specter examines, in this week’s issue. Read “The Gene Hackers” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @toddstjohn.
In this week’s Shouts & Murmurs, women seeking condoms (Satan’s rubber sombreros) at Unplanned Parenthood will be sent to the Sin Pits. Illustration by @taxali.
A cartoon by Drew Dernavich. See more cartoons on newyorker.com/cartoons. #TNYcartoons
The soprano Marlis Petersen returns to the title role of Alban Berg’s “Lulu” in a new staging by William Kentridge at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City. Illustration by @olimpiazagnoli.

In this week’s Tables for Two, Adam Gopnik visits the chef Gabriel Kreuther’s eponymous new N.Y.C. restaurant, which might be called post-nouvelle. Read the review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @jamespomerantz.

When Elizabeth Haysom’s parents were brutally murdered, she and her college boyfriend, Jens Soering, were convicted of the crime. Nathan Heller examines why, nearly thirty years after the case was closed, so many unanswered questions remain. Read “Blood Ties” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Oliver Munday; photographs: AP.
A cartoon by Roz Chast, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

The New York City bar-restaurant Macao Trading Co. suggests the sumptuous surfeit of old-world Shanghai (antique roulette wheels, birdcages, porcelain Buddhas), while also dipping into darker indulgences for which the sin city of Macau is known (opium pipes, sepia photos of provocatively clad women). Read @jiayangfan’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @boyounillo.

While “income inequality” has, for the past few years, been a key phrase for Democrats, it is one that Republicans don’t invoke. In this week’s issue, George Packer examines the G.O.P.’s middle-class problem, in which few candidates have been willing to confront the real issues facing lower-income voters. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by @nishantchoksi.
A cartoon by Bruce Eric Kaplan, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

E.D.M. can serve as a safe haven for artists who have lost their place in the mainstream—and even the most popular d.j.s need vocalists, like @elliegoulding, to make hit songs. What does this commingling mean for the genre? Read Carrie Battan’s “Past Peak” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Drushba Pankow.
This week, the photographer @rossmcdonnell is taking over @newyorkerphoto’s feed, sharing images as he travels around Eastern Ukraine. Here is a portrait of a rebel fighter nicknamed Fougasse.

With little money, few instruments, and no expectations of fame, an orchestra of self-taught classical musicians in the Democratic Republic of the Congo has attracted international acclaim. Alexis Okeowo looks at the rise of the unexpected ensemble, in this week’s issue. Illustration by Josh Cochran.
A cartoon by @willmcphail4, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

“To spend time in the company of a rescue crew is to see the country as a grid of horrible accidents and comical false alarms,” writes Nick Paumgarten about Iceland's search-and-rescue volunteers. For them, “Life is rescues.” Read Paumgarten’s piece on newyorker.com. Photograph by @benlowy.

Here, a forty-two-year-old banker named Elvar swims through snowmelt in the mountains of Landmannalaugar, Iceland, to rescue a family of tourists. A guide tells Nick Paumgarten, “If you’re a dude who wants to come here and do your bucket list and put your picture up on Facebook, you’ll go home in a black bag.” Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @benlowy.
The photographer @benlowy captures a search-and-rescue volunteer on patrol in Landmannalaugar, Iceland.  Read “Life Is Rescues” on newyorker.com.

Iceland's volunteer search-and-rescue squad, known by its acronym, ICE-SAR, saves missing hikers, stranded sheep, and helpless tourists. The group’s members are well equipped, self-funded, and enjoy a near-mythical reputation among their countrymen. Nick Paumgarten joins the search, in this week’s issue. Today, we’ll be sharing some of @benlowy’s photographs of the volunteers here. Visit newyorker.com to see more.
A cartoon by Edward Steed. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

Mary Gaitskill's new novel, “The Mare,” explores how intimacy between two people is formed: in fits and starts, and at different speeds. Read Alexandra Schwartz’s review on newyorker.com. Photograph by Dru Donovan.

This week, Anthony Lane reviews Tom McCarthy’s new film, starring Rachel McAdams, Michael Keaton, Mark Ruffalo, and Brian d’Arcy James as Boston Globe reporters investigating reports of child abuse by local Catholic clergy. “‘Spotlight’ comes across as the year’s least relaxing film, thanks to the attention that McCarthy and his fellow-screenwriter, Josh Singer, oblige you to pay,” Lane writes. Illustration by R. Kikuo Johnson.

About a year ago, Wendy Whelan retired from New York City Ballet, to bushels of flowers and not a few tears. Perhaps those tears were a bit premature. Now freelance, Whelan gets to call the shots. Her latest gig, “Hagoromo,” is a collaboration with her husband, the visual artist David Michalek, who directs the show at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The story involves an angel who loses her magical garment and the fisherman who finds it. The angel, of course, is Whelan. Photograph by @ioulex.
A cartoon by Bob Mankoff, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

“This image was inspired by a conversation with friends about the pleasure of walking through leaves—they thought of it after they moved to San Francisco,” the illustrator John Cuneo says of “Rolling Out the Gold Carpet,” his cover for this week’s issue. Read more about his inspiration on newyorker.com. #TNYcovers

At Dutch Kills, a whip-thin saloon in Long Island City, New York, the cocktails are almost self-conciously “craft,” writes Nicolas Niarchos. Read his review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Michael Kirkham.

Maurice Pialat's 1971 miniseries “The House in the Woods” portrays characters who are ravaged by the dangers and dislocations of the First World War, Richard Brody writes. Illustration by Victor Melamed.

The icon on a sign that identifies a business as a barbecue joint, in the way that a striped pole would indicate a barbershop, is a pig—usually a pig that looks remarkably cheerful considering the fate that has befallen the pigs to be found inside. In this week’s issue, Calvin Trillin explores the fight for authenticity in North Carolina barbecue. Photograph by @brianfinke.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

In Shouts & Murmurs this week, Ethan Kuperberg imagines how Bernie Sanders greets trick-or-treaters: “What are you? Speak up, I can’t hear you. A vampire? Huh. With the black suit and the fangs? I thought you were some sorta Wall Street guy. My mistake.” Illustration by Victor Kerlow.
In a Sketchbook in this week’s issue, Barry Blitt envisions Halloween costumes of the New York @Mets.

Everyone’s invited—but costumes are required—to march in the Village Halloween Parade, one of the city’s most exuberant traditions. “It’s a time for people in the most modern city in the world to come out and behave in a completely primitive way,” Jeanne Fleming, the event’s longtime director, told The New Yorker in 1989. (Sixth Ave. heading north from Canal St. to 16th St. tonight at 7 P.M.) Illustration by Jordan Awan.
A cartoon by @tbtoro. Visit our website to see more. #TNYcartoons

New York’s sodium-vapor street lamps cast a soft, yellowish glow. The city is slowly replacing these with light-emitting diodes, which will burn more brightly, if less mellifluously, and will save fourteen million dollars a year in energy and maintenance costs. By 2017, if everything goes according to plan, all the old bulbs—including the one above, photographed recently by @paridukovic in Tompkins Square Park—will have gone the way of the pay phone.
The revived Jams restaurant on New York City's Upper East Side harkens back to the opulence of Manhattan in the eighties. Read Amelia Lester’s review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @erichelgas.

Lauren Groff's new novel, “Fates and Furies,” tells the story of a marriage from two different perspectives—the husband’s and then the wife’s—and explores the fierce asymmetry of the two versions. Read James Wood’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Vivienne Flesher.

Charles Spence is proving that taste can be altered through color, shape, or sound alone. In this year’s Food Issue, Nicola Twilley looks at the experimental psychologist's work. Illustration by  @olimpiazagnoli.

Inside our annual Food Issue, out this week: Michael Specter on the quest for healthy fast food; Dana Goodyear on the merits of seaweed; Nicola Twilley on how a food’s packaging changes its flavor; Lauren Collins on the World’s 50 Best Restaurants list; and more. Pick up a copy or visit newyorker.com. Here, a look at this week’s cover, “Comfort Food,” by Ivan Brunetti, and previous Food Issues. #TNYcovers

Shrewd grammarians thought they discovered a mistake in Mary Norris’s book, “Between You and Me.” Shouldn’t “younger than me” be “younger than I”? The author and copy editor settles the case in the latest episode of our “Comma Queen” video series, produced  by @skydylanrobbins and @nate_lavey. #CommaQueen

In the Food Issue, on newsstands this week, Lauren Collins explores how a guide that began as a stunt became a mighty arbiter of fine food. She spoke with the chef @davidchang, who recalled balking at attending the World’s 50 Best Restaurants awards ceremony in London. “I can criticize it all I want,” he said, “but it’s so powerful.”

The first World’s 50 Best Restaurants list started when a group of food editors asked themselves, Where would you want to go if you weren’t French, rich, or old? Visit newyorker.com to read Lauren Collins’s piece “Who’s to Judge?” Illustration by @freebrianrea.
A cartoon by @farleykatz from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Almond-milk drinkers have often exhibited a special sort of self-righteousness, but they must now confront the nut's ecological impact. Read Dana Goodyear’s “What Milk Should I Drink?” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @chrisdelorenzo.

In our Food Issue, Dana Goodyear explores the emerging market for seaweed, which could be on its way to replacing kale as the most culturally ubiquitous green—if we can figure out how to make it taste good. Read “A New Leaf” on newyorker.com. Photograph by Kim Keever.

For-profit colleges in America game the taxpayer-funded financial-aid system by encouraging students to borrow as much as possible, James Surowiecki writes. Spiralling student debt isn't incidental to the rise of these colleges—it’s the business model. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @abstractsunday.
A cartoon from this week's issue, by Roz Chast. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

Fatty, salty meals remain far cheaper to produce, distribute, and buy than healthier alternatives. As the public’s tastes move toward kale and quinoa, big chain restaurants are trying to keep up. Read Michael Specter’s “Freedom from Fries” in our annual Food Issue. Photograph by @andrewbmyers.

The creators of “The Leftovers” are willing to risk the ridiculous in search of something profound, Emily Nussbaum writes. Read her review of the HBO show’s second season, on newyorker.com. Illustration by Emiliano Ponzi.

“I’m always buying gadgets for the kitchen,” says Ivan Brunetti, the artist behind “Comfort Food,” the cover of this week’s Food Issue. He continues: “I got a bread-maker, two different kinds of waffle-makers, a food processor, at least two blenders, a mixing set, a coffee grinder, lots of pots and pans, a nice wok, a huge stockpot, and probably even more stuff, but I seldom cook, and rarely use any of them.” Read more about this week’s cover on newyorker.com. #TNYcovers

In Lesley Nneka Arimah’s story from this week’s issue, a girl lives in a world where women must construct their own children, whether from porcelain, raffia, or mud. Read “Who Will Greet You at Home” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Jeffrey Fisher.
A cartoon by Michael Maslin, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

Alexander von Humboldt was a naturalist, an inventor, and a prolific author. Several of his books became international best-sellers, and inspired figures as diverse as Charles Darwin and Simón Bolívar. This week, Elizabeth Kolbert looks at the legacy of the world’s most celebrated explorer. Illustration by ATAK.

“Bridge of Spies” is the product of the first collaboration between the Coen brothers and Steven Spielberg. It’s a happy merger, Anthony Lane writes. Read his review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Olivier Balez.
In Shouts & Murmurs, Paul Rudnick offers a diagnostic exam: Do You Have Math Anxiety? Illustration by Yann Kebbi.

The Belgian theatre director Ivo van Hove pushes his actors emotionally and physically; injuries are not uncommon during productions. “He never asks me to do what I can do—he leads me to do things I didn’t know I could do,” one actress tells Rebecca Mead in this week’s issue. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @nadavkander.

Join us for the début of The New Yorker Radio Hour. In Episode One, David Remnick speaks with Ta-Nehisi Coates, @aw performs a Shouts & Murmurs piece, and Evan Osnos talks about sexism in politics with Senator Kirsten Gillibrand. Check your local listings or subscribe to the podcast. Illustration by Pete Gamlen.
The East Village’s Hummus Place has transformed into Timna, a more upscale and Pinterest-ready restaurant. Read @silviakillings’s review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @dina_litovsky.
For fourteen years, the Nolita bar Tropical 128 has been a haven for low-key drinkers and near-dawn gyrators. Read @emmaewallen’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Daniel Krall.

This week, Ed Kashi is taking over @newyorkerphoto’s Instagram feed to document The Millennium Villages Project, which addresses the root causes of extreme poverty, taking a holistic, community-led approach to sustainable development. Here is a young girl in Bonsaaso, Ghana, on October 4, 2015. Photograph by @edkashi/@viiphoto.
A cartoon by Michael Crawford, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
In a Web-based world, it’s harder to escape a bully—and easier to become one. Read Maria Konnikova’s “How the Internet Has Changed Bullying” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Min Heo.

The bright, bubbly actress Annaleigh Ashford’s newest project seems likely to boost her rising star: A. R. Gurney’s crowd-pleasing comedy, “Sylvia” (opening Oct. 27, at the Cort), about a New York couple who adopt a stray dog. Ashford plays the dog. Illustration by @kyle.t.webster.

Members of Mongolia’s traditional nomadic clans domesticate golden eagles to hunt foxes and other animals. Many of the men talk about loving the eagles like their own children. The photographer Palani Mohan documents the bond between man and bird in the Altai mountains. Photograph by Palani Mohan/Courtesy Merrell Publishers.
A cartoon by Dan Abromowitz and Eli Dreyfus. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
Robert O’Hara’s play “Barbecue” feeds on the junk of our times—and spits it out, Hilton Als writes. Read his review, on newyorker.com. Illustration by Heidi Chisholm.

Social media has had a profound effect on the migrant crisis. The founder of the widely used private Facebook group Asylum and Immigration Without Smugglers, a Syrian known as Abu Amar, has become “a real-time Harriet Tubman” for refugees, and provides maps such as this one. With the assistance of Abu Amar, fellow-refugees, and European smugglers, Ghaith—whose story is told in this week’s issue—reached Sweden in early July. “You are now under the custody of Sweden,” the immigration officer who processed him said. “Sweden will take care of you.” You can read Nicholas Schmidle’s piece “Ten Borders” on newyorker.com.

This week, Nicholas Schmidle tells the story of one twenty-four-year-old law student’s epic escape from Syria—a fraught year-long journey that, after several foiled attempts, eventually led him to Sweden. Read “Ten Borders” on newyorker.com. Photograph by Moises Saman/Magnum.
A cartoon by Emily Flake, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

In this week's issue, Ryan Lizza examines why Jeb Bush, the would-be G.O.P. front-runner, is “trailing behind a clutch of candidates, among them Donald Trump and Ben Carson, who have never held public office and encourage comparison to buffoons.” Read “What Would Jeb Do?” on newyorker.com. Illustration by André Carrilho.

From as early as the second century B.C. until the Spanish arrived, eighteen hundred years later, wealthy Incans, Aztecs, and their forebears were laid to rest with miniature palaces, ball courts, houses, and temples, built by pre-Columbian craftsmen. The first show on the subject in the United States, “Design for Eternity: Architectural Models for the Ancient Americas,” opens at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Oct. 26. Photograph by @erichelgas.
What accounts for the extraordinary wiring of the human mind? Read Kelly Clancy’s “The Strangers In Your Brain,” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @rrebekkaa.
A cartoon by William Haefeli, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

This week, Kelefa Sanneh listens to Joanna Newsom’s new album, “Divers.” “It is easier to describe what she does than what she makes. She is, equally, a singer and an instrumentalist, a song-writer and a composer; within indie rock and far beyond it, there is virtually no one whose music doesn’t seem a little casual, or careless, by comparison.” Read more on newyorker.com. Photograph by @birthepiontek.

“It’s incredible how people find the strength needed to flee from war and violence, to get on a rickety boat or walk endlessly with their small children and then attempt to make a new life in another country,” the artist Lorenzo Mattotti says of “On the Way,” his cover for this week’s issue. #TNYcovers

The film “Steve Jobs” veers closer to Vincente Minnelli’s bio-pic of van Gogh than to “The Social Network,” Anthony Lane writes. Read his review of the surprisingly old-fashioned homage to Apple's founder, on newyorker.com. Illustration by Cun Shi.
A cartoon by @steinbergdrawscartoons, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

Riad Sattouf has emerged as France’s best-known graphic novelist. He has cited Hergé as one of his primary influences, but his sensibility is closer to “South Park” than to “Tintin.” Read Adam Shatz’s Profile of the Charlie Hebdo cartoonist in this week’s issue. Photograph by @olaf_blecker.

On Thursdays, the speakeasy Gin Fizz, on Malcolm X Blvd., hosts Harlem Sessions—“a bit of soul music, a bit of jazz, and a bit of Jamaican.” Read Nicolas Niarchos’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @andreakalfas.

Order well at Seamore’s and you’ll have a meal that is spectacular in its simplicity. Read Shauna Lyon’s review of the beachy canteen at the edge of New York’s Little Italy, on newyorker.com. Photograph by @will_mebane.
A cartoon by Dan Abromowitz and Eli Dreyfus, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

This week, Dan Chiasson reads Robin Coste Lewis’s début poetry collection, “Voyage of the Sable Venus and Other Poems,” which derives its title from a notorious eighteenth-century engraving by Thomas Stothard. Illustration by @tonyrodriguezillustration.

We’re thrilled to bring The New Yorker to the radio with a new weekly, hour-long program hosted by our own David Remnick and co-produced by @WNYC Studios. Tune in to the first show on the radio, on the road, or online one week from today, on Saturday, October 24 (check your local listings or subscribe to the podcast).
A cartoon by Brian McLachlan. #TNYcartoons

This week, Ed Park reads a collection of dark, funny South Korean fiction that is introducing American readers to the country’s existential tumult and humor. Read “Sorry Not Sorry” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @hannahkleeee.

This week on @newyorkerphoto, the photographer Lauren Lancaster (@lrnlncstr) is taking a road trip along the Ohio River, where she is looking at the relationship between industry, environment, and culture as it pertains to the well-being of the river and the people who live along it. Here, Rob Walters of Three Rivers Water Keepers, in Pittsburgh, points at industrial effluents leaking into the Ohio River while out on routine patrol.

For some new businesses, the medieval guild represents a way of cultivating habits of excellence and communizing resources like office space, companionship, and broadband. Read Nathan Schneider’s “The New Guilded Age” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Boyoun Kim.
A cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

For decades, Laurie Anderson has been holding a skeptical mirror up to America’s shiny pop surfaces and techniques of social control. In this week’s issue, Alex Ross writes about his visit to Anderson’s installation “Habeas Corpus,” at the Park Avenue Armory. Photograph by @paridukovic.
In this week’s Shouts & Murmurs: the merman and the fish-catcher, and other new love stories. Read all of Cora Frazier’s “New Harlequin Titles” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Wren McDonald.
Follow us (thenewyorker) on @picturesoftext’s new project, The List App, for comprehensive reading lists, essential quotes from our weekly features, collections of magazine covers, and more.

“Walden” is less a cornerstone work of environmental literature than the original cabin porn, writes Kathryn Schulz in this week’s issue. Why, given its fabrications, inconsistencies, and moral myopia, do we continue to cherish it? Read “Pond Scum” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @ericbnyquist.

As waves of feminism rise and break, Gloria Steinem remains at the forefront of the cause. What keeps her going? This week, Jane Kramer profiles the eighty-one-year-old activist. Photograph by @inezvinoodh.
Today's Daily Cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez. #TNYcartoons

An increasingly ritualized form of violence is attracting unexpected perpetrators. In this week’s issue, Malcolm Gladwell examines the “overwhelmingly American” phenomenon of school shootings. Illustration by Oliver Munday.
Ridley Scott’s new film, “The Martian,” “thrums with an appetite for life,” writes Anthony Lane. Read the review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Tomer Hanuka.

“Where I live in Brooklyn, there’re always a lot of books being set out on the sidewalk, and there’re also a lot of authors walking around the neighborhood,” @adriantomine says of his cover for this week’s issue, “Recognition.” Read more about his inspiration on newyorker.com.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

John Kolle, a local entrepreneur who wanted “a temple of music and amusement” for Brooklyn society, built the first incarnation of the Grand Prospect Hall in 1892.
