It’s been a vaudeville theatre, a movie set, a speakeasy, and a ballroom-dancing venue, and now, on its palatial grounds, there’s a German beer garden. Read Amelia Lester’s review of Brooklyn Bavarian Biergarten on newyorker.com. Photograph by @meredithjenks.

At this year’s New Yorker Festival, the writer and star of @HamiltonMusical, Lin-Manuel Miranda, sat down with The New Yorker’s Rebecca Mead, who wrote in February that “the show is an achievement of historical and cultural reimagining.” Many people cry after seeing “Hamilton,” Miranda said, but not as much as he did writing it: “I was crying after every couplet. Sobs. Wracked over.” Photograph by Cindy Ord/Getty Images for The New Yorker.

When he’s producing music, Kris Klayton uses a number of aliases. As Kaytronik, he turns out records that are a bit darker, with menacing electronic tones; as K2, he creates buoyant reëdits of R. & B. songs. But as a d.j. he brings all of these characters into the booth with him. Illustration by Frank Stockton.

This past weekend, @haimtheband joined us at the 16th annual #NYerFest to talk singing and sisterhood with The New Yorker’s Kelefa Sanneh. Then they performed. Photograph by Thos Robinson/Getty Images for The New Yorker.
When a Chinatown bank was investigated for fraud, an immigrant community’s financial way of life was put on trial. Read @jiayangfan's “The Accused” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @javier_jaen.
A cartoon by Will McPhail, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

The ethos of the buzzy night spot Baby’s All Right—the relaxed atmosphere, the expert music programming, and dollar tacos—has turned it into a rare sort of venue that feels designed to engender good vibes. On October 10, Danielle Johnson (@danz_magic), who performs sugary synth pop as Computer Magic, celebrates the release of her new album, “Davos.” Photo illustration by @shaedetar.

This week on @newyorkerphoto, the photographer Zun Lee (@zunleephoto) is sharing found Polaroid photographs of African-American families from his project @faderesistance. There he is creating a digital archive and storytelling platform to reimagine narratives and, possibly, to reconnect images with their owners.

At night, densely populated areas become largely unpeopled, and a reclamation seems to take place. The photographer Lynn Saville aims to capture this emptiness. Here is a parking garage in Houston, Texas. See more of her photographs on newyorker.com.

To some critics, @olivier_rousteing's bedazzled clothes and embrace of reality-TV stars represent not just a threat to the tradition of French couture but the advent of a vulgar age. Rousteing, faced with this kind of criticism, says that he is bringing high fashion into the twenty-first century by erasing the distinction between luxury and popular culture. “It is too bad for critics if they cannot understand this, but the truth is now that their critiques do not matter.” Read John Colapinto’s Profile of the creative director of the French fashion house @balmainparis. Photograph by @ioulex.

Reid Hoffman seems to conceive of himself as a self-invented superhero: the Ubernode, the world’s most networked person. Nicholas Lemann profiles the @linkedin founder in this week's issue. Illustration by @stan_chow.
A cartoon by @farleykatz from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Can Bernie Sanders win the Democratic nomination, let alone the Presidency? In this week’s issue, Margaret Talbot Profiles the Vermont senator, and looks for the answer. Read “The Populist Prophet” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Edward Sorel.

At the New Yorker Festival’s #NYerTech, held at One World Trade Center this weekend, Sean Murray, the creator of the video game No Man’s Sky, spoke with The New Yorker’s Raffi Khatchadourian and presented a preview of the game. See a video of the exclusive demo on video.newyorker.com. Photograph from Hello Games. #NYerFest
Twitter's first user and co-founder Jack Dorsey is back at the company as permanent C.E.O. Revisit our 2013 Profile on newyorker.com. Illustration by Hellovon.

“The current boom in slivers of buildings does seem to be the result of a conspiracy between Russian billionaires and real-estate sharks,” says Bruce McCall, the artist behind the cover of the annual Money Issue, out this week.“It’s as if they were trying to make a cartoon of the skyline.” See more of McCall’s New York City-themed covers from the past two decades on newyorker.com. #TNYCovers

“It’s no longer about looking; it’s about seeing.” Peter Schjeldahl discussed minimalism during the New Yorker Festival tour of the Whitney Museum at its new home in New York City's Meatpacking District. This year’s #NYerFest is officially over, but we’ll continue to share highlights from the weekend in the days ahead. Regram @whitneymuseum.

“I’m a cisgender male and I’ve been given the role of a lifetime playing a transgender woman,” Jeffrey Tambor said of his character Maura on “Transparent” at #NYerFest. He went on to tell The New Yorker's Ariel Levy, “I get to use all of me. It’s sort of what I thought acting was when I was a little boy.” Photograph by Craig Barritt/Getty Images for The New Yorker.
Last night’s #NYerFest lineup at SVA Theatre. The events continue throughout the weekend. Regram @ughfinewhatever, we hope you enjoyed our Broad City event.
Last night, Blondes and Towkio performed at #NYerTech's SoundCloud Lounge in One World Trade Center. Regram @mattandchanel, thank you for coming. #NYerFest

Last night, we wrapped up day one of the 16th annual New Yorker Festival with events featuring @haimtheband, Sigourney Weaver, @jimgaffigan, the women of @broadcity, Toni Morrison, Trey Anastasio, and more. The Festival continues throughout the weekend. Click the link in our bio to buy tickets and learn more. #NYerFest

What is going to happen in Cuba now that it and the U.S. are no longer enemies but friendly adversaries? Hear perspectives from Cuba’s leading creative minds at the New Yorker Festival on Saturday, October 3. Illustration by @sarahevanslloyd.

National Sawdust is a century-old sawdust factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, reimagined as a classical-music venue and arts incubator. The space opened October 1, and the first month of concerts achieve breathtaking ambition and range. Illustration by Golden Cosmos.
A cartoon by Tom Toro. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

Den Bejar, who performs as Destroyer, has a reputation as a killjoy, and a curmudgeon. In his newest album, “Poison Season,” he “maintains a deliciously melancholic atmosphere, melting between austere piano ballads and keyed-up, E Street-style benders.” Read Benjamin Shapiro’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @ayakakeda.

During the worst of Harlem’s Manhattanville-Grant public-housing feud, residents regularly woke to the sound of gunfire. After his eighteen-year-old daughter was killed outside the apartment where she lived, Taylonn Murphy sought to make a change from within. Read Jennifer Gonnerman’s report on a father’s fight to stop the cycle of violence. Photograph by @christaanfelber.

The rapper and culinary-school dropout Action Bronson (@bambambaklava) stopped by @mariobatali's Eataly to sample an assortment of salumi and formaggi. Bronson declared the mortadella “stupid delicious” and the prosciutto “unheard of.” Read Andrew Marantz’s story in this week’s Talk of the Town. Illustration by Tom Bachtell.
The flutist Claire Chase’s career embodies entrepreneurship, technical virtuosity, and performance charisma. See her at the Kitchen, in New York City, Sept. 29 – Oct. 2. Photograph by @paridukovic.

This week, Rania Abouzeid reports from Iraq, where she explores the country’s violent underworld of sex trafficking and examines one former prostitute's efforts to rescue the ever-widening population of at-risk women. Illustration by Aude Van Ryn.

When Jorge Ramos asked Donald Trump about immigration, the Presidential candidate had him ejected from the room. This week, William Finnegan profiles the influential Univision news anchor. Photograph by @philipmontgomery.

“When I see dogs dragged out by their masters for a run, I wonder whether they may not rather be doing something else. As for cats, there’s never a question about what they want: a nap,” the artist Peter de Sève says of “Catnap,” his cover for this week’s issue. See a slide show of de Sève’s work on newyorker.com. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Mick Stevens. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

This week, Shauna Lyon reviews a new wine bar in New York City: “Like Solange Knowles, Wildair is the younger, possibly cooler sister of an older, more established star—the affordable-tasting-menu mecca Contra, on the Lower East Side.” Read more on newyorker.com. Photograph by @jamespomerantz.

“Climb every mountain. Such is the impulse that drives the dramatis personae of ‘Everest,’ who spend their days, and their dollars, tramping uphill until they run out of air.” Read Anthony Lane’s review of Baltasar Kormákur’s new movie, based on a 1996 expedition to the Himalayas. Illustration by @matttaylordraws.

A new short film about Ellis Island, narrated by Robert De Niro, will première at this year's New Yorker Festival. Join us on October 4th to see @jr, the Paris-born artist who directed the film, speak with The New Yorker’s art editor, Françoise Mouly. Visit the link in our bio to learn more. Photograph from jr-art.net. #NYerFest

When a beloved café on New York’s Macdougal Street closed this spring, the sprightly restaurateur Linden Pride opened a new bar with “aquatic delights” and “kicked-up” cocktails. Read @thecooperrrr’s review of Dante on newyorker.com. Illustration by @jeanniephan.
A cartoon by Zachary Kanin, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com/cartoons. #TNYcartoons

Last year, Alec Soth (@littlebrownmushroom) photographed museum security guards at the Minneapolis Institute of Art, capturing them in front of their favorite works of art and talking to them about their jobs. The quiet, contemplative portraits offer an unusual window into the guards’ private thoughts as they hold down their often tedious posts. Visit newyorker.com to see more.

On Saturday, October 3, Adam Driver of “Girls” sits down with The New Yorker’s Lizzie Widdicombe at the New Yorker Festival. Visit the link in our bio to buy tickets to our 16th annual celebration of arts and ideas. #NYerFest

In this week's Shouts & Murmurs, “Don't Swat at the Bee,” Kelly Stout offers metaphorical dating advice: “Don’t forget to offer it a beer. Bees always get really weird when you don’t offer.” Illustration by Leo Espinosa.

This week, Kelefa Sanneh profiles the musician Claire Boucher, who is better known by her stage name and alter ego, Grimes. @actuallygrimes started as an experimental electronic musician and drew a devoted online following. Now she wants to infiltrate the mainstream. But is she too punk to be a pop star? Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @jasonnocito666.
A cartoon by Paul Noth, in this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
After winning over Hollywood in “12 Years a Slave,” @lupitanyongo is set to make her New York stage début at the Public Theatre, in Danai Gurira’s “Eclipsed.” Illustration by @24houremergency.

Tickets for the 16th annual New Yorker Festival, October 2-4 in New York City, have arrived at our office. Is one of them yours? Visit the link in our bio to learn more about this year’s lineup. #NYerFest

In an essay in this week’s issue, David Sedaris recounts learning that the Supreme Court had legalized gay marriage—and then deciding to propose to his boyfriend eighteen times. Illustration by Luc Melanson.
A cartoon by Drew Dernavich. See more cartoons on newyorker.com/cartoons. #TNYcartoons

Ken Dornstein’s brother was one of the hundreds of people who died when Pan Am Flight 103 exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988. Ken was unsatisfied with the official investigation: “How could such a big act of mass murder have no author?” Here he is at his home, in Somerville, Massachusetts, where two rooms are devoted to the attack. After a decades-long investigation, has he finally solved the case? Read Patrick Radden Keefe’s piece on a relentless search for a terrorist on newyorker.com. Photograph by @will_mebane.

Join us on Saturday, October 3, to see Jason Segel in conversation with Michael Schulman at the 16th annual New Yorker Festival. The talks, performances, and one-of-a-kind excursions continue throughout the weekend. Visit festival.newyorker.com to purchase tickets and learn more. #NYerFest

In “Blood at the Root,” David Remnick travels to Charleston, South Carolina, and explores the city’s resistance and resilience in the aftermath of the June murders of nine people at Emanuel A.M.E. church. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by Anthony Russo.

“Basketball players are tall and lean, like the buildings in Manhattan, and New York is famous for basketball games in pickup playgrounds,” the artist Mark Ulriksen says of “Streetball,” his cover for this week’s issue. Read more about his inspiration, and see a slide show of his past sports covers, on newyorker.com. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Paul Noth. See more on newyorker.com/cartoons. #TNYcartoons
This week, Hilton Als previews Clive Owen’s first Broadway turn, in Harold Pinter’s “Old Times.” Illustration by Tomer Hanuka.

See @sleater_kinney in conversation with Dana Goodyear at this year’s New Yorker Festival, then fill your weekend with live performances, film previews, and one-of-a-kind excursions throughout New York City. Get tickets at the link in our bio. #NYerFest
This week, Emily Nussbaum watches “Catastrophe,” “Scrotal Recall,” and “You’re the Worst,” and considers the rise of the bite-size romantic comedy on television. Illustration by Zohar Lazar.
A cartoon by David Sipress, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

Ordering at Mulino a Vino, an Italian restaurant in New York’s Meatpacking District, involves mastering the menu’s taxonomy of food and wine (“Bright & Lively,” “Big & Luscious”). Read Amelia Lester’s review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @davideluciano.

“What does Denis Villeneuve do for fun? Does he know what fun is? Hard to say, but it’s not an aspect of life that looms large for the people in his films.” This week, Anthony Lane watches Villeneuve’s new film, “Sicario,” starring Emily Blunt. Illustration by Diego Patiño.
“Descriptions of Art at the Met That Could Double as My Tinder Bio,” by Blythe Roberson, in Daily Shouts. Read more on newyorker.com.

The bassist Hannah Lew’s band Cold Beat brings indie pop and post-punk into darker, icier territory. They’re currently in New York City for a weekend of performances at cozy Brooklyn venues. Illustration by @phantasmosis.

On Saturday, October 3, the comedian, actor, writer, and musician @reggiewatts talks with The New Yorker’s @emmaewallen at the 16th annual New Yorker Festival. Click the link in our bio to buy a ticket and learn more about this year’s Festival lineup. #NYerFest #NYerTech

“I like the idea that nobody’s one or the other,” Julianne Moore tells John Lahr in this week’s issue. “You can be the regular girl and you can be the monster at the same time.” Read “The Sphinx Next Door” on newyorker.com. Photograph by @paridukovic.
A cartoon by Tom Chitty (@drawnbytom). See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

A Sketchbook by Leanne Shapton depicts unpurchased items from her eBay and Etsy watch lists, including Vintage Clothes Hangers: “Their charm will only be concealed.” See the WWII Sheepskin Aviator Pants, the Hand-Knit Pom-Pom Hat, the 1970s Speedo, and more on newyorker.com.

Join us at the 16th annual New Yorker Festival, October 2-4, which every year brings the magazine to life with rich conversations, live performances, film previews, and one-of-a-kind excursions throughout New York City. On Saturday, October 3, Jesse Eisenberg sits down with The New Yorker’s Susan Morrison. Click the link in our bio to buy tickets and for details about the more than fifty events at this year’s Fest. #NYerFest
Visit newyorker.com for Rebecca Mead’s dispatch from Portofino, Italy, on Dolce & Gabbana’s recent Alta Moda presentation. Photograph by @lucalocatelliphoto/@institute.
@stefanogabbana holds a gold fan at an Alta Moda party whose dress code was gold. Visit newyorker.com to read Rebecca Mead’s story. Photograph by @lucalocatelliphoto/@instituteartist.

The week of Dolce & Gabbana’s Alta Moda event, Greece was edging toward economic collapse, and a deadline for establishing its terms of debt repayment to the European Union had been set for Sunday night—the evening of a party with a dress code of gold. The Dolce & Gabbana store in Athens had been closed. “To give respect,” Dolce said. For more, visit newyorker.com. Photograph by @lucalocatelliphoto/@instituteartist.

“The guests ascended to a terrace, where a tented pavilion had been erected to display the Alta Gioielleria jewelry collection. Two young men in satin frock coats and lace ruffs flanked the pavilion’s entrance, gently beating the air with fans of peacock feathers,” Rebecca Mead writes of Dolce & Gabbana’s lavish event for an élite clientele. Photograph by @lucalocatelliphoto/@instituteartist.

“There would be none of the hurried disrobing that often happens backstage at fashion shows: each model was to wear just one couture outfit,” Rebecca Mead writes of @dolcegabbana's Alta Moda show. “One ensemble had been made with metallic-lace fabric, from the nineteen-fifties, that had been found on a bolt containing only enough material for a single dress. Equally rare cloth had been obtained from the supplier of ecclesiastical finery to the Vatican.” Visit newyorker.com for the complete portfolio, and to read Mead’s story. Photograph by @lucalocatelliphoto/@instituteartist.

In “The Couture Club,” Rebecca Mead reports from Portofino, Italy, where Dolce & Gabbana recently presented this year’s collection of Alta Moda—made-to-measure haute couture—by throwing an over-the-top, four-day event for an élite international clientele. We’ll be sharing several images from the show over the course of the day. Visit newyorker.com for the complete portfolio, and to read Mead’s story. Photograph by @lucalocatelliphoto/@instituteartist.

This week, in The New Yorker’s Style Issue, Rebecca Mead writes about the Alta Moda collection, John Lahr profiles Julianne Moore, and Lizzie Widdicombe considers the rise of the “celebpreneur.” Here, a look back at the Style Issue through the years. For more, visit newyorker.com. #TNYarchive #TNYcovers

This week, Lizzie Widdicombe explores the rising phenomenon of celebrity C.E.O.s—known in gossip-blog parlance as “celebpreneurs”—and looks at how the reality star @bethennyfrankel parlayed a spot on “Real Housewives of New York City” into the multimillion-dollar Skinnygirl brand. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by Olivier Goka.
A cartoon by Drew Dernavich. See more on newyorker.com/cartoons. #TNYcartoons

The dauntless German sculptor Isa Genzken is back in New York, poised to knock our socks off again, after a star turn at MOMA, in 2013. Her new show, at the Zwirner gallery, which opens on Sept. 16, includes the latest in her ongoing series of “Schauspieler (Actors),” mannequins styled with a jaunty eccentricity that jolts sculptural realism into the twenty-first century. Photograph by @erichelgas.

“For the next generation of fashion talents, the question is how to create something new when the Internet puts everything from the past at anyone’s disposal,” says Greg Foley, the artist behind this week’s Style Issue cover, “Crosswalk.”

Montgomery Clift and Jennifer Jones play lovers on the verge of a breakup in Vittorio De Sica’s melodrama “Terminal Station.” The film will screen on September 30 in Film Forum’s monthlong De Sica retrospective in New York City. Illustration by Victor Melamed.

Aline Smithson's homemade Hollywood portraits are inspired by the Technicolor images of the nineteen-forties and fifties. She recreates vintage publicity photos, but with ordinary people. See more on newyorker.com.

A police force that kills black citizens is adding to America’s history of racial violence, but so is a police force that fails to keep them safe. This week, Kelefa Sanneh examines a set of books that address crime and punishment in black America. Illustration by @staufferstudio.
A cartoon by Bob Mankoff. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

This week, @silviakillings reviews Ganso Yaki, a self-described casual restaurant in Brooklyn. “One of the least helpful words to describe a restaurant in Brooklyn is ‘casual’; it indicates that you can dress however you like, but says nothing about how much you’ll spend or what to expect from the food.” Read more on newyorker.com. Photograph by @will_mebane.

Anne Washburn’s adaptation of Euripides’ “Iphigenia in Aulis,” playing now through September 27, is the centerpiece of Classic Stage Company’s Greek Festival. Read Michael Schulman’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @roman_m.

At the Mott Haven Bar and Grill, in the South Bronx, you can sit at a marble bar top and watch competitive arm wrestling on a screen while listening to nineties dance hits. Read Nicolas Niarchos’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Giacomo Bagnara.
In “Holy Orders,” Alexander Stille reports from Vatican City on how Pope Francis is trying to change the way the Church does business. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @omissamilativ.
In Shouts & Murmurs, Paul Simms offers eight very short science-fiction stories. Read them all on newyorker.com. Illustration by Victor Kerlow.
A cartoon by Jack Ziegler from this week’s issue. See more cartoons on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
In this week's issue, a Sketchbook by @paulrogersstudio pays homage to the spirit of the U.S. Open in New York City.

This year at the 16th annual New Yorker Festival, October 2-4 in New York City: @haimtheband, Adam Driver, the stars of Broad City, Toni Morrison, Jason Segel, @iammarkronson, Congressman John Lewis, @reggiewatts, Billy Joel, and more. Tickets go on sale today at 12 noon E.T. Visit festival.newyorker.com/tickets to grab a seat before they sell out. #NYerFest

Tomorrow, the Metropolitan Museum opens its performance season at the Temple of Dendur with an eightieth-birthday tribute to the Estonian composer Arvo Pärt, whose works of profound melancholy have enthralled the world. Photograph by @paridukovic.

A new self-help trend suggests that the key to success is pretending you’re in a video game. Read Nathan Heller’s piece “High Score” in this week’s issue and on newyorker.com. Illustration by @freebrianrea.

The defense lawyer Judy Clarke has long excelled at saving the lives of notorious killers, from the Unabomber to Jared Loughner. Then she took on the case of the one person she couldn’t save, the Boston bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. Read Patrick Radden Keefe’s “The Worst of the Worst” on newyorker.com. Photograph by @philipmontgomery.
A cartoon by Harry Bliss, from this week’s issue. See more cartoons on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

This week, Carrie Battan listens to The Weeknd’s new album, “Beauty Behind the Madness.” She writes, “the record is filled with the sort of exhaustive—and exhausting—nihilism that would make Bret Easton Ellis proud." Read the review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Michael Cho.

The photographer @screenlives uses long exposure times to turn cityscapes, public gatherings, and iconic sites into shimmering apparitions of drama and social energy. Here is Astoria Park Pool, 2015. See more highlights on newyorker.com.

In New York City, if you look closely, you can find people with noses in books on every park bench, museum step, patch of grass, and subway car. @jonnotherattman captured portraits of late-summer readers across the city. See more highlights on newyorker.com.
Which events are you most excited to see? Join us at #NYerFest October 2, 3, and 4. Get more details at festival.newyorker.com.

“Birds, animals, and insects tend not to fare too well in my fiction,” Danielle McLaughlin admits. Read her story on a woman’s fraying family life, “In the Act of Falling,” on newyorker.com. Design by David Drummond.
A cartoon by Trevor Spaulding. See more cartoons on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

Labor Day weekend is a final chance to knock items off our summer reading lists before the impending rush of fall and the new season of must-read books. From Brighton Beach to Governors Island to Grand Central Station, @jonnotherattman caught New Yorkers in their final moments of estival reading. See more highlights on newyorker.com.

At @farobk, a new Italian restaurant in Bushwick, the kitchen makes its pasta from grains grown upstate and the minimalist dining room is so spacious that it looks like an imagined Los Angeles. Photograph by @jeremy_liebman.

“Kanye West’s announcement of his intention to seek the Presidency reminds us that it’s not too early to start thinking about the 2020 campaign. (2016’s already old hat by now, anyway),” Barry Blitt says of his cover for next week’s issue. “2020 Vision” was inspired by the historic photo of Harry Truman’s win in 1948. #TNYcovers

A horse rider before a race at the Matheran race course. Matheran is a hill station town two hours from Mumbai, India, where cars, motorbikes, and bicycles are banned—the only car allowed on Matheran streets is the town ambulance. Over 500 horses serve as taxis for the town’s visitors. Photograph by @alexiawebster, regram @newyorkerphoto.

The forthcoming book “Beaton: Photographs,” out next week from @abramsbooks, presents an expansive chronological survey of Cecil Beaton’s career. His portraits evoke a startling purity—a spareness of composition seems to free his subjects from their respective eras. This is Gertrude Stein, photographed in 1938. See more of Beaton’s work on newyorker.com.

“Spring Awakening” is back on Broadway in an inventive revival by @deafwest. Performed in sign language and spoken English (characters are double-cast with deaf and hearing actors), the musical features more than twenty performers making their Broadway débuts. Photograph by @michael_marcelle.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
New York City’s police commissioner Bill Bratton insists broken-window policing works. Has it tainted his legacy? Ken Auletta examines in this week’s issue. Photograph by @paridukovic.
Revel, a gleaming glass hotel and casino, was heralded as a sign of a revitalized Atlantic City. What went wrong? Nick Paumgarten investigates in this week’s issue. Photograph by Andrew Moore.

Andrew Carmellini’s latest Tribeca restaurant, @littleparknyc, has a conundrum that could be filed under Good Problem to Have. The vegetable-focussed food is so good, so gorgeous and seasonal, that the setting feels incongruously dispassionate. How lovely it would be to eat this exuberant food in a garden! (A New Yorker can dream.) Read Shauna Lyon’s review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @erichelgas.
A cartoon by @farleykatz. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
Kathleen Alcott’s “Infinite Home” is one of the titles reviewed this week in Briefly Noted.

What’s really at stake when a school closes? In this week’s issue, Jelani Cobb examines the shuttering of his alma mater: Jamaica High School, in Queens. Illustration by Oliver Munday; Vic DeLucia/The New York Times/Redux; and @jacksonkrule.

In this week’s issue, George Packer reports from Paris’s banlieues—the immigrant-dominated suburbs that, to many of the city’s residents, signify housing projects, crime, unemployment, and extremism. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @arnau_bach.
On the tenth anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, a look back at Ana Juan's 2005 cover. #TNYcovers

Historical reconstructions—whether based on true stories or on classic fiction—will lead the way in movie theatres this fall. Read Richard Brody’s Fall Movies Preview on newyorker.com. Illustration by @nicolerifkin.

In this week’s issue, Elif Batuman tells the story of how Byzantine shipwrecks delayed construction of a high-speed train in one of the world's fastest-growing cities. Read “The Big Dig” on newyorker.com. Photograph by Raphaël Dallaporta.
A cartoon by Tom Chitty (@drawnbytom), from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
In this week’s issue, Alex Ross considers how the symphony survived the twentieth century. Illustration by @richardmcguirehere.

The photographer @mustafahabdulaziz travels the world, taking pictures of water. This spring, he reached China’s Yangtze River where he saw fishermen and poachers, conservationists and polluters, huge transport ships and tiny sampans. Here, boats trawl for seaweed and shrimp in Honghu.

At moments of extreme exasperation, parents may think that there’s something wrong with their teens’ brains. According to recent books on adolescence, there is. Read Elizabeth Kolbert’s piece “The Terrible Teens” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Édith Carron.

When two New York-based teams in the Vintage Base Ball Association compete on the parade grounds at Governors Island, on August 29, they’ll play according to 1864 rules, reviving the heroic struggles and wayward charms of an earlier age. Photograph by @christophergriffithstudio.

“I think he’s, like, dog-whistling,” one white nationalist says of Donald Trump in this week’s issue. Evan Osnos travelled to several states on Trump’s campaign trail to examine why the Presidential candidate has generated such a huge response from the extreme far right. Read “The Fearful and the Frustrated” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @asbtractsunday.
A cartoon by Will McPhail, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com/cartoons. #TNYcartoons

Although the mountainscapes in Meike Nixdorf’s new series “Your Earth Transforms" would seem, at first, to be thoroughly in the tradition of heroic alpine photography, they are not photographs, and Nixdorf has never actually visited these places. Rather, the panoramas are a kind of reverse origami, a partial flattening of 3-D imagery from Google Earth. Marcia Bjornerud, a geologist, writes that the images "reveal that geologic and human timescales are not so disparate, and that this old Earth is nimbler and more energetic than we might imagine.”

“I think it’s kind of beautiful and hilarious to see people eating their organic kale and quinoa salads while gazing across the opaque, fetid water,” @adriantomine says of his cover for this week’s issue, “Gowanus Canal, Brooklyn.” #TNYcovers
It’s women who quickly take and hold the stage in “John,” Annie Baker’s latest production at New York’s Pershing Square. Read Hilton Als’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Keith Negley.

In this week’s issue, Elizabeth Kolbert profiles Christiana Figueres, the Executive Secretary of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. “Of all the jobs in the world, Figueres’s may possess the very highest ratio of responsibility (preventing global collapse) to authority (practically none),” Kolbert writes. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by Ben Wiseman.

Raccoon Lodge, the thirty-three-year-old lower-Manhattan mainstay that will close in December, has long been a watering hole that attracts the whole village. Bankers, writers, ponytailed tough guys, women in tight pants, men with braids like Axl Rose: everybody sits side by side. Read Sarah Larson’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @jeanniephan.
At The Black Ant, in New York City, unusual ingredients are esteemed and insects are the crown jewels. Read @silviakillings’s review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @dina_litovsky.

This week, David Remnick reflects on the work of the photographer Alec Soth (@littlebrownmushroom), who travelled to New Orleans a decade after Katrina to capture the city of water, which exists in a state of both persistent suffering and persistent renewal. See more images on newyorker.com.
A cartoon by Avi Steinberg (@steinbergdrawscartoons), from this week's issue. See more on newyorker.com/cartoons. #TNYcartoons

This week on @newyorkerphoto, the photographer @danieltchetchik is sharing images of summer in Poland, where different elements and reflections of heat and sun intertwine with traces of the country’s history, landscape, and people.

Lina and Mengchun are roommates and inseparable friends who share a tiny apartment in Beijing. They work at an N.G.O. that provides services to the blind, and both have severe vision impairment themselves. The Spanish photographer @albertbonsfills began documenting their lives, studying a remarkably close friendship based on mutual guidance, care, and shared reliance on a single set of eyes. Despite their handicaps, @albertbonsfills said, the women “find themselves in perfect harmony facing everyday life in Beijing.”

This week, Malcolm Gladwell examines the long-term effects of the forced relocation of Hurricane Katrina victims from their New Orleans homes—and why, in some cases, this was a good thing. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by Matt Dorfman.

A list of elegant things, like a list of obscene things, includes no single trait in common across its members. Read Patrick House’s post "What Is Elegance in Science?" on newyorker.com. Illustration by @boyounillo.

An extraordinarily versatile performer, the Broadway actress Audra McDonald exudes both vulnerability and toughness, glamour and earthiness. Through August 23 at the Williamstown Theatre Festival, she transforms herself into the strapping farm girl at the center of Eugene O’Neill’s 1947 play “A Moon for the Misbegotten.” Photograph by @paridukovic.

“In the ten years since Hurricane Katrina, what has plagued me most is the unfinished business of it all,” Sarah M. Broom writes of the struggles that she and her family still face following the 2005 storm. Read Broom’s essay “The Yellow House” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @richardmcguirehere.
A cartoon by J. C. Duffy. See more from this week’s issue on newyorker.com/cartoons. #TNYcartoons

“I wanted to capture the memory of Hurricane Katrina and its aftereffects—the spirit of New Orleans, its resilience, its culture,” the artist Kadir Nelson says of “Second Line,” his cover for this week’s issue, which marks the tenth anniversary of the storm. #TNYcovers

The AMC series “Halt and Catch Fire” is a platform for a fascinating, buried period of digital history, portraying the battle to create the first portable computer and then the prehistory of today’s Silicon Valley gold rush. Emily Nussbaum reviews the show, along with German spy series “Deutschland 83,” in this week’s issue. Illustration by @sachinteng.

The most valuable innovation at the heart of Facebook was probably not the social network so much as the creation of a tool that convinced hundreds of millions of people to hand over so much personal data for so little in return. On newyorker.com, Tim Wu examines how our personal information has valued Facebook at two hundred and seventy billion dollars. Illustration by @jordan_awan.

This week, Sesame Street announced its move to HBO. In 2009, we spent time with Caroll Spinney, the puppeteer who has performed as Big Bird and Oscar for nearly fifty years. It was the first time he’d allowed himself to be photographed as half-man, half-bird. He also answered an important question, Does Big Bird read The New Yorker? “He likes the cartoons. He doesn’t understand some of them.” Photograph by Brian Finke.
“An X-Ray of My Suitcase,” by Tom Gauld.
A cartoon by Tom Toro. See more from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

According to a recent study conducted by Facebook, “lol” is out and “haha” is in. Have you read Sarah Larson’s breakdown of the different ways we e-laugh? Find it on newyorker.com. Illustration by @simonemassoni.

This week, @jimmy_chin takes over @newyorkerphoto’s account to share images and anecdotes from his new documentary, @merufilm. Here, the climber and filmmaker @renan_ozturk takes in the immensity of the Garwhal Himalaya from Tapovan Basecamp in India before an attempt of the Shark’s Fin. Follow @newyorkerphoto for more.

New photos by @philipmontgomery capture recent protests in Baltimore and Ferguson. Jelani Cobb writes, “These are not disjointed moments bound by a single artist’s perspective. These are stations in an American crucible.”

We often think of envy as a feeling of ill-will, but not all envy is created equal. Some flavors leave nothing but a bad aftertaste, Maria Konnikova writes, but others may inspire us to reach new heights of achievement. Illustration by Joohee Yoon.

“How impossible can a mission be, if it is successfully completed five times?” This week, Anthony Lane watches “Mission: Impossible—Rogue Nation,” featuring Tom Cruise; “The End of the Tour,” starring Jason Segel as David Foster Wallace; and “Best of Enemies,” a documentary about Gore Vidal and William F. Buckley, Jr. Read the reviews on newyorker.com. Illustration by R. Kikuo Johnson.

The San Francisco artists Barry McGee and Clare Rojas came together as partners, collaborators, and parents in the wake of the death of McGee’s first wife, Margaret Kilgallen. This week, Dana Goodyear explores the ghostly love triangle. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @peterbohler.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com/cartoons. #TNYcartoons
@lazypointnyc is an antidote for sweaty city days, making the fantasy of ocean breeze an urban reality. Read @emmaewallen’s review, on newyorker.com. Illustration by @matthewhollister.

This week in Shouts & Murmurs, @mindykaling imagines TV shows with recycled tropes the networks are clamoring for, including “Hot Serial Killer Who’s Kind of Literary,” “The Abandoned-Spinster Club,” and “Boy-Man Must Face the Adult World.” Illustration by Edwin Fotheringham.
There is no menu at the East Village restaurant @shukonyc—just a dizzying parade of sushi. Read Amelia Lester’s review, on newyorker.com. Photograph by @jamespomerantz.
A cartoon by Tom Toro. See more at newyorker.com/cartoons. #TNYcartoons
This month, Jane Lynch, who played “Glee’s” tracksuited villainess, brings her bossy schmalz to a cabaret performance at @joespub. Illustration by @simonemassoni.
Tonight we say goodbye to Jon Stewart on “The Daily Show.” David Remnick reflects on the longtime host's late-night legacy, on newyorker.com. Illustration by Tom Bachtell.

Seventy years after the bombing of Hiroshima, John Hersey's landmark report remains undiminished in its intensity. Read it online for the first time ever, on newyorker.com. Photograph: Rolls Press/Popperfoto via Getty.

Working-class voters face stagnant wages and diminished job prospects. Why on earth would they support the billionaire Donald Trump? James Surowiecki investigates, in this week’s issue. Illustration by @abstractsunday.

Carlos Chávez was indisputably the most powerful Mexican artistic figure, musical or otherwise, of his time. This year’s Bard Music Festival celebrates Chávez with two abundant weekends of concerts. Illustration by @edelrodriguez.

In this week’s issue, Kelefa Sanneh reads several books on the free-speech debate and considers how hypersensitivity and soft censorship may, in fact, muffle free speech in America. Read “The Hell You Say” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Post Typography.
A cartoon by Drew Dernavich, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com/cartoons. #TNYcartoons

This week, Peter Hessler investigates the increasing presence of Chinese-owned businesses in Egypt—from a booming lingerie industry to an expanding factory zone. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @renaeffendiphoto.

Ratking, the Harlem-bred trio at the forefront of the city’s hip-hop revival, delivers music that’s a pure product of Gotham, with washes of noise and beats intercut with sirens, subway doors opening, and snippets of street conversation. This week, the group holds court in a high temple of local hip-hop: the East River Park amphitheater. The venue’s crumbling remains long stood as a monument to the city’s rap scene, but in 2002 it was renovated, making it an ideal setting for a new generation. Photograph by @jasonnocito666.
Since the nineteen-sixties, the science of thermal comfort has tended to neglect women. Read Anthony Lydgate’s post “Is Your Thermostat Sexist?” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Tomi Um.
The cover of this week’s issue, “Summer Adventures,” by the Dutch cartoonist Joost Swarte. #TNYcovers
A cartoon by Cameron Harvey. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com/cartoons. #TNYcartoons
Jonathan Galassi’s “Muse” is one of the titles reviewed this week in Briefly Noted. Read the capsule review on newyorker.com.

Heinz Insu Fenkl comes from a family of storytellers, and his story in this week’s issue, “Five Arrows,” reflects the power of layered narrative and dialogue. The piece is taken from a work in progress called “Skull Water,” about the author’s coming of age. Illustration by @carsonellis.

Last night, the southern face of the Empire State Building became a giant projection screen filled with images of a snow leopard, a manta ray, and other imperilled land and sea creatures. The event, “Projecting Change: The Empire State Building,” was a union of art, activism, and ambitious publicity stunt, designed to call attention to the plight of endangered species. See more images and a video of the event on newyorker.com. Photograph by Matthew Pillsbury (@screenlives).

Chef Simpson Wong’s aim at his new restaurant, Chomp Chomp, is less to intimidate you with spice than to woo you with depth of flavor. Read @silviakillings’s review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @davideluciano.
Julia Pierpont’s “Among the Ten Thousand Things” is one of the titles reviewed this week in Briefly Noted. Read the capsule review on newyorker.com.
A cartoon by Emily Flake, from this week’s issue. Find more drawings, both ridiculous and sublime, on newyorker.com/cartoons.  #TNYcartoons

In Shouts & Murmurs this week, Jack Handey imagines an apocalyptic world in which he has a mysterious and persistent subscription to the magazine Cannibalism Today: “The magazine cover shows a vicious-looking hillbilly eating a baby! He holds the roasted infant up to his teeth like a slice of watermelon. The headline reads, ‘WHAT GOES WITH TATERS? TOTS!’ I feel sick to my stomach.” Illustration by @freebrianrea.
Donald Trump as @mileycyrus, by Barry Blitt. See more in “Trump Twelve Ways,” on newyorker.com.

The artist @melissacacciola_tintype created a series of portraits of New York skateboarders using a Civil War-era photography technique. Pictured here is the skater Brian Anderson. See more on newyorker.com.

Sinaloa’s secret team of architects and builders has perfected the art of underground drug smuggling. This week, Monte Reel examines how the Mexican drug lord El Chapo builds his supertunnels. “A lot of people think that you have a shovel and you dig. That’s not the way it works.” Illustration by Paul Rogers.

This week, Becky Cooper (@thecooperrrr) reviews the Brooklyn bar @loosierouge: “The most intoxicating elixir of all is the atmosphere, which, you suddenly realize, is homey and warm.” Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by Daniel Krall.

With the soulful grain in his bassoonlike voice, the great American bass-baritone Eric Owens awakens the inner life of his characters and makes them compelling in their own right. He performs in Verdi’s “Macbeth” through August 22 at the Glimmerglass Festival, in Cooperstown. Photograph by @ioulex.

This week, Larissa MacFarquhar tells the story of Sue and Hector Badeau, who—despite deep financial strain and space limitations—adopted a total of twenty children over eleven years: “There were so many children who, because they were too old, or too violent, or too traumatized, or unable to walk, or too close to death, or the wrong color, or had too many brothers and sisters, were unlikely ever to be adopted; and when Hector and Sue thought about what those children’s lives would be like without parents, lives that were already unimaginably difficult, they could not bear it.” Illustration by Oliver Munday.

“It’s remarkably difficult to find words for the flustering magnetism of the color abstractions by the painter Stanley Whitney,” Peter Schjeldahl writes in this week’s issue. Read his review of Whitney’s exhibit, “Dance the Orange,” at the Studio Museum in Harlem. Photograph by @tobiashutzlerstudios.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
To capture the subjects for her project “The Nature of Imitation,” the photographer Yola Monakhov Stockton (@yolchiki) collaborated with ornithologists. See more images on newyorker.com.
“It sure would be nice to get over a Manhattan traffic jam with one big leap on a skateboard,” Mark Ulriksen says about “Endless Summer,” his cover for this week’s issue. #TNYcovers
This week on @newyorkerphoto, the photographer Ben Huff (@huffphoto) is sharing images from a recent trip to Adak, Alaska, one of the Aleutian Islands. Pictured here is Sweeper Cove. #regram

Some say the Martini originated at the Knickerbocker hotel in 1912. It was a drinking spot so beloved that, six years into Prohibition, The New Yorker was still lamenting its closure. Now, the Knick is back with a lackluster atmosphere, halibut croquettes and chocolate mousse. Photograph by @erichelgas.

The Los Angeles band @_HEALTH_ indulges an adolescent fascination with noisy, industrial textures. It’s easier to imagine them hammering away on pieces of heavy machinery than playing traditional instruments. Hua Hsu reviews their latest album, “DEATH MAGIC,” in this week’s issue. Photograph by @paridukovic.

Tessa Hadley’s story, “Silk Brocade,” begins in a Bristol dressmaking shop in the nineteen-fifties. The first character we meet, Ann, believes that with the right clothes you can transform yourself. “That’s her particular way into a new freedom,” Hadley explains. #Regram from the illustrator, @javier_jaen.

This week, @stolincokes reviews a dive bar in the West Village: “At Johnny’s, you can draw Burt Reynolds on a napkin for the Burt Reynolds wall, or admire a Yoda doll driving a small blue Thunderbird. But it’s not so hip that you fear being throttled by a man bun.” Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @andreakalfas.
A Sketchbook by @bruceerickaplan.

What happens when conceptual artists become fitness instructors? At Oakland's “Sappho and Sweat,” dancers gyrate to Nicki Minaj songs and cool down with improvised goddess poses. Photograph by @yoyo.lisa.

In this week's Shouts & Murmurs, Paul Rudnick imagines a slumber party at Mitt Romney’s house with Republican Presidential hopefuls Chris Christie and Marco Rubio. “I thought it might be a heckuva lot of fun to stay up late and raid the fridge and loosen our neckties. Who knows? By the end of the night, we might all have frosted bangs!” Illustration by Zohar Lazar.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

Where does “Ant-Man,” the latest item to roll off the Marvel assembly line, fit into the distinguished list of ant-themed films? Read Anthony Lane’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @matttaylordraws.

This week on @newyorkerphoto, the photographer Ben Huff (@huffphoto) is sharing images from a recent trip to Adak, Alaska—an Aleutian island that was occupied by the U.S. Navy during the Cold War. #regram

“Though ‘Watchman’ is a complete failure as a novel (if ‘Mockingbird’ did not exist, this book would never have been published, not now, as it was not then), it is still testimony to how appealing a writer Harper Lee can be.” Read Adam Gopnik’s review of “Go Set a Watchman” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @llagj.

In this week’s Talk of the Town, Nick Paumgarten spends the day with a mountaineer in Manhattan: the prominent climber and photographer @jimmy_chin. Jimmy is pictured here in “Meru,” a film he co-directed with his wife, Elizabeth Chai Vasarhelyi. Courtesy of Music Box Films. Photo by Renan Ozturk.

In this week’s issue, Jeffrey Toobin considers how stalled policy reform affects roughly eleven million undocumented immigrants in America. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by @annaparini.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

Since uploading a candid cover of Fleet Foxes to YouTube in 2008, the Swedish sisters Klara and Johanna Söderberg, who perform as @firstaidkit, have released their third album, “Stay Gold.” On July 27, they play Central Park’s SummerStage. Photographed for the magazine by @laerkeposselt.
“Keyboard Shortcuts for Novelists,” by Tom Gauld.

Today in Iran, with more than sixty per cent of the population under the age of thirty-five, the energy is less in heady debates about an ideal Islamic state than in a practical scramble to exploit twenty-first-century technology to change society. Read Robin Wright’s reporting on the Iran nuclear deal and the revolution’s midlife crisis, on newyorker.com. Illustration by Emiliano Ponzi.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
@rosiesnyc serves watermelon margaritas and crab to be cracked at the table. The room, too, brings to mind a seaside vacations—all teals and pale blues. Photograph by @lrnlncstr.

Australian guitarist and vocalist @courtneymelba sings about characters who sound like they haven’t showered yet today. Her songs are sketches of bored and lonely youth, and her live show is brash. On July 22, she plays @terminal5nyc, her biggest New York venue yet. Illustration by Cun Shi.
This week, @newyorkerphoto is sharing dispatches from the Tour de France by @manualforspeed, a collaboration between Emiliano Granado (@quesofrito) and Daniel Pasley. #regram

Each Saturday through September 5, @momaps1 hosts Warm Up, a program of afternoon parties that has been a source of summer fun since the late nineties. This year, the series features an international lineup of dance-floor royalty including @boysnoize and #PCMusic. Photograph by @landonnordeman.

“Though a movie like ‘Trainwreck’ sounds filthy enough, it cleans itself up as it goes along—setting off at a rough lick, yet soon displaying signs of moral decency.” Read Anthony Lane’s review of the @amyschumer-written and @juddapatow-directed comedy, on newyorker.com. Illustration by David Saracino.

@stolincokes and @skydylanrobbins film our latest Snapchat story, in which Colin introduces his menacing sidekick and announces the winners of our Snapchat caption contest (a.k.a. The “Snaption” contest). Find us at newyorkermag for more behind-the-scenes moments and out-of-office adventures.

An early look at the cover of next week’s issue, “Belly Flop,” by Barry Blitt. “Donald Trump has entered the fray of Republican Presidential candidates with all the grace of a bully doing cannonballs and belly flops at the local swimming pool,” said the artist. Read the full Cover Story on newyorker.com. #TNYcovers

The pleasure of reading about what others eat and drink is somewhere between the satisfaction of feeding and that of being fed. Read Bee Wilson’s “Pleasures of the Literary Meal” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Nicole Rifkin.

The Pacific Northwest is overdue for a massive earthquake and tsunami—a natural disaster that the region is woefully underprepared for. Read Kathryn Schulz's “The Really Big One” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @abstractsunday.
A cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

This week, Dexter Filkins reports from Argentina on the mystery surrounding death of the prosecutor Alberto Nisman, who died soon after accusing the country’s president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, of striking a secret deal with the government of Iran and orchestrating a plan to scuttle the investigation of the bloodiest terrorist attack in Argentina’s history. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by Alex Williamson.
A Sketchbook in this week’s issue, by Art Spiegelman, depicts a wedding in Charleston.
In this week’s issue, Jon Lee Anderson looks at the changes coming to private enterprise in the new Cuba. Read “Opening for Business” on newyorker.com. Photograph by @sebastianliste.
A cartoon by Pat Byrnes, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
This week’s cover, “Under the Same Hat,” by J. J. Sempé. #TNYcovers

This summer, the greatest American political filmmaker, John Ford, gets a retrospective at Museum of the Moving Image, which spotlights the links between two of his crucial obsessions: mob violence and racial hatred. Illustration by @edwardkinsella.
A cartoon by Paul Noth. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

This weekend, the National Ballet of China brings its country’s most famous ballet, “The Red Detachment of Women,” to the Lincoln Center Festival. Read Joan Acocella's review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @simonemassoni.

This week, the photographer @christaanfelber is hosting @newyorkerphoto’s feed, sharing photos from the road in the American South and Southwest. Driving through Rose Hill, Mississippi, he took a portrait of Eddie Cooley, sitting outside of a gas station. Eddie co-wrote Peggy Lee’s 1956 hit “Fever,” which was subsequently covered by Elvis Presley, Madonna, and others. #regram
A cartoon by Carolita Johnson, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

In “The Walking Dead,” Maria Konnikova looks at the effects of sleep deprivation. “We lose more by skimping on rest than we can ever gain back by adding a few hours to our days.” Read our three-part series on the science of sleep on newyorker.com. Illustration by Min Heo.
A cartoon by @farleykatz. See more cartoons from this week’s issue on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

In the second installment of our three-part series on sleep, Maria Konnikova looks at the work our brains do while we’re asleep—replaying, learning, processing. “In a sense, they think,” she writes. Illustration by Min Heo.

This week’s fiction is “Reading Comprehension: Text No. 1,” by Alejandro Zambra. “Even if we did nothing but study, we knew that there would always be two or three impossible questions. We didn’t complain. We got the message: cheating was just part of the deal.” Illustration by Matt Dorfman.

This week on newyorker.com, Maria Konnikova delves into the science of sleep. In the first piece in her three-part series, she explores why we can’t fall asleep. “We are, as a population, sleeping less now than we ever have,” she writes. Illustration by Min Heo.
Today’s Daily Cartoon by Tom Toro. #TNYcartoons

This week, @christaanfelber is hosting @newyorkerphoto’s feed, sharing images of people and places he encounters in the American South and Southwest. Here is a portrait of Theodashia, who was working the late-night shift in Toomsuba, Mississippi, @christaanfelber's first stop on his journey West. #regram
In this week’s issue, Adam Gopnik considers how love lyrics have endured over time. He asks, “Can love, and its songs, go on forever?” Illustration by Eiko Ojala.
A cartoon by David Sipress, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

Don Winslow’s novel “The Cartel” follows narcos and a D.E.A. agent as they navigate a web of allegiances, double crosses, devious stratagems, vendettas, and regime changes. Read Laura Miller’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @edelrodriguez.

James Murphy of LCD Soundsystem keeps the hits coming with his latest venture—a captivating wine bar in Williamsburg. Read Amelia Lester's review of The Four Horsemen on newyorker.com. Photograph by @davidbrandongeeting.

“On summer Fridays and Saturdays, in the pleasant garden of the Kings County Distillery, one can enjoy a mint julep or a John Collins (apologies to Tom—it has bourbon in lieu of gin).” Read Emma Allen’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by @boyounillo.
At sixty-four, Ellen Greene returns to her seminal role of Audrey in “Little Shop of Horrors.” Illustration by @wesleyallsbrook.
A cartoon by Liam Francis Walsh, from this week's issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

In this week’s issue, Rachel Aviv investigates why juries in Caddo Parish, Louisiana, have sentenced more people to death, per capita, than any other county in America. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by Oliver Munday.

@liannelahavas boasts a rich and velvety alto, but the half-Greek, half-Jamaican performer has more to offer than a pretty voice. Next week, she plays the Bowery Ballroom in New York City. Photograph by @paridukovic.
This week, Emily Nussbaum watches Lifetime’s “UnREAL,” a fictional series set behind the scenes of a reality show. Illustration by Victor Melamed.
“If you can stomach something that’s not Brooklyn-fermented, the cocktails should be a priority.” Read @stolincokes's review of Threes Brewing on newyorker.com. Illustration by Daniel Krall.
In this week’s issue, Lizzie Widdicombe profiles a former Buddhist monk who is taking mindfulness mainstream with his iPhone app, Headspace. Illustration by Harry Campbell.
This week’s cover, “Rockaway Beach,” by Eric Drooker.
Today's Daily Cartoon by Tom Toro. #TNYcartoons

This marks the hundredth season of Maverick Concerts in Woodstock, NY. This year, the renowned percussion ensemble Nexus débuted a new work by a local legend, the composer and radio personality Peter Schickele. Illustration by @24houremergency.
A cartoon by @lianafinck, from this week’s issue. See more on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
It's a historic day, and one to revisit our 2013 cover, "Moment of Joy," by Jack Hunter. #TNYcovers
In this week’s issue, Jane Kramer examines the Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi’s ambitious plans for his country’s future. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by @riccardovecchio70.

The Supreme Court has ruled that same-sex marriage is a Constitutional right. See our collection of stories covering marriage equality on newyorker.com. This is Bob Staake's "Spectrum of Light," from 2012. #TNYcovers
This week in Tables for Two, @hannahgoldfield reviews George Mendes’s new restaurant, Lupulo, where Portuguese dishes pair beautifully with versatile beer. Photograph by @will_mebane.
A cartoon by Ariel Molvig, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

In Shouts & Murmurs, Monica Heisey imagines the agreements detailed on a contract between green juice and its imbiber: “Under no circumstances will the Juicee ever refer to the actual taste or the temperature of the juice.” Illustration by @benkalt.

Today on newyorker.com, read Lawrence Wright’s exclusive report on the secret civilian effort to save five American hostages in Syria. Pictured here are Diane and John Foley, the parents of the journalist Jim Foley, who was killed last summer after being abducted by ISIS forces. Photograph by Carla van de Puttelaar.

In “Power to the People,” Bill McKibben explores the complicated relationship between electric-utility companies and alternative energy. Read the story, on newyorker.com. Illustration by @doylepartners; photograph by @erichelgas.
This week, the string quintet Edward Arron and Friends kicks off Caramoor, the most elegant of Northeastern music festivals. Photograph by @paridukovic.

“As so often with Pixar, you feel that you are visiting a laboratory crossed with a rainbow.” Anthony Lane reviews “Inside Out,” a film starring the complicated emotions of an eleven-year-old girl, in this week’s issue. Illustration by @mikeyburton.
In a sketchbook from this week’s issue, Barry Blitt comments on the recent controversy surrounding Rachel Dolezal, the former president of the Spokane chapter of the N.A.A.C.P.
A cartoon by @mecharliehankin. See more cartoons from this week’s issue, on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
Just Lorraine’s Place has served what one customer calls "the cheapest drinks in Harlem" for the past five years. Read Nicolas Niarchos’s review, on newyorker.com. Illustration by @jeanniephan.
This summer, the Copenhagen-born artist Jeppe Hein has turned Brooklyn Bridge Park into a fun fair. Photograph by @tobiashutzlerstudios.

On “Apocalypse, girl,” Jenny Hval creates a kind of experimental folk music, which resists the rhythmic and melodic efficiencies of chart pop in favor of something stranger. Read Anwen Crawford’s review, on newyorker.com. Photograph by @olaf_blecker.
A cartoon by Trevor Spaulding, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
“It's distressing contemplating another story like this,” says Barry Blitt. His image, “Nine,” appears on next week’s cover, in response to the shootings in Charleston. #TNYcovers

This week, James Wood reads Alejandro Zambra’s new collection of stories, “My Documents,” and explores how the Chilean writer has helped revitalize Latin-American literature: Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @alvarotapiahidalgo.

In this week’s issue, Rachel Aviv explores Belgium’s embrace of euthanasia—even, in some cases, for people with non-terminal illnesses. Read “The Death Treatment,” on newyorker.com. Photograph courtesy Tom Mortier.
A cartoon by Mike Twohy, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

This week, the photographer Shawn Theodore (@_xST) is hosting @newyorkerphoto’s feed, sharing images from “The Avenues,” a project documenting life in African-American neighborhoods in Philadelphia and Baltimore. #regram
Anthony Lane calls “Jurassic World” “doggedly dull for the first hour and beefy with basic thrills for most of the second.” Read his review, on newyorker.com.
Distraction is hard to define: it can be internal or external, habitual or surprising. Joshua Rothman explores a new theory on getting sidetracked, on newyorker.com. Illustration by @danielzender.

In this week’s issue, Calvin Tomkins profiles the artist Mark Bradford. Bradford layers paper on a stretched canvas, then attacks it with power sanders and other tools, exposing earlier layers. “He works like an archeologist, rediscovering the past.” Read more on newyorker.com. Photograph by @catherineopie.
A cartoon by Barbara Smaller. See more cartoons from this week’s issue, on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

To make her pictures, the artist @anasamoylova prints photos of landscapes, molds them into three-dimensional forms using props like mirrors and iridescent wrapping paper, and photographs her tableaus. The resulting images turn commonplace source material into complex geometric abstractions. See more on newyorker.com.
In this week’s issue, Connie Bruck tells the behind-the-scenes story of Senator Dianne Feinstein’s fight to release the C.I.A. torture report. Photograph by @paridukovic.

This week on @newyorkerphoto, Shawn Theodore (@_xST) is sharing photos from his ongoing project “The Avenues,” which documents life in African-American neighborhoods in Philadelphia and Baltimore. #regram

From 2013 to 2014, the Spanish photographer @arnau_bach photographed Marseille, capturing the false expectations and hidden tensions of the French city. See more from Bach’s series “Capital” on newyorker.com.
A Monday cartoon from the archive, by @drewdernavich. Visit newyorker.com to see more cartoons for the working stiff, compiled by @stolincokes. #TNYcartoons
This week's cover, "Playdate," by Chris Ware. #TNYcovers

The carnivore researcher Alexandra Swanson placed more than two hundred “camera traps” in the Serengeti, aiming to capture animal activity at its most candid moments. See more of the snapshots on newyorker.com.
A cartoon by Liana Finck, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

From drive-in menus to the rise of basil, a century of restaurant menus provides meta-narratives of race, gender, and urban development in Los Angeles, now on display at the city's Public Library. Read more historical, culinary insights on newyorker.com. Image from "To Live and Dine in L.A.: A Century of Menus from the Collection of the Los Angeles Public Library," by Josh Kun, published by Angel City Press.

This week on @newyorkerphoto, @alexkpotter follows the path of Yeminis returning to their country—instead of fleeing it—in a time of war. The constant bombardment on Sanaa’s airport has forced them to make the long journey by sea. Here, a Yemeni man leans against the edge of the boat, talking about what he will do when he returns home. #regram

Can reading make you happier? “In a secular age, I suspect that reading fiction is one of the few remaining paths to transcendence.” Read Ceridwen Dovey’s story on the many forms of bibliotherapy, on newyorker.com. Illustration by @sarahmazzetti.
How does Swiss cheese get its holes? Nicola Twilley investigates, on newyorker.com. Photograph by Berliner Illustrations Gesellschaft / Ullstein Bild via Getty.
A cartoon by Edward Steed. For more, visit our Cartoons at Random page, on newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons

The actress Marion Cotillard “seems to fully inhabit her best roles, which often center on struggle and doubt conveyed through not too much dialogue. That’s part of Cotillard’s genius.” This summer, she makes her New York theatrical début in a fully staged reading of “Joan of Arc at the Stake,” directed by Côme de Bellescize. Read more from Hilton Als, on newyorker.com. Illustration by @sachinteng.

In Montana’s Bitterroot Valley, @muledragger leads a pack of Instagram’s most-loved mules. The animals are crucial to resupplying outposts in federally designated wilderness areas; their donkey genes make them tougher, stronger, and more sure-footed than most horses. Read more about @muledragger and his Internet-famous equine friends in @carocmon's story, on newyorker.com.

In “The Prospectors,” Karen Russell tells the story of two young women in Depression-era Oregon who steal from the wealthy men who court them. One night, they find themselves in the company of twenty-six gracious—and, unfortunately, long-dead—suitors. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photo illustration by @cwynars; birdcage illustration by @krookedfingers.
Today's Daily Cartoon by Christopher Weyant. #TNYcartoons

In a short essay, Thomas McGuane recalls his boyhood visits to Fall River, Massachusetts, during a time “when every town had, as Eudora Welty once said, an individual face, like that of a person.” Read “Fall River,” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @guascoriccardo.

In “Quaestio de Centauris,” Primo Levi recounts the lessons that a young man learns from the centaur who lives with his family—the hardest of which comes when they both fall for the same woman. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photo Illustration by @cwynars.
A cartoon by Christopher Weyant, from the annual Fiction issue. #TNYcartoons

In a short essay, Daniyal Mueenuddin remembers his father, a member of the civil service in undivided India, who had a penchant for hunting crocodiles. Read “Lost Luggage,” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @guascoriccardo.

A sunken car in Devil's Lake near Grand Harbor, North Dakota. This week on @newyorkerphoto, the photographer @iancbates is posting images from North Dakota’s plains, badlands and rolling hills, where he has been working on a project called Meadowlark. "I search, driving into the grassy abyss for those that pique my interest and pull me in into their lives, sharing their stories and faces." #regram

"Adam and Eve lived together happily for a few days. Being blind, Adam never had to see the oblong, splotchy birthmark across Eve’s cheek, or her rotated incisor, or the gnawed remnants of her fingernails. And, being deaf, Eve never had to hear how weakly narcissistic Adam was, how selectively impervious to reason and unwonderfully childlike. It was good.” Read Jonathan Safran Foer’s short story “Love Is Blind and Deaf,” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @mikellis.
A cartoon by P.C. Vey, from the archive. #TNYcartoons

@streetbirdnyc “is a lively, endearing but painfully unsubtle homage to Harlem through the decades, from the graffiti on the rafters to the sneakers dangling from the sprinkler system and the booths upholstered in Louis Vuitton and Gucci leather.” Read Hannah Goldfield’s review, on newyorker.com. Photograph by @brianfinke.

“It is in verse that militants most clearly articulate the fantasy life of jihad.” This week, Robyn Creswell and Bernard Haykel consider how poetry has become a mode of manifesto for ISIS militants. Illustration by @chadhagen.
A cartoon by @jacobfsamuel, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

A look at the color proofs for a photo portfolio in this week’s issue, which features the work of the Italian artist @nicolalocalzo. Lo Calzo’s most recent project, “Obia,” focusses on the Maroons of Suriname and French Guiana—a marginalized community of descendants of former African slaves. Photograph by Senior Photo Editor @siobhanbohnacker.

In a short essay, Rebecca Curtis considers her relationship with a man who, although he is different from her in almost every way, loves H. G. Wells’s “The Time Machine” as much as she does. Read “Morlocks and Eloi,” on newyorker.com. Illustration by @guascoriccardo.

Olivia Chaney and her harmonium are reinvigorating English folk music. John Donohue writes: "When she takes her place behind the harmonium to summon its low moaning notes and, with a steely gaze, starts singing, it’s as if a mystical spirit has entered the room." Chaney visits Roulette tonight and the Living Room on Saturday, in New York City. Illustration by @jonnyruzzo.
A cartoon by @j.a.k._, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

@iancbates has been photographing the vast and uninhabited landscape of North Dakota’s badlands and plains for his project, “Meadowlark.” This is Bobby Harper, one of about twenty residents in the tiny town of Leith, ND where over the past couple of years the community had been terrorized by a man named Craig Cobb. Cobb is a notorious Neo-Nazi who tried to make Leith a white-only enclave before being arrested last year. See @newyorkerphoto for more images and stories from “Meadowlark.” #regram

Over the next two weeks, we will be sharing stories from our annual summer Fiction issue, on newsstands today. Read an excerpt from “Purity,” Jonathan Franzen’s long-anticipated new novel, on newyorker.com. Photo illustration by @cwynars.

This summer, the Public Theatre’s Shakespeare in the Park kicks off its fifty-third season with Michael Greif’s rendition of “The Tempest.” Hilton Als reviews, on newyorker.com. Illustration by @simon_prades.
A cartoon by Drew Panckeri, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
At The Happiest Hour, you can guzzle mai tais amid palm-tree wallpaper and a flamboyance of flamingo tchotchkes. Read Emma Allen’s review, on newyorker.com. Illustration by Daniel Krall.
In this week’s issue, Elizabeth Kolbert examines the past and future of space exploration and humanity’s long-held dream of colonizing Mars. Illustration by Script & Seal.

Witanhurst, London's largest and most expensive home, is second only to Buckingham Palace in size. Who lives there? Ed Caesar investigates. Read the story, on newyorker.com. Illustration by Michael Kirkham.
A cartoon by Mike Twohy, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
"Rebelle is one of those places that regard the wine with as much seriousness as the food.” Read Amelia Lester’s review, on newyorker.com. Photograph by @landonnordeman.

Luanda, Angola—not Moscow, Tokyo, or Hong Kong—has become the world’s most expensive city for expats. Read Michael Specter’s story on the severe inequality of the Angolan oil boom, on newyorker.com. Illustration by Emiliano Ponzi.
Today's Daily Cartoon by Christopher Weyant. #TNYcartoons
This week’s cover, “Suiting Up,” by Mark Ulriksen. #TNYcovers
"Mad Max: Fury Road" gathers up all that we seem to crave from our movies and yanks it to the limit. Read Anthony Lane's review, on newyorker.com. Illustration by @chrisbmurray.
“This summer is a time of self-surpassing efforts for actors and directors alike.” Read Richard Brody’s Summer Movies Preview, on newyorker.com. Illustration by @amanda.s.lanzone.
A cartoon by Alex Gregory, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

“Wendy Whelan, who retired from New York City Ballet last fall, possesses certain traits—probing intelligence, grit—that render her irresistible to dance-makers.” Read Marina Harss’s Summer Dance Preview, on newyorker.com. Illustration by @okchickadee.

A portrait of the actress Léa Seydoux. This week on @newyorkerphoto, @julien_mignot and @studio_camille_russeau collaborated to make portraits of the filmmakers, actors, and artists at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival. #regram
In June, @champagnepapi will headline the first night of @govballnyc. For more from our Summer Music Preview, visit newyorker.com. Illustration by Goñi Montes.
A cartoon by Kaamran Hafeez, from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons

“Summertime is slow on Broadway, but a clown car of theatre festivals keeps things lively.” This summer, at the Lincoln Center Festival, Japan’s Ninagawa Company stages an adaptation of Haruki Murakami’s dreamlike novel “Kafka on the Shore.” For more, read Michael Schulman’s Summer Theatre Preview, on newyorker.com. Illustration by @blobsma.

In this week’s issue, David Owen travels the Colorado River to see firsthand how overuse, appropriation, and climate change are threatening one of the west’s most crucial water sources. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @brianlfrank.

In this week’s issue, Emily Nussbaum reflects on David Letterman’s comedic legacy: “His manner suggested that TV could puncture the culture, rather than prop it up.” After more than thirty years, the final episode of “Late Show with David Letterman” airs tonight. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @stan_chow.

At Astoria Seafood, "People of all ages, ethnicities, and economic brackets are drawn by a powerful common denominator: fresh fish, prepared simply and sold at a fraction of what it costs almost anywhere else." Read Hannah Goldfield’s review, on newyorker.com. Photograph by @lrnlncstr.

In this week’s issue, Jill Lepore examines why reproductive rights are in retreat at the very moment that gay rights are advancing. Read the full story on newyorker.com. Illustration by @cristianacouceiro.

“Drifting in Daylight” is a six-week show of outdoor works by eight artists, installed around the northern end of Central Park. Spencer Finch, a New Yorker who interprets light, offers ice cream in colors he derived from a sunset. Photograph by @davidbrandongeeting.
This week’s cover, “Early Start,” by Carter Goodrich. #TNYcovers

"Shamir moves freely: his songs draw on the history of dance music, especially disco and house, without being burdened by it." Read the full review of @shamir326's début album, "Rachet," on newyorker.com. Photograph by Jeff Minton.

The Getty Museum’s exhibition “Light, Paper, Process: Reinventing Photography” features work by artists who often dispense with the camera and lens entirely. Instead, they employ the bare essentials of paper, chemicals, and light to fashion near-abstract images that have a tantalizing physical presence. Photograph by John Chiara. See more on newyorker.com.
At Momofuku Ko, David Chang “has taught us at once how to take food more seriously and consume it more casually.” Read Amelia Lester’s review, on newyorker.com. Photograph by @jamespomerantz.
We are proud to announce that Bob Staake’s “Broken Arch” cover depicting the events in Ferguson, Missouri, has been selected as ASME’s Cover of the Year. #TNYcovers

“Even if Faulkner isn’t your thing, or if confusion of characters and time frames aren’t, either, it’s important to see the piece.” Hilton Als on a theatrical rendition of “The Sound and the Fury” at the Public theatre. Illustration by Marc Aspinall.
This week on @newyorkerphoto, @chiaragoia is sharing images from the opening week of the Venice Biennale. #regram
A cartoon by Paul Noth in our Innovators Issue, on newsstands and newyorker.com today. #TNYcartoons
A Mother's Day cover, by Art Spiegelman. #TNYcovers

To mark Mother’s Day this year, @savefamilyphotos spent a week hosting the @newyorkerphoto feed, posting images of family matriarchs along with moving reflections from their children and grandchildren. See more Mother’s Day photos on newyorker.com. #regram

A team of neuroscientists engineered their own strain of rabies to study the interplay of individual neurons in the brain. They gave the virus a fluorescence gene borrowed from jellyfish; as it moved, it left behind a luminous wake. Read the full story, and see more images, on newyorker.com. Image courtesy of Nicholas Wall.

In this week’s issue, Atul Gawande investigates the pervasive crisis of of “low-value” medical care—unnecessary tests and treatments that come at huge expense and do little or nothing to improve the health of American patients. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by @annaparini.
This week, @savefamilyphotos is hosting @newyorkerphoto’s feed in honor of Mother’s Day, featuring images of remarkable women who have shaped the lives of their families. #regram
In “Futuristic Archaeology,” the photographer Daesung Lee explores a changing Mongolia. To see more photos from the series, visit newyorker.com.
Today's Daily Cartoon by Christopher Weyant. #deflategate #TNYcartoons
Today's Daily Cartoon by Christopher Weyant. #TNYcartoons

In this week’s issue, Dan Chiasson reviews Terrance Hayes’s fifth collection of poetry: "The poems handle form so deftly that they sometimes seem backfilled with feeling, as though Hayes is afraid of his own aplomb.” Read more on newyorker.com. Artwork by @tonyrodriguezillustration.
A cartoon by Julia Suits, from this week's issue. For more, visit newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
The fierce and seductive men of flamenco, captured by @ruvenafanador. For more, visit newyorker.com.

Centuries of Chinese culture have inspired designers in the West. @MetMuseum's Costume Institute and Department of Asian Art examine that influence in more than a hundred pieces, including this Dior gown, by John Galliano, in “China: Through the Looking Glass.” Photo by @Platon. #ChinaLookingGlass
The @whitneymuseum is now open at its new downtown location. @landonnordeman got an early look. To see more, visit newyorker.com. (Or visit the Whitney.)
An early look at next week's cover, "Injustice: Baltimore, 2015." Read about artist Peter Mendelsund's inspiration for the work on newyorker.com. #TNYcovers
@davidemon’s “In the Russian East” is a tribute both to Richard Avedon’s work and to the enduring lure of the Trans-Siberian Railroad. View more on newyorker.com.
This week, Ryan Lizza takes an in-depth look at Elizabeth Warren’s next campaign: to influence Hillary Clinton’s run for President. Read the full story on newyorker.com. Photo by @lrnlncstr.
Ahead of the @whitneymuseum’s official opening later this week, @landonnordeman captured the energy and poetry of the new building. Visit newyorker.com for more photos.
Thanks, Larry Wilmore, for joining us this weekend at the #WHCD. @thenightlyshow

Regram, @lenadunham: "Yes that is David Remnick on LEAD guitar with LaChrisha Brown vocalizing at the White House Correspondents Jam. 'Twas an honor to introduce The Sequoias: journalists by day, lords of rock by night." #WHCD
Laverne Cox, at last night's #WHCD party. Photo by @dimitrioskphoto.
Scenes from last night: Nasim Pedrad, Cecily Strong--the host of tonight's #WHCD--and Michael Kelly at our party. Photo by @dimitrioskphoto.
Esther Fein, David Remnick, and @lenadunham at our #WHCD party. Photo by @dimitrioskphoto.
