On @newyorkerphoto this week, Misha Friedman takes us to the police academy in Kyiv, Ukraine, where police are being prepared to replace a Soviet-style militia.
Roger Angell on Mark Ulriksen’s latest cover, “Baseball Ballet”: “This drawing is prettier than anything seen in the Bronx so far this spring.” #TNYcovers

“I received a phone call informing me that my father had gone into cardiac arrest and needed to be put into a medically induced coma. I was alone and no idea of what would await me on the other end of my flight.” This week, @ianwillms shares his father’s journey from death to life after a tragic motorcycle accident. Follow @newyorkerphoto for more. #regram

In a small dome set on a remote volcano, six prospective astronauts simulate life on Mars. Visit newyorker.com to read Tom Kizzia’s story on the HI-SEAS research project. Illustration by Emiliano Ponzi.
Today’s daily cartoon by Emily Flake. #Coachella #TNYcartoons
On this week’s cover, Bruce McCall pictures life in the coming age of friendlier Cuban-American relations. #TNYcovers
“In the end, ‘Ex Machina’ lives and dies by Alicia Vikander.” Visit newyorker.com to read Anthony Lane’s review. Illustration by @brianewing.
In this week’s issue, a story about $22 billion in fake loans, a family feud, German filmmakers, and a maritime escape from Bahrain. Read more on newyorker.com. Illustration by @shoutilloz.
This week, @ilangodfrey is hosting @newyorkerphoto’s feed from the Umbabat Nature Reserve, in South Africa. #regram
“Apologies to my wife, but Penny, my miniature poodle, is my world,” says Harry Bliss, whose dog makes an appearance on this week’s cover. #TNYcovers

Christopher Marley struggled to balance his interest in taxidermy with his distaste for killing organisms. Now he turns reclaimed animals into art. View more from his forthcoming book, “Biophilia,” on newyorker.com.
From McLovin to Dwight Schrute, the casting director Allison Jones is remaking American comedy one misfit at a time. Read a profile of her on newyorker.com. Photo by @dollyfaibyshev.
This week, follow @newyorkerphoto as @dina_litovsky shares glimpses of daily life in Myanmar. #regram
This week’s cover, “Everybody Who’s Anybody,” by Carter Goodrich. #TNYcovers
This week on @newyorkerphoto, @mattblack_blackmatt documents life in Mexico’s poorest state since forty-three students went missing. Visit newyorker.com for more of his portraits.
“The problem with Happy Ending is that you can’t eat a double entendre.” Read Amelia Lester’s review, on newyorker.com. Photograph by @dina_litovsky.

Emily Nussbaum on “Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt”: “At times, it resembles a Nickelodeon tween show—which is just how its heroine might imagine her own life. Yet, without any contradiction, it’s also a sitcom about a rape survivor.” Read her full review on newyorker.com. Illustration by David Saracino.

Lonni Sue Johnson has no memory and no hippocampus, but she hasn’t lost her passion for art. On newyorker.com, read Daniel Zalewski’s profile of an artist who clings to her identity by drawing nonstop. Photograph by @mrtoledano.
Today’s daily cartoon by Emily Flake. #TNYcartoons

This week, six months after the disappearance of forty-three students in Mexico, @mattblack_blackmatt revisits his time in Guerrero, the country’s second-poorest and most violent state. Follow @newyorkerphoto for more. #regram
This week’s cover, “Clinton’s Emoji,” by Barry Blitt. #TNYcovers
A rare trove of century-old dresses from the Parisian haute-couture house Callot Soeurs was recently uncovered in a Florentine villa. For more of @paridukovic’s photos, visit newyorker.com.
In celebration of our Style Issue, some classic fashion profiles. Read them all, on newyorker.com/archive.

In recent years, the homely Birkenstock has become a curiously fashionable object. Rebecca Mead travels to the company headquarters in Germany to explore the past, and future, of the classic sandal. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photo by @paridukovic.

“For the average Joe who snags an off-hours reservation by calling a month in advance, the Polo Bar is like Disneyland for celebrity gawkers.” Read Hannah Goldfield’s review on newyorker.com. Photo by @erichelgas.
In his series “Vanishing Island,” the Ukrainian photographer @arthurbondar captured life in the Crimean Peninsula before and after the referendum. Visit newyorker.com for more.

In 1972, Michael McConville witnessed his mother’s abduction by I.R.A. members. He still sees some of the kidnappers around Belfast. Read Patrick Radden Keefe’s story on murder, accountability, and the long shadow of the Troubles. Photograph by @pietertenhoopen.
“I wanted to show the hipster in his natural habitat.” –@porliniers on his cover for this week’s issue. #TNYcovers

This week, Anthony Lane reviews David Cronenberg’s “Maps to the Stars”: “There remains a nagging sense that the finished film lags behind the times.” Read his full take on newyorker.com. Illustration by Boris Pelcer.
On newyorker.com, a look at Saul Leiter’s photographs of New York in the nineteen-fifties and sixties. (Estate of Saul Leiter. Courtesy Howard Greenberg Gallery.)

Emily Nussbaum on “Fresh Off the Boat”: “If the show emphasizes family warmth, that theme is complicated by sharp sociological details.” Read the full review on newyorker.com. Illustration by David Saracino.
This week, Loulou d’Aki (@dakiloulou) hosts @newyorkerphoto’s feed from Tehran. #regram

In the magazine this week, Rebecca Mead writes about Lin-Manuel Miranda’s “Hamilton”: “The musical presents the birth of the nation in an unfamiliar but necessary light: not solely as the work of élite white men but as the foundational story of all Americans.” Read the full story on newyorker.com. Every day, on newyorker.com, Emily Flake draws a cartoon based on current events. #TNYcartoons

“a cloud has no shape. As with us: only

when someone looks hard, or we catch

our reflections, do we solidify” - An excerpt of James Richardson’s poem, “Essay on Clouds,” in the Feb. 2 issue.

#regram via @newyorkerphoto, where @jacksonkrule has been posting behind-the-scene photos of our move downtown. #TNYmoves
Research into psychedelics may hold a key to treating anxiety, addiction, and existential dread. Read Michael Pollan’s story, on newyorker.com. Illustration by @doylepartners.
This week’s cover, “A Walk in the Snow,” by Mark Ulriksen. #TNYcovers
In this week’s issue, Alec Wilkinson profiles Yitang Zhang, who recently solved a theorem that has stumped mathematicians for over a century. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photo by @peterbohler.
From our shelves of writers’ scrapbooks in the archive. #libraryshelfie @nypl
Truman Capote once carved his name into Harold Ross’s desk, now at home in our new #1WTC offices. Photo by @jacksonkrule. #TNYmoves

In the magazine this week, Nick Paumgarten reflects on our move: “What was worth saving? Not as much as you’d anticipated, once you got into the spirit of paperlessness.” The archives, above, came with us. Photo by @jacksonkrule. #TNYmoves
Today’s daily cartoon by @joedator. #TNYcartoons
This week’s cover, by Bruce McCall, commemorates our move downtown. #TNYmoves #TNYcovers
Farewell Times Square. Regram via New Yorker staffer @benjaminnyc. #TNYmoves
Editor David Remnick and Deputy Editor Pam McCarthy sort through notes from Harold Ross, the magazine’s first editor. Photo by @jacksonkrule. #TNYmoves
We still have a magazine to put out this week. Photo by @jacksonkrule. #TNYmoves
The New Yorker book bench—yes, there’s a bench under all those books. We’ll be donating the ones that aren’t coming with us. Photo by @jacksonkrule. #TNYmoves

Cartoon assistant @stolincokes uncovers a 1959 drawing by Dana Fradon that never ran in the magazine. Its caption reads: “I’ve got $5 million worth of endorsement lined up on your return. When and if.” Photo by @jacksonkrule. #TNYmoves
But we’re taking these with us. Photo by @jacksonkrule. #TNYmoves
#TNYmoves Photo by @jacksonkrule.

As we prepare to move down to #1WTC this week, we’ll be sharing glimpses of the process and the things we uncover. Here, Bruce, who for 36 years has kept this place running, unveils a box of untouched copies of the magazine’s first issue (Feb. 21, 1925). Photo by @jacksonkrule. #TNYmoves
Last year, @geosteinmetz captured New York City from above during each of the four seasons. For more of his winter photos, visit newyorker.com.
This week’s cover, “The Dream of Reconciliation,” by Barry Blitt. #MLKDay #TNYcovers
A Friday cartoon by Danny Shanahan. #TNYcartoons
On @newyorkerphoto this week, @joaquintrujillo offers glimpses of Mexico’s Ferias Patronales, in his hometown of Ermita De Guadalupe. #regram
An update on our book situation, one week before the move to #1WTC.
“ ‘Still Alice’ is worth watching, for the sake of Julianne Moore.” Anthony Lane reviews the new movie in this week’s issue of the magazine. Illustration by Simon Prades.
Visit newyorker.com for more of Bob Eckstein’s live-drawings of last night’s events. #GoldenGlobes

“There are only 3-4 hours of daylight here, and because we are surrounded by mountains, the sun can never rise up higher than the mountains during December and January.” This week, @annielingphoto hosts @newyorkerphoto’s feed from Ólafsfjördur, Iceland. #regram
The cover of next week’s issue, by Ana Juan. #JeSuisCharlie #TNYcovers
A 2006 cartoon by Michael Shaw. #JeSuisCharlie
At @greenpointfish, “even the fiercest brunch hater will have a hard time arguing with the weekend midday menu.” Read Hannah Goldfield’s review on newyorker.com. Photo by @jamespomerantz.
A daily cartoon by @joedator. For more, visit newyorker.com. #TNYcartoons
Visit newyorker.com to read David Sedaris’s new story about a family vacation at the beach. Illustration by Miguel Gallardo.

This week, in Tables for Two, Amelia Lester reviews the Argentine steak house Balvanera: “Go with someone who loves you: the steaks come with a head of roasted garlic on the side, and there’s more in the chorizo.” Photograph by @lrnlncstr.
A cartoon by Michael Maslin, from this week’s issue of the magazine. #TNYcartoons
@paridukovic had a busy year, photographing everything from Full Figured Fashion Week to a studio performance by @perfumegenius. Visit newyorker.com for some of our favorite shots from 2014.
This week’s cover, “Dance Around a Piano,” by Jean-Jacques Sempé.

“I’m dreaming of an ozone layer,
Just like the one I used to know,
Which kept out UV rays,
Before aerosol sprays,
And allowed for actual snow.” For more climate-change Christmas carols, visit newyorker.com. Illustration by Nishant Choksi.
A cartoon by David Sipress, from this week’s issue of the magazine.

In our World Changers issue, Evan Osnos chronicles Samantha Power’s evolution from an activist who was often critical of the foreign-policy establishment to a diplomat and senior adviser to President Obama. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @vansarki.
@thefamilyacid is a project to digitize over 40 years’ worth of Roger Steffens’s Kodachrome slide photography. His daughter Kate shares some of the works on @newyorkerphoto this week. #regram
In 1965, Steve Schapiro followed the historic Selma-to-Montgomery march, documenting a resonant chapter in the black freedom struggle. For more of his rarely-seen photographs, visit newyorker.com.
Holiday covers by George Booth, including this week’s (on left).
“Paul Thomas Anderson has done Thomas Pynchon proud.” Anthony Lane reviews the film adaptation of “Inherent Vice” in the magazine this week. Illustration by Chris B. Murray.
Today, the @cooperhewitt reopens after a $91-million renovation that includes an “immersion room,” in which you can project your own wallpaper designs. Photograph by Raymond Meier.

With a show at @websterhall tonight, Parquet Courts and PC Worship are reviving the city’s rock scene. For more events going on around New York City, visit newyorker.com. Illustration by Gloria Pizzilli.
Last week, we sent @landonnordeman to capture @artbasel Miami Beach. Take a look at his photos, on newyorker.com.

The meteorologist Vyacheslav Korotki lives alone at an isolated Arctic outpost, measuring the temperatures, the snowfall, and the winds. Evgenia Arbugaeva, a photographer who grew up in the Arctic town of Tiksi, spent two extended stays with him. For more photos, visit newyorker.com.
This week’s cover, “High and Low,” by Ivan Brunetti.

This week, Sasha Frere-Jones reviews the Wu-Tang Clan’s latest album: “Although the group has been more flux than stasis in its career, every m.c. is as strong as he was twenty years ago.” Illustration by Stanley Chow.
David Sipress comments on the world’s growing #serial addiction, in today’s daily cartoon.
The titles reviewed in Briefly Noted this week.

“Photography took me off the streets,” said 29-year-old @tomsaater. When Tom was homeless in Nigeria, he would ask tourists if he could use their cameras to take pictures, and then if they could send him the pictures he had taken. Today, Tom is a social documentary photographer and filmmaker. For more of @malinfezehai’s photos from the Addis Foto Fest this week, follow @newyorkerphoto. #regram

Calf riders wait in the arena alley on the last day of the Youth Bull Riders World Finals, in Abilene, Texas. Visit newyorker.com for more of @jonnotherattman’s photos, and to read Burkhard Bilger’s story on the dangerous world of youth competitive bull riding.
Google thinks it’s changing management forever. So did G.M. In the magazine this week, Nicholas Lemann explores the art of the corporate devotional. Illustration by Adam Simpson.
A Thanksgiving cartoon by Liza Donnelly.
“I wanted to comment on the tragic rift that we’re witnessing,” Bob Staake says about his cover for next week’s issue. #Ferguson
In this week’s issue, Sasha Frere-Jones writes about @iamtovelo, @taylorswift, and the global influence of Swedepop. Illustration by António Soares.
Bruce McCall’s cover this week brings attention to what has become the subject of numerous editorials and rallies. Read more about it on newyorker.com.

“There’s an exuberance to the pork-chop dish, served with its crackling skin intact, in a plating that resembles a Dutch still-life.” Visit newyorker.com to read Amelia Lester’s take on @upland_nyc’s Californian cuisine. Photo by @jamespomerantz.
A cartoon from this week’s issue by Zachary Kanin. For more, visit newyorker.com/humor.
“Life is difficult and fucked up and complicated. The cutting room isn’t.” Remembering Mike Nichols, photographed here in John Lahr’s 2000 Profile. Photo by Richard Avedon.
Can the most accomplished woman in e-sports save StarCraft from decline? Visit newyorker.com to read Ben McGrath’s profile of Scarlett. Photo by @jennyhueston.

“Promoting diversity isn’t, as many techies think, pure do-gooderism. It’s genuinely good for business.” In the magazine this week, James Surowiecki explores the tech industry’s gender disparity. Illustration by Christoph Niemann.
This week, @vittoriamentasti hosts @newyorkerphoto’s feed from Israel and Palestine, where she’s exploring the physical and spiritual properties of the Dead Sea. #regram
In the Tech Issue this week: Lizzie Widdicombe on a talent company that represents computer programmers, John Seabrook on @spotify’s business model, and more. Cover by Richard McGuire.
An autumn sketchbook by Mark Ulriksen, in this week’s issue.
“If you don’t know the facts, try to keep it that way until you see ‘Foxcatcher,’ the better to savor its strangeness.” Read Anthony Lane’s review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Charles Williams.
This week, @pietertenhoopen hosts @newyorkerphoto’s feed from a pediatric clinic on the outskirts of Khartoum, Sudan. Above, Hawa, nine years old, waits to hear her little sister’s diagnosis. #regram

For over a decade, Martin Schoeller captured a wide range of famous characters for the magazine. A selection of these portraits are on view in a retrospective of his career at @hastedkraeutler. See more on newyorker.com.
In this week’s issue, Ryan Lizza looks at prospective challengers to a Hillary Clinton nomination in 2016. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by John Cuneo.
In advance of our move to #1WTC, it looks like everyone is getting books for the holidays.
This week’s cover, “The Elephant in the Room,” by the Argentine artist @porliniers.

Visit newyorker.com to read Alec Wilkinson’s story on the success and future of @modfarm, which founder Ann Marie Gardner calls “the farming magazine for media professionals.” Photo by @the_chris_buck.

King Bee’s pork-belly cracklings are “as irresistible as the best French fries and as sweet and sticky as taffy,” Hannah Goldfield writes. Read her review, and others, on newyorker.com. Photo by @quesofrito.
“Interstellar,” David Denby writes, “makes you feel virtuous for having sat through it rather than happy that you saw it.” Read his full review on newyorker.com. Illustration by Chris B. Murray.
Happy birthday to Harold Ross, who founded the magazine in 1925. Here, a portrait accompanying a 1995 profile of him (shown on his old desk).
On Chris Ware’s cover this week: a room full of nervous patients waiting for flu shots.

This week, @yanapaskova hosts @newyorkerphoto’s feed from Bulgaria, bridging the country’s Communist past with its current state of democracy, twenty-five years after the fall of the Berlin Wall. #regram
Remembering Car Talk’s Tom Magliozzi in today’s daily cartoon, by David Sipress. #TNYcartoons

“If this doesn’t work I can definitely see no one letting me direct a movie again.” In this week’s issue, Chris Rock talks to Kelefa Sanneh about his new film, “Top Five.” Read the story on newyorker.com. Photo by @paridukovic.
P is for pizza: Over the past week, @JamesPomerantz has been sharing his favorite New York City foods from A to Z with @newyorkerphoto. Post yours and tag them #TNYeats. #regram
A #Halloween cartoon by David Borchart from this week’s issue. #TNYcartoons
An illustration by Tom Gauld, on newyorker.com.
A 1985 Halloween cover by George Booth. #tbt
“If anyone tells you they had a bad time at Nobu New York, they’re lying.” In Tables for Two this week, Amelia Lester explores the restaurant’s enduring appeal. Photo by @jamespomerantz.
In this week’s issue, Michael Specter searches for an explanation for America’s ever-increasing avoidance of gluten. Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by Paul Rogers.
This week, @jamespomerantz shares his A to Z of New York food and drink on @newyorkerphoto. Join by posting your own photos, and tagging them #TNYeats.
“It’s an unprecedentedly excellent time to drink beer in Brooklyn.” Read more about Peter de Sève’s cover for our food issue, on newyorker.com.

Billy Joel hasn’t released a new pop album since 1993—but he was still one of the highest-grossing pop acts of the summer. Nick Paumgarten profiles the performer in this week’s issue. Photo by @paridukovic.
In the magazine this week, we published Tom Hanks’s début work of fiction, “Alan Bean Plus Four.” Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by Daniel Hertzberg.
Today’s daily cartoon by David Sipress.
On newyorker.com, Bob Eckstein shares drawings and stories inspired by bookstores around New York City.

This week, @dzalcman and @dannyghitis curate stories and images that aim to discuss and destigmatize mental illness. For more from this collaboration between @echosight and @1in20, follow @newyorkerphoto. #regram
“For some, a meal might wind up as three courses of perfectly fried dough, in various guises. Wear sweatpants.” Read Amelia Lester’s review, and others, on newyorker.com. Photo by Brea Souders.
In 1994, Susan Orlean joined Oscar de la Renta in his studio, where she chronicled the glamour and chaos in the lead-up to fashion week. Today we remember the iconic designer.
This week’s cover, “Fun and Games in Congress,” by Mark Ulriksen.
This week, Amelia Lester visits Dirty French, a New York City restaurant that “seems intent on bringing sexy back.” Read her review, and others, on newyorker.com. Photo by @erichelgas.
A look at the titles reviewed in Briefly Noted this week.

What happens when a New Yorker writer brings a snake into Chanel and a turtle to the @frickcollection? In the magazine this week, Patricia Marx sees just how far she can push society’s ever-increasing embrace of emotional-support animals. Photo by Corby Kummer.
Was Beethoven too great for the good of music? In this week’s issue, Alex Ross considers the composer’s profound influence. Illustration by Daniel Adel.
This week on @newyorkerphoto, @thomas_sauvin shares historical images recovered from a Chinese recycling plant on the edge of Beijing. #regram
Fall reading on this week’s cover, by Tom Gauld.
“If I said the things he does, I’d be beaten up. He’s a sociopath!” Larry David discussed his “Curb Your Enthusiasm” character with David Remnick at #NYerFest. (Photo by Thos Robinson/Getty Images)
The New Yorker's @kylebrzz weighed in during last night's Cats vs. Dogs event at #NYerFest. (#TeamDogs won.)
Watch our live stream of Jane Mayer’s virtual interview with Edward Snowden, on newyorker.com. #NYerFest

Last night, Bill Hader took a break from rehearsing for his @nbcsnl hosting gig to talk to Lizzie Widdicombe at #NYerFest, telling Taran Killam to play him while he was away. (Photo by Bryan Bedder/Getty Images)
We love what you did with Eustace, @mindykaling. See you tonight at #NYerFest. #regram
@lenadunham sits down with staff writer Ariel Levy at #NYerFest. (Photo by Thos Robinson/Getty Images for The New Yorker)
In next week’s issue, George Packer profiles Laura Poitras, the filmmaker Edward Snowden trusted most. Read the story early, on newyorker.com. Photograph by James Day.
A good morning to read our Money Issue. Cover by Bruce McCall.
A cartoon by Danny Shanahan from this week’s issue of the magazine. For more, visit newyorker.com/humor. #TNYcartoons

Amelia Lester on @gwmarket: “Just about all of the eight venders are at the peak of food-world buzziness, and, most of the time, their outposts live up to the hype.” Read the full review on newyorker.com. Photograph by @lrnlncstr.
Following California’s longest, driest summer, @mattblack_blackmatt captures the current situation in the state’s agricultural Central Valley. For more, follow @newyorkerphoto. #regram
Read Haruki Murakami’s short story in this week’s issue and on newyorker.com. Photo illustration by Merlin.
The titles reviewed in the Briefly Noted section of the magazine this week.
The photographer Moises Saman captured the assault on #HongKong protesters on Friday. For more of his powerful photos, visit newyorker.com.

In the magazine, Calvin Tomkins profiles Chris Ofili, whose first major New York retrospective opens at the @newmuseum this month. Knowing of the artist’s admiration for the Malian photographer Malick Sidibé, @newyorkerphoto arranged for Sidibé to take the portrait that accompanies the story.

At Hometown Bar-B-Que, “Billy Durney has nailed a formula: mostly Texas, a touch of North Carolina and Kansas City, but very Brooklyn.” For more restaurant reviews, visit newyorker.com. Photograph by @brianfinke.

“This is Lycabettus from the neighborhood of Pagrati in central Athens. A man of routine, my pappou walked every morning from his home in Kolonaki, to his studio in this area.” @eirinivour, a photographer from Greece, hosts @newyorkerphoto’s feed this week, sharing work inspired by the paintings and sketches of her grandfather. #regram
Visit newyorker.com to read James Wood’s review of Eimear McBride’s “blazingly daring” début novel, “A Girl Is a Half-Formed Thing.” Photograph by Philipp Ebeling.
This week, @malualvarezfotos hosts our photo department’s feed from a remote coastal region in Northern Spain, the homeland of her grandfathers. Follow @newyorkerphoto for more. #regram

“Dimes is where the cool kids want to be, discussing Bushwick apartments or their latest love affair or the purpose of Instagram.” Read Shauna Lyon’s review of the Chinatown eatery, on newyorker.com. Photograph by @erichelgas.
This week’s #football cover, “Illegal Procedure,” by Barry Blitt.

In the magazine this week, Dexter Filkins reports on the battle between ISIS and the Kurds, and the future of Iraq. Read the story on newyorker.com. (Above: Masoud Barzani, the President of the Kurdish regional government. Photograph by Moises Saman.)
In light of today’s referendum on Scottish independence, a daily cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz.
The cover of our Style Issue, by Lorenzo Mattotti.
In the magazine this week, Rivka Galchen profiles @mistyonpointe, #ballet’s rising star, whose goal is “to become the first African-American principal dancer with A.B.T.” Photograph by @paridukovic.

“This true cowboy from Kansas was waiting on a corner in Green River, Utah, for his ‘old lady’ to pick him up. He’s showing her around the West.” Follow @newyorkerphoto this week, as the photographer @jimmangan shares images from his road trip through the American Southwest.

In this week’s Style Issue, Lizzie Widdicombe attends New York’s Full Figured Fashion Week, and explores the rapidly evolving plus-size #fashion industry. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by @paridukovic.
“Performing, for him, is not so much a profession as a destiny.” Read John Lahr’s Profile of Al Pacino, on newyorker.com. Photograph by Dan Winters.

“I was on assignment in rural Togo, photographing a rice farmer. She had her kids running all over the farm, being kids. The moment they saw the camera, one started posing and the other was just amused at his brother’s instant transformation into a hip hop star.” Photo by Nana Kofi Acquah (@africashowboy). Follow @newyorkerphoto for more. #regram

While working on his film called “9/10: The Final Hours,” for the National Geographic Channel, Erik Nelson came across a trove of photographs taken by a World Trade Center electrician, Konstantin Petrov, in 2001. View more on newyorker.com. #September11

Ready for this year's New Yorker Festival? Advance ticket sales begin tomorrow at 11 A.M. ET, exclusively for MasterCard cardholders. All tickets go on general sale Friday at 12 noon ET. Visit newyorker.com/festival for details. Illustration by Barry Blitt.
This week's cover (top-right), which honors Saul Steinberg's centenary, joins other New Yorker classics by the legendary artist.

Theodor Adorno and Walter Benjamin taught intellectuals to pore over rap lyrics and sneaker ads. Visit newyorker.com to read Alex Ross’s take on the prophets of pop culture. Illustration by Patrick Bremer.

Arisleyda Tapia, who has worked at a Washington Heights McDonald’s for eight years, makes $8.35 an hour. 
In this week’s issue, William Finnegan visits the front lines of the fight for improved wages and conditions for America’s fast-food workers. Photograph by Misha Friedman.
Benjamin Schwartz remembers Joan Rivers, in today’s daily cartoon.

“By opening in the Flatiron district, [David] Waltuck is announcing both that he’s in the big-boys club ... and that he’s playing it safe. That’s O.K., though, since Waltuck’s safe is delicious and decadent.” Read Shauna Lyon’s review of élan on newyorker.com. Photo by @joaquintrujillo.

In this week’s issue, David Kushner takes an in-depth look at the history of the radical hacking collective Anonymous. Read the story on newyorker.com. (Paper Sculpture by Jeff Nishinaka/Photograph by Scott Dunbar)
Follow along as @markosian takes over @newyorkerphoto’s feed this week from Russia’s North Caucasus. #regram
An early look at next week's cover by Mark Ulriksen. Read Roger Angell's farewell to Derek Jeter, on newyorker.com.
Today’s daily cartoon by Benjamin Schwartz.

Bastian, a start-up entrepreneur from Chile, gets some help assembling his new bike from his housemates at a co-living space in San Francisco's Mission District. Photo by @laurakmorton. Follow @newyorkerphoto for more dispatches from San Francisco and Silicon Valley this week. #regram

“Just about everything’s enjoyable, even if you didn’t know you wanted lamb chops dusted in parsley bread crumbs, doused in jus, with a side of lamb bacon and vegetables in a Le Creuset pot.” Read Amelia Lester’s review of Bâtard on newyorker.com. Photo by Robin Siegel.

In this week’s issue, William Finnegan travels to Mexico and profiles Saúl Armendáriz, better known as the drag queen Cassandro—a world welterweight champion of lucha libre. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photo by @katieorlinsky.
An early look at next week’s cover, “Ferguson, Missouri,” by Eric Drooker.

Robert O’Hara’s latest full-length play, “Bootycandy,” begins previews at @phnyc tomorrow. Read why Hilton Als considers the playwright and director a virtuoso, on newyorker.com. Illustration by Steve Wacksman.

Yazidi refugees ride in the back of a truck, after being rescued from the Singar mountains, arriving to safety in Syria. Photo © Erin Trieb (@erintrieb), taken on Aug. 9, 2014. #regram via @newyorkerphoto

“Bob Robinson was Bob Lambert, and Bob Lambert was a spy.” In this week’s issue, Lauren Collins investigates one woman’s discovery that her long-estranged boyfriend—the father of her child—was an undercover agent. Illustration by Alex Williamson.
A look at this week’s cover by Danny Shanahan.
In the New Yorker copy department; contemplating some light weekend reading.

“With ‘The Maids,’ [Jean] Genet introduced a new way of making theatre, treating it as a plastic art,” Hilton Als writes in this week’s issue. Benedict Andrews’s staging of the play runs through August 16, as part of the @lincolncenter Festival. Illustration by Edward Kinsella.

In this week’s issue, Sasha Frere-Jones asks: “Do people enjoy ‘Weird Al’ Yankovic because he’s funny or because he’s not that funny?” Read his story on the comedian’s enduring appeal, at newyorker.com. Illustration by Mr. Bingo.
Farley Katz remembers #RobinWilliams in today's daily cartoon.

“It’s impossible to stay mad at Iris Café Store # 9, which feels like the best-kept secret in a neighborhood that’s known less for its interesting dining than for its streets named after fruits.” Visit newyorker.com for Amelia Lester’s full review of the Brooklyn Heights restaurant. Photo by @jamespomerantz.

New friend on the Danube Delta. Photo by @amivitale. For the past five weeks, eight photographers have been documenting life along the river as part of Danube Revisited: The Inge Morath Truck Project. For more photos from the journey, visit newyorker.com and @newyorkerphoto. #regram
Visit newyorker.com/archive to read Calvin Tomkins’s 1999 story on Philippe Petit, whose daring World Trade Center wire-walk took place 40 years ago today. #tbt
At 10AM EST, head to Reddit for an #AMA chat with New Yorker contributor, author of “The Hot Zone,” and Ebola expert Richard Preston. Ask him anything.

In the magazine this week, Malcolm Gladwell explores the upward mobility of organized crime in America, and why such criminal activity “wasn’t a rejection of legitimate society. It was an attempt to join in.” Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by Leslie Herman.
In this week’s issue, David Remnick explores how Vladimir Putin’s anti-Western, conservative creed is making him a hero at home. Illustration by Barry Blitt.
Water fight in the Danube, on the Croatian side of the border. Photo by @emilyschiffer. For more from the Danube Revisited project, follow @newyorkerphoto or visit newyorker.com. #regram
The titles in this week's Briefly Noted section. Visit newyorker.com to read our reviews.

“The language of money is a powerful tool, and it is also a tool of power. Incomprehension is a form of consent.” In this week’s issue, John Lanchester discusses—and decodes—financial jargon. Illustration by Oliver Munday.
Lassie sits down with our film critics Richard Brody and David Denby during a visit to the office.
Behind the scenes in our photo department: @genevievelizabeth sorting through negatives for a Photo Booth post. Credit: @theatraff
Tyrone Hood has been in jail for twenty-one years, and counting, for a murder he likely didn’t commit. Read Nicholas Schmidle’s powerful, tragic story, on newyorker.com. Photograph by Stefan Ruiz.
This week’s cover, “Venus on the Beach,” by Roz Chast.

“The last time most of humanity followed, by necessity, a paleo diet, there were maybe five million people on the planet.” In this week’s issue, Elizabeth Kolbert spends one week on the diet. Read her story on newyorker.com. Illustration by Mike Ellis.

Visit newyorker.com, and follow @newyorkerphoto, for a look at images from Danube Revisited, a project in which eight female photographers document daily life along the river for five weeks. Photo by Claire Martin.

The photographer George Steinmetz has shot his iconic aerial photographs from the skies over more than seventy countries. Visit newyorker.com to view a portfolio of his work exploring New York City from above.
Eric Drooker discusses love in New York City, and his cover of this week’s issue, on newyorker.com.

“I’m the heel, I’m the antihero. And I like it that way.” In this week’s issue, Kelefa Sanneh profiles the controversial U.F.C. star Ronda Rousey. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photo by @paridukovic.

A look at this week's sunny cover by Mark Ulriksen. Visit newyorker.com for more beach-themed covers from our archive.

“Don’t let the smiling head of garlic in a chef’s hat painted on the side of the truck scare you—there is greatness here.” To read Shauna Lyons’s take on Toum, and other Lebanese restaurants in NYC, visit newyorker.com. Photo by @joaquintrujillo.

In the magazine this week, Nathan Heller explores the battle for San Francisco: “Few gentrifying cities have a scapegoat as clear, or as slow to accept blame, as tech.” Read the story on newyorker.com. Illustration by Christian Gralingen.

The Classical Theatre of Harlem returns to the recently refurbished Richard Rodgers Amphitheatre, in Marcus Garvey Park, for a three-week run of “Romeo N Juliet.” For more events going on around NYC, visit newyorker.com. Photo by @jehadnga.
Last week, Katie Orlinsky hosted @newyorkerphoto’s feed from interior Alaska, where she had been visiting sled-dog kennels. Visit our Photo Booth blog, on newyorker.com, for more.

“Behind Eno stand John Cage, Marcel Duchamp, and Erik Satie, but those guys didn’t make pop records.” Sasha Frere-Jones charts Brian Eno’s musical career, and listens to his new album, “High Life.” Read the story on newyorker.com. Photograph by Richard Burbridge.
Read Emily Nussbaum’s review of the new season of “Orange Is the New Black,” on newyorker.com. Illustration by Peter Strain.

In the magazine this week, Héctor Tobar recounts the harrowing ordeal and hard-fought survival of the thirty-three Chilean miners who were trapped a mile underground for more than two months. Read the story on newyorker.com. Photo by Moises Saman.
In the magazine this week, John Colapinto looks at the success of the xx, and travels with them as they tour the American South and record their third album. Photograph by @paridukovic.

The composer and singer Kate Soper performs in the @metmuseum’s magnificent Temple of Dendur tonight. For more ideas on what to do this weekend in NYC, visit newyorker.com. Photograph by Richard Burbridge.

When Harriet Cleveland couldn’t pay her traffic-ticket fines, she was sentenced to two years’ probation with Judicial Correction Services, which added its own fees.

#regram via @newyorkerphoto: This week, Jane Hahn (@janehahn) photographs daily life around Mexico City. Above, a boy looks on as a young “escaramuza charra” watches another team compete during a Charreada Competition. Escaramuza, meaning skirmish, is a national sport involving precision horse riding and timed maneuvers by female teams wearing full traditional dress while riding side saddle at top speeds.

John Maynard Keynes once warned of a future of overabundant leisure. How did he get it so wrong? In this week’s issue, Elizabeth Kolbert examines why we’re busier than ever. Illustration by Nishant Choksi.

In the magazine this week, Hilton Als reviews a recent revival of John Steinbeck’s “Of Mice and Men”: “It’s yet another example of the ever trendy and ultimately dispiriting belief that if you throw any number of stars on a stage something will stick, the receipts will be fat and healthy, and, beyond that, who cares?” Photograph by @paridukovic.
This week on @newyorkerphoto, Daniel Arnold (@arnold_daniel) rides a different subway line to its end every day, documenting what he sees.

This week’s short story, “The Man in the Woods,” was found among Shirley Jackson’s papers at the Library of Congress. Read the newly discovered story on newyorker.com. Illustration by Edel Rodriguez. #fiction

Amelia Lester on the Writing Room: “The benign mediocrity of Elaine’s red-sauce Italian food has been replaced with middle-of-the-road newish American cuisine of the kind you might imagine Stephen Colbert would enjoy when in character.” Read more restaurant reviews on newyorker.com. Photograph by Malú Alvarez.

In this week’s issue, Dexter Filkins travels to Iraq to investigate the country’s return to the brink of civil war, and the extremist past of Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki, who gained power with the United States’ support. Photograph by Moises Saman.
Visit newyorker.com to read Jill Lepore’s piece on Elizabeth Warren’s new book, “A Fighting Chance.” Illustration by Shane Harrison.

Base camp in a cloud forest near the Chevé cave system in Oaxaca, Mexico. In this week’s issue, Burkhard Bilger writes about the ongoing effort to explore what may be the deepest cave in the world. Read his piece on newyorker.com. Photograph by @quesofrito (Emiliano Granado).
The photographer and avid sailor Ben Zucker (@saltysearabbit) documented a single day of sailing around New York City. For some of his photographs and audio from the trip, visit newyorker.com.

Hannah Goldfield on the Mongolian hot pot restaurant Little Lamb, in Queens: “This is the first and only official Little Lamb in New York, and, especially for anyone unfamiliar with hot pot, a meal here is extraordinary.” Visit newyorker.com for more restaurant reviews. Photograph by @erichelgas.

A team of cavers, led by Bill Stone, travelled to the remote Chevé cave system, in Mexico, and spent close to three months climbing and diving more than a mile underground. Why are so many carnivores beginning to love eating vegetables? In this week’s issue, Jane Kramer looks at the history of vegetarian cookbooks and the rise of vegetable-based diets in the United States. Illustration by Serge Bloch.

The Style Issue is out this week. Here's a look at the cover, "Metamorphosis," by Ana Juan.
In this week’s issue, Hilton Als reviews a new staging of Jean-Paul Sartre’s “No Exit.” Illustration by Riccardo Vecchio.
"Annie Clark, in her own small patch of the pop landscape, is close to redefining the rock star." Sasha Frere-Jones reviews St. Vincent's new album in this week's issue. Photo by @mark_peckmezian.

In this week’s issue of the magazine, Joan Acocella writes about the evolution of flamenco, and the “breathtaking virtuoso” Israel Galván’s performance at the Schimmel Center. For more events going on around New York City, visit newyorker.com. Illustration by Jonny Ruzzo.
#regram via @newyorkerphoto: Follow along with @jesse_burke and his daughters this week as they travel around New England for Burke's photographic series "Wild & Precious."

“Literary people know that at the sentence level and the word level she’s the best there is.” In this week’s issue, Dana Goodyear writes about the very-short-story writer Lydia Davis. Illustration by Chang Park.
Visit newyorker.com for a look at Ruven Afanador’s strange, sculptural photos of members of the Paul Taylor Dance Company rehearsing “Cloven Kingdom.”

In this week's issue, Tad Friend follows the director Darren Aronofsky through the process of his forthcoming Biblical epic, “Noah,” and explores what happens when a director known for his difficult films gets hired to make a blockbuster. Photo by Richard Burbridge.
Visit newyorker.com for a look at William Widmer’s photos of a ceremonial Courir de Mardi Gras in Louisiana’s Cajun country.

“The show’s tributes to the dead seem telling. It’s as if only dying could decisively counter today’s unholy momentum, with its pressures to get with this or that program.” Peter Schjeldahl reviews the Whitney Biennial in this week’s issue. Photograph by Raymond Meier.

In this week's issue, Hilton Als reviews a new production of Henrik Ibsen’s 1879 play, “A Doll’s House”: “Part of what makes the story feel so desperate and urgent in our hearts—we never want it to end—is that it so resembles life’s rhythms, with its various elisions and polite misdeeds and yearnings, and yet it’s better than reality.” Photograph by Grant Cornett.
Ahead of tonight's season finale of HBO's "True Detective," read Emily Nussbaum's review of the show on newyorker.com. Illustration by Victor Melamed.
Two days worth of books sent to our office. Spot any titles you're excited to read?

In the run-up to the World Cup in Brazil, this summer, New York’s Joyce Theatre presents its inaugural festival of Brazilian dance. Above, dancers from Companhia Urbana de Dança. Photo by Moises Saman.

Russell Platt on Trinity Wall Street’s daring Lenten music festival: “It’s an unusual move for a church to underwrite a Baroque orchestra and a new-music ensemble; many affluent religious institutions ... don’t seek to turn themselves into mini Lincoln Centers.” For more events going on in New York City, visit newyorker.com. Illustration by @laurierollitt.

#regram via @newyorkerphoto: The Sikh turban is a self initiation as royalty. The turban is a literal crown. All of Sikh gurus or teachers fought tirelessly against India's long standing caste system. The turban was a defiance against the caste system making everyone a king. For more of @markhartman's photos from Nepal and India, follow @newyorkerphoto.
In this week’s issue of the magazine, David Denby reviews Wes Anderson’s new movie, “The Grand Budapest Hotel.” Illustration by Stanley Chow.
In this week's issue, Jon Lee Anderson investigates Nicaragua’s plans to build a transoceanic waterway, the largest civil-engineering and construction project in history. Photograph by @jehadnga.
#regram from @newyorkerphoto: The golden temple at dusk, Amritsar, India. Photo by @markhartman. Hartman will be posting all week long from Nepal and India. Follow @newyorkerphoto for more.

“Foragers Market and Table encapsulates the contradictory nature of the New York diet, serving quality food that feels ‘healthy,’ and is often local and organic, but with none of that dull avocado-based asceticism.” Read more restaurant reviews on newyorker.com. Photograph by @jamespomerantz.
In this week’s issue, Paul Rudnick imagines the antics of a precocious, preschool-age Alec Baldwin. Illustration by Edwin Fotheringham.
In celebration of the #Oscars, a look at this week's cover by Barry Blitt.
Visit newyorker.com for Sasha Frere-Jones's review of Devonté Hynes’s recent album, “Cupid Deluxe.” Photograph by Andreas Laszlo Konrath.

Photo by @krisannejohnson. Visit newyorker.com for more photographs of the Born Frees, the first generation to come of age since the beginning of multiracial democracy in South Africa twenty years ago.

“Their music swells to something almost as cathartic as loud rock music while being entirely unlike it.” Sasha Frere-Jones writes about the Tuareg band Tinariwen in this week's issue. Photo by Ioulex.

"[Rebecca] Hall's slowness to react in rapid-fire situations is the only thing that holds our attention: it's like watching your own anxiety try to calm itself." Read Hilton Als's review of the first Broadway revival of "Machinal" on newyorker.com. Photograph by @yemchuk.

On March 2, two days before Mardi Gras, C. J. Chenier will bring hard-rocking and high-spirited zydeco music to an Irish bar in midtown. For more events going on this week, visit newyorker.com. Photograph by Dan Winters.
Photograph by Davide Monteleone. For more portraits of protesters in Kiev’s Independence Square, visit newyorker.com.

"To these Waldorf kids, using a paintbrush was as easy as brushing your teeth." @carolyndrake photographs students at the Chengdu Waldorf School in China. For more photos, and to read Ian Johnson's piece on the alternative education movement, visit newyorker.com.

“If you live for people-watching, and for floor-length mink coats, and for lines like ‘I don’t want to be on the family dole,’ you’ll be in Heaven at Betony. If you disdain those things, you’ll have no trouble tuning them out.” Read about Betony's spectacular new-American food on newyorker.com. Photograph by @_bflat_.
Jun Ahn, “Self-Portrait” (2008)/Courtesy Christophe Guye Galerie, Zürich. For a look at more artists' self-portraits curated by @jmwender, visit newyorker.com.

#regram from @newyorkerphoto: @ruddyroye photographs a fashion show hosted by students at Columbia University. For the next week, he will be taking over @newyorkerphoto's Instagram feed with stories exploring the last days of #blackhistorymonth 2014.
Read Joan Acocella's piece on Alvin Ailey Dance American Theatre’s Matthew Rushing, the company’s senior dancer, on newyorker.com. Photograph by Ioulex.
Read Rebecca Mead's Profile of the best-selling author Jennifer Weiner on newyorker.com. Photograph by @paridukovic.
The photographer Davide Monteleone captured the scene of the protests throughout #Kiev. For more photos, visit newyorker.com.
Deana Lawson, “Self-Portrait” (2012). Visit newyorker.com for a selection of striking and quirky self-portraits curated by @jmwender.
Books reviewed in the Briefly Noted section of this week's magazine. Take a look...

#regram from @newyorkerphoto: Young boys practice judo in the school gym in Khaishi. With no electricity and the sun going down the boys began their flips in near darkness. @ivorprickett #georgia #caucasus #khudoni #svaneti #judo #boys @panospictures

"A more fitting title for 'Intimacy' might be 'Innocence.' Because that's what Bradshaw's characters evince, no matter how reprehensible their emotional brutality." Read Hilton Als's review of Thomas Bradshaw's latest play on newyorker.com.  Photograph by @christaanfelber.
The cartoonist Liza Donnelly has been drawing scenes from the prime-time broadcast of the 2014 Winter Olympics. Take a look at some of her sketches from the past week on newyorker.com.

“Even if you listen to popular music all day, every day, you don't get many albums like this in your lifetime.” Sasha Frere-Jones reviews Beck’s new album in this week’s issue. Photograph by @richardburbridge.
Photograph by @christaanfelber. To read about “Rocky,” the musical, and other events going on this week, visit newyorker.com/arts/events.
Photograph by @paridukovic. Visit newyorker.com to read David Remnick's piece on the complexities of President Obama's second term.
Photograph by Brigitte Lacombe. In this week’s issue, Roger Angell reflects on his life at ninety-three. Read Angell's piece, now unlocked, on newyorker.com.
Photograph by Misha Friedman. For the past few weeks, Friedman has been in Russia to cover the Winter Olympics for the magazine. Visit newyorker.com for more photos.

#regram from @newyorkerphoto: Sanjay, a young Indian immigrant living in Georgia, buys fresh yogurt from an elderly woman selling dairy products in his neighbourhood. Rustavi, Georgia. By @ivorprickett @panospictures #india #georgia #farmers #agriculture #caucasus #documentary #photojournalism #iphoneography
“Jeanie and Will Kiss” (2011). Photograph by Isadora Kosofsky. This Valentine's Day, visit newyorker.com for a selection of photographers’ images of couples. @jmwender

#regram from @newyorkerphoto: Kate rides the subway home after walking in Calvin Klein, her last show in New York. She leaves Saturday for fashion weeks in Milan and then Paris. @lrnlncstr shadowing Kate Goodling through #NYFW. #nyc #kategoodling #fordmodels #nycsubway
The photographer Sim Chi Yin spent some time in Handan, one of the ten most polluted cities in China. For more photos, and to read Ian Johnson's piece on Handan, visit newyorker.com.
On a day like today, we couldn't resist sharing this snow day cartoon by Liza Donnelly from our archive.

“When the strawberry-balsamic ice cream and the baked Alaska arrive, the sense of being in a Ritz-Carlton in the late nineteen-nineties is fully realized.” Read our review of the Brooklyn restaurant Saul on newyorker.com. Photograph by Landon Nordeman.
#regram from @newyorkerphoto: Kate walking in Theory. @lrnlncstr shadowing Kate Goodling through #nyfw. #kategoodling #fordmodels #runway #nyc

@petesouza offers a behind-the-scenes look at @newyorkerphoto staff photographer @paridukovic’s shoot with President Obama. Read David Remnick’s piece on the complexities of Obama’s second term on newyorker.com.
The photographer Emiliano Granado shot Tough Mudder contestants helping each other through the Mud Mile obstacle. Read Lizzie Widdicombe's piece on the grueling race at newyorker.com.

The photographer Richard Barnes captures the dynamic and coördinated displays of starling flocks, known as murmurations. His series, “Murmur,” is now on view at New York’s @foleygallery. For more photos, visit newyorker.com.
The Brazil-based photographer Sebastián Liste spent time among the fans of the wildly popular Brazilian soccer club Corinthians. Read Ben McGrath’s piece on the team on newyorker.com.

“Hoffman was no prince, and he knew it, but he was wise enough to know that vanity burrows well below the skin.” Read Anthony Lane's tribute to Philip Seymour Hoffman on newyorker.com. Photograph by Brigitte Lacombe.

Photograph by @paridukovic. In this week's issue, Rebecca Mead profiles Neil DeGrasse Tyson, director of the Hayden Planetarium, at the American Museum of Natural History, and host of the new "Cosmos" series. Read the piece at newyorker.com.

#regram from @newyorkerphoto. @lrnlncstr shadows model Kate Goodling during her week at NYFW.

@newyorkermag will now feature notable photography from the magazine, but to keep up with our photographer take-overs, follow @newyorkerphoto.

Oregon | From their new home in Portland, Omar, Suhair, Mustafa, Ibrahim and Masarra thank all of you for following their story and for all of the welcoming comments.
I journeyed across the US with Omar and his son Mustafa. Omar worked with me in Iraq as a fixer/driver for 8 years. After moving to the states a few months ago, he is starting fresh in Portland, OR. @andreabruce_noor @noor images #noorimages #immigration #refugee #refugee_rights #iraq #roadtrip #home

Oregon | After running inside his new apartment in freezing weather, Omar is greeted by his daughter Masarra. His wife already had the apartment decorated. His children dragged him and Mustafa from room to room of the two-bedroom place. They were very happy to be in their new home, but still anxious about the hurdles to come.

Hello, this is @andreabruce_noor reporting with Omar and Mustafa, father and son from Iraq who are road-tripping across the United States to their new home in Portland, OR. Omar and I worked together for 8 years in Iraq while I worked for The Washington Post. A few months ago he and his family immigrated to the states, landing in the DC area where they faced a bed-bug infested apartment, bad schools, gangs and a high cost of living. This week I'm documenting their move to the west coast, a hopeful new start. 
The above photo was taken in their beautiful Baghdad home in 2011. Thanks to employees of The Washington Post, the Iraq Refugee Assistance Project and The Aftermath Project for getting them here. @refugee_rights @noorimages #theaftermathproject #refugee #immigration #iraq #usa #roadtrip

Finland, seen from the sky. Photo by @biekedepoorter Goodmorning everyone! When The New Yorker asked me to take over their instagram, I just booked a flight to the far North of Norway. George Harris (90) shows me his photo album, his plane he trained on in what was then called Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe). It's the only time he flew with a British plane during the war. His instructor (right) and him crashed this plane during a training exercise while flying 20 ft, a height that George says 'was the only way to survive the war.'

'I am a British, born and bred'. George Harris (right), 90, an ex-fighter pilot flying Mustang planes during World War Two, walks to the living room in the only expatriate elderly home called China Coast Community in Hong Kong. Most of the residents are alone with little to no ties to their home country or families. George is one of the lucky ones who has a son who lives in #hongkong.

'Home' always reminds me of elevators, glass, mirrors, tall buildings and more elevators. Welcome to #hongkong. My name is @dominicnahr and this is my first post for @newyorkermag from the island of Hong Kong in the South China Sea where I spent my first 20 years of my life. This week I will be posting pictures from the place I grew up in. A place I left nearly 10 years ago answering an urge to leave and find a new home in
a foreign land. Now I'm back, responding to a similar urge to return to a place that is both familiar and now foreign to me. Every so often
over the years I have come home to visit my mother and my friends and usually that has meant dealing with memories that I try to avoid and a city I have tried to forget. I am a foreigner here - and everywhere else it seems - a persistent expatriate and a shifting composite of the people I've lived with and and the places I've lived in. Like anyone's family history l mine is a complicated and conflicted one. As a professional photojournalist I live and work in the present but I'm learning that when history catches up with you everything changes.

This is the last photograph, fixating the time of our departure. It has been an enjoyable week in your presence, but I must say goodbye. For those who would like to keep in contact you may write me at pinkhassov@hotmail.com

Typing one of my favorite poems @littlebrownmushroom

The Snow Man
By Wallace Stevens

One must have a mind of winter
To regard the frost and the boughs
Of the pine-trees crusted with snow;

And have been cold a long time
To behold the junipers shagged with ice,
The spruces rough in the distant glitter

Of the January sun; and not to think
Of any misery in the sound of the wind,
In the sound of a few leaves,

Which is the sound of the land
Full of the same wind
That is blowing in the same bare place

For the listener, who listens in the snow,
And, nothing himself, beholds
Nothing that is not there and the nothing that is.

Good morning!  This is @chiplitherland and I'm excited to take over the feed this week and bring you some Florida warmth and color the holidays. I'm a freelance editorial, commercial, travel, and sports photographer down here in this weird peninsula we call the Sunshine State - but absolutely love it for all it's weirdness and beauty.  I chase color and light all day - and have been Instagramming (is that a verb?) my iPhone scraps from my travels up and down the coastlines for a while now, which is what you'll be seeing this week from me. More of my work can be found at http://www.chiplitherland.com and thanks for having me @newyorkermag!

Project Mi Barrio – Donde el Campo se Une con la Ciudad (Where the Countryside Meets the City). It was quite an experience hanging out with the man on top of the volcano. Now I'm heading home. Thanks so much for following this story. I really enjoyed digging in this week and exploring my barrio.  If you have any questions, comments, or ideas please feel free to contact me @ ivankphoto@gmail.com. The story continues @ivankphoto, #projectmibarrio, @runa_photos Learn more @ runaphotos.com/blog

Project Mi Barrio – El Hombre Encima del Volcán III (The Man on Top of the #Volcano III). José Luis Chuquimarca, 76, says he has lived on top of #Ilalo, an extinct volcano, for 50 years. He is a humble man, living off the land, an example of how the whole valley was years ago. José looks after the cows and makes sure no one steals them. The thieves poison his dogs in attempt to rob the cattle. #Ecuador. #photojournalism, #projectmibarrio, @runa_photos,
Photo: @ivankphoto, Learn more @ runaphotos.com/blog

Project Mi Barrio – Papas Peladas (Peeled Potatoes) – María Guamán, 70, stands in her doorway as her husband comes home in #Rumihuaico, #Ecuador. Photo: @ivankphoto. Learn more @ www.runaphotos.com/blog

Project Mi Barrio – Taita Ilalo – Hello! I’m Ivan Kashinsky @ivankphoto. I live in a neighborhood called #Rumihuaico in a valley about thirty minutes outside of #Quito, #Ecuador.  This week I’ll be hosting the New Yorker instagram feed with photos from an ongoing project called #projectmibarrio.  This story is about change.  It’s about the mixture of past, present, and future. Not so long ago, this valley, which sits right bellow Quito, was just vast farmland.  In recent years there has been a population explosion, leading to super highways and shopping malls.  Despite the exponential growth and the rise of fast-food joints and global pop culture, parts of this area maintain the qualities of a small Ecuadorian pueblo.  Rumihuaico, #Tumbaco, and the rest of the neighborhoods in this valley are the perfect example of the old vs. new, chicha (a Pre-Columbian corn drink) vs. Coca-Cola Zero, or cockfights vs. movie theaters.  It is a fusion of the old generation and the new generation, a chaotic mixture, which I am a part of.  I hope you enjoy the ride. Learn more @ www.runaphotos.com/blog

This photograph was taken by Maam, one of twelve Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok participants, part of a series of close-up textures she made at the market where she works. Her family’s stall seems to sell every variety of tropical fruit. Although Maam is open about her HIV status with her family and close community, she still often feels like she is carrying a deep secret inside. She looks to everyday things to stay connected to her spirit. “When I see the shape and color of these, it makes me smile. All those childlike shapes are a simple reminder of happiness and joy.” This is part of the daily feed from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

This intimate image of her father-in-law was taken by Maam, one of twelve Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok participants. “Before I moved into the home of my husband’s family, I did not know them very well, and they did not know me. I worried that they would not accept me given my HIV-positive status. However, after moving in I began taking care of my mother-in-law and I got a chance to feel like family. Especially to my father-in-law. I feel like he is my true father. I lost my father very young, so he is like a real father to me.” This is part of the daily feed from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

Maam is one of twelve participants in Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok. She lives with her HIV-positive husband, her father-in-law, three daughters, and one stepdaughter. She is the primary caretaker of the family, and much of her time is spent worrying over the family’s affairs. She took this photo in her home using a tripod and self-timer. “In my house we call this ‘Ladies Corner.’ Every day I come home exhausted from taking care of people. But once I see the mirror it reminds me that I have to take care of myself too.” This is part of the daily feed from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

This is another of Joe's images made for Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok. Joe suffers from paralysis on the left side of his body. “I feel like half of my heart is missing. But I will not give up. You have to have a good heart to live. Just like the dragon fruit, even through you cut it in half, it still maintains its beauty.” This is part of the daily feed from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

This image is by Joe Chon, he is one of twelve participants in Though Positive Eyes-Bangkok. The left side of his body is partially paralyzed due to an HIV-related fungal infection in his brain. He made this image trying to illustrate the numb sensation that makes him feel that his body is divided. Because of his disabilities he made this image in collaboration with a friend who clicked the shutter after Jo had framed the image. “Even though only half of my body is good and the other half is not, it doesn’t mean I cannot function. Most of my body carries on without any problems. This is what I want to say: I still can work and I still can be useful.” This is part of the daily feed from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

This is another of Keng’s images made for Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok. “My son is in the tree and my son-in-law is sitting below. Every Sunday they go to the river to fish. I always go with them and sit in the sun waiting for them to catch fish. Once they catch one, we release it back. We don’t want to kill it. I love to be with all the kids. They make me so happy.” This is part of the daily feed from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

On the final day of this feed from Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok, I am introducing the images of three participants who traveled from Chonburi Province to take part. Keng, an HIV-positive mother and grandmother worked so hard to make some amazing photographs of her warm family life. This image was taken in her bedroom using a tripod and self-timer: “Watching TV at night is a daily ritual that that my kids and I do together. This is my favorite time of the day.” This is part of the daily feed from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

This is my portrait  of Jo whose home I visited today. He is one of the twelve HIV-participants in Through Positive Eyes – Bangkok and his work over the last five days has been amazing.  He is a recovering injecting drug user and outspoken activist. This is part of the daily feed from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

This is another of Jo’s images made for Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok using a tripod and self-timer. As a former drug addict, Jo is extremely aware of his tendency toward an array of addictions: “I would never tell people to smoke because once you get addicted it is very difficult to quit. Burning the cigarette is like burning yourself as well. I don’t know what my lungs look like right now. If I didn’t smoke, I might have better health and be stronger. I have smoked for 35 years and, at this point, I don’t think I can quit.” This is part of the daily feed from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

This is another of Jo’s images made for Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok using a tripod and self-timer. As a former drug addict, Jo is extremely aware of his tendency toward an array of addictions: “I would never tell people to smoke because once you get addicted it is very difficult to quit. Burning the cigarette is like burning yourself as well. I don’t know what my lungs look like right now. If I didn’t smoke, I might have better health and be stronger. I have smoked for 35 years and, at this point, I don’t think I can quit.” This is part of the daily feed from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

I’ve been blown away by the photographs taken by Jo, one of the twelve HIV-participants in Through Positive Eyes – Bangkok. He is a recovering injecting drug user and outspoken activist. He has worked so hard and creatively since the start of the project five days ago, shooting over 2,000 images. “This photo shows that I have the freedom to do anything, get dressed up, take a photo, whatever I want. There’s no limit on my life. In general I feel very lonely, but photography has opened up my vision and honed my concentration and skill. Taking photos is keeping me occupied.” his is part of the daily feed from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

As part of Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok, Wat records elements of his daily life as an HIV-positive person using his tripod and self-timer: “When I’m home I always exercise to be strong. I do it every day. Specifically, I work to strengthen my lungs because my breathing is a problem. If I don’t love myself, who is going to love me? If I get sick, who will take care of others?” This is part of the daily feed from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

This is another of Wat’s intriguing images made by collaborating with his brother. He framed the photo with a tripod and asked his brother to click the shutter. He is one of twelve HIV-participants in Through Positive Eyes – Bangkok: “Most Thai people go to the temple to ask for a blessing from the Buddha image. Instead I wash my mother’s feet, because she is like God to me. She is the most important person in my life. When I was diagnosed HIV-positive, the doctors said I wouldn’t live long. But my mom said, ‘No mother raises her child to die.’ She wouldn’t let me. Since then, I believe that my mother is sacred.” This is part of the daily feed from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

Wat is one of the twelve HIV-positive participants in Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok. He has been living with HIV for twenty years. This photo shows him at work helping to provide HIV medication. “I invented a medicine bank to collect medication from the hospital and help distribute it to people who live too far away, or can’t afford a doctor’s appointment. When people are short on medication, they can call me and I help them. I encourage them to take their medications properly, and to disclose their HIV status to their loved ones. It’s better that way. This patient was sick for 16 years, but he only just got on medication three months ago because he didn’t know about his right to get free medication.” This is part of the daily feed from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

Continuing the day-by-day presentation of the Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok work, this image was made by made by Jai, collaborating with a friend. "I've recreated an old memory of mine at my workplace, an organization that assists women living with HIV. It's a flashback to when I first visited the organization. I had just found out that I was HIV-positive. I was worried about who I might run into. I thought, if anyone sees me here, they will know I have HIV. At the time my HIV status was secret. I didn't want my story to be public. People were gossiping. When I did decide to disclose my HIV status many people shunned me." This Is part of the daily feed from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

One of twelve HIV-positive participants in Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok, Sam photographs himself in a Buddhist temple-part of his truly profound set of images: "My life is empty. At the very end all humans leave nothing behind. Being born, getting old, getting sick, dying-it's all the same. A stable thing can also be unstable. So, everyday I make my life as happy as I can. I always think that today is my last day because I don't know how long I will live." This Is part of the daily feed from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

Continuing the process of making his philosophical thoughts into photographs, Sam plays upon a textual rhyme in Thai language, referencing two great Buddhist religious principles: "I try to blend myself into two of my favorite things, nature (thamachat) and the Buddha's teaching (dhamaa). This is the truth of life." Sam is one of twelve participants in Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok. This Is part of the daily feed of images from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

Sam explores his personal philosophy as an HIV-positive participant in Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok: "Standing under the massive sky, I feel so lonely. I feel that I would like to transcend this wide world but I can't do it. I'm stuck with my condition." This Is part of the daily feed of images from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

Introducing a series of photographs by Sam, an HIV-positive former sex worker who is participating in Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok. "As I take my HIV medication, I lean on The Lord Buddah. He gives me peace and calm." This Is part of the daily feed of images from the project curated by @gideonmendel.

Aoy, one of the participants in Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok made this dramatic picture to illustrate the neuropathy she suffers from: "A side effect from the HIV medication makes my right fingertips feel numb. I can't even make a fist. Nobody knows the pain that I get from my HIV medication. Nobody else feels it. But I know it, and I feel it. This Is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

This is another in the series of images made by Aoy where she used a tripod and self-timer to document some of the daily moments of her life. She is one of the twelve HIV-positive participants in the Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok project. "Every morning, even if I'm running late, even if I'm in a rush, I want to sweep and clean my room. If my room isn't clean when I come back from work, and I'm tired, and I see my messy room-I will be very annoyed. So annoyed it can cause me a migraine." This Is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

Continuing Aoy's documentation of her daily life, here she used a tripod and self-timer to document breakfast with her husband. "Coffee is a routine for every morning. I have to drink coffee. It makes me feel fresh. The only day I don't drink it is when I have to go to my blood/piss doctor's appointment." She's one of twelve HIV-positive participants in Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok. This Is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

Aoy is one of the twelve inspiring HIV-positive participants in Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok. She has taken a series of images about her daily routine: "My body clock tells me when to take my medication. Time is very important to me. I have four clocks and six watches. I wake up at 4am in the morning. I exercise, shower, get dressed, clean my apartment, and drink coffee. To be able to go out and live my life outside is crucial. I pay attention to my appearance. I take a long time to get dressed. I like to look ordinary." This Is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

Bee is one of the twelve participants in Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok. A proud 'ladyboy,' she faces multiple layers of stigma for being both HIV-positive and transgender: "I took this picture with the tripod and self-timer. It shows me practicing my cabaret act with my boyfriend, Koh, holding the light. He takes care I me. He has inspired me to become a more beautiful person inside. I found out I was HIV-positive in August 5, 2006. I felt very down. I used to have nobody with me. My Dad and Mom didn't want anything to do with me because I'm transgender and HIV-positive." This is part of the daily feed of images from the project curated by @gideonmendel

Auwn is one of the twelve participants in Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok who are photographing their own lives. This reminds me of myself, my daughter carrying her child just as I carried her. I got infected with HIV when I got pregnant, at the age of seventeen. I am glad that she was safe and not infected." This Is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

Auwn is one of the twelve participants in Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok. "This photo reminds me of myself, my daughter carrying her child just as I carried her. I got infected with HIV when I got pregnant, at the age of seventeen. I am glad that she was safe and not infected." This Is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

A self-portrait by Auwn made as part of her engagement with Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok. She is showing how she sleeps in the floor with some of the seven grandchildren that she cares for: "Nothing is better than spending time with family. Maybe it's not a lot, but it makes me happy. In my household, my children and grandchildren do not have any problem with my HIV condition. I am satisfied with what I have now. I never have any thought about wanting a bigger house or wanting more rooms. Never." This Is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

No explores abstraction in her photograph for Through Positive Eyes- Bangkok. "This broken wall is a metaphor for my relationship with my family. I only talk with them on the phone. I never visit them and they never visit me." This Is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

This photograph was taken by No, one of the twelve participants in Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok. She is also the partner of Aoi, whose images have just been shown. "I snapped this photo after my boyfriend took his methadone. I didn't want him to take it. He is old and it makes him tired, but he needs it as therapy. After he takes it I need to help take care of him. I do not dream of him being free of sickness. I just hope he won't get sicker." This Is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

This self-portrait is taken by Aoi, a recovering injecting drug user participating in Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok. "I realize that in my life is some good, some bad, but I hope that my photographs allow people to see my goodness, even just a little." This Is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

As part of Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok, Aoi took this photograph of his own body: "I got the tattoo while I was in jail. My prisoner friend gave it to me by using a sewing needle and ink we collected from a prison guard. The watchtower is the image I saw everyday while going back and forth in jail. My last time in prison was the longest: seven and a half years." This Is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

Here is my photograph of Aoi working on a close-up self portrait at his home as part of his involvement with the Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok project. He is one of the twelve remarkable participants who I am visiting in the coming days. Aoi is a poetic thinker and a gentle spirit, making images that I feel channel the heart of the Through Positive Eyes vision. He is a former heroin addict, now on methadone: "Before I began taking my HIV medication I looked very sick. My weight was 42 kilograms (92 pounds). I now look so much better. I can go out and work without having to worry." This is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

This photograph was taken by Jo, one of the twelve HIV-positive participants in the Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok project. "Although he is not my dog, I feel so connected to him. When I visit his house, this dog always comes and greets me. His eyes give me power and strength." This is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel

This photograph from an anti-government protest was taken by Jo, one of the twelve participants in the Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok project. "I snapped this photo along Ratchadamnoen Road, a main area for the political gatherings in Bangkok, near Democracy Monument. Why does an animal have to be the victim of political issues?" This is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

This photograph was taken by Jo, one of the twelve HIV-positive participants in the Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok project. "Normally you see people from the front. I want to show my back so that nobody can know what I'm thinking. Society has the idea that tattooed people are bad or represent a bad image. But society doesn't know the whole me." This is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

This photograph was taken by Jo, one of the twelve HIV-positive participants in the Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok project. "This is the hand if a person I respect. He's like an older brother to me. His is a powerful fist that has been through so many experiences. In 2012, I found that I have a new illness in addition to HIV: Hepatitis B and C. I don't receive any medication for Virus C because it's expensive and the health care is not covering this medicine yet." This is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

This tableau was created in the Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok workshop today by Aoy, one of the twelve HIV-positive participants in the project. "Even though I have HIV, I have high ambitions of my life. I'm determined to reach my goals and to live the life I want to live." This is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

This self portrait was taken by Aoy, one of the twelve HIV-positive participants in the Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok project. "Even though I'm HIV-infected, it doesn't mean I don't care about my personal beauty. I can make myself look good. I don't want society to see HIV as something pathetic. I don't want them to feel sorry for me." This is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel

This photograph was taken by Auwn, one of the twelve HIV positive participants in the Through Positive Eyes-Bangkok project. "Look at the river, how big is it? Look at my hand, how big is it? I don't care how big a river is, but I can be a part of it." This is part of the daily feed of video and images curated by @gideonmendel.

As part of the through Positive Eyes training workshop in Bangkok, Maam captures a detail of dried dragon fruit: "I hadn't realized the dryness of the fruit before. It surprised me. One day I will get old and become like this. I wish I could remain beautiful." This Is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel.

Sam, a 28-year old gay man in the Through Positive Eyes training workshop in Bangkok, creates a self-portrait he titles 'Half Made Full': "In this photo, I wanted to reflect on how half my life disappeared when I was diagnosed with HIV. I'm convinced that I am normal but, physically, I still have to take medicine everyday. It will be like this for the rest of my life." This is part of the daily feed of video and images curated by @gideonmendel.

A portrait of Auwn taken by Sam on the first day of the Through Positive Eyes training workshop in Bangkok. Auwn: "Flowers look so alive. I want to feel fresh and alive like that. I have been HIV-infected for eighteen years. I am a family lady who has raised three children by myself and seven grandchildren. From my outside appearance some might think I am a tomboy or lesbian, but I am not anything." This is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel

A self- portrait by Aoy, (made using a small tripod) as she takes her morning medication on the first day of the Through Positive Eyes training workshop in Bangkok. "In order to stay healthy I have to be very careful about the timing of my drugs. I wish there was a cure, so that I would not have to take medicine anymore." This is part of the daily feed of images curated by @gideonmendel

Aqui Vivimos - A last view of Tegucigalpa before we say goodbye. Elections found National Party's Juan Orlando Hernandez the winner of presidential seat. The majority of the population remains unimpressed with the political process. It remains to be seen how Libre Party will respond. If you are interested in following our project further through the region in the coming weeks, we will be posting on @dominicbracco and @jeremyrelph. #pulitzercenter #primecollective #honduras #elecciones2013 #honduranelections #tegucigalpa #catracho #flowers #monte
