Enduring Rifts - Santiago, Chile. @jonlowenstein #pulitzercenter #tedfellows #nofilter My father and his partner Lee, walk back to their hotel room after dinner. At age 4 he was put on a train alone and sent away from Nazi Germany in the #Kindertransport. That saved his life. Our grandparents and out uncle Ralph emigrated to the United States. Personal rifts occur to all of us and how we survive and move on helps to form how society's heal from trauma.  #immigration #parents #night #energy #trauma #society #socialmedia

Enduring Rifts - Santiago, Chile. Photo by @Jon Lowenstein Located on the outskirts of Santiago, Villa Grimaldi is considered one of the most important and infamous of DINa's (Dirección de Inteligencia Nacional, the Chilean secret police force) many places that were used for the detention, interrogation and torture of political prisoners during Gen. Augusto Pinochet's dictatorship. The former social club was open from 1974 to 1978. About 4,500 detainees were brought to Villa Grimaldi during these years, at least 240 of whom were 'disappeared' or killed by DINA. Rebuilt from survivors' memories, the site is dedicated to preserving the memory of those tortured, interrogated and killed by Pinochet's henchman. #killer #interrogation #pulitzercenter @noorimages #torture #torturado #pinochet #DINA #villagrimaldi #santiago #power #truth #truthandreconciliation #deny #land #social #sick #blackandwhite #nofilter  #jeffklo @jonlowenstein #

Enduring Rifts - Santiago, Chile. Michelle Bachelet is the leader among 9 presidential candidates. She was president from 2006 until 2010. She and her family were political prisoners and tortured at #Villa Grimaldi, Pinochet's infamous detention center in Santiago during the 1970's. Villa Grimaldi is considered the most important of DINA's (Direction in National Intelligence) many detention centers that were used throughout Chile to torture and detain political prisoners. DINA was the regime's secret police. The center was in operation from 1974-1978. Before it was used for torture it was a high end resort for the wealthy. On Sunday November 17 the voters will go to the polls to decide the elections' outcome. Bachelet's father died after being tortured at Villa Grimaldi.  @jonlowenstein @noorimages #pulitzercenter #restaurant #dark #president #providencia #blackandwhite  #food #elections #presidential #media #memory #history #humanrights #past #dining #nofilter @noorimages #DINA #torture #desaparecidos #disappeared

Enduring Rifts - Santiago, Chile. The younger generation continues to move forward 40 years after Pinochet toppled Allende's government. The combination of intense development led by the Chicago Boys back in the day and the rapid communication revolution is changing Chile by leaps and bounds. Yet a serious economic divide between rich and poor exists and will need to be addressed by the incoming President and leaders.  What will happen in the coming years will no doubt be interesting. #jeffklo #jeffkellylowenstein #socialmedia #nofilter #noorimages #past #grafitti #santiago #pulitzercenter @pulitzercenter #noorimages @noorimages @jonlowenstein @TED #TED #chicagoboys #chicago #gringo #desaparecidos #publictransport

Enduring Rifts - Santiago, Chile. A man stands near the entrance to the Museum of Memory and Human Rights. The museum which was opened just four years ago is dedicated to commemorate the victims of human rights violations during the military regimes led by Augusto Pinochet after the coup d'état in 1973 and up to 1990. Former president and leader in the current polls for this years election Michelle Bachelet inaugurated the space on January 11, 2010. Chile is still grappling with the impact of the large scale human rights violations during this time. For much of the last forty years much of the true history has been denied. Today, the country is dealing with repairing the legacy through spaces such as the museum but for many people who suffered undue extreme hardship the reality is still extremely raw. @jonlowenstein #memory #movimiento #tears #water #pulitzercenter #journeys #humanrights #nofilter #noorimages #jeffkellylowenstein #power #víctimas #desaparecidos #museum #blackandwhite #water

Enduring Rifts - Santiago, Chile. Four decades after Augusto Pinochet's military overthrew Salvador Allende's democratically-elected government, the past remains a vital force in the country. Ana Gonzalez points to her husband and the only remaining image of her family that was taken before her husband, two sons and her pregnant daughter in law were disappeared during Pinochet's rule. Gonzalez related a powerful story about a traveling photographer who had taken the photograph of her family by chance many years ago. It's the only image that she has of her family when it was intact. She is pointing at her husband. #pulitzercenter @jonlowenstein #noorimages @noorimages #memory #photograph #photography #blackandwhite #nofilter @newyorkermag #neruda #past

Enduring Rifts - Santiago, Chile. Images of Pablo Neruda and Salvador Allende hang in Ana Gonzalez's house in Santiago, Chile. Gonzalez's husband, two sons and her pregnant daughter in law were all disappeared by Augusto Pinochet's regime. Despite these life changing losses Gonzalez has consistently fought for social justice and equality for all humans on this planet. She is a life long member of the communist party. #cemetery #neruda #pabloneruda #salvadorallende #pulitzercenter @noorimages #noorimages #jeffkellylowenstein @jonlowenstein #writer #poet #power #politics #photography #images #power #pinochet #salvadorallende #nofilter #blackandwhite

Enduring Rifts - Santiago, Chile. Four decades after the military overthrew Salvador Allende's democratically elected government, the past remains a vital force in the country. This next two weeks we are taking an in-depth look at the legacy of Pinochet's regime four decades after the coup. Patio 29 was a section of Santiago's General Cemetery where political dissidents were buried in mass graves during the early part of Augusto Pinochet's regime. Hundreds of men and women were buried here and to this day not all the victims have been correctly identified. #dissident #massgrave #graves #dissapeared #desaparecido #pulitzercenter #jeffkellylowenstein @jonlowenstein #noorimages @noorimages #photograph #blackandwhite #nofilter #pinochet #communist #cemetery #cross #thecross

Enduring Rifts - Santiago.
Chile. Four decades after the military overthrew Chile's democratically elected government, the past remains a vital force in the country. My brother and fellow documentarian Jeff Kelly Lowenstein and I have embarked on an amazing exploration of where the country is at 40 years after Salvador Allende was deposed. Ana Gonzalez saw her husband, two sons and her pregnant daughter in law  were disappeared by Augusto Pinochet's government. A life long communist, at 87 she exudes a powerful thirst for justice and true equality. Gonzalez held forth at her house in a neighborhood in Santiago which was filled with images of everyone from Pablo Neruda to Che Guevara. She has fought tirelessly for social justice for more than six decades and is one of the most inspirational people I've ever met. @jonlowenstein #pulitzercenter @noorimages #survivor #pinochet #salvadorallende #communist #blackandwhite #nofilter @jeffklo #jeffkellylowenstein #face #power #smile #elder #elderly #desaparecido #politics #artist #art

Meet Ahmed, an elevator operator in a 23-story office building in downtown Cairo. Between the hours of 8am to 3pm, Ahmed sits on his wooden stool in the corner of the elevator, greets passengers with a kind smile and clicks away at the controllers prompted by the employee's desired destination. Up and down, down and up, the elevator beeps at every floor to signal its arrival, Ahmed's ears pop from very high to very low floors and he makes small chat with passengers between "destinations". Everyone knows Ahmed in this building. He earns 550 Egyptian pounds per month ($80). Meet "Uncle Mohamed", a flower seller in Cairo specializing in red and white roses only. For the past 35 years, he's provided for his wife and five kids by chasing after customers in their cars at red lights: "Flowers, sir?", "A flower for you Madam?" Photo by @laura_eltantawy #cairo #egypt #middleeast #northafrica #dailylife #portrait #peopleimeet #peoplewithastory @viiphoto @everydayafrica #مصر #القاهرة #وسط #البلد

Meet my friendly popcorn seller friend Baha'a. We go back more than two years. I first met Baha'a in Tahrir Square during the Jan. 25, 2011 revolution. A small chat with him back then and another a few days later left an impression on me. I lost touch with him two years ago and today by sheer coincidence I found him. I am incredibly happy. Baha'a is 30-years-old, has a wife, children and survives on 100 Egyptian pounds per day ($14.5). Photo by @laura_eltantawy #cairo #egypt #middleeast #northafrica #portrait #peopleimeet #peoplewithastory #dailylife #مصر #القاهرة #وسط البلد

Meet Mohamed, the charismatic tea seller of Fouad Street, now called 26th of July, in downtown Cairo. Everyone on the street knows Mohamed, who works at the local coffee shop but takes orders on the go from shop merchants and street vendors, recalls them from memory, then delivers tens of drinks to customers straight to their place of work. He sells a cup of tea for 1 Egyptian pound ($0.15). Photo by @laura_eltantawy #cairo #egypt #northafrica #middleeast #dailylife #portrait #peopleimeet #peoplewithastory @viiphoto @everydayafrica

Meet Gaber. At 22, he serves in the military and on his time off, he tries to put his Egyptian history degree to good use by working as a tour guide around Cairo. For the past two years, business has been dry. Photo by @laura_eltantawy #cairo #egypt #middleeast #northafrica #dailylife #peopleimeet #portrait #peoplewithastory @viiphoto @everydayafrica

Meet Mohamed, a 15-year-old liquorice juice drink seller working the streets of downtown Cairo. Mohamed, whose been doing this for the past two years, is holding the traditional (folkloric) container for the drink, which is believed to date to Ottoman times, decorated with colorful flowers and all. He earns nearly 50.00 per day (approximately $7.26 per day). In the next few days, I'll be posting a number of portraits of people I encounter this week on the streets of Cairo. A fully veiled woman cut flowers to make a bouquet to give her friend, a thoughtful yet illegal by park standards gesture that later got her in trouble with one of the park's gardeners and security. Good morning Côte d'Ivoire. This is photographer @iwanbaan for @newyorkermag. I'll be posting here all week, so join me as we explore crazy and beautiful west Africa. It's a few days in the hustle of Abidjan to rediscover some African modernist architecture, then a move to the rural countryside for a taste of the vernacular. After spending a few days with me here, I hope my passion for travel, cultures & the built environment rubs off on you! 
@iwanbaan @newyorkmag #africa

The bridge over the Yazoo river glows as dusk settles on Greenwood, Mississippi, on October 17, 2013. The river separates north and south Greenwood, serving as a physical barrier between the people of the Baptist Town neighborhood and their more affluent neighbors. This will be the last image I post from #Greenwood for now. For the last three years I have photographed this wonderful community and I am still constantly amazed by the hospitality of the residents and intrigued by their complex history. Thanks to everyone following along for the eyes and dialogue, and thanks to @NewYorkerMag for letting me share a little glimpse of this beautiful and noteworthy town. I am currently camping somewhere in Alabama while on a search for Bigfoot. Perhaps I will share a peek tomorrow before the next photographer picks up the reins. @MattEich for @NewYorkerMag. #matteich #photographer #river #yazooriver #greenwood #mississippi #ms #mississippidelta #baptisttown #dusk #personalwork #onassignment #commission #travels #america #usa

Hi there, my name is @MattEich and I am a freelance photographer from Norfolk, Virginia. For the last three years I have been working on a project about contemporary race and class disparities in the town of Greenwood, Mississippi. This week I'd like to invite you to join me as I spend time in this incredibly beautiful and complex community. This first image is of Roger "Winky" Williams tinting the windows of a car in the Baptist Town neighborhood of Greenwood, MS on October 14, 2013. An ex-con with almost five children and limited employment opportunities, Winky must constantly struggle to provide for his growing family. @MattEich for @NewYorkerMag. #matteich #photographer #photography #baptisttown #greenwood #mississippi #ms #mirror #reflection #window #tint #neighborhood #community #race #class #disparity #personalwork #personalproject #travels #america #usa

A three year old small girl is celebrated for her growth and well-being during her Hichi-Go-San, literally Seven-Five-Three, rite. It is Japan’s traditional passage and festival day for three- and seven-year-old girls and three- and five-year-old boys. It is supposed to be held annually on November 15th, but due to Shinto priest’s schedule, it is often held long before. Tsurugaoko Hachimangu Shrine, Kamakura. Photo by @qsakamaki /@reduxpictures for @newyorkermag #shinto #shrine #kamakura #japan #Hichi_Go_San #Tsurugaoko_Hachimangu

Homework. Reading this every night trying to get some background. Harness racing is really different from thoroughbred racing for a bunch of reasons beside the cart they pull. The horses race in gait, either trotting, (their feet move diagonally,) or pacing, (the feet on each side go diagonally.) It's also much more small time, its easier for folks to be involved in it without being millionaires. It's the kind of business where a small time trainer like Dick Taylor can run a small farm, breed carefully, and with some smarts and luck come up with a handful of champions over the years. 
Victor J. Blue @epicvistas
#oldtimers #harnessracing #horses #nosubstituteforexperience #trotlife

Damn it. Bit of a setback today. I was lunging the filly on the longline and Grandad came over to help. She got mad and rared back and fired off and kicked him good in the knee. Sometimes it's easy to forget just how powerful these horses are. He's gonna be awful sore for a bit. I'll be able to do some training on my own, but not all of it. And besides, fact is he's the brains behind this operation. Now I have to be the knees. 
Victor J. Blue @epicvistas
#horseman #indiana #farmlife  #owwwwwch

Grandad lunging Moment on the long line. 
The story so far: Dick Taylor, my Grandad, has been a harness horse trainer all his life. For the last three years I have been coming to his farm here just north of Indianapolis to photograph him and help out around the place. I came here straight from three months in Afghanistan to stay for a month to help him break Moment, his yearling trotting filly, and I'm posting some pictures of our progress. Thanks for following. This is @chiyin_sim signing off from Beijing. Thanks for coming along on the ride over the past week as I've been on assignment and shooting the streets of this city, reflecting on six years of living here. I hope you've enjoyed this vignette of daily life here. 
Thanks for following, and thank you to @newyorkermag for having me! Goodbye, or in the literal translation of 再见 -- see you again！

Going home. A youth on his smart phone in a long-distance bus heading for the outskirts from a bus station in downtown Beijing. 
Cheaper Chinese-made smart phones and data plans have revolutionised how Chinese communicate in the last four years or so. Even in back country villages these days, one can see people using smart phones and getting online. The Chinese government still blocks western Web 2.0 apps like Facebook and Twitter, but there are Chinese equivalents and the torrent of public opinion on those sites can now sometimes serve as a form of pressure on the government, especially in exposing official corruption. 
Picture by @chiyin_sim / @VIIPhoto Mentor Program

After a few beautiful blue sky days, and the regular Beijing smog is back. Air quality/pollution index 279 as at 3pm local time. Air pollution is probably the worst thing about living in this city, for me and other residents. This year, and this past winter especially, the pollution hit record levels. Air pollution is often the top reason people cite for moving out of Beijing.

Migrant worker and rag and bone man, Mr Zhang, 63 years old, originally from Zhumadian in Henan province. He has been in Beijing for over a decade, collecting waste paper, cardboard and plastic to sell to recyclers. He buys each kilogram of cardboard for 60 mao (cents) and sells it for 80 cents. He buys each of the giant plastic oil bottles for 80 cents and sells them for 1 yuan, making a profit of 20 cents each. He hauls the waste material from the posh Golden Treasures (Jinbao) street in downtown Beijing to the eastern outskirts on his motorised tricycle daily. Picture by @chiyin_sim / @VIIPhoto Mentor Program
 #urban #beijing #china #asia #reportage #documentary #capital #city #trash #recycling #migrant #worker

As dusk falls in downtown Beijing, a young man seems happy to head home, walking towards a bus stop. As the capital, Beijing is a magnet for migrants from all over the country, white collar or blue collar. For a young Chinese to have "made it" in Beijing is a great source of pride for his family back home in the provinces. Even those who don't exactly make it big and live in squalid conditions in the capital often feel they cannot go back to their hometowns for fear of loss of "face". Picture by @chiyin_sim / @VIIPhoto Mentor Program
#dusk #transport #urban #beijing #china #asia #reportage #documentary #capital #city

Chit chat. Mr Wang, 59, a disabled pedicab rider and his pair of crutches. One of the things I like most about Beijing - and China - is random conversations (sometimes long and involved!) with strangers just met. Sometimes, urban China can feel like a cold and unfriendly place where everyone just minds their own business. But other times, serendipity leads people like Mr Wang to strike up a conversation. I speak Mandarin and these days, most cannot tell I'm a foreigner so they speak fairly freely. Parked outside a big bus station, Mr Wang tells me he was waiting for his college-going son. He also showed me a certificate he got for being an exemplary disabled individual, and told me he played in China's national Paralympic basketball team in the Beijing Paralympics in 2008 -- an event I had photographed. 
Picture by @chiyin_sim / @VIIPhoto Mentor Program
#transport #conversations #strangers #urban #beijing #china #asia #reportage #documentary #capital #city

East, West, somewhere in the middle… 
A billboard of a western model looms over the subway crowd in downtown Beijing. 
As ethnic Chinese, I can look local -- and having been here six years I am able to sound local -- but do I, will I really belong? 
Picture by @chiyin_sim / @VIIPhoto Mentor Program
#transport #subway #train #crowd #underground #mondayblues #urban #beijing #china #asia #reportage #documentary #capital #city

Wet start to the work week. With its heavy pollution and summer / autumn rains, Beijing can be a gray city. Sometimes dreary. Bicycles and pedestrians fight for space at a crossing under a bridge in the city's Central Business District. The Beijing of old was known for its sea of cyclists, but as Chinese have become more affluent, cars are much more common and traffic jams a common pain. 
Picture by @chiyin_sim / @VIIPhoto Mentor Program
#rain #weather #puddle #reflection #shadows #mondayblues #urban #beijing #china #asia #reportage #documentary #capital #city

Morning rush hour at an underground subway station in Beijing's Central Business District. 
Life can feel like a daily competition living in this city of 20 million and country of 1.3 billion. Rushing around, elbowing and pushing to get one's way is often the name of the game getting any train, plane or bus. I come from a country of 5 million people (Singapore) and my Chinese friends like to remind me that even a single district in Beijing is larger than Singapore. 
Picture by @chiyin_sim / @VIIPhoto Mentor Program
#transport #subway #train #underground #mondayblues #urban #beijing #china #asia #reportage #documentary #capital #city

Good Morning, Beijing! Pedestrians and cars fight for space on the streets early on a rainy morning in Beijing's Central Business District, in front of the iconic China Central Television building famously designed by Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas. Colloquially, Chinese call the building "big pants" -- or erm, something *beep* *beep* ruder. Climbing can be so much more than a sport.  It's a lifestyle, an inclusive community, and set of ethics for interacting with the mountains.  Within the iconic climbing meccas around the globe I'm constantly blown away by the spirit of the tribe. It's what drives us to continue to share it to best of our ability. [story/photo by @renan_ozturk. @thenorthface @camp4collective #bugaboos collection]

@conradclimber contemplating the open space of the #bubagoos.  Forest fires burning in the valleys below provided very unique light on this particular night. [story/photo by @renan_ozturk. @thenorthface @camp4collective collection]

It's been a pleasure sharing our story here with #thenewyorkermag. Today is the last day of our posts.  Thanks for following from the whole crew: @alexhonnold @conradclimber @jimmy_chin @robfrostmedia @renan_ozturk [story by Renan, photo by Conrad. @thenorthface @camp4collective collection]

Climbing technology has also progressed over the years to allow us to move lighter, faster, and with less impact on the mountains.  @thenorthface team captain @conradclimber has always advocated for an #alpinestyle of climbing which entails no fixed ropes and small nimble teams.  Here Conrad is using a modern camming device just as a backup in case he falls. This #freeclimbing style is the same as @alexhonnold's #freesolo ascent, just with backup. [story by @renan_ozturk, photo by @robfrostmedia. @camp4collective collection]

Being a professional athlete / artist, it's hard to lead a low impact lifestyle. The #bugaboos is a often used as an example of 'climate change', as the glaciers there are melting at a rapid pace that even I've witnessed during the span of my adventures there. The issues of climate change are complex ; scary, confusing, yet motivating. Although it took a lot of fuel flying helis to get here, it makes us feel good that the entire production was solar powered. #solarlife [photo/story by @renan_ozturk @camp4collective @thenorthface @goalzero @kesslercrane]

Freesoloing is the purest form of climbing, but one mistake and you die. @alexhonnold is one of a kind in his ability to freesolo big walls. To film and photograph our friends while they freesolo can be incredibly hard, technically and mentally. I know that while I'm filming Alex, I'm capturing something so rare and am very aware not to affect his headspace. We have shot/climbed together a lot and feel comfortable at this point, but the risk of him falling, and having to witness that, is always there. Rope on his back for the descent. [story/photo by @renan_ozturk @camp4collective @thenorthface #bugaboos]

Timelapse photography has natural parallels to my roots in landscape painting. These days, timelapse technology is all about moving the camera through a landscape, on multiple axes.  Pictured here is our experimental 300 ft cable cam dolly that runs through the boulders at basecamp, powered by the #syrpgenie and suspended by lightweight Amsteel cable. [story/photo by @renan_ozturk @camp4collective @thenorthface @syrp_ #unearthedfilm collection]

During our ascent of the South Howser we came across a climber who had fallen and broken his ankle.  Although he was in stable condition and we offered to help with a human powered rescue he opted for a full on heli rescue from the side of the rock face.  We called it in via our sat texter and watched from above as they long-lined him off the face.  On some climbs there isn't this possibility and the added self reliance gives you an even greater adventure. [story by @renan_ozturk, photo by @jimmy_chin. @thenorthface @camp4collective #unearthedfilm collection]

On day 8, the team had descended but we waited shivering to see if we might get a tiny glimpse of the elusive alpenglow. [story/photo by @renan_ozturk, @thenorthface @camp4collective #unearthedfilm collection]

The first big climb I did with @jimmy_chin @conrad_climber was in 2008 on Mt. Meru, the most tried and failed upon big-wall in the Himalaya.  After 19 days of climbing with only 8 days of food, we failed within a rope-length from the top, at the edge of our limits.  Sometimes you have to turn back and instead take away the friendships that were built along the way.  Jimmy, pictured here atop Pigeon spire in the #bugaboos.  I feel lucky to still be building these friendships in such places. [story/photo by @renan_ozturk. @thenorthface #unearthedfilm. @camp4collective collection]

Behind the scenes, we tend to put our gear through some serious tests of gravity & weather. I love how emerging technology allows for incredible potential for documenting stories in challenging conditions. At this point we only seem to be limited by creativity. #bugaboos @liteprogear #feathercameracrane [story by @renan_ozturk / photo by @robfrostmedia #unearthedfilm collection @thenorthface @camp4collective]

It's not about adrenaline and kicks for the world's most accomplished free soloist @alexhonnold.  It's about knowing his abilities, calmly assessing risk and the love of rock climbing.  Pictured  here, 2K feet above the ground, Alex climbs a route he repeated days later without a rope. #SouthHowser #lostinthetowers #bugaboos [story by @renan_ozturk, photo by @jimmy_chin. @thenorthface @camp4collective #unearthedfilm collection]

For me, creating art and climbing have always gone hand in hand. Being in these wild places is my ultimate inspiration, and has led to expression in other storytelling mediums of photo and video. It was great to find a moment in the #bubaboos to create these birthday cards for @alexhonnold @mikeylikesrocks and @robfrostmedia. [photo/story by @renan_ozturk @thenorthface @camp4collective #unearthedfilm collection]

@conradclimber has been know for saying that 'enlightenment isn't found with a full stomach or on a soft pillow.' Although 3am alpine starts are painful, there are always a few unforgettable sunrise moments. [story/photo by @renan_ozturk @thenorthface @camp4collective #unearthedfilm collection]

Happy to be running 100% on @goalzero solar power for this expedition while shooting on the #redepic and backing up ~500 GB of data per day. #solarlife [story by @renan_ozturk, photo by expedition member & close friend @jimmy_chin. Part of @thenorthface @camp4collective #unearthedfilm series collection]

Portrait of #bugaboo spire. First climbed in 1916 by Conrad Kain, it's easy to see why this peak is the namesake of the range. [story/photo by @renan_ozturk, part of the @thenorthface @camp4collective #unearthedfilm collection]

Friend, mentor & one of the most accomplished expedition climbers on the planet @conradclimber kicks off our climbing escapades on the laser cut cracks of the South Howser tower.  When shooting climbing the best images are almost always taken while hanging from ropes above your subjects. However, when forging into new mountain terrain you never have that luxury. #buttshot #bugaboos [story/photo by @renan_ozturk, part of the @thenorthface @camp4collective #unearthed film series]

We are set up in basecamp, and the weather is unsettled but beautiful. Watching the conditions is everything. Things can get serious pretty quickly if you head up onto the big walls at the wrong time. [photo by @renan_ozturk part of the @camp4collective #unearthed film series]

This is the heli ride into the 'east creek' basin basecamp of the #bugaboos & our 1st look at the massive Howser towers, 3K ft tall monoliths of steep granite inspiration. [photo by @renan_ozturk part of the @thenorthface @camp4collective #unearthed film expedition]

A new adventure begins in the alpine wonderlands of the #Bugaboos mountains!  This is filmmaker/photographer @renan_ozturk sharing images this week fresh from the field from our @thenorthface @camp4collective #unearthed film project. Stay tuned for a close look into the #expedition #climbing life.  Thanks for following!

Hello! My name is Erin Brethauer (@erinbrethauer) and I’m a photographer based in Asheville, North Carolina. This week I’m guest hosting the New Yorker feed from Camp Lakey Gap, a camp for people with autism in Black Mountain, NC. 
I’ve been photographing at the camp since 2008 while working on a personal project. In July, I spent two weeks taking pictures with my iPhone. You’re going to see a mix of images from a week with 4-10 year old high-functioning kids with autism and a week with adults with autism. 
I hope you enjoy your week at camp with these fine folks and thanks for looking! 
#camp #camplakeygap #autism #northcarolina #blackmountain #pooltime #campers

July 2013, Dover Beaches North
39°59’26.1”N, 74°3’41.78”W

In early November I made several helicopter flights over the New Jersey Shore to document the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy for The New Yorker, and went back in a few weeks ago to see what had changed.  Over the next seven days you will see a series of before-and-after views of the most devastated parts of the coast between Seaside Heights and Manasquan (seen below). Here sand was being removed from city streets and brought back to the beach to build a protective barrier before a winter snow storm blew in. Pictures by George Steinmetz @geosteinmetz @thephotosociety #NewJersey #hurricanesandy
Manasquan on July 5th, by George Steinmetz  For more pictures of the Jersey shore go to @geosteinmetz @thephotosociety #NewJersey #hurricane sandy

Hello everybody! Brendan Hoffman here (@hoffmanbrendan). For the rest of the week, I'll be your guide to Webster City, Iowa, and the Hamilton County Fair. It's a full schedule, starting with tonight's parade right up through the demolition derby on Sunday. Background: in March 2011, the washing machine factory here in town closed and moved to Juarez, Mexico. In a city of 8000 people, the plant employed 2000 at one point, and the local economy has taken a hit. I've been documenting the town for the past two years. This is a picture of Alley, age 8, with Trigger, her entry in the model horse competition.

About me: I'm a news and documentary photographer based (until recently) in Washington, DC, and a co-founder of the photography collective Prime. #webstercity #iowa #countyfair #primecollective

The f/v Torsken finally launched today! This is my setnet skiff. It's a 22 ft boat designed to catch and haul up to 6500 lbs of wild sockeye salmon in one load. We hope to max out at least a few times this year. The beauty of the Bristol Bay fleet is that there are thousands of small family run businesses rather then large corporate owned fishing enterprises. We fish two persons to a skiff, and haul our nets by hand. Next, a trip down the Naknek River, then a day of loading and packing. We will shove off Saturday or Sunday morn, and that's where this story will end. (No reception out at Graveyard Point) Photo: Corey Arnold @arni_coraldo #setnet #sockeyesalmon #naknekriver #alaska #commercialfishing #savebristolbay #salmonnation #fishingboat #sockeyesalmon #harvest

Howdy folks! This is Corey Arnold @arni_coraldo I'm a commercial fisherman in Bristol Bay, Alaska, home to the worlds largest Wild Sockeye Salmon spawning grounds. For the next week, I'm going to show you around Naknek, where thousands of fishermen are preparing for the arrival of an estimated 26,000,000 salmon. This is one of the most sustainable small scale fisheries in the world, now under threat by a massive proposed open pit copper mine, and it's 10 billion tons of toxic waste. #bristolbay #nopebblemine #pebblemine #commercialfishing #sockeye #salmonfishing #coreyarnold #latergram www.coreyfishes.com leaving Portland, Oregon tonight!

It was an intense 2 weeks in NYC. The project in Times Square,  the project at Rikers Jail, the gallery show with @joseparla ... I am on my way to aiport now for new adventures and pastings in the rest of the world !! I ll be on @JR from now on ... #insideoutnyc

Our intern @jocelynegilead staring Star Trek into the darkness :) and still finding time to come and paste. .. @JR

Back at work in Times Square for a long night. ..

I have a photobooth at the house because everyday artist come by and exchange and we ll inspire each other...having @joseparla @trim1tnc_byi @mathieukassovitz @solguy @reyparlastudio @zevs @chris just now was inspiring
Faces of the New Yorkers who came by the @insideoutproject photobooth on Times Square ! We ll finsih tomorrow @timessquarenyc  #insideoutnyc #timessquarealliance
And of course making more glue... this all project in Times Square wouldn't have been possible without the great help of Times Square Alliance !! Thank you !
Work in progress in Times Square.... #insideoutnyc  @JR
@mathieukassovitz and @JR working on a special one for the New Yorkers...
And now printing more for a special pasting tonight for @insideoutproject .. @JR

We just pasted the eye of another Inmate on the 2 South Building. He wanted me to choose his eye looking left as life in jail is all about watching your back...
He came out in the jail Yard when we were pasting. He's 18years old, it's his second time in Jail. Even if no one will recognize his eye he knows he's part of a bigger picture. He said "Who's looking who" ? In a way he's happy no one will know who he is so he wont get jalousy from the Inside or be recognized on the outside.
On my end I felt this eye is bringing even more pression next to all to the guards and the video cameras watching the inmates already... But that's what the inmates asked me to do, for them this place is a just tuff and that's how they want to remember it. They asked us to join on another pasting one day but this time on the outside :) more photos on @JR .... thanks to my great team there @trim1tnc_byi @solguy @takao5020 @mathieukassovitz
The jail is right next to La Guardia airport... I took this photo from Inside the jail @JR

This is one of the eyes of an inmate that I just installed in the corridor of the jail... Really strong discussion with the Inmate. The one on the photo says it's his first and last time there as he never want to put a feet in jail again in his life. He never thought that art could have an impact on him too and even if his proud to have participate to the project he wants other people to remember this place as a hard place...that's why he wanted a strong and sad eyes. His family could have bail him out but he decided to stay to experience jail and appreciate his freedom even more.... #sorryformypoorenglish @JR
Now time for work
Rikers Island... even with wings you don't fly from there @JR

Eye of Inmate I photographed today at Rikers Jail... the blue lines are the different strip of the pasting... Long discussion with inmates today about the project.  They wanted to see a sad and strong eye on their wall because they never want to come back there @JR

Hey everyone I am @JR and I am taking over @newyorkermag account for the week... I am working since 2 years on a project name @insideoutproject. Anyone in the world can send me their portrait,  me and my team will print it and send it back to you (for FREE if you cant afford it). Then people will paste it (or not) wherever they feel like... since the beginning we sent 140 000 photos to more than 100 countries and actions took place in 10000 cities... This week we build a photobooth truck where we can print your photo in 5 seconde and you can paste it right away ! Look for #insideoutnyc ! I ll be giving you the locatioms in real time! Here we are in the bronx right now...

Bob (Bengie) Powers, who grew up in Brooklyn in the nineteen-fifties, had his first drink at 8 years old, stabbed someone at 12, was out of school by 16, and was taking drugs at 18.  Iconic NYC photographer Bruce Davidson photographed the street gang called the Jokers, of which Bengie was the leader.  Follow this link to see a selection of Davidson's pictures of Bengie and his gang: http://nyr.kr/ZyM9QN This photo: On the beach at Coney Island.

See photos from @Robin_Schwartz 's body of work "Amelia's World," a magical portrait stretching over 11 years, which pictures her daughter, Amelia, with all types of animals: http://nyr.kr/Xq4jkK This photo: “Lola Does Not Like Fake Fruit” (2012). Amelia: "I set up this shoot with my mom, and added some fake fruit in the background. When Lola, a White-Faced Capuchin, came on set and picked up a fake orange there was a moment of confusion after she tried to take a bite. Then, pow, the “orange” collided with my head."

See photos from Robin Schwartz's body of work "Amelia's World," a magical portrait stretching over 11 years, which pictures her daughter, Amelia, with all types of animals: http://nyr.kr/Xq4jkK This photo: “Graham, Cotton Top Tamerin” (2012). Amelia: "Graham’s tiny face melted everyone’s heart, and mine was no exception. He climbed up my arm and onto my head, his favorite place on anyone. He stayed on my head for a while, looking at the huge camera across from him."

See photos from Robin Schwartz's body of work "Amelia's World," a magical portrait stretching over 11 years, which pictures her daughter, Amelia, with all types of animals: http://nyr.kr/Xq4jkK This photo: “Reaching, Girls” (2005). Amelia: "I was a ballerina with my two dancers behind me. Or maybe I was Beyoncé with her Destiny’s Child-mates. I felt like Darlene Love from the Crystals."

See photos from Robin Schwartz's body of work "Amelia's World," a magical portrait stretching over 11 years, which pictures her daughter, Amelia, with all types of animals: http://nyr.kr/Xq4jkK This photo: “Amelia and Ricky, 3 and 2 years old” (2002). Amelia: "This image represents the beginning of my modelling career. I have a memory of hugging Ricky, his soft-as-velvet face and warm breath."

Well folks, it has been a weird and wild few days in Texas. I have enjoyed the opportunity to share some experiences with you, good, bad and otherwise. Thanks for following along, and especially to those who stimulated constructive dialogue. I will leave you with an image of Mike Sells, wearing a mask and laying in a casket in front of his RV that I stumbled upon in Sweetwater outside of the round-up. He plays this prank every year to scare people driving by and seems to get a kick out of it. It embodied the strange quirkiness of Texas to me pretty well. Peace out. @MattEich for @NewYorkerMag #sweetwater #texas #tx #man #casket #mask #prank #onassignment #commission #travels #america #americana #usa #peaceout

Hi folks, my name is Matt Eich - I am a freelance photographer based in Virginia. I will be manning The New Yorker's Instagram feed for the next few days. Welcome to Sweetwater, Texas, where I am photographing the 55th annual Sweetwater Rattlesnake Round-Up, which is the largest such event in the world. Thousands of snakes are gathered, milked, measured and killed as a means of controlling the population. @MattEich for @NewYorkerMag. #sweetwater #texas #reptiles #snake #snakes #rattlesnakes #event #gathering #jars #assignment #commission #onassignment #travels #america #usa

For blocks at a time, the ground-level units—would-be storefronts—are cinder-blocked shut and spray-painted with the phone numbers of leasing agents. Simon Norfolk photographs a failed development project in #Spain; his pictures present the stark reality of the country's economic collapse: http://nyr.kr/13aNzjx

When the Mayor of Seseña reviewed development plans for the Residencial Francisco Hernando, he could find no feasible arrangement for delivering water or electricity or any other services. He withheld construction permits, but the developer kept building anyway. Simon Norfolk photographs a failed development project in #Spain; his pictures present the stark reality of the country's economic collapse: http://nyr.kr/13aNzjx

The Residencial Francisco Hernando is now a ghost town. The complex is surrounded by weedy lots and a mountain of discarded tires. Simon Norfolk photographs a failed development project in #Spain; his pictures present the stark reality of the country's economic collapse: http://nyr.kr/13aNzjx

Cape Town, South Africa | February 2, 2013 - Clinton, of the Golden Classic's choir, practices his solo song before the choir takes the stage at the Keep The Dream Malay Choir Forum held at the Good Hope Center. The Cape Malay community in Cape Town are decedents of political dissidents, Muslim religious leaders, and slaves from south east Asia who were forcibly brought to South Africa during Dutch rule starting in 1654. Nazeem Martin, the official singing coach of the Golden Classic's says about the choirs, "What is very important is that none of these guys that are singing here can actually read music. And you will find that even 80% of the coaches coaching them, can not read music. So it's a cultural thing...like an athlete that can run without being trained." Photo by Charlie Shoemaker @Charlieshoemaker via @everydayafrica #capetown #SouthAfrica #choir #goodhopecenter #goldenclassics #TheGoldenClassics

A woman dances at a club called Djanjou on the outskirts of Bamako, Mali on February 1. Guitarist Bahah, originally from the northern town of Gao, which was controlled by separatists Islamists until it was recently liberated by French military forces, played to a packed house of mainly northerners who celebrated traditional music and newfound freedom. Photo by @glennagordon via @everydayafrica. #mali #bamako #music #club #dancing #france #liberation #guitar

A man named Innocent stands at the small clothing shop he keeps inside a market in Abidjan, Ivory Coast. "I want to be independent financially. I want to be I independent spiritually. I want to be independent morally," he says of his strong work ethic. Innocent is also a pastor. He once owned a large clothing store, but it was destroyed in heavy fighting during the country's bout of post-election violence in 2011. Jean Armel, 29, strikes a pose in Allahteresekro, a small village near Leleble, about three hours north of Abidjan in Ivory Coast. He was very excited to learn that the Red Sox, after decades of coming up short, had won two World Series in the last ten years. "Champions!" He cried out to his friends. The flag, liquor bottle, bicycle tire, etc, behind him are helping to weigh down a tarp that provides cover from the sun as he and his friends pass the time playing games and drinking moonshine. He offered me a swig. I took a quick smell and declined. Photo by @austin_merrill via @everydayafrica. January 10, 2013. #ivorycoast #cotedivoire #moonshine #americanflag #flag #boston #redsox #bostonredsox #bicycle #africa

Franschhoek, South Africa | February 1, 2013 - Working On Fire wildfire firefighter Elroy Esau, 23, Riversdale, stands for a portrait in his gear after working a 24 hour shift fighting the Wemmerhoekdam wildfire. Elroy grew up dreaming of becoming a firefighter and now loves his job. He says the only thing he would change about his job is the salary. "The one thing they need to do is increase our salary, its the only thing they need to work on. For me this job is very nice, we enjoy what we are doing, we love it." Elroy earns R75 ($8.35) a day fighting wildfires in Western Cape of South Africa. Photo by Charlie Shoemaker @Charlieshoemaker via @everydayafrica #Franschhoek #SouthAfrica #firefighter #wildfire #firemen

Playing in the surf at Grand-Bassam, which lies on the Atlantic, about 20 miles east of Abidjan. Grand-Bassam was the first colonial capital of Ivory Coast, when it was under the control of France. The historic old town, which was the capital from 1893 to 1896, was made a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2012. Photo taken January 12, 2013, by @austin_merrill via @everydayafrica. #ivorycoast #cotedivoire #abidjan #grandbassam #unesco #worldheritagesite #unescoworldheritage #worldheritage #africa #beach #surf
Women shop at the Casino supermarket in Dakar, Senegal on Thursday, January 31, 2013. Photo by Jane Hahn @janehahn via @everydayafrica #shopping #dakar #senegal #everyday

Cape Town, South Africa | January 31, 2013 - Shoukit, 52, has run the family corner shop out of his home in the historical Bo-Kaap neighborhood his whole life. As an act of kindness to members of his community, Shoukit keeps a book of credits for people who can not pay him up front, but will pay when they can. And as a result of his kindness, members of the community come to spend time with him and his family daily. Photo by Charlie Shoemaker @Charlieshoemaker via @everydayafrica #CapeTown #SouthAfrica #bokaap

Hauwa and Femi celebrate their one year wedding anniversary at their home in Lagos, Nigeria on January 13. Photo by @glennagordon via @everydayafrica. #love #nigeria #lagos #marriage #joy #celebration

On a day when hundreds of young men were protesting the presidency of Mohamed Morsi in Tahrir Square, Alaa, 21, prepares pink roses for selling at the sidewalk flower stand where he works in Cairo, Egypt, Jan. 30, 2013. Cairo is a spread-out city of almost 20 million people, with the majority of demonstrations happening in a relatively small area, near the center. Through the political and economic changes and the dramatic upheavals of the past two years, some Cairenes have carried on with a life as normal as possible. Photo by Holly Pickett @hollypickettpix @everydayafrica #egypt #cairo #roses #flowers #dailylife #economy

South Africa was recently called the most financially unequal place on Earth in a report released by Oxfam.

Cape Town, South Africa: William, 26, from Democratic Republic of the Congo is a night guard of multiple houses in Fresnaye, an area of Cape Town where houses sell for up to R63,500,000.00 ($7,035,504.00). William has been in South Africa since 2007 and is working towards becoming a paramedic. He has to take time off from school to raise funds for this education. As a guard, he works twelve hour shifts, three times a week making a monthly income of R4000.00 ($443.00). January 29, 2013 Photo by Charlie Shoemaker @Charlieshoemaker via @everydayafrica #CapeTown #SouthAfrica #portrait #LionsHead #Fresnaye #guard #nightguard @oxfamamerica

Yao Konan shows a photo of himself as an infant with his three aunts in rural Ivory Coast in the late 1960's. Konan spent years living in Europe and was educated in London, but eventually wanted to live in his native country again. He returned and had a successful tourism company, bringing groups across West Africa. Since the start of conflict in Ivory Coast a decade ago, he's had to adjust his business model and now drives mostly journalists. Photo in via @everydayafrica by Peter DiCampo @pdicampo. #ivorycoast #familyphoto #vintage
Birds fly over an apartment building in Dakar, Senegal. Photo by Jane Hahn @janehahn for @everydayafrica #dakar #senegal #birds

Fadima Wallet Jnorene, age 19, who wants to be a doctor one day, fled from her home near Timbuktu, Mali last year when Islamists separatists seized power. She and her family came to the capital Bamako in a two car convoy after several neighbors accused them of being terrorists because they are Tuaregs, a group associated with the seperatists. She'd like to go home soon now that a French military interventions has reclaimed Timbuktu, but fears it won't be safe for her anytime soon. Photo by @glennagordon on assignment for @unrefugeeagency in Mali, via @everydayafrica. #mali #timbuktu #bamako #portrait #teeanager #highschool #displaced #idp #refugee
Man pulls the Mkokoteni up the road in Nairobi, Kenya. January 28, 2013 Photo by Idil Ibrahim @i_am_idil. @everydayafrica #kenya #mkokoteni

Pyramid of Man - crowds in Tahrir Square create a makeshift human pyramid over a burnt police armored vehicle that was captured by demonstrators last night and set alight. It's now a temporary souvenir and a "tourist spot" for pictures as clashes between protesters and police in the capital continued for the 5th day in a row and instability across major cities across Egypt persisted - Cairo, Egypt 29/1/2013 photo @laurael_tantawy via @everydayafrica #cairo #egypt #clashes #protest #jan25 #revolutionanniversary #middleeast #northafrica

Morning, just as the work day begins, in Plateau, the business district of Abidjan, Ivory Coast, on January 15, 2013. Photo via @everydayafrica by @pdicampo. #plateau #abidjan #ivorycoast #business #commerce #commute #dailylife #africa #middleclass

At the Allocodrome in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, one of the best places in the city for authentic Ivorian cuisine -- grilled chicken and fish smothered in an onion, tomato, cucumber vinaigrette, and served with attieke (cassava that has been grated and fermented) and fried plantains (alloco). These two guys sold us cold bottles of beer, and had been in the thick of an animated conversation -- until she walked by. Photo taken on January 11, 2013, by @austin_merrill, via @everydayafrica. #abidjan #ivorycoast #cotedivoire #africa #africancuisine

South Africa was recently was called the most financially unequal place on Earth in a report released by Oxfam in January 2013. 
Cape Town, South Africa: Bongani Gezane, 25, eats a leftover pizza given to him by a car stopped at the intersection he sells comedy pamphlets at. When given food, he tries to eat it immediately as an expression of gratitude.l. On a good day Bongani will make R100 ($11.00) and on a bad day roughly R15/$1.65. January 28, 2013 Photo by Charlie Shoemaker @charlieshoemaker via @everydayafrica @oxfamamerica #CapeTown #SouthAfrica #pizza

Zainabu Cisse, the second wife of Mohammed Cisse, had feet covered in henna for a relative's wedding last Thursday in Bamako, Mali. Her husband, his first wife, and their seven children fled from Goumndaum, a town near Timbuktu in northern Mali when Islamist separatists took power last April. She took a boat, and then a bus, to get to Bamako. Her family is now three months behind on rent in their small apartment and though a French military intervention is reclaiming much territory, the Cisses fear ongoing instability as well as reprisals and aren't ready to head home yet. Photo by @glennagordon on assignment in Mali for @unrefugeeagency. Via @everydayafrica. #mali #bamako #henna #refugee #displaced #urban #idps
Two boys help retrieve a surfer's longboard in Dakar, Senegal. Photo by Jane Hahn @janehahn for @everydayafrica #surf #senegal #dakar #endlesssummer

A young woman washes the eyes of a protester with a milky liquid to counter the effects of tear gas during clashes with police near Qasr al-Nil bridge just outside of Tahrir (or "Liberation") Square, Cairo, Egypt, Jan. 28, 2012. Demonstrations, barricaded streets, and tear gas have occurred with some regularity in Egypt's capital city, especially near Tahrir, since former president Hosni Mubarak resigned from power in the face of massive demonstrations nearly two years ago. The January 25 commemoration of the Egyptian uprising's beginning and death sentences for 21 accused in last year's Port Said soccer stadium massacre have sparked more conflict in Cairo, Port Said, and in other Egyptian cities. Photo by Holly Pickett @hollypickettpix for @everydayafrica #egypt #cairo #tahrir #revolution #teargas #protest #demonstration #protester #portsaid

Scene earlier today (still ongoing) just off Tahrir (Liberation) Square. Protesters battling police/tear gas as clashes in the capital reach 4th day in a row - Cairo, Egypt 28/1/2013 photo @laurael_tantawy #jan25 #revolutionanniversay #egypt #cairo #clashes #teargas #protest

Entesar, an Arabic name meaning "victory," washes tomatoes in the Nile River. She is preparing lunch, cooking "Kirsha" a dish made of chunks of meat from the cow's intestine, tomato sauce and garlic and onion, Entesar is part of a 10-member fishing family living on small boats on the Nile in Cairo. Photo @laurael_tantawy #laurael_tantawy @viiphoto @everydayafrica #cairo #egypt #dailylife #documentaryphotography #livingonthenile #middleeast #northafrica

Good morning. A neighbor's hanging laundry added a dash of color to a rather mundane "waking-up to" view this morning. Photo @laurael_tantawy #laurael_tantawy @viiphoto #cairo #egypt @everydayafrica #middleeast #northafrica #residentialneighborhood #dailylife #documentaryphotography

Inside a Cairo taxi cab, my preferred mode of transport in the capital. I genuinely enjoy talking with the drivers about the situation in the country. Most of Cairo's taxi drivers are with some degree, if not high degrees, but sweeping unemployment and a culture of "Wasta" (relying on personal connections to get anything done) has left many with little chances of financial survival but to take on odd jobs or drive a taxi. Photo @laurael_tantawy #lauraeltantawy @viiphoto @everydayafrica #cairo #egypt #dailylife #documentaryphotography #lifeincairo #middleeast #northafrica #taxi #cairobynight #cairotaxi

After casting his net in the river, or "the sea" as people here like to say, Hamed, 13-years-old, sits at the edge of the boat waiting. Hamed is his father's right hand. Today, five hours in the river got them only two fish, both weighing no more than 1.25 kilos. Photo @laurael_tantawy #laurael_tantawy @viiphoto @everydayafrica #cairo #egypt #nile #river #rich #poor #livingonthenile #dailylife #documentaryphotography #middleeast #northafrica

May, 14-years-old, is part of a 10-member fishing family living on the River Nile in Cairo. May, like her other siblings, has not been to school and is likely to follow in the footsteps of her parents and lead a life of fishing for survival. Photo @laurael_tantawy #laurael_tantawy @viiphoto #cairo #egypt #middleeast #northafrica #nile #livingonthenile #beauty #survival #poor #river #river

Good morning from sunny Cairo. Nader tells his mother, Entesar, a secret and the two start laughing. Eleven-year-old Nader is Entesar's favorite child. The two are part of a 10-member fishing family living on three small boats along the River Nile in Cairo. Looking down on them are towering apartment buildings with a spectacular view of the Nile and surely they are among some of the most expensive real estate in the Egyptian capital, a place where stark contrasts live side by side. Photo @ laurael_tantawy @viiphoto @everydayafrica #cairo #egypt #middleeast #northafrica #dailylife #livingonthenile #nile #river #rich #poor #documentaryphotography

Reda Ahmed Salama, a Cairo traffic cop for the past 18 years, yells at drivers speaking on their mobile phones while driving. Today he is working in Talaat Harb Square in central Cairo, a city of more than 16 million people. Salama said on numerous occasions, he's been struck by passing cars in the middle of the chaos. Photo by @laurael_tantawy @viiphoto #cairo #egypt #middleeast #northafrica #traffic

Good morning. I am @laurael_tantawy and I'm very happy to be with you this week from my hometown of #cairo #egypt. It's another turbulent week in Egypt, mass protests expected tomorrow as controversial new draft constitution vote pushes through, but I will not be showing you any of it. I will be photographing little vignettes of daily life in Cairo as well as pictures of a 10 member fishing family who live on small boats on the River Nile, which I am photographing this week. Here Amr performs prayer on his boat while Entesar sits near by. Photo @laurael_tantawy @viiphoto #northafrica #middleeast #dailylife

A golf cart crosses Del Webb Boulevard in Sun City, Arizona. This age-restricted, self-governed city of 40,000 retirees was Webb's vision. This new idea of retirement Webb envisioned more than 50 years ago centered on nurturing a lifestyle that emphasized staying active. Sun City opened January 1, 1960 and today it has seven recreation centers and more than 120 clubs. Photo by @KendrickBrinson. #suncity #arizona #delwebb #golf #retirement #aging #retiree #palmtree

The Sundial Dance Club's members are serendaded by the Rhythm Ramblers at the Glitter Ball in Sun City, Arizona Saturday night. Fox trot, waltz, swing, and ladies choice waltz were listed on the dance board. Photo by @KendrickBrinson. #suncity #arizona #dance #retirement #retire #retiree

When I met Mary Ryan, 82, in the Tip Top dance class yesterday, I asked her if she danced before she moved to Sun City and she replied that she hadn't since she was a young girl because she joined a convent immediately after high school. Today, she introduced us to her three cats, played two songs on the organ she recently bought to learn how to play, and insisted we eat some cake before we left. Cocoa Aiuchi, 21, prepares for work in the dressing room of a bar in Tokyo. In Japan, a hostess is a young woman who entertains men at bars or clubs; customers pay for flirting, but not sex. “Anything new, anything worth doing, can’t be recognized.” Picasso light-drawing with a flashlight, 1949. Photograph by Gjon Mili/Time & Life Pictures/Getty. Happy birthday, Pablo Picasso: http://nyr.kr/P5LpzN

"Art is not the application of a canon of beauty but what the instinct and the brain can conceive beyond any canon. When we love a woman we don’t start measuring her limbs.” Picasso checking Brigitte Bardot’s face with a light meter during the Cannes Film Festival, 1956. Photograph by Jerome Brierre/RDA/Getty. Happy birthday, Pablo Picasso: http://nyr.kr/P5LpzN

“Art is a lie that makes us realize the truth.” Pablo Picasso on the beach in Provence, France, with his son Claude and his partner Françoise Gilot, 1948. Photograph by Robert Capa/Magnum. Happy birthday, Pablo Picasso: http://nyr.kr/P5LpzN

By Jason Nocito.  Follow the link to see photos from “Attachments,” a group photography show featured in this week’s Goings On About Town section Curated by Kathy Grayson and Tim Barber, the show features work by nine contemporary photographers. Grayson on the title: "‘Attachments’ was a suggestion by Tim that we both loved because it emphasizes the digital nature of image making and viewing—most people will only see this show on the internet or in an e-mail attachment,” she said. “But it also emphasizes the community nature of the show." http://nyr.kr/VkmnuQ

There are hundreds of stands each occupied by a particular gallery from anywhere around the world. The galleries display work by their artists for sale. Some deals are struck there and then whilst possible future clients details can be carefully filed away.

Gangway the entrance walkway to the fair adorned by this colourful graphic. The fair was founded by a pair of philanthropists in 2003 to support contemporary art. It occupies a huge space within central London's Regents Park. #fldn12 #frieze #art #london

DAY 3 of the London Frieze Art Fair. Hello I'm @ewenspencer & I've been following the art fair all week for the New Yorker. Yesterday saw the preview of the actual fair set within London's ancient Regents Park. Thousands of art lovers travel from across the globe to buy and sell art at the annual fair. Back to parties and private views tomorrow but for now bear witness to the art world at work.

My final image for the day. #TheasterGates at #whitecube.  I'm sharpening my elbows to join in with the mele at the #Frieze art fair at Regents Park this afternoon. Hope you've enjoyed last nights shenanigans. More tomorrow! #art  #fldn12 #frieze #iphoneonly @ewenspencer
